analyzed: kata adhikāro tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinantaḥ sikhissa bhagavato kāle mālākāra kule  nibbattitvā viññu tam pattaḥ eka divasam sikhim bhagavantam passitvā pasanna mānasaḥ sumana pupphehi  pūjam akāsi saḥ tena puñña kammena deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde aññatarassa
translated: He, too, had formed his aspiration under former Buddhas, and had stored up much merit in various existences. In the dispensation of the Master Sikhī he was reborn in a family of garland-makers.🔽When he had grown up, he saw the Master Sikhī one day, and with a glad heart he worshipped him with Sumana flowers.🔽By the power of that meritorious deed he passed through the round of existences in the heavenly world and the world of men, and was reborn in the house of a certain lay disciple in the dispensation of the present Buddha.

original: upāsakassa gehe paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhi. So ca upāsako āyasmato anuruddhattherassa upaṭṭhāko🔽ahosi. Tassa ca tato pubbe jātājātā dārakā mariṃsu. Tena so “sacāhaṃ idāni ekaṃ puttaṃ
analyzed: upāsakassa gehe paṭisandhim gaṇhi saḥ ca upāsakaḥ āyasmataḥ anuruddha therassa upaṭṭhāko  ahosi tassa ca tatas pubbe jāta ajātāḥ dārakāḥ mariṃsu tena saḥ sacā aham idāni ekam puttam
translated: This lay disciple was a supporter of the Elder Anuruddha.🔽Now all the children born to him had died in infancy. Therefore he made the vow, “If I obtain a son, I will give him to the Elder Anuruddha to be ordained.”

original: labhissāmi, ayyassa anuruddhattherassa santike pabbājessāmī”ti cittaṃ uppādesi. So
analyzed: labhissāmi ayyassa anuruddha ttherassa santike pabbājessāmi iti cittam uppādesi saḥ
translated: The lay disciple obtained a son,

original: ca dasamāsaccayena jāto arogoyeva hutvā anukkamena vaḍḍhento sattavassiko ahosi,
analyzed: ca dasa māsa cayena jātaḥ hutvā anukkamena vaḍḍhentaḥ sattavassikaḥ ahosi
translated: And after ten months had passed, he was born in perfect health. As he grew up, he became a boy of seven years.

original: taṃ pitā therassa santike pabbājesi. So pabbajitvā tato paripakkañāṇattā vipassanāya
analyzed: tam pitā therassa santike pabbājesi saḥ pabbajitvā tatas paripakka ñāṇa ttā vipassanāya
translated: His father caused him to be admitted to the Order in the presence of the Elder. After he had been admitted to the Order, he developed insight,

original: kammaṃ karonto nacirasseva chaḷabhiñño hutvā theraṃ upaṭṭhahanto “pānīyaṃ āharissāmī”ti
analyzed: kammam karontaḥ nacirassa iva chaḷabhiññaḥ hutvā theram upaṭṭhahantaḥ pānīyam āharissāmi iti
translated: and in a very few days attained Arahatship. One day he said to himself, “I will bring water for the Elder.”

original: ghaṭaṃ ādāya iddhiyā anotattadahaṃ agamāsi. Atheko micchādiṭṭhiko nāgarājā anotattadahaṃ🔽paṭicchādento sattakkhattuṃ bhogena parikkhipitvā upari mahantaṃ phaṇaṃ katvā sumanassa
analyzed: ghaṭam ādāya iddhiyā anotat tat aham agamāsi atha ekaḥ micchādiṭṭhikaḥ nāga rājā anotat tat aham  paṭicchādentaḥ satta kkhattum bhogena parikkhipitvā upari mahantam phaṇam katvā sumanassa
translated: So taking a water-pot, he went by means of his Supernatural Power to the Lake Anotatta. Now at that time a certain Nāga king of heretical views,🔽encircling the Lake Anotatta seven times with his coils, spread his hood over the surface of the water and would not permit Sumana to draw water.

original: pānīyaṃ gahetuṃ okāsaṃ na deti. Sumano garuḷarūpaṃ gahetvā taṃ nāgarājaṃ abhibhavitvā
analyzed: pānīyam okāsam na deti sumanaḥ garuḷa rūpam gahetvā tam nāga rājam abhibhavitvā
translated: Sumana assumed the form of a Garuḷa, and overpowering the Nāga king,

original: pānīyaṃ gahetvā therassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ uddissa ākāsena gacchati. Taṃ satthā jetavane
analyzed: pānīyam gahetvā therassa vasanaṭṭhānam uddissa ākāsena gacchati tam satthā jetavane
translated: drew water and started off through the air in the direction of the Elder’s dwelling-place. The Teacher, who was seated in the Jetavana,

original: nisinno tathā gacchantaṃ disvā dhammasenāpatiṃ āmantetvā, “sāriputta, imaṃ passā”tiādinā
analyzed: nisinnaḥ tathā gacchantam disvā dhamma senāpatim āmantetvā sāriputta imam passa ati ādinā
translated: saw him as he went along, and calling the General of the Dhamma to him, said, “Sāriputta, look at him.”

original: catūhi gāthāhi tassa guṇe abhāsi. Atha sumanatthero –
analyzed: catūhi gāthāhi tassa guṇe abhāsi atha sumana theraḥ
translated: and he spoke these four verses in praise of his virtues. Then the Elder Sumanā said:

original: “Yadā navo pabbajito, jātiyā sattavassiko;
analyzed: yadā navaḥ pabbajitaḥ jātiyā satta vassikaḥ
translated: “When he had newly gone forth, at the age of seven years,

original: Iddhiyā abhibhotvāna, pannagindaṃ mahiddhikaṃ.
analyzed: id dhiyai pannagindam mahiddhikam
translated: By his psychic power he subdued the mighty king of the snakes.

original: “Upajjhāyassa udakaṃ, anotattā mahāsarā;
analyzed: upajjhāyassa udakaṃ anotattā mahā sarā
translated: “Because the water in the great lake was not yet warm,

original: Āharāmi tato disvā, maṃ satthā etadabravi.
analyzed: āharāmi tatas disvā mam satthā etat abravi
translated: I brought water from the river. Seeing this, the Teacher said to me:

original: “Sāriputta imaṃ passa, āgacchantaṃ kumārakaṃ;
analyzed: sāriputta imam passe āgacchantam kumārakam
translated: “Sāriputta, look at this young boy coming,

original: Udakakumbhamādāya, ajjhattaṃ susamāhitaṃ.
analyzed: udaka kumbham ādāya ajjhattam su samāhitam
translated: Holding a water pot, his mind well-composed.

original: “Pāsādikena vattena, kalyāṇairiyāpatho;🔽Sāmaṇeronuruddhassa, iddhiyā ca visārado.🔽“Ājānīyena ājañño, sādhunā sādhukārito;
analyzed: pāsādikena vattena kalyāṇa airiyāpathaḥ  iddhiyā ca visāradaḥ  ājānīyena ājaññaḥ sādhunā sādhu kāritaḥ
translated: “With his pleasing manner, his good conduct,🔽The novice monk, confident in his psychic power,🔽“The thoroughbred, well-trained by the thoroughbred,

original: Vinīto anuruddhena, katakiccena sikkhito.
analyzed: vinītaḥ anuruddhena kata kiccena sikkhitaḥ
translated: The well-disciplined one, trained by the one who has done his duty,

original: “So patvā paramaṃ santiṃ, sacchikatvā akuppataṃ;
analyzed: saḥ patvā paramam santim sacchikatvā akuppatam
translated: “Having attained the highest peace, having realized the deathless,

original: Sāmaṇero sa sumano, mā maṃ jaññāti icchatī”ti. –
analyzed: sāmaṇeraḥ sa sumanaḥ mā mama jaññāti icchati iti
translated: The novice monk Sumanā wishes: ‘May they not know me.’“

original: Aññābyākaraṇavasena cha gāthā abhāsi.
analyzed: cha gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: and he spoke these six verses in the manner of a declaration of his knowledge.

original: Tattha ādito dve gāthā sumanatthereneva bhāsitā, itarā catasso taṃ pasaṃsantena satthārā
analyzed: tattha āditas dve gāthā sumana therena iva bhāsitā itarā catassaḥ tam pasaṃsantena satthārā
translated: Herein, the first two verses were spoken by the Elder Sumanā, and the other four were spoken by the Master in his praise of him.

original: bhāsitā. Tā sabbā ekajjhaṃ katvā sumanatthero pacchā aññābyākaraṇavasena abhāsi.
analyzed: bhāsitā tā sabbā ekajjham katvā sumana thero pacchā aññā byākaraṇa vasena abhāsi
translated: All of them together were spoken by the Elder Sumanā later on in the form of a declaration of his own special qualities.

original: Tattha pannagindanti nāgarājaṃ. Tatoti tattha, yadā navo pabbajito jātiyā sattavassiko
analyzed: tattha nāga rājam tato ti tattha yadā navaḥ pabbajitaḥ jātiyā satta vassikaḥ
translated: Herein, the word pannagindam means a king of snakes. Then : there, when I was a novice of seven years’ standing,

original: iddhibalena mahiddhikaṃ nāgarājaṃ abhibhavitvā anotattadahato upajjhāyassa pānīyaṃ
analyzed: iddhi balena mahiddhikam nāga rājam abhibhavitvā upajjhāyassa pānīyam
translated: I overpowered the mighty king of snakes by my psychic power and brought water from the Anotatta Lake for my preceptor to drink.

original: āharāmi, tasmiṃ kāleti attho.
analyzed: āharāmi tasmin kāle iti
translated: That is the meaning.🔽The Master said this to me with reference to me. Pointing out that, he said, ‘Sariputta, look at this’ .

original: Maṃ uddissa mayhaṃ satthā etadabravi, taṃ dassento, “sāriputta, imaṃ passā”tiādimāha. Ajjhattaṃ susamāhitanti visayajjhattabhūtena aggaphalasamādhinā suṭṭhu samāhitaṃ.
analyzed: mam uddissa mayham satthā etat abravi tam dassentaḥ sāriputtaḥ imam passa ati ādim āha ajjhattam su samāhitam ti visaya jjhatta bhūtena agga phala samādhinā suṭṭhu samāhitam
translated: Well composed in mind : well composed by means of the highest fruit of jhana, which is the object of the word ‘inside’ .

original: Pāsādikena vattenāti passantānaṃ pasādāvahena ācāravattena, karaṇatthe idaṃ karaṇavacanaṃ.
analyzed: pāsādikena vattena ati passantānam pasādāvahena ācāravattena karaṇa atthe idam karaṇa vacanam
translated: With a pleasing deportment : with a conduct that is a source of confidence to those who see it. This is a gerundive expression in the sense of instrument.

original: Kalyāṇairiyāpathoti sampanniriyāpatho. Pāsādikena vattenāti vā itthambhūtalakkhaṇe
analyzed: kalyāṇa eriyāpatho ti sampad niriyāpatho pāsādikena vattena ati vā ittham bhūta lakkhaṇe
translated: “Of good conduct” : of perfect conduct. “With a pleasing manner” : the manner of speaking is stated as the instrument.

original: karaṇavacanaṃ. Samaṇassa bhāvo sāmaṇyaṃ, sāmaññanti attho. Tadatthaṃ īrati pavattatīti
analyzed: karaṇa vacanam samaṇassa bhāvaḥ sāmaṇyam sāmaññanti atthaḥ tad attham īrati pavattati iti
translated: “The state of a recluse” : the state of a recluse is samaṇya; the meaning is, the state of a monk. He is a sāmaṇera because he goes to that state.

original: sāmaṇero, samaṇuddeso. Iddhiyā ca visāradoti iddhiyampi byatto sukusalo. Ājānīyenāti
analyzed: sāmaṇeraḥ samaṇuddesaḥ iddhiyā ca visāra daḥ ti iddhiyam pi byattaḥ su kusalaḥ ājānīyena ati
translated: He is a sāmaṇera, a novice monk. “Confident in his psychic power” : he is also confident in psychic power, he is well-trained in it.🔽“With the thoroughbred’s gait” : with the gait of a thoroughbred horse.

original: purisājānīyena. Attahitaparahitānaṃ sādhanato sādhunā katakiccena anuruddhena sādhu
analyzed: purisājānīyena atta hita para hitānam sādhanataḥ sādhunā kata kiccena anuruddhena sādhu
translated: Anuruddha, having accomplished his own and others’ welfare, is good because he has done his duty.🔽He is good because he accomplishes the welfare of both himself and others, or because he is well-trained, well-tamed, a thoroughbred.

original: ubhayahitasādhako, suṭṭhu vā ājañño kārito damito. Aggavijjāya vinīto asekkhabhāvāpādanena
analyzed: ubhaya hita sādhako suṭṭhu vā ājaññaḥ kāritaḥ damitaḥ agga vijjāya vinītaḥ asekkha bhāva āpādanena
translated: “Trained in the supreme knowledge” : trained by attaining the state of a non-learner,

original: sikkhito sikkhāpitoti attho.
analyzed: sikkhitaḥ sikkhāpito ti attho
translated: trained, taught, is the meaning.

original: So sāmaṇero sumano paramaṃ santiṃ nibbānaṃ patvā aggamaggādhigamena adhigantvā sacchikatvā
analyzed: saḥ sāmaṇeraḥ sumano paramam santim nibbānam patvā agga magga adhigamena adhigantvā sacchikatvā
translated: That sāmaṇera, having attained the supreme peace, Nibbāna, having attained it by reaching the highest path, having realized it,

original: attapaccakkhaṃ katvā akuppataṃ arahattaphalaṃ appicchabhāvassa paramukkaṃsagatattā
analyzed: atta paccakkham katvā a kuppa tam arahatta phalam appiccha bhāvassa paramukkaṃsa gata ttā
translated: having made it manifest to himself, having attained the unshakable Arahant fruit, because of his extreme fewness of wishes,

original: mā maṃ jaññāti maṃ “ayaṃ khīṇāsavo”ti vā “chaḷabhiñño”ti vā kocipi mā jāneyyāti icchati abhikaṅkhatīti.
analyzed: mā mam jaññāti mam ayam khīṇa āsavaḥ iti vā chaḷabhiñño iti vā kocipi mā jāneyyāti icchati abhikaṅkhati iti
translated: He wishes, he longs, that no one may know him thus: “He is one whose cankers are destroyed” or “He is one who possesses the six kinds of direct knowledge.”

original: Sumanattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽11. Nhātakamunittheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: sumana thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  nhātaka muni thera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the verses of the Elder Sumana is finished.

original: Vātarogābhinītotiādikā āyasmato nhātakamunissa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi purimabuddhesu
analyzed: vāta roga abhinītaḥ ti ādikā āyasmataḥ nhātaka munissa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi purima buddhesu
translated: The verse beginning “The sage who bathed” is that of the Elder Nhātakamuni. What is the origin of it? This elder too, having formed his aspiration in the presence of past Buddhas,

original: katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinitvā imasmiṃ buddhuppāde rājagahe brāhmaṇakule
analyzed: kata adhikāraḥ tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinitvā imasmin buddhuppāde rājagahe brāhmaṇa kule
translated: having accumulated merit in various existences, was reborn in a brahmin family in Rājagaha in this Dispensation.

original: nibbattitvā vayappatto vijjāṭṭhānādīsu nipphattiṃ gato nhātakalakkhaṇayogena nhātakoti
analyzed: nibbattitvā vaya ppattaḥ vijjāṭṭhāna ādīsu nipphattim gataḥ nhātaka lakkhaṇa yogena nhātako ti
translated: Having reached maturity, he became proficient in the branches of knowledge, etc., and was known as Nhātaka because he possessed the characteristics of one who has bathed.

original: paññāyittha. So tāpasapabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā rājagahassa tiyojanappamāṇe ṭhāne araññāyatane
analyzed: paññāyittha saḥ tāpasapabbajjam pabbajitvā rājagahassa ti yojana ppamāṇe ṭhāne arañña āyatane
translated: He went forth as a forest-dweller and lived in a forest abode three leagues from Rājagaha,

original: nīvārehi yāpento aggiṃ paricārayamāno vasati. Tassa satthā ghaṭe viya padīpaṃ hadayabbhantare
analyzed: nīvārehi yāpentaḥ aggim paricārayamānaḥ vasati tassa satthā ghaṭe viya padīpam hadaya bbhantare
translated: subsisting on roots and fruits, tending the sacred fire. The Teacher, like a pot,🔽in the heart of the elder,

original: pajjalantaṃ arahattūpanissayaṃ disvā assamapadaṃ agamāsi. So bhagavantaṃ disvā haṭṭhatuṭṭho
analyzed: pajjalantam arahatta upanissayam disvā assama padam agamāsi saḥ bhagavantam disvā haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ
translated: and seeing that it was burning with the fire of Arahatship, he went to the monastery. When he saw the Buddha, he was filled with joy and satisfaction.

original: attano upakappananiyāmena āhāraṃ upanesi. Taṃ bhagavā paribhuñji. Evaṃ tayo divase
analyzed: attanaḥ upakappana niyāmena āhāram upanesi tam bhagavā paribhuñji evam tayaḥ divase
translated: According to his own custom, he brought food and offered it to the Buddha. The Buddha accepted it and ate it. In this way he gave food to the Buddha for three days.

original: datvā catutthadivase “bhagavā tumhe paramasukhumālā, kathaṃ iminā āhārena yāpethā”ti
analyzed: catuttha divase bhagavā tumhe katham iminā āhārena yāpetha ati
translated: On the fourth day he said, “Reverend Sir, you are very delicate; how can you live on this food?”

original: āha. Tassa satthā ariyasantosaguṇaṃ pakāsento dhammaṃ desesi. Tāpaso taṃ sutvā sotāpanno
analyzed: āha tassa satthā ariya santosa guṇam pakāsento dhammam desesi tāpasaḥ tam sutvā sotāpanno
translated: The Teacher preached the Law, setting forth the virtues of the Saints. The devotee, having listened to the Law, became a Stream-enterer.

original: hutvā pabbajitvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Bhagavā taṃ arahatte patiṭṭhapetvā gato. So pana🔽tattheva viharanto aparabhāge vātābādhena upadduto ahosi. Satthā tattha gantvā paṭisanthāramukhena
analyzed: hutvā pabbajitvā arahattam pāpuṇi bhagavā tam arahatte patiṭṭhapetvā gataḥ saḥ pana  tattha iva viharantaḥ aparabhāge vāta ābādhena upaddutaḥ ahosi satthā tattha gantvā paṭisanthāra mukhena
translated: He then retired from the world and attained Arahatship. The Buddha established him in Arahatship and then departed. The devotee

original: tassa vihāraṃ pucchanto –
analyzed: tassa vihāram pucchantaḥ
translated: remained there, but in the course of time was attacked by a severe wind-disease. The Teacher went there and asked him about his health, saying,

original: “Vātarogābhinīto tvaṃ, viharaṃ kānane vane;
analyzed: tvam kānane vane
translated: “Afflicted with a wind-disease, in a forest-grove, in a lonely place,🔽How, O monk, will you live?”

original: Paviddhagocare lūkhe, kathaṃ bhikkhu karissasī”ti. – gāthamāha; Atha thero –
analyzed: paviddha gocare lūkhe katham bhikkhu karissasi iti gātham āha atha theraḥ
translated: The Elder replied,

original: “Pītisukhena vipulena, pharitvāna samussayaṃ;
analyzed: pīti sukhena vipulena samussayam
translated: “With rapture and pleasure so vast, I’ll fill my heart and mind,

original: Lūkhampi abhisambhonto, viharissāmi kānane.
analyzed: lūkham pi abhisambhontaḥ viharissāmi kānane
translated: And, though the life be hard, I’ll live in the forest.

original: “Bhāvento satta bojjhaṅge, indriyāni balāni ca;
analyzed: bhāvento satta bojjhaṅge indriyāni balāni ca
translated: “Developing the seven factors of Awakening, the faculties and powers,

original: Jhānasokhummasampanno, viharissaṃ anāsavo.
analyzed: viharissam anāsavaḥ
translated: And perfecting the serenity of the absorptions, I’ll live without defilements.

original: “Vippamuttaṃ kilesehi, suddhacittaṃ anāvilaṃ;
analyzed: vippamuttam kilesehi suddha cittam anāvilam
translated: “Free from defilements, my mind pure and clear,

original: Abhiṇhaṃ paccavekkhanto, viharissaṃ anāsavo.
analyzed: abhiṇham paccavekkhantaḥ viharissam anāsavaḥ
translated: I’ll often reflect on this, and live without defilements.

original: “Ajjhattañca bahiddhā ca, ye me vijjiṃsu āsavā;
analyzed: ajjhattañca bahiddhā ca ye me āsavā
translated: “Whatever defilements I have within and without,

original: Sabbe asesā ucchinnā, na ca uppajjare puna.
analyzed: sabbe asesāḥ ucchinnāḥ na ca uppajjare puna
translated: All without exception are cut off, and will not arise again.

original: “Pañcakkhandhā pariññātā, tiṭṭhanti chinnamūlakā;
analyzed: pañca kkhandhā pariññātā tiṭṭhanti chinna mūlakā
translated: “The five aggregates are fully understood, standing with their roots cut off;

original: Dukkhakkhayo anuppatto, natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti. –
analyzed: dukkha kkhayo anuppatto natthi dāni punabbhavaḥ ti
translated: The destruction of suffering has been reached, and there is no more renewed existence.”

original: Imāhi sesagāthāhi attano vihāraṃ satthu pavedesi.
analyzed: imāhi sesa gāthāhi attanaḥ vihāram satthu pavedesi
translated: With these remaining verses he announced his own dwelling place to the Teacher.

original: Tattha jhānasokhummasampannoti jhānasukhumabhāvena samannāgato. Jhānasukhumaṃ nāma
analyzed: tattha jhāna sokhumma sampanno ti jhāna sukhuma bhāvena samannāgataḥ jhānasukhumam nāma
translated: Herein, perfecting the serenity of the absorptions means endowed with the serenity of the absorptions. The serenity of the absorptions is🔽the formless jhana. Thus it is said that he has attained the eight attainments. By this he shows that he has

original: arūpajjhānaṃ, tasmā aṭṭhasamāpattilābhimhīti vuttaṃ hoti. Tena attano ubhatobhāgavimuttitaṃ
analyzed: arūpa jhānam tasmai aṭṭha samāpatti lābhimhi iti vuttam hoti tena attanaḥ ubhatobhāga vimutti tam
translated: liberation in both ways.

original: dasseti. Apare panāhu – “sokhummanti aggamaggaphalesu adhipaññāsikkhā adhippetā,
analyzed: dasseti apare pana āhu sokhummanti aggamagga phalesu adhipaññā sikkhā adhippetā
translated: But others say that the “peace” is the higher training in wisdom in the noble paths and fruits,🔽and that by mentioning the jhānas he shows his own deliverance by both sides.

original: tato jhānaggahaṇena attano ubhatobhāgavimuttitaṃ vibhāvetī”ti. Vippamuttaṃ kilesehīti
analyzed: tatas jhāna ggahaṇena attanaḥ ubhatobhāga vimutti tam vibhāveti iti vippamuttam kilesehi iti
translated: “Freed from the defilements” :🔽freed from all defilements by the deliverance of the state of peace;

original: paṭippassaddhivimuttiyā sabbakilesehi vimuttaṃ, tato eva suddhacittaṃ, anāvilasaṅkappatāya
analyzed: paṭippassaddhi vimuttiyā sabba kilesehi vimuttam tatas eva suddha cittam anāvila saṅkappa tāya
translated: therefore “pure of heart,” because his intentions are untainted.

original: anāvilaṃ, tīhipi padehi arahattaphalacittameva vadati. Sesaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayameva.
analyzed: anāvilam tīhi pi padehi arahatta phala cittam eva vadati sesam heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva
translated: By all three phrases he refers to the consciousness of the fruition of arahantship. The rest is as already stated.

original: Imameva ca therassa aññābyākaraṇaṃ ahosīti.
analyzed: imam eva ca therassa aññā byākaraṇam ahosi iti
translated: And this was the Elder’s declaration of his knowledge.

original: Nhātakamunittheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nhātaka muni thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the verses of the Elder Nhātakamuni is finished.

original: 12. Brahmadattattheragāthāvaṇṇanā🔽Akkodhassātiādikā āyasmato brahmadattattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi purimabuddhesu
analyzed: brahmadatta thera gāthā vaṇṇanā  akkodhassa ati ādikā āyasmataḥ brahmadatta therassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi purima buddhesu
translated: The verses of the Elder Brahmadinna🔽The verses beginning with the words “Free from anger” are those of the Elder Brahmadinna. What is the origin of these verses? This Elder also, having performed meritorious deeds in various existences under past Buddhas,

original: katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinitvā imasmiṃ buddhuppāde sāvatthiyaṃ
analyzed: kata adhikāraḥ tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinitvā imasmin buddhuppāde sāvatthiyam
translated: in this dispensation was born into a brahmin family of good birth, high family, and great wealth, in the town of Thullakotthita.

original: kosalarañño putto hutvā nibbatti, brahmadattotissa nāmaṃ ahosi. So vayappatto jetavanamahe
analyzed: kosala rañño puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti brahmadatta itissa nāmam ahosi saḥ vaya pattaḥ jetavana mahe
translated: He was born as the son of the King of Kosala and was named Brahmadatta. When he had grown up he went to the Great Grove of Jetavana

original: buddhānubhāvaṃ disvā paṭiladdhasaddho pabbajitvā vipassanāya kammaṃ karonto saha
analyzed: buddha anubhāvam disvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbajitvā vipassanāya kammam karonto saha
translated: and saw the Buddha. He was filled with faith and became a monk. He did the work of insight meditation and attained the six super-knowledges together with the analytical knowledges.

original: paṭisambhidāhi chaḷabhiñño ahosi. Taṃ ekadivasaṃ nagare piṇḍāya carantaṃ aññataro
analyzed: paṭisambhidāhi chaṣ abhiññaḥ ahosi tam eka divasam nagare piṇḍāya carantam aññataraḥ
translated: One day, as he was going on his alms round in the city, a certain brahmin abused him.

original: brāhmaṇo akkosi. Thero taṃ sutvāpi tuṇhībhūto piṇḍāya caratiyeva, brāhmaṇo punapi
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ akkosi theraḥ tam sutvā api tuṇhībhūtaḥ piṇḍāya brāhmaṇaḥ punar api
translated: The elder remained silent and continued on his alms round, but the brahmin abused him again.

original: akkosiyeva. Manussā evaṃ akkosantampi naṃ “ayaṃ thero na kiñci bhaṇatī”ti āhaṃsu.
analyzed: akkosiyā iva manussāḥ evam akkosantam pi nam ayam theraḥ na kiñci bhaṇati iti āhaṃsu
translated: The people said, “This elder says nothing at all.”

original: Taṃ sutvā thero tesaṃ manussānaṃ dhammaṃ desento –
analyzed: tam sutvā theraḥ tesam manussānam dhammaṃ desento
translated: When the elder heard this, he taught the Dhamma to those people with the following verses:

original: “Akkodhassa kuto kodho, dantassa samajīvino;
analyzed: akkodhassa kutas kodhaḥ dantassa sama jīvino
translated: “How can there be anger in one who is without anger, who is self-controlled and lives in peace,

original: Sammadaññā vimuttassa, upasantassa tādino.
analyzed: sammad aññāḥ vimuttassa upasantassa tādinaḥ
translated: who is liberated by right knowledge, who is calm and restrained?

original: “Tasseva tena pāpiyo, yo kuddhaṃ paṭikujjhati;
analyzed: tassa iva tena pāpiyaḥ yaḥ kuddham paṭikujjhati
translated: “He is worse than the angry person who angers him;

original: Kuddhaṃ appaṭikujjhanto, saṅgāmaṃ jeti dujjayaṃ.
analyzed: kuddham a paṭikujjhantaḥ saṅgāmam jeti dujjayam
translated: he who, when not angered, does not return anger for anger, wins a battle hard to win.

original: “Ubhinnamatthaṃ carati, attano ca parassa ca;
analyzed: carati attano ca parassa ca
translated: “He lives for the good of both, for his own and for the other’s,

original: Paraṃ saṅkupitaṃ ñatvā, yo sato upasammati.
analyzed: param saṅkupitam ñatvā yaḥ sataḥ
translated: Knowing the other to be angry, he who is mindful and self-controlled,

original: “Ubhinnaṃ tikicchantaṃ taṃ, attano ca parassa ca;
analyzed: ubhinnam tikicchantam tam attano ca parassa ca
translated: He who heals both himself and the other,

original: Janā maññanti bāloti, ye dhammassa akovidā. ;
analyzed: janā maññanti bālo ti ye dhammassa akovidā
translated: The people think him a fool, those who are unskilled in the Dhamma.

original: “Uppajje te sace kodho, āvajja kakacūpamaṃ;
analyzed: uppajje te sace kodhaḥ āvajja kakacūpamam
translated: If anger should arise in you, remember the simile of the saw;

original: Uppajje ce rase taṇhā, puttamaṃsūpamaṃ sara.
analyzed: uppajje ce rase taṇhā putta maṃsu upamam sara
translated: If craving for tastes should arise, remember the simile of the flesh of your son.

original: “Sace dhāvati cittaṃ te, kāmesu ca bhavesu ca;
analyzed: sace dhāvati cittam te kāmesu ca bhavesu ca
translated: If your mind should run hither and thither among sensual pleasures and becoming,

original: Khippaṃ niggaṇha satiyā, kiṭṭhādaṃ viya duppasu”nti. –
analyzed: khippam niggaṇha satiyā kiṭṭhādam viya duppasunti
translated: Quickly restrain it with mindfulness, as a good cowherd restrains the cows with a stick.

original: Imā gāthā abhāsi.🔽Tattha akkodhassāti kodharahitassa maggena samucchinnakodhassa. Kuto kodhoti kuto
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi  tattha akkodhassa ati kodha rahitassa maggena samucchinna kodhassa kutas kodho ti kutas
translated: He spoke these verses.

original: nāma hetu kodho uppajjeyya, tassa uppattikāraṇaṃ natthīti attho. Dantassāti uttamena🔽damena aggamaggadamathena dantassa. Samajīvinoti kāyavisamādīni sabbaso pahāya kāyasamādīnaṃ
analyzed: nāma hetu kodhaḥ uppajjeyya tassa uppatti kāraṇam natthi iti atthaḥ dantassa ati uttamena  damena agga magga damathena dantassa sama jīvino ti kāya visama ādīni sabbaso pahāya
translated: Herein, without anger: free from anger, with anger utterly destroyed by the path. Whence anger? Whence, indeed, could there be a cause for anger? The meaning is that there is no cause for its arising. Self-controlled: self-controlled by the highest self-control, by the self-control of the path of arahatship.🔽Living in comfort: living in comfort by means of bodily comfort, etc., by means of the comfort of the seven factors of enlightenment.

original: vasena samaṃ jīvantassa sattaṭṭhāniyena sampajaññena sammadeva vattantassa. Sammadaññā
analyzed: vasena samam jīvantassa satta ṭṭhāniyena sampajaññena sammat eva vattantassa sammadaññā
translated: Conducting himself properly: conducting himself properly by means of right understanding, by means of the right understanding of the seven factors of enlightenment.

original: vimuttassāti sammā aññāya abhiññeyyādike dhamme jānitvā sabbāsavehi vippamuttassa.
analyzed: vimuttassa ati sammā aññāya abhiññeyya ādike dhamme jānitvā sabba āsavehi vippamuttassa
translated: Vimuttassa means to one who is liberated from all cankers by knowing rightly the things to be directly known, etc.

original: Tato eva sabbakilesadarathapariḷāhavūpasamena upasantassa. Iṭṭhādīsu tādilakkhaṇappattiyā
analyzed: tatas eva sabba kilesa daratha pariḷāha vūpasamena upasantassa iṭṭha ādīsu ta ādi lakkhaṇa ppattiyā
translated: And because of that, to one who is tranquil by the subsiding of all defilements, troubles, and fevers,

original: tādino khīṇāsavassa kuto kodhoti aññāpadesena thero attano kodhābhāvaṃ tassa ca kāraṇāni
analyzed: tādinaḥ khīṇāsavassa kutas kodho ti añña apadesena theraḥ attano kodha abhāvam tassa ca kāraṇāni
translated: How can there be anger in one who is such, who has destroyed the taints?

original: vatvā idāni kodhe akodhe ca ādīnavānisaṃsadassanena dhammaṃ kathento “tassevā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: vatvā idāni kodhe akodhe ca ādīnava anisaṃsa dassanena dhammam kathentaḥ tassa iva ati ādim āha
translated: Having thus shown by the words “to one who is liberated” and so on his own absence of anger and the reasons for it, the Elder now said “Tasseva,” etc., in order to expound the Dhamma by showing the danger and disadvantage in anger and the benefit and advantage in non-anger.

original: Tattha yo kuddhaṃ paṭikujjhatīti yo puggalo attano upari kuddhaṃ kupitaṃ puggalaṃ
analyzed: tattha yaḥ kuddham paṭikujjhati iti yaḥ puggalaḥ attanaḥ upari kuddham kupitam puggalam
translated: Herein, yo kuddhaṃ paṭikujjhati means if a person gets angry in return at a person who is angry at him,

original: paṭikujjhati, tasseva tena paṭikujjhanapaccakkosanapaṭippaharaṇādinā pāpiyo idhaloke
analyzed: paṭikujjhati tassa iva tena paṭikujjhana paccakkosana paṭippaharaṇa ādinā idha loke
translated: then it is worse for him in this very life by the return of the anger, by the reproach, by the punishment, and so on.

original: viññūgarahādivasena paraloke nirayadukkhādivasena abhaddakataraṃ akalyāṇataraṃ hoti.
analyzed: viññūgaraha ādi vasena para loke niraya dukkha ādi vasena abhaddakataram akalyāṇataram hoti
translated: And in the life to come it is more unbeneficial, more unwholesome, by the censure of the wise and so on, and by the suffering of hell and so on.🔽But there is no need to say that there is evil for one who is not angry when another is angry.

original: Kujjhanena pana akuddhassa pāpaṃ hotīti vattabbameva natthi. Keci pana “yo akuddhaṃ
analyzed: kujjhanena pana akuddhassa pāpam hoti iti vattabbam eva na atthi keci pana yaḥ akuddham
translated: But some people say: “If one who is not angry

original: paṭikuddhaṃ ārabbha kujjhatī”ti atthaṃ vadanti. Kuddhaṃ appaṭikujjhantoti yo pana
analyzed: paṭikuddham ārabbha kujjhati iti attham vadanti kuddham a paṭikujjhanto iti yaḥ pana
translated: They say that the meaning is this: “He gets angry when another is angry.”🔽Not getting angry when another is angry: but if,

original: kuddhaṃ puggalaṃ “ayaṃ kuddho kodhapareto”ti ñatvā na paṭikujjhati khamati, so dujjayaṃ
analyzed: kuddham puggalam ayam kuddhaḥ kodha paretaḥ iti ñatvā na paṭikujjhati khamati saḥ dujjayam
translated: knowing that another person is angry, he does not get angry in return, he is said to conquer the hard-to-conquer

original: kilesasaṅgāmaṃ jeti nāma. Na kevalañcassa kilesasaṅgāmajayo eva, atha kho ubhayahitapaṭipattimpīti
analyzed: kilesa saṅgāmam jeti nāma na kevalam ca assa kilesa saṅgāma jayaḥ eva atha kho ubhaya hita paṭipattim pi iti
translated: afflictive struggle. And not only does he conquer the afflictive struggle, but he also practices for the welfare of both.

original: dassento āha “ubhinnamatthaṃ…pe… upasammatī”ti. Yo paraṃ puggalaṃ saṅkupitaṃ kuddhaṃ
analyzed: dassentaḥ āha yaḥ param puggalam saṅkupitam kuddham
translated: Showing this, he said, “He practices for the welfare of both … is pacified” .

original: “kodhapareto”ti ñatvā taṃ mettāyanto ajjhupekkhanto vā sato sampajāno hutvā upasammati
analyzed: kodha paretā iti ñatvā tam mettāyantaḥ ajjhupekkhantaḥ vā sataḥ sampajānaḥ hutvā upasammati
translated: If, knowing that another person is angry, he is full of loving kindness toward him, or if he is mindful and clearly comprehending, he is pacified,

original: khamati na paṭippharati. So attano ca parassa cāti ubhinnaṃ ubhayalokasukhāvahaṃ🔽atthaṃ hitaṃ carati.
analyzed: khamati na paṭippharati saḥ attanaḥ ca parassa ca ati ubhinnam ubhaya loka sukha āvaham  attham hitam carati
translated: he forgives and does not retaliate. He practices for the welfare of both himself and the other,🔽the welfare that brings happiness in both worlds.

original: Ubhinnaṃ tikicchantaṃ tanti taṃ attano ca parassa cāti ubhinnaṃ dvinnaṃ kodhabyādhitikicchāya
analyzed: ubhinnam tikicchantam tanti tam attano ca parassa ca ati ubhinnam dvinnam kodha byādhi tikicchāya
translated: He is one who heals both: he heals both himself and the other.

original: tikicchantaṃ khamantaṃ puggalaṃ ye janā dhammassa ariyācāradhamme akusalā, te bālā🔽“ayaṃ aviddasu yo attānaṃ akkosantassa paharantassa kiñci na karotī”ti maññanti,
analyzed: tikicchantam khamantam puggalam ye janāḥ dhammassa ariya ācāra dhamme akusalā te bālā  ayam aviddasu yaḥ attānam akkosantassa paharantassa kiñci na karoti iti maññanti
translated: People who are unskilled in the ariyan way of virtue, who are ignorant of the Dhamma,🔽think that a man who, when being abused, forgives the abuser, is a fool.

original: taṃ tesaṃ ayoniso maññananti adhippāyo. “Tikicchana”ntipi paṭhanti, tikicchanasabhāvanti attho.
analyzed: tam tesam ayonisas maññananti adhippāyaḥ tikicchananti pi paṭhanti attho
translated: The meaning is that this is their wrong reflection.🔽The brahmin who abused the elder was remorseful and gained confidence.

original: Evaṃ therena vuccamānaṃ dhammaṃ sutvā akkosakabrāhmaṇo saṃviggo pasannacitto ca hutvā🔽theraṃ khamāpetvā tasseva santike pabbaji. Thero tassa kammaṭṭhānaṃ dento “imassa
analyzed: evam therena vuccamānam dhammam sutvā akkosaka brāhmaṇaḥ saṃviggaḥ pasanna citto ca hutvā  theram khamāpetvā tassa iva santike pabbaji thero tassa kammaṭṭhānam dentaḥ imassa
translated: He asked the elder’s forgiveness and went forth into homelessness under him.🔽The elder gave him a meditation subject.🔽“This man is suitable for the development of loving-kindness,” he thought, and he gave him the meditation subject of loving-kindness.

original: mettābhāvanā yuttā”ti mettākammaṭṭhānaṃ datvā kodhapariyuṭṭhānādīsu paccavekkhaṇādividhiṃ🔽dassento “uppajje te”tiādimāha. Tattha uppajje te saceti sace te kammaṭṭhānaṃ anuyuñjantassa
analyzed: mettā bhāvanā yuttā ti mettā kammaṭṭhānam da tvā kodha pariyuṭṭhāna ādīsu paccavekkhaṇa ādi vidhim  dassentaḥ uppajje te iti ādim āha tattha uppajje te sace iti sace te kammaṭṭhānam anuyuñjantassa
translated: Then, showing him the way to reflect on anger, etc.,🔽he said: “If anger should arise in you,

original: kañci puggalaṃ nissāya ciraparicayo kodho uppajjeyya, tassa vūpasamāya –
analyzed: kañci puggalam nissāya cira paricayaḥ kodhaḥ uppajjeyya tassa vūpasamāya
translated: If, while you are pursuing your meditation subject, anger should arise in you towards anyone owing to some wrong state of affairs, then, in order to allay it,

original: “Ubhatodaṇḍakena cepi, bhikkhave, kakacena corā ocarakā aṅgamaṅgāni okanteyyuṃ, tatrāpi yo mano padūseyya, na me so tena sāsanakaro”ti –
analyzed: ubhatodaṇḍakena ce pi bhikkhave kakacena corāḥ ocarakāḥ aṅgam aṅgāni tatra api yaḥ manaḥ padūseyya na me saḥ tena sāsana karoti
translated: “Monks, even if thieves were to carve you up limb by limb with a two-handled saw, he who should give rise to a mind of hate towards them would not be carrying out my instruction.”🔽Recall the Saw-Dust Simile Advice given by the Teacher.

original: Satthārā vuttaṃ kakacūpamaṃ ovādaṃ āvajjehi. Uppajje ce rase taṇhāti sace te madhurādibhede rase taṇhā abhilāso uppajjeyya, tassa vūpasamāya –
analyzed: satthārā vuttam kakaca upamam ovādam āvajjehi uppajje ce rase taṇhā ati sace te madhura ādi bhede rase taṇhā abhilāsaḥ uppajjeyya tassa vūpasamāya
translated: If craving for tastes arises in you: if craving, longing, for tastes such as sweet arises in you, then, in order to allay it,

original: “Puttamaṃsaṃ jāyampatikā yathā kantāranittharaṇatthameva khādiṃsu, na rasataṇhāya evaṃ kulaputtopi pabbajito piṇḍapātaṃ paṭisevati…pe… phāsuvihāro cā”ti –
analyzed: putta maṃsam jāyampatikāḥ yathā kantāra nittharaṇa attham eva khādiṃsu na rasa taṇhāya evam kula puttaḥ api pabbajitaḥ piṇḍapātam paṭisevati pe phāsu vihāro ca ati
translated: “Just as a man and his wife, in order to cross the desert, ate the flesh of their son, so too, a clansman who has gone forth should consume alms food… and so on as in § 111 up to… live in ease.”

original: Evaṃ vuttaṃ puttamaṃsūpamovādaṃ sara anussara.🔽Sace dhāvati te cittanti ayoniso manasi karoto tava cittaṃ kāmesu pañcakāmaguṇesu
analyzed: evam vuttam putta maṃsu upama uvādam sara anussara  sace dhāvati te ayonisaḥ manasi tava cittam kāmesu pañca kāmaguṇesu
translated: Recall the advice given in the Flesh of One’s Son Simile.🔽If your mind runs out: if, through unwise attention, your mind runs out, goes out, to the five cords of sense desire, the five kinds of sensual pleasures,

original: chandarāgavasena, kāmabhavādīsu bhavesu bhavapatthanāvasena sace dhāvati sarati javati.
analyzed: chanda rāga vasena kāma bhava ādīsu bhavesu bhava patthanā vasena sace dhāvati sarati javati
translated: through desire and lust for them; or if it runs out to the kinds of being in the sensual realm of existence, etc., through the wish for renewed existence there.

original: Khippaṃ niggaṇha satiyā, kiṭṭhādaṃ viya duppasunti tathā dhāvituṃ adento yathā nāma
analyzed: khippam niggaṇha satiyā kiṭṭhādam viya tathā dhāvitum a dentaḥ yathā nāma
translated: “Quickly bind him with mindfulness, As a man binds a wild ram with a rope,

original: puriso kiṭṭhādaṃ sassakhādakaṃ duppasuṃ duṭṭhagoṇaṃ yottena thambhe bandhitvā attano🔽vase vatteti, evaṃ satiyā satiyottena sammādhithambhe bandhanto khippaṃ sīghameva
analyzed: purisaḥ kiṭṭhādam sassa khādakam duppasum duṭṭha goṇam yottena thambhe bandhitvā attano  vase vattā iti evam satiyā satiyā uttena sammā adhithambhe bandhantaḥ khippam sīgham eva
translated: As a man binds a wild ram with a rope. Just as a man binds a wild ram with a rope, a ram that is difficult to subdue, that eats the crops, to a post with a yoke-tie,🔽and makes it behave as he wishes, so too, binding him with the rope of mindfulness to the post of concentration,

original: niggaṇha, yathā kilesavigamena nibbisevanaṃ hoti, tathā damehīti. Keci pana “thero
analyzed: niggaṇha yathā kilesa vigamena nibbisevanam hoti tathā damehi iti keci pana thero
translated: quickly, swiftly, bind him, and tame him so that he will be no more fed with defilements.

original: puthujjanova hutvā akkosaṃ adhivāsento tesaṃ manussānaṃ ariyaguṇe pakāsento dhammaṃ
analyzed: puthujjanaḥ uva hutvā akkosam adhivāsento tesam manussānam ariya guṇe pakāsento dhammaṃ
translated: But some say that the Elder, though still an ordinary man, preached the Dhamma, revealing the noble qualities of the people who had reviled him,

original: kathetvā pacchā dvīhi gāthāhi attānaṃ ovadanto vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ patvā
analyzed: kathetvā pacchā dvīhi gāthāhi attānam ovadantaḥ vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam patvā
translated: and after that, increasing his insight by means of the two verses of advice to himself, he attained arahatship and then,

original: aññaṃ byākaronto imāyeva gāthā abhāsī”ti vadanti.🔽Brahmadattattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: aññam byākarontaḥ imāyā iva gāthāḥ abhāsi iti vadanti  brahmadatta thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: declaring his enlightenment, uttered these very verses.”🔽The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Brahmadattatthera is finished.

original: 13. Sirimaṇḍattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: sirimaṇḍa tthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Verses of the Elder Sirimanda

original: Channamativassatītiādikā āyasmato sirimaṇḍattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi purimabuddhesu🔽katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinitvā imasmiṃ buddhuppāde saṃsumāragire
analyzed: channam ativassati iti ādikā āyasmataḥ sirimaṇḍa ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi purima buddhesu  kata adhikāraḥ tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinitvā imasmin buddhuppāde saṃsumāra gire
translated: The story of the Elder Sirimanda is given in the Commentary to the stanza, “The rain falls on the covered man.”🔽The Elder Sirimanda had made a Beginning under former Buddhas,🔽and in various states of existence had stored up abundant merit. At the time of the appearance of our Buddha, he was reborn in a certain Brāhmaṇa family in the Himalayas.

original: brāhmaṇakule nibbattitvā sirimaṇḍoti laddhanāmo vayappatto bhesakalāvane bhagavati
analyzed: brāhmaṇa kule nibbattitvā sirimaṇḍaḥ iti laddha nāmaḥ vaya pattaḥ bhesakalāvane bhagavati
translated: When he had grown up, he received the name Sirimanda. The Teacher was then residing in the Bhesakalāvana.

original: viharante satthāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā dhammaṃ sutvā paṭiladdhasaddho pabbajitvā laddhūpasampado
analyzed: viharante satthāram upasaṅkamitvā dhammam sutvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbajitvā laddha upasampadaḥ
translated: Sirimanda went to the Teacher, heard the Law, and obtained faith. He retired from the world, received the higher ordination,

original: samaṇadhammaṃ karonto ekasmiṃ uposathadivase pātimokkhuddesaṭṭhāne nisinno nidānuddesassa
analyzed: samaṇa dhammam karontaḥ ekasmin uposatha divase pātimokkha uddesa ṭṭhāne nisinno nidāna uddesassa
translated: and applied himself to the practice of meditation. On a certain fast-day, as he was sitting in the Hall of Precepts,

original: pariyosāne “āvikatā hissa phāsu hotī”ti pāḷiyā atthaṃ upadhārento āpannaṃ āpattiṃ
analyzed: pariyosāne āvika tā hissa phāsu hoti iti pāḷiyā attham upadhārentaḥ āpannam āpattim
translated: at the conclusion of the recitation of the Prātimokṣa, he reflected, “If a man confesses his sins, he will feel at ease.”

original: anāvikatvā paṭicchādento uparūpari āpattiyo āpajjati, tenassa na phāsu hoti, āvikatvā
analyzed: an āvikatvā paṭicchādentaḥ upari upari āpattiyaḥ āpajjati tena assa na phāsu hoti āvikatvā
translated: But he had committed a certain offense and had not confessed it. As he sat there, he committed one offense after another, and as a consequence he felt no ease. But if a man confesses his sins and makes amends for them according to the Law, he will feel at ease.

original: pana yathādhammaṃ paṭikarontassa phāsu hotīti imamatthaṃ manasi katvā “aho satthu
analyzed: pana yathādhammam paṭikarontassa phāsu hoti iti imam attham manasi katvā aho satthu
translated: With this thought in his mind, he said to himself, “Oh, that the Teacher would preach the Law to me!”

original: sāsanaṃ suvisuddha”nti laddhappasādo tathā uppannaṃ pītiṃ vikkhambhetvā vipassanaṃ
analyzed: sāsanam su visuddhanti laddha ppasādaḥ tathā uppannam pītim vikkhambhetvā vipassanam
translated: Having thus suppressed the joy that had arisen, he increased his insight,🔽and after attaining arahantship he surveyed his own progress.

original: vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ patvā attano paṭipattiṃ paccavekkhitvā pasannamānaso bhikkhūnaṃ ovādaṃ dento –
analyzed: vaḍḍhetvā arahattam patvā attano paṭipattim paccavekkhitvā pasanna mānasaḥ bhikkhūnam ovādam dentaḥ
translated: With his mind serene, he gave this advice to the bhikkhus:

original: “Channamativassati, vivaṭaṃ nātivassati;
analyzed: channam ativassati vivaṭam na ativassati
translated: “What is covered by a roof leaks; what is open does not leak.

original: Tasmā channaṃ vivaretha, evaṃ taṃ nātivassati.
analyzed: tasmāt channam vivaretha evam tam na ativassati
translated: Therefore, open up what is covered, and then it will not leak.

original: “Maccunābbhāhato loko, jarāya parivārito;
analyzed: lokaḥ jarāya parivāritaḥ
translated: “The world is struck down by death, surrounded by old age;

original: Taṇhāsallena otiṇṇo, icchādhūpāyito sadā. ;
analyzed: taṇhā sallena otiṇṇaḥ icchā dhūpāyitaḥ sadā
translated: It is caught in the snare of craving, and is always enveloped in the mist of desire.

original: “Maccunābbhāhato loko, parikkhitto jarāya ca;
analyzed: maccunā abbhāhataḥ loko parikkhitto jarāya ca
translated: “The world is struck down by death, surrounded by old age;

original: Haññati niccamattāṇo, pattadaṇḍova takkaro.
analyzed: haññati nicca mattāṇo patta daṇḍaḥ iva takkaro
translated: It is always without protection, like a tree with a saw set to it.

original: “Āgacchantaggikhandhāva, maccu byādhi jarā tayo;
analyzed: maccu jarā
translated: “The three—death, sickness, and old age—come like a chariot with a yoke;

original: Paccuggantuṃ balaṃ natthi, javo natthi palāyituṃ.
analyzed: paccuggantum balam natthi javaḥ natthi palāyitum
translated: There is no strength to resist them, no speed to flee from them.

original: “Amoghaṃ divasaṃ kayirā, appena bahukena vā;
analyzed: amogham divasam kayirāḥ appena bahukena vā
translated: “One should make each day fruitful, whether by night or by much;

original: Yaṃ yaṃ vijahate rattiṃ, tadūnaṃ tassa jīvitaṃ.
analyzed: yam yam vijahate rattim tad ūnam tassa jīvitam
translated: For each night that passes, life is shortened by just that much.

original: “Carato tiṭṭhato vāpi, āsīnasayanassa vā;
analyzed: carataḥ tiṭṭhataḥ vā api āsīna sayanassa vā
translated: “Whether walking or standing,

original: Upeti carimā ratti, na te kālo pamajjitu”nti. –
analyzed: upeti carimā ratti na te kālaḥ pamajjitunti
translated: It’s not the time for you to be negligent.”

original: Imā gāthā abhāsi.
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: He spoke these verses.

original: Tattha channanti chāditaṃ yathābhūtaṃ avivaṭaṃ appakāsitaṃ duccaritaṃ. Ativassatīti
analyzed: tattha channanti chāditam yathābhūtam a vivaṭam appakāsitam duccaritam ativassati iti
translated: Herein, concealed is concealed as bad conduct, not revealed as it actually is, not made plain. It rains down is

original: āpattivassañceva kilesavassañca ativiya vassati. Āpattiyā hi chādanaṃ alajjibhāvādinā
analyzed: āpatti vassam ca iva kilesa vassam ca ativiya vassati āpattiyā hi chādanam alajji bhāva ādinā
translated: raining down both the rain of offenses and the rain of defilements. For the concealment of an offense is a cause for the rain of offenses because of lack of conscience, etc.,

original: tādisova, chādanena tato aññathāva punapi tathārūpaṃ tato vā pāpiṭṭhataraṃ āpattiṃ🔽āpajjeyyāti chādanaṃ vassanassa kāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Vivaṭanti pakāsitaṃ appaṭicchannaṃ.
analyzed: tādisā uva chādanena tatas aññathā ava puna api tathārūpam tatas vā pāpiṭṭhataram āpattim  āpajjeyya ati chādanam vassanassa kāraṇam vuttam vivaṭanti pakāsitam appaṭicchannam
translated: and because of concealment he would again commit an offense similar to the first or even worse than the first.🔽So concealment is called a cause for the rain of offenses. Revealed is made plain, not concealed.

original: Nātivassatīti ettha atīti upasaggamattaṃ, na vassatīti attho. Avassanañcettha vuttavipariyāyena
analyzed: na ativassati iti ettha ati iti upasagga mattam na vassati iti atthaḥ avassanam ca ittha vutta vipariyāyena
translated: It does not rain down: here the prefix ati is merely a reiterative particle; the meaning is that it does not rain down. And the non-raining down should be understood in the opposite sense to the raining down.

original: veditabbaṃ cittasantānassa visodhitattā. Tasmāti vuttamevatthaṃ kāraṇabhāvena paccāmasati,
analyzed: veditabbam citta santānassa visodhita ttā tasmā iti vuttam evattham kāraṇa bhāvena paccāmasati
translated: So is a term for the meaning already stated. He reminds: he makes it known that it is a cause

original: channassa duccaritassa āpattivassādīnaṃ ativassanato vivaṭassa ca avassanatoti attho.
analyzed: channassa duccaritassa āpatti vassa ādīnam ativassanataḥ vivaṭassa ca avassanataḥ ti attho
translated: for the non-raining down of offenses, etc., because of the non-concealment of revealed bad conduct and because of the concealment of concealed bad conduct.

original: Channaṃ vivarethāti puthujjanabhāvena chādanādhippāye uppannepi taṃ ananuvattitvā
analyzed: channam vivaretha iti puthujjana bhāvena chādana adhippāye uppanne pi tam an anuvattitvā
translated: ‘Open up the six sense doors’: even if the desire to conceal arises through being an ordinary man,

original: vivaretha āvikareyya, yathādhammaṃ paṭikareyya. Evanti vivaraṇena yathādhammaṃ paṭipattiyā.
analyzed: vivaretha āvikareyya yathādhammam paṭikareyya evanti vivaraṇena yathādhammam paṭipattiyā
translated: he should not follow it but should open up, reveal, and confess it according to the rule. ‘Thus’ is in the sense of practice according to the rule by revealing.

original: Tanti taṃ channaṃ duccaritaṃ. Nātivassati āpattivassaṃ kilesavassañca na vassati,
analyzed: tanti tam channam duccaritam na ativassati āpatti vassam kilesa vassam ca na vassati
translated: ‘That’: that concealed misconduct. He does not rain down, he does not rain down the rain of offences and the rain of defilements.

original: suddhante puggalaṃ patiṭṭhapetīti attho.
analyzed: suddhante puggalam patiṭṭhapeti iti atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he establishes the person in purity.

original: Idāni “ekaṃsena sīghaṃyeva ca attā sodhetabbo, appamādo kātabbo”ti tassa kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: idāni ekaṃsena sīghaṃyā iva ca attā sodhetabbaḥ appamādaḥ kātabbaḥ ti tassa kāraṇam
translated: Now, the reason why ‘he should purify himself quickly and all at once and should be heedful’

original: saṃvegavatthuṃ dassento “maccunābbhāhato loko”tiādimāha. Tattha maccunābbhāhato lokoti
analyzed: saṃvega vatthum dassentaḥ maccunā abbhāhataḥ loka uti ādim āha tattha maccunā abbhāhataḥ loka uti
translated: is shown by the verse beginning, ‘The world is smitten by the King of Death’ . Herein, the world is smitten by the King of Death:

original: ayaṃ sabbopi sattaloko coro viya coraghātakena, sabbavaṭṭanipātinā maccunā maraṇena
analyzed: ayam sabbaḥ api satta lokaḥ coraḥ viya cora ghātakena sabba vaṭṭa nipātinā maccunā maraṇena
translated: this whole world of beings is smitten by the King of Death, who is like a robber and who brings about all the kinds of misfortune in the round of rebirths,

original: abhihato, na tassa hatthato muccati. Jarāya parivāritoti ayaṃ loko uppādato uddhaṃ
analyzed: abhihato na tassa hatthataḥ muccati jarāya parivāritaḥ ti ayam lokaḥ uppādataḥ uddham
translated: and it does not escape from his hand. It is surrounded by ageing:

original: maraṇūpanayanarasāya jarāya parivārito ajjhotthaṭo, jarāsaṅghātaparimukkoti attho.🔽Taṇhāsallena otiṇṇoti sarīrassa anto nimuggena visapītakhurappena viya upādānalakkhaṇena
analyzed: maraṇa upanayana rasāya jarāya parivāritaḥ ajjhotthaṭaḥ jarā saṅghāta parimukkaḥ ti attho  taṇhā sallena otiṇṇoti sarīrassa antar nimuggena visa pīta khurappena viya upādāna lakkhaṇena
translated: He is surrounded, hemmed in by aging that brings death, the meaning is, by the aging that is the forerunner of death.

original: taṇhāsaṅkhātena sallena otiṇṇo hadayabbhantare ogāḷho. Taṇhā hi pīḷājananato anto
analyzed: taṇhā saṅkhātena sallena otiṇṇaḥ hadaya bbhantare ogāḷhaḥ taṇhā hi pīḷā jananataḥ antaḥ
translated: He is pierced by the dart of craving: by the dart consisting of craving, which has the characteristic of grasping,🔽he is pierced, plunged, in the heart, as if pierced by a poisoned shaft. For craving is called a “dart” because it afflicts,

original: tudanato duruddhārato ca “sallo”ti vuccati. Icchādhūpāyitoti ārammaṇābhipatthanalakkhaṇāya🔽icchāya santāpito. Taṃ visayaṃ icchanto hi puggalo yadicchitaṃ visayaṃ labhanto vā
analyzed: tudanataḥ duruddhārataḥ ca sallo ti vuccati icchā dhūpāyito ti ārammaṇa abhipatthana lakkhaṇāya  icchāya tam visayam icchantaḥ hi puggalaḥ yad icchitam visayam labhantaḥ vā
translated: because it penetrates inside, and because it is hard to get out.🔽He is inflamed by the smoke of desire: he is heated by desire, which has the characteristic of longing for an object.🔽For when a person longs for a particular object, whether he gets it or not, he is heated, overwhelmed by the mere occurrence of the desire that has the characteristic of unsatiatedness.

original: alabhanto vā tāya eva anudahanalakkhaṇāya icchāya santatto pariḷāhappatto hoti. Sadāti
analyzed: a labhantaḥ vā tāya eva anudahana lakkhaṇāya icchāya santattaḥ pariḷāha ppatto hoti sadā ati
translated: He is constantly

original: sabbakālaṃ, idañca padaṃ sabbapadesu yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: sabbakālam idam ca padam sabba padesu yojetabbam
translated: This phrase should be construed with all the preceding phrases.

original: Parikkhitto jarāya cāti na kevalaṃ maccunā abbhāhatoyeva, atha kho jarāya ca parikkhitto.
analyzed: parikkhittaḥ jarāya ca ati na kevalam maccunā abbhāhataḥ yā iva atha kho jarāya ca parikkhittaḥ
translated: He is hemmed in by aging and death: not only is he struck down by death, but he is also hemmed in by aging.

original: Jarāya samavaruddho jarāpākāraparikkhitto, na taṃ samatikkamatīti attho. Haññati
analyzed: jarāya samavaruddhaḥ jarā pākāra parikkhittaḥ na tam samatikkamati iti atthaḥ haññati
translated: “He does not get beyond aging” means that he is completely surrounded by aging, completely hemmed in by aging, he does not get beyond it.

original: niccamattāṇoti atāṇo asaraṇo hutvā niccakālaṃ jarāmaraṇehi haññati vibādhīyati. Yathā
analyzed: nicca mattāṇo ti a tāṇaḥ a saraṇaḥ hutvā nicca kālam jarā maraṇehi haññati vibādhīyati yathā
translated: “He is always being killed” means that he is killed, he is harmed, by aging and death, always, without a protector, without a refuge.

original: kiṃ? Pattadaṇḍova takkaro yathā takkaro coro katāparādho vajjhappatto atāṇo rājāṇāya
analyzed: kim patta daṇḍaḥ uva takkaraḥ yathā takkaraḥ coraḥ kata aparādhaḥ vajjha ppattaḥ a tāṇaḥ rājāṇāya
translated: “Like a criminal sentenced to death” means that just as a criminal who has committed a crime, who has been sentenced to death, who is without a protector, without a refuge, is killed by the king’s men,

original: haññati, evamayaṃ loko jarāmaraṇehīti dasseti.
analyzed: haññati evam ayam lokaḥ jarā maraṇehi iti dasseti
translated: so this world is by aging and death.

original: Āgacchantaggikhandhāvāti mahāvane ḍayhamāne taṃ abhibhavantā mahantā aggikkhandhā
analyzed: āgacchanta aggi khandhā avāti mahā vane ḍayhamāne tam abhibhavantā mahantau aggi khandhā
translated: “With the mass of fire approaching” means that just as in a great forest that is burning, the great mass of fire,

original: viya maccu byādhi jarāti ime tayo anudahanaṭṭhena aggikkhandhā imaṃ sattalokaṃ abhibhavantā🔽āgacchanti, tesaṃ pana paṭibalo hutvā paccuggantuṃ abhibhavituṃ balaṃ ussāho natthi,
analyzed: ime tayaḥ anudahana ṭṭhena aggi khandhāḥ imam satta lokam abhibhavantā  āgacchanti tesam pana paṭibalaḥ hutvā paccuggantum abhibhavitum balam ussāhaḥ natthi
translated: overwhelming it, approaches, so too Death, Disease, and Aging, as masses of fire, overwhelm this world of beings and approach.🔽But there is no power, no strength, no effort to overcome them,

original: imassa lokassa, javo natthi palāyituṃ javantesu, ajjhottharantesu. Yattha te nābhibhavanti,
analyzed: imassa lokassa javaḥ natthi palāyitum javantesu ajjhottharantesu yattha te na abhibhavanti
translated: to escape from this world, to run away, to those who are swift,🔽while they are overwhelming it.

original: piṭṭhiṃ dassetvā tato palāyitumpi imassa lokassa jaṅghājavo natthi, evaṃ attanā asamattho
analyzed: piṭṭhim dassetvā tatas palāyitum pi imassa lokassa jaṅghā javaḥ na atthi evam attanā asamatthaḥ
translated: and if he were to run away, there is no speed in his legs to get away from this world.

original: māyādīhi upāyehi appaṭikāre tividhe balavati paccāmitte niccupaṭṭhite kiṃ kātabbanti
analyzed: māyā ādīhi upāyehi appaṭikāre tividhe balavati pacca amitte nicca upaṭṭhite kim kātabbanti
translated: So what is to be done when the three kinds of powerful enemies, which cannot be warded off by any means such as magic, etc., are constantly on the watch?🔽One should make the day fruitful, even with a mere handful,

original: ce? Amoghaṃ divasaṃ kayirā, appena bahukena vāti appena antamaso gaddūhanamattampi
analyzed: ce amogham divasam kayirāḥ appena bahukena vāti appena antamasaḥ
translated: even with a mere handful of work, with the mere tip of a hair,

original: kālaṃ pavattitena bahukena vā sakalaṃ ahorattaṃ pavattitena vipassanāmanasikārena🔽amoghaṃ avañjhaṃ divasaṃ kareyya, yasmā yaṃ yaṃ vijahate rattiṃ, tadūnaṃ tassa jīvitaṃ
analyzed: kālam pavattitena bahukena vā sakalam ahorattam pavattitena vipassanā manasikārena  amogham a vañjham divasam kareyya yasmai yam yam vijahate rattim tad ūnam tassa jīvitam
translated: or with the whole day and night’s work, by the attention given to insight.🔽For the life of a being is diminished by each night that passes,

original: ayaṃ satto yaṃ yaṃ rattiṃ vijahati nāseti khepeti, tadūnaṃ tena ūnaṃ tassa sattassa
analyzed: ayam sattaḥ yam yam rattim vijahati nāseti khepeti tat ūnam tena ūnam tassa sattassa
translated: by each night that passes, that is, that is used up, wasted, or spent, the life of that being is diminished.

original: jīvitaṃ hoti. Etena rattikkhayo nāma jīvitakkhayo tassa anivattanatoti dasseti. Tenāha –
analyzed: jīvitam hoti etena ratti kkhayaḥ nāma jīvita kkhayo tassa a nivattanato ti dasseti tena āha
translated: This shows that the passing of the night is the passing of life, since it does not return. Hence it is said:

original: “Yamekarattiṃ paṭhamaṃ, gabbhe vasati māṇavo;
analyzed: yam eka rattim paṭhamam gabbhe vasati māṇavaḥ
translated: “The moment the child is born Into the mother’s womb,

original: Abbhuṭṭhitova so yāti, sa gacchaṃ na nivattatī”ti. ;
analyzed: abbhuṭṭhitaḥ uva saḥ yāti sa gaccham na nivattati iti
translated: It starts to grow older and die; It goes, but never turns again.”

original: Na kevalaṃ rattivaseneva, atha kho iriyāpathavasenāpi jīvitakkhayo upadhāretabboti🔽āha “carato”tiādi. Caratoti gacchantassa. Tiṭṭhatoti ṭhitaṃ kappentassa. Āsīnasayanassa
analyzed: na kevalam ratti vasena iva atha kho iriyāpatha vasena api jīvita kkhayaḥ upadhāretabbo ti  āha carato tiādi caratoti gacchantassa tiṭṭhatoti ṭhitam kappentassa āsīna sayanassa
translated: Not only by the night, but also by the posture, should the end of life be reflected upon.

original: vāti āsīnassa sayanassa vā, nisinnassa nipajjantassa vāti attho. “Āsīdana”ntipi paṭhanti,🔽tattha sāmiatthe upayogavacanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Upeti carimā rattīti carimakacittasahitā
analyzed: vā ati āsīnassa sayanassa vā nisinnassa nipajjantassa vā ati atthaḥ āsīdana nti pi paṭhanti  tattha sāmi atthe upayoga vacanam daṭṭhabbam upeti carimā rattī iti carimaka citta sahitā
translated: Hence he said ‘while walking’ and so on. While walking: while going. Standing: while standing, relieving nature. Sitting: while sitting, lying: while lying, or while sitting, falling asleep: this is the meaning. ‘Āsīdana’ is also read.

original: ratti upagacchati, rattiggahaṇañcettha desanāsīsamattaṃ. Gamanādīsu yena kenaci iriyāpathena🔽samaṅgībhūtassa carimakāloyeva, tenevassa iriyāpathakkhaṇā jīvitaṃ khepetvā eva gacchanti,🔽tasmā na te kālo pamajjituṃ nāyaṃ tuyhaṃ pamādaṃ āpajjituṃ kālo “imasmiṃ nāma kāle
analyzed: ratti upagacchati ratti ggahaṇam ca ittha desanā sīsa mattam gamana ādīsu yena kenaci iriyāpathena  samaṅgībhūtassa carima kāloya iva tena iva ssa iriyāpatha khaṇāḥ jīvitam khepetvā eva gacchanti  tasmā na te kālaḥ pamajjitum na ayam pamādam āpajjitum kālaḥ imasmin nāma kāle
translated: Here the word ‘upeti’ should be taken as a gerund. The last night is approaching: the night together with the last consciousness is approaching. The mention of the night is only by way of a simile. In going and so on, when one is endowed with any posture whatsoever,

original: maraṇaṃ na hotī”ti aviditattā. Vuttaṃ hi –
analyzed: maraṇam na hoti iti a vidita ttā vuttam hi
translated: the end of life goes away even in the last moment. Therefore, this is not the time for you to be negligent. This is not the time for you to fall into negligence, thinking ‘death will not come at this time’ because it is unknown. For this is said:

original: “Animittamanaññātaṃ, maccānaṃ idha jīvitaṃ;
analyzed: animittam an aññātam maccānam idha jīvitam
translated: ‘The life of mortals here is signless and unknown,

original: Kasirañca parittañca, tañca dukkhena saṃyuta”nti. ;
analyzed: kasirañca parittañca tañca dukkhena saṃyutanti
translated: and the narrow and the small, and all are joined with pain.

original: Tasmā evaṃ attānaṃ ovaditvā appamattena tīsu sikkhāsu anuyogo kātabboti adhippāyo.
analyzed: tasmai evam attānam ovaditvā appamattena tīsu sikkhāsu anuyogaḥ kātabbaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: So, having thus admonished himself, he should apply himself to the three trainings with diligence. This is the purport.

original: Sirimaṇḍattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sirimaṇḍa thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Sirimanda is finished.

original: 14. Sabbakāmittheragāthāvaṇṇanā🔽Dvipādakotiādikā āyasmato sabbakāmittherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayaṃ kira padumuttarassa
analyzed: sabba kāmitthera gāthā vaṇṇanā  dvipādaka uti ādikā āyasmataḥ sabbakāma therassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam kira padumuttarassa
translated: Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Sabbakami🔽The verse beginning with “Two-footed” is that of the Elder Sabbakami. What is the origin of it? It seems that he saw an elder who had arisen in the Dispensation of the Blessed One Padumuttara,

original: bhagavato sāsane uppannaṃ abbudaṃ sodhetvā paṭipākatikaṃ ṭhapentaṃ ekaṃ theraṃ disvā,
analyzed: bhagavataḥ sāsane uppannam abbudam sodhetvā paṭipāka tikam ṭhapentam ekam theram disvā
translated: and who was removing the abscesses and establishing the remainder in the path.

original: “ahampi anāgate ekassa buddhassa sāsane abbudaṃ sodhetvā paṭipākatikaṃ ṭhapetuṃ samattho
analyzed: aham pi anāgate ekassa buddhassa sāsane abbudam sodhetvā paṭipāka tikam ṭhapetum samatthaḥ
translated: “May I too in the future be able to remove the abscesses and establish the remainder in the path in the Dispensation of a Buddha,”

original: bhaveyya”nti patthanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā tadanurūpāni puññāni katvā devamanussesu saṃsaranto
analyzed: bhaveyyanti patthanam paṭṭhapetvā tad anurūpāni puññāni katvā deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ
translated: and he made the aspiration and performed the corresponding meritorious deeds. Transmigrating among gods and humans,

original: imasmiṃ buddhuppāde aparinibbute eva bhagavati vesāliyaṃ khattiyakule nibbattitvā
analyzed: imasmin buddhuppāde a parinibbute eva bhagavati vesāliyam khattiya kule nibbattitvā
translated: at the time of the present Buddha, even before the Blessed One attained enlightenment, he was reborn in a noble family in Vesali.

original: sabbakāmoti laddhanāmo vayappatto ñātakehi dārapariggahaṃ kārito nissaraṇajjhāsayatāya
analyzed: sabbakāmo ti laddha nāmaḥ vaya ppattaḥ ñātakehi dāra pariggaham kāritaḥ nissaraṇa jhāsaya tāya
translated: He was called Sabbakāma. When he reached the age of maturity, he was married by his relatives.

original: gharāvāsaṃ jigucchanto dhammabhaṇḍāgārikassa santike pabbajitvā samaṇadhammaṃ karonto
analyzed: ghara āvāsam jigucchantaḥ dhammabhaṇḍāgārikassa santike pabbajitvā samaṇa dhammam karontaḥ
translated: But because he was inclined to renunciation, he went forth into homelessness in the presence of the Elder Dhammabhaṇḍāgārika.

original: upajjhāyena saddhiṃ vesāliṃ upagato ñātigharaṃ agamāsi. Tattha naṃ purāṇadutiyikā
analyzed: upajjhāyena saddhim vesālim upagataḥ ñāti gharam agamāsi tattha nam purāṇadutiyikā
translated: He went to Vesālī with his preceptor and then went to the house of his relatives. There his former wife,

original: pativiyogadukkhitā kisā dubbaṇṇā analaṅkatā kiliṭṭhavatthanivasanā vanditvā rodamānā
analyzed: pati viyoga dukkhitā kisā dubbaṇṇā analaṅkatā kiliṭṭha vattha nivasanā vanditvā rodamānā
translated: who was afflicted with the sorrow of separation, thin, pale, unadorned, and dirty, paid homage to him and stood weeping at one side.

original: ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Taṃ disvā therassa karuṇāpurassaraṃ mettaṃ upaṭṭhāpayato anubhūtārammaṇe
analyzed: ekamantam aṭṭhāsi tam disvā therassa karuṇā purassaram mettam upaṭṭhāpayataḥ anubhūta ārammaṇe
translated: When the elder saw her, he aroused loving-kindness towards her out of compassion.🔽But as he was reflecting on the object of his meditation, lust arose in him suddenly because of improper attention.🔽He was as if struck by a poisoned dart. He was overcome with remorse. He went to the charnel ground and

original: ayonisomanasikāravasena sahasā kileso uppajji.
analyzed: ayonisoma nasikāra vasena sahasā kilesaḥ uppajji
translated: took up the meditation subject of foulness.

original: So tena kasāhi tāḷito ājānīyo viya sañjātasaṃvego tāvadeva susānaṃ gantvā, asubhanimittaṃ🔽uggahetvā, tattha paṭiladdhajhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā, vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā, arahattaṃ
analyzed: saḥ tena tāḷitaḥ ājānīyaḥ viya sañjāta saṃvegaḥ tāvat eva su sānam gantvā asubha nimittam 🔽uggahetvā tattha paṭiladdha jhānam pādakam katvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam
translated: He developed the jhāna he had already acquired there as a basis and, increasing his insight, he reached Arahantship.

original: pāpuṇi. Athassa sasuro alaṅkatapaṭiyattaṃ dhītaraṃ ādāya mahatā parivārena naṃ uppabbājetukāmo
analyzed: pāpuṇi athassa sa suraḥ alaṅkata paṭiyattam dhītaram ādāya mahatā parivārena nam uppabbājetu kāmo
translated: and he became a monk. Then his father-in-law, wishing to give his daughter away in marriage,🔽went to the monastery with her, all decked out in finery, and with a great retinue.🔽The Elder, knowing her intention,

original: vihāraṃ agamāsi. Thero tassā adhippāyaṃ ñatvā attano kāmesu virattabhāvaṃ sabbattha
analyzed: vihāram thero tassāḥ adhippāyam ñatvā attano kāmesu viratta bhāvam sabbattha
translated: and his own freedom from passion, and his unattachedness in all things,

original: ca anupalittataṃ pakāsento –
analyzed: ca pakāsentaḥ
translated: said:

original: “Dvipādakoyaṃ asuci, duggandho parihīrati;
analyzed: asuci duggandhaḥ
translated: “This body with its two feet, impure, stinking,

original: Nānākuṇapaparipūro, vissavanto tato tato.
analyzed: nānā kuṇapa paripūraḥ vissavanto tatas tatas
translated: is filled with various kinds of filth, oozing here and there.

original: “Migaṃ nilīnaṃ kūṭena, baḷiseneva ambujaṃ;
analyzed: migam nilīnam kūṭena baḷisena iva ambujam
translated: “Like a deer caught in a snare, like a lotus in the mud,

original: Vānaraṃ viya lepena, bādhayanti puthujjanaṃ.🔽“Rūpā saddā rasā gandhā, phoṭṭhabbā ca manoramā;
analyzed: vānaram viya lepena bādhayanti puthujjanam  rūpā saddā rasā gandhā phoṭṭhabbā ca manoramā
translated: like a monkey stuck in the tar, the worldling is caught by the five strands of sense pleasure.🔽“Forms, sounds, tastes, smells, and tangibles, these five strands of sense pleasure,

original: Pañca kāmaguṇā ete, itthirūpasmi dissare.
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇāḥ ete dissare
translated: are to be found in the form of a woman.

original: “Ye etā upasevanti, rattacittā puthujjanā;
analyzed: ye etāḥ upasevanti ratta cittā puthujjanā
translated: “Those who, with lustful minds, approach her, the worldlings,

original: Vaḍḍhenti kaṭasiṃ ghoraṃ, ācinanti punabbhavaṃ.
analyzed: vaḍḍhenti kaṭasim ghoram ācinanti punarbhavam
translated: increase the terrible mass of suffering, and accumulate rebirth.

original: “Yo cetā parivajjeti, sappasseva padā siro;
analyzed: yaḥ cetā parivajjeti sappassa iva padā siraḥ
translated: “But he who avoids her, as one would the foot of a snake,

original: Somaṃ visattikaṃ loke, sato samativattati.
analyzed: somam visattikam loke sataḥ samativattati
translated: the wise one, with mindfulness, passes over the world’s delight.

original: “Kāmesvādīnavaṃ disvā, nekkhammaṃ daṭṭhu khemato;
analyzed: kāmesu ādīnavam disvā nekkhammam daṭṭhu khemataḥ
translated: “Seeing the danger in sense pleasures, and seeing the peace of renunciation,

original: Nissaṭo sabbakāmehi, patto me āsavakkhayo”ti. –
analyzed: nissaṭaḥ sabba kāmehi pattaḥ me āsava kkhayaḥ ti
translated: He has renounced all sensual desires, And I have reached the destruction of the taints.

original: Imā gāthā abhāsi.
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: He uttered these stanzas.

original: Tattha dvipādakoti yadipi apādakādayopi kāyā asucīyeva, adhikāravasena pana ukkaṭṭhaparicchedena🔽vā evaṃ vuttaṃ. Yasmā vā aññe asucibhūtāpi kāyā loṇambilādīhi abhisaṅkharitvā manussānaṃ
analyzed: tattha dvipādako ti yadi api apādaka ādayaḥ api kāyāḥ adhikāra vasena pana ukkaṭṭha paricchedena  vā evam vuttam yasmai vā aññe asuci bhūtāḥ api kāyāḥ loṇambila ādīhi abhisaṅkharitvā manussānam
translated: Herein, though the bodies of the legless and so on are impure too, still he said “two-footed” by way of what is more obvious,

original: bhojanepi upanīyanti, na pana manussakāyo, tasmā asucitarasabhāvamassa dassento “dvipādako”ti
analyzed: bhojane pi upanīyanti na pana manussa kāyaḥ tasmai a sucita rasa bhāvam assa dassentaḥ dvipādakaḥ ti
translated: or by way of the most obvious part. Or alternatively, though other impure bodies are brought to people’s mouths by being prepared with salt, oil, etc., still the human body is not, so he said “two-footed” to show that its nature is that of an impure thing.

original: āha. Ayanti tadā upaṭṭhitaṃ itthirūpaṃ sandhāyāha. Asucīti asuci eva, na ettha kiñcipi
analyzed: āha tadā upaṭṭhitam itthi rūpam sandhāya āha asuci iti asuci eva na ettha kiñcipi
translated: “Here” : he said this referring to the woman’s form that appeared. “Impure” : it is just impure, there is nothing pure in it at all, is the meaning.

original: sucīti attho. Duggandho parihīratīti duggandho samāno pupphagandhādīhi saṅkharitvā
analyzed: suci iti atthaḥ duggandho parihīrati iti duggandho samānaḥ puppha gandha ādīhi saṅkharitvā
translated: “Smelly, disgusting” : being smelly, it is carried about by being prepared with flowers, scents, etc.

original: pariharīyati. Nānākuṇapaparipūroti kesādianekappakārakuṇapabharito. Vissavanto tato
analyzed: pariharīyati kesa ādi aneka ppakāra kuṇapa bharitaḥ vissavantaḥ tatas
translated: “Filled with various kinds of ordure” : filled with various kinds of ordure such as head hairs, body hairs, etc.

original: tatoti pupphagandhādīhissa jegucchabhāvaṃ paṭicchādetuṃ vāyamantānampi taṃ vāyāmaṃ
analyzed: tatas ti puppha gandha ādīhissa jeguccha bhāvam paṭicchādetum tam
translated: “From here and there” : though they try to conceal its repulsiveness with flowers, scents, etc., still it oozes here and there

original: nipphalaṃ katvā navahi dvārehi kheḷasiṅghāṇikādīni lomakūpehi ca sedajallikaṃ ‘vissavantoyeva
analyzed: nipphalam katvā navahi dvārehi kheḷa siṅghāṇika ādīni lomakūpehi ca seda jallikam
translated: and through the nine orifices, such as the mouth, nose, etc., he lets out spittle, mucus, and so on, and through the pores of his body he lets out sweat and dirt.

original: parihīratī’ti sambandho.
analyzed: parihīrati iti sambandhaḥ
translated: He is constantly leaking.

original: Evaṃ jegucchopi samāno cāyaṃ kāyo kūṭādīhi viya migādike attano rūpādīhi andhaputhujjane
analyzed: evam jegucchaḥ api samānaḥ ca ayam kāyaḥ kūṭa ādīhi viya miga ādike rūpa ādīhi andha puthujjane
translated: Although this body is so disgusting, it deceives the ordinary people, the blind, with its form, etc., as a magician deceives people with tricks, etc.

original: vañcetiyevāti dassento “miga”ntiādimāha. Tattha migaṃ nilīnaṃ kūṭenāti pāsavākarādinā🔽kūṭena nilīnaṃ, paṭicchannaṃ katvā migaṃ viya nesādo. Vakkhamāno hi iva-saddo idhāpi
analyzed: vañca itiyā iva ati dassentaḥ miga nti ādim āha tattha migam nilīnam kūṭena ati pāsava ākara ādinā  kūṭena nilīnam paṭicchannam katvā migam viya nesādaḥ vakkhamānaḥ hi iva saddaḥ idha api
translated: Showing this, the Master said, “Like a hunter with a deer,” etc. Herein, “with a deer lying in wait with a trick” means with a snare, a trap, etc.

original: ānetvā yojetabbo. Baḷiseneva ambujanti ambujaṃ macchaṃ āmisabaddhena baḷisena viya🔽bāḷisiko. Vānaraṃ viya lepenāti rukkhasilādīsu pakkhittena makkaṭalepena makkaṭaṃ
analyzed: ānetvā yojetabbaḥ baḷisena iva ambujanti ambujam maccham āmisa baddhena baḷisena viya  bāḷisikaḥ vānaram viya lepena ati rukkha silā ādīsu pakkhittena makkaṭa lepena makkaṭam
translated: Like a hunter who, having hidden himself, lies in wait for a deer, so too the Master of the House, the Master of the World, the King of Death, lies in wait for the ordinary people, the blind, with the five aggregates as objects of clinging.🔽The word “like” should be brought in here also.🔽“Like a fisherman with a fish,” means like a fisherman with a fish caught on a hook baited with food.

original: viya migaluddo andhaputhujjanaṃ vañcento bādhentīti.
analyzed: viya miga luddaḥ andha puthujjanam vañcentaḥ bādhenti iti
translated: “Like a monkey with a lump of meat,” means like a monkey hunter who, having smeared a lump of meat with glue, lies in wait for a monkey in the forest glades.🔽So too the Master of the House, the Master of the World, the King of Death, lies in wait for the ordinary people, the blind, with the five aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: Ke pana bādhentīti āha. “Rūpā saddā”tiādi. Rūpādayo hi pañca kāmakoṭṭhāsā visesato
analyzed: ke pana bādhenti iti āha rūpa saddāti ādi rūpa ādayaḥ hi pañca kāma koṭṭhāsāḥ visesato
translated: But who are they that lie in wait? The Master said, “With forms, sounds,” etc. The five cords of sense desire, namely, forms, sounds, odors, tastes, and touches, are the bait.

original: visabhāgavatthusannissayā vipallāsūpanissayena ayonisomanasikārena parikkhittānaṃ
analyzed: visa bhāga vatthu sannissayāḥ vipallāsu upanissayena a yoniso manasikārena parikkhittānam
translated: They are called “hindrances” because they hinder the minds of ordinary people who are surrounded by wrong reflection, which is the proximate cause of the perversions, and which has as its support the objects of the opposite kind.

original: andhaputhujjanānaṃ mano ramento kilesavatthutāya anatthāvahabhāvato te bādhenti nāma.
analyzed: andha puthujjanānam manaḥ ramentaḥ kilesa vatthu tāya anattha āvaha bhāvataḥ te bādhenti nāma
translated: They hinder by being unprofitable and by being the basis for defilements.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “rūpā saddā…pe… itthirūpasmi dissare”ti.
