translated: “You are young, gone forth” means that when you went forth you were young, you went forth as a youth, a mere boy.

original: pabbajantena sattame dasake sampatteva pabbajitabbanti dasseti. Tiṭṭhāhi mama sāsaneti mama vacane tiṭṭha.
analyzed: pabbajantena sattame dasake sampattā iva pabbajitabbanti dasseti tiṭṭhāhi mama sāsane iti mama vacane tiṭṭha
translated: “Stay in my Dispensation” means stay in my words.

original: Kiṃ pana tanti āha “bhuñja mānusake kāme”ti kāme paribhuñjitukāmassa rūpasampatti,
analyzed: kim pana tanti āha bhuñja mānusake kāma iti kāme paribhuñjitu kāmassa rūpa sampatti
translated: But what is that? He said: “Enjoy human sensual pleasures.” One who wishes to enjoy sensual pleasures should wish for the perfection of beauty,

original: vayasampatti, parivārasampatti, bhogasampatti ca icchitabbā. Tattha “kuto me bhogasampattī”ti
analyzed: vaya sampatti parivāra sampatti bhoga sampatti ca icchitabbā tattha kutas me bhoga sampatti iti
translated: the perfection of youth, the perfection of retinue, and the perfection of wealth. There, if he were to say: “How can I have the perfection of wealth?”

original: vadeyyāti, āha “ahaṃ vittaṃ dadāmi te”ti. “Tayidaṃ vacanaṃ kathaṃ saddahātabba”nti
analyzed: vadeyya iti āha aham vittam dadāmi te iti tayā idam vacanam katham saddahātabbanti
translated: he said: “I will give you wealth.” “How can this statement be believed?”

original: maññeyyāti taṃ saddahāpentī āha “saccaṃ te paṭijānāmi, aggiṃ vā te harāmaha”nti.🔽“Bhuñja mānusake kāme, ahaṃ vittaṃ dadāmi te”ti yadidaṃ mayā paṭiññātaṃ, taṃ ekaṃsena
analyzed: maññeyya iti tam saddahāpentī āha saccam te paṭijānāmi aggim vā te harāmahanti  bhuñja mānusake kāme aham vittam dadāmi te iti yat idam mayā paṭiññātam tam ekaṃsena
translated: “I’ll believe you” means that she said, “I admit it’s true. I’ll either carry off your fire or I’ll carry off your wealth.”🔽“Enjoy human pleasures. I’ll give you wealth” means that what I admitted is true. If you don’t believe me,

original: saccameva paṭijānāmi, sace me na pattiyāyasi, aggiṃ vā te harāmahaṃ aggiṃ haritvā
analyzed: saccam eva paṭijānāmi sace me na pattiyāyasi aggim vā te harām aham aggim haritvā
translated: I’ll carry off your fire. Having carried off the fire,🔽I make an oath with the fire as a condition. The meaning is that we both have a stake in the matter.

original: aggipaccayaṃ sapathaṃ karomīti attho. Ubhayattha kaṭaggahoti amhākaṃ ubhinnaṃ jiṇṇakāle
analyzed: aggi paccayam sa patham karomi iti atthaḥ ubhayattha amhākam ubhinnam jiṇṇa kāle
translated: “We both have a stake in the matter” means that we both have a stake in the matter of going forth when we are old.

original: pabbajjanaṃ ubhayattha jayaggāho. Yaṃ mayaṃ yāva daṇḍaparāyanakālā bhoge bhuñjāma,
analyzed: pabbajjanam ubhayattha jaya ggāhaḥ yam mayam yāva daṇḍa parāyana kālāḥ bhoge bhuñjāma
translated: As long as we enjoy wealth until the time of our death,

original: evaṃ idhalokepi bhogehi na jīyāma, mayaṃ pacchā pabbajissāma, evaṃ paralokepi bhogehi🔽na jīyāmāti adhippāyo. Tatoti taṃ nimittaṃ, kāmehi nimantentiyā “yuvāsi tva”ntiādinā
analyzed: evam idha loke pi bhogehi na jīyāma mayam pacchā pabbajissāma evam para loke pi bhogehi  na jīyāma ati adhippāyo tatoti tam nimittam kāmehi yuvā asi tvanti ādinā
translated: we won’t be defeated in this world by wealth. Later we will go forth. In this way we won’t be defeated in the world beyond by wealth.🔽This is the intention. “From that” means from that sign. “You are young” and so on

original: “yadā jiṇṇā bhavissāmā”tiādinā ca tassā vesiyā vuttavacanahetu. Tañhi vacanaṃ aṅkusaṃ
analyzed: yadā jiṇṇāḥ bhavissāma ati ādinā ca tassāḥ vesiyāḥ vutta vacana hetu tañhi vacanam aṅkusam
translated: is what the prostitute said, “When we are old” and so on. That statement is a goad.

original: katvā thero samaṇadhammaṃ karonto sadatthaṃ paripūresi. Sesaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayameva.
analyzed: katvā thero samaṇa dhammam karontaḥ sadattham paripūresi sesam heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva
translated: and the Elder, performing the duties of a recluse, fulfilled his own welfare. The rest is as already told.

original: Sundarasamuddattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sundara samudda tthera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Sundarasamudda is finished.

original: 2. Lakuṇḍakabhaddiyattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: lakuṇḍaka bhaddiya tthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Lakuṇṭakabhaddiya

original: Pare ambāṭakārāmetiādikā āyasmato lakuṇḍakabhaddiyattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayaṃ
analyzed: pare ambāṭaka ārāma iti ādikā āyasmataḥ lakuṇḍakabhaddiya therassa gāthā kā uppatti ayaṃ
translated: “The others, the mango-tree, the banyan-tree” , etc., are the verses of the Elder Lakuṇṭakabhaddiya. How did their origin come about?

original: kira padumuttarassa bhagavato kāle haṃsavatīnagare mahābhoge kule nibbattitvā, vayappatto🔽satthu santike dhammaṃ suṇanto nisinno tasmiṃ khaṇe satthāraṃ ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ mañjussarānaṃ
analyzed: kira padumuttarassa bhagavataḥ kāle haṃsavatī nagare mahā bhoge kule nibbattitvā vaya ppatto  satthu santike dhammam suṇantaḥ nisinnaḥ tasmin khaṇe satthāram ekam bhikkhum mañjussarānam
translated: This Elder, it seems, was reborn in a family of great wealth in the city of Haṃsavatī in the dispensation of the Lord Padumuttara. When he grew up

original: aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapentaṃ disvā, sayampi taṃ ṭhānaṃ patthento buddhappamukhassa bhikkhusaṅghassa🔽mahādānaṃ datvā, “aho vatāhampi anāgate ayaṃ bhikkhu viya ekassa buddhassa sāsane
analyzed: agga ṭṭhāne ṭhapentam disvā sayam pi tam ṭhānam patthentaḥ buddha ppamukhassa bhikkhu saṅghassa  mahādānam da tvā aho vata aham pi anāgate ayam bhikkhu viya ekassa buddhassa sāsane
translated: he sat listening to the Dhamma in the presence of the Teacher. At that moment he saw the Teacher placing a certain bhikkhu in the foremost position among those who have a good memory.

original: mañjussarānaṃ aggo bhaveyya”nti paṇidhānaṃ akāsi. Bhagavā ca tassa anantarāyataṃ
analyzed: mañjussarānam aggaḥ bhaveyyanti paṇidhānam akāsi bhagavā ca tassa
translated: He himself made a vow, saying, “Oh that in the future I might become in the dispensation of a certain Buddha the foremost of those who have a good memory, just as this bhikkhu is in the dispensation of this Buddha.” The Lord Buddha Padumuttara🔽saw that he would be reborn in a womb seven times and that he would then attain Nibbāna.

original: disvā byākaritvā pakkāmi.
analyzed: disvā byākaritvā pakkāmi
translated: and after he had seen the Teacher and had received his answer, he departed.

original: So tattha yāvajīvaṃ puññāni katvā devamanussesu saṃsaranto phussassa bhagavato kāle
analyzed: so tattha yāvajīvam puññāni katvā deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ phussassa bhagavato kāle
translated: After he had lived there the remainder of his life, performing works of merit, and had passed from that existence, he was reborn in the World of the Gods and in the World of Men, and finally in the time of the Buddha Phussa he was reborn as a parrot.

original: cittapattakokilo hutvā rājuyyānato madhuraṃ ambaphalaṃ tuṇḍenādāya gacchanto satthāraṃ
analyzed: cittapatta kokilaḥ hutvā rāja uyyānataḥ madhuram amba phalam tuṇḍena ādāya gacchantaḥ satthāram
translated: One day, as he was going through the royal gardens, he saw a mango fruit, and taking it in his beak, he started off. But as he was going along, he saw the Teacher.

original: disvā pasannamānaso “dassāmī”ti cittaṃ uppādesi. Satthā tassa cittaṃ ñatvā pattaṃ
analyzed: disvā pasanna mānasaḥ dassāmi iti cittam uppādesi satthā tassa cittam ñatvā pattaṃ
translated: Straightway he conceived the thought, “I will give him the mango.” The Teacher, knowing what was in his mind, took his bowl,

original: gahetvā nisīdi. Kokilo dasabalassa patte ambapakkaṃ patiṭṭhāpesi. Satthā taṃ paribhuñji.
analyzed: gahetvā nisīdi kokilaḥ dasabalassa patte amba pakkam patiṭṭhāpesi satthā tam paribhuñji
translated: and sat down. The parrot placed the mango in the bowl of the Ten-Powered One. The Teacher ate the mango.

original: So kokilo pasannamānaso teneva pītisukhena sattāhaṃ vītināmesi. Tena ca puññakammena
analyzed: so kokilaḥ pasanna mānasaḥ tena iva pīti sukhena sattāham vītināmesi tena ca puñña kammena
translated: The parrot, filled with joy, spent seven days in a state of ecstasy. By reason of this act of merit,

original: mañjussaro ahosi. Kassapasammāsambuddhakāle pana cetiye āraddhe kiṃ pamāṇaṃ karoma?
analyzed: mañjussaraḥ ahosi kassapa sammāsambuddha kāle pana cetiye āraddhe kim pamāṇam karoma
translated: he became a man of sweet speech. But in the time of the Supremely Enlightened Kassapa, when the people were building a tope, they said, “What size shall we make it?”

original: Sattayojanappamāṇaṃ. Atimahantametaṃ. Chayojanappamāṇaṃ. Etampi atimahantaṃ. Pañcayojanaṃ,
analyzed: satta yojana ppamāṇam atimahantam etam cha yojana ppamāṇam etam pi atimahantam pañca yojanam
translated: “Seven leagues.” “That is too large.” “Six leagues.” “That is too large.” “Five leagues.”

original: catuyojanaṃ, tiyojanaṃ, dviyojananti vutte ayaṃ tadā jeṭṭhavaḍḍhakī hutvā “etha,
analyzed: catu yojanam ti yojanam dvi yojanam iti vutte ayam tadā jeṭṭhavaḍḍhakī hutvā etha
translated: When the four-league, three-league, and two-league measurements were proposed, he said, “Come,

original: bho, anāgate sukhapaṭijaggiyaṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti vatvā rajjuyā parikkhipanto gāvutamattake🔽ṭhatvā “ekekaṃ mukhaṃ gāvutaṃ gāvutaṃ hotu, cetiyaṃ ekayojanāvaṭṭaṃ yojanubbedhaṃ
analyzed: bho anāgate sukhapaṭijaggiyam kātum vaṭṭati iti vatvā rajjuyā parikkhipantaḥ gāvuta mattake  ṭhatvā ekekam mukham gāvutam gāvutam hotu cetiyam eka yojana avaṭṭam yojana ubbedham
translated: let us make it so that we can take good care of it in the future.” He then measured it off with a rope, and when he had gone a distance of about a furlong,

original: bhavissatī”ti āha. Te tassa vacane aṭṭhaṃsu. Iti appamāṇassa buddhassa pamāṇaṃ akāsīti.
analyzed: bhavissati iti āha te tassa vacane aṭṭhaṃsu iti appamāṇassa buddhassa pamāṇam akāsi iti
translated: he said, “Let each face be a furlong long. The shrine will be a league in circumference and a league in height.” They agreed to his proposal. Thus he made a measurement of the immeasurable Buddha.

original: Tena pana kammena nibbattanibbattaṭṭhāne aññehi nīcatarappamāṇo hoti.
analyzed: tena pana kammena nibbatta nibbatta ṭṭhāne aññehi nīcatara ppamāṇaḥ hoti
translated: As a result of this deed, wherever he was reborn, he was shorter than the others.

original: So amhākaṃ satthu kāle sāvatthiyaṃ mahābhogakule nibbatti, bhaddiyotissa nāmaṃ ahosi.🔽Atirassatāya pana lakuṇḍakabhaddiyoti paññāyittha. So satthu santike dhammaṃ sutvā,
analyzed: saḥ amhākam satthu kāle sāvatthiyam mahā bhogakule nibbatti bhaddiyotissa nāmam ahosi  a tirassa tāya pana lakuṇḍakabhaddiyaḥ ti paññāyittha so satthu santike dhammaṃ sutvā
translated: In our Buddha’s time he was reborn in a wealthy family in Sāvatthī. His name was Bhaddiya.🔽Because of his extreme shortness he was known as Little Bhaddiya. He listened to the Dhamma in the presence of the Teacher,

original: paṭiladdhasaddho pabbajitvā, bahussuto dhammakathiko hutvā madhurena sarena paresaṃ
analyzed: paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbajitvā bahu ssutaḥ dhamma kathikaḥ hutvā madhurena sarena paresam
translated: gained faith, went forth, and became a learned preacher of the Dhamma. With his sweet voice he preached the Dhamma to others,

original: dhammaṃ kathesi. Athekasmiṃ ussavadivase ekena brāhmaṇena saddhiṃ rathena gacchantī
analyzed: dhammam kathesi atha ekasmin ussava divase ekena brāhmaṇena saddhim rathena gacchantī
translated: and preached the Dhamma to her. One festival day, while she was going in a chariot with a certain brāhmaṇa,

original: aññatarā gaṇikā theraṃ disvā dantavidaṃsakaṃ hasi. Thero tassā dantaṭṭhike nimittaṃ
analyzed: aññatarā gaṇikā theram disvā danta vidaṃsakam hasi thero tassāḥ dantaṭṭhike nimittam
translated: she saw the Elder and laughed, breaking her teeth. The Elder took the teeth as a sign

original: gahetvā jhānaṃ uppādetvā, taṃ pādakaṃ katvā, vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā, anāgāmī ahosi.
analyzed: gahetvā jhānam uppādetvā tam pādakam katvā vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā anāgāmī ahosi
translated: and, after developing jhāna, making them the basis, and beginning insight, she became a non-returner.

original: So abhiṇhaṃ kāyagatāya satiyā viharanto ekadivasaṃ āyasmatā dhammasenāpatinā ovadiyamāno
analyzed: saḥ abhiṇham kāyagatāya satiyā viharantaḥ eka divasam āyasmatā dhammasenāpatinā ovadiyamānaḥ
translated: She lived constantly in mindfulness of the body, and one day, being advised by the Venerable Dhamma-sena,

original: arahatte patiṭṭhahi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: arahatte patiṭṭhahi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: she was established in arahatship. Therefore it is said in the Apadana:

original: “Padumuttaro nāma jino, sabbadhammesu cakkhumā;
analyzed: padumuttaraḥ nāma jino sabba dhammesu cakkhumā
translated: “The Victor Padumuttara, who was the eye of all the world,

original: Ito satasahassamhi, kappe uppajji nāyako.
analyzed: itas sata sahassamhi kappe uppajji nāyako
translated: The Leader, appeared a hundred thousand eons ago.

original: “Tadāhaṃ haṃsavatiyaṃ seṭṭhiputto mahaddhano;
analyzed: tadā aham haṃsavatiyam seṭṭhi putto mahat dhano
translated: “At that time I was the son of a wealthy merchant in Haṃsavati;

original: Jaṅghāvihāraṃ vicaraṃ, saṅghārāmaṃ agacchahaṃ.
analyzed: jaṅghā vihāram vicaram saṅgha ārāmam agaccha aham
translated: While I was walking in the Jaṅgha-vihāra, I went to the Saṅgha-ārāma.

original: “Tadā so lokapajjoto, dhammaṃ desesi nāyako;
analyzed: tadā so loka pajjotaḥ dhammam desesi nāyako
translated: “Then the Light of the World, the Leader, preached the Dhamma;

original: Mañjussarānaṃ pavaraṃ, sāvakaṃ abhikittayi.
analyzed: mañjussarānam pavaram sāvakam abhikittayi
translated: He proclaimed as the foremost of those who are quick-witted his disciple

original: “Taṃ sutvā mudito hutvā, kāraṃ katvā mahesino;
analyzed: tam sutvā muditaḥ hutvā kāram katvā
translated: “Hearing this, I was filled with joy, and I did honor to the Teacher.

original: Vanditvā satthuno pāde, taṃ ṭhānamabhipatthayiṃ.
analyzed: vanditvā satthuno pāde tam ṭhānam abhipatthayiṃ
translated: I bowed down at the feet of the Teacher and made a vow concerning that place.

original: “Tadā buddho viyākāsi, saṅghamajjhe vināyako;
analyzed: tadā buddhaḥ saṅgha majjhe vināyakaḥ
translated: “Then the Buddha, the Leader, declared in the midst of the Sangha:

original: Anāgatamhi addhāne, lacchase taṃ manorathaṃ.
analyzed: anāgatamhi lacchase tam manoratham
translated: ‘In the future you will fulfill that wish.’

original: “Satasahassito kappe, okkākakulasambhavo;
analyzed: sata sahassitaḥ kappe okkāka kula sambhavaḥ
translated: “After a hundred thousand eons, you will be born in the Okkāka family.

original: Gotamo nāma gottena, satthā loke bhavissati.
analyzed: gotamaḥ nāma gottena satthā loke bhavissati
translated: You will be a teacher in the world, named Gotama.

original: “Tassa dhammesu dāyādo, oraso dhammanimmito;
analyzed: tassa dhammesu dāyādaḥ orasaḥ dhamma nimmito
translated: “You will be a heir to his Dhamma, a heart-son of the one with ten powers.

original: Bhaddiyo nāma nāmena, hessati satthu sāvako.
analyzed: bhaddiyaḥ nāma nāmena hessati satthu sāvakaḥ
translated: You will be named Bhaddiya, a disciple of the Teacher.

original: “Tena kammena sukatena, cetanāpaṇidhīhi ca;
analyzed: tena kammena su katena cetanā paṇidhīhi ca
translated: “Through that good deed, through my intention and aspiration,

original: Jahitvā mānusaṃ dehaṃ, tāvatiṃsamagacchahaṃ.
analyzed: jahitvā mānusam deham tāvatiṃsam agaccha aham
translated: I abandoned the human body and went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.

original: “Dvenavute ito kappe, phusso uppajji nāyako;
analyzed: dvenavute itas kappe phussaḥ uppajji nāyako
translated: “Two and a half eons ago, the Leader Phussa arose.

original: Durāsado duppasaho, sabbalokuttamo jino.
analyzed: durāsadaḥ duppasahaḥ sabba lokuttamaḥ jinaḥ
translated: He was unapproachable, hard to attend to, the best in the world, the Victor.

original: “Caraṇena ca sampanno, brahā uju patāpavā;
analyzed: caraṇena ca sampannaḥ brahāḥ uju patāpavā
translated: “He was endowed with good conduct, was great, straight, and radiant.

original: Hitesī sabbasattānaṃ, bahuṃ mocesi bandhanā.
analyzed: hita īsī sabba sattānam bahum mocesi bandhanā
translated: He was a benefactor to all beings, and he released many from bondage.

original: “Nandārāmavane tassa, ahosiṃ phussakokilo;
analyzed: nandārāma vane tassa ahosim phussa kokilaḥ
translated: “In the Nandana Grove, I was a cuckoo bird for Phussa.

original: Gandhakuṭisamāsanne, ambarukkhe vasāmahaṃ.
analyzed: gandhakuṭi samāsanne amba rukkhe vasām aham
translated: I lived in a mango tree near the Fragrant Cottage.

original: “Tadā piṇḍāya gacchantaṃ, dakkhiṇeyyaṃ jinuttamaṃ;
analyzed: tadā piṇḍāya gacchantam dakkhiṇeyyam jinuttamam
translated: “When I saw the Worthy One, the most worthy of those worthy of offerings,

original: Disvā cittaṃ pasādetvā, mañjunābhinikūjahaṃ.
analyzed: disvā cittam pasādetvā
translated: Going for alms, I gladdened my mind and cried out sweetly.

original: “Rājuyyānaṃ tadā gantvā, supakkaṃ kanakattacaṃ;
analyzed: rājuyyānam tadā gantvā su pakkam kanakattacam
translated: “Then, going to the royal park, I took a ripe mango with a golden skin,

original: Ambapiṇḍaṃ gahetvāna, sambuddhassopanāmayiṃ.
analyzed: amba piṇḍam gahetvāna sambuddhaḥ sa upanāmayim
translated: And offered it to the Fully Awakened One.

original: “Tadā me cittamaññāya, mahākāruṇiko jino;
analyzed: tadā me cittam aññāya mahā kāruṇikaḥ jino
translated: “Then, knowing my mind, the Victor, the one of great compassion,

original: Upaṭṭhākassa hatthato, pattaṃ paggaṇhi nāyako.
analyzed: upaṭṭhākassa hatthato pattam paggaṇhi nāyakaḥ
translated: The Leader, took the bowl from the attendant’s hand.

original: “Adāsiṃ haṭṭhacittohaṃ, ambapiṇḍaṃ mahāmune;
analyzed: adāsim haṭṭha cittaḥ ūham amba piṇḍam mahā mune
translated: “With a gladdened heart I offered the mango to the Great Sage,

original: Patte pakkhippa pakkhehi, pañjaliṃ katvāna mañjunā.
analyzed: patte pakkhippa pakkhehi pañjalim katvāna mañjunā
translated: And placing it in the bowl, I made reverential salutation with my wings.

original: “Sarena rajanīyena, savanīyena vaggunā;
analyzed: sarena rajanīyena savanīyena vaggunā
translated: “With a lovely, melodious, sweet voice,

original: Vassanto buddhapūjatthaṃ, nīḷaṃ gantvā nipajjahaṃ.
analyzed: vassantaḥ buddha pūjā attham nīḷam gantvā nipajjaham
translated: I sang in praise of the Buddha, and then, going to my nest, I lay down.

original: “Tadā muditacittaṃ maṃ, buddhapemagatāsayaṃ;
analyzed: tadā mudita cittam mam buddha pema gata āsayam
translated: “Then, with a mind full of joy, my heart set on the beauty of the Buddha,

original: Sakuṇagghi upāgantvā, ghātayī duṭṭhamānaso.
analyzed: upāgantvā ghātayī duṭṭha mānaso
translated: A wicked bird came and killed me.

original: “Tato cutohaṃ tusite, anubhotvā mahāsukhaṃ;
analyzed: tatas mahā sukham
translated: “Then, having fallen from there, and having experienced great happiness in Tusita,

original: Manussayonimāgacchiṃ, tassa kammassa vāhasā.
analyzed: manussa yonim āgacchim tassa kammassa vāhasā
translated: Through the power of that deed I was reborn in a human womb.

original: “Imamhi bhaddake kappe, brahmabandhu mahāyaso;
analyzed: imamhi bhaddake kappe brahmabandhu mahāyaso
translated: “In this auspicious aeon, a kinsman of Brahma, of great fame,

analyzed: imāḥ tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi  tattha parā iti seṭṭhe adhike visiṭṭhā iti atthaḥ adhika vācī hi ayam para saddaḥ param  viya mattāyāti ādīsu viya ambāṭaka ārāma iti evaṃnāmake ārāme saḥ kira chāyū udaka sampanno  vana saṇḍa maṇḍitaḥ ramaṇīyaḥ hoti tena parā iti visesetvā vuttaḥ ambāṭaka vane ambāṭakehi  abhilakkhita vana iti ca vadanti vana saṇḍamhi iti vana gahane ghana nicita rukkha gaccha latā samūhe

original: vaneti attho. Bhaddiyoti evaṃnāmako, attānameva thero aññaṃ viya vadati. Samūlaṃ🔽taṇhamabbuyhāti taṇhāya mūlaṃ nāma avijjā. Tasmā sāvijjaṃ taṇhaṃ aggamaggena samugghāṭetvāti

translated: Herein, “best” means “superior.” For the word para is a word for the superior, as in such passages as “He is to be honoured as the best” . In the Ambattha Grove: in a park of that name. And they say: “In the Ambattha Grove, which is marked out by ambattha trees” . In the wood: in the forest, in a mass of trees, a mass of tree-trunks, a mass of creepers, in a wood, is the meaning. Bhaddiya: the elder refers to himself as if he were another, as in the passage beginning, “The bhikkhu who is content” . Having uprooted craving with its root: the root of craving is ignorance. So he means that he has plucked up craving by the root together with ignorance by the supreme path.

original: attho. Tattha bhaddova jhāyatīti lokuttarehi sīlādīhi bhaddo sundaro tasmiṃyeva vanasaṇḍe🔽katakiccatāya diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāravasena aggaphalajhānena jhāyati.

original: vuttaṃ. Ajjhattanti attano santāne khandhāyatanādidhammaṃ. Bahiddhāti parasantāne.🔽Atha vā ajjhattanti, mama abbhantare asekkhasīlakkhandhādiṃ. Bahiddhāti, mameva ākappasampattiyādiyuttaṃ

translated: “Internally” means the aggregates, sense bases, etc., in one’s own continuum. “Externally” means in the continua of others.🔽Or else, “internally” means the aggregates of virtue, etc., in one’s own person. “Externally” means the external appearance of form, etc., and the occurrence of eye-consciousness, etc., in another person.

translated: “Surrounded by a fence” means that he is surrounded by a fence of ignorance because he does not know the internal and external bases. He is “enmeshed in the net,” that is, he is caught in the net of wrong knowledge.

original: so paraneyyabuddhiko bālo ghosena paresaṃ vacanena vuyhati niyyati ākaḍḍhīyati.
analyzed: saḥ paraneyyabuddhikaḥ bālaḥ ghosena paresam vacanena vuyhati niyyati ākaḍḍhīyati
translated: He is one who is guided by others, a fool who is led away, carried away, and dragged away by the word of others.

analyzed: bahiddhā ca vipassati iti yaḥ ca vutta nayena ajjhattam na jānāti bahiddhā pana suta anusārena

analyzed: ākappa sampatti ādi upadhāraṇena vā visesataḥ passati guṇa visesa yuttaḥ siyā ti maññati

original: lokiyābhiññekadesadassanaṃ chaḷabhiññabhāvavibhāvanatthaṃ. Tenāha apadāne “chaḷabhiññā sacchikatā”ti.
analyzed: lokiya abhiññā eka desa dassanam chaḷ abhiñña bhāva vibhāvana attham tena āha apadāne chaḷ abhiññā sacchikatā iti
translated: showing the state of the six kinds of direct knowledge by showing a part of the mundane direct knowledges. Hence it is said in the Apadana: “The six direct knowledges were realized.”

original: Bhaddattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: bhaddatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the verses of the Elder Bhaddā is finished.

original: 4. Sopākattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: sopākatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The verses of the Elder Sopāka

analyzed: disvā pāsāda chāyāyanti ādikā āyasmataḥ sopāka ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi purima buddhesu
translated: Disvā pāsādachāyāyaṃ, etc. These are the verses of the Elder Sopāka. What is their origin? This elder, too, in the time of former Buddhas,

analyzed: kata adhikāro tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinantaḥ siddhatthassa bhagavato kāle brāhmaṇa kule
translated: having begun the good works, accumulated merit in various existences, and in the time of the Blessed One Siddhattha,🔽having been reborn in a brahmin family,

original: nibbattitvā viññutaṃ patto brāhmaṇānaṃ vijjāsippesu nipphattiṃ gato kāmesu ādīnavaṃ
analyzed: nibbattitvā viññutam pattaḥ brāhmaṇānam vijjā sippesu nipphattim gataḥ kāmesu ādīnavam
translated: having attained maturity, having become proficient in the sciences and the arts of the brahmins, having seen the danger in sense pleasures,

original: disvā gharāvāsaṃ pahāya tāpasapabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā ekasmiṃ pabbate viharati. Satthā
analyzed: disvā ghara āvāsam pahāya tāpasapabbajjam pabbajitvā ekasmin pabbate viharati satthā
translated: having left the household life, having gone forth in the ascetic life of the wanderers, he dwelt on a certain mountain. The Teacher,

original: āsannamaraṇaṃ taṃ ñatvā tassa santikaṃ agamāsi. So bhagavantaṃ disvā pasannacitto
analyzed: āsanna maraṇam tam ñatvā tassa santikam agamāsi saḥ bhagavantam disvā pasanna citto
translated: Knowing that his death was near, he went to the place where the Teacher was. When he saw the Teacher, he was filled with joy,

original: uḷāraṃ pītisomanassaṃ pavedento pupphamayaṃ āsanaṃ paññapetvā adāsi. Satthā tattha
analyzed: uḷāram pīti somanassam pavedento puppha mayam āsanam paññapetvā adāsi satthā tattha
translated: and expressing his joy and gladness in a loud voice, he prepared a seat of flowers and offered it to the Teacher. The Teacher sat down

original: nisīditvā, aniccatāpaṭisaṃyuttaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ kathetvā tassa passantasseva ākāsena🔽agamāsi. So pubbe gahitaṃ niccaggāhaṃ pahāya aniccasaññaṃ hadaye ṭhapetvā, kālaṅkatvā,
analyzed: nisīditvā anicca tā paṭisaṃyuttam dhammim katham kathetvā tassa passantassa iva ākāsena  agamāsi saḥ pubbe gahitam nicca ggāham pahāya anicca saññam hadaye ṭhapetvā kālam katvā
translated: there and preached the Law in orderly sequence, beginning with the topic of Impermanence. Then he rose up into the air🔽and departed. The Elder, looking after him, abandoned the false view that he had previously entertained, namely, that the world is permanent, and fixed in his mind the true conception of Impermanence. After death he was reborn in the World of the Gods.

original: devaloke uppajitvā, aparāparaṃ devamanussesu saṃsaranto, imasmiṃ buddhuppāde rājagahe🔽sopākayoniyaṃ nibbatti. So jātiāgatena sopākoti nāmena paññāyi. Keci pana “vāṇijakule
analyzed: deva loke uppajitvā apara aparam deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde rājagahe  sopāka yoniyam nibbatti so jāti āgatena sopākaḥ iti nāmena paññāyi keci pana vāṇija kule
translated: Passing from one state of existence to another, he was finally reborn in the dispensation of the present Buddha, in the family of a slave, in Rājagaha.🔽Because he was born in the family of a slave, he was called Sopāka. But some say that he was born in the family of a merchant, and that his name was Sopāka. This, however, is contrary to the story as related in the Commentary.

original: nibbatto, ‘sopāko’ti pana nāmamatta”nti vadanti. Taṃ apadānapāḷiyā virujjhati “pacchime🔽bhave sampatte, sopākayonupāgami”nti vacanato.
analyzed: nibbatto sopāko iti pana nāma matta nti vadanti tam apadāna pāḷiyā virujjhati pacchime 🔽bhave sampatte vacanataḥ
translated: In his last existence he was born in the family of a slave.

original: Tassa catumāsajātassa pitā kālamakāsi, cūḷapitā posesi. Anukkamena sattavassiko jāto.
analyzed: tassa catu māsa jātassa pitā kālam akāsi cūḷa pitā posesi anukkamena satta vassikaḥ jātaḥ
translated: When the child was four months old, his father died, and his uncle brought him up. In due course he reached the age of seven years.

original: Ekadivasaṃ cūḷapitā “attano puttena kalahaṃ karotī”ti kujjhitvā, taṃ susānaṃ netvā,🔽dve hatthe rajjuyā ekato bandhitvā, tāya eva rajjuyā matamanussassa sarīre gāḷhaṃ
analyzed: eka divasam cūḷa pitā attano puttena kalaham karoti iti kujjhitvā tam su sānam netvā  dve hatthe rajjuyā ekatas bandhitvā tāya eva rajjuyā mata manussassa sarīre gāḍham
translated: One day his uncle, angry because the child was quarreling with his own son, took him to the charnel-ground,

original: bandhitvā gato “siṅgālādayo khādantū”ti. Pacchimabhavikatāya dārakassa puññaphalena
analyzed: bandhitvā gataḥ siṅgāla ādayo khādantu uti pacchimabhavika tāya dārakassa puñña phalena
translated: bound his two hands together with a rope, and with the same rope bound him tightly to the corpse of a dead man, saying, “Let jackals and the like devour him.” But by the fruit of his own merit the child, who was destined to attain his last existence,

original: sayaṃ māretuṃ na visahi, siṅgālādayopi na abhibhaviṃsu. Dārako aḍḍharattasamaye evaṃ vippalapati –
analyzed: sayam māretum na siṅgāla ādayaḥ api na dārakaḥ aḍḍha ratta samaye evam vippalapati
translated: was unable to kill himself, and the jackals and the like were unable to overcome him. At midnight the child began to lament,

original: “Kā gati me agatissa, ko vā bandhu abandhuno;
analyzed: kā gati me agatissa kaḥ vā bandhu abandhunaḥ
translated: “What fate is mine, who have no protector? What kinsman have I, who am without kinsman?

original: Susānamajjhe bandhassa, ko me abhayadāyako”ti.
analyzed: susāna majjhe bandhassa kaḥ me abhaya dāyakaḥ ti
translated: In the midst of this charnel-ground, bound to a corpse, who will give me freedom from fear?”

original: Satthā tāya velāya veneyyabandhave olokento dārakassa hadayabbhantare pajjalantaṃ arahattūpanissayaṃ disvā obhāsaṃ pharitvā satiṃ janetvā evamāha –
analyzed: satthā tāya velāya veneyya bandhave olokentaḥ dārakassa hadaya bbhantare pajjalantam arahatta upanissayam disvā obhāsam pharitvā satim janetvā evam āha
translated: The Teacher, surveying the world at that time to see who was ready to be converted, beheld the child, and saw that within his heart the root of worthiness was aflame. Therefore he sent forth a radiance to arouse his mindfulness, and spoke to him as follows:

original: “Ehi sopāka mā bhāyi, olokassu tathāgataṃ;
analyzed: ehi sopāka mā bhāyi tathāgatam
translated: “Come, Sopāka, do not fear, but look upon the Tathāgata.

original: Ahaṃ taṃ tārayissāmi, rāhumukheva candima”nti.
analyzed: aham tam tārayissāmi rāhu mukhā iva candimanti
translated: I will deliver you, as the moon from the mouth of Rāhu.”

original: Dārako buddhānubhāvena chinnabandhano gāthāpariyosāne sotāpanno hutvā gandhakuṭisammukhe
analyzed: dārakaḥ buddha anubhāvena chinna bandhanaḥ gāthā pariyosāne sotāpannaḥ hutvā gandhakuṭi sammukhe
translated: By the power of the Buddha the child’s bonds were loosened. At the end of the stanza he was established in the Fruit of Conversion. He stood in the presence of the Perfumed Chamber.

original: aṭṭhāsi. Tassa mātā puttaṃ apassantī cūḷapitaraṃ pucchitvā tenassa pavattiyā akathitāya🔽tattha tattha gantvā vicinantī “buddhā kira atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ jānanti, yaṃnūnāhaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi tassa mātā puttam a passantī cūḷa pitaram pucchitvā tena assa pavattiyā a kathitāya  tattha tattha gantvā vicinantī buddhā kira atīta anāgata paccuppannam jānanti yat nūna aham
translated: His mother, not seeing her son, asked his father about him. His father told her what had happened.

original: bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā mama puttassa pavattiṃ jāneyya”nti satthu santikaṃ agamāsi.🔽Satthā, iddhiyā taṃ paṭicchādetvā, “bhante, mama puttaṃ na passāmi, apica bhagavā
analyzed: bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā mama puttassa pavattim jāneyyan ti satthu santikam agamāsi  satthā iddhiyā tam paṭicchādetvā bhante mama puttam na passāmi apica bhagavā
translated: She went here and there, searching for her son. “The Buddhas, it is said, know the past, the present, and the future. Suppose I were to go to the Exalted One and ask him to tell me what has become of my son.”

original: tassa pavattiṃ jānātī”ti tāya puṭṭho –
analyzed: tassa pavattim jānāti iti tāya puṭṭhaḥ
translated: Accordingly she went to the Teacher. The Teacher, by his supernatural power, concealed her from the view of all the other monks. “Reverend Sir,” said she, “I do not see my son. Moreover, the Exalted One knows what has become of him.”

original: “Na santi puttā tāṇāya, na pitā nāpi bandhavā;
analyzed: na santi puttā tāṇāya na pitā na api bandhavā
translated: When she had thus spoken, the Teacher replied, “There is no son to save you, nor father, nor kinsman.

original: Antakenādhipannassa, natthi ñātīsu tāṇatā”ti. –
analyzed: antakena adhipannassa na atthi ñātīsu tāṇa tā ati
translated: When the King of Death has seized you, there is no salvation in all your kinsfolk.”

original: Dhammaṃ kathesi. Taṃ sutvā sā sotāpannā ahosi. Dārako arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: dhammam kathesi tam sutvā sā sotāpannā ahosi dārakaḥ arahattam pāpuṇi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: and he preached the Law. She, having heard it, became a Stream-Winner. The boy attained Arahatship. Therefore it is said in the Apadana:🔽“While I was clearing away the rubbish,

original: “Pabbhāraṃ sodhayantassa, vipine pabbatuttame;
analyzed: pabbhāram sodhayantassa vipine pabbata uttame
translated: on the mountain-top in the forest,🔽the Exalted One named Siddhattha

original: Siddhattho nāma bhagavā, āgacchi mama santikaṃ.
analyzed: siddhatthaḥ nāma bhagavā āgacchi mama santikam
translated: came into my presence.🔽“Having seen the Buddha come,

analyzed: buddham upagatam disvā loka jeṭṭhassa tādinaḥ
translated: the chief of the world, the Tamer,🔽I spread out a couch,

analyzed: santharam santharitvāna
translated: and gave him a flower-seat.🔽“Having sat down on the flower-seat,

analyzed: puppha āsane nisīditvā siddhatthaḥ loka nāyakaḥ
translated: Siddhattha, the Leader of the world,🔽knowing that I was a woman,

analyzed: mamañca gati maññāya aniccatam udāhari
translated: spoke of impermanence.

original: “Aniccā vata saṅkhārā, uppādavayadhammino;
analyzed: aniccāḥ vata saṅkhārāḥ uppāda vaya dhammino
translated: “Impermanent, indeed, are all component things;🔽they are subject to rise and fall.🔽Having arisen, they cease;

original: Uppajjitvā nirujjhanti, tesaṃ vūpasamo sukho.
analyzed: uppajjitvā nirujjhanti tesam vūpasamaḥ sukhaḥ
translated: their calm is bliss.🔽“Having spoken thus, the Omniscient One,

original: “Idaṃ vatvāna sabbaññū, lokajeṭṭho narāsabho;
analyzed: idam vatvāna sabbaññū loka jeṭṭhaḥ narāsabhaḥ
translated: the chief of the world, the Hero, the Best of Men,🔽rose up into the sky

original: Nabhaṃ abbhuggamī vīro, haṃsarājāva ambare.
analyzed: nabham abbhuj gamī vīraḥ ambare
translated: like a king of swans in the sky.🔽“Having given up my own view,

analyzed: sakam diṭṭhim jahitvāna bhāvaya anicca saññaham
translated: I developed the perception of impermanence.🔽Having developed it for one day,

analyzed: ekāham bhāvayitvāna tattha kālam kataḥ aham
translated: I died and was reborn there.🔽“Having enjoyed two kinds of happiness,

original: “Dve sampattī anubhotvā, sukkamūlena codito;
analyzed: dve sampattī anubhotvā sukka mūlena coditaḥ
translated: having been urged on by the root of merit,

analyzed: pacchime bhave sampatte  agārā abhinikkhamma pabbajim anagāriyam
translated: In my last existence I was reborn in a family of cooks.🔽Having gone forth from the home life into homelessness,

analyzed: jātiyā
translated: I attained Liberation seven years after my birth.

original: “Āraddhavīriyo pahitatto, sīlesu susamāhito;
analyzed: āraddha vīriyaḥ pahitatto sīlesu su samāhito
translated: Endowed with energy, intent, and virtue well-composed,

translated: I pleased the Great Sage and received Acceptance.

translated: For ninety-four aeons I did this deed,

analyzed: duggatim na abhijānāmi puppha dānassa idam phalam
translated: and I do not recall any bad destination: this is the fruit of the flower offering.

analyzed: catunnavutitaḥ kappe yam saññam bhāvayim tadā
translated: For ninety-four aeons I developed this perception,

analyzed: tam saññam bhāvayantassa pattaḥ me āsava kkhayo
translated: and while developing this perception, I attained the destruction of the pollutants.

original: “Paṭisambhidā catasso…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: paṭisambhidā katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: The four analytical knowledges … The Buddha’s instruction has been carried out.”

original: Atha bhagavā iddhiṃ paṭisaṃhari. Sāpi puttaṃ disvā haṭṭhatuṭṭho tassa khīṇāsavabhāvaṃ
analyzed: atha bhagavā iddhim paṭisaṃhari sā api puttam disvā haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ tassa khīṇāsava bhāvam
translated: Then the Blessed One withdrew his psychic power. She, too, having seen her son, was delighted and satisfied.

original: sutvā pabbājetvā gatā. So satthāraṃ gandhakuṭicchāyāyaṃ caṅkamantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā,
analyzed: sutvā pabbājetvā gatā so satthāram gandhakuṭi chāyāyam caṅkamantam upasaṅkamitvā
translated: Having heard that he had destroyed the pollutants, she had him go forth and left. He approached the Teacher, who was pacing back and forth in the shade of the Fragrant Cottage,🔽and said,

original: vanditvā anucaṅkami. Tassa bhagavā upasampadaṃ anujānitukāmo “ekaṃ nāma ki”ntiādinā
analyzed: vanditvā anucaṅkami tassa bhagavā upasampadam anujānitu kāmaḥ ekam nāma kinti ādinā
translated: and then departed. The Exalted One, desiring to grant him the Upasampadā ordination, asked him ten questions, beginning with “What is one?”

original: dasa pañhe pucchi. Sopi satthu adhippāyaṃ gaṇhanto sabbaññutaññāṇena saṃsandento
analyzed: dasa pañhe pucchi saḥ api satthu adhippāyam gaṇhantaḥ sabbaññuta ññāṇena saṃsandentaḥ
translated: and the youth, understanding the Exalted One’s intention, answered the questions in such a way as to show that he possessed the knowledge of omniscience,

original: “sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikā”tiādinā te pañhe vissajjesi. Teneva te kumārapañhā nāma
analyzed: sabbe sattā āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati ādinā te pañhe vissajjesi tena iva te kumārapañhāḥ nāma

original: jātā. Satthā tassa pañhabyākaraṇena ārādhitacitto upasampadaṃ anujāni. Tena sā pañhabyākaraṇūpasampadā
analyzed: jātā satthā tassa pañha byākaraṇena ārādhita cittaḥ upasampadam anujāni tena sā pañha byākaraṇa upasampadā
translated: The Exalted One, pleased with the answers to his questions, granted him the Upasampadā ordination. Thus the answers to the questions came to be called the Upasampadā ordination.

original: nāma jātā. Tassimaṃ attano pavattiṃ pakāsetvā thero aññaṃ byākaronto –
analyzed: nāma jātā tassa imam attanaḥ pavattim pakāsetvā theraḥ aññam byākarontaḥ
translated: Having thus related his own story, the Elder related the story of another monk.🔽“Seeing the Supreme of Men

original: “Disvā pāsādachāyāyaṃ, caṅkamantaṃ naruttamaṃ;
analyzed: disvā caṅkamantam naruttamam
translated: walking in the shade of the palace,🔽I approached him,

original: Tattha naṃ upasaṅkamma, vandissaṃ purisuttamaṃ.
analyzed: tattha nam upasaṅkamma vandissam purisa uttamam
translated: and paid obeisance to the Supreme of Men.

original: “Ekaṃsaṃ cīvaraṃ katvā, saṃharitvāna pāṇayo;
analyzed: eka aṃsam cīvaram katvā saṃharitvāna pāṇayaḥ
translated: Having arranged my robe over one shoulder,🔽and having placed my hands together in reverential salutation,

original: Anucaṅkamissaṃ virajaṃ, sabbasattānamuttamaṃ.
analyzed: anucaṅkamissam virajam sabba sattānam uttamam
translated: I walked behind the stainless one, the Supreme of all beings.

original: “Tato pañhe apucchi maṃ, pañhānaṃ kovido vidū;
analyzed: tatas pañhe apucchi mama pañhānam kovidaḥ
translated: Then the wise one, skilled in questions, asked me questions.

original: Acchambhī ca abhīto ca, byākāsiṃ satthuno ahaṃ.
analyzed: a chambhī ca a bhītaḥ ca byākāsim satthunaḥ aham
translated: I was not afraid, not terrified, I answered the Teacher’s question.

original: “Vissajjitesu pañhesu, anumodi tathāgato;
analyzed: vissajjitesu pañhesu anumodi tathāgataḥ
translated: “When the questions were answered, the Realised One rejoiced,

original: Bhikkhusaṅghaṃ viloketvā, imamatthaṃ abhāsatha.
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅgham viloketvā imam attham abhāsatha
translated: and after looking over the Community of monks, he spoke this meaning:

original: “‘Lābhā aṅgānaṃ magadhānaṃ, yesāyaṃ paribhuñjati;
analyzed: lābhāḥ aṅgānam magadhānam yesāyam paribhuñjati
translated: ‘It is a gain for the people of Aṅga and Magadha that they enjoy

original: Cīvaraṃ piṇḍapātañca, paccayaṃ sayanāsanaṃ;
analyzed: cīvaram piṇḍapātañca paccayam sayana āsanam
translated: the robe, alms-food, resting place, and medicinal requisites,

original: Paccuṭṭhānañca sāmīciṃ, tesaṃ lābhā’ti cābravi.
analyzed: paccuṭṭhānam ca sāmīcim ca bravi
translated: and the service of the Community of monks,’ he said.

original: “‘Ajjadagge maṃ sopāka, dassanāyopasaṅkama;
analyzed: ajja dagge mam sopāka dassanāya upasaṅkama
translated: “‘Come to see me tomorrow, Sopāka,

original: Esā ceva te sopāka, bhavatu upasampadā”’.
analyzed: esā ca iva te sopāka bhavatu upasampadā
translated: and this will be your higher ordination, Sopāka.’

original: “Jātiyā sattavassena, laddhāna upasampadaṃ;
analyzed: jātiyā satta vassena laddhānaḥ upasampadam
translated: “Having received the higher ordination at the age of seven,

original: Dhāremi antimaṃ dehaṃ, aho dhammasudhammatā”ti. – imā gāthā abhāsi;🔽Tattha pāsādachāyāyanti gandhakuṭicchāyāyaṃ. Vandissanti, abhivandiṃ.
analyzed: dhāremi antimam deham aho dhamma su dhamma tā ti imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi  tattha pāsāda chāyāyanti gandhakuṭi chāyāyam vandissanti abhivandim
translated: I bear this last body, how good is the Teaching!”🔽Herein, in the shade of the Palace means in the shade of the Fragrant Cottage. I worshipped, I paid homage.

original: Saṃharitvāna pāṇayoti ubho hatthe kamalamakuḷākārena saṅgate katvā, añjaliṃ paggahetvāti

original: Pañheti kumārapañhe. Vidūti veditabbaṃ viditavā, sabbaññūti attho. “Satthā maṃ pucchatī”ti

analyzed: dhammam desesi so paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbajitvā vipassanāya kammam karontaḥ nacirassa eva  arahattam patvā tattha iva vasati athassa tāpasa kāle katā paṇṇa sālā jiṇṇā paluggā

original: Thero “kuṭikā yathā tāpasakāle katā, idāni tathā kātuṃ na sakkā”ti taṃ sabbaṃ pakāsento –

translated: And built a hut of leaves;🔽Therefore the name Sarabhanga

translated: “Today it is not proper for me to break the grass with my hands;

analyzed: tattha sare hatthehi bhañjitvā ati pubbe tāpasa kāle sara tiṇāni mama hatthehi chinditvā  tiṇa kuṭim katvā acchisam vasim nisīdin ca iva nipajjin ca tena ati kuṭi karaṇa attham sarānam
translated: Herein, having broken the grass with my hands means that in the past, during the time of the ascetics, having cut the grass with my hands,

analyzed: bhañjanena sammutiyā ati anvattha sammutiyā sarabhaṅgo ti nāmam ahu ahosi  na mayham kappate ajja ati ajja idāni upasampannassa mayham sare sara tiṇe hatthehi

translated: Having thus shown the reason for not rebuilding the hut by one method, he now shows it by another method,🔽“The whole disease, the whole affliction,

translated: I did not see before,🔽But now that I have seen the disease,

translated: Herein, the whole means all. The whole affliction means the complete, the entire, the unabridged. translated: whether gods by convention, gods by rebirth, or gods by purification, by his own virtue, etc.,

translated: and by his obedience to the advice of the Perfectly Enlightened One, the superlative god, has done as the Teacher said, that is, he has seen the disease called the five aggregates.

translated: “By the same path Vipassi went, and Sikhi, Vessabhu,

translated: Kakusandha, Konagamana, and Kassapa, by that path Gotama went.

translated: “Free from craving, free from grasping, the seven Buddhas, the destroyers of existence,

translated: “The four noble truths, out of compassion for living beings,

translated: “And having heard the stainless speech, the cleanser of the mire of destinies,

original: Pāpuṇiṃ amataṃ santaṃ, sesehi saha sattahi.
analyzed: pāpuṇim amatam santam sesehi saha sattahi
translated: I attained the deathless peace, together with the remaining seven.

original: “Adhippāyavidū jāto, sugatassa mahāmate.
analyzed: adhippāya vidū jātaḥ sugatassa mahāmate
translated: “The one of great wisdom, the Sugata, has made me a master of the doctrine.

original: Ṭhapito etadagge ca, susamiddhamanoratho.
analyzed: ṭhapitaḥ etad agge ca su samiddha manorathaḥ
translated: He has placed me in the foremost rank, and my heart’s desire has been fulfilled.

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: My passions have been quenched, my doubts have been resolved, and the will of the Buddha has been done.”

original: Atha satthā “etha, bhikkhavo”ti hatthaṃ pasāresi. Te tāvadeva dvaṅgulamattakesamassukā
analyzed: atha satthā etha bhikkhavaḥ ti hattham pasāresi te tāvat eva dvaṅgula matta kesa massukā
translated: Then the Teacher extended his hand and said, “Come hither, monks.” Instantly they became monks of twenty years’ standing, with hair and beard down-growing,

original: iddhimayapattacīvaradharā vassasaṭṭhikattherā viya ahesuṃ. Evaṃ thero sadatthaṃ nipphādetvā,
analyzed: iddhi maya patta cīvara dharāḥ vassasaṭṭhika therāḥ viya ahesuṃ evam theraḥ sadattham nipphādetvā
translated: with the three garments of a monk, and with all the other characteristics of monks of sixty years’ standing. Thus did the Elder fulfill his own desire.

original: “bhante, rājā pajjoto tumhākaṃ pāde vandituṃ dhammañca sotuṃ icchatī”ti satthu ārocesi.
analyzed: bhante rājā pajjotaḥ tumhākam pāde vanditum dhammañca sotum icchati iti satthu ārocesi
translated: “Reverend Sir,” said he, “King Pajjota desires to pay obeisance at your feet and to hear the Law.”

original: Satthā, “tvaṃyeva, bhikkhu, tattha gaccha, tayi gatepi rājā pasīdissatī”ti āha. Thero
analyzed: satthā tvaṃ yeva bhikkhu tattha gaccha tayi gate api rājā pasīdissati iti āha theraḥ
translated: “Go you, monk,” said the Teacher, “and if you go, the king will be satisfied.” The Elder,

original: satthu āṇāya attaṭṭhamo tattha gantvā rājānaṃ pasādetvā avantīsu sāsanaṃ patiṭṭhāpetvā
analyzed: satthu āṇāya atta ṭṭhamaḥ tattha gantvā rājānam pasādetvā avantīsu sāsanam patiṭṭhāpetvā
translated: in obedience to the Teacher, went thither, accompanied by eight thousand monks, and satisfied the king. Having established the Faith in Avantī,

original: puna satthu santikameva gato. So ekadivasaṃ sambahule bhikkhū samaṇadhammaṃ pahāya
analyzed: puna satthu santikam eva gataḥ saḥ eka divasam sambahule bhikkhū samaṇa dhammam pahāya
translated: he returned to the Teacher. One day a number of monks, abandoning the duties of monks,

original: kammārāme saṅgaṇikārāme rasataṇhānugate ca pamādavihārino disvā tesaṃ ovādavasena –
analyzed: kamma ārāme saṅgaṇikā ārāme rasa taṇhā anugate ca pamāda vihārinaḥ disvā tesam ovāda vasena
translated: and seeing them living in a place of work, in a place of crowds, and living negligently, following after the craving for tastes, he spoke this advice to them:

original: “Kammaṃ bahukaṃ na kāraye, parivajjeyya janaṃ na uyyame;
analyzed: kammam bahukam na kāraye parivajjeyya janam naḥ uyyame
translated: “Do not have much work done, avoid crowds, do not strive;

original: So ussukko rasānugiddho, atthaṃ riñcati yo sukhādhivāho.
analyzed: saḥ ussukkaḥ rasa anugiddhaḥ attham riñcati yaḥ sukha adhivāhaḥ
translated: He who is diligent, following after tastes, is one who forsakes the good, the one who is devoted to happiness.

original: “Paṅkoti hi naṃ avedayuṃ, yāyaṃ vandanapūjanā kulesu;
analyzed: hi nam avedayum vandana pūjanā kulesu
translated: “They say that this is a bog, this worship and veneration in families;

original: Sukhumaṃ sallaṃ durubbahaṃ, sakkāro kāpurisena dujjaho”ti. –
analyzed: sukhumam sallam durubbaham sakkāraḥ kāpurisena dujjahoti
translated: A subtle dart, hard to pull out, respect is hard to abandon by a bad man.”

original: Dve gāthā abhāsi.🔽Tattha kammaṃ bahukaṃ na kārayeti navāvāsakārāpanādiṃ samaṇadhammakaraṇassa paribandhabhūtaṃ
analyzed: dve gāthāḥ abhāsi  tattha kammam bahukam na kāraya iti nava āvāsa kārāpana ādim samaṇa dhamma karaṇassa paribandha bhūtam
translated: He spoke these two verses.🔽Herein, do not have much work done means do not undertake great new work that is a hindrance to the performance of the ascetic’s duties, such as the building of a new dwelling.

original: mahantaṃ navakammaṃ na paṭṭhapeyya, khuddakaṃ appasamārambhaṃ khaṇḍaphullapaṭisaṅkharaṇādiṃ
analyzed: mahantam nava kammam na paṭṭhapeyya khuddakam appa samārambham khaṇḍa phulla paṭisaṅkharaṇa ādim
translated: But small work, which is of little consequence, such as the repairing of what is broken or fallen to pieces,🔽must be done for the purpose of honouring the Teacher’s word. Avoid crowds means

original: satthu vacanapaṭipūjanatthaṃ kātabbameva. Parivajjeyya jananti gaṇasaṅgaṇikavasena
analyzed: satthu vacana paṭipūjana attham kātabbam eva parivajjeyya jananti gaṇa saṅgaṇika vasena
translated: avoid crowds by way of the company of crowds.

original: janaṃ vivajjeyya. Jananti vā yādisaṃ saṃsevato bhajato payirupāsato kusalā dhammā
analyzed: janam vivajjeyya jananti vā yādisam saṃsevataḥ bhajataḥ payirupāsataḥ kusalāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: Or crowds means whatever kinds of wholesome states

original: parihāyanti, akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, tādisaṃ akalyāṇamittabhūtaṃ janaṃ parivajjeyya.
analyzed: parihāyanti akusalāḥ dhammāḥ abhivaḍḍhanti tādisam akalyāṇa mitta bhūtam janam parivajjeyya
translated: and unwholesome states increase, one should avoid such a person who is a bad friend.

original: Na uyyameti, paccayuppādanatthaṃ kulasaṅgaṇhanavasena na vāyameyya, yasmā so ussukko
analyzed: na paccaya uppādana attham kula saṅgaṇhana vasena na vāyameyya yasmā saḥ ussukkaḥ
translated: He does not strive: he does not make an effort to acquire requisites by way of associating with families. Because he is intent

original: rasānugiddho, atthaṃ riñcati yo sukhādhivāhoti yo rasānugiddho rasataṇhāvasiko bhikkhu🔽paccayuppādanapasuto, so kulasaṅgaṇhanatthaṃ ussukko, tesu sukhitesu sukhito, dukkhitesu🔽dukkhito, uppannesu kiccakaraṇīyesu attanā yogaṃ āpajjati, yo sukhādhivāho samathavipassanāmaggaphalanibbānasukhāvaho
analyzed: rasa anugiddhaḥ attham riñcati yaḥ sukha adhivāhaḥ iti yaḥ rasa anugiddhaḥ rasa taṇhā vasikaḥ bhikkhu  paccaya uppādana pasutaḥ so kula saṅgaṇhana attham ussukkaḥ tesu sukhitesu sukhitaḥ dukkhitesu  dukkhitaḥ uppannesu kicca karaṇīyesu attanā yogam āpajjati yaḥ sukha adhivāhaḥ samatha vipassanā magga phala nibbāna sukha āvahaḥ
translated: On flavors, he forsakes the good: the bhikkhu who is intent on flavors, who is devoted to craving for flavors,🔽is intent on acquiring requisites and is concerned with “Who is well? Who is happy? Who has what needs?”

original: sīlādiattho, taṃ riñcati pajahati ekaṃsena attānaṃ tato vivecetīti attho.
analyzed: sīla ādi atthaḥ tam riñcati pajahati ekaṃsena attānam tatas viveceti iti atthaḥ
translated: He is intent on happiness, but he forsakes the good, that is, virtue and the other factors of the dispensation, which lead to the happiness of serenity, insight, path, fruit, and Nibbana. The meaning is that he completely separates himself from them.

original: Evaṃ paṭhamagāthāya “kammārāmataṃ saṅgaṇikārāmataṃ paccayagedhañca vajjethā”ti ovaditvā
analyzed: evam paṭhama gāthāya kamma ārāmatam saṅgaṇikā ārāmatam paccaya gedham ca vajjetha ati ovaditvā
translated: Having thus advised in the first stanza, “Abandon the delight in work, the delight in company, and the pursuit of requisites,”

original: idāni sakkārābhilāsaṃ garahanto dutiyaṃ gāthamāha. Tassattho – yā ayaṃ bhikkhāya
analyzed: idāni sakkāra abhilāsam garahantaḥ dutiyam gātham āha tassa atthaḥ yā ayam bhikkhāya
translated: Now, in order to censure the desire for honour, he uttered the second stanza.

original: upagatānaṃ pabbajitānaṃ kulesu gehavāsīhi guṇasambhāvanāya karīyamānā vandanā pūjanā🔽ca, yasmā taṃ abhāvitattānaṃ osīdāpanaṭṭhena malinabhāvakaraṇaṭṭhena ca paṅko kaddamoti
analyzed: upagatānam pabbajitānam kulesu geha vāsīhi guṇa sambhāvanāya karīyamānā vandanā pūjanā  ca yasmai tam abhāvita ttānam osīdāpana ṭhena malina bhāva karaṇa ṭṭhena ca paṅko kaddamaḥ ti
translated: Now, in order to censure the desire for honour, he uttered the second stanza. Its meaning is this: This saluting and worshipping, which is done by householders towards the homeless ones who have gone forth into homelessness, in the form of an esteeming of their virtues,

original: buddhādayo ariyā pavedayuṃ abbhaññaṃsu pavedesuṃ vā, yasmā ca apariññātakkhandhānaṃ🔽andhaputhujjanānaṃ sakkārābhilāsaṃ duviññeyyasabhāvatāya pīḷājananato anto tudanato🔽duruddharaṇato ca sukhumaṃ sallaṃ durubbahaṃ pavedayuṃ, tato eva sakkāro kāpurisena
analyzed: buddha ādayaḥ ariyā pavedayum vā yasmā ca a pariññāta kkhandhānam  andha puthujjanānam sakkāra abhilāsam du viññeyya sabhāva tāya pīḷā jananataḥ antar tudanataḥ  duruddharaṇataḥ ca sukhumam sallam durubbaham tatas eva sakkāraḥ kāpurisena
translated: is called by the Noble Ones, the Buddhas, etc., ‘mud’ and ‘dirt’, in the sense of causing the sinking down of those who are undeveloped in mind, and in the sense of causing the defilement of their minds.🔽And because it is a subtle dart, hard to extract, hard to pull out, because it causes suffering by the twofold nature of its unknowability, they call it a dart for those who are ignorant of the aggregates,

original: dujjaho duppajaheyyo tassa pahānapaṭipattiyā appaṭipajjanato. Sakkārābhilāsappahānena
analyzed: dujjahaḥ duppajaheyyo tassa pahāna paṭipattiyāḥ a paṭipajjanataḥ sakkāra abhilāsa ppahānena
translated: the ordinary men who are blind. And because it is hard to abandon, hard to give up, by one who does not practice the way of abandoning it, the desire for honour,

original: hi sakkāro pahīno hoti, tasmā tassa pahānāya āyogo karaṇīyoti dasseti –
analyzed: hi sakkāro pahīnaḥ hoti tasmā tassa pahānāya āyogo karaṇīyaḥ iti dasseti
translated: is hard to abandon for a bad person. Thus he shows that the effort should be made for its abandoning.

original: “Na parassupanidhāya, kammaṃ maccassa pāpakaṃ;
analyzed: na parassa upanidhāya kammam maccassa pāpakam
translated: “Not for another’s sake should one, a mortal, do a wicked deed.

original: Attanā taṃ na seveyya, kammabandhū hi mātiyā.
analyzed: attanā tam na seveyya kamma bandhū hi mātiyā
translated: One should not do that which one would not like done to oneself. For kinsmen are one’s own acts.

original: “Na pare vacanā coro, na pare vacanā muni;
analyzed: na pare coraḥ na pare
translated: “Not for another’s sake is one a thief, not for another’s sake is one a sage.

original: Attā ca naṃ yathā vedi, devāpi naṃ tathā vidū.
analyzed: attā ca nam yathā vedi devā api nam tathā vidū
translated: As one knows oneself, so does the deva know one.

original: “Pare ca na vijānanti, mayamettha yamāmase;
analyzed: pare ca na vijānanti mayam ettha yamāmase
translated: “Others do not know here that we are restrained.

original: Ye ca tattha vijānanti, tato sammanti medhagā.
analyzed: ye ca tattha vijānanti tatas sammanti medhagā
translated: But those who know here are restrained by that.

original: “Jīvate vāpi sappañño, api vittaparikkhayo;
analyzed: jīvate vā api sappaññaḥ api vitta parikkhayaḥ
translated: “The wise one lives even though his wealth be lost.

original: Paññāya ca alābhena, vittavāpi na jīvati.
analyzed: paññāya ca alābhena vittavā api na jīvati
translated: But the wealthless one does not live even though he gain wisdom.

original: “Sabbaṃ suṇāti sotena, sabbaṃ passati cakkhunā;
analyzed: sabbam suṇāti sotena sabbam passati cakkhunā
translated: “He hears all by means of the ear, he sees all by means of the eye.

original: Na ca diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ dhīro, sabbaṃ ujjhitumarahati.
analyzed: na ca diṭṭham sutam dhīro sabbam ujjhitum arahati
translated: But the wise one should not abandon all that is seen and heard.

original: “Cakkhumāssa yathā andho, sotavā badhiro yathā;
analyzed: cakkhumā assa yathā andho sotavā badhiraḥ yathā
translated: “As if he were blind, though he have eyes, as if he were deaf, though he have ears,

original: Paññavāssa yathā mūgo, balavā dubbaloriva;
analyzed: yathā mūgaḥ balavā dubbaloḥ iva
translated: as if he were dumb, though he have wisdom, as if he were weak, though he have strength,

original: Atha atthe samuppanne, sayetha matasāyika”nti. –
analyzed: atha atthe samuppanne sayetha matasāyikanti
translated: then, when the matter has arisen, he should lie down as if he were dead.”

original: Imā cha gāthā rañño pajjotassa ovādavasena abhāsi. So kira brāhmaṇe saddahitvā pasughātayaññaṃ
analyzed: imā cha gāthā raññaḥ pajjotassa ovāda vasena abhāsi saḥ kira brāhmaṇe saddahitvā pasughāta yaññam
translated: These six stanzas were spoken by the Elder Mahā-Moggallāna to King Pajjota as advice. It seems that he, having believed in the brāhmaṇas, was preparing to perform a sacrifice in which cattle were slaughtered.

original: kāreti, kammaṃ asodhetvāva acore corasaññāya daṇḍesi, aṭṭakaraṇe ca assāmike sāmike
analyzed: kāreti kammam a sodhetvā ava a core cora saññāya daṇḍesi aṭṭa karaṇe ca a ssāmike sāmike

if he accuses one who has not been ejected for not

original: karoti, sāmike ca assāmike. Tato naṃ thero vivecetuṃ “na parassā”tiādinā cha gāthā abhāsi.🔽Tattha na parassupanidhāya, kammaṃ maccassa pāpakanti parassa maccassa sattassa upanidhāya
analyzed: karoti sāmike ca assāmike tatas nam theraḥ vivecetum na parassa ati ādinā cha gāthāḥ abhāsi  tattha na parassa upanidhāya kammam maccassa pāpakam ti parassa maccassa sattassa upanidhāya
translated: He had the thief punished without having the offence investigated. He made a non-owner into an owner. He made an owner into a non-owner. Then the Elder recited six stanzas beginning with the words, “Not for another’s sake” in order to instruct him.

original: uddissa kāraṇaṃ katvā pāpakaṃ vadhabandhādikammaṃ na seveyya, parena na kārāpeyyāti
analyzed: uddissa kāraṇam katvā pāpakam vadha bandha ādi kammam na seveyya parena na kārāpeyya ati
translated: Herein, not for another’s sake, an offence for a mortal, he should not pursue: he should not pursue, should not do, should not cause to be done, an offence, a bad action such as killing, binding, etc., for the sake of another, for the benefit of another, for the welfare of another.

original: attho. Attanā taṃ na seveyyāti attanāpi taṃ pāpakaṃ na kareyya. Kasmā? Kammabandhū
analyzed: attho attanā tam na seveyya ati attanā api tam pāpakam na kareyya kasmai kamma bandhū
translated: The meaning is: he should not pursue it by himself. He should not pursue it by himself: he should not do it by himself. Why? Because:

original: hi mātiyā ime mātiyā maccā kammadāyādā, tasmā attanā ca kiñci pāpakammaṃ na kareyya,
analyzed: hi mātiyāḥ ime mātiyāḥ maccā kamma dāyādā tasmai attanā ca kiñci pāpa kammam na kareyya
translated: Mortals are kinsmen of their deeds, mortals are heirs of their deeds. Therefore he should not do any bad action by himself.

original: parenapi na kārāpeyyāti attho.
analyzed: parena api na kārāpeyyā ati attho
translated: The meaning is: he should not cause it to be done by another.

original: Na pare vacanā coroti attanā coriyaṃ akatvā paravacanā parassa vacanamattena coro
analyzed: na pare vacanā coro ti attanā coriyam a katvā para vacanā parassa vacana mattena coro
translated: Not a thief by another’s word: not a thief by himself, not a thief by another’s word, not a thief by the mere word of another.

original: nāma na hoti, tathā na pare vacanā muni parassa vacanamattena muni suvisuddhakāyavacīmanosamācāro🔽na hoti. Ettha hi pareti vibhattialopaṃ katvā niddeso. Keci pana “paresanti vattabbe
analyzed: nāma na hoti tathā na pare muni parassa vacana mattena muni su visuddha kāya vacī manaḥ samācāraḥ  na hoti ettha hi parā iti vibhatti a lopam katvā niddesaḥ keci pana vattabbe
translated: and he is not called a sage by others, a sage is not one who is merely called a sage by others. He is one whose bodily, verbal and mental conduct are well purified.🔽Herein, the locative case-ending is omitted in the compound “pare” . Some, however, say that the locative case-ending is omitted in the compound “pare” ,

original: pareti saṃ-kāralopaṃ katvā niddiṭṭha”nti vadanti. Attā ca naṃ yathā vedīti naṃ sattaṃ
analyzed: parā iti saṃkāra lopam katvā vadanti attā ca nam yathā vedi iti nam sattam
translated: which should be analyzed as “pare” .

original: tassa attā cittaṃ yathā “ahaṃ parisuddho, aparisuddho vā”ti yāthāvato avedi jānāti.
analyzed: tassa attā cittam yathā aham parisuddhaḥ a parisuddhaḥ vāti yāthāvataḥ avedi jānāti
translated: The self knows him as he is: the self of that person, his mind, knows him as he is, as pure or impure.

original: Devāpi naṃ tathā vidūti visuddhidevā, upapattidevā ca tathā vidū vidanti jānanti,
analyzed: devā api nam tathā vidū ti visuddhidevāḥ upapattidevā ca tathā vidū vidanti jānanti
translated: The gods also know him as such: the gods of purity and the gods of rebirth know him as such, know him as he is.

original: tasmā sayaṃ tādisā devā ca pamāṇaṃ suddhāsuddhānaṃ suddhāsuddhabhāvajānane, na ye
analyzed: tasmai sayam tādisāḥ devā ca suddha asuddha nam suddha asuddha bhāva jānane na ye
translated: Therefore, the gods who are like him are the standard for knowing purity and impurity, not those who are not like him.

original: keci icchādosaparetā sattāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: keci icchā dosa paretā sattā ati adhippāyo
translated: The meaning is: those who are influenced by the faults of desire.

original: Pareti paṇḍite ṭhapetvā tato aññe, kusalākusalasāvajjānavajjaṃ kammaṃ kammaphalaṃ
analyzed: parā iti paṇḍite ṭhapetvā tatas aññe kusala akusala sāvajja anavajjam kammam kamma phalam
translated: Others: those other than the wise. Wholesome and unwholesome, blameable and blameless, action and the result of action,

original: kāyassa asubhataṃ saṅkhārānaṃ aniccataṃ ajānantā idha pare nāma. Te mayamettha imasmiṃ
analyzed: kāyassa asubha tam saṅkhārānaṃ anicca tam a jānantāḥ idha pare nāma te mayam ettha imasmin
translated: Not knowing the foulness of the body and the impermanence of formations, they are called “others” here. They are

original: jīvaloke yamāma uparamāma, “satataṃ samitaṃ maccu santikaṃ gacchāmā”ti na jānanti.
analyzed: jīva loke yamāmaḥ uparamāma satatam samitam mat cu santikam gacchāma ati na jānanti
translated: Not knowing the foulness of the body and the impermanence of formations, they do not know that here in this world of life they are “going to Yama” , that is, they are “coming to an end” , that they are “constantly and continuously approaching death” .

original: Ye ca tattha vijānantīti ye ca tattha paṇḍitā “mayaṃ maccu samīpaṃ gacchāmā”ti vijānanti.🔽Tato sammanti medhagāti evañhi te jānantā medhagānaṃ paravihiṃsanānaṃ vūpasamāya
analyzed: ye ca tattha vijānanti iti ye ca tattha paṇḍitāḥ mayam mad cu samīpam gacchāma ati vijānanti  evam hi te jānantā medha gānam para vihiṃsanānam vūpasamāya
