original: Pasaṃsitanti buddhādīhi pasaṭṭhaṃ, vaṇṇitaṃ thomitaṃ atthīti yojanā. Taṃ panetaṃ
analyzed: pasaṃsitanti buddha ādīhi pasaṭṭham vaṇṇitam thomitam atthi iti yojanā tam pana itam
translated: “Praised by the Noble Ones”: recommended by the Enlightened One, etc., praised, extolled, recommended.

original: sīlaṃ gahaṭṭhasīlaṃ pabbajitasīlanti duvidhaṃ. Tattha gahaṭṭhasīlaṃ nāma pañcasikkhāpadasīlaṃ,
analyzed: sīlam gahaṭṭha sīlam pabbajita sīlanti duvidham tattha gahaṭṭha sīlam nāma pañca sikkhāpada sīlam
translated: This virtue is of two kinds, that is to say, virtue of the house life and virtue of the renunciation of the house life. Herein, virtue of the house life is the virtue of the five training precepts,

original: yaṃ gahaṭṭhena rakkhituṃ sakkā. Pabbajitasīlaṃ nāma dasasikkhāpadasīlaṃ upādāya sabbaṃ
analyzed: yam gaha ṭṭhena rakkhitum sakkā pabbajita sīlam nāma dasa sikkhāpada sīlam upādāya sabbam
translated: which can be observed by one who remains in the house life. Virtue of the renunciation of the house life is all the virtue beginning with the ten training precepts,

original: catupārisuddhisīlaṃ, tayidaṃ sabbampi akhaṇḍādibhāvena aparāmaṭṭhatāya “kalyāṇa”nti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: catu pārisuddhi sīlam tayidam sabbam pi akhaṇḍa ādi bhāvena aparāmaṭṭha tāya kalyāṇan ti veditabbam
translated: and the virtue of the fourfold purity . This virtue should be understood as “good” because it is unpunctured, etc., and because it is unadulterated by the following:

original: Saṅghe pasādo yassatthīti “suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho”tiādinā ariyasaṅghe🔽pasādo saddhā yassa puggalassa atthi acalo suppatiṭṭhitoti ānetvā yojetabbaṃ. Ujubhūtañca🔽dassananti diṭṭhivaṅkābhāvato kilesavaṅkābhāvato ca ujubhūtaṃ. Akuṭilaṃ ajimhaṃ kammassakatādassanañceva
analyzed: saṅghe pasādaḥ yassa atthi iti suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvaka saṅghaḥ ti ādinā ariya saṅghe  pasādaḥ saddhā yassa puggalassa atthi acalo suppatiṭṭhito ti ānetvā yojetabbam uju bhūtam ca  dassananti diṭṭhi vaṅka abhāvato kilesa vaṅka abhāvato ca uju bhūtam akuṭilam a jimham kammassaka tā dassanam ca eva
translated: He who has confidence in the Saṅgha is one who has unshakable, well-established confidence in the noble Saṅgha,🔽in the four pairs of persons, the eight types of individuals.

original: sappaccayanāmarūpadassanañcāti duvidhampi dassanaṃ yassa atthi acalaṃ suppatiṭṭhitanti
analyzed: sappaccaya nāma rūpa dassanam ca ati duvidham pi dassanam yassa atthi acalam suppatiṭṭhitanti
translated: He who has the straight view is one who has the twofold straight view, the view that sees the self-responsibility for kamma and the view that sees the dependent origination of name-and-form.🔽He who has unshakable, well-established confidence in the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha and the straight view is called “one who is not poor.”

original: yojanā. Adaliddoti taṃ āhu saddhādhanaṃ, sīladhanaṃ, sutadhanaṃ, cāgadhanaṃ, paññādhananti
analyzed: yojanā adaliddā iti tam āhu saddhā dhanam sīla dhanam suta dhanam cāga dhanam paññā dhananti
translated: The noble ones, the Buddhas, etc., say that confidence is the wealth of faith, virtue, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

original: imesaṃ suvisuddhānaṃ dhanānaṃ atthitāya “adaliddo”ti taṃ tādisaṃ puggalaṃ buddhādayo🔽ariyā āhu. Amoghaṃ tassa jīvitaṃ tassa tathārūpassa jīvitaṃ diṭṭhadhammikādiatthādhigamena
analyzed: imesam su visuddhānam dhanānam atthitāya adaliddaḥ ti tam tādisam puggalam buddha ādayaḥ  ariyāḥ āhu amogham tassa jīvitam tassa tathārūpassa jīvitam diṭṭhadhammika ādi attha adhigamena
translated: Because he possesses these very pure kinds of wealth, he is called “one who is not poor.”

original: amoghaṃ avañjhaṃ saphalamevāti āhūti attho.
analyzed: amogham avañjham sa phalam eva ati attho
translated: The noble ones say that the life of such a person is not fruitless, not barren, but fruitful, because he has attained the goal of the present life and the future goal.

original: Tasmāti, yasmā yathāvuttasaddhādiguṇasamannāgato puggalo “adaliddo amoghajīvito”ti🔽vuccati, tasmā ahampi tathārūpo bhaveyyanti. Saddhañca…pe… sāsananti “sabbapāpassa
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmai yathā vutta saddhā ādi guṇa samannāgataḥ puggalaḥ adaliddaḥ amogha jīvito ti  vuccati tasmai aham pi tathārūpaḥ bhaveyyanti saddhañcape sāsananti sabba pāpassa
translated: Therefore: because a person endowed with the faith, etc., mentioned above is called “not poor, one who lives not in vain,” therefore I too will be such.

original: akaraṇa”ntiādinā vuttaṃ buddhānaṃ sāsanaṃ anussaranto kulaputto vuttappabhedaṃ saddhañceva
analyzed: akaraṇa nti ādinā vuttam buddhānam sāsanam anussarantaḥ kula puttaḥ vutta ppabhedam saddham ca eva
translated: And recollecting the Dispensation of the Buddhas, which is stated thus: “Abstinence from all evil,” etc.,

original: sīlañca dhammadassanahetukaṃ dhamme sunicchayā vimokkhabhūtaṃ pasādañca anuyuñjeyya vaḍḍheyyāti.
analyzed: sīlañca dhamma dassana hetukam dhamme su nicchayā vimokkha bhūtam pasādañca anuyuñjeyya vaḍḍheyya ati
translated: the clansman should practice and increase the faith, virtue, and confidence of the kind already described, which have the vision of the Dhamma as their cause, and which are the basis for the deliverance of the mind through confidence in the Dhamma.

original: Evaṃ thero bhikkhūnaṃ dhammadesanāmukhena attani vijjamāne guṇe pakāsento aññaṃ byākāsi.
analyzed: evam theraḥ bhikkhūnam dhamma desanā mukhena attani vijjamāne guṇe pakāsentaḥ aññam byākāsi
translated: Thus the elder declared his own virtues by way of a discourse on the Dhamma to the bhikkhus and thereby revealed himself.

original: Sirimittattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sirimitta thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the verses of the elder Sirimata is finished.

original: 3. Mahāpanthakattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
translated: Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Mahapanthaka

original: Yadā paṭhamamaddakkhintiādikā āyasmato mahāpanthakattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayaṃ
analyzed: yadā āyasmataḥ mahāpanthaka ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayaṃ
translated: The verses beginning with the words “When I first saw” were spoken by the elder Mahapanthaka. What is the origin of these verses?

original: kira padumuttarassa bhagavato kāle haṃsavatīnagare vibhavasampanno kuṭumbiyo hutvā
analyzed: kira padumuttarassa bhagavataḥ kāle haṃsavatī nagare vibhava sampannaḥ kuṭumbiyaḥ hutvā
translated: It is said that in the time of the Buddha Padumuttara he was reborn in the city of Hansavati as a wealthy householder.

original: ekadivasaṃ satthu santike dhammaṃ suṇanto satthāraṃ ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ saññāvivaṭṭakusalānaṃ
analyzed: eka divasam satthu santike dhammaṃ suṇanto satthāram ekam bhikkhum saññā vivaṭṭa kusalānam
translated: One day, while listening to the Teacher preach the Law, he heard the Teacher declare a certain monk to be the most skillful of all his disciples in the exercise of the faculty of recollecting his former births.

original: aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapentaṃ disvā sayampi taṃ ṭhānantaraṃ patthento buddhappamukhassa bhikkhusaṅghassa🔽sattāhaṃ mahādānaṃ pavattetvā, “bhante, yaṃ bhikkhuṃ tumhe ito sattadivasamatthake
analyzed: agga ṭṭhāne ṭhapentam disvā sayam pi tam ṭhāna antaram patthentaḥ buddha ppamukhassa bhikkhu saṅghassa  sattāham mahādānam pavattetvā bhante yam bhikkhum tumhe ito satta divasa matthake
translated: One day, as he was listening to the Law in the presence of the Teacher, he saw the Teacher place a certain monk in the foremost position as regards skill in the revolution of thought.

original: – ‘saññāvivaṭṭakusalānaṃ ayaṃ mama sāsane aggo’ti etadagge ṭhapayittha, ahampi imassa
analyzed: saññā vivaṭṭa kusalānam ayam mama sāsane aggo ti etad agge ṭhapayittha aham pi imassa
translated: Thereupon he also made a vow, saying, “Reverend Sir, on the seventh day from this time you will place a certain monk in the foremost position as regards skill in the revolution of thought.

original: adhikārakammassa balena so bhikkhu viya anāgate ekassa buddhassa sāsane aggo bhaveyya”nti🔽patthanaṃ akāsi. Kaniṭṭhabhātā panassa tatheva bhagavati adhikārakammaṃ katvā manomayassa
analyzed: adhikāra kammassa balena so bhikkhu viya anāgate ekassa buddhassa sāsane aggaḥ bhaveyyanti  patthanam akāsi kaniṭṭha bhātā panassa tathā iva bhagavati adhikāra kammam katvā manomayassa
translated: I also, by the power of this deed of merit, may I become like that monk, the foremost in the dispensation of a certain Buddha in the future.”

original: kāyassābhinimmānaṃ cetovivaṭṭakosallanti dvinnaṃ aṅgānaṃ vasena vuttanayeneva paṇidhānaṃ
analyzed: kāyassa abhinimmānam cetaḥ vivaṭṭa kosallanti dvinnam aṅgānam vasena vutta nayena iva paṇidhānam
translated: His younger brother also performed a like deed of merit in the presence of the same Buddha, and made a vow, saying, “May I become the foremost in the dispensation of a certain Buddha in the future, as regards the creation of a mind-made body and skill in the revolution of thought.”

original: akāsi. Bhagavā dvinnampi patthanaṃ anantarāyena samijjhanabhāvaṃ disvā “anāgate kappasatasahassamatthake
analyzed: akāsi bhagavā dvinnam pi patthanam anantarāyena samijjhana bhāvam disvā anāgate kappa sata sahassa matthake
translated: The Blessed One, seeing that the wishes of both would be fulfilled without hindrance, declared: “In the future, after a hundred thousand aeons,

original: gotamassa nāma sammāsambuddhassa sāsane tumhākaṃ patthanā samijjhissatī”ti byākāsi.
analyzed: gotamassa nāma sammāsambuddhassa sāsane tumhākam patthanā samijjhissati iti byākāsi
translated: in the dispensation of the Supremely Enlightened One named Gotama, your wishes will be fulfilled.”

original: Te ubhopi janā tattha yāvajīvaṃ puññāni katvā tato cuto devaloke nibbattiṃsu. Tattha
analyzed: te ubho api janā tattha yāvajīvam puññāni katvā tatas cutaḥ deva loke nibbattiṃsu tattha
translated: Both of them, having performed works of merit there as long as they lived, passed away and were reborn in the world of the gods.

original: mahāpanthakassa antarākataṃ kalyāṇadhammaṃ na kathīyati. Cūḷapanthako pana kassapassa
analyzed: mahā panthakassa antarākatam kalyāṇa dhammam na kathīyati cūḷa panthakaḥ pana kassapassa
translated: The good qualities of Mahāpanthaka are not mentioned in the texts. But Cūḷapanthaka, having gone forth in the dispensation of the Master Kassapa,

original: bhagavato sāsane pabbajitvā vīsati vassasahassāni odātakasiṇakammaṃ katvā devapure
analyzed: bhagavato sāsane pabbajitvā vīsati vassa sahassāni odāta kasiṇa kammam katvā devapure
translated: practised the meditation on the white kasiṇa for twenty thousand years and was reborn in the city of the gods.

original: nibbatti. Apadāne pana “cūḷapanthako padumuttarassa bhagavato kāle tāpaso hutvā himavante
analyzed: nibbatti apadāne pana cūḷapanthako padumuttarassa bhagavataḥ kāle tāpasaḥ hutvā himavante
translated: But in the Apadāna it is said: “Cūḷapanthaka, in the time of the Blessed One Padumuttara, being an ascetic, dwelt in the Himalayas.🔽Seeing the Blessed One there, he worshipped him with a handful of flowers.”

original: vasanto tattha bhagavantaṃ disvā pupphacchattena pūjaṃ akāsī”ti āgataṃ. Tesaṃ devamanussesu
analyzed: vasantaḥ tattha bhagavantam disvā puppha chattena pūjam akāsi iti āgatam tesam deva manussesu
translated: In the world of the gods and in the world of men

original: saṃsarantānaṃyeva kappasatasahassaṃ atikkantaṃ. Atha amhākaṃ satthā abhisambodhiṃ
analyzed: saṃsarantānam yeva kappa sata sahassam atikkantam atha amhākam satthā abhisambodhim
translated: and they had been wandering on in Saṃsāra for a hundred thousand cycles of time. Then our Teacher,

original: patvā pavattitavaradhammacakko rājagahaṃ upanissāya veḷuvane mahāvihāre viharati.
analyzed: patvā pavattita vara dhamma cakkaḥ rājagaham upanissāya veḷuvane mahāvihāre viharati
translated: after attaining to the Supreme Enlightenment, and setting rolling the excellent Wheel of the Law, was dwelling in the Great Monastery in the Bamboo Grove, in the neighbourhood of Rājagaha.

original: Tena ca samayena rājagahe dhanaseṭṭhissa dhītā attano dāsena saddhiṃ santhavaṃ katvā
analyzed: tena ca samayena rājagahe dhanaseṭṭhissa dhītā attanaḥ dāsena saddhim santhavam katvā
translated: And at that time in Rājagaha the daughter of a rich man, having had an intrigue with her slave,

original: ñātakehi bhītā hatthasāraṃ gahetvā tena saddhiṃ palāyitvā aññattha vasantī taṃ paṭicca🔽gabbhaṃ labhitvā paripakkagabbhā “ñātigharaṃ gantvā vijāyissāmī”ti gacchantī antarāmaggeyeva🔽puttaṃ vijāyitvā sāminā nivattitā pubbe vasitaṭṭhāne vasantī puttassa panthe jātattā
analyzed: ñātakehi bhītā hattha sāram gahetvā tena saddhim palāyitvā aññattha vasantī tam paṭicca  gabbham labhitvā paripakka gabbhā ñāti gharam gantvā vijāyissāmi iti gacchantī  puttam vijāyitvā sāminā nivattitā pubbe vasita ṭṭhāne vasantī puttassa panthe jāta ttā
translated: was frightened by her relations, and taking her slave with her, fled away, and lived somewhere or other.🔽And in course of time she became pregnant, and when her time was come, thinking, “I will go to my relations’ house and give birth,” she set out on her journey, but on the way🔽she gave birth to a son. Her husband turned back and went to the place where she had formerly lived, and she, living there, gave her son the name of Panthaka,

original: panthakoti, nāmaṃ akāsi. Tasmiṃ ādhāvitvā vidhāvitvā vicaraṇakāle tameva paṭicca
analyzed: panthakā uti nāmam akāsi tasmin ādhāvitvā vidhāvitvā vicaraṇa kāle tam eva paṭicca
translated: because he was born on the road. While he was running about and playing, she became pregnant again,

original: dutiyaṃ gabbhaṃ paṭilabhitvā paripakkagabbhā pubbe vuttanayeneva antarāmagge puttaṃ
analyzed: dutiyam gabbham paṭilabhitvā paripakka gabbhā pubbe vutta nayena iva antarāmagge puttam
translated: and when her time was come, she gave birth to a son on the way, as before.

original: vijāyitvā sāminā nivattitā jeṭṭhaputtassa mahāpanthakoti kaniṭṭhassa cūḷapanthakoti
analyzed: vijāyitvā sāminā nivattitā jeṭṭha puttassa mahā panthako ti kaniṭṭhassa cūḷa panthako ti
translated: When she had given birth, her husband turned back and went home. The elder son was named Mahāpanthaka, the younger Cūḷapanthaka.

original: nāmaṃ katvā yathāvasitaṭṭhāneyeva vasantī anukkamena dārakesu vaḍḍhantesu tehi, “amma,
analyzed: nāmam katvā yathā vasita ṭṭhāneyā iva vasantī anukkamena dārakesu vaḍḍhantesu tehi amma
translated: They remained where they were, and as the boys grew up, they said to their mother, “Mother,

original: ayyakakulaṃ no dassehī”ti nibundhiyamānā dārake mātāpitūnaṃ santikaṃ pesesi. Tato
analyzed: ayyaka kulam naḥ dassehi iti nibundhiyamānā dārake mātā pitūnam santikam pesesi tatas
translated: show us the house of our uncle.” She was importuned by them until at last she sent the boys to their father and mother.

original: paṭṭhāya dārakā dhanaseṭṭhino gehe vaḍḍhanti. Tesu cūḷapanthako atidaharo. Mahāpanthako🔽pana ayyakena saddhiṃ bhagavato santikaṃ gato satthāraṃ disvā saha dassanena paṭiladdhasaddho🔽dhammaṃ sutvā upanissayasampannatāya pabbajitukāmo hutvā pitāmahaṃ āpucchi. So satthu
analyzed: paṭṭhāya dārakāḥ dhana seṭṭhinaḥ gehe vaḍḍhanti tesu cūḷa panthakaḥ ati daharaḥ mahā panthako  pana ayyakena saddhim bhagavato santikam gataḥ satthāram disvā saha dassanena paṭiladdha saddho  dhammam sutvā upanissaya sampanna tāya pabbajitu kāmaḥ hutvā pitāmaham āpucchi so satthu
translated: From that time on the boys grew up in the house of the treasurer. Cūḷapanthaka was very young, but Mahāpanthaka🔽went with his uncle to the Teacher. As soon as he saw the Teacher, he obtained faith.🔽When he heard the Law, he desired to become a monk, being ripe for the reception of the Law. He asked his grandfather, and the latter

original: tamatthaṃ ārocetvā taṃ pabbājesi. So pabbajitvā bahuṃ buddhavacanaṃ uggaṇhitvā paripuṇṇavasso
analyzed: tam attham ārocetvā tam pabbājesi saḥ pabbajitvā bahum buddha vacanam uggaṇhitvā paripuṇṇa vassaḥ
translated: informed the Teacher of the facts and caused him to be admitted to the Order. He became a monk, learned much of the Buddha’s Word, and at the end of the rainy season,

original: upasampajjitvā yonisomanasikāre kammaṃ karonto visesato catunnaṃ arūpajjhānānaṃ lābhī
analyzed: upasampajjitvā yonisomanasikāre kammaṃ karontaḥ visesato catunnam arūpajjhānānam lābhī
translated: and after he had attained it, he devoted himself to the practice of careful consideration and became a master of the four immaterial states of mind.

original: hutvā tato vuṭṭhāya vipassanaṃ ussukkāpetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Iti so saññāvivaṭṭakusalānaṃ
analyzed: hutvā tatas vuṭṭhāya vipassanam ussukkāpetvā arahattam pāpuṇi iti so saññā vivaṭṭa kusalānam
translated: After emerging from that attainment, he developed insight and attained arahatship. Thus he became the foremost of those who are skilled in the reversal of perception.

original: aggo jāto. So jhānasukhena phalasukhena vītināmento ekadivasaṃ attano paṭipattiṃ
analyzed: aggaḥ jātaḥ saḥ jhāna sukhena phala sukhena vītināmentaḥ eka divasam attano paṭipattim
translated: Living in the bliss of jhāna and the bliss of fruition, one day he surveyed his own career of practice,

original: paccavekkhitvā adhigatasampattiṃ paṭicca sañjātasomanasso sīhanādaṃ nadanto –
analyzed: paccavekkhitvā adhigata sampattim paṭicca sañjāta somanassaḥ sīha nādam nadantaḥ
translated: and in view of his attainment he became filled with joy. Roaring his lion’s roar, he exclaimed:

original: “Yadā paṭhamamaddakkhiṃ, satthāramakutobhayaṃ;
analyzed: yadā satthāram akutobhayam
translated: “When I first beheld the Teacher, the One Free from Fear,

original: Tato me ahu saṃvego, passitvā purisuttamaṃ.
analyzed: tatas me ahu saṃvegaḥ passitvā purisa uttamam
translated: I was filled with awe, beholding the Supreme Man.

original: “Siriṃ hatthehi pādehi, yo paṇāmeyya āgataṃ;
analyzed: sirim hatthehi pādehi yaḥ paṇāmeyya āgatam
translated: “He who would drive away glory, which comes to him with hands and feet,

original: Etādisaṃ so satthāraṃ, ārādhetvā virādhaye.🔽“Tadāhaṃ puttadārañca, dhanadhaññañca chaḍḍayiṃ;
analyzed: etādisam saḥ satthāram ārādhetvā virādhaye  tadā aham putta dāram ca dhana dhaññam ca chaḍḍayim
translated: Must serve such a Teacher and then abandon him.🔽“Then I abandoned my children and wife,

original: Kesamassūni chedetvā, pabbajiṃ anagāriyaṃ.
analyzed: kesa massūni chedetvā pabbajim anagāriyam
translated: My wealth and grain, and had my hair and beard shaved off, And went forth into homelessness.

original: “Sikkhāsājīvasampanno, indriyesu susaṃvuto;
analyzed: sikkhā sājīva sampannaḥ indriyesu su saṃvutaḥ
translated: “Endowed with training and livelihood, my faculties well controlled,

original: Namassamāno sambuddhaṃ, vihāsiṃ aparājito.
analyzed: namassamānaḥ sambuddham vihāsim aparājitaḥ
translated: I lived in honor, undefeated, paying homage to the Enlightened One.

original: “Tato me paṇidhī āsi, cetaso abhipatthito;
analyzed: tatas me paṇidhī āsi cetasaḥ abhipatthitaḥ
translated: “Then this aspiration arose in me,

original: Na nisīde muhuttampi, taṇhāsalle anūhate.
analyzed: na nisīde taṇhā salle
translated: I did not sit down even for a moment,

original: “Tassa mevaṃ viharato, passa vīriyaparakkamaṃ;
analyzed: tassa mā evam viharataḥ passa vīriya parakkamam
translated: As I was living thus, see my energy and exertion!

original: Tisso vijjā anuppattā, kataṃ buddhassa sāsanaṃ.
analyzed: tissaḥ vijjāḥ anuppattā katam buddhassa sāsanam
translated: The three knowledges have been attained, the Buddha’s word has been fulfilled.

original: “Pubbenivāsaṃ jānāmi, dibbacakkhu visodhitaṃ;
analyzed: pubbenivāsam jānāmi dibba cakkhu visodhitam
translated: I know my manifold past abodes, the divine eye has been purified;

original: Arahā dakkhiṇeyyomhi, vippamutto nirūpadhi.
analyzed: arahā dakkhiṇeyyaḥ ahi vippamuttaḥ nirūpadhi
translated: I am worthy of offerings, liberated, without acquisitions.

original: “Tato ratyāvivasāne, sūriyuggamanaṃ pati;
analyzed: tatas ratyā vivasāne sūri yuj gamanam pati
translated: Then, at the end of the night, at sunrise,🔽Having destroyed all craving, I sat down on the seat.

original: Sabbaṃ taṇhaṃ visosetvā, pallaṅkena upāvisi”nti. – imā gāthā abhāsi;
analyzed: sabbam taṇham visosetvā pallaṅkena upāvisinti imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: These verses were spoken:

original: Tattha yadāti yasmiṃ kāle. Paṭhamanti ādito. Addakkhinti passiṃ, satthāranti, bhagavantaṃ.
analyzed: tattha yadā iti yasmin kāle paṭhamanti āditas passim satthāranti bhagavantam
translated: Herein, as to the words then, at that time, at the beginning: he saw, he looked, the Teacher, the Blessed One, is what is said.🔽Without fear from anywhere: fearless. This is the meaning here:

original: Akutobhayanti nibbhayaṃ. Ayañhettha attho – sabbesaṃ bhayahetūnaṃ bodhimūleyeva pahīnattā
analyzed: akutobhayanti nibbhayam ayam ha ittha atthaḥ sabbesam bhaya hetūnam bodhi mūleya iva pahīna ttā
translated: because all causes for fear had been abandoned at the foot of the Bodhi Tree,

original: kutocipi bhayābhāvato akutobhayaṃ nibbhayaṃ, catuvesārajjavisāradaṃ diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaparamatthehi
analyzed: kutocipi bhaya abhāvataḥ akutobhayam nibbhayam catu vesārajja visāradam diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika paramatthehi
translated: because of the absence of fear from anywhere, without fear from anywhere, fearless, confident with the four confidences, in the highest good of the present life and the life to come,

original: veneyyānaṃ yathārahamanusāsanato satthāraṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ mayhaṃ pitāmahena saddhiṃ
analyzed: veneyyānam yathāraham anusāsanataḥ satthāram sammāsambuddham mayham pitāmahena saddhim
translated: Because of the teaching of the Dhamma in accordance with the needs of those to be taught, my grandfather went with the Teacher, the Perfectly Enlightened One,

original: gantvā yāya velāya sabbapaṭhamaṃ passiṃ, taṃ purisuttamaṃ sadevake loke aggapuggalaṃ
analyzed: gantvā yāya velāya sabba paṭhamam passim tam purisa uttamam sa devake loke agga puggalam
translated: and at the time when he saw the Best of Men, the foremost person in the world together with the gods,

original: passitvā tato dassanahetu tato dassanato pacchā “ettakaṃ kālaṃ satthāraṃ daṭṭhuṃ
analyzed: passitvā tatas dassana hetu tatas dassanataḥ pacchā ettakam kālam satthāram daṭṭhum
translated: after seeing him, because of that seeing, afterwards, “for so long I did not get to see the Teacher,

original: dhammañca sotuṃ nālattha”nti mayhaṃ saṃvego ahu sahottappaṃ ñāṇaṃ uppajji. Uppannasaṃvego
analyzed: dhammañca sotum na alatthanti mayham saṃvegaḥ ahu saha uttappam ñāṇam uppajji uppanna saṃvegaḥ
translated: and to hear the Dhamma,” there arose in me a sense of spiritual urgency, and knowledge accompanied by shame arose. Having arisen with a sense of urgency,

original: panāhaṃ evaṃ cintesinti dasseti siriṃ hatthehīti gāthāya. Tassattho – yo vibhavatthiko
analyzed: pana aham evam cintesin ti dasseti sirim hatthehi iti gāthāya tassa atthaḥ yaḥ vibhavatthikaḥ
translated: I thought like this, as shown in the verse beginning with “I would drive away with my hands and feet”. The meaning is: a man who is in a state of poverty,

original: puriso “upaṭṭhāyiko hutvā tava santike vasissāmī”ti saviggahaṃ siriṃ sayane upagataṃ
analyzed: purisaḥ upaṭṭhāyikaḥ hutvā tava santike vasissāmi iti sa viggaham sirim sayane upagatam
translated: having gone to a bed, having approached a fortune with a family, saying: “having become a servant I will live near you”,

original: hatthehi ca pādehi ca koṭṭento paṇāmeyya nīhareyya, so tathārūpo alakkhikapuriso
analyzed: hatthehi ca pādehi ca koṭṭento paṇāmeyya nīhareyya saḥ tathārūpaḥ alakkhika puriso
translated: having beaten it with his hands and feet, would drive it away, would remove it, that kind of unlucky man,

original: etādisaṃ satthāraṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ ārādhetvā imasmiṃ navame khaṇe paṭilabhitvā virādhaye
analyzed: etādisam satthāram sammāsambuddham ārādhetvā imasmin navame khaṇe paṭilabhitvā virādhaye
translated: having propitiated such a Teacher, the Perfectly Enlightened One, having obtained him in this ninth moment, would drive him away,

original: tassa ovādākaraṇena taṃ virajjheyya, ahaṃ panevaṃ na karomīti adhippāyo. Tenāha “tadāhaṃ…pe…
analyzed: tassa ovāda akaraṇena tam virajjheyya aham pana evam na karomi iti adhippāyaḥ tena āha tadā aham pe
translated: and he would be free from that by not doing what he advised. But I do not do so. This is the meaning. Therefore he said: “Then I …

original: anagāriya”nti. Tattha chaḍḍayinti, pajahiṃ. “Chaḍḍiya”ntipi pāṭho. Nanu ayaṃ thero
analyzed: tattha chaḍḍayinti pajahim chaḍḍiyanti pi pāṭhaḥ nanu ayam thero
translated: left the world.” Herein, he abandoned, he rejected. The reading is also “chaḍḍiya.”

original: dārapariggahaṃ akatvāva pabbajito, so kasmā “puttadārañca chaḍḍayi”nti avocāti? Yathā
analyzed: dāra pariggaham a katvā ava pabbajito saḥ kasmai putta dārañca avoca ati yathā
translated: But did not this Elder Gotama leave the world without taking a wife? Why did he say “I left wife and child”?

original: nāma puriso anibbattaphalameva rukkhaṃ chindanto acchinne tato laddhaphalehi parihīno
analyzed: nāma purisaḥ a nibbatta phalam eva rukkham chindantaḥ a chinne tatas laddha phalehi parihīnaḥ
translated: Just as a man who cuts down a tree that has not yet borne fruit is deprived of the fruit he would have got from it if he had not cut it down,

original: nāma hoti. Evaṃsampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: nāma hoti evaṃsampadam idam daṭṭhabbam
translated: so this should be regarded.

original: Sikkhāsājīvasamāpannoti yā adhisīlasikkhā, tāya ca, yattha bhikkhū saha jīvanti,
analyzed: sikkhā sājīva samāpannaḥ ti yā adhi sīla sikkhā tāya ca yattha bhikkhū saha jīvanti
translated: He had reached the training and the life of purity: the training in higher virtue is the training. And where monks live together

original: ekajīvikā sabhāgavuttino honti, tena bhagavatā paññattasikkhāpadasaṅkhātena sājīvena
analyzed: ekajīvikā sabhāgavuttino honti tena bhagavatā paññatta sikkhāpada saṅkhātena sa ājīvena
translated: they have a common life, they live the life in common. With the life of purity consisting in the training rule announced by the Blessed One,

original: ca samannāgato sikkhanabhāvena samaṅgībhūto, sikkhaṃ paripūrento sājīvañca avītikkamanto
analyzed: ca samannāgataḥ sikkhana bhāvena samaṅgībhūtaḥ sikkham paripūrento sa ājīvam ca a vītikkamanto
translated: he was endowed, he was furnished with the state of one who trains, fulfilling the training, not transgressing the life of purity,

original: hutvā tadubhayaṃ sampādentoti attho. Tena suvisuddhe pātimokkhe sīle patiṭṭhitabhāvaṃ
analyzed: hutvā tat ubhayam sampādento ti attho tena su visuddhe pātimokkhe sīle patiṭṭhita bhāvam
translated: By this he shows that he was established in virtue with the Pāṭimokkha rules well purified.

original: dasseti. Indriyesu susaṃvutoti manacchaṭṭhesu indriyesu suṭṭhu saṃvuto. Rūpādivisayesu🔽uppajjanakānaṃ abhijjhādīnaṃ pavattinivāraṇavasena satikavāṭena supihitacakkhādidvāroti
analyzed: dasseti indriyesu su saṃvutaḥ ti manacchaṭṭhesu indriyesu suṭṭhu saṃvutaḥ rūpa ādi visayesu  uppajjanakānam abhijjhā ādīnam pavatti nivāraṇa vasena sati kavāṭena su pihita cakkha ādi dvārā ti
translated: Well restrained with the sense faculties guarded: well restrained with the six sense faculties, i.e., the mind being the sixth.🔽The meaning is that he was well guarded with the door of the eye, etc., well closed by the fence of mindfulness, in the sense of preventing the arising of covetousness, etc., with regard to the objects of the eye, etc.

original: attho. Evaṃ pātimokkhasaṃvaraindriyasaṃvarasīlasampattidassanena itarasīlampi atthato🔽dassitameva hotīti thero attano catupārisuddhisīlasampadaṃ dassetvā “namassamāno
analyzed: evam pātimokkha saṃvara aindriya saṃvara sīla sampatti dassanena itara sīlam pi atthataḥ  dassitam eva hoti iti theraḥ attano catu pārisuddhi sīla sampadam dassetvā namassamānaḥ
translated: By showing the perfection of virtue consisting in restraint by the Pāṭimokkha and restraint by the sense faculties, he also shows the other kinds of virtue by implication.

original: sambuddha”nti iminā buddhānussatibhāvanānuyogamāha. Vihāsiṃ aparājitoti kilesamārādīhi🔽aparājito eva hutvā vihariṃ, yāva arahattappatti, tāva tehi anabhibhūto, aññadatthu🔽te abhibhavanto eva vihāsinti attho.
analyzed: sambuddha iti iminā buddha anussati bhāvanā anuyogam āha vihāsim aparājitaḥ iti kilesa māra ādīhi 🔽aparājitaḥ eva hutvā viharim yāva arahatta ppatti tāva tehi an abhibhūtaḥ 🔽te abhibhavantaḥ eva vihāsinti attho
translated: Therefore, having shown his own perfection of virtue consisting in the four purifications, the Elder said, “Honouring the Sambuddha,” to show that he was engaged in the development of the recollection of the Buddha.

original: Tatoti tasmā, yasmā suvisuddhasīlo satthari abhippasanno kilesābhibhavanapaṭipattiyañca
analyzed: tato ti tasmai yasmai su visuddha sīlo satthari abhippasanno kilesa abhibhavana paṭipattiyañca
translated: “Tato”: therefore, because he was one of pure virtue, had full confidence in the Master, and was established in the practice of overcoming the defilements,

original: ṭhito, tasmā. Paṇidhīti paṇidhānaṃ. Tato vā cittābhinīhāro. Āsīti ahosi. Cetaso abhipatthitoti,
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ tasmai paṇidhi iti paṇidhānam tatas vā citta abhinīhāraḥ āsi iti ahosi cetasaḥ abhipatthito ti
translated: “Paṇidhī” is the resolve. Or it is the mental aspiration. “Āsī” means was. “Cetaso abhipatthito” means desired by my mind.

original: mama cittena icchito. Kīdiso pana soti āha “na nisīde muhuttampi, taṇhāsalle anūhate”ti.🔽“Aggamaggasaṇḍāsena mama hadayato taṇhāsalle anuddhaṭe muhuttampi na nisīde, nisajjaṃ
analyzed: mama cittena icchitaḥ kīdisaḥ pana saḥ iti āha na nisīde muhuttam pi taṇhā salle  agga magga saṇḍāsena mama hadayato taṇhā salle an uddhaṭe muhuttam pi na nisīde nisajjam
translated: “But what was it like?” He said: “I would not sit down even for a moment, until I had uprooted the dart of craving.”

original: na kappeyya”nti evaṃ me cittābhinīhāro ahosīti attho.
analyzed: na kappeyyanti evam me citta abhinīhāraḥ ahosi iti attho
translated: “I would not sit down even for a moment until I had uprooted the dart of craving from my heart by means of the path of arahatship. I would not consent to sitting down.” This is the meaning.

original: Evaṃ pana cittaṃ adhiṭṭhāya bhāvanaṃ bhāvayitvā ṭhānacaṅkameheva rattiṃ vītināmento
analyzed: evam pana cittam adhiṭṭhāya bhāvanam bhāvayitvā ṭhāna caṅkameha iva rattim
translated: Having thus resolved in his mind and having continued his practice of meditation, he spent the night walking and standing.

original: arūpasamāpattito vuṭṭhāya jhānaṅgamukhena vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ sacchākāsi.
analyzed: arūpa samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāya jhāna aṅga mukhena vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam sacchākāsi
translated: Having emerged from the formless attainments, he established insight by means of the jhāna factors and realized arahatship.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “tassa me”tiādi. Nirūpadhīti kilesupadhiādīnaṃ abhāvena nirupadhi. Ratyāvivasāneti
analyzed: tena vuttam tassa mā itiādi nirūpadhī iti kilesa upadhi ādīnam abhāvena nirupadhi ratyā vivasānā iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “Tassa me” and so forth. “Nirūpadhi” means without upadhi, because of the absence of the upadhi of defilements and so forth.

original: rattibhāgassa vigamane vibhātāya rattiyā. Sūriyuggamanaṃ patīti sūriyuggamanaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: ratti bhāgassa vigamane vibhātāya rattiyā sūri yuj gamanam pati iti sūri yuj gamanam lakkhaṇam
translated: At the end of the night, at the break of dawn, at sunrise,

original: katvā. Sabbaṃ taṇhanti kāmataṇhādibhedaṃ sabbaṃ taṇhāsotaṃ aggamaggena visosetvā
analyzed: katvā sabbam taṇhanti kāma taṇhā ādi bhedam sabbam taṇhā sotam aggamaggena visosetvā
translated: having dried up the whole flood of craving by the path to its end,

original: sukkhāpetvā “taṇhāsalle anūhate na nisīde”ti, paṭiññāya mocitattā. Pallaṅkena upāvisinti
analyzed: sukkhāpetvā taṇhāsalle anūhate na nisīdeti paṭiññāya mocita ttā pallaṅkena upāvisinti
translated: having dried it up, he sat down, having freed himself by his vow, “I will not sit down until I have dried up the flood of craving.”

original: pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā nisīdinti. Sesaṃ uttānatthameva.
analyzed: pallaṅkam ābhujitvā nisīdinti sesam uttānattham eva
translated: He sat down cross-legged: he sat down having folded his legs crosswise. The rest is plain.

original: Mahāpanthakattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mahāpanthaka thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Mahāpanthaka is finished.

original: Aṭṭhakanipātavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: aṭṭhaka nipāta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Book of Eights is finished.

original: 9. Navakanipāto
analyzed: navaka nipātaḥ
translated: The Book of Nines

original: 1. Bhūtattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
translated: The Elder Bhūta’s Verses

original: Navakanipāte yadā dukkhantiādikā āyasmato bhūtattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi
analyzed: navaka nipāte yadā dukkhanti ādikā āyasmataḥ bhūtattherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi
translated: In the Book of Nines, the verses of the venerable Bhūta begin thus: “When there is suffering” . How did this Elder come to be?

original: purimabuddhesu katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ puññaṃ upacinanto
analyzed: purima buddhesu kata adhikāraḥ tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭu upanissayam puññam upacinantaḥ
translated: He had made his aspiration in the presence of past Buddhas, and in various existences he had accumulated merit as a support for his deliverance.

original: siddhatthassa bhagavato kāle brāhmaṇakule nibbattitvā senoti laddhanāmo viññutaṃ
analyzed: siddhatthassa bhagavataḥ kāle brāhmaṇa kule nibbattitvā seno ti laddha nāmaḥ viññutam
translated: In the dispensation of the Blessed One Siddhattha he was reborn in a brahmin family and received the name Sena.

original: patto ekadivasaṃ satthāraṃ disvā pasannamānaso “usabhaṃ pavara”ntiādinā catūhi gāthāhi abhitthavi.
analyzed: eka divasam satthāram disvā pasanna mānasaḥ usabham pavaranti ādinā catūhi gāthāhi
translated: and on one occasion, having seen the Teacher, he extolled him with four stanzas, beginning with the words, “The Bull, the Supreme One.”

original: So tena puññakammena devamanussesu saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde sāketanagarassa
analyzed: so tena puñña kammena deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde sāketa nagarassa
translated: As the fruit of this deed, he passed through the round of existences in the celestial world and in the world of men (until eventually he was born in the dispensation of the present Buddha) in the city of Sāketa,

original: dvāragāme mahāvibhavassa seṭṭhissa putto hutvā nibbatti. Tassa kira seṭṭhino jātā
analyzed: dvāragāme mahāvibhavassa seṭṭhissa puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti tassa kira seṭṭhinaḥ jātā
translated: in a village at the city gate, as the son of a certain wealthy merchant. It is said that all the children born to this merchant

original: jātā dārakā baddhāghātena ekena yakkhena khāditā, imassa pana pacchimabhavikattā
analyzed: jātāḥ dārakāḥ baddha āghātena ekena yakkhena khāditāḥ imassa pana pacchimabhavikattā
translated: were devoured by a certain demon who had taken up his abode in the house. But this child, because it was his last existence,

original: bhūtā ārakkhaṃ gaṇhiṃsu. Yakkho pana vessavaṇassa upaṭṭhānaṃ gato, puna nāgamāsi.🔽Nāmakaraṇadivase cassa “evaṃ kate amanussā anukampantā parihareyyu”nti bhūtoti nāmaṃ
analyzed: bhūtāḥ ārakkham gaṇhiṃsu yakkhaḥ pana vessavaṇassa upaṭṭhānam gato puna na āgamāsi  nāmakaraṇa divase ca ssa evam kate amanussāḥ anukampantā parihareyyunti bhūtaḥ ti nāmaṃ
translated: was protected by the spirits. The demon, however, had gone to wait upon Vessavaṇa, and therefore did not return.🔽On the day when the child’s name was to be given him, the spirits, moved with compassion, said, “If you give him the name Bhūta, we will protect him.”

original: akaṃsu. So pana attano puññabalena anantarāyo vaḍḍhi, tassa “tayo pāsādā ahesu”ntiādi
analyzed: so pana attano puñña balena anantarāyaḥ vaḍḍhi tassa tayo pāsādāḥ ahesuṃ tiādi
translated: Therefore they gave him the name Bhūta. By the power of his own merit, he grew up without hindrance. It is said that he had three palaces,

original: sabbaṃ yasassa kulaputtassa vibhavakittane viya veditabbaṃ. So viññutaṃ patto satthari
analyzed: sabbam yasassa kula puttassa vibhava kittane viya veditabbam so viññutam pattaḥ satthari
translated: and so on. All this may be understood as told in the story of the wealthy young man Yasa. When he had reached years of discretion,

original: sākete vasante upāsakehi saddhiṃ vihāraṃ gato. Satthu santike dhammaṃ sutvā paṭiladdhasaddho
analyzed: sākete vasante upāsakehi saddhim vihāram gataḥ satthu santike dhammam sutvā paṭiladdha saddho
translated: and went to Sāketa to stay with the lay devotees there. After hearing the Dhamma in the presence of the Teacher, he gained faith,

original: pabbajitvā ajakaraṇiyā nāma nadiyā tīre leṇe vasanto vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā nacirasseva
analyzed: pabbajitvā ajakaraṇiyāḥ nāma nadiyāḥ tīre leṇe vasantaḥ vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā nacirassa eva
translated: and after going forth he lived in a cave on the bank of the river Ajakaraṇī. After setting his insight in motion, he reached

original: arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: arahattam pāpuṇi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: arahantship in no long time. Therefore it was said in the Apadāna:

original: “Usabhaṃ pavaraṃ vīraṃ, mahesiṃ vijitāvinaṃ;
analyzed: usabham pavaram vīram mahā isim vijitāvinam
translated: “Who would not be gladdened on seeing the supreme bull, the hero, the great seer, the conqueror,

original: Suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ sambuddhaṃ, ko disvā nappasīdati.
analyzed: suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam sambuddham kaḥ disvā na pasīdati
translated: the one of golden complexion, the Enlightened One?

original: “Himavā vāparimeyyo, sāgarova duruttaro;
analyzed: himavā sāgaraḥ uva duruttaraḥ
translated: “As the Himalayas are immeasurable, as the ocean is hard to cross,

original: Tatheva jhānaṃ buddhassa, ko disvā nappasīdati.
analyzed: tathā iva jhānam buddhassa kaḥ disvā na ppasīdati
translated: so is the meditation of the Buddha; who would not be gladdened on seeing it?

original: “Vasudhā yathāppameyyā, cittā vanavaṭaṃsakā;
analyzed: vasudhā yathā appameyyā cittā vana vaṭaṃsakā
translated: “As the earth is immeasurable, as the forest of Cittalapabbata is,

original: Tatheva sīlaṃ buddhassa, ko disvā nappasīdati.
analyzed: tathā iva sīlam buddhassa kaḥ disvā na ppasīdati
translated: so is the virtue of the Buddha; who would not be gladdened on seeing it?

original: “Anilañjasāsaṅkhubbho, yathākāso asaṅkhiyo;
analyzed: anilañjasā asaṅkhubbhaḥ yathā ākāsaḥ asaṅkhiyaḥ
translated: “As the wind is swift and unhindered, as space is incalculable,

original: Tatheva ñāṇaṃ buddhassa, ko disvā nappasīdati.
analyzed: tathā iva ñāṇam buddhassa kaḥ disvā na ppasīdati
translated: so is the knowledge of the Buddha; who would not be gladdened on seeing it?

original: “Imāhi catugāthāhi, brāhmaṇo senasavhayo;
analyzed: imāhi catu gāthāhi brāhmaṇaḥ sena savhayaḥ
translated: “The brahmin Seniya, with these four verses,

original: Buddhaseṭṭhaṃ thavitvāna, siddhatthaṃ aparājitaṃ.
analyzed: buddha seṭṭham thavitvāna siddhattham aparājitam
translated: having extolled the best of Buddhas, Siddhattha the Invincible,

original: “Catunnavutikappāni, duggatiṃ nupapajjatha;
analyzed: catunnavuti kappāni duggatim nu papajjatha
translated: For ninety-four aeons, I did not go to a bad destination.

original: Sugatiṃ sukhasampattiṃ, anubhosimanappakaṃ.
analyzed: sugatim sukha sampattim
translated: I experienced a good destination and the happiness of prosperity for a long time.

original: “Catunnavutito kappe, thavitvā lokanāyakaṃ;
analyzed: catunnavutitaḥ kappe thavitvā lokanāyakam
translated: For ninety-four aeons, I was a leader of the world.

original: Duggatiṃ nābhijānāmi, thomanāya idaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: duggatim na abhijānāmi thomanāya idam phalam
translated: I do not recall a bad destination. This is the fruit of my praise.

original: “Cātuddasamhi kappamhi, caturo āsumuggatā;
analyzed: cātuddasamhi kappamhi caturaḥ
translated: In the fourth aeon, there were four who were raised up.

original: Sattaratanasampannā, cakkavattī mahabbalā.
analyzed: satta ratana sampannā cakkavattī mahat balā

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.🔽Arahattaṃ pana patvā aparena samayena ñātīnaṃ anukampāya sāketaṃ gantvā katipāhaṃ
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti  arahattam pana patvā aparena samayena ñātīnam anukampāya sāketam gantvā katipāham
translated: My defilements were burned up … The Buddha’s instruction has been carried out.”🔽But after attaining perfection, he went out of compassion for his relatives to Saketa, where he stayed

original: tehi upaṭṭhiyamāno añjanavane vasitvā puna attanā vasitaṭṭhānameva gantukāmo gamanākāraṃ

original: dassesi. Ñātakā “idheva, bhante, vasatha, tumhepi na kilamissatha, mayampi puññena
analyzed: dassesi ñātakāḥ idha iva bhante vasatha tumhe pi na kilamissatha mayam pi puññena
translated: His relatives asked him to stay, saying, “Venerable sir, stay right here. You will not be bothered, and we will increase in merit.”

original: vaḍḍhissāmā”ti theraṃ yāciṃsu. Thero attano vivekābhiratiṃ tattha ca phāsuvihāraṃ pakāsento –
analyzed: vaḍḍhissāma ati theram yāciṃsu theraḥ attanaḥ viveka abhiratim tattha ca phāsu vihāram pakāsentaḥ

analyzed: yadā dukkham jarā maraṇanti paṇḍitaḥ aviddasū yattha sitā puthujjanā

analyzed: yadā dukkhassa avahanim visattikam papañca saṅghāta dukha adhivāhinim

translated: he meditates mindfully, having abandoned craving, and finds no delight in anything higher.

analyzed: yadā sivam dve catur aṅga gāminam magga uttamam sabba kilesa sodhanam

translated: he meditates mindfully, having seen with wisdom, and finds no delight in anything higher.

analyzed: yadā asokam virajam asaṅkhatam santam padam sabba kilesa sodhanam

analyzed: yadā nadīnam kusuma ākulānam vicitta vāneyya vaṭaṃsakānam
translated: “When, on the banks of rivers with their flowers in bloom, in lovely forests with their trees and thickets,

analyzed: tīre nisinnaḥ sumanāḥ uva jhāyati tatas ratim paramataram na vindati
translated: He sits and meditates with a happy mind, he finds no greater delight than this.

analyzed: yadā nisīthe rahitamhi kānane deve gaḷantamhi nadanti dāṭhinaḥ

original: Bhikkhū ca pabbhāragatova jhāyati, tato ratiṃ paramataraṃ na vindati.
analyzed: bhikkhū ca pabbhāra gataḥ iva jhāyati tatas ratim paramataram na vindati
translated: And the monk meditates on a mountain top, he finds no greater delight than this.

analyzed: yadā vitakke naga antare naga vivaram

original: “Yadā sukhī malakhilasokanāsano,

translated: “When, happy, free from dust and dirt and grief,

analyzed: bhedaḥ maraṇam jarā maraṇa sīsena ca itthā jarā maraṇavantaḥ dhammā gahitā tayā idam jarā maraṇam

analyzed: dukkhanti aviddasū yathābhūtam a jānantā puthujjanā yattha yasmin upādāna khandha pañcake
translated: “Suffering” : the worldlings who have not discovered, who have not penetrated, this ageing-and-death as it really is, who do not know it as it really is, are “attached” to, are “bound” to, are “fixed” upon, the five aggregates as objects of clinging,

original: sitā paṭibandhā allīnā, taṃ “idaṃ dukkhaṃ, ettakaṃ dukkhaṃ, na ito bhiyyo”ti vipassanāpaññāsahitāya

analyzed: magga paññāya parijānitvā idha imasmin sāsane sataḥ sampajāno paṇḍitaḥ bhikkhu yadā  yasmin kāle lakkhaṇa upanijjhānena jhāyati tatas vipassanā ratitaḥ magga phala ratitaḥ ca
translated: the wise bhikkhu, mindful and fully aware, in this Dispensation, when he

analyzed: paramataram uttamataram ratim na vindati na paṭilabhati tena āha bhagavā
translated: meditates by observing the characteristics of the five aggregates as objects of clinging, finds no delight, no satisfaction, in anything more or better than that, in the delight of insight, in the delight of the paths and fruits. Hence the Blessed One said:

analyzed: yatas yatas sammasati khandhānam udaya bbayam
translated: “Whenever he comprehends the rise and fall Of any of the five aggregates,

analyzed: labhatī pīti pāmojjam amatam tam vijānatam
translated: He gains a happiness and joy That are beyond all measure.

original: “Paṭhabyā ekarajjena, saggassa gamanena vā;
analyzed: paṭhabyāḥ eka rajjena saggassa gamanena vā
translated: “No happiness in all the world

original: Sabbalokādhipaccena, sotāpattiphalaṃ vara”nti. ;🔽Evaṃ pariññābhisamayamukhena vivekaratiṃ dassetvā idāni pahānābhisamayādimukhenapi
analyzed: sabba loka ādhipaccena sa utāpatti phalam varanti  evam pariññā abhisamaya mukhena viveka ratim dassetvā idāni pahāna abhisamaya ādi mukhena api
translated: and the fruit of Stream-Entry is the best, since it is the overlord of the whole world.

original: taṃ dassetuṃ dutiyādikā tisso gāthā abhāsi. Tattha dukkhassāvahaninti dukkhassa āyatiṃ
analyzed: tam dassetum dutiya ādikā tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha dukkhassa avahanim ti dukkhassa āyatim
translated: Having thus shown the happiness of seclusion by the means of full-understanding and penetration, he now spoke three verses beginning with the second, in order to show it also by the means of abandoning, penetration, etc. Herein, he said: “The cause of suffering” , the future

original: pavattiṃ, dukkhassa nipphattikanti attho. Visattikanti taṇhaṃ. Sā hi visatāti visattikā,🔽visālāti visattikā, visaṭāti visattikā, visakkatīti visattikā, visaṃ haratīti visattikā,
analyzed: pavattim dukkhassa nipphattikanti atthaḥ visattikanti taṇham sā hi visatā ati visattikā  visālā ati visattikā visaṭā ati visattikā visakkati iti visattikā visam harati iti visattikā
translated: occurrence of suffering, is the meaning. “The spreading” is craving. For that is spread out , thus it is a spreading ;🔽it is extensive , thus it is a spreading; it is scattered , thus it is a spreading; it is scattered about , thus it is a spreading;

original: visaṃvādikāti visattikā, visamūlāti visattikā, visaphalāti visattikā, visaparibhogāti
analyzed: visaṃvādikā ati visattikā visa mūlā ati visattikā visa phalā ati visattikā visa paribhogā ati
translated: it deceives , thus it is a spreading; it is a false root , thus it is a spreading; it is a false fruit , thus it is a spreading; it is a false enjoyment , thus it is a spreading;

original: visattikā, visālā vā pana sā taṇhā rūpe sadde gandhe rase phoṭṭhabbe dhamme kule
analyzed: visattikā visālā vā pana sā taṇhā rūpe sadde gandhe rase phoṭṭhabbe dhamme kule
translated: or else it is extensive in the case of this craving for visible forms, sounds, odours, flavours, tangible objects and ideas, in a family,

original: gaṇe vitthaṭāti visattikāti vuccati. Papañcasaṅghātadukhādhivāhininti sattasantānaṃ
analyzed: gaṇe vitthaṭā ati visattikā ati vuccati satta santānam
translated: in a group, in being spread out , thus it is called a spreading. “The cause of the suffering of the mass of proliferation” , the continuity of beings,

original: saṃsāre papañcenti vitthārentīti papañcā, rāgādayo mānādayo ca. Te eva pavattidukkhassa🔽saṅghātaṭṭhena saṅghātā, sadarathapariḷāhasabhāvattā dukkhañcāti papañcasaṅghātadukhaṃ,
analyzed: saṃsāre papañcenti vitthārenti iti papañcāḥ rāga ādayaḥ māna ādayaḥ ca te eva pavatti dukkhassa  saṅghāta ṭṭhena saṅghātā sada ratha pariḷāha sabhāva ttā dukkham ca ati papañca saṅghāta dukham
translated: They are proliferations because they proliferate, spread out, in the round of rebirths. They are the defilements of lust, etc., and of conceit, etc. They are a mass because they are a heap of suffering in occurrence,🔽and they are suffering because they are the nature of the burning of the fever of craving. So it is a “proliferation-mass-suffering” that is borne by him.

original: tassa adhivāhato nibbattanato papañcasaṅghātadukhādhivāhinī. Taṃ taṇhaṃ pahantvānāti
analyzed: tassa adhivāhataḥ nibbattanataḥ papañca saṅghāta dukha adhivāhinī tam taṇham pahantvā ānāti
translated: Having abandoned that craving,

original: ariyamaggena samucchinditvā.
analyzed: ariya maggena samucchinditvā
translated: having cut it off by means of the noble path,

original: Sivanti khemaṃ, akhemakarānaṃ kilesānaṃ samucchindanena tehi anupaddutanti attho.
analyzed: sivanti khemam a khema karānam kilesānam samucchindanena tehi anupaddutam ti attho
translated: he is safe, which means that he is not troubled by the defilements that make for danger, since they have been cut off.

original: Sammādiṭṭhiādīnaṃ vasena dvicaturaṅgo hutvā ariye nibbānaṃ gametīti dvecaturaṅgagāminaṃ,🔽gāthāsukhatthañcettha vibhattialopo katoti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Rūpūpapattimaggādīsu sabbesu
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi ādīnam vasena dvi catur aṅgaḥ hutvā ariye nibbānam gameti iti dve caturaṅga gāminam  gāthā sukha attham ca ittha vibhatti a lopaḥ kataḥ iti daṭṭhabbam rūpa upapatti magga ādīsu sabbesu
translated: It goes to the noble Nibbāna, which has two or four factors, namely, right view, etc.,

original: maggesu uttamattā magguttamaṃ. Tenāha bhagavā – “maggānaṭṭhaṅgiko seṭṭho”tiādi. Sabbehi
analyzed: maggesu uttama ttā magguttamam tena āha bhagavā maggānaṭṭhaṅgiko seṭṭhaḥ ti ādi sabbehi
translated: and it is the supreme path because it is the best of all paths, such as the path of the form-world gods, the path of the formless world, the path of serenity, the path of insight, and so on.

original: kilesamalehi sattānaṃ sodhanato sabbakilesasodhanaṃ. Paññāya passitvāti paṭivedhapaññāya
analyzed: kilesa malehi sattānam sodhanato sabba kilesa sodhanam paññāya passitvā ati paṭivedha paññāya
translated: It is the cleanser of all defilements since it cleanses beings of the defilements’ stain.

original: bhāvanābhisamayavasena abhisamecca.
analyzed: bhāvanā abhisamaya vasena abhisamet ca
translated: Having seen with wisdom: having penetrated by way of the penetration of development.

original: Sokahetūnaṃ abhāvato puggalassa ca sokābhāvahetuto natthi ettha sokoti asokaṃ. Tathā
analyzed: soka hetūnam abhāvataḥ puggalassa ca soka abhāva hetutaḥ natthi ettha soko ti asokam tathā
translated: It is sorrowless since there is no sorrow here for a person because of the absence of the causes for sorrow.

original: vigatarāgādirajattā virajaṃ. Na kenaci paccayena saṅkhatanti asaṅkhataṃ. Sabbesaṃ🔽kilesānaṃ sabbassa ca dukkhassa vūpasamabhāvato, saṃsāradukkhadditehi pajjitabbato🔽adhigantabbato ca santaṃ padaṃ. Sabbehi kilesamalehi sattasantānassa sodhananimittato
analyzed: vigata rāga ādi rajattā virajam na kenacid paccayena saṅkhatanti asaṅkhatam sabbesam  kilesānam sabbassa ca dukkhassa vūpasama bhāvataḥ saṃsāra dukkha dditehi pajjitabbato  adhigantabbataḥ ca santam padam sabbehi kilesa malehi satta santānassa sodhana nimittato
translated: It is stainless since it is free from the stain of lust, etc. It is the unformed since it is not formed by any conditions.🔽It is the peaceful state since it is the state of the stilling of all defilements and of all suffering, and since it is to be entered upon and realized by those who are weary of the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: sabbakilesasodhanaṃ. Bhāvetīti sacchikiriyābhisamayavasena abhisameti. Bahukkhattuñhi
analyzed: sabba kilesa sodhanam bhāveti iti sacchikiriyā abhisamaya vasena abhisameti bahu khattum hi
translated: It is the cleanser of all defilements since it is the cause for the cleansing of the continuity of beings of all defilements’ stain.

original: nibbānaṃ ārabbha sacchikiriyābhisamayaṃ pavattentassa ālambake labbhamānavisesakaṃ
analyzed: nibbānam ārabbha sacchikiriyā abhisamayam pavattentassa ālambake labbhamāna visesakam
translated: He develops: he penetrates by way of the penetration of realization. For when one is engaged in the penetration of realization with regard to Nibbāna, which is the object, the distinction that is found in the object is found in the subject as well.

original: ālambitabbe āropetvā evaṃ vuttaṃ. Saṃyojanasaṅkhātānaṃ bandhanānaṃ chedanato saṃyojanabandhanacchidaṃ.
analyzed: ālambitabbe āropetvā evam vuttam saṃyojana saṅkhātānam bandhanānam chedanataḥ saṃyojana bandhana chidam
translated: and the expression “to be grasped” is used in the sense of “to be taken up.” It is “the severing of fetters and bonds” because it severs the bonds called fetters.

original: Nimittañhettha kattubhāvena upacāritaṃ, yathā ariyabhāvakarāni saccāni ariyasaccānīti.
analyzed: nimittam ha itthā kattu bhāvena upacāritam yathā ariya bhāva karāni saccāni ariya saccāni iti
translated: Here the sign is figuratively designated as the maker, just as the noble truths are called “noble” because they cause the noble state.

original: Yathā purimagāthāsu yadā jhāyati, tadā tato ratiṃ paramataraṃ na vindatīti yojanā.
analyzed: yathā purima gāthāsu yadā jhāyati tadā tatas ratim paramataram na vindati iti yojanā
translated: In the previous verses, the construction is: “When he meditates, he finds no delight in anything higher than that.”

original: Evaṃ idha yadā bhāveti, tadā tato ratiṃ paramataraṃ na vindatīti yojanā.
analyzed: evam yadā tadā tatas ratim paramataram na vindati iti yojanā
translated: Here the construction is: “When he develops it, he finds no delight in anything higher than that.”

original: Evaṃ thero catūhi gāthāhi attānaṃ anupanetvāva catusaccapaṭivedhakittanena aññaṃ
analyzed: evam thero catūhi gāthāhi attānam an upanetvā ava catu sacca paṭivedha kittanena aññam
translated: Thus, after introducing himself with four verses, the Elder recited the following verse in order to explain himself further:

original: byākaritvā idāni attanā vasitaṭṭhānassa vivittabhāvena phāsutaṃ dassento “yadā nabhe”tiādikā🔽gāthā abhāsi. Tattha nabheti ākāse. Siniddhagambhīranigghosatāya meghoyeva dundubhi
analyzed: byākaritvā idāni attanā vasita ṭṭhānassa vivitta bhāvena phāsutam dassentaḥ yadā nabha iti ādikā  gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha nabhā iti ākāse siniddha gambhīra nigghosa tāya meghoyā iva dundubhi
translated: The Elder recited the following verse in order to show the ease of living in a secluded place:🔽Here, “in the sky” means in the air. The cloud itself is a drum because of its deep and resonant sound.🔽The cloud is the drum. “Turbulent with rain” means full of rain falling all around.

original: meghadundubhi. Samantato paggharantīhi dhārāhi ākulāti dhārākulā. Vihagānaṃ pakkhīnaṃ
analyzed: samantataḥ paggharantīhi dhārāhi ākulā ati dhārā ākulā vihagānam pakkhīnam
translated: “Birds” are flying creatures.

original: gamanamaggattā vihagapathe nabheti yojanā. Tatoti jhānaratito.
analyzed: gamana magga ttā vihaga pathe yojanā tato ti jhāna ratito
translated: The interpretation is that the sky is called “the path of birds” because it is the path for birds’ going and coming. “From the jhāna-happiness”: from the happiness of jhāna.

original: Kusumākulānanti tarūhi gaḷitakusumehi samohitānaṃ. Vicittavāneyyavaṭaṃsakānanti vane
analyzed: kusuma ākulānanti tarūhi gaḷita kusumehi vicitta vāneyya vaṭaṃsakānanti vane
translated: “With flowers strewn”: strewn with flowers fallen from trees. “With variegated forest-creepers and boughs”:

original: jātattā vāneyyāni vanapupphāni, vicittāni vāneyyāni vaṭaṃsakāni etāsanti vicittavāneyyavaṭaṃsakā
analyzed: jāta ttā vāneyyāni vana pupphāni vicittāni vāneyyāni vaṭaṃsakāni etāsanti vicitta vāneyya vaṭaṃsakā
translated: the flowers in the forest are “forest-creepers” ; or the forest-creepers are “variegated” because of the variety of their flowers and fruits, and the boughs are “forest-creepers” ;

original: nadiyo, tāsaṃ nānāvidhavanapupphavaṭaṃsakānanti attho. Uttarimanussadhammavasena
analyzed: nadiyaḥ tāsam nānāvidha vana puppha vaṭaṃsakānam ti attho uttari manussa dhamma vasena
translated: the rivers have “variegated forest-creepers and boughs” because of the flowers and creepers in the forest on their banks. The meaning is that they have “variegated forest-creepers and boughs” of various kinds.

original: sundaro mano etassāti sumano jhāyati.🔽Nisītheti rattiyaṃ. Rahitamhīti, janasambādhavirahite vivitte. Deveti meghe. Gaḷantamhīti🔽vuṭṭhidhārāyo paggharante vassante. Dāṭhinoti sīhabyagghādayo paṭipakkhasattā. Te
analyzed: sundaraḥ manaḥ etassa ati su manaḥ jhāyati  nisītha iti rattiyam iti jana sambādha virahite vivitte deva iti meghe  vuṭṭhi dhārāyo paggharante vassante dāṭhino ti sīha byaggha ādayo paṭipakkha sattā te
translated: “With a mind fair with a superhuman state”: he meditates with a mind fair, lovely, with a superhuman state.🔽“In the night’s stillness”: in the night, when it is still. “We are free”: we are free from the obstruction of people, in a lonely place. “When the rain god pours”:🔽when the rain god pours down showers. “The beasts of prey”: lions, tigers, etc., as opponents.

original: hi dāṭhāvudhāti “dāṭhino”ti vuccanti, nadanti dāṭhinoti idampi janavivekadassanatthameva gahitaṃ.

translated: For they are called “beasts of prey” because of their weapon-like fangs. The sound of their roaring is also included in order to show that people are absent.

original: Vitakke uparundhiyattanoti attasantānapariyāpannatāya attano kāmavitakkādike micchāvitakke

original: paṭipakkhabalena nisedhetvā. Attanoti vā idaṃ vindatīti iminā yojetabbaṃ “tato ratiṃ🔽paramataraṃ attanā na vindatī”ti. Nagantareti pabbatantare. Nagavivaranti pabbataguhaṃ🔽pabbhāraṃ vā. analyzed: paṭipakkha balena nisedhetvā attanoti vai idam vindati iti iminā yojetabbam tatas ratim  paramataram attanā na vindati iti naga antarā iti pabbata antare naga vivaranti pabbata guham  pabbhāram vā samassitaḥ ti nissitaḥ upagataḥ vīta ddaraḥ iti vigata kilesa darathaḥ vīta khilaḥ iti pahīna cetaḥ khilaḥ  sukhī iti jhāna ādi sukhena sukhitaḥ rāga ādīnam
translated: Or else, “himself” should be construed with “finds delight,” thus: “he finds no delight in himself more excellent than that.”🔽“In the midst of the wood”: in the midst of a forest. “In the wood’s interior”: in a forest grove, or in a mountain cave.🔽“Leaning against a tree”: leaning against a tree, having gone to it. “Free from fever”: free from the fever of defilements. “Free from anxiety”: having abandoned the five mental hindrances.

original: cetokhilānaṃ ñātiviyogādihetukassa sokassa ca pahāyako. Niraggaḷoti, aggaḷaṃ vuccati
analyzed: cetaḥ khilānam ñāti viyoga ādi hetukassa sokassa ca pahāyako niraggaḷaḥ ti aggaḷam vuccati
translated: “Happy”: made happy by the happiness of jhāna, etc. “Destroyer of stain, anxiety, and sorrow”: the destroyer of the stains of lust, etc., and of the five mental anxieties, and of sorrow caused by separation, etc.

original: avijjā nibbānapurapavesanivāraṇato, tadabhāvato niraggaḷo. Nibbanathoti nitaṇho.

translated: “Shutterless”: ignorance is called the “shutter” because it prevents one from entering the city of Nibbāna. Since he is devoid of that, he is “shutterless.” “Unencumbered”: free from encumbrances.

analyzed: saḥ bodhisattena saddhim kumāra kīḷam kīḍantaḥ vuddhim agamāsi

analyzed: taṅ khaṇaṃya iva iddhi maya patta cīvara dharāḥ vassasaṭṭhika therāḥ viya ahesum arahattam  pattato paṭṭhāya pana ariyāḥ majjhattāḥ ava honti tasmā raññā pahita sāsanam dasabalassa
translated: became monks, and in that very moment became like monks of sixty years’ seniority, wearing the supernatural robe and bowl. But although they had attained arahatship,🔽they were still indifferent, and therefore did not tell the Teacher what the king had said. The king thought, “The messenger has not returned, nor have I heard any news.” So he sent a second

original: na kathesi. Rājā “neva gatabalakoṭṭhako āgacchati, na sāsanaṃ suyyatī”ti aparampi
analyzed: na kathesi rājā na iva gata balakoṭṭhakaḥ āgacchati na sāsanam suyyati iti aparam pi
translated: messenger.

analyzed: amaccam purisa sahassena pesesi tasmin pi tathā paṭipanne evam navahi amaccehi
translated: and sent a thousand men with him. When he had gone in the same way, he sent nine more ministers,

analyzed: saddhim nava purisa sahassāni pesesi sabbe arahattam patvā tuṇhī ahesuṃ  atha rājā cintesi ettakāḥ janāḥ mayi sineha abhāvena dasabalassa idha āgamana tthāya
translated: and sent him with a thousand men. When he had gone in the same way, the king sent nine other ministers with nine thousand men. All of them attained arahatship and became silent.

translated: Then the king thought, “These people have not said anything to the One of Ten Powers to come here because of their lack of affection for me. But this Udāyī is a contemporary of the One of Ten Powers and a playmate from his boyhood, and he is affectionate towards me.

original: puttaṃ dassehī”ti vutto rājagahaṃ gantvā satthu dhammadesanāvelāya parisapariyante
analyzed: puttam dassehi iti vuttaḥ rājagaham gantvā satthu dhamma desanā velāya parisapariyante
translated: I will send him.” He summoned him and said, “Dear, you go with a thousand men and bring the One of Ten Powers from Rājagaha.” He was sent off. translated: Was on his way, and as he went on his way

original: “Paribhuñji mahāvīro, paramannaṃ subhojanaṃ;
analyzed: paribhuñji mahāvīro param annam su bhojanam
translated: “The Great Hero ate the most excellent food, the most excellent meal,

translated: I will extol him; listen to me as I speak.

analyzed: assa puñña vipākena dibba gandha samāyutam
translated: “By the ripening of that merit, he will be endowed with celestial fragrance,

analyzed: ākāse chadanam katvā dhārayissati tāvade
translated: will be held up in the air, a canopy for him.

original: “Pañcavīsatikkhattuñca, cakkavattī bhavissati;
analyzed: pañcavīsati kkhattum ca cakkavattī bhavissati
translated: Twenty-five times a wheel-turner he will be,

analyzed: pathabyāḥ rajjam pañca satam vasudham āvasissati
translated: and for five hundred years he will rule the earth.

original: “Kappasatasahassamhi, okkākakulasambhavo;
analyzed: kappa sata sahassamhi okkāka kula sambhavaḥ
translated: In a period of a thousand times a hundred thousand aeons,

analyzed: so pacchā pabbajitvāna sukka mūlena coditaḥ  sabba asave pariññāya

translated: The Kinsman of the Sun will place him at the head🔽of those who have attained analytical knowledge,🔽who have done their tasks and are without taints.

original: “Padhānapahitatto so, upasanto nirūpadhi;
analyzed: saḥ upasantaḥ
translated: He will be intent on striving, calm, without possessions,

original: Udāyī nāma nāmena, hessati satthu sāvako.
analyzed: udāyī nāma nāmena hessati satthu sāvako
translated: and will be called the disciple Udāyī.🔽Craving, hatred, and delusion,

original: “Rāgo doso ca moho ca, māno makkho ca dhaṃsito;
analyzed: rāgaḥ doso ca moho ca māno makkho ca dhaṃsito
translated: conceit, contempt, and obstinacy,🔽having fully understood all the taints,

original: Sabbāsave pariññāya, viharāmi anāsavo.
analyzed: sabba āsave pariññāya viharāmi anāsavaḥ

original: “Tosayiñcāpi sambuddhaṃ, ātāpī nipako ahaṃ;

translated: The Sambuddha was satisfied with me, and he placed me at the head of those who are ardent and watchful.
