analyzed: paṭisambhidā katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: “I have attained the four analytical knowledges. I have fulfilled the Buddha’s dispensation.”

original: Arahattaṃ pana patvā “na tāvāyaṃ dasabalassa kulanagaraṃ gantuṃ kālo, vasante pana
analyzed: arahattam pana patvā na tāva ayam dasabalassa kula nagaram gantum kālaḥ vasante pana
translated: But when he had attained arahatship, he thought to himself, “It is not yet time for the One of Ten Powers to go to the city of his clan. But when the hot season is past

original: upagate pupphitesu vanasaṇḍesu haritatiṇasañchannāya bhūmiyā gamanakālo bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: upagate pupphitesu vana saṇḍesu harita tiṇa sañchannāya bhūmiyā gamana kālaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: and the trees are in full flower, when the ground is covered with fresh green grass, then will be the time for him to go. ”

original: kālaṃ paṭimānento vasante sampatte satthu kulanagaraṃ gantuṃ gamanamaggavaṇṇaṃ saṃvaṇṇento –
analyzed: kālam paṭimānentaḥ vasante sampatte satthu kula nagaram gantum gamana magga vaṇṇam saṃvaṇṇentaḥ
translated: And as he waited for the time, when the hot season was past and the trees were in full flower, he extolled the beauty of the road to the city of his clan, saying,

original: “Aṅgārino dāni dumā bhadante, phalesino chadanaṃ vippahāya;
analyzed: aṅgārino dāni dumāḥ bhadante phalesino chadanam vippahāya
translated: “The trees are now in flower, O Blessed One, and have cast off their withered leaves.

original: Te accimantova pabhāsayanti, samayo mahāvīra bhāgīrasānaṃ.
analyzed: te accimantaḥ iva pabhāsayanti samayaḥ mahāvīra bhāgīrasānam
translated: They shine like flames of fire. It is now the proper time for the great hero to go to the city of his clan.

original: “Dumāni phullāni manoramāni, samantato sabbadisā pavanti;
analyzed: dumāni phullāni manoramāni samantataḥ sabbadisā pavanti
translated: “The trees are in full flower, and their fragrance spreads in all directions.

original: Pattaṃ pahāya phalamāsasānā, kālo ito pakkamanāya vīra.
analyzed: pattam pahāya phalam āsasānā kālaḥ itas pakkamanāya vīra
translated: Having cast off their withered leaves, they now bear fruit. It is now the proper time for the hero to depart from here.

original: “Nevātisītaṃ na panātiuṇhaṃ, sukhā utu addhaniyā bhadante;
analyzed: na iva ati sītam na panāti uṇham sukhā utu addhaniyā bhadante
translated: “It is neither too cold nor too hot. The weather is delightful, O Blessed One.

original: Passantu taṃ sākiyā koḷiyā ca, pacchāmukhaṃ rohiniyaṃ tarantaṃ.
analyzed: passantu tam sākiyā koḷiyā ca pacchāmukham rohiniyam tarantam
translated: Let the Sakyans and Koliyan see him, Crossing the Rohini with his face to the west.

original: “Āsāya kasate khettaṃ, bījaṃ āsāya vappati;
analyzed: āsāya kasate khettam bījam āsāya vappati
translated: “In hope the field is tilled, in hope the seed is sown, in hope the farmer ploughs his land;

original: Āsāya vāṇijā yanti, samuddaṃ dhanahārakā;
analyzed: āsāya vāṇijāḥ yanti samuddam dhana hārakā
translated: In hope the merchant travels, carrying his wealth across the sea;

original: Yāya āsāya tiṭṭhāmi, sā me āsā samijjhatu.
analyzed: yāya āsāya tiṭṭhāmi sā me āsā samijjhatu
translated: May the hope for which I stand here be fulfilled.

original: “Punappunañceva vapanti bījaṃ, punappunaṃ vassati devarājā;
analyzed: punar punar ca iva vapanti bījam punar punar vassati devarājā
translated: “Again and again the seed is sown, again and again the king of gods rains;

original: Punappunaṃ khettaṃ kasanti kassakā, punappunaṃ dhaññamupeti raṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: punappunam khettam kasanti kassakā punappunam dhaññam upeti raṭṭham
translated: Again and again the field is tilled by the farmer, again and again the country is filled with grain.

original: “Punappunaṃ yācanakā caranti, punappunaṃ dānapatī dadanti;
analyzed: punappunam yācanakā caranti punappunam dānapatī dadanti
translated: “Again and again the beggars go about, again and again the donors give;

original: Punappunaṃ dānapatī daditvā, punappunaṃ saggamupenti ṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: punappunam dānapatī daditvā punappunam saggam upenti ṭhānam
translated: Having given again and again, the donors go again and again to heaven.

original: “Vīro have sattayugaṃ puneti, yasmiṃ kule jāyati bhūripañño;
analyzed: vīraḥ have satta yugam puneti yasmim kule jāyati bhūri paññaḥ
translated: “The hero, indeed, revives the seven generations, in whatever family the one of great wisdom is born;

original: Maññāmahaṃ sakkati devadevo, tayā hi jāto muni saccanāmo.
analyzed: maññām aham sakkati devadevaḥ tayā hi jātaḥ muni sacca nāmo
translated: I think Sakka is the god of gods, for the sage of true name was born of you.

original: “Suddhodano nāma pitā mahesino, buddhassa mātā pana māyanāmā;
analyzed: suddhodanaḥ nāma pitā mahesinaḥ buddhassa mātā pana māya nāmā
translated: “The father of the Great Seer was named Suddhodana, the mother of the Buddha was named Maya;

original: Yā bodhisattaṃ parihariya kucchinā, kāyassa bhedā tidivamhi modati.
analyzed: yā bodhisattam parihariya kucchinā kāyassa bhedā tidivamhi modati
translated: She, having carried the Bodhisatta in her womb, rejoices in heaven after the break-up of the body.

original: “Sā gotamī kālakatā ito cutā, dibbehi kāmehi samaṅgibhūtā;
analyzed: sā gotamī kālakatā itas cutā dibbehi kāmehi samaṅgi bhūtā
translated: “Gotami has died, gone from here, and is endowed with heavenly sense-pleasures.

original: Sā modati kāmaguṇehi pañcahi, parivāritā devagaṇehi tehi.
analyzed: sā modati kāma guṇehi pañcahi parivāritā deva gaṇehi tehi
translated: She rejoices with the five strands of heavenly sense pleasure, surrounded by those groups of gods.

original: “Buddhassa puttomhi asayhasāhino, aṅgīrasassappaṭimassa tādino;
analyzed: buddhassa putto amhi asayhasāhinaḥ aṅgīrasassa appaṭimassa tādinaḥ
translated: “I am the son of the Buddha, the one who cannot be overcome, the one who is like Aṅgīrasa, the one who is like the Tathāgata.

original: Pitupitā mayhaṃ tuvaṃsi sakka, dhammena me gotama ayyakosī”ti. –
analyzed: pitu pitā mayham tuvaṃsi sakka dhammena me gotama ayyakosi iti
translated: You are the father of my father, Sakka, and by Dhamma I am your brother, Gotama.”

original: Imā gāthā abhāsi.
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: He spoke these verses.

original: Tattha aṅgārinoti aṅgārāni viyāti aṅgārāni, rattapavāḷavaṇṇāni rukkhānaṃ pupphapallavāni,🔽tāni etesaṃ santīti aṅgārino, atilohitakusumakisalayehi aṅgāravuṭṭhisaṃparikiṇṇā
analyzed: tattha aṅgārino ti aṅgārāni viyā ati aṅgārāni ratta pavāḷa vaṇṇāni rukkhānam puppha pallavāni  tāni etesam santi iti aṅgārinaḥ ati lohita kusuma kisalayehi aṅgāra vuṭṭhi saṃparikiṇṇā
translated: Herein, aṅgārino means they are like embers, the flowers and shoots of trees are the color of red embers,

original: viyāti attho. Idānīti imasmiṃ kāle. Dumāti rukkhā. Bhadanteti, bhaddaṃ ante etassāti
analyzed: viya ati attho idāni iti imasmin kāle dumā ati rukkhāḥ bhadanta iti bhaddam ante etassa ati
translated: they have these, thus they are aṅgārino. The meaning is, they are surrounded by the shoots of extremely red flowers like a heap of embers. Idānī means at this time. Dumā means trees. Bhadante means good is in front of this, thus

original: bhadanteti ekassa dakārassa lopaṃ katvā vuccati, guṇavisesayutto, guṇavisesayuttānañca
analyzed: bhadanta iti ekassa dakārassa lopam katvā vuccati guṇa visesa yuttaḥ guṇa visesa yuttānam ca
translated: bhadante. After omitting one of the two dakāras, it is said. It is endowed with a special quality, and the Teacher is foremost among those endowed with special qualities.

original: aggabhūto satthā. Tasmā bhadanteti satthu ālapanaṃ. Paccattavacanañcetaṃ ekārantaṃ
analyzed: agga bhūtaḥ satthā tasmai bhadanta iti satthu ālapanam paccatta vacanam ca itam ekāra antam
translated: Therefore it is an address to the Teacher as bhadante. This is a first-person singular form.

original: “sukaṭe paṭikamme sukhe dukkhepi ce”tiādīsu viya. Idha pana sambodhanatthe daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: su kaṭe paṭikamme sukhe dukkhe pi ca iti ādīsu viya idha pana sambodhana atthe daṭṭhabbam
translated: “As in the case of the words ‘In the cart, in the pleasure, and in the pain’ . But here it should be taken in the sense of addressing.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “bhadanteti ālapana”nti. “Bhaddasaddasamānatthaṃ padantarameka”nti keci.🔽Phalāni esantīti phalesino. Acetanepi hi sacetanakiriyamāropetvā voharanti, yathā🔽kulaṃ patitukāmanti, phalāni gahetumāraddhā sampattiphalagahaṇakālāti attho. Chadanaṃ
analyzed: tena vuttam bhadanta iti ālapanam ti bhadda sadda samāna ttham padantaram ekam iti keci  phalāni acetane api hi sa cetana kiriyam āropetvā voharanti yathā  kulam patitu kāmanti phalāni gahetum āraddhā sampatti phala gahaṇa kālā ati attho chadanam
translated: Hence it is said, ‘Bhadante is an address.’ ‘The word is the same as bhadda, but the meaning is different’ some say.🔽They seek fruits, thus they are fruit-seekers . For they speak of even the insentient as though they were sentient, as in the case of the words ‘The family is desirous of coming’ . They have begun to take the fruits, thus they are fruit-seekers. The meaning is: the time for taking the fruits of prosperity.🔽Having abandoned the covering,

original: vippahāyāti purāṇapaṇṇāni pajahitvā sampannapaṇḍupalāsāti attho. Teti dumā. Accimantova
analyzed: vippahāya ati purāṇa paṇṇāni pajahitvā sampanna paṇḍu palāsā ati attho te iti dumāḥ accimantaḥ iva
translated: thus they are leafless. The meaning is: they have perfect sere leaves. They, thus the trees.

original: pabhāsayantīti dīpasikhāvanto viya jalitaaggī viya vā obhāsayanti sabbā disāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: pabhāsayanti iti dīpa sikhāvantaḥ viya jalita aggī viya vā obhāsayanti sabbā disā ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: Shining, thus they are shining. The intention is: they illuminate all directions, as though they were flames of a lamp or as though they were burning fires.

original: Samayoti kālo, “anuggahāyā”ti vacanaseso. Mahāvīrāti mahāvikkanta. Bhāgī rasānanti
analyzed: samayaḥ ti kālaḥ anuggahāya ati vacana sesaḥ mahāvīra ati bhāgī
translated: The time, thus the season. The meaning is: ‘for the purpose of favouring.’ Great heroes, thus great wanderers .🔽A partaker of flavours, thus a partaker of the flavours of meaning,

original: attharasādīnaṃ bhāgī. Vuttañhetaṃ dhammasenāpatinā – “bhāgī vā bhagavā attharasassa
analyzed: attha rasa ādīnam bhāgī vuttam ha etam dhammasenāpatinā bhāgī vā bhagavā attha rasassa
translated: etc. For this is said by the General of the Dhamma: ‘The Blessed One is a partaker of the flavour of meaning,

original: dhammarasassā”tiādi. Mahāvīra, bhāgīti ca idampi dvayaṃ sambodhanavacanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: dhamma rasassa ati ādi mahāvīra bhāgī iti ca idam pi dvayam sambodhana vacanam daṭṭhabbam
translated: And the words ‘Mahāvīra’ and ‘Bhāgīratha’ should be regarded as terms of address.

original: Bhāgīrathānanti pana pāṭhe bhagīratho nāma ādirājā. Tabbaṃsajātatāya sākiyā bhāgīrathā,
analyzed: pana pāṭhe bhagīrathaḥ nāma ādirājā tad baṃsa jāta tāya sākiyāḥ bhāgīrathāḥ
translated: But if the reading is ‘Bhāgīrathān,’ then the first king was called Bhāgīratha. The Sākiyas are called ‘Bhāgīrathas’ because they are descended from him.

original: tesaṃ bhāgīrathānaṃ upakāratthanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: tesam bhāgīrathānam upakāra attham ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is: ‘for the benefit of those Bhāgīrathas.’

original: Dumānīti liṅgavipallāsena vuttaṃ, dumā rukkhāti attho. Samantato sabbadisā pavantīti,
analyzed: dumāni iti liṅga vipallāsena vuttam dumā rukkhā ti attho samantataḥ sabbadisā pavanti iti
translated: ‘Dumānī’ is said with a change of gender; the meaning is: ‘trees.’ ‘Blossom all around in every direction’

original: samantato sabbabhāgato sabbadisāsu ca phullāni, tathā phullattā eva sabbadisā pavanti🔽gandhaṃ vissajjenti. Āsamānāti āsīsantā gahitukāmā. Evaṃ rukkhasobhāya gamanamaggassa🔽rāmaṇeyyataṃ dassetvā idāni “nevātisīta”ntiādinā utusampattiṃ dasseti. Sukhāti nātisītanātiuṇhabhāveneva
analyzed: samantataḥ sabba bhāgataḥ sabba disāsu ca phullāni tathā phullattāḥ eva sabba disā pavanti  gandham vissajjenti āsamānā ati āsīsantā gahitu kāmā evam rukkha sobhāya gamana maggassa  rāmaṇeyyatam dassetvā idāni na iva atisītan ti ādinā utu sampattim dasseti sukhāti na atisītana ati uṇha bhāvena iva
translated: means: they blossom in every way, in every direction, and because they blossom thus, they ‘blossom all around in every direction.’🔽They emit fragrance. ‘Come to enjoy’ means: they come to enjoy, they come to take. Having thus shown the beauty of the trees on the road by which he was going, he now shows the excellence of the climate with ‘neither too cold’ and so on. ‘Pleasant’ means: not too cold and not too hot,

original: sukhā iṭṭhā. Utu addhaniyāti addhānagamanayoggā utu. Passantu taṃ sākiyā koḷiyā ca,
analyzed: sukhā iṭṭhā utu addhaniyā ati addhānagamanayoggā utu passantu tam sākiyā koḷiyā ca
translated: therefore pleasant, desirable. ‘Climate suitable for travelling’ means: a climate suitable for travelling a long distance. ‘Let the Sākiyas and Koḷiyas see it’

original: pacchāmukhaṃ rohiniyaṃ tarantanti rohinī nāma nadī sākiyakoḷiyajanapadānaṃ antare
analyzed: pacchāmukham rohiniyam rohinī nāma nadī sākiya koḷiya janapadānam antare
translated: “Crossing the Rohini with its current facing eastwards”: The river Rohini is between the Sakyan and Koliyan countries.

original: uttaradisato dakkhiṇamukhā sandati, rājagahaṃ cassā puratthimadakkhiṇāya disāya,
analyzed: uttara disatas dakkhiṇa mukhā sandati rājagaham cassā puratthima dakkhiṇāya disāya
translated: It flows southwards from the northern direction, and Rajagaha is in its south-eastern direction.

original: tasmā rājagahato kapilavatthuṃ gantuṃ taṃ nadiṃ tarantā pacchāmukhā hutvā taranti.
analyzed: tasmai rājagahataḥ kapilavatthum gantum tam nadim pacchāmukhāḥ hutvā taranti
translated: Therefore, those who go from Rajagaha to Kapilavatthu cross the river with their faces to the west.

original: Tenāha “passantu taṃ…pe… taranta”nti. “Bhagavantaṃ pacchāmukhaṃ rohiniṃ nāma nadiṃ
analyzed: tena āha passantu taṃpe bhagavantam pacchāmukham rohinim nāma nadim
translated: Hence it is said: “Let them see you crossing the Rohini with its current facing eastwards.”

original: atikkamantaṃ sākiyakoḷiyajanapadavāsino passantū”ti kapilavatthugamanāya bhagavantaṃ āyācanto ussāheti.
analyzed: atikkamantam sākiya koḷiya janapada vāsino passantu uti kapilavatthu gamanāya bhagavantam āyācantaḥ ussāheti
translated: “Let the people living in the Sakyan and Koliyan countries see the Blessed One crossing the river Rohini” — thus he urges the Blessed One to go to Kapilavatthu.

original: Idāni attano patthanaṃ upamāhi pakāsento “āsāya kasate”ti gāthamāha. Āsāya kasate🔽khettanti kassako kasanto khettaṃ phalāsāya kasati. Bījaṃ āsāya vappatīti kasitvā
analyzed: idāni attanaḥ patthanam upamāhi pakāsentaḥ āsāya kasata iti gātham āha āsāya kasate  khettanti kassakaḥ kasanto khettam phala āsāya kasati bījam āsāya vappati iti kasitvā
translated: Now, in order to illustrate his request with a simile, he spoke the stanza, “He who ploughs a field in hope,” etc.🔽“He who ploughs a field in hope”: the ploughman ploughs the field in the hope of a crop.🔽“He who sows seed in hope”: having ploughed,

original: ca vapantena phalāsāya eva bījaṃ vappati nikkhipīyati. Āsāya vāṇijā yantīti dhanahārakā
analyzed: ca vapantena phala āsāya eva bījam vappati āsāya vāṇijāḥ yanti iti dhana hārakā
translated: he sows the seed in the hope of a crop. He puts it in. “The trader who goes by sea in hope”: the merchant who goes by sea

original: vāṇijā dhanāsāya samuddaṃ tarituṃ desaṃ upagantuṃ samuddaṃ nāvāya yanti gacchanti.
analyzed: vāṇijāḥ dhana āsāya samuddam taritum desam upagantum samuddam nāvāya yanti gacchanti
translated: The merchants set out on the ocean in a ship to go to the place they want to reach in order to make a profit.

original: Yāya āsāya tiṭṭhāmīti evaṃ ahampi yāya āsāya patthanāya bhagavā tumhākaṃ kapilapuragamanapatthanāya
analyzed: yāya āsāya tiṭṭhāmi iti evam aham pi yāya āsāya patthanāya bhagavā tumhākam kapilapura gamana patthanāya
translated: In the same way, I am standing here with the hope, with the wish, that the Blessed One will go to Kapilavatthu.

original: idha tiṭṭhāmi. Sā me āsā samijjhatu, tumhehi “kapilavatthu gantabba”nti vadati, āsāya
analyzed: idha tiṭṭhāmi sā me āsā samijjhatu tumhehi kapilavatthu gantabbanti vadati āsāya
translated: May that hope of mine be fulfilled. You say, “Kapilavatthu should be gone to.”

original: sadisatāya cettha kattukamyatāchandaṃ āsāti āha.
analyzed: sadisatāya ca itthā āsā iti āha
translated: In this context, the wish is the desire to do, which is similar to the hope.

original: Gamanamaggasaṃvaṇṇanādinā anekavāraṃ yācanāya kāraṇaṃ dassetuṃ “punappuna”ntiādi
analyzed: gamana magga saṃvaṇṇana ādinā aneka vāram yācanāya kāraṇam dassetum punappunanti ādi
translated: The words “again and again” are stated in order to show the reason for the repeated request by the praise of the path to be gone, and so on.

original: vuttaṃ. Tassattho – sakiṃ vuttamattena vappe asampajjamāne kassakā punappunaṃ dutiyampi🔽tatiyampi bījaṃ vapanti. Pajjunno devarājāpi ekavārameva avassitvā punappunaṃ kālena
analyzed: vuttam tassa atthaḥ sakim vutta mattena vappe a sampajjamāne kassakā punappunam dutiyam pi  tatiyam pi bījam vapanti pajjunnaḥ devarājā api eka vāram eva avassitvā punappunam kālena
translated: The meaning is this: When the farmers do not understand the cultivation, they sow the seed again and again, a second time,

original: kālaṃ vassati. Kassakāpi ekavārameva akasitvā sassasampattiatthaṃ paṃsuṃ kaddamaṃ
analyzed: kālam vassati kassakā api eka vāram eva a kasitvā sassa sampatti attham paṃsum kaddamam
translated: a third time. The king of the gods, Pajjunna, also rains again and again, from time to time, after having rained once. The farmers also, without having ploughed once, for the sake of the success of the harvest, remove the soil and the mud,

original: vā muduṃ kātuṃ khettaṃ punappunaṃ kasanti. Ekavārameva dhaññaṃ saṅgahaṃ katvā “alamettāvatā”ti
analyzed: vā mudum kātum khettam punappunam kasanti eka vāram eva dhaññam saṅgaham katvā alam ettāvatā iti
translated: But the grain is gathered in once only. Thinking: “That is enough,”

original: aparitussanato koṭṭhāgārādīsu paṭisāmanavasena manussehi upanīyamānaṃ punappunaṃ
analyzed: a paritussanataḥ koṭṭhāgāra ādīsu paṭisāmana vasena manussehi upanīyamānam punappunam
translated: the people, without being over-anxious, bring the grain again and again to the granary, etc., for storage.

original: sāliādidhaññaṃ raṭṭhaṃ upeti upagacchati.
analyzed: sāli ādi dhaññam raṭṭham upeti upagacchati
translated: The grain thus reaches the kingdom, i.e., comes to the people, again and again.

original: Yācanakāpi yācantā punappunaṃ kulāni caranti upagacchanti, na ekavārameva, yācitā🔽pana tesaṃ punappunaṃ dānapatī dadanti, na sakiṃyeva. Tathā pana deyyadhammaṃ punappunaṃ
analyzed: yācanakā api yācantā punappunam kulāni caranti upagacchanti na eka vāram eva yācitā  pana tesam punappunam dānapatī dadanti na sakiṃyeva tathā pana deyya dhammam punappunam
translated: The beggars, too, go to the houses again and again, i.e., they come to the houses again and again, not just once, when they are begging.🔽But the givers, when asked again and again, give again and again, not just once.

original: dānapatī daditvā dānamayaṃ puññaṃ upacinitvā punappunaṃ aparāparaṃ saggamupenti ṭhānaṃ
analyzed: dānapatī daditvā dāna mayam puññam upacinitvā punappunam apara aparam saggam upenti ṭhānam
translated: Thus the givers, having again and again given away the things to be given, having thus accumulated the merit consisting of giving, again and again reach heaven, i.e.,

original: paṭisandhivasena devalokaṃ upagacchanti. Tasmā ahampi punappunaṃ yācāmi bhagavā mayhaṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhi vasena deva lokam upagacchanti tasmai aham pi punappunam yācāmi bhagavā mayham
translated: they come to the heavenly world by way of rebirth. Therefore I, too, beg again and again. May the Blessed One

translated: “When the cool, fragrant, delightful breeze blows,

translated: “In the forest covered with flowers, on the cool mountain slope,

translated: after taking the Fortunate One’s feet on his head, worshipping the Teacher, sat down on one side together with a thousand ministers. The Teacher,

original: tesaṃ dhammaṃ desesi. Desanāpariyosāne saddhiṃ parisāya arahatte patiṭṭhāsi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: tesam dhammam desesi desanā pariyosāne saddhim parisāya arahatte patiṭṭhāsi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: and he preached the Dhamma to them. At the conclusion of the lesson, together with his retinue, he was established in Arahantship. Therefore it is said:

original: “Padumuttaro nāma jino, sabbadhammāna pāragū;
analyzed: padumuttaraḥ nāma jinaḥ sabba dhammāna pāragū
translated: “The Conqueror named Padumuttara, who had gone beyond all things,

original: Udito ajaṭākāse, ravīva saradambare.
analyzed: uditaḥ a jaṭā kāse raviḥ iva sarat ambare
translated: Shone forth in the place called Ajàtã, like the sun in a cloudless sky in autumn.

original: “Vacanābhāya bodheti, veneyyapadumāni so;
analyzed: vacana ābhāya bodha iti veneyya padumāni saḥ
translated: “He awakened the lotus-buds of his disciples with the radiance of his words,

original: Kilesapaṅkaṃ soseti, matiraṃsīhi nāyako.
analyzed: kilesa paṅkam
translated: And with the rays of his wisdom he dried up the mud of their passions.

original: “Titthiyānaṃ yase hanti, khajjotābhā yathā ravi;
analyzed: titthiyānam yase hanti khajjota ābhā yathā ravi
translated: “He destroyed the glory of the sectarians, as the sun destroys the glow of the fire-flies,

original: Saccatthābhaṃ pakāseti, ratanaṃva divākaro.
analyzed: saccattha ābham pakāseti ratanam va divākaraḥ
translated: And he revealed the radiance of the truth, as the sun reveals the jewel of the dawn.

original: “Guṇānaṃ āyatibhūto, ratanānaṃva sāgaro;
analyzed: āyati bhūtaḥ sāgaraḥ
translated: “He was the future of all virtues, as the ocean is of jewels,

original: Pajjunnoriva bhūtāni, dhammameghena vassati.
analyzed: pajjunnoḥ iva bhūtāni dhamma meghena vassati
translated: And he rained down the rain of the Dhamma with the clouds of his wisdom, as Pajjunna rains down water.

original: “Akkhadasso tadā āsiṃ, nagare haṃsasavhaye;
analyzed: akkhadassaḥ tadā āsim nagare haṃsa savhaye
translated: “I was a gambler in the city of Haṃsavati,

original: Upecca dhammamassosiṃ, jalajuttamanāmino.
analyzed: upecca dhamma massosim jala juttama nāminaḥ
translated: And I approached him and listened to the Dhamma, like a swan listening to the sound of the water.🔽“To the monk who was the disciple of the Teacher,

original: “Ovādakassa bhikkhūnaṃ, sāvakassa katāvino;
analyzed: ovādakassa bhikkhūnam sāvakassa katāvinaḥ
translated: Who was the foremost of those who had been admonished,

original: Guṇaṃ pakāsayantassa, tappayantassa me manaṃ.
analyzed: guṇam pakāsayantassa tappayantassa me manam
translated: And who was revealing his own virtues, I gave my heart.

original: “Sutvā patīto sumano, nimantetvā tathāgataṃ;
analyzed: sutvā sumanaḥ
translated: “Having heard him, I was filled with joy and gladness, and I invited the Tathágata,

original: Sasissaṃ bhojayitvāna, taṃ ṭhānamabhipatthayiṃ.
analyzed: sa sissam bhojayitvāna tam ṭhānam abhipatthayim
translated: and fed the king, I made a wish for that place.

original: “Tadā haṃsasamabhāgo, haṃsadundubhinissano;
analyzed: tadā haṃsa sama bhāgaḥ haṃsa dundubhi nissanaḥ
translated: “At that time I was the one who was like a goose, who had the voice of a goose,

original: Passathetaṃ mahāmattaṃ, vinicchayavisāradaṃ.
analyzed: passatha etam mahā mattam vinicchaya visāra dam
translated: you saw that great minister, who was skilled in deciding (cases).

original: “Patitaṃ pādamūle me, samuggatatanūruhaṃ;
analyzed: patitam pāda mūle me samuggata tanūruham
translated: “He fell at my feet, his body was covered in hair,

original: Jīmūtavaṇṇaṃ pīṇaṃsaṃ, pasannanayanānanaṃ.
analyzed: jīmūta vaṇṇam pīṇaṃsam pasanna nayana ānanam
translated: he was dark-brown in colour, his body was well-developed, his eyes and face were clear.

original: “Parivārena mahatā, rājayuttaṃ mahāyasaṃ;
analyzed: parivārena mahatā rāja yuttam mahā āyasam
translated: “With a great retinue, the king’s minister, of great fame,

original: Eso katāvino ṭhānaṃ, pattheti muditāsayo.
analyzed: eso katāvino ṭhānam pattheti mudita āsayo
translated: he, with a joyful heart, wished for the place of the one who had done (good deeds).

original: “Iminā paṇipātena, cāgena paṇidhīhi ca;
analyzed: iminā paṇipātena cāgena paṇidhīhi ca
translated: “Through this act of worship, through this offering, and through this aspiration,

original: Kappasatasahassāni, nupapajjati duggatiṃ.
analyzed: kappa sata sahassāni nu upapajjati duggatim
translated: for a hundred thousand aeons he will not go to the Downfall.

original: “Devesu devasobhaggaṃ, manussesu mahantataṃ;
analyzed: devesu deva sobhaggam manussesu mahantatam
translated: “Among the gods he will be the most beautiful, among humans he will be the greatest,

original: Anubhotvāna sesena, nibbānaṃ pāpuṇissati.
analyzed: anubhotvāna sesena nibbānam pāpuṇissati
translated: and having experienced (this) for the rest of (his) time, he will attain Emancipation.

original: “Satasahassito kappe, okkākakulasambhavo;
analyzed: sata sahassitaḥ kappe okkāka kula sambhavaḥ
translated: “After a hundred thousand aeons, (he will be born) in the family of the crows,

original: Gotamo nāma gottena, satthā loke bhavissati.
analyzed: gotamaḥ nāma gottena satthā loke bhavissati
translated: he will be called Gotama by family, and will be a Teacher in the world.

original: “Tassa dhammesu dāyādo, oraso dhammanimmito;
analyzed: tassa dhammesu dāyādaḥ orasaḥ dhamma nimmito
translated: “He will be an heir to his Dhamma, a direct product of his Dhamma,

original: Kappino nāma nāmena, hessati satthu sāvako.
analyzed: kappinaḥ nāma nāmena hessati satthu sāvakaḥ
translated: and will be called Kappina, and will be a disciple of the Teacher.

original: “Tatohaṃ sukataṃ kāraṃ, katvāna jinasāsane;
analyzed: tatas ham su katam kāram katvāna jina sāsane
translated: “Then I, having done a good deed, in the Dispensation of the Victor,

original: Jahitvā mānusaṃ dehaṃ, tusitaṃ agamāsahaṃ.
analyzed: jahitvā mānusam deham tusitam agama asaham
translated: I left the human body And went to the Tusita heaven.

original: “Devamānusarajjāni, sataso anusāsiya;
analyzed: satasaḥ
translated: “Having ruled over hundreds of kingdoms Of gods and humans,

original: Bārāṇasiyamāsanne, jāto keṇiyajātiyaṃ.
analyzed: bārāṇasiyam āsanne jātaḥ keṇiya jātiyam
translated: I was reborn near Bārāṇasī, In the Keṇiya clan.

original: “Sahassaparivārena, sapajāpatiko ahaṃ;
analyzed: sahassa parivārena sa pajāpatikaḥ aham
translated: “With a retinue of a thousand, Together with my wife,

original: Pañcapaccekabuddhānaṃ, satāni samupaṭṭhahiṃ.
analyzed: pañca paccekabuddhānam satāni samupaṭṭhahim
translated: I served five hundred Paccekabuddhas.

original: “Temāsaṃ bhojayitvāna, pacchādamha ticīvaraṃ;
analyzed: temāsam bhojayitvāna ti cīvaram
translated: “Having fed them for three months, Afterwards I gave them three robes.

original: Tato cutā mayaṃ sabbe, ahumha tidasūpagā.
analyzed: tato cutāḥ mayam sabbe ahumha tidasūpagā
translated: Then all of us, having passed away, Went to the heaven of the Thirty-three.

original: “Puno sabbe manussattaṃ, agamimha tato cutā;
analyzed: punar sabbe manussattam agamimha tatas cutā
translated: “Again, all of us, having passed away from there, Were reborn as humans.

original: Kukkuṭamhi pure jātā, himavantassa passato.
analyzed: kukkuṭamhi pure jātāḥ himavantassa passato
translated: We were born in the city of Kukkuṭa, In front of the Himalayas.

original: “Kappino nāmahaṃ āsiṃ, rājaputto mahāyaso;
analyzed: kappinaḥ nāma aham āsim rāja puttaḥ mahā yasaḥ
translated: “I was called Kappina, A prince of great fame.

original: Sesāmaccakule jātā, mameva parivārayuṃ.
analyzed: jātāḥ mama iva
translated: The others were born in the families of my ministers And served me.

original: “Mahārajjasukhaṃ patto, sabbakāmasamiddhimā;
analyzed: mahā rajja sukham pattaḥ sabba kāma samiddhimā
translated: “Having attained the happiness of a great kingdom, With all my desires fulfilled,

original: Vāṇijehi samakkhātaṃ, buddhuppādamahaṃ suṇiṃ.
analyzed: vāṇijehi samakkhātam buddhuppāda maham suṇim
translated: I heard of the arising of the Buddha, As proclaimed by merchants.

original: “Buddho loke samuppanno, asamo ekapuggalo;
analyzed: buddhaḥ loke samuppannaḥ asamaḥ eka puggalaḥ
translated: “The Buddha has arisen in the world, The matchless, one-to-one person.

original: So pakāseti saddhammaṃ, amataṃ sukhamuttamaṃ.
analyzed: saḥ pakāseti saddhammam amatam sukham uttamam
translated: He proclaims the true Dhamma, The deathless, supreme happiness.

original: “Suyuttā tassa sissā ca, sumuttā ca anāsavā;
analyzed: su yuttā tassa sissā ca su muttā ca anāsavā
translated: “His disciples are well-connected, Well-released, and without defilements.

original: Sutvā nesaṃ suvacanaṃ, sakkaritvāna vāṇije.
analyzed: sutvā na īsam suvacanam vāṇije
translated: Having heard their good words, I honoured the merchants.

original: “Pahāya rajjaṃ sāmacco, nikkhamiṃ buddhamāmako;
analyzed: pahāya rajjam sāmaccaḥ nikkhamim buddha māmakaḥ
translated: “Having given up the kingdom with my relatives, I went forth, devoted to the Buddha;

original: Nadiṃ disvā mahācandaṃ, pūritaṃ samatittikaṃ.
analyzed: nadim disvā mahā candam pūritam sama tittikam
translated: Having seen the great river Aciravatī, filled to the banks.

original: “Appatiṭṭhaṃ anālambaṃ, duttaraṃ sīghavāhiniṃ;
analyzed: appatiṭṭham anālambam duttaram sīgha vāhinim
translated: “Without support, without a foothold, difficult to cross, flowing swiftly;

original: Guṇaṃ saritvā buddhassa, sotthinā samatikkamiṃ.
analyzed: guṇam saritvā buddhassa sotthinā samatikkamiṃ
translated: Having remembered the Buddha’s qualities, I safely crossed over.

original: “Bhavasotaṃ sace buddho, tiṇṇo lokantagū vidū;
analyzed: bhava sotam sace buddhaḥ tiṇṇaḥ lokantagū vidū
translated: “If the Buddha has crossed the stream of existence, the wise one who has gone to the end of the world;

original: Etena saccavajjena, gamanaṃ me samijjhatu.
analyzed: etena saccavajjena gamanam me samijjhatu
translated: By this declaration of the truth, may my going be successful.

original: “Yadi santigamo maggo, mokkho caccantikaṃ sukhaṃ;
analyzed: yadi santi gamaḥ maggaḥ mokkhaḥ caccantikam sukham
translated: “If there is a path to the other side, freedom, happiness beyond grief;

original: Etena saccavajjena, gamanaṃ me samijjhatu.
analyzed: etena saccavajjena gamanam me samijjhatu
translated: By this declaration of the truth, may my going be successful.

original: “Saṅgho ce tiṇṇakantāro, puññakkhetto anuttaro;
analyzed: saṅghaḥ ce tiṇṇa kantāraḥ puñña kkhettaḥ anuttaro
translated: “If the Saṅgha is the one who has crossed over the flood, the unsurpassed field of merit;

original: Etena saccavajjena, gamanaṃ me samijjhatu.
analyzed: etena saccavajjena gamanam me samijjhatu
translated: By this declaration of the truth, may my going be successful.

original: “Saha kate saccavare, maggā apagataṃ jalaṃ;
analyzed: saha kate sacca vare maggāḥ apagatam jalam
translated: “When the excellent truth was spoken, the water on the path disappeared;

original: Tato sukhena uttiṇṇo, nadītīre manorame.
analyzed: tatas sukhena uttiṇṇaḥ nadī tīre manorame
translated: Then with ease I crossed over, to the delightful riverbank.

original: “Nisinnaṃ addasaṃ buddhaṃ, udentaṃva pabhaṅkaraṃ;
analyzed: nisinnam addasam buddham udentam iva pabhaṅkaram
translated: “I saw the Buddha sitting, like the rising sun,

original: Jalantaṃ hemaselaṃva, dīparukkhaṃva jotitaṃ.
analyzed: jalantam hema selam iva dīpa rukkham iva jotitam
translated: Like a burning golden peak, like a radiant island tree.

original: “Sasiṃva tārāsahitaṃ, sāvakehi purakkhataṃ;
analyzed: sasim iva tārā sahitam sāvakehi purakkhatam
translated: “Surrounded by his disciples, like the moon by the stars,

original: Vāsavaṃ viya vassantaṃ, desanājaladantaraṃ.
analyzed: vāsavam viya vassantam desanā jalada antaram
translated: The rain-cloud of the Teaching poured down, like Vāsava.

original: “Vanditvāna sahāmacco, ekamantamupāvisiṃ;
analyzed: vanditvāna ekamantam upāvisim
translated: “Having paid homage to the Buddha, I sat down to one side;

original: Tato no āsayaṃ ñatvā, buddho dhammamadesayi.
analyzed: tatas naḥ āsayam ñatvā buddhaḥ dhammam adesayi
translated: Then, knowing our disposition, the Buddha taught the Dhamma.

original: “Sutvāna dhammaṃ vimalaṃ, avocumha mayaṃ jinaṃ;
analyzed: sutvāna dhammam vimalam avocumha mayam jinam
translated: “Having heard the stainless Dhamma, we spoke to the Victor:

original: Pabbājehi mahāvīra, nibbindāmha mayaṃ bhave.
analyzed: pabbājehi mahāvīra nibbindāmha mayam bhave
translated: ‘Great hero, ordain us; we are disenchanted with existence.’

original: “Svakkhāto bhikkhave dhammo, dukkhantakaraṇāya vo;
analyzed: svakkhātaḥ bhikkhave dhammaḥ dukkhanta karaṇāya vaḥ
translated: “‘The Dhamma is well-expounded, monks, for the cessation of suffering.

original: Caratha brahmacariyaṃ, iccāha munisattamo.
analyzed: caratha brahmacariyam iccā āha muni sattamaḥ
translated: Practice the spiritual life; this is the Blessed One’s instruction.’

original: “Saha vācāya sabbepi, bhikkhuvesadharā mayaṃ;
analyzed: saha vācāya sabbe pi bhikkhu vesa dharāḥ mayam
translated: “With those words, we all became monks,

original: Ahumha upasampannā, sotāpannā ca sāsane.
analyzed: upasampannā sā utāpannā ca sā āsane
translated: and we were fully ordained and became stream-enterers in the Dispensation.

original: “Tato jetavanaṃ gantvā, anusāsi vināyako;
analyzed: tatas jetavanam gantvā
translated: “Then, having gone to Jeta’s Grove, the Teacher instructed us;

original: Anusiṭṭho jinenāhaṃ, arahattamapāpuṇiṃ.
analyzed: anusiṭṭhaḥ jinena aham
translated: instructed by the Victor, I attained perfection.

original: “Tato bhikkhusahassāni, anusāsimahaṃ tadā;
analyzed: tatas bhikkhu sahassāni anusāsim aham tadā
translated: “Then I instructed a thousand monks;

original: Mamānusāsanakarā, tepi āsuṃ anāsavā.
analyzed: mama anusāsana karā te pi āsum anāsavā
translated: those who followed my instructions were also free from defilements.

original: “Jino tasmiṃ guṇe tuṭṭho, etadagge ṭhapesi maṃ;
analyzed: jinaḥ tasmin guṇe tuṭṭhaḥ etad agge ṭhapesi mam
translated: “The Victor, pleased with my virtue, placed me at the head of those

original: Bhikkhuovādakānaggo, kappinoti mahājane.
analyzed: mahājane
translated: who instruct the monks, of those who are worthy of offerings from the great people.

original: “Satasahasse kataṃ kammaṃ, phalaṃ dassesi me idha;
analyzed: sata sahasse katam kammam phalam dassesi me idha
translated: “A hundred thousand deeds have I performed, and now their fruit is shown to me.

original: Pamutto saravegova, kilese jhāpayiṃ mama.
analyzed: pamuttaḥ sara vegaḥ uva kilese mama
translated: Like one who has escaped from prison, I have burned up all the Depravities.

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: “I have burned up all the Depravities. . . . I have fulfilled the Teacher’s bidding.”

original: Arahattaṃ patvā pana te sabbeva satthāraṃ pabbajjaṃ yāciṃsu. Satthā te “etha, bhikkhavo”ti
analyzed: arahattam patvā pana te sabbe iva satthāram pabbajjam yāciṃsu satthā te bhikkhavaḥ ti
translated: But when they had attained Arahatship, they all asked the Teacher to admit them to the Order. The Teacher said to them, “Come, monks!”

original: āha. Sā eva tesaṃ pabbajjā upasampadā ca ahosi. Satthā taṃ bhikkhusahassaṃ ādāya
analyzed: āha sā eva tesam pabbajjā upasampadā ca ahosi satthā tam bhikkhu sahassam ādāya
translated: This was their admission into the Order and their ordination as monks. The Teacher took the thousand monks with him and

original: ākāsena jetavanaṃ agamāsi. Athekadivasaṃ bhagavā tassantevāsike bhikkhū āha – “kacci,🔽bhikkhave, kappino bhikkhūnaṃ dhammaṃ desetī”ti? “Na, bhagavā, deseti. Appossukko
analyzed: ākāsena jetavanam agamāsi atha eka divasam bhagavā tassa antevāsike bhikkhū āha kacci  bhikkhave kappinaḥ bhikkhūnam dhammam deseti iti na bhagavā deseti appa ussukkaḥ
translated: went through the air to Jetavana. One day the Exalted One said to the monks who were his pupils, “Monks,

original: diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāramanuyutto viharati, ovādamattampi na detī”ti. Satthā theraṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāram anuyuttaḥ viharati ovāda mattam pi na deti iti satthā theraṃ
translated: I trust that the monk Kappina is teaching the monks the Law?” “No, Reverend Sir, he is not teaching the Law. He is living a life of ease, enjoying the happiness of the life of one who has done his duty. He does not even give advice to the monks.” The Teacher sent for the Elder Kappina and asked him,

original: pakkosāpetvā – “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, kappina, antevāsikānaṃ ovādamattampi na desī”ti?
analyzed: pakkosāpetvā saccam kira tvam kappina antevāsikānam ovāda mattam pi na desi iti
translated: “Is it true, Kappina, that you are doing as these monks say?”

original: “Saccaṃ, bhagavā”ti. “Brāhmaṇa, mā evaṃ kari, ajja paṭṭhāya upagatānaṃ dhammaṃ desehī”ti.🔽“Sādhu, bhante”ti thero satthu vacanaṃ sirasā sampaṭicchitvā ekovādeneva samaṇasahassaṃ
analyzed: saccam bhagavā ati brāhmaṇa mā evam kari ajja paṭṭhāya upagatānam dhammam desehi iti  sādhu bhante ti theraḥ satthu vacanam sirasā sampaṭicchitvā ekovādena iva samaṇa sahassam
translated: “It is true, Reverend Sir.” “Brahmin, do not act thus. From this day forth, preach the Law to those who come to you.”

original: arahatte patiṭṭhāpesi. Tena naṃ satthā paṭipāṭiyā attano sāvake there ṭhānantare
analyzed: arahatte patiṭṭhāpesi tena nam satthā paṭipāṭiyā attano sāvake there ṭhāna antare
translated: “Very well, Reverend Sir,” replied the Elder, and with bowed head accepted the words of the Teacher. By means of a single exhortation he established a thousand monks in Arahatship. The Teacher, placing the Elder in the foremost position among those who exhort the monks,

original: ṭhapento bhikkhuovādakānaṃ aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapesi. Athekadivasaṃ thero bhikkhuniyo ovadanto –
analyzed: ṭhapentaḥ bhikkhu ovādakānam aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapesi atha eka divasam theraḥ bhikkhuniyo ovadantaḥ
translated: placed the other Elders in the various positions in due order. One day the Elder, exhorting the nuns, said as follows,

original: “Anāgataṃ yo paṭikacca passati, hitañca atthaṃ ahitañca taṃ dvayaṃ;
analyzed: anāgatam yaḥ paṭikacca passati hitam ca attham ahitam ca tam dvayam
translated: “He who looks into the future, and sees both good and evil,

original: Viddesino tassa hitesino vā, randhaṃ na passanti samekkhamānā.
analyzed: viddesinaḥ tassa hitesinaḥ vā randham na passanti samekkhamānā
translated: whether he be a seeker after truth or a teacher of truth, will find no occasion for fault-finding.

original: “Ānāpānasatī yassa, paripuṇṇā subhāvitā;
analyzed: āna apāna satī yassa paripuṇṇā su bhāvitā
translated: “He whose mindfulness of breathing is complete, and well developed,

original: Anupubbaṃ paricitā, yathā buddhena desitā;
analyzed: anupubbam paricitā yathā buddhena desitā
translated: and who has thoroughly mastered it, step by step, as taught by the Buddha,

original: Somaṃ lokaṃ pabhāseti, abbhā muttova candimā.
analyzed: somam lokam pabhāseti abbhā muttaḥ uva candimā
translated: shines forth in the world like the moon when freed from a cloud.

original: “Odātaṃ vata me cittaṃ, appamāṇaṃ subhāvitaṃ;
analyzed: odātam vata me cittam appamāṇam su bhāvitam
translated: “My mind is pure, and immeasurable, and well developed;

original: Nibbiddhaṃ paggahītañca, sabbā obhāsate disā.
analyzed: nibbiddham paggahītam ca sabbā obhāsate disā
translated: shines in all directions.

original: “Jīvate vāpi sappañño, api vittaparikkhayo;
analyzed: jīvate vā api sappaññaḥ api vitta parikkhayaḥ
translated: The wise one lives even if his wealth is lost,

original: Paññāya ca alābhena, vittavāpi na jīvati.
analyzed: paññāya ca alābhena vittavā api na jīvati
translated: but the one who is not wise does not live even if he has wealth.

original: “Paññā sutavinicchinī, paññā kittisilokavaddhanī;
analyzed: paññā suta vinicchinī paññā
translated: Wisdom is the judge of what is heard; wisdom increases fame and praise;

original: Paññāsahito naro idha, api dukkhesu sukhāni vindati.
analyzed: paññā sahitaḥ naraḥ idha api dukkhesu sukhāni vindati
translated: the person who is endowed with wisdom finds happiness even in the midst of suffering.

original: “Nāyaṃ ajjatano dhammo, nacchero napi abbhuto;
analyzed: na ayam ajjatanaḥ dhammaḥ na cheraḥ na pi abbhutaḥ
translated: This is not a new teaching, nor is it a wonder,

original: Yattha jāyetha mīyetha, tattha kiṃ viya abbhutaṃ.
analyzed: yattha jāyetha mīyetha tattha kim viya abbhutam
translated: where one is born and dies—what is there to wonder at?🔽For immediately after birth,

original: “Anantarañhi jātassa, jīvitā maraṇaṃ dhuvaṃ;
analyzed: anantaram hi jātassa jīvitā maraṇam dhuvam
translated: death is certain for the living.

original: Jātā jātā marantīdha, evaṃ dhammā hi pāṇino.
analyzed: jātāḥ jātāḥ maranti idha evam dhammāḥ hi pāṇinaḥ
translated: The born are dying here—such is the nature of living beings.

original: “Na hetadatthāya matassa hoti, yaṃ jīvitatthaṃ paraporisānaṃ;
analyzed: na ha etat atthāya matassa hoti yam jīvita attham para porisānam
translated: It is not for the sake of that, for the sake of life, that one should harm another.

original: Matamhi ruṇṇaṃ na yaso na lokyaṃ, na vaṇṇitaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇehi.
analyzed: ruṇṇam na yasaḥ na lokyam na vaṇṇitam samaṇa brāhmaṇehi
translated: When one is dead, there is no fame, no reputation, no praise by ascetics and brahmins.

original: “Cakkhuṃ sarīraṃ upahanti tena, nihīyati vaṇṇabalaṃ matī ca;
analyzed: cakkhum sarīram upahanti tena nihīyati vaṇṇa balam matī ca
translated: The eye harms the body; because of that, beauty, strength, and wisdom diminish.

original: Ānandino tassa disā bhavanti, hitesino nāssa sukhī bhavanti.
analyzed: ānandinaḥ tassa disāḥ bhavanti hitesinaḥ na assa sukhī bhavanti
translated: Those who delight in it have misfortune; those who wish it well are not happy.

original: “Tasmā hi iccheyya kule vasante, medhāvino ceva bahussute ca;
analyzed: tasmai hi iccheyya kule vasante medhāvino ca iva bahussute ca
translated: “Therefore one should wish for the living in a family, the wise and the learned,

original: Yesañhi paññāvibhavena kiccaṃ, taranti nāvāya nadiṃva puṇṇa”nti. –
analyzed: yesam hi paññā vibhavena kiccam taranti nāvāya nadim iva puṇṇanti
translated: For by the wealth of their wisdom they accomplish their task, like a boat full of people crossing a river.”

original: Imā gāthā abhāsi.
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: He spoke these verses.

original: Tattha anāgatanti na āgataṃ, avindanti, attho. Paṭikaccāti putetaraṃyeva. Passatīti
analyzed: tattha anāgatam ti na āgatam avindanti attho paṭikacca ati putetaraṃ yeva passati iti
translated: Herein, not come is not arrived, not found is the meaning. Before is more quickly. Sees is

original: oloketi. Atthanti kiccaṃ. Taṃ dvayanti hitāhitaṃ. Viddesinoti amittā. Hitesinoti
analyzed: oloketi kiccam tam dvayanti hita ahitam viddesinoti amittāḥ hitesinoti
translated: looks. Task is purpose. That twofold is beneficial and harmful. Seekers of a weakness are enemies. Seekers of welfare are

original: mittā. Randhanti chiddaṃ. Samekkhamānāti gavesantā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yo puggalo🔽attano hitāvahaṃ ahitāvahaṃ tadubhayañca atthaṃ kiccaṃ anāgataṃ asampattaṃ puretaraṃyeva
analyzed: mittāḥ randhanti chiddam samekkhamānāḥ ati gavesantāḥ idam vuttam hoti yaḥ puggalo  tat ubhayam ca attham kiccam anāgatam asampattam puretaraṃya eva
translated: friends. Opening is a hole. Looking for is seeking. This is what is said:

original: paññācakkhunā ahaṃ viya passati vīmaṃsati vicāreti, tassa amittā vā ahitajjhāsayena
analyzed: paññācakkhunā aham viya passati vīmaṃsati vicāreti tassa amittā vā
translated: The person who, like me, sees with the eye of wisdom, investigates and considers, before it has come, before it has arrived, the purpose, the task, which is beneficial, which is harmful, and which is both beneficial and harmful,

original: mittā vā hitajjhāsayena randhaṃ gavesantā na passanti, tādiso paññavā puggalo acchiddavutti,
analyzed: mittāḥ vā randham gavesantāḥ na passanti tādiso paññavā puggalo acchidda vutti
translated: his enemies, with a desire to do harm, or his friends, with a desire to do good, do not see a weakness while seeking for one. Such a wise person is one who lives without an opening,

original: tasmā tumhehi tathārūpehi bhavitabbanti.🔽Idāni ānāpānasatibhāvanāya guṇaṃ dassento tattha tāni yojetuṃ “ānāpānasatī yassā”ti
analyzed: tasmā tumhehi tathārūpehi bhavitabbanti  idāni āna apāna sati bhāvanāya guṇam dassento tattha tāni yojetum āna apāna satī yassa iti
translated: Therefore you should be like that.🔽Now, showing the benefit of the development of mindfulness of breathing, he said the second stanza, beginning “Mindfulness of breathing,” in order to direct them to it.

original: dutiyaṃ gāthamāha. Tattha ānanti assāso. Apānanti passāso. Assāsapassāsanimittārammaṇā🔽sati ānāpānasati. Satisīsena cettha taṃsampayuttasamādhibhāvanā adhippetā. Yassāti,
analyzed: dutiyam gātham āha tattha ānanti assāsaḥ apānanti passāsaḥ assāsa passāsa nimitta ārammaṇā  sati āna apāna sati sati sīsena ca ittha tad sampayutta samādhi bhāvanā adhippetā yassa āti
translated: Herein, in-breath is assāsa; out-breath is passāsa. Mindfulness with the in-breath and out-breath as its object is mindfulness of breathing. And here the development of concentration associated with mindfulness is intended.

original: yassa yogino. Paripuṇṇā subhāvitāti catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ soḷasannañca ākārānaṃ
analyzed: yassa yogino paripuṇṇā su bhāvitā ati catunnam satipaṭṭhānānam soḷasannam ca ākārānam
translated: Whose is complete, well developed: it is complete in the sense of being fulfilled by the fulfilment of the four foundations of mindfulness and the sixteen kinds of contemplation,

original: pāripūriyā sabbaso puṇṇā sattannaṃ bojjhaṅgānaṃ vijjāvimuttīnañca pāripūriyā suṭṭhu🔽bhāvitā vaḍḍhitā. Anupubbaṃ paricitā, yathā buddhena desitāti “so satova assasatī”tiādinā
analyzed: pāripūriyā sabbaso puṇṇā sattannam bojjhaṅgānam vijjā vimuttīnam ca pāripūriyā suṭṭhu  bhāvitā vaḍḍhitā anupubbam paricitā yathā buddhena desitā ati saḥ satas iva assasati itiādinā
translated: and it is well developed in the sense of being increased and expanded by the fulfilment of the seven factors of enlightenment and of the knowledge and freedom.🔽Contemplated in due order as taught by the Buddha: it is contemplated in due order, practised, made to occur frequently, in the way taught by the Blessed One in the passage beginning “He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in … shall breathe out experiencing happiness’” .🔽It is contemplated in due order, practised, made to occur frequently, in the way taught by the Blessed One in the passage beginning “He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in … shall breathe out experiencing bliss’” .

original: yathā bhagavatā desitā, tathā anupubbaṃ anukkamena paricitā āsevitā bhāvitā. Somaṃ
analyzed: yathā bhagavatā desitā tathā anupubbam anukkamena paricitā āsevitā bhāvitā somam
translated: It is contemplated in due order, practised, made to occur frequently, in the way taught by the Blessed One in the passage beginning “He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in … shall breathe out tranquilizing the bodily formation’” .🔽It is contemplated in due order, practised, made to occur frequently, in the way taught by the Blessed One in the passage beginning “He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in … shall breathe out experiencing the mind’” .🔽It is contemplated in due order, practised, made to occur frequently, in the way taught by the Blessed One in the passage beginning “He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in … shall breathe out gladdening the mind’” .🔽It is contemplated in due order, practised, made to occur frequently, in the way taught by the Blessed One in the passage beginning “He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in … shall breathe out concentrating the mind’” .🔽It is contemplated in due order, practised, made to occur frequently, in the way taught by the Blessed One in the passage beginning “He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in … shall breathe out liberating the mind’” .🔽It is contemplated in due order, practised, made to occur frequently, in the way taught by

original: lokaṃ pabhāseti, abbhā muttova candimāti so yogāvacaro yathā abbhādiupakkilesā vimutto
analyzed: lokam pabhāseti abbhā muttaḥ uva candimā iti saḥ yoga avacaraḥ yathā abbhā ādi upakkilesāḥ vimuttaḥ
translated: He illuminates the world, as does the moon when it is freed from an eclipse.

original: cando candālokena imaṃ okāsalokaṃ pabhāseti, evaṃ avijjādiupakkilesavimutto ñāṇālokena
analyzed: cando canda ālokena imam okāsa lokam pabhāseti evam avijjā ādi upakkilesa vimuttaḥ ñāṇa ālokena
translated: Just as the moon, when freed from an eclipse, illuminates the world with its own light, so the meditator, when freed from the defilements of ignorance, etc.,

original: attasantānapatitaṃ parasantānapatitañca saṅkhāralokaṃ pabhāseti pakāseti. Tasmā tumhehi
analyzed: atta santāna patitam para santāna patitam ca saṅkhāra lokam pabhāseti pakāseti tasmā tumhehi
translated: illuminates, makes manifest, the world of formations that is included in his own continuum and in the continua of others. Therefore you should

original: ānāpānasatibhāvanā bhāvetabbāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: āna apāna sati bhāvanā bhāvetabbā ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: develop the meditation on mindfulness of breathing.

original: Idāni attānaṃ nidassanaṃ katvā bhāvanābhiyogassa saphalataṃ dassento “odātaṃ vata🔽me citta”nti tatiyaṃ gāthamāha. Tassattho – nīvaraṇamalavigamato odātaṃ suddhaṃ vata
analyzed: idāni attānam nidassanam katvā bhāvanā abhiyogassa saphala tam dassento odātam vata  me cittam ti tatiyam gātham āha tassa atthaḥ nīvaraṇa mala vigamataḥ odātam suddham vata
translated: Now, showing the success of his own devotion to meditation by pointing to himself, he said the third stanza:🔽“My mind is pure and bright,🔽The meaning is this. My mind is pure and bright, cleansed by the removal of the stain of the hindrances.

original: mama cittaṃ. Yathā pamāṇakarā rāgādayo pahīnā, appamāṇañca nibbānaṃ paccakkhaṃ kataṃ
analyzed: mama cittam yathā pamāṇa karāḥ rāga ādayaḥ pahīnāḥ appamāṇam ca nibbānam paccakkham katam
translated: As the measureless has been realized by me,

original: ahosi, tathā bhāvitattā appamāṇaṃ subhāvitaṃ, tato eva catusaccaṃ nibbiddhaṃ paṭivijjhitaṃ,
analyzed: ahosi tathā bhāvita ttā appamāṇam su bhāvitam tatas eva catu saccam nibbiddham paṭivijjhitam
translated: and the measureless has been well developed by me, and the four noble truths have been penetrated by me through the dispassion that arises from the measureless,

original: sakalasaṃkilesapakkhato paggahitañca hutvā dukkhādikā pubbantādikā ca disā obhāsate
analyzed: sakala saṃkilesa pakkhataḥ paggahitañca hutvā dukkha ādikā pubbanta ādikā ca disā obhāsate
translated: and having taken up the side of the whole of the defilement-class, it illuminates the directions of suffering, etc., and of the past, etc.

original: tattha vitiṇṇakaṅkhattā sabbadhammesu vigatasammohattā ca. Tasmā tumhehipi evaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: tattha vitiṇṇa kaṅkha ttā sabba dhammesu vigata sammoha ttā ca tasmā tumhehi pi evam cittam
translated: Herein, because of the absence of doubt, and because of the absence of confusion about all ideas,

original: bhāvetabbanti dasseti.
analyzed: bhāvetabbanti dasseti
translated: therefore he shows that it should be developed by you too.

original: Yathā bhāvanāmayā paññā cittamalavisodhanādinā purisassa bahupakārā, evaṃ itarāpīti
analyzed: yathā bhāvanā mayā paññā citta mala visodhana ādinā purisassa bahu pakārā evam itarā api iti
translated: Just as wisdom consisting in what is heard, etc., is of much service to a man by the purification of the mind’s surface, etc., so too is the other,

original: dassento “jīvate vāpi sappañño”ti catutthagāthamāha. Tassattho – parikkhīṇadhanopi
analyzed: dassentaḥ jīvate vā api sappaññaḥ ti catuttha gātham āha tassa atthaḥ parikkhīṇa dhanaḥ api
translated: showing this, he said the fourth stanza, ‘The wise man lives though poor in wealth’, the meaning of which is this: a man of wise understanding, though his wealth be exhausted,

original: sappaññajātiko itarītarasantosena santuṭṭho anavajjāya jīvikāya jīvatiyeva. Tassa
analyzed: sappañña jātiko itarītara santosena santuṭṭho anavajjāya jīvikāya jīvatiyā iva tassa
translated: lives content with what is got anyhow, and he lives by a blameless means of living.

original: hi jīvitaṃ jīvitaṃ nāma. Tenāha bhagavā – “paññājīviṃ jīvitamāhu seṭṭha”nti. Dummedhapuggalo
analyzed: hi jīvitam jīvitam nāma tena āha bhagavā paññā jīvim jīvitam āhu seṭṭham ti dummedha puggalo
translated: For his living is a living indeed. Hence the Blessed One said ‘The wise man’s living they call best of livings’ .

original: pana paññāya alābhena diṭṭhadhammikaṃ samparāyikañca atthaṃ virādhento vittavāpi
analyzed: pana paññāya alābhena diṭṭhadhammikam samparāyikam ca attham virādhentaḥ
translated: But a man of dull understanding, by failing to acquire the other kinds of wisdom, fails to get the benefit both in this life and in the life to come,🔽and though he has wealth,

original: na jīvati, garahādippattiyā jīvanto nāma na tassa hoti, anupāyaññutāya vā yathādhigataṃ🔽dhanaṃ nāsento jīvitampi sandhāretuṃ na sakkotiyeva, tasmā pārihāriyapaññāpi tumhehi
analyzed: na jīvati garaha ādi ppattiyā jīvantaḥ nāma na tassa hoti anupāyaññutāya vā yathā adhigatam  dhanam na āsentaḥ jīvitam pi sandhāretum na tasmā pārihāriya paññā api tumhehi
translated: He does not live, for one who lives by the means of blame does not live in the true sense, or else, because of his unskillfulness, he is unable to maintain his life by the means he has learned.🔽Therefore, even the wisdom of a miser is not for you.

original: appamattehi sampādetabbāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: appamattehi sampādetabbā ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: He does not live, for he who lives by the acquisition of blame does not live. Or, because he is not skillful in means, he cannot even keep himself alive by selling the wealth he has acquired. Therefore, the intention is that you should also acquire the wisdom of skill in means.

original: Idāni paññāya ānisaṃse dassetuṃ “paññā sutavinicchinī”ti pañcamaṃ gāthamāha. Tattha
analyzed: idāni paññāyaḥ ānisaṃse dassetum paññā suta vinicchinī iti pañcamam gātham āha tattha
translated: Now, in order to point out the benefits of wisdom, he uttered the fifth stanza: “Wisdom discerns what is heard.” Herein

original: paññā sutavinicchinīti paññā nāmesā sutassa vinicchayinī, yathāsute sotapathamāgate
analyzed: paññā suta vinicchinī ti paññā nāma īsā sutassa vinicchayinī yathā sute sota patham āgate
translated: wisdom discerns what is heard: this wisdom is the discerner of what is heard. When the meaning that has been heard comes into the range of hearing,

original: atthe “ayaṃ akusalo, ayaṃ kusalo, ayaṃ sāvajjo, ayaṃ anavajjo”tiādinā vinicchayajananī.
analyzed: atthe ayam akusalaḥ ayam kusalaḥ ayam sa avajjaḥ ayam anavajjaḥ iti ādinā vinicchaya jananī
translated: it generates discernment thus: “This is unskillful, this is skillful; this is blameworthy, this is blameless,” and so on.

original: Kittisilokavaddhanīti kittiyā sammukhā pasaṃsāya silokassa patthaṭayasabhāvassa vaddhanī,
analyzed: kitti siloka vaddhanī iti kittiyā sammukhā pasaṃsāya silokassa patthaṭa yasa bhāvassa vaddhanī
translated: It increases fame and renown: it increases fame, which is praise in the present, and renown, which is the nature of being well known.

original: paññavatoyeva hi kittiādayo viññūnaṃ pāsaṃsabhāvato. Paññāsahitoti pārihāriyapaññāya,
analyzed: paññavataḥ yā iva hi kitti ādayaḥ viññūnam pāsaṃsa bhāvato paññā sahitaḥ ti pārihāriya paññāya
translated: For it is only the wise man who has fame, etc., because of his being worthy of praise by the discerning. Accompanied by wisdom: accompanied by the wisdom of skill in means.

original: vipassanāpaññāya ca yutto. Api dukkhesu sukhāni vindatīti ekantadukkhasabhāvesu khandhāyatanādīsu
analyzed: vipassanā paññāya ca yuttaḥ api dukkhesu sukhāni vindati iti ekanta dukkha sabhāvesu khandha āyatana ādīsu
translated: and he is endowed with the wisdom of insight.🔽Even in the midst of suffering he finds happiness.

original: sammāpaṭipattiyā yathābhūtasabhāvāvabodhena nirāmisānipi sukhāni paṭilabhati.🔽Idāni tāsaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ aniccatāpaṭisaṃyuttaṃ dhīrabhāvāvahaṃ dhammaṃ kathento “nāyaṃ
analyzed: sammā paṭipattiyā yathā bhūta sabhāva avabodhena nirāmisāni api sukhāni paṭilabhati  idāni tāsam bhikkhunīnam anicca tā paṭisaṃyuttam dhīra bhāva āvaham dhammam kathentaḥ na ayam
translated: By the right practice of the path, by the understanding of the true nature of things, he obtains the happiness of the deathless even in the midst of the aggregates, sense bases, etc., which are by nature entirely suffering.

original: ajjatano dhammo”tiādinā sesagāthā abhāsi. Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepattho – yvāyaṃ sattānaṃ🔽jāyanamīyanasabhāvo, ayaṃ dhammo ajjatano adhunāgato na hoti, abhiṇhapavattikatāya
analyzed: ajjatanaḥ dhammaḥ ti ādinā sesa gāthāḥ abhāsi tatra ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ yvā ayam sattānam  ayam dhammaḥ ajjatanaḥ adhunāgataḥ na hoti abhiṇha pavattika tāya
translated: Now, in order to teach the Dhamma, which is the source of courage and is concerned with impermanence, to those nuns, the Buddha spoke the remaining verses, beginning with the line, “This nature of things is not of today” . Here is the condensed meaning:

original: na acchariyo, abbhutapubbatābhāvato nāpi abbhuto. Tasmā yattha jāyetha mīyetha, yasmiṃ
analyzed: na acchariyaḥ abbhuta pubbata abhāvataḥ na api abbhutaḥ tasmai yattha jāyetha mīyetha yasmin
translated: This nature of things, which is the arising and passing away of beings, is not of today, not of this present time; it is not wonderful because it occurs frequently; nor is it marvelous because it is not something new.

original: loke satto jāyeyya, so ekaṃsena mīyetha, tattha kiṃ viya? Kiṃ nāma abbhutaṃ siyā?
analyzed: loke sattaḥ jāyeyya saḥ ekaṃsena mīyetha tattha kim viya kim nāma abbhutam siyā
translated: Therefore, wherever a being is born, in whatever world, he will certainly die. What is there to wonder at? What is marvelous?

original: Sabhāvikattā maraṇassa – na hi khaṇikamaraṇassa kiñci kāraṇaṃ atthi. Yato anantarañhi
analyzed: sabhāvika ttā maraṇassa na hi khaṇika maraṇassa kiñci kāraṇam atthi yatas anantaram hi
translated: Because death is natural. For there is no cause for momentary death.

original: jātassa, jīvitā maraṇaṃ dhuvaṃ jātassa jātisamanantaraṃ jīvitato maraṇaṃ ekantikaṃ🔽uppannānaṃ khandhānaṃ ekaṃsena bhijjanato. Yo panettha jīvatīti lokavohāro, so tadupādānassa
analyzed: jātassa jīvitā maraṇam dhuvam jātassa jāti samanantaram jīvitataḥ maraṇam ekantikam  uppannānam khandhānam ekaṃsena bhijjanataḥ yaḥ pana ittha jīvati iti lokavohāro so tad upādānassa
translated: Death is certain for the born: death is certain for the born, is inevitable for those who have been born, because the aggregates that have arisen are bound to break up.

original: anekapaccayāyattatāya anekantiko, yasmā etadevaṃ, tasmā jātā marantīdha, evaṃdhammā
analyzed: aneka paccaya āyatta tāya anekantikaḥ yasmai etat evam tasmai jātāḥ maranti idha evaṃdhammā
translated: But the worldly convention “he lives” is not certain, because it depends on many conditions.🔽Since this is so, therefore: “The born die here; such is the nature of living beings.”

original: hi pāṇinoti ayaṃ sattānaṃ pakati, yadidaṃ jātānaṃ maraṇanti jātiyā maraṇānubandhanataṃ āha.
analyzed: hi pāṇinā iti ayam sattānam yat idam jātānam āha
translated: This is the nature of living beings, namely, that death follows on birth.

original: Idāni yasmā tāsu bhikkhunīsu kāci sokabandhitacittāpi atthi, tasmā tāsaṃ sokavinodanaṃ
analyzed: idāni yasmā tāsu bhikkhunīsu kāci soka bandhita cittā api atthi tasmā tāsam soka vinodanam
translated: Now, since some of those bhikkhunis were still bound by sorrow, he said this in order to dispel their sorrow:

original: kātuṃ “na hetadatthāyātiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha na hetadatthāya matassa hotīti yaṃ matassa🔽jīvitatthaṃ jīvitanimittaṃ paraporisānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ ruṇṇaṃ, etaṃ tassa matassa
analyzed: kātum na ha etad atthāya atiādi vuttam tattha na ha etad atthāya matassa hoti iti yam matassa  jīvita attham jīvita nimittam para porisānam para puggalānam ruṇṇam etam tassa matassa
translated: “Not for the sake of that” . Herein, not for the sake of that means not for the sake of the dead man’s life.

original: sattassa jīvitatthaṃ tāva tiṭṭhatu, kassacipi atthāya na hoti, ye pana rudanti, tesampi

translated: The meaning is: he gave it to me. But some read “adāsī” as “pādapuñchani” . Some say:

analyzed: pāda puñchana coḷakkhaṇḍam pāda asi iti vadanti tat ayuttam iddhiyā abhisaṅkharitvā coḷakkhaṇḍassa
translated: “He gave me a piece of cloth for washing the feet.”🔽This is appropriate, because he gave a piece of cloth that he had created by supernormal power.🔽You should resolve on this pure cloth:

original: dinnattā. Etaṃ suddhaṃ adhiṭṭhehi, ekamantaṃ svadhiṭṭhitanti, etaṃ suddhaṃ coḷakkhaṇḍaṃ🔽“rajoharaṇaṃ, rajoharaṇa”nti manasikārena svadhiṭṭhitaṃ katvā ekamantaṃ ekamante
analyzed: etam suddham adhiṭṭhehi ekamantam su adhiṭṭhitan ti etam suddham coḷa kkhaṇḍaṃ  rajoharaṇam rajoharaṇam ti manasikārena su adhiṭṭhitam katvā ekam antam ekam ante
translated: you should resolve on this pure piece of cloth,🔽making it resolved by the attention “dustbin, dustbin.” Sitting in a secluded place, in front of the perfumed chamber,

original: vivitte gandhakuṭipamukhe nisinno adhiṭṭhehi tathā cittaṃ samāhitaṃ katvā pavattehi.
analyzed: vivitte gandha kuṭi pamukhe nisinnaḥ adhiṭṭhehi tathā cittam samāhitam katvā pavattehi
translated: in one place, you should resolve on it thus, making the mind concentrated in this way, you should keep it in being.

original: Tassāhaṃ vacanaṃ sutvāti, tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ ovādaṃ ahaṃ sutvā tasmiṃ sāsane🔽ovāde rato abhirato hutvā vihāsiṃ yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjiṃ. Paṭipajjanto ca samādhiṃ
analyzed: tassa aham vacanam sutvā ati tassa bhagavataḥ vacanam ovādam aham sutvā tasmim sāsane  ovāde rataḥ abhirataḥ hutvā vihāsim yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjim paṭipajjanto ca samādhim
translated: I dwelt delighting in and devoted to that advice in the Dispensation.

original: paṭipādesiṃ, uttamatthassa pattiyāti, uttamattho nāma arahattaṃ, tassa adhigamāya
analyzed: uttamatthassa pattiyā ati uttamatthaḥ nāma arahattam tassa adhigamāya
translated: Practising the way to attain the supreme goal: the supreme goal is Arahantship. For the purpose of attaining that,

original: kasiṇaparikammavasena rūpajjhānāni nibbattetvā jhānapādakaṃ vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā🔽maggapaṭipāṭiyā aggamaggasamādhiṃ sampādesinti attho. Ettha hi samādhīti upacārasamādhito🔽paṭṭhāya yāva catutthamaggasamādhi, tāva samādhisāmaññena gahito, aggaphalasamādhi
analyzed: kasiṇa parikamma vasena rūpa jjhānāni nibbattetvā jhāna pādakam vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā  magga paṭipāṭiyā agga magga samādhim sampādesin ti atthaḥ ettha hi samādhi iti upacāra samādhito  paṭṭhāya yāva catuttha magga samādhi tāva samādhi sāmaññena gahitaḥ agga phala samādhi
translated: after producing the jhanas by way of the preliminary work of the kasiṇas, he set about insight,

original: pana uttamatthaggahaṇena, sātisayaṃ cevāyaṃ samādhikusalo, tasmā “samādhiṃ paṭipādesi”nti
analyzed: pana uttamattha ggahaṇena sa atisayam ca iva ayam samādhi kusalo tasmai samādhim paṭipādesin ti
translated: and he perfected the concentration of the path in the order of the path, is the meaning. For here ‘concentration’ is included by the general characteristic of concentration, beginning with access concentration and ending with the concentration of the fourth path. But the concentration of the supreme fruit is included by the words ‘the supreme goal.’🔽And this venerable one was particularly skilled in concentration, so he said ‘he practised concentration.’ For it was through his skill in concentration that this venerable one became known as skilled in turning the mind .

original: āha. Samādhikusalatāya hi ayamāyasmā cetovivaṭṭakusalo nāma jāto, mahāpanthakatthero
analyzed: āha samādhi kusala tāya hi ayam āyasmā cetovivaṭṭakusalaḥ nāma jātaḥ mahāpanthaka ttheraḥ
translated: The Elder Mahapanthaka

original: pana vipassanākusalatāya saññāvivaṭṭakusalo nāma. Eko cettha samādhilakkhaṇe cheko,
analyzed: pana vipassanā kusala tāya saññā vivaṭṭa kusalo nāma ekaḥ ca ittha samādhi lakkhaṇe cheko
translated: One of them was skilled in the characteristic of concentration,

original: eko vipassanālakkhaṇe, eko samādhigāḷho, eko vipassanāgāḷho eko aṅgasaṃkhitte cheko,
analyzed: ekaḥ vipassanā lakkhaṇe ekaḥ samādhi gāḷhaḥ ekaḥ vipassanā gāḷhaḥ ekaḥ aṅga saṃkhitte chekaḥ
translated: one in the characteristic of insight, one was strong in concentration, one in insight, one was skilled in the abbreviation of the factors,

original: eko ārammaṇasaṃkhitte, eko aṅgavavatthāne, eko ārammaṇavavatthāneti vaṇṇenti. Apica🔽cūḷapanthakatthero sātisayaṃ catunnaṃ rūpāvacarajjhānānaṃ lābhitāya cetovivaṭṭakusalo
analyzed: ekaḥ ārammaṇa saṃkhitte ekaḥ aṅga vavatthāne ekaḥ ārammaṇa vavatthāne iti vaṇṇenti api ca  cūḷapanthaka thero sa atisayam catunnam rūpāvacara jhānānam lābhitāya cetaḥ vivaṭṭa kusalaḥ
translated: one in the abbreviation of the object, one in the definition of the factors, one in the definition of the object.🔽Moreover, the Elder Cūḷapanthaka was called skilled in the turn of cognizance🔽because he had attained the four fine-material-sphere jhānas to excess.

original: vutto, mahāpanthakatthero sātisayaṃ catunnaṃ arūpāvacarajjhānānaṃ lābhitāya saññāvivaṭṭakusalo.🔽Paṭhamo vā rūpāvacarajjhānalābhī hutvā jhānaṅgehi vuṭṭhāya arahattaṃ pattoti cetovivaṭṭakusalo,
analyzed: vuttaḥ mahāpanthaka theraḥ sa atisayam catunnam arūpāvacara jhānānam lābhi tāya saññā vivaṭṭa kusalaḥ  paṭhamaḥ vā rūpāvacara jhāna lābhī hutvā jhāna aṅgehi vuṭṭhāya arahattam patto ti cetaḥ vivaṭṭa kusalaḥ
translated: The Elder Mahāpanthaka was called skilled in the turn of perception because he had attained the four immaterial-sphere jhānas to excess.🔽Or the first was called skilled in the turn of cognizance because, having attained the fine-material-sphere jhānas, he reached Arahantship by emerging from the jhāna factors,

original: itaro arūpāvacarajjhānalābhī hutvā jhānaṅgehi vuṭṭhāya arahattaṃ pattoti saññāvivaṭṭakusalo.
analyzed: itaraḥ arūpāvacara jhāna lābhī hutvā jhāna aṅgehi vuṭṭhāya arahattam patto ti saññā vivaṭṭa kusalo
translated: while the other was called skilled in the turn of perception because, having attained the immaterial-sphere jhānas, he reached Arahantship by emerging from the jhāna factors.

original: Manomayaṃ pana kāyaṃ nibbattento aññe tayo vā cattāro vā nibbattanti, na bahuke,
analyzed: manaḥ mayam pana kāyam nibbattento aññe tayaḥ vā cattāro vā nibbattanti na bahuke
translated: But when one creates a mind-made body, one creates either three or four others, not many.

original: ekasadiseyeva ca katvā nibbattenti, ekavidhameva kammaṃ kurumāne. Ayaṃ pana thero
analyzed: eka sadisā iya iva ca katvā nibbattenti ekavidham eva kammam kurumāne ayam pana thero
translated: And one creates them all alike, all doing the same work. But this Elder

original: ekāvajjanena samaṇasahassaṃ māpesi, dvepi na kāyena ekasadise akāsi, na ekavidhaṃ
analyzed: ekāvajjanena samaṇa sahassam mā āpesi dve api na kāyena eka sadise akāsi na ekavidham
translated: created a thousand ascetics with a single adverting. He did not make them all alike in body, nor did he make them all do the same work.

original: kammaṃ kurumāne. Tasmā manomayaṃ kāyaṃ abhinimminantānaṃ aggo nāma jāto.
analyzed: kammam kurumāne tasmai manaḥ mayam kāyam abhinimminantānam aggaḥ nāma jātaḥ
translated: So he became known as the foremost of those who create mind-made bodies.

original: Idāni attano adhigatavisesaṃ dassetuṃ “pubbenivāsaṃ jānāmī”tiādimāha. Kāmañcāyaṃ
analyzed: idāni attanaḥ adhigata visesam dassetum pubbenivāsam jānāmi iti ādim āha kāmañca ayam
translated: Now, in order to point out his own special quality, he said, “I know my past lives,” and so on.

original: thero chaḷabhiñño, yā pana abhiññā āsavakkhayañāṇādhigamassa bahūpakārā, taṃ dassanatthaṃ
analyzed: thero chaḷabhiññaḥ yā pana abhiññā āsava kkhaya ñāṇa adhigamassa bahu upakārā tam dassana attham
translated: And although this Elder was one who possessed the six kinds of direct knowledge, he said this in order to show the direct knowledge that is most helpful for the attainment of the destruction of the taints.

original: “pubbenivāsaṃ jānāmi, dibbacakkhu visodhita”nti vatvā “tisso vijjā anuppattā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pubbenivāsam jānāmi dibba cakkhu visodhitanti vatvā tissaḥ vijjāḥ anuppattā ti vuttam
translated: So he said, “I know my past lives, my divine eye is clear,” and then, “I have attained the three true knowledges.”

original: Pubbenivāsayathākammupagaanāgataṃsañāṇāni hi vipassanācārassa bahūpakārāni, na tathā itarañāṇāni.
analyzed: pubbenivāsa yathā kamma upaga anāgataṃsa ñāṇāni hi vipassanā ācārassa bahu upakārāni na tathā itara ñāṇāni
translated: For the three true knowledges of recollection of past lives, knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings, and knowledge of the destruction of the taints are very helpful to one who is practising insight, not so the other kinds of direct knowledge.

original: Sahassakkhattunti sahassaṃ. “Sahassavāra”nti keci vadanti. Ekāvajjanena pana thero🔽sahasse manomaye kāye nimmini, na vārena. Te ca kho aññamaññamasadise vividhañca🔽kammaṃ karonte. “Kiṃ pana sāvakānampi evarūpaṃ iddhinimmānaṃ sambhavatī”ti? Na sambhavati🔽sabbesaṃ, abhinīhārasampattiyā pana ayameva thero evamakāsi, tathā hesa iminā aṅgena🔽etadagge ṭhapito. Panthako nisīdīti attānameva paraṃ viya vadati. Ambavaneti, ambavane🔽jīvakena katavihāre. Vehāsādupasaṅkaminti vehāsāti karaṇe nissakkavacanaṃ, vehāsenāti
analyzed: sahassa kkhattum ti sahassam sahassa vāran ti keci vadanti ekāvajjanena pana thero  sahasse manaḥ maye kāye na vārena te ca kho aññam aññam asadise vividhañca  kammam karonte kim pana sāvakānam pi evarūpam iddhi nimmānam sambhavati iti na sambhavati  sabbesam abhinīhāra sampattiyā pana ayam eva theraḥ evam akāsi tathā ha isaḥ iminā aṅgena  etad agge ṭhapitaḥ panthakaḥ nisīdi iti attānam eva param viya vadati amba vana iti amba vane  jīvakena kata vihāre vehāsāt upasaṅkaminti vehāsa ati karaṇe nissakka vacanam vehāsena ati
translated: “A thousand times” means “a thousand” . Some say “a thousand times” . But the Elder created a mind-made body a thousand times with a single adverting, not a thousand times in succession. And those created bodies were of various kinds, similar to each other, and they did various kinds of work. “But is such a creation of supernormal power possible for disciples too?” It is possible. But this Elder did it because he had perfected the act of adverting. That is why he is placed first in this section. “Panthaka sat down” : he speaks of himself as if he were another. In the Mango Grove: in the monastery built by Jīvaka. He approached by the sky: the word vehāsa is a noun formed from the root veh to play; it means “the sky.”

original: attho, da-kāro padasandhikaro. Athāti, mama nisajjāya pacchā. Paṭiggahīti dakkhiṇodakaṃ🔽paṭiggaṇhi. Āyāgo sabbalokassāti, sabbassa sadevakassa lokassa aggadakkhiṇeyyatāya
analyzed: atthaḥ dakāraḥ pada sandhi karo atha ati mama nisajjāya pacchā paṭiggahi iti dakkhiṇa udakam 🔽paṭiggaṇhi āyāgaḥ sabba lokassa ati sabbassa sa devakassa lokassa agga dakkhiṇeyya tāya
translated: “A thousand times” means a thousand. Some say “a thousand times” . But the Elder did the creating by a single adverting, not by a thousand. And the created beings were of various kinds, doing different kinds of work, and they were similar to each other. “But is such a creation by supernormal power possible for disciples too?” It is not possible for all disciples, but this Elder did it because he had perfected the act of adverting. That is why he is placed first in this section. “Sit down, Panthaka” : he speaks of himself as if he were another. In the Mango Grove: in the monastery built by Jīvaka. He approached by the air-path: the word vehāsa is a locative in the sense of an instrumental; the meaning is “by the air-path.” The syllable da is a word-divider. Then: after my sitting down. He accepted: he accepted the water and the fan. The foremost in the world’s gifts: because he is the foremost worthy of gifts in the whole world with its deities.

original: deyyadhammaṃ ānetvā yajitabbaṭṭhānabhūto. Āhutīnaṃ paṭiggahoti, mahāphalabhāvakaraṇena🔽dakkhiṇāhutīnaṃ paṭiggaṇhako. Paṭiggaṇhittha dakkhiṇanti jīvakena upanītaṃ yāgukhajjādibhedaṃ
analyzed: deyya dhammaṃ ānetvā yajitabba ṭṭhāna bhūtaḥ āhutīnam paṭiggaho ti mahā phala bhāva karaṇena  dakkhiṇāhutīnam paṭiggaṇhako paṭiggaṇhittha dakkhiṇanti jīvakena upanītam yāgu khajja ādi bhedam
translated: He accepted the offerings, the gruel, etc.,

original: dakkhiṇaṃ paṭiggahesi.
analyzed: dakkhiṇam paṭiggahesi
translated: which Jīvaka brought.

original: Atha kho bhagavā katabhattakicco āyasmantaṃ cūḷapanthakaṃ āṇāpesi – “anumodanaṃ karohī”ti.🔽So sineruṃ gahetvā mahāsamuddaṃ manthento viya pabhinnapaṭisambhidāppattatāya tepiṭakaṃ
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā kata bhatta kiccaḥ āyasmantam cūḷapanthakam āṇāpesi anumodanam karohi iti  saḥ sinerum gahetvā mahā samuddam manthentaḥ viya pabhinna paṭisambhidā appatta tāya tepiṭakam
translated: Then, after the Blessed One had finished his meal, he told the venerable Cūḷapanthaka to give thanks.🔽As if churning the ocean with the mountain Sineru, he gave thanks, shaking the whole of the Buddha’s word, which consists of the three Piṭakas,

original: buddhavacanaṃ saṅkhobhento satthu ajjhāsayaṃ gaṇhanto anumodanaṃ akāsi. Tathā upanissayasampannopi🔽cāyamāyasmā tathārūpāya kammapilotikāya paribādhito catuppadikaṃ gāthaṃ catūhipi
analyzed: buddha vacanam saṅkhobhentaḥ satthu ajjhāsayam gaṇhantaḥ anumodanam akāsi tathā upanissaya sampannaḥ api  ca ayam āyasmā tathārūpāya kamma pilotikāya paribādhitaḥ catuppadikam gātham
translated: and he did so by taking the Teacher’s intention into account, because he had attained the discriminations and the analytical knowledges.🔽Although this venerable one had the necessary supporting conditions,🔽he was hindered by such a great amount of work that he was unable to learn even a four-line stanza in four months.

original: māsehi gahetuṃ nāsakkhi. Taṃ panassa upanissayasampattiṃ oloketvā satthā pubbacariyānurūpaṃ
analyzed: māsehi gahetum na asakkhi tam panassa upanissaya sampattim oloketvā satthā pubba cariyā anurūpam
translated: But the Teacher, seeing that he had the necessary supporting conditions, gave him a task in accordance with his past lives.

original: yonisomanasikāre niyojesi. Tathā hi bhagavā tadā jīvakassa nivesane nisinno eva “cūḷapanthakassa
analyzed: yoniso manasikāre niyojesi tathā hi bhagavā tadā jīvakassa nivesane nisinnaḥ eva cūḷapanthakassa
translated: and he exhorted him to apply himself to right reflection. For the Exalted One, while sitting in Jīvaka’s house, knew that Cūḷapanthaka’s🔽mind was concentrated, that he had entered the path, and that he had attained insight. And without rising from his seat, he manifested himself to Cūḷapanthaka and said, “Panthaka, if this piece of cloth were soiled and stained with dust, would you be able to cleanse it and make it clean?”🔽“Yes, venerable sir,” replied Cūḷapanthaka.🔽“In the same way, Panthaka, if the mind is defiled, it is possible to cleanse it.”

original: cittaṃ samāhitaṃ, vīthipaṭipannā vipassanā”ti ñatvā yathānisinnova attānaṃ dassetvā,
analyzed: cittam samāhitam vīthi paṭipannā vipassanā iti ñatvā yathā nisinnaḥ uva attānam dassetvā
translated: “Panthaka, if this piece of cloth were soiled and stained with dust, would you be able to cleanse it and make it clean?”🔽“Yes, venerable sir.”🔽“In the same way, Panthaka, if the mind is defiled, it is possible to cleanse it.”

original: “panthaka, yadipāyaṃ pilotikā saṃkiliṭṭhā rajānukiṇṇā, ito pana añño eva ariyassa🔽vinaye saṃkileso rajo cāti dassento –
analyzed: panthaka yadipā ayam pilotikā saṃkiliṭṭhā raja anukiṇṇā itas pana aññaḥ eva ariyassa  vinaye saṃkileso rajaḥ ca ati
translated: “Panthaka, if this piece of cloth were soiled and stained with dust, would you be able to cleanse it and make it clean?”🔽“Yes, venerable sir.”🔽“In the same way, Panthaka, if the mind is defiled, it is possible to cleanse it.”

original: “Rāgo rajo na ca pana reṇu vuccati, rāgassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ rajoti;
analyzed: rāgaḥ rajaḥ na ca pana reṇu vuccati rāgassa ītam adhivacanam rajaḥ ti
translated: “Lust is called dust, not the dust of the earth; this is a designation for lust.

analyzed: etam rajam vippajahitvā bhikkhavaḥ viharanti te vīta rajassa sāsane  dosaḥ raja upe sa āsane
translated: Having abandoned this dust, the monks live in the Dispensation of the One Free from Dust.🔽“Hatred is called dust …

analyzed: mohaḥ rajaḥ pe vīta rajaḥ sa sāsanā iti  imāḥ tissaḥ obhāsa gāthāḥ abhāsi gāthā pariyosāne cūḷa panthakaḥ abhiññā paṭisambhidā parivāram arahattam pāpuṇi iti  cūḷapanthaka thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: “Delusion is called dust … in the Dispensation of the One Free from Dust.”

original: 5. Kappattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: kappatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: At the conclusion of the stanzas, Cūḷapanthaka attained arahantship together with the analytic knowledges.

translated: The story of the Elder Kappā is told in the stanza, “The pool filled full of various kinds of mud.”🔽In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, this Elder, who was then a poor man, made an image of the Buddha and worshipped it.🔽In the dispensation of the Buddha Vipassī, he was a potter and made a bowl of clay and offered it to the Buddha.

original: katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinanto siddhatthassa bhagavato kāle vibhavasampanne🔽kule nibbattitvā pitu accayena viññutaṃ patto nānāvirāgavaṇṇavicittehi vatthehi anekavidhehi
analyzed: kata adhikāro tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinantaḥ siddhatthassa bhagavato kāle vibhava sampanne  kule nibbattitvā pitu accayena viññu tam pattaḥ nānā virāga vaṇṇa vicittehi vatthehi anekavidhehi
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Sikhī, he was a poor man and offered a handful of sand to the Buddha.🔽In the dispensation of the Buddha Kakusandha, he was a poor man and offered a handful of parched grain to the Buddha.🔽In the dispensation of the Buddha Koṇāgamana, he was a poor man and offered a handful of beans to the Buddha.

original: vuṭṭhāya lokaṃ volokento ñāṇajāle paññāyamānaṃ disvā, “kiṃ nu kho bhavissatī”ti āvajjento,
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya lokam volokentaḥ ñāṇa jāle paññāyamānam disvā kim nu kho bhavissati iti āvajjentaḥ
