original: sappāyasampajaññaṃ, gocarasampajaññaṃ, asammohasampajaññanti catūhi sampajaññehi
analyzed: sa pāya sampajaññam gocara sampajaññam a sammoha sampajaññanti catūhi sampajaññehi
translated: The four kinds of clear comprehension are clear comprehension of what is proper, clear comprehension of the field, clear comprehension of the extent , and clear comprehension of danger.

original: sampajānānaṃ, cattāropi āsavā atthaṃ gacchanti parikkhayaṃ abhāvaṃ gacchantīti attho.
analyzed: sampajānānam cattāraḥ api āsavāḥ attham gacchanti parikkhayam abhāvam gacchanti iti attho
translated: The meaning is that the four taints are destroyed, are brought to an end, are annihilated.

original: Idāni attano santike ṭhitabhikkhūnaṃ ovādaṃ dento “ujumaggamhī”ti gāthamāha. Tattha
analyzed: idāni attanaḥ santike ṭhita bhikkhūnam ovādam dentaḥ uju maggamhi iti gātham āha tattha
translated: Now, giving advice to the bhikkhus who were standing near him, he spoke the stanza, “The straight path has been shown.” Herein,

original: ujumaggamhi akkhāteti antadvayaparivajjanena kāyavaṅkādippahānena ca ujuke majjhimapaṭipadābhūte
analyzed: uju maggamhi akkhātā iti anta dvaya parivajjanena kāya vaṅka ādi ppahānena ca ujuke majjhima paṭipadā bhūte
translated: the straight path has been shown by the Master is the noble path, which is straight, being the middle way avoiding the two extremes of sense-gratification and self-mortification, and which is the straight path in the sense of being the path to be trodden by the straight man.

original: ariyamagge satthārā bhāsite. Gacchathāti paṭipajjatha. Mā nivattathāti antarā vosānaṃ
analyzed: ariya magge satthārā bhāsite gacchatha ati paṭipajjatha mā nivattatha ati antarā vosānam
translated: Go along it is enter upon it. Do not turn back is do not fall into the middle of the way.

original: māpajjatha. Attanā codayattānanti idha atthakāmo kulaputto apāyabhayapaccavekkhaṇādinā
analyzed: mā āpajjatha attanā idha attha kāmaḥ kula puttaḥ apāya bhaya paccavekkhaṇa ādinā
translated: Stirring up your own energies is here a clansman who desires his own good, who reflects upon the fearfulness of the states of loss, etc.,

original: attanāva attānaṃ codento. Nibbānamabhihārayeti, attānaṃ nibbānaṃ abhihareyya upaneyya,
analyzed: attanā va attānam codentaḥ nibbānam abhihāraya iti attānam nibbānam abhihareyya upaneyya
translated: stirring up his own energies. Bring yourselves to Nibbāna is bring yourselves to Nibbāna, lead yourselves to Nibbāna,

original: yathā naṃ sacchikaroti, tathā paṭipajjeyyāti attho.
analyzed: yathā nam sacchikaroti tathā paṭipajjeyya attho
translated: the meaning is, practise in such wise that you may realize it.

original: Idāni mayāpi evameva paṭipannanti, attano paṭipattiṃ dassetuṃ “accāraddhamhī”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Accāraddhamhi vīriyamhīti vipassanaṃ bhāventena mayā samādhinā vīriyaṃ samarasaṃ
analyzed: idāni mayā api evam eva paṭipannanti attanaḥ paṭipattim dassetum acca āraddham hi itiādi  vuttam acca āraddhamhi vīriyamhi iti vipassanam bhāventena mayā samādhinā vīriyam samarasam
translated: Now, I too am practicing in the same way. In order to show his own practice, he said, “I was over-exerted.”🔽While I was developing insight, I did not balance my energy with my concentration,

original: akatvā ativiya vīriye paggahite. Accāraddhavīriyatā cassa heṭṭhā vuttāyeva. Vīṇopamaṃ
analyzed: a katvā ativiya vīriye paggahite accāraddha vīriya tā ca ssa heṭṭhā vuttāya iva vīṇā upamam
translated: and I exerted myself too much. The danger of over-exertion has already been explained.🔽I was like a lute player.

original: karitvā meti āyasmato soṇassa “ye kho keci bhagavato sāvakā āraddhavīriyā viharanti.🔽Ahaṃ tesaṃ aññataro, atha ca pana me nānupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccati, tasmāhaṃ🔽vibbhamissāmī”ti citte uppanne satthā iddhiyā tassa sammukhe attānaṃ dassetvā “kasmā
analyzed: karitvā mā iti āyasmato soṇassa ye kho keci bhagavataḥ sāvakāḥ āraddha vīriyāḥ viharanti  aham tesam aññataraḥ atha ca pana me na an upādāya āsavehi cittam vimuccati tasmā aham  vibbhamissāmi iti citte uppanne satthā iddhiyā tassa sammukhe attānam dassetvā kasmā
translated: When the venerable Soṇa thought, “The Blessed One has said that those disciples of his who live exerting themselves energetically are living according to the Teacher’s Dispensation,🔽but although I live exerting myself energetically, my mind is not yet freed from the taints without grasping. I shall abandon this body in such a way that afterwards I shall be reborn no more.”

original: tvaṃ, soṇa, ‘vibbhamissāmī’ti cittaṃ uppādesi, kusalo tvaṃ pubbe agāriyabhūto vīṇāya
analyzed: tvam soṇa vibbhamissāmi iti cittam uppādesi kusalaḥ tvam pubbe agāriya bhūtaḥ vīṇāya
translated: and his thought of abandoning arose, the Teacher, by his psychic power, appeared before him and asked him, “Soṇa, why did you arouse this thought of abandoning?”

original: tantissare”ti pucchitvā tena “evaṃ, bhante”ti vutte “taṃ kiṃ maññasi, soṇa? Yadā
analyzed: tantissara iti pucchitvā tena evam bhante iti vutte tam kim maññasi soṇa yadā
translated: and he replied, “Yes, venerable sir.” The Teacher asked him, “What do you think, Soṇa?

original: te vīṇāya tantiyo accāyatā honti, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṃ samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā
analyzed: te vīṇāya tantiyaḥ accāyatāḥ honti api nu te vīṇā tasmin samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā
translated: and the strings of the lute were too taut, would the lute then give forth its notes clearly and sweetly?”

original: vāti? No hetaṃ, bhante! Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, soṇa, yadā te vīṇāya tantiyo atisithilā
analyzed: vāti no hetam bhante tam kim maññasi soṇa yadā te vīṇāya tantiyaḥ ati sithilā
translated: “No, venerable sir.” “What do you think, Soṇa? When the strings of the lute were too loose,

original: honti, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṃ samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā vāti? No hetaṃ, bhante.
analyzed: honti api nu te vīṇā tasmin samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā vāti no hetam bhante
translated: would the lute then give forth its notes clearly and sweetly?”

original: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, soṇa, yadā pana te vīṇāya tantiyo neva accāyatā honti, nātisithilā
analyzed: tam kim maññasi soṇa yadā pana te vīṇāya tantiyaḥ na iva accāyatāḥ honti na ati sithilā
translated: “No, venerable sir.” “What do you think, Soṇa? When the strings of the lute were neither too taut nor too loose but were set at an even tension,

original: same guṇe patiṭṭhitā, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṃ samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā vāti?
analyzed: same guṇe patiṭṭhitāḥ api nu te vīṇā tasmin samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā vāti
translated: would the lute then give forth its notes clearly and sweetly?”

original: Evaṃ, bhante. Evameva kho, soṇa, accāraddhavīriyaṃ uddhaccāya saṃvattati, atilīnavīriyaṃ
analyzed: evam bhante evam eva kho soṇa acca āraddha vīriyam uddhaccāya saṃvattati ati līna vīriyam
translated: “Yes, venerable sir.” “So too, Soṇa, excessive energy leads to restlessness, and when energy is lacking, it leads to laziness.

original: kosajjāya saṃvattati, tasmātiha tvaṃ, soṇa, vīriyasamataṃ adhiṭṭhaha, indriyānañca
analyzed: kosajjāya saṃvattati tasmā ati ha tvam soṇa vīriya samatam adhiṭṭhahe
translated: Therefore, Soṇa, you should practise thus: ‘Our energy will be neither too slack nor too tense; and it will be neither constricted internally nor distracted externally.’“

original: samataṃ paṭivijjhā”ti evaṃ vīṇaṃ upamaṃ katvā pavattitena vīṇopamovādena mayhaṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: samatam paṭivijjhāti evam vīṇam upamam katvā pavattitena vīṇā upama uvādena mayham dhammam
translated: So the Blessed One taught me the Dhamma with a simile having six constituent parts,

original: desesi. Tassāhaṃ vacanaṃ sutvāti tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ vīṇopamovādaṃ sutvā antarā
analyzed: desesi tassa aham vacanam sutvā ati tassa bhagavataḥ vacanam vīṇā upama uvādam sutvā antarā
translated: I heard his speech. Having heard the Blessed One’s speech, the advice called the “Discourse on the Lute,” I abandoned the desire to disrobe that had arisen in me

original: uppannaṃ vibbhamitukāmataṃ pahāya satthu sāsane rato abhirato vihariṃ.🔽Viharanto ca samathaṃ paṭipādesiṃ vīriyasamataṃ yojento saddhāpaññānaṃ viya samādhivīriyānaṃ
analyzed: uppannam vibbhamitu kāma tam pahāya satthu sāsane rataḥ abhirataḥ viharim  viharanto ca samatham vīriya samatam yojento saddhā paññānam viya samādhi vīriyānam
translated: and I lived devoted to and intent upon the Teacher’s Dispensation.🔽And while living thus I practiced serenity, I applied serenity-energy,

Khadiravaniya-Revata-Tissa-Theragatha-Commentary🔽In the Catuddasakanipata, the verses beginning “When they beat me” are those of the venerable Khadiravaniya-Revata-Tissa-Thera.🔽What is the origin of these verses? analyzed: handa aham parinibbissam vippamuttaḥ mhi sabbadhi iti imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: He uttered these verses:

original: Tatthāyaṃ apubbapadavaṇṇanā imasmiṃ dīghamantareti, yadā ahaṃ pabbajitomhi, tato
analyzed: tattha ayam apubba pada vaṇṇanā imasmin dīgham antareti yadā aham pabbajitaḥ mhi tatas
translated: Here is the commentary on the new terms: “In this long period” means from the time of my going forth

original: paṭṭhāya ayañca me carimakālo, etasmiṃ dīghamantare kāle “idaṃ mayhaṃ hotū”ti abhijjhāvasena
analyzed: paṭṭhāya ayam ca me carima kālaḥ etasmin dīgham antare kāle idam mayham hotu iti abhijjhā vasena
translated: up to this present time, this last period of my life. In this long period of time I do not recall any unrighteous thought,🔽accompanied by hate, such as ‘May this be mine’ through covetousness,

original: vā, “ime sattā haññantū”tiādinā byāpādavasena vā anariyaṃ dosasaṃhitaṃ saṅkappaṃ🔽nābhijānāmīti yojanā.🔽Mettañca abhijānāmīti, mijjati siniyhati etāyāti mettā, abyāpādo. Mettā etissā atthīti
analyzed: vai ime sattāḥ haññantu uti ādinā byāpāda vasena vā anariyam dosa saṃhitam saṅkappam  na abhijānāmi iti yojanā  mettam ca abhijānāmi iti mijjati siniyhati etāyāti mettā a byāpādaḥ mettā etissā atthi iti
translated: or ‘May these beings be slain’ through ill will.

original: mettā, mettābhāvanā mettābrahmavihāro, taṃ mettaṃ. Ca-saddena karuṇaṃ muditaṃ upekkhañcāti
analyzed: mettā mettā bhāvanā mettā brahmavihāro tam mettam ca saddena karuṇam muditam upekkhan ca ati
translated: “And loving-kindness I recall”: “It melts , it softens , thus it is loving-kindness” . Loving-kindness is non-ill will. It has loving-kindness , thus it is loving-kindness . The development of loving-kindness is the divine abiding of loving-kindness . That loving-kindness. “And” includes compassion, gladness, and equanimity.

original: itarabrahmavihāre saṅgaṇhāti. Abhijānāmīti, abhimukhato jānāmi. Adhigatañhi jhānaṃ
analyzed: itara brahmavihāre saṅgaṇhāti abhijānāmi iti abhimukhataḥ jānāmi adhigatam hi jhānam
translated: “I recall”: I know by direct experience. For when one reviews the jhāna that has been attained, the knowledge of reviewing is face to face with it.

original: paccavekkhato paccavekkhaṇañāṇassa abhimukhaṃ hoti. Kīdisanti āha “appamāṇa”ntiādi.
analyzed: paccavekkhato paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇassa abhimukham hoti kīdisam ti āha appamāṇa ntiādi
translated: “What kind?” He answers, “immeasurable,” etc.

original: Tañhi yathā buddhena bhagavatā desitaṃ, tathā anodissakapharaṇavasena aparimāṇasattārammaṇatāya🔽appamāṇaṃ. Paguṇabalavabhāvāpādanena suṭṭhu bhāvitattā subhāvitaṃ. Paṭhamaṃ mettā,
analyzed: tat hi yathā buddhena bhagavatā desitam tathā anodissaka pharaṇa vasena aparimāṇa satta ārammaṇa tāya  appamāṇam paguṇa balava bhāva āpādanena suṭṭhu bhāvita ttā su bhāvitam paṭhamam mettā
translated: For it is immeasurable in that it has as its object the immeasurable beings, by extending without any limitation as to direction, just as it was taught by the Blessed One.🔽It is well developed in that it is well developed by bringing about the state of being a powerful friend.🔽I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.🔽I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.

original: tato karuṇā, tato muditā, pacchā upekkhāti evaṃ anupubbaṃ anukkamena paricitaṃ āsevitaṃ,🔽bahulīkataṃ abhijānāmīti yojanā.
analyzed: tatas karuṇā tatas muditā pacchā upekkhā ati evam anupubbam anukkamena paricitam āsevitam  bahulīkatam abhijānāmi iti yojanā
translated: I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.🔽I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.

original: Sabbesaṃ sattānaṃ mitto, sabbe vā te mayhaṃ mittāti sabbamitto. Mettañhi bhāvento🔽sattānaṃ piyo hoti. Sabbasakhoti, etthāpi eseva nayo. Sabbabhūtānukampakoti, sabbasattānaṃ
analyzed: sabbesam sattānam mittaḥ sabbe vā te mayham mittā ati sabba mittaḥ mettam hi bhāvento  sattānam piyaḥ hoti sabba sakhaḥ iti ettha api esa iva nayaḥ sabba bhūta anukampako ti sabba sattānam
translated: I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.🔽I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.🔽I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.🔽I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.🔽I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.🔽I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.🔽I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.🔽I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.🔽I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.

original: anuggaṇhanako. Mettacittañca bhāvemīti, mettāya sahitaṃ sampayuttaṃ cittaṃ visesato
analyzed: anuggaṇhanakaḥ metta cittam ca bhāvemi iti mettāya sahitam sampayuttam cittam visesataḥ
translated: I recollect the development of the four divine abodes in the following order: first loving-kindness, then compassion, then gladness, and finally equanimity.

original: bhāvemi, vaḍḍhemi, pakāsemi vā akathentepi bhāvanāya ukkaṃsagatabhāvato. “Mettaṃ
analyzed: bhāvemi vaḍḍhemi pakāsemi vā a kathente pi bhāvanāya ukkaṃsa gata bhāvataḥ
translated: I recollect the development of the four

original: cittañca bhāvemī”ti vā pāṭho. Tassattho heṭṭhā vuttanayova. Abyāpajjaratoti, abyāpajje
analyzed: cittam ca bhāvemi iti vā pāṭho tassa attho heṭṭhā vutta nayo va abyāpajja rataḥ ti abyāpajje
translated: Or else the reading is “I develop the mind of loving-kindness.” The meaning is as already stated.🔽He delights in harmlessness: he delights in the harmlessness consisting in the refraining from killing living beings, etc., and in the harmlessness consisting in the bestowing of welfare.

original: sattānaṃ hitūpasaṃhāre abhirato. Sadāti, sabbakālaṃ, tena tattha sātaccakiriyaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: sattānam hitūpasaṃhāre abhirataḥ sadā ati sabbakālam tena tattha sātacca kiriyam dasseti
translated: Always: at all times. He shows that he is constant in this.

original: Asaṃhīranti na saṃhīraṃ, āsannapaccatthikena rāgena anākaḍḍhaniyaṃ. Asaṃkuppanti
analyzed: a saṃhīranti na saṃhīram āsanna paccatthikena rāgena an ākaḍḍhaniyam a saṃkuppanti
translated: Unharmed: not harmed, not drawn in by lust, which is a near enemy.

original: na kuppaṃ, dūrapaccatthikena byāpādena akopiyaṃ, evaṃbhūtaṃ katvā mama mettacittaṃ
analyzed: na kuppam dūra paccatthikena byāpādena a kopiyam evaṃbhūtam katvā mama metta cittam
translated: Unperturbed: not perturbed, not angered by ill will, which is a far enemy. Having made his mind of loving-kindness like this,🔽he gladdens, he delights, he develops the divine abiding of loving-kindness.

original: āmodayāmi abhippamodayāmi brahmavihāraṃ bhāvemi. Akāpurisasevitanti, kāpurisehi nīcajanehi🔽asevitaṃ, akāpurisehi vā ariyehi buddhādīhi sevitaṃ brahmaṃ seṭṭhaṃ niddosaṃ mettādivihāraṃ
analyzed: āmodayāmi abhippamodayāmi brahmavihāram bhāvemi a kāpurisa sevitanti kāpurisehi nīca janehi  a sevitam a kāpurisehi vā ariyehi buddha ādīhi sevitam brahmam seṭṭham niddosam mettā ādi vihāram
translated: Not frequented by bad men: not frequented by bad men, by low people,

original: bhāvemi vaḍḍhemīti attho.
analyzed: bhāvemi vaḍḍhemi iti attho
translated: or frequented by good men, by noble ones, by Buddhas, etc. He develops the divine abiding of loving-kindness, which is noble, best, blameless, and without hate. The meaning is that he increases it.

original: Evaṃ attuddesavasena pañcahi gāthāhi attano paṭipattiṃ dassetvā idāni taṃ aññāpadesena
analyzed: evam attuddesa vasena pañcahi gāthāhi attanaḥ paṭipattim dassetvā idāni tam añña apadesena
translated: Having thus shown his own practice in five stanzas by way of self-direction, now, by way of direction to others,

original: dassento “avitakka”ntiādinā catasso gāthā abhāsi. Tattha avitakkaṃ samāpannoti, vitakkavirahitaṃ
analyzed: dassentaḥ avitakkam ti ādinā catassaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha avitakkam samāpannaḥ ti vitakka virahitam
translated: The Elder replied with four verses beginning with “I have attained the imperturbable,” showing how he had attained the imperturbable.

original: dutiyādijhānaṃ samāpanno, etena thero brahmavihārabhāvanāya aññāpadesena attanā dutiyādijhānādhigamamāha.
analyzed: dutiya ādi jhānam samāpannaḥ etena theraḥ brahmavihāra bhāvanāya aññāpadesena attanā dutiya ādi jhāna adhigamam āha
translated: Herein, he has attained the imperturbable means he has attained the second jhāna, which is devoid of applied thought.🔽By this the Elder shows that he had attained the second jhāna, etc., by the description of his further-men’s state.

original: Yasmā panāyaṃ thero tameva jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā ekāsaneneva
analyzed: yasmai pana ayam thero tam eva jhānam pādakam katvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā eka āsanena iva
translated: But since it was by making that jhāna the basis for insight that he reached Arahantship in one more sitting,

original: arahattaṃ gaṇhi, tasmā tamatthaṃ aññāpadeseneva dassento “avitakkaṃ samāpanno”ti
analyzed: arahattam gaṇhi tasmā tam attham añña apadesena iva dassento a vitakkam samāpanno ti
translated: he shows that meaning by the description of his further-men’s state, beginning with “I have attained the imperturbable,”

original: vatvā “sammāsambuddhasāvako. Ariyena tuṇhībhāvena, upeto hoti tāvade”ti āha. Tattha
analyzed: vatvā sammāsambuddha sāvakaḥ ariyena tuṇhībhāvena upetaḥ hoti āha tattha
translated: and he concludes with the words “The disciple of the Perfect Sambuddha, then, is endowed with the Noble Silence.”

original: vacīsaṅkhārābhāvato avitakkāvicārā samāpatti “ariyo tuṇhībhāvo”ti vadanti. “Sannipatitānaṃ
analyzed: vacī saṅkhāra abhāvataḥ a vitakka a vicārā samāpatti ariyaḥ tuṇhībhāvaḥ ti vadanti sannipatitānam
translated: Herein, they say that the attainment without applied thought and sustained thought is “the Noble Silence” because there is no verbal formation.

original: vo, bhikkhave, dvayaṃ karaṇīyaṃ dhammī vā kathā ariyo vā tuṇhībhāvo”ti pana vacanato
analyzed: vaḥ bhikkhave dvayam karaṇīyam dhammī vā kathā ariyaḥ vā tuṇhībhāvaḥ ti pana vacanato
translated: For it is said: “Bhikkhus, when you have met together you have two duties, either to hold talk on the True Idea or to keep noble silence” .

original: yā kāci samāpatti ariyo tuṇhībhāvo nāma. Idha pana catutthajjhānikā aggaphalasamāpatti adhippetā.
analyzed: yā kāci samāpatti ariyaḥ tuṇhībhāvaḥ nāma idha pana catuttha jhānikā agga phala samāpatti adhippetā
translated: Any attainment is called “noble silence.” But here the attainment of the highest fruit in the fourth jhāna is intended.

original: Idāni tassādhigatattā lokadhammehi akampanīyataṃ upamāya pakāsento “yathāpi pabbato”ti
analyzed: idāni tassa adhigata ttā loka dhammehi akampanīya tam upamāya pakāsentaḥ yathā api pabbato ti
translated: Now, in order to show by means of a simile how, when that has been reached, one is unshakable by worldly states, he said: “Just as a rock,”

original: gāthamāha. Tattha yathāpi pabbato seloti, yathā silāmayo ekaghanaselo pabbato, na
analyzed: gātham āha tattha yathā api pabbataḥ selo ti yathā silā mayaḥ eka ghana selo pabbataḥ na
translated: and so on. Herein, just as a rock, a solid mass of stone, is a rock,

original: paṃsupabbato na missakapabbatoti attho. Acalo suppatiṭṭhitoti, suṭṭhu patiṭṭhitamūlo
analyzed: paṃsu pabbataḥ na missaka pabbataḥ ti attho acalaḥ suppatiṭṭhitaḥ ti suṭṭhu patiṭṭhita mūlo
translated: not a sand-bank, not a mixed-up bank, is the meaning. Immovable, well-set down,

original: pakativātehi acalo akampanīyo hoti, tasmā arahattaṃ nibbānañca evaṃ mohakkhayā bhikkhu,
analyzed: pakati vātehi acalaḥ a kampanīyaḥ hoti tasmai arahattam nibbānam ca evam moha kkhayā bhikkhu
translated: with well-set-down roots, it is unshakable by winds that scatter everything else. So too the bhikkhu, by destruction of delusion,🔽does not waver, like the rock.

original: pabbatova na vedhatīti mohassa anavasesappahānā, mohamūlakattā ca sabbākusalānaṃ
analyzed: pabbataḥ uva na vedhati iti mohassa anavasesa ppahānā moha mūlaka ttā ca sabba akusalānam
translated: And because of the complete abandonment of delusion, and because of the fact that all unprofitable things have delusion as their root,

original: pahīnasabbākusalo bhikkhu yathā so pabbato pakativātehi, evaṃ lokadhammehi na vedhati
analyzed: pahīna sabba akusalaḥ bhikkhu yathā saḥ pabbataḥ pakati vātehi evam loka dhammehi na vedhati
translated: the bhikkhu, who has abandoned all that is unprofitable, does not waver, like the rock, by worldly states.

original: na kampati, mohakkhayoti vā yasmā arahattaṃ nibbānañca vuccati, tasmā mohakkhayāti
analyzed: na kampati moha kkhayaḥ ti vā yasmai arahattam nibbānam ca vuccati tasmai moha kkhayā ati
translated: He does not tremble. Or alternatively, since arahatship and extinction are called “destruction of delusion,”

original: mohakkhayassa hetu nibbānassa arahattassa ca adhigatattā catūsu ariyasaccesu suppatiṭṭhito
analyzed: moha kkhayassa hetu nibbānassa arahattassa ca adhigata ttā catūsu ariya saccesu suppatiṭṭhito
translated: because he had attained the destruction of delusion and the state of Nibbāna and of Arahantship, he was well-established in the four noble Truths.

original: asamāpannakālepi pabbato viya na vedhati, pageva samāpannakāleti adhippāyo.
analyzed: a samāpanna kāle api pabbataḥ viya na vedhati pagā iva samāpanna kāle ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is this: even when he had not yet attained the jhānas, he was not shaken like a mountain, how much less so when he had attained them.

original: Idāni pāpaṃ nāmetaṃ asucisīlo eva samācarati, na ca sucisīlo, sucisīlassa pana taṃ
analyzed: idāni pāpam nāma etam a suci sīlaḥ eva samācarati na ca suci sīlaḥ suci sīlassa pana taṃ
translated: Now, the intention is this: not only does the unvirtuous person commit evil, but also the virtuous person,🔽but for the virtuous person it appears as heavy even in the slightest degree,

original: aṇumattampi bhāriyaṃ hutvā upaṭṭhātīti dassento “anaṅgaṇassā”tiādigāthamāha. Tassattho
analyzed: aṇumattam pi bhāriyam hutvā upaṭṭhāti iti dassentaḥ anaṅgaṇassa iti ādi gātham āha tassa atthaḥ
translated: showing this, he uttered the stanza beginning with “Anaṅgaṇassa.” Its meaning is this:

original: – rāgādiaṅgaṇābhāvato anaṅgaṇassa sabbakālaṃ sucianavajjadhamme eva gavesantassa
analyzed: rāga ādi aṅgaṇa abhāvataḥ anaṅgaṇassa sabbakālam suci anavajja dhamme eva gavesantassa
translated: because he is free from the stain of lust, etc., he is without stain; he is a good person who is always seeking only pure and faultless things;

original: sappurisassa vālaggamattaṃ kesaggamattaṃ pāpassa lesamattampi sakalaṃ lokadhātuṃ
analyzed: sappurisassa vālagga mattam kesagga mattam pāpassa lesa mattam pi sakalam lokadhātum
translated: even the slightest degree of evil, the mere tip of a hair, the mere tip of a hair’s feather,

original: pharitvā ṭhitaṃ abbhamattaṃ hutvā upaṭṭhāti, tasmā na evarūpe kamme mādisā āsaṅkitabbāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: pharitvā ṭhitam abbha mattam hutvā upaṭṭhāti tasmā naḥ evarūpe kamme mā ādisā āsaṅkitabbā ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: spreads throughout the entire world-sphere and appears as if it were right in front of him. Therefore, one like me should not engage in such an action.

original: Yasmā nikkilesesupi andhabālā evarūpe apavāde samuṭṭhāpenti, tasmā atthakāmehi sakkaccaṃ
analyzed: yasmai nikkilesesu pi andha bālāḥ evarūpe apavāde samuṭṭhāpenti tasmai attha kāmehi sakkaccam
translated: Since even those who are free from defilements are accused by the blind fools, those who desire their welfare should carefully

original: attā rakkhitabboti ovādaṃ dento “nagaraṃ yathā”tiādigāthamāha. Tassattho – yathā
analyzed: attā rakkhitabbo ti ovādam dentaḥ nagaram yathā iti ādi gātham āha tassa atthaḥ yathā
translated: He gave this advice in the verse beginning, “As people living in a border town.” The meaning is as follows:

original: pana paccantanagaravāsīhi manussehi paccantaṃ nagaraṃ dvārapākārādīni thirāni karontehi
analyzed: pana paccanta nagara vāsīhi manussehi paccantam nagaram dvāra pākāra ādīni thirāni karontehi
translated: Just as people living in a border town make the town secure by making the gates, walls, etc., strong,

original: saantaraṃ, uddāpaparikhādīni thirāni karontehi sabāhiranti santarabāhiraṃ guttaṃ🔽karīyati, evaṃ tumhehipi satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā ajjhattikāni cha dvārāni pidahitvā dvārarakkhitaṃ
analyzed: sa antaram uddāpa parikhā ādīni thirāni karontehi sa bāhiranti santara bāhiram guttam  evam tumhehi pi satim upaṭṭhapetvā ajjhattikāni cha dvārāni pidahitvā dvāra rakkhitam
translated: by making the inner and outer ramparts strong,🔽by closing the six inner doors after setting up mindfulness,

original: satiṃ avissajjetvā yathā gayhamānāni bāhirāni cha āyatanāni ajjhattikāni upaghātāya🔽saṃvattanti, tathā aggahaṇena tānipi thirāni katvā tesaṃ appavesāya dvārarakkhitaṃ🔽satiṃ appahāya vicarantā attānaṃ gopetha. Kasmā? Khaṇo vo mā upaccagā. Yo hi evaṃ
analyzed: satim a vissajjetvā yathā gayhamānāni bāhirāni cha āyatanāni ajjhattikāni upaghātāya  saṃvattanti tathā aggahaṇena tāni api thirāni katvā tesam appavesāya dvāra rakkhitam  satim appahāya vicarantāḥ attānam gopetha kasmā khaṇaḥ vaḥ mā upaccagā yaḥ hi evam
translated: by not letting go of the mindfulness that guards the doors, and by not letting in the six external sense-bases that might harm the inner faculties,

original: attānaṃ na gopeti, taṃ puggalaṃ buddhuppādakkhaṇo, manussattabhāvakkhaṇo, majjhimadese
analyzed: attānam na gopeti tam puggalam buddhuppāda kkhaṇaḥ manussatta bhāva kkhaṇaḥ majjhima dese
translated: in the same way you should guard yourselves by making the external sense-bases strong by not grasping them, by not letting them enter, and by not giving up the mindfulness that guards the doors. Why? “Lest the opportunity pass you by.” For the opportunity to meet a Buddha, to be born as a human being, to be born in the Middle Country,

original: uppattikkhaṇo, sammādiṭṭhiyā paṭiladdhakkhaṇo, channaṃ āyatanānaṃ avekallakkhaṇoti
analyzed: uppatti kkhaṇo sammādiṭṭhiyā paṭiladdha kkhaṇo channam āyatanānam avekalla kkhaṇo ti
translated: The moment of arising, the moment of obtaining right view, the moment of non-confusion of the six sense bases.

original: sabbopi ayaṃ khaṇo atikkamati, so khaṇo tumhe mā atikkamatūti.
analyzed: sabbaḥ api ayam khaṇaḥ atikkamati saḥ khaṇaḥ tumhe mā atikkamatu uti
translated: All this moment passes away. Let not that moment pass away for you.

original: Evaṃ thero imāya gāthāya sarājikaṃ parisaṃ bhikkhū ca ovaditvā puna maraṇe jīvite
analyzed: evam theraḥ imāya gāthāya sa rājikam parisam bhikkhū ca ovaditvā puna maraṇe jīvite
translated: Thus the Elder, having advised the monks and the assembly with the king, again with this verse, about his equanimity in regard to death and life,

original: ca attano samacittataṃ katakiccatañca pakāsento “nābhinandāmi maraṇa”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: ca samacittatam katakiccatam ca pakāsentaḥ na abhinandāmi
translated: and about his having done what had to be done, said, “I do not rejoice in death.”

original: Taṃ heṭṭhā vuttatthameva.🔽Evaṃ pana vatvā attano parinibbānakālaṃ upaṭṭhitaṃ disvā saṅkhepeneva nesaṃ ovādaṃ
analyzed: tam heṭṭhā vutta ttham eva  evam pana vatvā attanaḥ parinibbāna kālam upaṭṭhitam disvā saṅkhepena iva na īsam ovādam
translated: The meaning of this has already been given above.🔽But having said this, and seeing that the time for his own Parinibbana had arrived, he gave them advice in brief,

original: datvā parinibbānaṃ pavedento osānagāthamāha. Tattha sampādethappamādenāti sampādetabbaṃ🔽dānasīlādiṃ appamādena sampādetha, diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikapabhede gahaṭṭhavatte
analyzed: da tvā parinibbānam pavedentaḥ osāna gātham āha tattha sampādetha ppamādena ati sampādetabbam  dāna sīla ādim appamādena sampādetha diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika pabhede gaha ṭṭha vatte
translated: and announcing his own Parinibbana, he uttered the following final verse: “Be diligent, be not negligent, guard your minds with heedfulness; this is my advice to you all.”🔽Herein, be diligent, be not negligent means be diligent, be not negligent, in the fulfilment of the virtue, etc., that should be fulfilled,

original: sīlānurakkhaṇe samathaanuyoge vipassanābhāvanāya ca appamattā hotha. Esā me anusāsanīti

original: dānasīlādīsu na pamajjathāti esā mama anusiṭṭhi ovādo.
analyzed: dāna sīla ādīsu na esā mama ovādaḥ
translated: Do not be negligent in giving, virtue, etc. This is my advice and instruction to you.

original: Evaṃ sikhāpattaṃ parahitapaṭipattiṃ dīpetvā attahitapaṭipattiyāpi matthakaṃ gaṇhanto🔽“handāhaṃ parinibbissaṃ, vippamuttomhi sabbadhī”ti āha. Tattha vippamuttomhi sabbadhīti
analyzed: evam sikhā pattam para hita paṭipattim dīpetvā atta hita paṭipattiyā api matthakam gaṇhanto  handa aham parinibbissam vippamuttaḥ mhi sabbadhi iti āha tattha vippamuttaḥ mhi sabbadhi iti
translated: Having thus shown the practice of benefitting others, which is the crest-jewel, he also took the crest-jewel of the practice of benefitting himself,

original: sabbaso kilesehi bhavehi ca vippamutto amhi, tasmā ekaṃsena parinibbāyissāmīti.

original: Evaṃ pana vatvā ākāse pallaṅkena nisinno tejodhātuṃ samāpajjitvā pajjalanto anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyi.

analyzed: apara aparam sañcaritvā vāṇijjena jīvikam kappeti yathāvibhavam puññāni api karoti so

analyzed: eka divasam antarāmagge dhure yutta goṇe vahitum a sakkonte patite manussesu tam vuṭṭhāpetum  a sakkontesu sayam eva gantvā tam naṅguṭṭhe gāḷham vijjhi goṇaḥ ayam a sappurisaḥ mama  balābalam a jānantaḥ gāḷham vijjhati iti kuddhaḥ manussa vācāya bho godatta aham ettakam
translated: One day, on the road, the oxen yoked to his cart were unable to draw it. When the men fell down, he was unable to get them up.🔽So he himself went and pierced the ox’s hide deeply with a goad. The ox, “This is a bad man.

original: kālaṃ attano balaṃ aniguhanto tuyhaṃ bhāraṃ vahiṃ, ajja pana asamatthabhāvena patitaṃ
analyzed: kālam balam a niguhantaḥ tuyham bhāram vahim ajja pana asamattha bhāvena patitam
translated: Without knowing my strength or weakness, he pierces me deeply,” was angry and spoke to him in human speech: “Sir Godatta, for so long I have not concealed my strength from you and have drawn your load. But today, because I am unable, I have fallen down

analyzed: paṭisattu bhaveyyanti patthana anurūpena akkosi tam sutvā godattaḥ evam nāma satte

analyzed: bādhetvā kim imāya jīvikāya ati saṃvega jātaḥ sabbam vibhavam pahāya aññatarassa mahā therassa  santike pabbajitvā vipassanāya kammam karontaḥ nacirassa iva arahattam patvā samāpatti sukhena

translated: The subject of his discourse was the world and worldly things:🔽“Just as a fine thoroughbred horse,

translated: when yoked to a well-built chariot,

analyzed: mathitaḥ atibhārena saṃyugam na ativattati
translated: does not break the yoke though heavily laden,🔽“So those who are wise and restrained,

translated: like the ocean by the water,

analyzed: narā dukkham nigacchanti te idha socanti māṇavā

analyzed: unnatā sukha dhammena dukkha dhammena ca ūnatā
translated: “The high are high through pleasant things, the low are low through painful things.

analyzed: ye ca dukkhe sukhasmin ca majjhe sibbini maccagū

analyzed: ṭhitā te inda khīlā uva na te unnata onatā
translated: they stand firm like a pillar, neither high nor low.

analyzed: na ha iva lābhe na alābhe na yase na ca kittiyā
translated: “Not by gain or by loss, not by fame or by disgrace,

analyzed: na ninda ayam pasaṃsāya na te dukkhe sukhamhi ca
translated: not by praise or by blame, not by pleasure or by pain,

translated: The loss that is in accordance with the Dhamma is better, not the gain that is contrary to the Dhamma.

analyzed: ca appabuddhīnam viññūnam ayaso ca yo

translated: The blame of the wise is better, not the praise of the foolish.

translated: “The pleasure that is sensual and the pain that is secluded:

analyzed: pa viveka dukkham seyyaḥ yat ce kāma mayam sukham  jīvitañca adhammena dhammena maraṇañca yaṃ

analyzed: maraṇam dhammikam seyyaḥ yat ce jīve adhammikam
translated: Better to die righteously Than to live unrighteously.

analyzed: kāma kopa ppahīnāḥ ye santa cittāḥ bhava abhave
translated: Those who have abandoned sense-desires and anger, Who are peaceful in mind, in the world of becoming and un-becoming,

analyzed: caranti loke asitāḥ na atthi tesam piya apiyam
translated: They wander in the world unstained, For them there is nothing that is dear or not dear.

analyzed: bhāvayitvāna indriyāni balāni ca

translated: Having attained the highest peace, They are fully quenched, without pollutants.

translated: The yoke means the yoke placed on his own shoulders. He does not go beyond, does not exceed, the yoke. Having properly raised the yoke

analyzed: dhuram chaḍḍetvā na tiṭṭhati yathā saḥ dhorayhaḥ attanaḥ bhadrājānīyatāya attanaḥ  dhīra vīra tāya attanaḥ bhāram na ativattati na pariccajati evam ye vārinā viya mahā samuddaḥ
translated: He does not stand still, abandoning the load. Just as that good horse, by his own good qualities,

analyzed: lokiya lokuttarāya paññāya tittā dhātā paripuṇṇā te pare nihīna paññe na atimaññanti  na paribhavanti tattha kāraṇam āha ariya dhammaḥ uva pāṇinam ti pāṇinam sattesu ayam
translated: by his own courage and heroism, does not exceed or abandon his own load, so too those who are full, complete, and replete with mundane and supramundane wisdom do not despise others who are of inferior wisdom,🔽they do not treat them with contempt. Herein, he gives the reason: “The noble Dhamma is the life of breathing things.” This noble Dhamma of the noble ones, namely, their perfection of wisdom, is the life of breathing things, of beings,

original: ariyānaṃ dhammo yadidaṃ tesaṃ paññāya pāripūriṃ gatattā lābhādinā attānukkaṃsanaṃ

translated: since it is by means of it that they live happily. For just as the noble ones do not boast about themselves by way of gain, etc.,

original: viya alābhādinā paresaṃ avambhanaṃ.🔽Evaṃ paññāpāripūriyā ariyānaṃ sukhavihāraṃ dassetvā tadabhāvato anariyānaṃ dukkhavihāraṃ
analyzed: alābha ādinā paresam  evam paññāpāripūriyā ariyānam sukha vihāram dassetvā tad abhāvataḥ anariyānam dukkha vihāram
translated: when they have reached perfection in wisdom, so too they do not disparage others by way of non-gain, etc.

original: dassetuṃ “kāle”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha kāleti lābhālābhādinā samaṅgībhūtakāle. Kālavasaṃ
analyzed: dassetum kāla itiādi vuttam tattha kāla iti lābha alābha ādinā samaṅgībhūta kāle kāla vasam
translated: Having thus shown the noble ones’ happy life through the perfection of wisdom, he now shows the ignoble ones’ unhappy life through its absence, saying “in time” , etc. Herein, in time means at the time of the occurrence of gain, non-gain, etc. In the power of time means in the power of time, under the control of time.

original: pattāti lābhādikālassa ca vasaṃ upagatā, lābhādinā somanassitā alābhādinā ca domanassitāti
analyzed: pattā ati lābha ādi kālassa ca vasam upagatā lābha ādinā somanassitā alābha ādinā ca domanassitā ati

analyzed: atthaḥ bhava abhava vasam gatā ati bhavassa abhavassa ca vasam upagatā vuddhi hāniyaḥ anuvattantā
translated: “Gone to the control of existence and non-existence” means that they are under the control of existence and non-existence, and that they follow increase and decrease.

translated: “Men go to suffering” means that they are called “men” and “young men” ,

translated: By the words “The lofty” , etc., he shows the occurrence of harm to beings by worldly conditions. Herein, the lofty

analyzed: sukha dhammena ati sukha hetunā sukha paccayena bhoga sampatti ādinā unnatim gatāḥ bhoga mada ādinā

analyzed: mattā ti attho dukkha dhammena conatā ti dukkha hetunā dukkha paccayena bhoga vipatti ādinā
translated: Through the conditions of pain means through the causes of pain, through the conditions of pain, through the misfortune of wealth and so on,

original: nihīnataṃ gatā dāliddiyādinā kāpaññataṃ pattā. Dvayenāti yathāvuttena unnationatidvayena
analyzed: nihīna tam gatāḥ dāliddiya ādinā kāpañña tam pattāḥ dvayena ati yathāvuttena unnati onati dvayena
translated: They have fallen into lowliness, having reached poverty, etc.,🔽By the two: by the two kinds of exaltation and depression stated,

original: lābhālābhādidvayena vā bālaputhujjanā haññanti, anurodhapaṭivirodhavasena vibādhīyanti
analyzed: lābha alābha ādi dvayena vā bāla puthujjanāḥ haññanti anurodha paṭivirodha vasena vibādhīyanti
translated: Or by the two, gain and loss, etc., fools and ordinary men are destroyed, they are thwarted, they are afflicted,

original: pīḷiyanti. Kasmā? Yathābhūtaṃ adassino yasmā te dhammasabhāvaṃ yāthāvato nabbhaññaṃsu,🔽pariññātakkhandhā pahīnakilesā ca na honti, tasmāti attho. “Yathābhūtaṃ adassanā”tipi
analyzed: kasmai yathābhūtam a dassinaḥ yasmā te dhamma sabhāvam yāthāvataḥ nabbhaññaṃsu  pariññāta kkhandhāḥ pahīna kilesāḥ ca na honti tasmā ati atthaḥ yathābhūtam
translated: Why? Because they have not seen in accordance with reality: because they have not penetrated the individual essences of the states in accordance with reality,🔽they have not fully understood the aggregates and have not abandoned the defilements, is the meaning. They read “because of not seeing in accordance with reality,”

original: paṭhanti, adassanahetūti attho. Ye ca dukkhe sukhasmiñca, majjhe sibbinimaccagūti🔽ye pana ariyā dukkhavedanāya sukhavedanāya majjhattatāvedanāya ca tappaṭibaddhaṃ
analyzed: paṭhanti a dassana hetū ti atthaḥ ye ca dukkhe sukhasmin ca majjhe  ye pana ariyāḥ dukkha vedanāya sukha vedanāya majjhatta tā vedanāya ca tad paṭibaddham
translated: the meaning being “because of the cause of not seeing.”🔽But those who have cast off the dart of craving for pleasure, pain, and the neutral feeling that binds them to it,

original: chandarāgabhūtaṃ sibbiniṃ taṇhaṃ aggamaggādhigamena accagū atikkamiṃsu, te indakhīlo
analyzed: chanda rāga bhūtam sibbinim taṇham agga magga adhigamena accagū atikkamiṃsu te indakhīlo
translated: But those who are Noble, having cast off the dart of craving, which is a state of desire and passion, for the feeling of pleasure, the feeling of pain, and the feeling of neutrality, having attained the path of stream-entry,

original: viya vātehi lokadhammehi asampakampiyā ṭhitā, na te unnataonatā, kadācipi unnatā
analyzed: viya vātehi loka dhammehi asampakampiyā ṭhitā na te unnata onatā kadācipi unnatā
translated: are established like a pillar of stone, unshaken by the states of the world, like the wind by a pillar of stone. They are not exalted or depressed,

original: vā onatā vā na honti sabbaso anunayapaṭighābhāvato.
analyzed: vā onatāḥ vā na honti sabbaso anunaya paṭigha abhāvato
translated: They are not bent either way, because of the complete absence of approval and resistance.

original: Evaṃ vedanādhiṭṭhānaṃ arahato anupalepaṃ dassetvā idāni lokadhamme vibhajitvā sabbatthakamevassa
analyzed: evam vedanā adhiṭṭhānam arahataḥ anupalepam dassetvā idāni loka dhamme vibhajitvā sabbatthakam eva assa
translated: Having thus shown the arahant’s freedom from defilement in regard to feeling, the Exalted One now proceeds to show his freedom from defilement in regard to all objects by distinguishing the worldly states.

original: anupalepaṃ dassento “na hevā”tiādimāha. Tattha lābheti cīvarādīnaṃ paccayānaṃ paṭilābhe.
analyzed: anupalepam dassentaḥ na ha iva ati ādim āha tattha lābhe iti cīvara ādīnam paccayānam paṭilābhe
translated: “He is not perturbed” he says, etc. Herein, gain is the acquisition of requisites such as robes, etc.

original: Alābheti tesaṃyeva appaṭilābhe apagame. Na yaseti parivārahāniyaṃ akittiyañca. Kittiyāti🔽parammukhā kittane patthaṭayasatāyaṃ. Nindāyanti sammukhā garahāyaṃ. Pasaṃsāyanti,
analyzed: alābhe iti tesam yeva appaṭilābhe apagame na yasā iti parivāra hāniyam akittiyam ca kittiyā ati  parammukhāḥ kittane nindāyanti sammukhāḥ garahāyam pasaṃsāyanti
translated: Non-gain is the non-acquisition of them. Disrepute is the loss of a retinue and the loss of a good reputation. Reputation is the acquisition of a retinue and a good reputation.

original: paccakkhato guṇābhitthavane. Dukkheti dukkhe uppanne. Sukheti etthāpi eseva nayo.
analyzed: paccakkhataḥ guṇa abhitthavane dukkhā iti dukkhe uppanne sukhā iti ettha api esā iva nayo
translated: Blame is censure in one’s absence. Praise is the proclamation of one’s good qualities in one’s presence. Pain is the arising of pain. Pleasure is the arising of pleasure.

original: Sabbatthāti sabbasmiṃ yathāvutte aṭṭhavidhepi lokadhamme, sabbattha vā rūpādike visaye
analyzed: sabbattha ati sabbasmin yathā vutte aṭṭhavidhe api loka dhamme sabbattha vā rūpa ādike visaye
translated: In all these eight worldly conditions, or in all objects beginning with visible forms,

original: te khīṇāsavā na limpanti sabbaso pahīnakilesattā. Yathā kiṃ? Udabinduva pokkhare
analyzed: te khīṇa āsavāḥ na limpanti sabbaso pahīna kilesa ttā yathā kim pokkhare
translated: the cankers are destroyed, the taints are abandoned, and therefore they are not defiled. How are they not defiled? Like a water drop on a lotus leaf,

original: yathā kamaladale jalabindu allīyitvā ṭhitampi tena na limpati, jalabindunā ca kamaladalaṃ,
analyzed: yathā kamala dale jala bindu tena na limpati jala bindunā ca kamala dalam
translated: Just as a drop of water on a lotus leaf does not stick to it and is not stuck by it,

original: aññadatthu visaṃsaṭṭhameva, evametepi upaṭṭhite lābhādike, āpāthagate rūpādiārammaṇe🔽ca visaṃsaṭṭhā evaṃ. Tato eva dhīrā paṇḍitā sabbattha lābhādīsu ñāṇamukhena piyanimittānaṃ
analyzed: añña datthu visaṃsaṭṭham eva evam ete api upaṭṭhite lābha ādike āpātha gate rūpa ādi ārammaṇe  ca visaṃsaṭṭhā evam tatas eva dhīrā paṇḍitā sabbattha lābha ādīsu ñāṇa mukhena piya nimittānam
translated: but is quite separate from it, so too, when gain, etc., occur and visible objects, etc., come into focus,🔽they are quite separate from the wise man. And precisely for that reason the wise man is happy because of the absence of grief, etc., due to the disappearance of the signs of the dear and the rest by means of the knowledge of gain, etc.,

original: sokādīnañca abhāvato sukhitā lābhādīhi ca anabhibhavanīyato sabbattha aparājitāva honti.🔽Idāni lābhālābhādīsu seyyaṃ niddhāretvā dassento “dhammenā”tiādimāha. Tattha dhammena
analyzed: soka ādīnam ca abhāvataḥ sukhitāḥ lābha ādīhi ca an abhibhavanīyato sabbattha aparājitāḥ ava honti  idāni lābha alābha ādīsu seyyam niddhāretvā dassentaḥ dhammena ati ādim āha tattha dhammena
translated: and he is unconquered everywhere because he is not overcome by gain, etc.

original: ca alābho yoti yo dhammaṃ rakkhantassa taṃnimittaṃ alābho lābhābhāvo, lābhahāni.
analyzed: ca alābhaḥ yaḥ ti yaḥ dhammam rakkhantassa tad nimittam alābhaḥ lābha abhāvaḥ lābha hāni
translated: Now, in order to show the better of gain and loss, etc., he said “By the Dhamma” , etc. Herein, the loss that is by the Dhamma is the non-gain, the non-occurrence, the loss of gain, for one who keeps to the Dhamma.

original: Yo ca lābho adhammiko adhammena aññāyena buddhapaṭikuṭṭhena vidhinā uppanno, tesu
analyzed: yaḥ ca lābhaḥ adhammikaḥ adhammena aññāyena buddha paṭikuṭṭhena vidhinā uppannaḥ tesu
translated: And the gain that is by the undhamma is the gain that has arisen by an undhamma method, by an unrighteous means, by a means condemned by the Buddhas.

original: dvīsu alābho dhammiko dhammāvaho seyyo, yādisaṃ lābhaṃ parivajjantassa akusalā dhammā
analyzed: dvīsu alābhaḥ dhammikaḥ dhamma āvahaḥ seyyaḥ yādisam lābham parivajjantassa akusalāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: Of these two, the loss that is by the Dhamma is better, the gain of unrighteous gain is worse.

original: parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, tādiso alābho pāsaṃsataro atthāvaho. Yañce
analyzed: parihāyanti kusalāḥ dhammāḥ abhivaḍḍhanti tādisaḥ alābhaḥ pāsaṃsataraḥ attha āvahaḥ yat ce
translated: and unwholesome states decline, such gain is more praiseworthy and more profitable.

original: lābho adhammikoti yo lābho adhammena uppanno, so na seyyoti adhippāyo.🔽Yaso ca appabuddhīnaṃ, viññūnaṃ ayaso ca yoti yo appabuddhīnaṃ duppaññānaṃ vasena
analyzed: lābhaḥ adhammikaḥ ti yaḥ lābhaḥ adhammena uppanno saḥ na seyyaḥ ti adhippāyo  ca appabuddhīnam viññūnam ayaso ca yaḥ ati yaḥ appabuddhīnam duppaññānam vasena
translated: And gain that’s contrary to Dhamma: the intention is that gain that has arisen contrary to the Dhamma is not good.🔽And fame among the witless, And disrepute among the wise: the fame that a person gets among the witless, the witless being those who are undistinguished and unwise,

original: puggalassa yaso labbhati, yo ca viññūnaṃ paṇḍitānaṃ vasena ayaso yasahāni. Imesu🔽dvīsu ayasova seyyo viññūnaṃ. Te hissa yathā akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā
analyzed: puggalassa yasaḥ labbhati yaḥ ca viññūnam paṇḍitānam vasena ayasaḥ imesu  dvīsu ayasā uva seyyaḥ viññūnam te hissa yathā akusalāḥ dhammāḥ parihāyanti kusalāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: and the disrepute, the loss of fame, that he gets among the wise, among the wise being those who are distinguished and have understanding—

original: abhivaḍḍhanti, evaṃ yasahāniṃ iccheyyuṃ, tathā ca bhabbajātiko taṃ aguṇaṃ pahāya🔽guṇe patiṭṭheyya. Na yaso appabuddhīnanti duppaññānaṃ vasena yaso seyyo hoti, te
analyzed: abhivaḍḍhanti evam yasa hānim iccheyyum tathā ca bhabba jātikaḥ tam aguṇam pahāya  guṇe patiṭṭheyya na yasaḥ appabuddhīnam ti duppaññānam vasena yasaḥ seyyaḥ hoti te
translated: of these two, disrepute is better among the wise. For they would wish for him a loss of fame in such a way that unwholesome states would decline and wholesome states would increase in him, and he would be the kind of person who would be able to abandon that fault and establish himself in good qualities.

original: hi abhūtaguṇābhibyāhāravasenāpi naṃ uppādeyyuṃ, so cassa idha ceva viññūgarahādinā
analyzed: hi abhūta guṇa abhibyāhāra vasena api naṃ uppādeyyum saḥ ca assa idha ca iva viññūgaraha ādinā
translated: Not fame among the witless: fame is not good among the witless, for they would bring it about even by proclaiming his non-existent good qualities. And that would be a cause for his harm here and now and in the life to come.

original: samparāye ca duggatiyaṃ dukkhaparikkilesādinā anatthāvaho. Tenāha bhagavā – “lābho
analyzed: samparāye ca duggatiyam dukkha parikkilesa ādinā anattha āvaho tena āha bhagavā lābho
translated: and in the life to come it brings misfortune in the way of suffering, defilement, etc., in an unhappy destination. Hence the Blessed One said: “Gain, honour, and fame,🔽and the false glory that is born of these,🔽are the snare of the clansman gone forth,

original: siloko sakkāro, micchāladdho ca yo yaso”ti “sakkāro kāpurisaṃ hantī”ti ca.
analyzed: silokaḥ sakkāraḥ micchāladdho ca yaḥ yasaḥ iti sakkāro kāpurisam hanti iti ca
translated: the destroyer of the man of evil mind” .

original: Dummedhehīti, nippaññehi. Yañce bālappasaṃsanāti bālehi aviddasūhi yā nāma pasaṃsanā.🔽Kāmamayikanti vatthukāmamayaṃ, kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppannaṃ. Dukkhañca pavivekiyanti
analyzed: dummedhehi iti nippaññehi yat ce bāla ppasaṃsanā ati bālehi aviddasūhi yā nāma pasaṃsanā  kāmamayikanti vatthu kāma mayam kāma guṇe paṭicca uppannam dukkham ca pavivekiyanti
translated: “The foolish” : the unskilled. “Praise by fools” : praise by fools, by the undiscerning.

original: pavivekato nibbattaṃ kāyakilamathavasena pavattaṃ visamāsanupatāpādihetukaṃ kāyikaṃ
analyzed: pavivekataḥ nibbattam kāya kilamatha vasena pavattam visamāsana upatāpa ādi hetukam kāyikam
translated: “Born of sense desires” : born of sense desires as objects of attachment. “The suffering of seclusion” : the bodily pain that arises from seclusion, that is to say, from bodily discomfort due to sitting in the same posture for a long time, etc.

original: dukkhaṃ, taṃ pana nirāmisavivaṭṭūpanissayatāya viññūnaṃ pāsaṃsā. Tena vuttaṃ “pavivekadukkhaṃ seyyo”ti.🔽Jīvitañca adhammenāti adhammena jīvikakappanaṃ jīvitahetu adhammacaraṇaṃ. Dhammena
analyzed: dukkham tam pana nirāmisa vivaṭṭu upanissaya tāya viññūnam pāsaṃsā tena vuttam paviveka dukkham seyyaḥ ti  jīvitam ca adhammena ati adhammena jīvika kappanam jīvita hetu adhamma caraṇam dhammena
translated: This is blameless in the eyes of the discerning because it is the proximate cause for the emergence of the deathless. Hence it is said: “Better is the suffering of seclusion” .🔽“To live by what is contrary to the True Idea” : to live by what is contrary to the True Idea in order to live. “To die by what is in accordance with the True Idea” : when someone says “We will kill him if he does not do this evil” and he dies

original: maraṇaṃ nāma “imaṃ nāma pāpaṃ akarontaṃ taṃ māressāmī”ti kenaci vutte mārentepi tasmiṃ
analyzed: maraṇam nāma imam nāma pāpam akarontam tam māressāmi iti kenacid vutte mārente api tasmin
translated: while doing it.

original: pāpaṃ akatvā dhammaṃ avikopentassa dhammahetumaraṇaṃ dhammikaṃ seyyoti tādisaṃ maraṇaṃ
analyzed: pāpam a katvā dhammam a vikopentassa dhamma hetu maraṇam dhammikam seyyaḥ uti tādisam maraṇam
translated: “Having done no evil, having disturbed no one’s faith, dying for the Dhamma is righteous.”🔽

original: dhammato anapetattā dhammikaṃ saggasampāpanato nibbānupanissayato ca viññūnaṃ pāsaṃsataraṃ. Tathā hi vuttaṃ –
analyzed: dhammataḥ an apeta ttā dhammikam sagga sampāpanataḥ nibbāna upanissayato ca viññūnam pāsaṃsataram tathā hi vuttam
translated: Without doing evil and without violating the Dhamma, death for the sake of the Dhamma is righteous. Such a death is righteous because it is not divorced from the Dhamma, and it is more praiseworthy to the wise because it leads to heaven and to the support of nibbana. For this is said:

original: “Caje dhanaṃ aṅgavarassa hetu, aṅgaṃ caje jīvitaṃ rakkhamāno;
analyzed: caje dhanam aṅga varassa hetu aṅgam caje jīvitam rakkhamānaḥ
translated: “For the sake of a limb one may give up wealth; for the sake of a limb one may give up life and guard it.

original: Aṅgaṃ dhanaṃ jīvitañcāpi sabbaṃ, caje naro dhammamanussaranto”ti. ;
analyzed: aṅgam dhanam jīvitam ca api sabbam caje naraḥ dhammam anussarantaḥ ti
translated: For the sake of a limb one may give up wealth, life, and all; a man who follows the Dhamma may give up all.”

original: Yañce jīve adhammikanti puriso yaṃ dhammato apetaṃ jīvikaṃ jīveyya, taṃ na seveyya viññūhi garahitattā apāyasampāpanato cāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: yat ce jīve adhammikanti purisaḥ yam dhammataḥ apetam jīvikam jīveyya tam na seveyya viññūhi garahita ttā apāya sampāpanato ca ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: “And if one lives by what is unrighteous” : the intention is that one should not live by a livelihood that is unrighteous, because it is censured by the wise and because it leads to states of deprivation.

original: Idāni yathāvuttaṃ khīṇāsavānaṃ anupalepaṃ kāraṇato dassento “kāmakopapahīnā”tiādigāthamāha.
analyzed: idāni yathā vuttam khīṇa āsavānam anupalepam kāraṇataḥ dassentaḥ kāma kopa pahīna iti ādi gātham āha
translated: Now, in order to show the reason why the lust-free do not cling as stated, he uttered the stanza beginning with “Having abandoned lust and anger.”

original: Tattha kāmakopapahīnāti ariyamaggena sabbasova pahīnā anurodhapaṭivirodhā. Santacittā
analyzed: tattha kāma kopa pahīnā ti ariya maggena sabbaso va pahīnā anurodha paṭivirodhā santa cittā
translated: Herein, having abandoned lust and anger : having abandoned by the noble path all lust and anger, all compliance and opposition. With their minds peaceful,

original: bhavābhaveti khuddake ceva mahante ca bhave anavasesapahīnakilesapariḷāhatāya vūpasantacittā.
analyzed: bhava abhava iti khuddake ca iva mahante ca bhave anavasesa pahīna kilesa pariḷāha tāya vūpasanta cittā
translated: In the world of being and non-being : in the small and great worlds. With their minds stilled : with their minds stilled through the complete abandonment of defilements and of the fever of craving.

original: Loketi khandhādiloke. Asitāti taṇhādiṭṭhinissayavasena anissitā. Natthi tesaṃ piyāpiyanti
analyzed: loke ti khandha ādi loke asitā ti taṇhā diṭṭhi nissaya vasena anissitā na atthi tesam piya apiyanti
translated: The world : the world of the aggregates, etc. Not clinging : not clinging through craving and views. There is nothing dear or undear to them :

original: tesaṃ khīṇāsavānaṃ katthaci lābhādike rūpādivisaye ca piyaṃ vā apiyaṃ vā natthi,
analyzed: tesam khīṇāsavānam katthaci lābha ādike rūpa ādi visaye ca piyam vā apiyam vā natthi
translated: there is nothing dear or undear to them who are without cankers,

original: taṃnimittānaṃ kilesānaṃ sabbaso samucchinnattā.🔽Idāni yāya bhāvanāya te evarūpā jātā, taṃ dassetvā anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā desanāya
analyzed: tad nimittānam kilesānam sabbaso  idāni yāya bhāvanāya te evarūpā jātā tam dassetvā anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā desanāya
translated: because they have completely eradicated the defilements that have those things as their objects.🔽Now, in order to show the development by which they have become such, and in order to conclude the teaching with the element of extinction without residue, he uttered the verse “Having developed” ,

original: kūṭaṃ gaṇhanto “bhāvayitvānā”ti osānagāthamāha. Tattha pappuyyāti, pāpuṇitvā. Sesaṃ
analyzed: kūṭam gaṇhantaḥ osāna gātham āha tattha pappuyya āti pāpuṇitvā sesam
translated: having taken the peak . Therein, having attained : having reached. The rest is

original: heṭṭhā vuttanayameva. Imā eva ca gāthā therassa aññābyākaraṇāpi ahesuṃ.
analyzed: heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva imāḥ eva ca gāthāḥ therassa aññā abyākaraṇā api ahesuṃ
translated: as stated above. And these verses were also the Elder’s reply to a question.

original: Godattattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: godatta thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The story of the Elder Godatta is finished.

original: Cuddasakanipātavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: cuddasaka nipāta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Fourteenth Section is finished.

original: 15. Soḷasakanipāto
analyzed: sa ūḍasaka nipātaḥ
translated: The Fifteenth Section

original: 1. Aññāsikoṇḍaññattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: aññāsikoṇḍañña thera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Elder Aññāsikoṇḍañña’s verses,

original: Soḷasakanipāte esa bhiyyotiādikā āyasmato aññāsikoṇḍaññattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti?
analyzed: soḷasaka nipāte bhiyyo ti ādikā āyasmataḥ aññāsikoṇḍañña ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti
translated: What was the occasion?

original: Ayampi padumuttarassa bhagavato kāle haṃsavatīnagare gahapatimahāsālakule nibbattitvā
analyzed: ayam pi padumuttarassa bhagavato kāle haṃsavatī nagare gahapati mahāsāla kule nibbattitvā
translated: This Elder was reborn in the time of the Buddha Padumuttara, in the city of Haṃsavatī, in the family of a great treasurer.

original: viññutaṃ patvā ekadivasaṃ satthu santike dhammaṃ suṇanto satthāraṃ ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ
analyzed: viññutam patvā ekadivasam satthu santike dhammaṃ suṇantaḥ satthāram ekam bhikkhum
translated: When he had attained to years of discretion, one day as he was listening to the Law in the presence of the Teacher, he saw the Teacher place a certain monk

original: attano sāsane paṭhamaṃ paṭividdhadhammarattaññūnaṃ aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapentaṃ disvā sayampi
analyzed: attano sāsane paṭhamam paṭividdha dhamma ratta ññūnam aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapentam disvā sayam pi
translated: in the foremost position among those who were well versed in the Law, who had penetrated the Law for themselves. Thereupon he made his Earnest Wish, saying, “May I also obtain that place.”

original: taṃ ṭhānantaraṃ patthento satasahassabhikkhuparivārassa satthuno sattāhaṃ mahādānaṃ
analyzed: tam ṭhāna antaram patthento sata sahassa bhikkhu parivārassa satthuno sattāham mahādānam
translated: For seven days he provided the Teacher, who was surrounded by a company of a hundred thousand monks, with abundant offerings,

original: pavattetvā paṇidhānaṃ akāsi. Satthāpissa anantarāyataṃ disvā bhāviniṃ sampattiṃ byākāsi.
analyzed: pavattetvā paṇidhānam akāsi satthā api sampattim byākāsi
translated: and made his Earnest Wish. The Teacher perceived that no obstacle lay in the way of his attaining his wish, and therefore he prophesied that he would attain his wish.

translated: Surrounding the Sambuddha, they worshipped, with hands together in reverential salutation.

original: “Sabbe devā tuṭṭhamanā, ākāse sañcaranti te;
analyzed: sabbe devā tuṭṭha manāḥ ākāse sañcaranti te

analyzed: buddhaḥ ayam an uppattaḥ andhakāra tamonudaḥ

translated: There he will rule as a wheel-turning monarch for a thousand times.

translated: Having gone forth from the home life, he will live for six years.

translated: I went forth into homelessness to destroy the defilements,

analyzed: nisinnaḥ paṭhamam paṭividdha dhamma bhāvam dīpento etat aggam bhikkhave mama sāvakānam

analyzed: viveka abhiratiyā viharitu kāmo ca attanaḥ santikam upagatānam gahaṭṭha pabbajitānam paṭisanthāra karaṇam pi  papañcam maññamānaḥ satthāram āpucchitvā himavantam pavisitvā chaddantehi nāgehi upaṭṭhiyamānaḥ

analyzed: chaddantadaha tīre dvādasa vassāni evam tattha vasantam theram eka divasam sakko

analyzed: disvā tad paṭipakkha bhūtam ca assa anukkamam anussaritvā attanaḥ ca sabbasas tatas vinivattita māna satam

original: āvajjetvā tadatthaṃ dīpetvā –🔽“Bahūni loke citrāni, asmiṃ pathavimaṇḍale;🔽Mathenti maññe saṅkappaṃ, subhaṃ rāgūpasaṃhitaṃ.
analyzed: āvajjetvā tad attham dīpetvā  bahūni loke citrāni asmin pathavi maṇḍale  mathenti maññe saṅkappam subham rāgu upasaṃhitam
