original: “Rajamuhatañca vātena, yathā meghopasammaye;🔽Evaṃ sammanti saṅkappā, yadā paññāya passatī”ti. – dve gāthā abhāsi;
analyzed: vātena yathā 🔽evam saṅkappāḥ yadā paññāya passati iti dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Because it is taught as the fading away of lust, it is called the fading away of lust.

original: Tattha bahūni loke citrānīti rūpādivasena tatthāpi nīlapītādivasena itthipurisādivasena🔽ca anekāni loke cittavicittāni ārammaṇajātāni. Asmiṃ pathavimaṇḍaleti paccakkhabhūtaṃ
analyzed: tattha bahūni loke citrāni iti rūpa ādi vasena tattha api nīla pīta ādi vasena itthi purisa ādi vasena  ca anekāni loke citta vicittāni ārammaṇa jātāni asmim pathavi maṇḍale ti paccakkha bhūtam
translated: Herein, there are many kinds of ideas in the world means that there are many kinds of objects of consciousness in the world, classed as visible objects, etc., and also classed as blue, yellow, etc., and as female, male, etc.

original: manussalokaṃ sandhāya vadati. Mathenti maññe saṅkappanti tajjaṃ purisavāyāmasahitaṃ
analyzed: manussa lokam sandhāya vadati mathenti maññe saṅkappanti tajjam purisa vāyāma sahitam
translated: In this world means in the world of men, which is the world that is the opposite of the world of the gods, etc., and is the world of men because it is the world of men.

original: araṇisahitaṃ viya aggiṃ ayonisomanasikārābhisaṅkhātāni micchāsaṅkappāni mathenti
analyzed: araṇi sahitam viya aggim a yonisoma nasikāra abhisaṅkhātāni micchāsaṅkappāni mathenti
translated: They grind as if they were grinding a fire means that wrong thoughts, which are called improper attention, stand as if they were grinding, grinding with the human effort appropriate to them as with fire sticks.

original: maññe mathentāni viya tiṭṭhanti. Kīdisaṃ? Subhaṃ rāgūpasaṃhitaṃ, kāmavitakkanti attho.
analyzed: maññe mathentāni viya tiṭṭhanti kīdisam subham rāgu upasaṃhitam kāma vitakkanti attho
translated: What are they like? Beautiful, associated with greed: the meaning is, thoughts of sensual desire.

original: So hi subhākāraggahaṇena “subho”ti voharīyati.🔽Rajamuhatañca vātenāti ca-iti nipātamattaṃ. Yathā gimhānaṃ pacchime māse vātena ūhataṃ
analyzed: saḥ hi subha ākāra ggahaṇena subha uti  vātena ati ca eti nipāta mattam yathā gimhānam pacchime māse vātena
translated: For that is called “beautiful” because it grasps the aspect of beauty.🔽And the dust that the wind raises means that just as a great rain cloud puts an end to, stops, the dust that the wind raises up in the last month of the Rains,

original: uṭṭhitaṃ rajaṃ mahāmegho vassanto upasammaye, vūpasameyya. Evaṃ sammanti saṅkappā,
analyzed: uṭṭhitam rajam mahā meghaḥ vassantaḥ upasammaye vūpasameyya evam sammanti saṅkappāḥ
translated: so thoughts

original: yadā paññāya passatīti yadā ariyasāvako tāni lokacitrāni samudayato, assādato, ādīnavato,
analyzed: yadā paññāya passati iti yadā ariya sāvako tāni loka citrāni samudayataḥ assādataḥ ādīnavataḥ
translated: When he sees with understanding: when a noble disciple sees with understanding as it really is the diversity of the world’s beauty as its origin, as its passing away, as its allure, as its danger,

original: nissaraṇato ca yathābhūtaṃ paññāya passati, atha yathā taṃ rajaṃ uhataṃ meghena,
analyzed: nissaraṇataḥ ca yathābhūtam paññāya passati atha yathā tam rajam meghena
translated: and as the escape from it, then, as the dust-heap covered by the cloud,

original: evaṃ sammanti paññāya sabbepi micchāsaṅkappā. Na hi uppannāya sammādiṭṭhiyā micchāsaṅkappā
analyzed: evam paññāya sabbe api micchāsaṅkappāḥ na hi uppannāya sammādiṭṭhiyā micchāsaṅkappā
translated: so all his wrong thoughts are covered by understanding. For when right view has arisen, wrong thoughts

original: patiṭṭhaṃ labhanti. Yathā pana paññāya passati, taṃ dassento –
analyzed: patiṭṭham labhanti yathā pana paññāya passati tam dassento
translated: find no footing. Showing how he sees with understanding, he said:

original: “Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccāti, yadā paññāya passati;
analyzed: sabbe saṅkhārāḥ aniccā ati yadā paññāya passati
translated: “When he sees with understanding that all formations are impermanent,

original: Atha nibbindati dukkhe, esa maggo visuddhiyā.
analyzed: atha nibbindati dukkhe esa maggaḥ visuddhiyā
translated: Then he becomes dispassionate towards suffering; this is the path to purification.

original: “Sabbe saṅkhārā dukkhāti…pe… esa maggo visuddhiyā.
analyzed: sabbe saṅkhārāḥ dukkha atipe esa maggaḥ visuddhiyā
translated: “When he sees with understanding that all formations are suffering … this is the path to purification.

original: “Sabbe dhammā anattāti, yadā paññāya passati;
analyzed: sabbe dhammā anattā ati yadā paññāya passati
translated: “When he sees with understanding that all ideas are not self,

original: Atha nibbindati dukkhe, esa maggo visuddhiyā”ti. –
analyzed: atha nibbindati dukkhe esa maggaḥ visuddhiyā ati
translated: Then he becomes dispassionate towards suffering; this is the path to purification” .

original: Tisso gāthā abhāsi.
analyzed: tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: He uttered these three stanzas.

original: Tattha sabbe saṅkhārāti chaḷārammaṇasaṅgahā sabbe tebhūmakā pañcakkhandhā. Aniccāti
analyzed: tattha sabbe saṅkhārā ati chaṭṭha ārammaṇa saṅgahā sabbe tebhūmakā pañca kkhandhāḥ aniccā ti
translated: Herein, all formations are the five categories of the three planes of existence included in the six bases for contact. Impermanent:

original: “ādimajjhaantavantato, aniccantikato, tāvakālikato, tattha tattha bhijjanato na niccā”ti
analyzed: ādi majjha antavantataḥ tāvakālikataḥ tattha tattha bhijjanataḥ na nicca ati
translated: “They are not permanent because of having a beginning, middle, and end, because of being subject to impermanence, because of being for a time, and because of breaking up here and there.”

original: yadā vipassanāpaññāya passati. Atha nibbindati dukkheti atha imasmiṃ vaṭṭadukkhe🔽nibbindati, nibbindanto dukkhaparijānanādividhinā saccāni paṭivijjhati. Esa maggo
analyzed: yadā vipassanā paññāya passati atha nibbindati dukkhe iti atha imasmim vaṭṭa dukkhe  nibbindati nibbindantaḥ dukkha parijānana ādi vidhinā saccāni paṭivijjhati esa maggo
translated: When he sees them thus with insight knowledge, then he becomes dispassionate towards them.🔽When he becomes dispassionate, he penetrates the truths in the way beginning “He becomes dispassionate, detaches, is released” .

original: visuddhiyāti esa yathāvutto vipassanāvidhi ñāṇadassanavisuddhiyā, accantavisuddhiyā
analyzed: visuddhiyā ti esa yathā vuttaḥ vipassanā vidhi ñāṇa dassana visuddhiyā accanta visuddhiyā
translated: This is the way: this is the method stated thus far for the purification by knowledge and vision of the way, for the complete surmounting of sorrow.

original: ca maggo adhigamupāyo.
analyzed: ca maggaḥ adhigama upāyaḥ
translated: The way is the means to the attainment of purification.

original: Dukkhāti sappaṭibhayato, udayabbayasampaṭipīḷanato, dukkhamato, sukhapaṭikkhepato ca dukkhā. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: dukkhā ti sa paṭibhayataḥ udaya bbaya sampaṭipīḍanataḥ dukkhamataḥ sukha paṭikkhepato ca dukkhā sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: They are suffering because of being subject to cankers, because of oppression by rise and fall, because of being the basis for suffering, and because of being opposed to happiness. The rest is as already stated.

original: Sabbe dhammā anattāti sabbepi catubhūmakā dhammā anattā. Idha pana tebhūmakadhammāva
analyzed: sabbe dhammā anattā ti sabbe pi catu bhūmakāḥ dhammāḥ anattāḥ idha pana tebhūmaka dhammāḥ ava
translated: All dhammas are not-self: all dhammas in the four planes are not-self. But here only the dhammas in the three planes should be taken.

original: gahetabbā. Te hi asārato, avasavattanato, suññato, attapaṭikkhepato ca anattāti vipassitabbā.
analyzed: gahetabbā te hi asārataḥ a vasavattanataḥ suññataḥ atta paṭikkhepataḥ ca anattā ati vipassitabbā
translated: For they should be seen as not-self because of being insubstantial, because of not being one’s own, because of being void, and because of being opposed to self.

original: Sesaṃ purimasadisameva.
analyzed: sesam purima sadisam eva
translated: The rest is as already stated.

original: Evaṃ vipassanāvidhiṃ dassetvā tena vidhinā katakiccaṃ attānaṃ aññaṃ viya katvā dassento –
analyzed: evam vipassanā vidhim dassetvā tena vidhinā kata kiccam attānam aññam viya katvā dassento
translated: Having thus shown the method of insight, he showed himself as one who had done the task by that method, saying:

original: “Buddhānubuddho yo thero, koṇḍañño tibbanikkamo;
analyzed: buddhānubuddhaḥ yaḥ thero koṇḍañño tibba nikkamaḥ
translated: The Elder who was Buddha’s disciple, Koṇḍañña, of great endeavour,

original: Pahīnajātimaraṇo, brahmacariyassa kevalī.🔽“Oghapāso daḷhakhilo, pabbato duppadālayo;
analyzed: pahīna jāti maraṇaḥ brahmacariyassa kevalī  oghapāsaḥ daḷhakhilo pabbataḥ duppada ālayo
translated: Who had abandoned birth and death, and was the sole remainder of the holy life.🔽The snare of the flood, the firm-set stake, the rock that is so hard to move,

original: Chetvā khilañca pāsañca, selaṃ bhetvāna dubbhidaṃ;
analyzed: chetvā khilam ca pāsam ca selam bhetvāna dubbhidam
translated: Having cut the stake and the snare, and split the rock so hard to split,

original: Tiṇṇo pāraṅgato jhāyī, mutto so mārabandhanā”ti. –
analyzed: tiṇṇaḥ jhāyī muttaḥ saḥ
translated: The meditator has crossed over, has gone to the further shore, and is freed from Mara’s bonds.

original: Gāthādvayamāha.
analyzed: gāthā dvayam āha
translated: He uttered these two stanzas.

original: Tattha buddhānubuddhoti buddhānaṃ anubuddho, sammāsambuddhehi bujjhitāni saccāni
analyzed: tattha buddha anubuddhaḥ iti buddhānam anubuddhaḥ sammāsambuddhehi bujjhitāni saccāni
translated: Herein, Buddha’s disciple : he was a disciple of the Buddhas, he was awakened to the truths awakened to by the Supremely Awakened Ones;

original: tesaṃ desanānusārena bujjhatīti attho. Thirehi asekkhehi sīlasārādīhi samannāgatoti,
analyzed: tesam desanā anusārena bujjhati iti attho thirehi asekkhehi sīla sāra ādīhi samannāgataḥ ti
translated: the meaning is that he awakened to them by following their teaching. He was an elder in being possessed of the essence of virtue, etc.,

original: thero. Koṇḍaññoti gottakittanaṃ. Tibbanikkamoti daḷhavīriyo, thiraparakkamo. Jātimaraṇānaṃ
analyzed: thero koṇḍañño ti gotta kittanam tibbanikkamo ti daḷha vīriyaḥ thira parakkamaḥ jāti maraṇānam
translated: Koṇḍañña is a name-calling. Of great endeavour: of great energy, of great exertion.

original: pahīnakāraṇattā pahīnajātimaraṇo. Brahmacariyassa kevalīti maggabrahmacariyassa anavasesaṃ,
analyzed: pahīna kāraṇa ttā pahīna jāti maraṇaḥ brahmacariyassa kevalī iti magga brahmacariyassa anavasesam
translated: He had abandoned birth and death because he had abandoned the cause of birth and death. He was the sole remainder of the holy life, of the path holy life,

original: anavasesato vā maggabrahmacariyassa pāripūrako, atha vā kevalī nāma kilesehi asammissatāya🔽maggañāṇaṃ phalañāṇañca, taṃ imasmiṃ atthīti kevalī. Yasmā pana tadubhayampi maggabrahmacariyassa
analyzed: anavasesataḥ vā magga brahmacariyassa pāripūrakaḥ atha vā kevalī nāma kilesehi a sammissa tāya  magga ñāṇam phala ñāṇam ca tam imasmin atthi iti kevalī yasmā pana tat ubhayam pi magga brahmacariyassa
translated: Or else he is called “perfect” because he fulfills the holy life of the path without remainder.🔽The knowledge of the path and the knowledge of fruition are called “perfect” because they are not mixed with defilements.

original: vasena hoti na aññathā, tasmā “brahmacariyassa kevalī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vasena hoti na aññathā tasmā brahmacariyassa kevalī iti vuttam
translated: Since both of these are possible only through the holy life of the path and not otherwise, it is said: “he is perfect in the holy life.”

original: Oghapāsoti “kāmogho, bhavogho, diṭṭhogho, avijjogho”ti evaṃ vuttā cattāro oghā –
analyzed: ogha pāso ti kāma oghaḥ bhava oghaḥ diṭṭha oghaḥ avijja oghaḥ ti evam vuttā cattāro oghā
translated: The four floods are called “floods” in the passage: “The flood of sensuality, the flood of becoming, the flood of views, the flood of ignorance” .

original: “antalikkhacaro pāso, yvāyaṃ carati mānaso”ti evaṃ vutto rāgapāso ca. Daḷhakhiloti🔽“satthari kaṅkhati, dhamme kaṅkhati, saṅghe kaṅkhati, sikkhāya kaṅkhati, sabrahmacārīsu🔽kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto”ti evaṃ vutto daḷho thiro pañcavidho
analyzed: antalikkha caro pāsaḥ yvā ayam carati mānaso ti evam vutto rāgapāso ca daḷha khilo ti  satthari kaṅkhati dhamme kaṅkhati saṅghe kaṅkhati sikkhāya kaṅkhati sabrahmacārīsu  kupitaḥ hoti anatta manaḥ āhata citto khila jātaḥ ti evam vuttaḥ daḷhaḥ thiraḥ pañcavidhaḥ
translated: The snare of lust is called “snare” in the passage: “The snare that wanders about in the sky, that dwells in the mind” .🔽The five stubbornnesses are called “stubbornnesses” in the passage: “He is doubtful about the Teacher, doubtful about the Dhamma, doubtful about the Sangha, doubtful about the training, and he is angry and displeased with his companions in the holy life, resentful and callous” .

original: cetokhilo ca. Pacurajanehi padāletuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya duppadālayo. Tato eva pabbatasadisatāya
analyzed: cetokhilo ca pacura janehi padāletum a sakkuṇeyya tāya tatas eva pabbata sadisa tāya
translated: The five stubbornnesses are stubbornness about one’s view, stubbornness about one’s persistence, stubbornness about one’s opinions, stubbornness about one’s conceits, and stubbornness about one’s lust.🔽They are hard to remove because they cannot be removed by ordinary people. Because they are like a mountain, they are called “stubbornnesses.”

original: pabbatoti ca saṅkhaṃ gato. “Dukkhe aññāṇa”ntiādinā vā nayena vutto aññāṇappabhedo
analyzed: pabbato ti ca saṅkham gataḥ dukkhe aññāṇa nti ādinā vā nayena vuttaḥ aññāṇa ppabhedaḥ
translated: and it is called a mountain. Or else, it is the ignorance that is stated in the way beginning, “Through not knowing suffering” .

original: ca. Iti etaṃ sabbaṃ chetvā khilañca pāsañcāti etesu catubbidhesu saṃkilesadhammesu
analyzed: ca iti etam sabbam chetvā khilam ca pāsam ca ati etesu catubbidhesu saṃkilesa dhammesu
translated: Thus, having cut away all this, the thicket and the snare, in regard to these four kinds of defiled states,

original: yo khilañca pāsañca ariyamaggañāṇāsinā chinditvā. Selaṃ bhetvāna dubbhidanti yena
analyzed: yaḥ khilam ca pāsam ca ariya magga ñāṇa asinā chinditvā selam bhetvāna dubbhidanti yena
translated: having cut away the thicket and the snare with the sword of the knowledge of the noble path,🔽having cut away with the knowledge that is like a diamond the ignorance-mountain that cannot be cut away by any other kind of knowledge,

original: kenaci ñāṇena chindituṃ asakkuṇeyyaṃ aññāṇaselaṃ vajirūpamañāṇena chinditvā, cattāropi
analyzed: kenaci ñāṇena chinditum a sakkuṇeyyam aññāṇa selam vaji rūpam a ñāṇena chinditvā cattāro api
translated: having crossed the four floods,

original: oghe taritvā, tesaṃ paratīre nibbāne ṭhitattā tiṇṇo pāraṅgato. Ārammaṇūpanijjhānalakkhaṇena
analyzed: oghe taritvā tesam para tīre nibbāne ṭhita ttā pāraṅgataḥ ārammaṇa upanijjhāna lakkhaṇena
translated: having stood on the other side of the floods, which is Nibbāna, having crossed over and gone to the further shore,

original: lakkhaṇūpanijjhānalakkhaṇenāti duvidhenapi jhāyī; mutto so mārabandhanāti so evarūpo
analyzed: lakkhaṇa upanijjhāna lakkhaṇena ati duvidhena api jhāyī muttaḥ saḥ māra bandhanā ati saḥ evarūpo
translated: having seen with the two kinds of insight, which have the characteristic of penetrating the sign of the object and the characteristic of penetrating the specific nature of the object,

original: khīṇāsavo sabbasmāpi kilesamārabandhanā mutto vippamutto visaṃyuttoti. Attānameva
analyzed: khīṇa āsavaḥ sabbasmā api kilesa māra bandhanā muttaḥ vippamuttaḥ visaṃyuttaḥ ti attānam eva
translated: he is freed from Māra’s bonds: that one of such a kind, who has destroyed the taints, is freed, completely freed, from all the bonds of the defilement-Māra.

original: sandhāya thero vadati.
analyzed: sandhāya theraḥ vadati
translated: The Elder speaks with reference to himself.

original: Athekadivasaṃ thero, attano saddhivihārikaṃ ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ akalyāṇamittasaṃsaggena
analyzed: atha eka divasam theraḥ attanaḥ saddhivihārikam ekam bhikkhum akalyāṇa mitta saṃsaggena
translated: Then one day the Elder, because of his association with an unvirtuous bhikkhu who was his pupil,

original: kusītaṃ hīnavīriyaṃ uddhataṃ unnaḷaṃ viharantaṃ disvā, iddhiyā tattha gantvā, taṃ
analyzed: kusītam hīna vīriyam uddhatam unnaḷam viharantam disvā iddhiyā tattha gantvā tam
translated: and seeing him lazy, with little energy, excited, and living in a state of agitation, he went there by his psychic power, and

original: “mā, āvuso, evaṃ kari, akalyāṇamitte pahāya kalyāṇamitte sevanto samaṇadhammaṃ karohī”ti
analyzed: mā āvuso evam kari akalyāṇa mitte pahāya kalyāṇa mitte sevantaḥ samaṇa dhammam karohi iti
translated: “Friend, don’t act in this way. Having abandoned bad friends, and associating with good friends, practice the ascetic’s life.”

original: ovadi. So therassa vacanaṃ nādiyi. Thero tassa anādiyanena dhammasaṃvegappatto puggalādhiṭṭhānāya
analyzed: ovadi so therassa vacanam na ādiyi thero tassa an ādiyanena dhamma saṃvega ppatto puggala adhiṭṭhānāya
translated: But he did not listen to the Elder’s words. The Elder, because of his not listening, became disgusted with him, and in a talk based on persons,

original: kathāya micchāpaṭipattiṃ garahanto sammāpaṭipattiṃ vivekavāsañca pasaṃsanto –
analyzed: kathāya micchā paṭipattim garahantaḥ sammā paṭipattim viveka vāsam ca pasaṃsantaḥ
translated: condemning wrong practice, and praising right practice and the life of seclusion, said:

original: “Uddhato capalo bhikkhu, mitte āgamma pāpake;
analyzed: uddhataḥ capalaḥ bhikkhu mitte āgamma pāpake
translated: “The excited, fickle monk, having come to bad friends,

original: Saṃsīdati mahoghasmiṃ, ūmiyā paṭikujjito.
analyzed: saṃsīdati mahā oghasmin ūmiyā paṭikujjitaḥ
translated: Sinks in the great flood, like a boatman in a river.

original: “Anuddhato acapalo, nipako saṃvutindriyo;
analyzed: an uddhataḥ a capalaḥ nipakaḥ saṃvuti indriyaḥ
translated: “The unexcited, not fickle, the watchful, the one with restrained faculties,

original: Kalyāṇamitto medhāvī, dukkhassantakaro siyā.
analyzed: kalyāṇa mittaḥ medhāvī dukkhassanta karaḥ siyā
translated: The good friend, the wise one, can make an end to suffering.

original: “Kālapabbaṅgasaṅkāso, kiso dhamanisanthato;
analyzed: kāla pabbaṅga saṅkāsaḥ kisaḥ dhamani santhato
translated: “Pale like a broken rain cloud, thin, with veins showing all over,

original: Mattaññū annapānasmiṃ, adīnamanaso naro.
analyzed: mattaññū anna pānasmin adīna manasaḥ naraḥ
translated: The one who knows moderation in food and drink, the one with an undepressed mind.

original: “Phuṭṭho ḍaṃsehi makasehi, araññasmiṃ brahāvane;
analyzed: phuṭṭhaḥ ḍaṃsehi makasehi araññasmim brahā vane
translated: “Touched by flies and bees, in the forest, in the great wood,

original: Nāgo saṅgāmasīseva, sato tatrādhivāsaye.
analyzed: nāgaḥ tatra adhivāsaye
translated: The one who is mindful should endure it, like an elephant in the front of battle.

original: “Nābhinandāmi maraṇaṃ…pe… sampajāno patissato.🔽“Pariciṇṇo mayā satthā…pe… bhavanetti samūhatā.🔽“Yassa catthāya pabbajito, agārasmānagāriyaṃ;
analyzed: na abhinandāmi maraṇaṃpe sampajāno patissato  pariciṇṇaḥ mayā satthāpe bhavanetti samūhatā  yassa ca atthāya pabbajitaḥ agārasmā anagāriyam
translated: I do not welcome death, nor do I welcome life.🔽I have served the Teacher, the Buddha, the Kinsman of the Sun, and I have destroyed the conduit to existence.🔽The purpose for which I went forth from the home life into homelessness has been achieved.

original: So me attho anuppatto, kiṃ me saddhivihārinā”ti. –
analyzed: saḥ me atthaḥ an uppattaḥ kim me saddhivihārinā ati
translated: What have I to do with a companion?

original: Imā gāthā abhāsi.🔽Tattha uddhatoti uddhaccayutto asamāhito vikkhittacitto. Capaloti pattacīvaramaṇḍanādinā
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi  tattha uddhataḥ ti uddhacca yuttaḥ asamāhitaḥ vikkhitta cittaḥ capalaḥ ti patta cīvara maṇḍana ādinā
translated: He uttered these verses.

original: cāpalyena samannāgato lolapakatiko. Mitte āgamma pāpaketi akalyāṇamitte nissāya samaṇadhammaṃ🔽akaronto. Saṃsīdati mahoghasmiṃ, ūmiyā paṭikujjitoti yathā mahāsamudde patitapuriso
analyzed: cāpalyena samannāgataḥ lola pakatikaḥ mitte āgamma pāpake iti akalyāṇa mitte nissāya samaṇa dhammaṃ  a karontaḥ saṃsīdati mahā oghasmin ūmiyā paṭikujjitaḥ iti yathā mahā samudde patita purisaḥ
translated: Herein, excited means possessed of excitement, not concentrated, with his mind scattered. Fickle means given to fickleness, to adorning his bowl and robes, etc., of unsteady nature. Having come to evil friends means having taken up the practice of a recluse with bad friends. He sinks in the great flood,

original: samuddavīcīhi otthaṭo sīsaṃ ukkhipituṃ alabhanto tattheva saṃsīdati, evaṃ saṃsāramahoghasmiṃ🔽paribbhamanto kodhupāyāsaūmiyā paṭikujjito otthaṭo vipassanāvasena paññāsīsaṃ ukkhipituṃ
analyzed: samudda vīcīhi otthaṭaḥ sīsam ukkhipitum a labhanto tattha iva saṃsīdati evam saṃsāra mahā oghasmin  paribbhamantaḥ kodha upāyāsa ūmiyā paṭikujjitaḥ otthaṭaḥ vipassanā vasena paññāsīsam ukkhipitum
translated: like a man in water, his head submerged. Just as a man who has fallen into the great ocean is submerged by the waves of the ocean and is unable to raise his head, so too, wandering in the great flood of saṃsāra,

original: alabhanto tattheva saṃsīdati.
analyzed: a labhantaḥ tattha iva saṃsīdati
translated: submerged by the waves of anger and despair, he is unable to raise the head of insight and sinks right there.

original: Nipakoti nipuṇo, attatthaparatthesu kusalo. Saṃvutindriyoti manacchaṭṭhānaṃ indriyānaṃ🔽saṃvaraṇena pihitindriyo. Kalyāṇamittoti kalyāṇehi mittehi samannāgato. Medhāvīti
analyzed: nipakaḥ iti nipuṇaḥ atta ttha para atthesu kusalaḥ saṃvuti indriyaḥ ti manaccha ṭṭhānam  saṃvaraṇena pihita indriyaḥ kalyāṇa mittaḥ iti kalyāṇehi mittehi samannāgataḥ medhāvī iti
translated: “He is watchful” means he is skillful in his own and others’ welfare. “He is restrained” means he is restrained by the restraint of the six senses.

original: dhammojapaññāya samaṅgībhūto. Dukkhassantakaro siyāti so tādiso sakalassāpi vaṭṭadukkhassa antakaro bhaveyya.
analyzed: dhammoja paññāya samaṅgībhūtaḥ dukkhassa anta karaḥ siyāti saḥ tādisaḥ sakalassa api vaṭṭa dukkhassa anta karaḥ bhaveyya
translated: “He is a good friend” means he is endowed with good friends. “He is wise” means he is endowed with the wisdom of the Dhamma. “He would be the end of suffering” means he would be the end of all the suffering of the round.

original: Kālapabbaṅgasaṅkāsotiādi vivekābhiratikittanaṃ. Nābhinandāmītiādi pana katakiccabhāvadassanaṃ.
analyzed: kāla pabbaṅga saṅkāsaḥ itiādi viveka abhirati kittanam na abhinandāmi itiādi pana kata kicca bhāva dassanam
translated: “Pale as a sea-monster’s cast-off skin” and so on is praise of his delight in solitude. “I do not rejoice” and so on shows that he sees that his work is done.

original: Taṃ sabbaṃ heṭṭhā vuttatthameva. Osāne pana kiṃ me saddhivihārināti attano saddhivihārikaṃ
analyzed: tat sabbam heṭṭhā vutta ttham eva osāne pana kim me saddhivihārinā ati attanaḥ saddhivihārikam
translated: All this has the same meaning as what was said above. But in the conclusion, “What have I to do with a companion?” he is referring to his own companion.

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tasmā edisena dubbacena anādarena saddhivihārinā kiṃ me payojanaṃ
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam tasmai edisena dubbacena anādarena saddhivihārinā kim me payojanam
translated: Therefore the meaning is: “What have I to do with a companion who is so hard to discipline and so disrespectful?

original: ekavihāroyeva mayhaṃ ruccatīti attho.
analyzed: eka vihāro yā iva mayham ruccati iti
translated: I prefer to live alone.”

original: Evaṃ pana vatvā chaddantadahameva gato. Tattha dvādasa vassāni vasitvā upakaṭṭhe parinibbāne satthāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā parinibbānaṃ anujānāpetvā tattheva gantvā parinibbāyi.
analyzed: evam pana vatvā chaddanta daham eva gataḥ tattha dvādasa vassāni vasitvā upakaṭṭhe parinibbāne satthāram upasaṅkamitvā parinibbānam anujānāpetvā tattha eva gantvā parinibbāyi
translated: Having said this, he went to the Chaddanta Elephant. There he lived twelve years. When the time for the Parinibbana of the Buddha drew near, he approached the Teacher, obtained his permission to attain Parinibbana, and then went back to his place and attained Parinibbana.

original: Aññāsikoṇḍaññattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: aññāsikoṇḍañña thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the verses of the Elder Aññāsikoṇḍañña is finished.

original: 2. Udāyittheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: udāyi tthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The verses of the Elder Udāyī

original: Manussabhūtantiādikā āyasmato udāyittherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi purimabuddhesu
analyzed: manussa bhūta nti ādikā āyasmataḥ udāyi ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi purima buddhesu
translated: The verses beginning with the words, “Having been a human being,” were spoken by the Elder Udāyī. What was the origin of these verses? This Elder also rendered service to the Buddhas of the past.

original: katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ puññaṃ upacinitvā devamanussesu
analyzed: kata adhikāraḥ tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭu upanissayam puññam upacinitvā deva manussesu
translated: Here and there, in the course of his round of births, he accumulated merit, and was reborn in the course of his round of births, both among gods and among men.

original: saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde kapilavatthusmiṃ brāhmaṇakule nibbattitvā udāyīti
analyzed: saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde kapilavatthusmim brāhmaṇa kule nibbattitvā udāyi iti
translated: In the dispensation of the present Buddha, he was reborn in the city of Kapilavatthu in the family of a brāhman. He was called Udāyī.

original: laddhanāmo vayappatto satthu ñātisamāgame buddhānubhāvaṃ disvā, paṭiladdhasaddho
analyzed: laddha nāmaḥ vaya pattaḥ satthu ñāti samāgame buddha anubhāvam disvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ
translated: When he had reached years of discretion, he saw the power of the Buddha at the time of the Great Miracle, and obtained faith.

original: pabbajitvā vipassanāya kammaṃ karonto nacirasseva arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Tayo hi ime udāyittherā
analyzed: pabbajitvā vipassanāya kammam karontaḥ nacirassa iva arahattam pāpuṇi tayaḥ hi ime udāyi ttherā
translated: He retired from the world, and in a short time attained Arahatship by the practice of insight. There were three Elders named Udāyī.

original: amaccaputto pubbe āgato kāḷudāyī, kovariyaputto lāludāyī, ayaṃ brāhmaṇaputto mahāudāyīti.
analyzed: amacca putto pubbe āgataḥ kāḷudāyī kovariya putto lāludāyī ayam brāhmaṇa puttaḥ mahāudāyī iti
translated: Kāḷudāyī, the son of a minister, came first; Lāludāyī, the son of a Koliyan, came next; and Mahāudāyī, the son of a brāhmaṇa, came last.

original: Svāyaṃ ekadivasaṃ satthārā setavāraṇaṃ sabbālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ mahājanena pasaṃsiyamānaṃ
analyzed: svāyam eka divasam satthārā seta vāraṇam sabba alaṅkāra paṭimaṇḍitam mahājanena pasaṃsiyamānam
translated: One day the Teacher was riding on a white elephant, which was adorned with all sorts of ornaments and was being praised by the multitude.

original: aṭṭhuppattiṃ katvā nāgopamasuttante desite desanāpariyosāne attano ñāṇabalānurūpaṃ🔽satthu guṇe anussaritvā, buddhārammaṇāya pītiyā samussāhitamānaso “ayaṃ mahājano🔽imaṃ tiracchānagataṃ nāgaṃ pasaṃsati, na buddhamahānāgaṃ. Handāhaṃ buddhamahāgandhahatthino
analyzed: aṭṭhuppattim katvā nāgopama suttante desite desanā pariyosāne attanaḥ ñāṇa bala anurūpam  satthu guṇe anussaritvā buddha ārammaṇāya pītiyā samussāhita mānasaḥ ayam mahājanaḥ  imam tiracchāna gatam nāgam pasaṃsati na buddha mahā nāgam handa aham buddha mahā gandha hatthinaḥ
translated: When the Teacher had related the story of the elephant, and had preached the Law by pronouncing the following Stanzas in the Nāga Sutta,🔽Mahāudāyī, in accordance with the measure of his own understanding,

original: guṇe pākaṭe karissāmī”ti satthāraṃ thomento –
analyzed: guṇe pākaṭe karissāmi iti satthāram thomentaḥ
translated: called to mind the virtues of the Teacher, and filled with joy of heart, which arose in consequence of his meditation upon the Buddha, thought to himself, “This great multitude is praising this beast, an elephant, and not the Great Nāga, the Buddha. Well, then, I will make known the virtues of the Great Nāga, the Buddha, the Great Elephant, the Great Nāga, the Great Man.” And he extolled the Teacher in the following Stanzas,

original: “Manussabhūtaṃ sambuddhaṃ, attadantaṃ samāhitaṃ;
analyzed: manussa bhūtam sambuddham atta dantam samāhitam
translated: “The Self-becoming One, the Supremely Enlightened, who has overcome the lusts, who is self-controlled, who is collected,

original: Iriyamānaṃ brahmapathe, cittassūpasame rataṃ.🔽“Yaṃ manussā namassanti, sabbadhammāna pāraguṃ;
analyzed: iriyamānam brahma pathe ratam  yam manussāḥ namassanti sabba dhammāna pāragum
translated: Who is ever treading the path of the gods, who delights in the tranquillity of mind.

original: Devāpi taṃ namassanti, iti me arahato sutaṃ.
analyzed: devāḥ api tam namassanti iti me arahataḥ sutam
translated: “The gods pay reverence to him whom men revere, who has passed beyond all things that bind. Thus have I heard from the Arahats.

original: “Sabbasaṃyojanātītaṃ, vanā nibbanamāgataṃ;
analyzed: sabba saṃyojana atītam vanā nibbanam āgatam
translated: “He has gone beyond all fetters, has come out of the forest of craving,

original: Kāmehi nekkhammarataṃ, muttaṃ selāva kañcanaṃ.
analyzed: kāmehi nekkhamma ratam muttam kañcanam
translated: and delights in renunciation, free from sense desires, like a golden palm tree.

original: “Sa ve accaruci nāgo, himavāvaññe siluccaye;
analyzed: sa ve acca ruci nāgaḥ himavāvaññe siluccaye
translated: “He is a true Nāga, like the Himalayas, the king of mountains,

original: Sabbesaṃ nāganāmānaṃ, saccanāmo anuttaro.
analyzed: sabbesam nāga nāmānam sacca nāmaḥ anuttaraḥ
translated: and of all the names of Nāgas, the name ‘Truthful’ is unsurpassed.

original: “Nāgaṃ vo kittayissāmi, na hi āguṃ karoti so;
analyzed: nāgam vaḥ kittayissāmi na hi āgum karoti saḥ
translated: “I will extol the Nāga for you, for he does not commit offenses.

original: Soraccaṃ avihiṃsā ca, pādā nāgassa te duve.
analyzed: soraccam avihiṃsā ca pādā nāgassa te duve
translated: Gentleness and harmlessness are his two feet.

original: “Sati ca sampajaññañca, caraṇā nāgassa tepare;
analyzed: sati ca caraṇāḥ nāgassa te pare
translated: “Mindfulness and clear comprehension are his two other feet.

original: Saddhāhattho mahānāgo, upekkhāsetadantavā.
analyzed: saddhā hatthaḥ mahā nāgaḥ upekkhā seta dantavā
translated: The great Nāga has faith for his trunk and equanimity for his tusks.

original: “Sati gīvā siro paññā, vīmaṃsā dhammacintanā;
analyzed: sati gīvā siro paññā vīmaṃsā dhamma cintanā
translated: “Mindfulness is his neck, wisdom is his head, investigation is his thought on the Dhamma,

original: Dhammakucchisamāvāso, viveko tassa vāladhi.
analyzed: dhammakucchi samāvāsaḥ vivekaḥ tassa vāladhi
translated: and his dwelling is in the Dhamma-womb, and seclusion is his tail.

original: “So jhāyī assāsarato, ajjhattaṃ susamāhito;
analyzed: so jhāyī assa asarataḥ ajjhattam su samāhitaḥ
translated: “He is a meditator, delighting in the unconditioned, well-concentrated within,

original: Gacchaṃ samāhito nāgo, ṭhito nāgo samāhito.
analyzed: gaccham samāhitaḥ nāgaḥ ṭhitaḥ nāgaḥ samāhitaḥ
translated: going, standing, or sitting, the Nāga is concentrated.

original: “Sayaṃ samāhito nāgo, nisinnopi samāhito;
analyzed: sayam samāhitaḥ nāgaḥ nisinnaḥ upi samāhitaḥ
translated: “The Nāga is concentrated when lying down, and also when sitting,

original: Sabbattha saṃvuto nāgo, esā nāgassa sampadā.
analyzed: sabbattha saṃvutaḥ nāgaḥ esā nāgassa sampadā
translated: and everywhere the Nāga is restrained: this is the perfection of the Nāga.

original: “Bhuñjati anavajjāni, sāvajjāni na bhuñjati;
analyzed: bhuñjati anavajjāni sāvajjāni na bhuñjati
translated: “He eats what is blameless, not what is blameworthy,

original: Ghāsamacchādanaṃ laddhā, sannidhiṃ parivajjayaṃ.
analyzed: ghāsam acchādanam laddhā sannidhim parivajjayam
translated: Having received food and clothing, avoid hoarding.

original: “Saṃyojanaṃ aṇuṃ thūlaṃ, sabbaṃ chetvāna bandhanaṃ;
analyzed: saṃyojanam aṇum thūlam sabbam chetvāna bandhanam
translated: Having cut off all bonds, whether gross or subtle,

original: Yena yeneva gacchati, anapekkhova gacchati.
analyzed: yena yena iva gacchati anapekkhaḥ uva gacchati
translated: Wherever he goes, he goes without concern.

original: “Yathāpi udake jātaṃ, puṇḍarīkaṃ pavaḍḍhati;
analyzed: yathā api udake jātam puṇḍarīkam pavaḍḍhati
translated: Just as a lotus, born in the water, grows up out of the water,

original: Nopalippati toyena, sucigandhaṃ manoramaṃ.
analyzed: na upalippati toyena suci gandham manoramam
translated: And though it is in the water, the water does not stick to it, fragrant and lovely,

original: “Tatheva ca loke jāto, buddho loke viharati;🔽Nopalippati lokena, toyena padumaṃ yathā.
analyzed: tathā iva ca loke jātaḥ buddhaḥ loke viharati  na upalippati lokena toyena padumam yathā
translated: So too the Buddha, born in the world, dwells in the world,🔽But is not stained by the world, just as the water does not stick to the lotus.

original: “Mahāgini pajjalito, anāhāropasammati;
analyzed: pajjalitaḥ
translated: Just as a great fire, blazing,

original: Aṅgāresu ca santesu, nibbutoti pavuccati.
analyzed: aṅgāresu ca santesu nibbutaḥ iti pavuccati
translated: When the fuel is exhausted, is extinguished,

original: “Atthassāyaṃ viññāpanī, upamā viññūhi desitā;
analyzed: atthassa ayam viññāpanī upamā viññūhi desitā
translated: This is the simile taught by the wise to illustrate the meaning,

original: Viññissanti mahānāgā, nāgaṃ nāgena desitaṃ.
analyzed: viññissanti mahā nāgāḥ nāgam nāgena desitam
translated: The great seers will understand the seer taught by the seer.

original: “Vītarāgo vītadoso, vītamoho anāsavo;
analyzed: vīta rāgaḥ vīta dosaḥ vīta mohaḥ anāsavaḥ
translated: Free from passion, free from hatred, free from delusion, without defilements,🔽The seer will lay down his body, and will attain final Nibbana without clinging.

original: Sarīraṃ vijahaṃ nāgo, parinibbissatyanāsavo”ti. – imā gāthā abhāsi;
analyzed: sarīram vijaham nāgaḥ parinibbissati anāsavaḥ ti imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: These verses were spoken.

original: Tattha manussabhūtanti manussesu bhūtaṃ, nibbattaṃ; manussattabhāvaṃ vā pattaṃ. Satthā
analyzed: tattha manussa bhūtam ti manussesu bhūtam nibbattam manussa atta bhāvam vā pattam satthā
translated: Herein, he was born among men means he was born among men, he was reborn, or he attained the state of being a man. The Teacher

original: hi āsavakkhayañāṇādhigamena sabbagativimuttopi carimattabhāve gahitapaṭisandhivasena
analyzed: hi āsava kkhaya ñāṇa adhigamena sabba gati vimuttaḥ api carimatta bhāve gahita paṭisandhi vasena
translated: For although he was completely liberated from all destinations by the attainment of the knowledge of the destruction of the taints, he was still called a “man” in the last existence he had taken rebirth in.

original: “manusso”tveva voharīyatīti. Guṇavasena pana devānaṃ atidevo, brahmānaṃ atibrahmā.🔽Sambuddhanti sayameva bujjhitabbabuddhavantaṃ. Attadantanti attanāyeva dantaṃ. Bhagavā
analyzed: manuḥ sotvā iva voharīyati iti guṇa vasena pana devānam atidevaḥ brahmānam atibrahmā  sambuddham ti sayam eva bujjhitabba buddhavantam atta dantam iti attanāya iva dantam bhagavā
translated: But in terms of his special qualities he was a god above the gods, a Brahmā above the Brahmas.🔽Enlightened: possessed of the knowledge that can be called “enlightened” because it is the knowledge of one who has awakened by himself.🔽Self-tamed: tamed by means of the noble path that he himself has produced.

original: hi attanāyeva uppāditena ariyamaggena cakkhutopi…pe… manatopi uttamena damathena🔽danto. Samāhitanti aṭṭhavidhena samādhinā maggaphalasamādhinā ca samāhitaṃ. Iriyamānaṃ
analyzed: hi attanāya iva uppāditena ariya maggena cakkhutaḥ pipe manataḥ pi uttamena damathena  danto samāhitanti aṭṭhavidhena samādhinā magga phala samādhinā ca samāhitam iriyamānam
translated: For the Blessed One is tamed by the highest taming, namely, by the path and fruit of arahantship.🔽Concentrated: concentrated by means of the eight meditative concentrations and the concentration of the path and fruit.

original: brahmapatheti catubbidhepi brahmavihārapathe, brahme vā seṭṭhe phalasamāpattipathe🔽samāpajjanavasena pavattamānaṃ. Kiñcāpi bhagavā na sabbakālaṃ yathāvutte brahmapathe
analyzed: brahma patha iti catubbidhe api brahmavihāra pathe brahme vā seṭṭhe phala samāpatti pathe  samāpajjana vasena pavattamānam kiñca api bhagavā na sabbakālam yathā vutte brahmapathe
translated: Practising the divine abidings: practising the four divine abidings, or the divine abiding that is the highest, namely, the attainment of fruition concentration.

original: iriyati, tattha iriyasāmatthiyaṃ pana tanninnatañca upādāya “iriyamāna”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: iriyati tattha iriya sāmatthiyam pana tad ninna tañca upādāya iriyamānanti vuttam
translated: Although the Blessed One did not always practise the divine abidings in the way described, still he is said to “practise” them because he is capable of doing so and because he is devoted to them.

original: Cittassūpasame ratanti cittassa upasamahetubhūte sabbasaṅkhārasamathe, nibbāne, abhirataṃ.
analyzed: cittassa upasame ratanti cittassa upasama hetu bhūte sabba saṅkhāra samathe nibbāne abhiratam
translated: “Delights in the stilling of the mind”: delights in the stilling of the mind, which is the cause for the stilling of the mind, in the stilling of all formations, in Nibbāna.

original: Yaṃ manussā namassanti, sabbadhammāna pāragunti yaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ sabbesaṃ khandhāyatanādidhammānaṃ
analyzed: yam manussāḥ namassanti sabba dhammāna pāragunti yam sammāsambuddham sabbesam khandha āyatana ādi dhammānam
translated: “Whom men revere, the one who has gone beyond all things”: whom men, the wise khattiyas, etc., revere.🔽The one who has gone beyond all things, who has gone beyond in six ways, who has gone beyond the six kinds of excellence, namely, the excellence of direct knowledge, the excellence of full understanding, the excellence of abandoning, the excellence of realization, the excellence of developing, and the excellence of entering upon ;

original: abhiññāpāragū, pariññāpāragū, pahānapāragū, bhāvanāpāragū, sacchikiriyapāragū, samāpattipāragūti🔽chadhā pāraguṃ paramukkaṃsagatasampattiṃ khattiyapaṇḍitādayo manussā namassanti.
analyzed: abhiññā pāragū pariññā pāragū pahāna pāragū bhāvanā pāragū sacchikiriya pāragū samāpatti pāragū ti  chadhā pāragum param ukkaṃsa gata sampattim khattiya paṇḍita ādayaḥ manussāḥ namassanti
translated: who has gone beyond, who has gone to the other side, who has gone to the further shore.

original: Dhammānudhammapaṭipattiyā pūjentā kāyena vācāya manasā ca tanninnā tappoṇā tappabbhārā🔽honti. Devāpi taṃ namassantīti na kevalaṃ manussā eva, atha kho aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu
analyzed: dhamma anudhamma paṭipattiyā pūjentā kāyena vācāya manasā ca tad ninnā tad poṇā tad pabbhārā  honti devāḥ api tam namassanti iti na kevalam manussāḥ eva atha kho aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu
translated: “Honouring him with thoughts of love”: honouring him with thoughts of love, with thoughts of loving-kindness, with thoughts of love and kindness, with thoughts of love and sympathy, with thoughts of love and help, with thoughts of love and protection, with thoughts of love and caring, with thoughts of love and cherishing, with thoughts of love and affection, with thoughts of love and devotion.🔽“The gods revere him too”: not only men, but also the gods in the innumerable world systems

original: devāpi taṃ namassanti. Iti me arahato sutanti evaṃ mayā ārakattādīhi kāraṇehi arahato,
analyzed: devāḥ api tam namassanti iti me arahataḥ sutanti evam mayā ārakatta ādīhi kāraṇehi arahataḥ

He who has the tusks of equanimity, which is purified perception distinguished by knowledge, is the one “with the tusks of equanimity” .

original: Uttamaṅgaṃ paññā, tassā adhiṭṭhānaṃ satīti āha “sati gīvā siro paññā”ti. Vīmaṃsā
analyzed: uttamaṅgam paññā tassāḥ adhiṭṭhānam satī iti āha sati gīvā siro paññā ati vīmaṃsā
translated: Wisdom is the head, and its basis is mindfulness, so it is said: “The neck is mindfulness, the head is wisdom” .

original: dhammacintanāti yathā khāditabbākhāditabbassa soṇḍāya parāmasanaṃ ghāyanañca hatthināgassa
analyzed: dhamma cintanā ati yathā khāditabba a khāditabbassa soṇḍāya parāmasanam ghāyanam ca hatthi nāgassa
translated: The investigation of dhammas is the thought of dhammas such as the profitable, etc. Just as the elephant’s trunk is used for seizing what is to be eaten and for smelling,

original: vīmaṃsā nāma hoti, evaṃ buddhanāgassa kusalādidhammacintanā vīmaṃsā. Samā vasanti
analyzed: vīmaṃsā nāma hoti evam buddha nāgassa kusala ādi dhamma cintanā vīmaṃsā samāḥ vasanti
translated: so the Buddha-elephant’s investigation of dhammas is the thought of dhammas such as the profitable, etc.

original: etthāti, samāvāso, bhājanaṃ kucchi eva samāvāso, abhiññāsamathānaṃ ādhānabhāvato

analyzed: samatha vipassanā saṅkhāto dhammo kucchi samāvāso etassa ati dhamma kucchi samāvāsaḥ viveko ti  upadhi viveko tassa ati buddha nāgassa vāladhi pariyosāna aṅga bhāvato  jhāyī iti ārammaṇa upanijjhānena ca jhāyana sīlo assāsa rataḥ ti parama ssāsa bhūte nibbāne  rataḥ ajjhattam su samāhitaḥ ti visaya jjhatte phala samāpattiyam suṭṭhu samāhitaḥ tat idam
translated: The Dhamma called serenity and insight is the “womb” of this one, thus he is “one who has the Dhamma as his womb.” “Seclusion” is

original: samādhānaṃ suṭṭhu sabbakālikanti dassetuṃ “gacchaṃ samāhito nāgo”tiādi vuttaṃ. Bhagavā🔽hi savāsanassa uddhaccassa pahīnattā vikkhepābhāvato niccaṃ samāhitova. Tasmā yaṃ
analyzed: samādhānam suṭṭhu sabba kālikanti dassetum gaccham samāhitaḥ nāgaḥ tiādi vuttam bhagavā  hi sa vāsanassa uddhaccassa pahīna ttā vikkhepa abhāvataḥ niccam samāhitaḥ uva tasmai yaṃ
translated: the seclusion from acquisitions. “The end” is the end of the path. “The tip” is the tip of the path. “The Buddha-elephant” is the Buddha, the elephant of a Buddha. “The one who delights in the forest” is the one who delights in the forest of jhana. “The meditator” is the one who has the habit of meditating by fixing his attention on an object. “The one who delights in the highest bliss” is the one who delights in nibbana, which is the highest bliss. “Well concentrated within” is well concentrated in the fruition attainment, which is the object within. original: yaṃ iriyāpathaṃ kappeti, taṃ taṃ samāhitova kappesīti.
analyzed: yam iriyāpatham kappeti tam tam samāhitaḥ uva kappesi iti
translated: For the Blessed One is always concentrated, without distraction, because he has abandoned agitation together with its underlying tendencies. Therefore he performs whatever posture he wishes to perform while remaining concentrated.

original: Sabbatthāti, sabbasmiṃ gocare, sabbasmiñca dvāre sabbaso pihitavutti. Tenāha – “sabbaṃ
analyzed: sabbattha iti sabbasmin gocare sabbasmin ca dvāre sabbaso pihita vutti tena āha sabbam
translated: “Everywhere” means in all resorts and in all doors of activity. He is “one who keeps his conduct well restrained” in all ways. Therefore it is said:🔽“The elephant of concentration goes,

original: kāyakammaṃ ñāṇapubbaṅgamaṃ ñāṇānuparivatta”ntiādi. Esā nāgassa sampadāti esā “na
analyzed: kāya kammam ñāṇa pubbaṅgamam ñāṇa anuparivattanti ādi esā nāgassa sampadā ati esā na
translated: “Bodily action has knowledge as its forerunner, knowledge as its companion, and knowledge as its outcome” .

original: hi āguṃ karoti so”tiādinā “sambuddha”ntiādinā eva vā yathāvuttā vakkhamānā ca buddhagandhahatthino
analyzed: hi āgum karoti saḥ iti ādinā sambuddha iti ādinā eva vā yathā vuttā ca buddha gandha hatthino
translated: This is the elephant’s perfection: this is the perfection of the Buddha-elephant described above and to be described in the passage beginning “He does not go by night” and ending “The Enlightened One” .

original: sampatti guṇaparipuṇṇā.
analyzed: sampatti guṇa paripuṇṇā
translated: It is the fulfilment of his special qualities.

original: Bhuñjati anavajjānīti sammājīvassa ukkaṃsapāramippattiyā bhuñjati agarahitabbāni,
analyzed: bhuñjati anavajjāni iti sammājīvassa ukkaṃsa pārami pattiyā bhuñjati a garahitabbāni
translated: He eats what is blameless: he eats what is not to be blamed, what is excellent, in the attainment of the perfection of right livelihood.

original: micchājīvassa sabbaso savāsanānañca pahīnattā sāvajjāni garahitabbāni na bhuñjati
analyzed: micchājīvassa sabbaso sa vāsanānam ca pahīna ttā sāvajjāni garahitabbāni na bhuñjati
translated: He does not eat what is blameful, what is to be blamed, because he has abandoned wrong livelihood together with its underlying tendencies.

analyzed: anavajjāni ca sannidhim bhuñjati iti yojanā  saṃyojananti vaṭṭa dukkhena saddhim santānam saṃyojanataḥ vaṭṭe osīdāpana samattham
translated: And the construction of the sentence is: “Eating what is blameless, he eats avoiding hoarding.”🔽Fetters: the ten fetters, which are capable of causing beings to sink in the round of rebirths together with the suffering of the round.

original: dasavidhampi saṃyojanaṃ. Aṇuṃ thūlanti khuddakañceva mahantañca. Sabbaṃ chetvāna
analyzed: dasavidham pi saṃyojanam aṇum thūlanti khuddakam ca iva mahantam ca sabbam chetvāna
translated: Small and great: both the minor and the major.🔽Having cut off all: having cut off all the fetters without exception.

original: bandhananti maggañāṇena anavasesaṃ kilesabandhanaṃ chinditvā. Yena yenāti yena yena disābhāgena.
analyzed: bandhanam ti magga ñāṇena anavasesam kilesa bandhanam chinditvā yena yena ati yena yena disā bhāgena
translated: By whatever direction: by whatever direction.

original: Yathā hi udake jātaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ udake pavaḍḍhati nopalippati toyena, anupalepasabhāvattā,
analyzed: yathā hi udake jātam puṇḍarīkam udake pavaḍḍhati na upalippati toyena an upalepa sabhāvat tā
translated: Just as a lotus born in the water and growing in the water, reaches up above the water’s surface and stands unsullied by the water, because of its nature to be unsoiled,

original: tatheva loke jāto buddho loke viharati, nopalippati lokena taṇhādiṭṭhimānalepābhāvatoti yojanā.
analyzed: tathā iva loke jātaḥ buddhaḥ loke viharati na upalippati lokena taṇhā diṭṭhi māna lepa abhāvataḥ iti yojanā
translated: so too the Buddha, born in the world and living in the world, stands unsullied by the world, because of the absence of defilements such as craving and views.

original: Ginīti aggi. Anāhāroti anindhano.🔽Atthassāyaṃ viññāpanīti satthu guṇasaṅkhātassa upameyyatthassa viññāpanī, pakāsanī
analyzed: aggi anāhāraḥ iti anindhanaḥ  atthassa ayam viññāpanī iti satthu guṇa saṅkhātassa upameyyatthassa viññāpanī pakāsanī
translated: “Fire” is the same as “ginī.” “Without fuel” means without craving.🔽“This is the one that points out the meaning”: this is the simile of the elephant, which points out, which makes known, the meaning to be illustrated, namely, the qualities of the Teacher.

original: ayaṃ nāgūpamā. Viññūhīti satthu paṭividdhacatusaccadhammaṃ parijānantehi attānaṃ🔽sandhāya vadati. Viññissantītiādi kāraṇavacanaṃ, yasmā nāgena mayā desitaṃ nāgaṃ
analyzed: ayam nāga upamā viññūhi iti satthu paṭividdha catu sacca dhammam parijānantehi attānam  sandhāya vadati viññissanti itiādi kāraṇavacanam yasmā nāgena mayā desitam nāgam
translated: “The wise” refers to those who have penetrated the Four Noble Truths and fully understood the Dhamma.

original: tathāgatagandhahatthiṃ mahānāgā khīṇāsavā attano visaye ṭhatvā vijānissanti, tasmā
analyzed: tathāgata gandhahatthim mahā nāgā khīṇa āsavāḥ attanaḥ visaye ṭhatvā vijānissanti tasmai
translated: “The wise will understand” and so forth are the reasons. Because the elephant taught by me, the Tathāgata’s fragrant elephant, the great elephant, will be understood by those with defilements exhausted, who abide within their own domain,

original: aññesaṃ puthujjanānaṃ ñāpanatthaṃ ayaṃ upamā amhehi bhāsitāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: aññesam puthujjanānam ñāpana attham ayam upamā amhehi bhāsitā ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: therefore, the intention is that this simile is spoken by us for the purpose of making known to others, to ordinary people.

original: Sarīraṃ vijahaṃ nāgo, parinibbissatyanāsavoti bodhimūle saupādisesaparinibbānena🔽anāsavo sammāsambuddhanāgo, idāni sarīraṃ attabhāvaṃ vijahanto khandhaparinibbānena parinibbāyissatīti.
analyzed: sarīram vijaham nāgaḥ parinibbissati anāsavaḥ ti bodhimūle sa aupādisesa parinibbānena  anāsavaḥ sammāsambuddha nāgaḥ idāni sarīram atta bhāvam vijahantaḥ khandha parinibbānena parinibbāyissati iti
translated: At the foot of the Bodhi Tree, the Naga, the Perfectly Enlightened One, without residue of clinging, attained extinction with residue of clinging.🔽Now, renouncing his body, his personality, he will attain extinction with the extinction of the aggregates.

original: Evaṃ cuddasahi upamāhi maṇḍetvā, soḷasahi gāthāhi, catusaṭṭhiyā pādehi satthu guṇe vaṇṇento anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā desanaṃ niṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: evam cuddasahi upamāhi maṇḍetvā soḷasahi gāthāhi catusaṭṭhiyā pādehi satthu guṇe vaṇṇento anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā desanam niṭṭhāpesi
translated: Having thus adorned the Teacher with fourteen similes, and having extolled his virtues in sixteen stanzas, in sixty-four lines, he concluded his discourse on the element of extinction without residue of clinging.

original: Udāyittheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: udāyi tthera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Udāyī is finished.

original: Soḷasakanipātavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: soḷasaka nipāta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Section of Sixteens is finished.

original: 16. Vīsatinipāto🔽1. Adhimuttattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: vīsati nipātaḥ  adhimutta thera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: . The Twentieth Section🔽. The Verses of the Elder Adhimutta

original: Vīsatinipāte yaññatthaṃ vātiādikā āyasmato aparassa adhimuttattherassa gāthā. Kā
analyzed: vīsati nipāte yaññattham vāti ādikā āyasmataḥ aparassa adhimutta therassa gāthā kā
translated: In the Twentieth Section, the first stanza, “For the sake of sacrifice,” etc., is the stanza of the Elder Adhimutta.

original: uppatti? Ayampi purimabuddhesu katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinanto
analyzed: uppatti ayam pi purima buddhesu kata adhikāraḥ tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinanto
translated: What is the origin of the story? This Elder also performed meritorious deeds in the past under former Buddhas, and accumulating merit here and there,

original: atthadassissa bhagavato kāle vibhavasampanne kule nibbattitvā viññutaṃ patto satthari
analyzed: atthadassissa bhagavataḥ kāle vibhava sampanne kule nibbattitvā viññu tam patto satthari
translated: was reborn in a wealthy family in the dispensation of the Blessed One Atthadassī. Having attained maturity, he

original: parinibbute bhikkhusaṅghaṃ upaṭṭhahanto mahādānāni pavattesi. So tena puññakammena
analyzed: parinibbute bhikkhu saṅgham upaṭṭhahantaḥ mahādānāni pavattesi saḥ tena puñña kammena
translated: and after the Master’s Parinibbana he looked after the Community of Bhikkhus and gave great gifts.

original: devamanussesu saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde āyasmato saṃkiccattherassa bhaginiyā🔽kucchimhi nibbatti, adhimuttotissa nāmaṃ ahosi. So vayappatto mātulattherassa santike
analyzed: deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde āyasmataḥ saṃkicca ttherassa bhaginiyā  kucchimhi nibbatti adhimuttaḥ tissa nāmam ahosi saḥ vaya pattaḥ mātula ttherassa santike
translated: By that meritorious deed he passed from one happy state of existence to another and in this generation of the Buddha he was conceived in the womb of the Elder Saṅkicca’s sister.

original: pabbajitvā vipassanāya kammaṃ karonto sāmaṇerabhūmiyaṃyeva ṭhito arahattaṃ pāpuṇi.
analyzed: pabbajitvā vipassanāya kammam karonto sāmaṇera bhūmiyam yā iva ṭhitaḥ arahattam pāpuṇi
translated: When he was old enough he went forth into homelessness in the presence of his maternal uncle and while he was still a novice he reached Arahantship by doing the meditation subject.

original: Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: tena vuttam apadāne
translated: As it is said in the Apadana:

original: “Nibbute lokanāthamhi, atthadassīnaruttame;
analyzed: nibbute lokanāthamhi attha dassī naruttame
translated: “When the Lord of the World, the Best of Visionary Sages, had passed away,

original: Upaṭṭhahiṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ, vippasannena cetasā.
analyzed: upaṭṭhahim bhikkhu saṅgham vippasannena cetasā
translated: I looked after the Community of Bhikkhus with a serene mind.

original: “Nimantetvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ, ujubhūtaṃ samāhitaṃ;
analyzed: nimantetvā bhikkhu saṅgham uju bhūtam samāhitam
translated: “Having invited the Community of Bhikkhus, upright and composed,

original: Ucchunā maṇḍapaṃ katvā, bhojesiṃ saṅghamuttamaṃ.
analyzed: ucchunā maṇḍapam katvā bhojesim saṅgham uttamam
translated: I had a pavilion built and fed the Supreme Community.

original: “Yaṃ yaṃ yonupapajjāmi, devattaṃ athamānusaṃ;
analyzed: yam yam devattam
translated: “Wherever I was reborn, whether as a god or a human being,

original: Sabbe satte abhibhomi, puññakammassidaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: sabbe satte abhibhomi puñña kammassa idam phalam
translated: I was the chief of all beings: this was the fruit of my meritorious deed.

original: “Aṭṭhārase kappasate, yaṃ dānamadadiṃ tadā;
analyzed: aṭṭhārase kappa sate yam dānam adadim tadā
translated: “For eighteen hundred kalpas I enjoyed the fruit of that gift,

original: Duggatiṃ nābhijānāmi, ucchudānassidaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: duggatim na abhijānāmi ucchudānaḥ idam phalam
translated: I do not know of any bad destination, this is the fruit of the giving of food.

original: “Paṭisambhidā catasso…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: paṭisambhidā katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: The four analytical knowledges… the Buddha’s instruction has been accomplished.”

original: Arahattaṃ pana patvā samāpattisukhena vītināmento upasampajjitukāmo “mātaraṃ āpucchissāmī”ti
analyzed: arahattam pana patvā samāpatti sukhena vītināmentaḥ upasampajjitu kāmaḥ mātaram āpucchissāmi iti
translated: But after attaining Liberation, while passing the time with the happiness of attainment, he thought: “I will inform my mother.”

original: mātu santikaṃ gacchanto antarāmagge devatāya balikammakaraṇatthaṃ maṃsapariyesanaṃ
analyzed: mātu santikam gacchantaḥ antarāmagge devatāya bali kamma karaṇa attham maṃsa pariyesanam
translated: While going to his mother, on the way he met with five hundred thieves who were searching for meat

original: carantehi pañcasatehi corehi samāgacchi. Corā ca taṃ aggahesuṃ “devatāya bali bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: carantehi pañcasatehi corehi samāgacchi corā ca tam aggahesum devatāya bali bhavissati iti
translated: to make an offering to a deity. The thieves seized him, thinking: “He will be the offering to the deity.”

original: So corehi gahitopi abhīto acchambhī vippasannamukhova aṭṭhāsi. Taṃ disvā coragāmaṇiacchariyabbhutacittajāto pasaṃsanto –
analyzed: so corehi gahitaḥ api abhītaḥ acchambhī vippasanna mukhaḥ iva aṭṭhāsi tam disvā cora gāmaṇi acchariya bbhuta citta jātaḥ pasaṃsanto
translated: Even though he was seized by the thieves, he stood there fearless, confident, with a clear face. Seeing him, the leader of the thieves, his mind amazed and astonished, praised him, saying:

original: “Yaññatthaṃ vā dhanatthaṃ vā, ye hanāma mayaṃ pure;
analyzed: yaññattham vā dhanattham vā ye hanāma mayam pure
translated: “For the sake of a sacrifice or for the sake of wealth, in the past we killed

original: Avasesaṃ bhayaṃ hoti, vedhanti vilapanti ca.
analyzed: avasesam bhayam hoti vedhanti vilapanti ca
translated: and there was fear left over, they were wounded and they cried out.

original: “Tassa te natthi bhītattaṃ, bhiyyo vaṇṇo pasīdati;
analyzed: tassa te natthi bhītattam bhiyyaḥ vaṇṇaḥ pasīdati
translated: “For you there is no fear, your beauty shines forth even more;

analyzed: kasmā na paridevesi evarūpe mahat bhaya iti dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Why do you not lament, When such a great fear has come?

original: Tattha yaññatthanti yajanatthaṃ devatānaṃ balikammakaraṇatthaṃ vā. Vā-saddo vikappanattho.
analyzed: tattha yañña ttham ti yajana attham devatānam bali kamma karaṇa ttham vā vā saddaḥ vikappana tthaḥ
translated: Herein, for sacrifice means for the purpose of sacrificing, or for the purpose of making offerings to deities. The word vā has the meaning of vikappana .

original: Dhanatthanti sāpateyyaharaṇatthaṃ. Ye hanāma mayaṃ pureti ye satte mayaṃ pubbe hanimha.
analyzed: dhanattham ti sāpateyya haraṇa attham ye hanāma mayam purā iti ye satte mayam pubbe hanimha
translated: For the sake of wealth means for the purpose of taking away their property. Those whom we formerly killed means those beings whom we formerly killed.🔽For this is a present-tense expression in the sense of the past.

original: Atītatthe hi idaṃ vattamānavacanaṃ. Avaseti avase aserike katvā. Tanti tesaṃ. “Avasesanti”pi
analyzed: atīta atthe hi idam vattamāna vacanam avasā iti avase katvā tanti tesam
translated: Having spared means having left over. Them means those .🔽They also read avasesanti .

original: paṭhanti. Amhehi gahitesu taṃ ekaṃ ṭhapetvā avasesānaṃ; ayameva vā pāṭho. Bhayaṃ
analyzed: paṭhanti amhehi gahitesu tam ekam ṭhapetvā ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ bhayam
translated: Having taken some of them, having left over the rest; or this is the reading.🔽Fear comes means the fear of death comes.

original: hotīti maraṇabhayaṃ hoti. Yena te vedhanti vilapanti,cittutrāsena vedhanti, “sāmi,
analyzed: maraṇa bhayam yena te vedhanti vilapanti cittu trāsena vedhanti sāmi
translated: By which they are pierced and lament. They are pierced by the fear in their hearts. They lament, saying: “Sir,

original: tumhākaṃ idañcidañca dassāma, dāsā bhavissāmā”tiādikaṃ vadantā vilapanti.
analyzed: tumhākam idam ca idam ca dassāma dāsāḥ bhavissāma ati ādikam vadantāḥ vilapanti
translated: we will give you this and that, we will be your slaves,” and so on.

original: Tassa teti yo tvaṃ amhehi devatāya balikammatthaṃ jīvitā voropetukāmehi ukkhittāsikehi
analyzed: tassa te iti yaḥ tvam amhehi devatāya bali kamma attham jīvitā voropetu kāmehi ukkhitta asikehi
translated: Because of that, they

original: santajjito, tassa te. Bhītattanti bhītabhāvo, bhayanti attho. Bhiyyo vaṇṇo pasīdatīti
analyzed: santajjito tassa te bhītattanti bhīta bhāvaḥ bhayanti atthaḥ bhiyyaḥ vaṇṇo pasīdati iti
translated: “You are frightened, and your face is pale.”🔽The meaning is that he is afraid.🔽“Your face is even more radiant than before.”

original: pakativaṇṇato uparipi te mukhavaṇṇo vippasīdati. Therassa kira tadā “sace ime māressanti,
analyzed: pakati vaṇṇataḥ upari pi te mukha vaṇṇaḥ vippasīdati therassa kira tadā sace ime māressanti
translated: The Elder’s thought was: “If they kill me,🔽I shall attain final Nibbāna without clinging. The burden will be dropped.”

original: idānevāhaṃ anupādāya parinibbāyissāmi, dukkhabhāro vigacchissatī”ti uḷāraṃ pītisomanassaṃ
analyzed: idānā iva aham an upādāya parinibbāyissāmi dukkha bhāraḥ vigacchissati iti uḷāram pīti somanassam
translated: He experienced a sublime joy and happiness.🔽“In the presence of such a great fear” means: in the presence of such a great fear of death.

original: uppajji. Evarūpe mahabbhayeti edise mahati maraṇabhaye upaṭṭhite. Hetuatthe vā etaṃ bhummavacanaṃ.
analyzed: uppajji evarūpe mahat bhayā iti edise mahati maraṇa bhaye upaṭṭhite hetu atthe vā etam bhumma vacanam
translated: Or this is a locative of cause: “In the presence of such a great fear of death as this.”

original: Idāni thero coragāmaṇissa paṭivacanadānamukhena dhammaṃ desento –
analyzed: idāni thero coragāmaṇissa paṭivacana dāna mukhena dhammaṃ desento
translated: Now the Elder, in the manner of one who gives a reply, taught the Dhamma to the robber chief with the verse:

original: “Natthi cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ, anapekkhassa gāmaṇi;
analyzed: natthi cetasikam dukkham an apekkhassa gāmaṇi
translated: “There is no mental suffering, chief, for one who is free from expectation;

original: Atikkantā bhayā sabbe, khīṇasaṃyojanassa ve.
analyzed: atikkantā bhayā sabbe khīṇa saṃyojanassa ve
translated: All fears are transcended for one whose fetters are destroyed.

original: “Khīṇāya bhavanettiyā, diṭṭhe dhamme yathātathe;
analyzed: khīṇāya bhava nettiyā diṭṭhe dhamme yathātathe
translated: “When the round of births is ended, and the true Dhamma is seen,

original: Na bhayaṃ maraṇe hoti, bhāranikkhepane yathā.
analyzed: na bhayam maraṇe hoti bhāra nikkhepane yathā
translated: There is no fear of death, as when a burden is laid down.”

original: “Suciṇṇaṃ brahmacariyaṃ me, maggo cāpi subhāvito;
analyzed: su ciṇṇam brahmacariyam me maggaḥ ca api su bhāvito
translated: “The holy life has been lived by me, and the path has been well developed;

original: Maraṇe me bhayaṃ natthi, rogānamiva saṅkhaye.
analyzed: maraṇe me bhayam saṅkhaye
translated: I have no fear of death, as if diseases were to be destroyed.

original: “Suciṇṇaṃ brahmacariyaṃ me, maggo cāpi subhāvito;
analyzed: su ciṇṇam brahmacariyam me maggaḥ ca api su bhāvito
translated: I have well practiced the spiritual life, and the path has been well developed.

original: Nirassādā bhavā diṭṭhā, visaṃ pitvāva chaḍḍitaṃ.
analyzed: nirassādā bhavā diṭṭhā visam pitvā ava chaḍḍitam
translated: The worlds have been seen to be without essence, like poison that has been discarded.

original: “Pāragū anupādāno, katakicco anāsavo;
analyzed: pāragū an upādānaḥ kata kiccaḥ an āsavaḥ
translated: Having gone beyond, without clinging, having done what had to be done, being without defilements,

original: Tuṭṭho āyukkhayā hoti, mutto āghātanā yathā.
analyzed: tuṭṭhaḥ āyu khayā hoti muttaḥ āghātanā yathā
translated: he is satisfied at the end of life, as if released from a murder charge.

original: “Uttamaṃ dhammataṃ patto, sabbaloke anatthiko;
analyzed: uttamam dhamma tam pattaḥ sabba loke anatthikaḥ
translated: Having attained the supreme state of the Dhamma, not seeking anything in the whole world,

original: Ādittāva gharā mutto, maraṇasmiṃ na socati.
analyzed: muttaḥ maraṇasmin na socati
translated: as if released from a burning house, he does not grieve over death.

original: “Yadatthi saṅgataṃ kiñci, bhavo vā yattha labbhati;
analyzed: yat atthi saṅgatam kiñci bhavaḥ vā yattha labbhati
translated: Whatever is connected, whatever existence is obtained,

original: Sabbaṃ anissaraṃ etaṃ, iti vuttaṃ mahesinā.
analyzed: sabbam anissaram etam iti vuttam mahesinā
translated: all of this is without escape, so it was said by the Great Sage.

original: “Yo taṃ tathā pajānāti, yathā buddhena desitaṃ;
analyzed: yaḥ tam tathā pajānāti yathā buddhena desitam
translated: One who understands that as it was taught by the Buddha

original: Na gaṇhāti bhavaṃ kiñci, sutattaṃva ayoguḷaṃ.
analyzed: na gaṇhāti bhavam kiñci ayaḥ guḷam
translated: does not grasp at any existence, like a heated iron ball.

original: “Na me hoti ‘ahosi’nti, ‘bhavissa’nti na hoti me;
analyzed: na me hoti ahosinti bhavissanti na hoti me
translated: I do not think ‘I was,’ nor do I think ‘I will be.’

original: Saṅkhārā vigamissanti, tattha kā paridevanā.
analyzed: saṅkhārāḥ vigamissanti tattha kā paridevanā
translated: The formations will depart, so what is there to lament?

original: “Suddhaṃ dhammasamuppādaṃ, suddhaṃ saṅkhārasantatiṃ;
analyzed: suddham dhamma samuppādam suddham saṅkhāra santatim
translated: The pure arising of phenomena, the pure continuity of formations,

original: Passantassa yathābhūtaṃ, na bhayaṃ hoti gāmaṇi.
analyzed: passantassa yathābhūtam na bhayam hoti gāmaṇi
translated: When one sees things as they really are, there is no fear, O chieftain.

original: “Tiṇakaṭṭhasamaṃ lokaṃ, yadā paññāya passati;
analyzed: tiṇa kaṭṭha samam lokam yadā paññāya passati
translated: When one sees the world as being like grass and sticks,

original: Mamattaṃ so asaṃvindaṃ, ‘natthi me’ti na socati.
analyzed: mamattam saḥ asaṃvindam na atthi mā iti na socati
translated: one does not cling to the notion of “mine” and does not grieve, thinking, “I am not.”

original: “Ukkaṇṭhāmi sarīrena, bhavenamhi anatthiko;
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhāmi sarīrena bhavena amhi anatthikaḥ
translated: I am disgusted with the body; I have no desire for becoming.

original: Soyaṃ bhijjissati kāyo, añño ca na bhavissati.
analyzed: saḥ ayam bhijjissati kāyaḥ añño ca na bhavissati
translated: This body will break up, and another will not come into existence.

original: “Yaṃ vo kiccaṃ sarīrena, taṃ karotha yadicchatha;
analyzed: yam vaḥ kiccam sarīrena tam karotha yat icchatha
translated: Whatever you have to do with the body, do it now, as you wish.

original: Na me tappaccayā tattha, doso pemañca hehitī”ti. –
analyzed: na me tad paccayā tattha doso
translated: I have no quarrel with you, and I have no love for you.”

original: Imā gāthā abhāsi.
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: These verses were spoken by the Elder.

original: “Tassa taṃ vacanaṃ sutvā, abbhutaṃ lomahaṃsanaṃ;
analyzed: tassa tam vacanam sutvā abbhutam loma haṃsanam
translated: Having heard his words, so wonderful and hair-raising,

original: Satthāni nikkhipitvāna, māṇavā etadabravu”nti. –
analyzed: satthāni nikkhipitvāna māṇavāḥ etat abravunti
translated: the youths put down their weapons and said to him:

original: Ayaṃ saṅgītikārehi vuttagāthā. Ito aparā tisso corānaṃ, therassa ca vacanapaṭivacanagāthā –
analyzed: ayam saṅgīti kārehi vutta gāthā itas aparā tissaḥ corānam therassa ca vacana paṭivacana gāthā
translated: These verses were spoken by the compilers of the canon. The following three verses were spoken by the thieves and the Elder:

original: “Kiṃ bhadante karitvāna, ko vā ācariyo tava;
analyzed: kim bhadante karitvāna kaḥ vā tava
translated: “What, O venerable one, have you done? Who is your teacher?

original: Kassa sāsanamāgamma, labbhate taṃ asokatā.
analyzed: kassa sāsanam āgamma labbhate tam asoka tā
translated: By whose teaching have you attained this sorrowlessness?

original: “Sabbaññū sabbadassāvī, jino ācariyo mama;
analyzed: sabbaññū sabba dassāvī jinaḥ ācariyaḥ mama
translated: The Victorious One, the Omniscient One, the All-Seeing One is my teacher.

original: Mahākāruṇiko satthā, sabbalokatikicchako.
analyzed: mahā kāruṇikaḥ satthā sabba loka tikicchako
translated: The Teacher, the Greatly Compassionate One, The Healer of the World’s entire disease.

original: “Tenāyaṃ desito dhammo, khayagāmī anuttaro;
analyzed: tena ayam desito dhammo khaya gāmī anuttaro
translated: “Therefore this Dhamma is taught, The unsurpassed way to destruction,

original: Tassa sāsanamāgamma, labbhate taṃ asokatā.
analyzed: tassa sāsanam āgamma labbhate tam asoka tā
translated: Having come to his Dispensation, That sorrowlessness can be obtained.

original: “Sutvāna corā isino subhāsitaṃ, nikkhippa satthāni ca āvudhāni ca;
analyzed: sutvāna corāḥ isino subhāsitam nikkhippa satthāni ca āvudhāni ca
translated: “Having heard the sage’s good words, The thieves put down their weapons,

original: Tamhā ca kammā viramiṃsu eke, eke ca pabbajjamarocayiṃsu.
analyzed: tamhā ca kammā viramiṃsu eke eke ca pabbajjam arocayiṃsu
translated: And some of them desisted from that deed, And some of them desired the going-forth.

original: “Te pabbajitvā sugatassa sāsane, bhāvetva bojjhaṅgabalāni paṇḍitā;
analyzed: te pabbajitvā sugatassa sāsane bhāvetvā bojjhaṅga balāni paṇḍitā
translated: “Having gone forth in the Sugata’s Dispensation, The wise ones, having developed the factors of Awakening,

original: Udaggacittā sumanā katindriyā, phusiṃsu nibbānapadaṃ asaṅkhata”nti. –
analyzed: udagga cittā sumanā katindriyā phusiṃsu nibbāna padam
translated: With uplifted minds, gladdened, with faculties at peace, Touched Nibbāna, the unconditioned state.”

original: Imāpi saṅgītikārehi vuttagāthā.
analyzed: imā api saṅgīti kārehi vutta gāthā
translated: These verses were also spoken by the compilers.

original: Tattha natthi cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ, anapekkhassa, gāmaṇīti gāmaṇi, apekkhāya, taṇhāya,
analyzed: tattha natthi cetasikam dukkham anapekkhassa gāmaṇi iti gāmaṇi apekkhāya taṇhāya
translated: Herein, there is no mental suffering, for one who is without concern, O village headman, is a village headman, by means of concern, by means of craving,

original: abhāvena anapekkhassa mādisassa, lohitasabhāvo pubbo viya, cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ
analyzed: abhāvena anapekkhassa mādisassa lohita sabhāvo pubbaḥ viya cetasikam dukkham domanassam
translated: by the absence of concern, for one like me, mental suffering, grief,

original: natthi, domanassābhāvāpadesena bhayābhāvaṃ vadati. Tenāha “atikkantā bhayā sabbe”ti.
analyzed: natthi domanassa abhāva apadesena bhaya abhāvam vadati tena āha atikkantā bhayā sabbā iti
translated: is not, like pus in a blood-clotting wound. By the statement of the absence of grief, he declares the absence of fear. Therefore he said: “All fears are transcended.”

original: Atikkantā bhayā sabbeti khīṇasaṃyojanassa arahato pañcavīsati mahābhayā, aññe ca
analyzed: atikkantā bhayā sabbā iti khīṇa saṃyojanassa arahato pañcavīsati mahābhayāḥ aññe ca
translated: “He has gone beyond all fears” : the one who has destroyed the fetters, the Arahant, has gone beyond the twenty-five great fears and all other fears as well.

original: sabbepi bhayā ekaṃsena atikkantā atītā, apagatāti attho.🔽Diṭṭhe dhamme yathātatheti catusaccadhamme pariññāpahānasacchikiriyabhāvanāvasena
analyzed: sabbe api bhayāḥ ekaṃsena atikkantāḥ atītāḥ apagatā ati attho  diṭṭhe dhamme yathā tathā iti catu sacca dhamme pariññā apahāna sacchikiriya bhāvanā vasena
translated: “Gone beyond” means “transcended.”🔽“In this very life as it really is” : by means of the path-wisdom he has seen the four noble truths as they really are, by way of full understanding, abandoning, realizing, and developing.

original: maggapaññāya yathābhūtaṃ diṭṭhe. Maraṇeti maraṇahetu. Bhāranikkhepane yathāti yathā
analyzed: magga paññāya yathābhūtam diṭṭhe maraṇa iti maraṇa hetu bhāra nikkhepane yathā ati yathā
translated: “Death” : the cause of death.

original: koci puriso sīse ṭhitena mahatā garubhārena saṃsīdanto tassa nikkhepane, apanayane
analyzed: koci purisaḥ sīse ṭhitena mahatā garu bhārena saṃsīdanto tassa nikkhepane apanayane
translated: “As in the laying down of a burden” : just as a man who is exhausted from carrying a heavy load on his head is not afraid of laying it down, of removing it,

original: na bhāyati, evaṃ sampadamidanti attho. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: na bhāyati evam sampadam idam ti atthaḥ vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: so it is here. The Exalted One has said:

original: “Bhārā have pañcakkhandhā, bhārahāro ca puggalo;
analyzed: bhārāḥ have pañca kkhandhāḥ bhāra hāraḥ ca puggalo
translated: “The five aggregates are indeed a burden; the person is the bearer of the burden.

original: Bhārādānaṃ dukhaṃ loke, bhāranikkhepanaṃ sukha”nti. ;
analyzed: bhāra ādānam dukham loke bhāra nikkhepanam sukhanti
translated: Taking up a burden is suffering in the world; laying down a burden is happiness.”

original: Suciṇṇanti suṭṭhu caritaṃ. Brahmacariyanti, sikkhattayasaṅgahaṃ sāsanabrahmacariyaṃ.
analyzed: su ciṇṇam ti suṭṭhu caritam brahmacariyanti sikkhattaya saṅgaham sāsana brahmacariyam
translated: “Well-practiced” : well-practiced is the life of purity, which is the life of purity of the Dispensation, which includes the three trainings.

original: Tato eva maggo cāpi subhāvito aṭṭhaṅgiko ariyamaggopi sammadeva bhāvito. Rogānamiva
analyzed: tatas eva maggo ca api su bhāvitaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ ariya maggaḥ api sammat eva bhāvitaḥ
translated: Therefore, the Noble Eightfold Path, too, is well developed,🔽As with the quelling of disease.

original: saṅkhayeti yathā bahūhi rogehi abhibhūtassa āturassa rogānaṃ saṅkhaye pītisomanassameva
analyzed: saṅkhaya iti yathā bahūhi rogehi abhibhūtassa āturassa rogānam saṅkhaye pīti somanassam eva
translated: Just as a sick person, overcome by many diseases, has only joy and gladness when his diseases are quelled,

original: hoti, evaṃ khandharogasaṅkhaye maraṇe mādisassa bhayaṃ natthi.
analyzed: hoti evam khandha roga saṅkhaye maraṇe mādisassa bhayam natthi
translated: so there is no fear of death for one like me when the disease of the aggregates is quelled.🔽I have seen that the worlds are without essence,🔽overcome by the three kinds of suffering, ablaze with the eleven fires,

original: Nirassādā bhavā diṭṭhāti tīhi dukkhatāhi abhibhūtā, ekādasahi aggīhi ādittā, tayo🔽bhavā nirassādā, assādarahitā, mayā diṭṭhā. Visaṃ pitvāva chaḍḍitanti pamādavasena
analyzed: nirassādā bhavā diṭṭhā ati tīhi dukkha tāhi abhibhūtā ekādasahi aggīhi ādittā tayo  bhavāḥ nirassādāḥ assāda rahitāḥ mayā diṭṭhāḥ visam pitvā ava pamāda vasena
translated: the three worlds are without essence, devoid of essence.

original: visaṃ pivitvā tādisena payogena chaḍḍitaṃ viya maraṇe me bhayaṃ natthīti attho.
analyzed: visam pivitvā tādisena payogena chaḍḍitam viya maraṇe me bhayam natthi iti
translated: I have seen them as if they were poison discarded after the poison has been extracted. The meaning is: I have no fear of death.🔽I am freed from the slaughter-house,

original: Mutto āghātanā yathāti yathā corehi māraṇatthaṃ āghātanaṃ nīto kenaci upāyena tato
analyzed: muttaḥ āghātanā yathā ati yathā corehi māraṇa attham āghātanam nītaḥ kenacid upāyena tatas
translated: just as one who has been led to the slaughter-house by thieves for the purpose of being killed becomes elated and glad if he is somehow freed from that,

original: mutto haṭṭhatuṭṭho hoti, evaṃ saṃsārapāraṃ, nibbānaṃ, gatattā pāragū, catūhipi upādānehi
analyzed: muttaḥ haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ hoti evam saṃsāra pāram nibbānam gata ttā pāragū catūhi pi upādānehi
translated: so I have gone beyond the round of rebirths, to nibbana, and therefore I am one who has gone beyond by means of the four kinds of clinging.

original: anupādāno, pariññādīnaṃ soḷasannaṃ kiccānaṃ katattā katakicco kāmāsavādīhi anāsavo,
analyzed: an upādānaḥ pariññā ādīnam kiccānam kata ttā kata kicco kāma āsava ādīhi an āsavaḥ
translated: He is unattached because he has done what had to be done, namely, the sixteen duties beginning with full understanding of the three kinds of things to be fully understood. He is without influxes because he is without the influxes of sense desire, etc.

original: āyukkhayā āyukkhayahetu tuṭṭho somanassiko hoti.
analyzed: āyu khayā āyu khaya hetu tuṭṭhaḥ somanassikaḥ hoti
translated: He is satisfied and glad because of the exhaustion of his life span and because of the cause for the exhaustion of his life span.🔽Supreme: best. Nature: individual essence.🔽In the case of the state of arahantship, the cause of its establishment is the reason for its desirability, etc.,

original: Uttamanti seṭṭhaṃ. Dhammatanti, dhammasabhāvaṃ. Arahatte siddhe sijjhanahetu iṭṭhādīsu
analyzed: uttamam ti seṭṭham dhammatanti dhamma sabhāvam arahatte siddhe sijjhana hetu iṭṭha ādīsu
translated: and its being the first is the reason for its being foremost.

original: tādibhāvaṃ. Sabbaloketi sabbalokasmimpi, dīghāyukasukhabahulatādivasena saṃyuttepi
analyzed: ta ādi bhāvam sabbaloka iti sabba lokasmin pi dīgha āyuka sukha bahula tā ādi vasena saṃyutte pi
translated: In all the world: in all the world consisting of the four primary and the eight secondary quarters, which is connected by the continuity of aggregates, etc., and by the continuity of the aggregates, etc., in the form of long life, much happiness, etc.

original: loke. Anatthikoti, anapekkho. Ādittāva gharā muttoti yathā koci puriso samantato🔽ādittato pajjalitato gehato nissaṭo, tato nissaraṇanimittaṃ na socati, evaṃ khīṇāsavo
analyzed: loke anatthikaḥ ti anapekkhaḥ ādittā ava gharā muttaḥ iti yathā koci purisaḥ samantataḥ  ādittataḥ pajjalitataḥ gehataḥ nissaṭaḥ tatas nissaraṇa nimittam na socati evam khīṇa āsavaḥ
translated: He is uninterested: he is indifferent.

original: maraṇanimittaṃ na socati.🔽Yadatthi saṅgataṃ kiñcīti yaṃkiñci imasmiṃ loke atthi, vijjati, upalabbhati saṅgataṃ,
analyzed: maraṇa nimittam na socati  yat atthi saṅgatam kiñci iti yat kiñci imasmin loke atthi vijjati upalabbhati saṅgatam
translated: He is like one freed from a burning house: just as a man who has escaped from a burning house ablaze with flames would not grieve over the cause of his escape, so the one free from influxes does not grieve over the cause of his death.🔽Whatever there is that is connected: whatever there is that exists, is found, is obtained, is connected,

original: sattehi saṅkhārehi vā samāgamo, samodhānaṃ. “Saṅkhata”ntipi pāṭho, tassa yaṃkiñci
analyzed: sattehi saṅkhārehi vā samāgamaḥ samodhānam pāṭhaḥ tassa yaṃkiñci

analyzed: kiñci khuddakam vā mahantam vā bhavam na gaṇhāti na tattha taṇham karoti iti attho
translated: He does not take up any state, whether small or great, and he does not feel craving for it.🔽“I was” : he does not think, “In the past I was such and such.”🔽“I will be” : he does not think, “In the future I will be such and such.”

analyzed: na me hoti ahosinti atītam addhānam aham īdisaḥ ahosinti atta diṭṭhi vasena na me  citta ppavatti atthi diṭṭhiyā sammat eva ugghāṭita ttā dhamma sabhāvassa ca su diṭṭha ttā  bhavissanti na hoti mā iti tatas eva anāgatam addhānam aham edisaḥ katham nu kho bhavissam
translated: “I will not be” : he does not think, “In the future I will not be such and such.”🔽“He will be” : he does not think, “In the future another will be such and such.”🔽“He will not be” : he does not think, “In the future another will not be such and such.”🔽“His being” : he does not think, “In the future another will be such and such.”🔽“His non-being” : he does not think, “In the future another will not be such and such.”

original: vinassissanti, khaṇe khaṇe bhijjissantī”ti. Tattha kā paridevanāti evaṃ passantassa
analyzed: vinassissanti khaṇe khaṇe bhijjissanti iti tattha kā paridevanā ati evam passantassa
