analyzed: mādisassa tattha saṅkhāra gate kā nāma paridevanā
translated: “His passing away” : he does not think, “In the future another will

original: Suddhanti kevalaṃ, attasārena asammissaṃ. Dhammasamuppādanti paccayapaccayuppannadhammasamuppattiṃ
analyzed: suddham ti kevalam atta sārena asammissam dhamma samuppādanti paccaya paccaya uppanna dhamma samuppattim
translated: “Pure” means exclusively, not mixed with selfhood. “The arising of ideas” means the arising of ideas that are conditions and are conditionally arisen.

original: avijjādipaccayehi saṅkhārādidhammamattappavattiṃ. Saṅkhārasantatinti kilesakammavipākappabhedasaṅkhārapabandhaṃ.
analyzed: avijjā ādi paccayehi saṅkhāra ādi dhamma matta ppavattim saṅkhāra santatim ti kilesa kamma vipāka ppabheda saṅkhāra pabandham
translated: The occurrence of ideas such as formations, etc., through ignorance, etc., as conditions. “The continuity of formations” means the continuity of formations classed as defilements, actions, and results.

original: Passantassa yathābhūtanti saha vipassanāya maggapaññāya yāthāvato jānantassa.
analyzed: passantassa yathābhūtanti saha vipassanāya magga paññāya yāthāvataḥ jānantassa
translated: “When he sees with understanding as it really is” means when he knows as it really is with path understanding accompanied by insight.

original: Tiṇakaṭṭhasamaṃ lokanti yathā araññe apariggahe tiṇakaṭṭhe kenaci gayhamāne aparassa
analyzed: tiṇa kaṭṭha samam lokam ti yathā araññe a pariggahe tiṇa kaṭṭhe kenaci gayhamāne aparassa
translated: “The world is like grass and sticks” : just as when grass and sticks in a forest unowned by anyone are being taken away by someone,

original: “mayhaṃ santakaṃ ayaṃ gaṇhatī”ti na hoti, evaṃ so asāmikatāya tiṇakaṭṭhasamaṃ saṅkhāralokaṃ🔽yadā paññāya passati, so tattha mamattaṃ asaṃvindaṃ asaṃvindanto alabhanto akaronto.
analyzed: mayham santakam ayam gaṇhati iti na hoti evam saḥ a sāmika tāya tiṇa kaṭṭha samam saṅkhāra lokam  yadā paññāya passati so tattha mamattam a saṃvindam a saṃvindantaḥ a labhantaḥ a karontaḥ
translated: there is no other’s thought “He is taking away what is mine,” so too, since the world of formations is unowned,🔽when he sees it as like grass and sticks, then he does not assume ownership of it. Not assuming ownership, not taking it as “mine,” he does not grieve.

original: Natthi meti “ahu vata sohaṃ, taṃ me natthī”ti na socati.
analyzed: natthi me iti ahu vata sā uham tam me natthi iti na socati
translated: “There is no ‘I’ or ‘mine’” : he does not grieve, thinking “I was, but now I am not.”

original: Ukkaṇṭhāmi sarīrenāti asārakena abhinudena dukkhena akataññunā asuciduggandhajegucchapaṭikkūlasabhāvena
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhāmi sarīrena ati asārakena abhinudena dukkhena akataññunā asuci duggandha jeguccha paṭikkūla sabhāvena
translated: I am disgusted with this body, which is insubstantial, deceptive, painful, ungrateful, impure, foul-smelling, disgusting, and repulsive.

original: iminā kāyena ukkaṇṭhāmi imaṃ kāyaṃ nibbindanto evaṃ tiṭṭhāmi. Bhavenamhi anatthikoti
analyzed: iminā kāyena ukkaṇṭhāmi imam kāyam nibbindanto evam tiṭṭhāmi bhavena amhi anatthikaḥ ti
translated: I stand here, disenchanted with this body. I am not interested in any kind of existence.

original: sabbenapi bhavena anatthiko amhi, na kiñci bhavaṃ patthemi. Soyaṃ bhijjissati kāyoti
analyzed: sabbena api bhavena anatthikaḥ amhi na kiñci bhavam patthemi saḥ ayam bhijjissati kāyo ti
translated: I am not interested in any kind of existence at all; I do not seek any kind of existence. This body will break up.

original: ayaṃ mama kāyo idāni tumhākaṃ payogena aññathā vā aññattha bhijjissati. Añño ca na
analyzed: ayam mama kāyaḥ idāni tumhākam payogena aññathā vā aññattha bhijjissati ca na
translated: This body of mine will now break up either through your efforts or otherwise.🔽And there will be no other.

original: bhavissatīti añño kāyo mayhaṃ āyatiṃ na bhavissati, punabbhavābhāvato.
analyzed: bhavissati iti aññaḥ kāyaḥ mayham āyatim na bhavissati punabbhava abhāvato
translated: There will be no other body for me in the future, because there will be no renewed existence.🔽Do with the body🔽whatever you have to do.

original: Yaṃ vo kiccaṃ sarīrenāti yaṃ tumhākaṃ iminā sarīrena payojanaṃ, taṃ karotha yadicchatha,
analyzed: yam vaḥ kiccam sarīrena ati yam tumhākam iminā sarīrena payojanam tam karotha yat icchatha
translated: If you wish, you may do whatever you want with this body, for whatever purpose you have in mind.

original: icchatha ce. Na me tappaccayāti, taṃ nimittaṃ imassa sarīrassa tumhehi yathicchitakiccassa
analyzed: icchatha ce na me tad paccayā ati tam nimittam imassa sarīrassa tumhehi yathicchita kiccassa
translated: I am not interested in it.🔽In regard to that, whether you do it or not,

original: karaṇahetu. Tatthāti tesu karontesu ca akarontesu ca. Doso pemañca hehitīti yathākkamaṃ
analyzed: karaṇa hetu tattha ati tesu karontesu ca a karontesu ca yathākkamam
translated: hatred and love are the same.

original: paṭigho anunayo na bhavissati, attano bhave apekkhāya sabbaso pahīnattāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: paṭighaḥ anunayaḥ na bhavissati attanaḥ bhave apekkhāya sabbaso pahīna ttā ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: and there will be no resentment or approval, since he has given up all concern for his own existence.🔽The meaning intended is this.

original: Aññapaccayā aññattha ca paṭighānunayesu asantesupi tappaccayā, “tatthā”ti vacanaṃ
analyzed: añña paccayā aññattha ca paṭigha anunayesu a santesu pi tad paccayā tattha ati vacanam
translated: Although resentment and approval are absent elsewhere, because of them there is the expression “there” .

original: yathādhigatavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: yathā adhigata vasena vuttam
translated: This is said with reference to what has been attained.

original: Tassāti adhimuttattherassa. Taṃ vacananti “natthi cetasikaṃ dukkha”ntiādikaṃ maraṇe
analyzed: tassa ti adhimutta therassa tam vacanam ti natthi cetasikam dukkham ti ādikam maraṇe
translated: “His” : the Elder Adhimutta’s. “That speech” : the speech that declares the absence of fear of death, etc.,

original: bhayābhāvādidīpakaṃ, tato eva abbhutaṃ lomahaṃsanaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā. Māṇavāti corā.
analyzed: bhaya abhāva ādi dīpakam eva abbhutam loma haṃsanam vacanam sutvā corā
translated: and that is wondrous and thrilling, because of that. “Robbers” : thieves.

original: Corā hi “māṇavā”ti vuccanti “māṇavehi saha gacchanti katakammehi akatakammehipī”tiādīsu viya.
analyzed: corāḥ hi māṇava ati vuccanti māṇavehi saha gacchanti kata kammehi a kata kammehi pi iti ādīsu viya
translated: For thieves are called “māṇavas” , as in such passages as “They go with māṇavas, both those who have done their duties and those who have not done their duties.”

original: Kiṃ bhadante karitvānāti, bhante, kiṃ nāma tapokammaṃ katvā. Ko vā tava ācariyo kassa
analyzed: kim bhadante bhante kim nāma tapo kammam katvā kaḥ vā tava ācariyaḥ kassa
translated: “What, venerable sir, having done” : what ascetic practice, venerable sir, having done? “Who is your teacher” : whose teaching,

original: sāsanaṃ, ovādaṃ nissāya ayaṃ asokatā maraṇakāle sokābhāvo labbhatīti etaṃ atthaṃ
analyzed: sāsanam ovādam nissāya ayam asoka tā maraṇa kāle soka abhāvaḥ labbhati iti etam attham
translated: following whose advice, does this freedom from sorrow, this absence of grief at the time of death, come about? This is the meaning of the question.

original: abravuṃ, pucchāvasena kathesuṃ, bhāsiṃsu.
analyzed: abravum pucchā vasena kathesum bhāsiṃsu
translated: They spoke, they said, in the form of a question.

original: Taṃ sutvā thero tesaṃ paṭivacanaṃ dento “sabbaññū”tiādimāha. Tattha sabbaññūti paropadesena
analyzed: tam sutvā thero tesam paṭivacanam dento sabbaññu iti ādim āha tattha sabbaññu iti para upadesena
translated: whereby he showed that the Blessed One is omniscient, all-seeing, and all-knowing.

original: vinā sabbapakārena sabbadhammāvabodhanasamatthassa ākaṅkhāpaṭibaddhavuttino anāvaraṇañāṇassa
analyzed: vinā sabba pakārena sabba dhamma avabodhana samatthassa ākaṅkhā paṭibaddha vuttino anāvaraṇa ñāṇassa
translated: The Blessed One is omniscient because he has attained the unobstructed knowledge that is able to comprehend all dhammas in all modes without exception, without relying on the instruction of another, and that occurs in accordance with his wish.

original: adhigamena atītādibhedaṃ sabbaṃ jānātīti, sabbaññū. Teneva samantacakkhunā sabbassa
analyzed: adhigamena atīta ādi bhedam sabbam jānāti iti sabbaññū tena iva samanta cakkhunā sabbassa
translated: He is all-seeing because he sees all with the eye of omniscience.

original: dassanato sabbadassāvī. Yamhi anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ, tadeva sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, nattheva asādhāraṇañāṇapāḷiyā
analyzed: dassanato sabba dassāvī yamhi anāvaraṇa ñāṇam tat eva sabbaññuta ññāṇam nattha iva asādhāraṇa ñāṇa pāḷiyā
translated: The knowledge that is unobstructed is the same as the knowledge of omniscience. There is no contradiction with the texts that speak of a knowledge unique to the Buddha,

original: virodho visayuppattimukhena aññehi asādhāraṇabhāvadassanatthaṃ ekasseva ñāṇassa dvidhā
analyzed: virodhaḥ visaya uppatti mukhena aññehi asādhāraṇa bhāva dassana attham ekassa iva ñāṇassa dvidhā
translated: for the same knowledge is stated twice in order to show that it is unique to the Buddha by way of its object.🔽What should be said here has been said in detail in the commentary to the Itivuttaka.

original: vuttattā. Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ itivuttakavaṇṇanāyaṃ vitthārato vuttamevāti🔽tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Pañcannampi mārānaṃ vijayato jino, hīnādivibhāgabhinne
analyzed: vutta ttā yam pana ittha vattabbam tam itivuttaka vaṇṇanāyam vitthārataḥ vuttam eva ati 🔽tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbam vijayataḥ jinaḥ hīna ādi vibhāga bhinne
translated: Therefore it should be understood in the way stated there.🔽The Blessed One is the Victor because he has conquered the five kinds of enemies beginning with the defilements.

original: sabbasmiṃ sattanikāye adhimuttavuttitāya mahatiyā karuṇāya samannāgatattā mahākāruṇiko,
analyzed: sabbasmin satta nikāye adhimutta vutti tāya mahatiyā karuṇāya samannāgata ttā mahā kāruṇikaḥ
translated: He is “greatly compassionate” because he is endowed with great compassion, which is the state of mind of being intent on all living beings.

original: diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaparamatthehi yathārahaṃ veneyyānaṃ anusāsanato satthā, tato
analyzed: diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika paramatthehi yathāraham veneyyānam anusāsanato satthā tatas
translated: He is “the Teacher” because he instructs disciples in the way that is fitting for them in regard to the highest good in this life and the next.

original: eva sabbalokassa kilesarogatikicchanato sabbalokatikicchako, sammāsambuddho ācariyo
analyzed: eva sabba lokassa kilesa roga tikicchanataḥ sabba loka tikicchakaḥ sammāsambuddhaḥ ācariyaḥ
translated: He is “the physician of the whole world” because he cures the disease of defilements in the whole world. He is “the Teacher, the Fully Enlightened One” because he is the teacher who has fully awakened to the four noble truths.

original: mamāti yojanā. Khayagāmīti nibbānagāmī.
analyzed: mama ati yojanā khaya gāmī iti nibbāna gāmī
translated: The construction is: “He is my Teacher.” “Leading to destruction” means leading to Nibbāna.

original: Evaṃ therena satthu sāsanassa ca guṇe pakāsite paṭiladdhasaddhā ekacce corā pabbajiṃsu,
analyzed: evam therena satthu sāsanassa ca guṇe pakāsite paṭiladdha saddhāḥ ekacce corā pabbajiṃsu
translated: When the Elder had thus extolled the Teacher and the Dhamma, some of the thieves obtained faith and went forth,🔽while others declared themselves to be lay followers. To illustrate this, the Dhamma-preachers recited two verses:

original: ekacce upāsakattaṃ pavedesuṃ. Tamatthaṃ dīpento dhammasaṅgāhakā “sutvāna corā”tiādinā
analyzed: ekacce upāsaka ttam pavedesum tam attham dīpentaḥ dhamma saṅgāhakā sutvāna corāti ādinā
translated: “Having heard the Elder’s words, the thieves, the robbers,🔽The thieves laid aside their weapons and their trade,🔽and they went forth into homelessness in the Dispensation of the One of Ten Powers.”

original: dve gāthā abhāsiṃsu. Tattha isinoti adhisīlasikkhādīnaṃ esanaṭṭhena isino, adhimuttattherassa.
analyzed: dve gāthāḥ abhāsiṃsu tattha isino ti adhi sīla sikkhā ādīnam esana ṭṭhena isino adhimutta therassa
translated: Herein, “the Sage’s” means the Elder’s, who was intent on the training in the higher virtue, etc., which is called “the search for the truth” .

original: Nikkhippāti pahāya. Satthāni ca āvudhāni cāti asiādisatthāni ceva dhanukalāpādiāvudhāni
analyzed: nikkhippa ati pahāya satthāni ca āvudhāni ca ati asi ādi satthāni ca iva dhanu kalāpa ādi āvudhāni
translated: “They laid aside” means they abandoned. “Weapons and their trade” means swords and other weapons, and bows, quivers, etc., which are the trade of thieves.

original: ca. Tamhā ca kammāti tato corakammato.
analyzed: ca tamhā ca kamma ati tatas cora kammato
translated: “From that deed” means from that deed of thievery.

original: Te pabbajitvā sugatassa sāsaneti te corā sobhanagamanatādīhi sugatassa bhagavato
analyzed: te pabbajitvā sugatassa sāsane iti te corā sobhana gamana tā ādīhi sugatassa bhagavato
translated: Having gone forth in the Dispensation of the One of Good Conduct,

original: sāsane pabbajjaṃ upagantvā. Bhāvanāvisesādhigatāya odagyalakkhaṇāya pītiyā samannāgamena🔽udaggacittā. Sumanāti somanassappattā. Katindriyāti bhāvitindriyā. Phusiṃsūti aggamaggādhigamena
analyzed: sāsane pabbajjam upagantvā bhāvanā visesa adhigatāya odagya lakkhaṇāya pītiyā samannāgamena  udagga cittā sumanā ati somanassa pattā katindriyā ati bhāvita indriyā aggamagga adhigamena
translated: having gone forth in the Dispensation of the Blessed One, the One of Good Conduct, by means of the going forth that is good to go forth, etc.,🔽with a mind uplifted by means of the rapture that has the characteristic of uplifting, which they had attained by means of the distinction of development,🔽they were uplifted in mind. They had attained joy, they had attained mental joy. They had developed faculties, they had developed the faculties. They had touched, they had attained the deathless, Nibbāna, by means of the attainment of the highest path.

original: asaṅkhataṃ nibbānaṃ adhigacchiṃsu. Adhimutto kira core nibbisevane katvā, te tattheva
analyzed: asaṅkhatam nibbānam adhigacchiṃsu adhimuttaḥ kira core nibbisevane katvā te tattha iva
translated: It is said that Adhimutta, having made the thieves enter the monastery,

original: ṭhapetvā, mātu santikaṃ gantvā, mātaraṃ āpucchitvā, paccāgantvā tehi saddhiṃ upajjhāyassa
analyzed: ṭhapetvā mātu santikam gantvā mātaram āpucchitvā paccāgantvā tehi saddhim upajjhāyassa
translated: having left them there, having gone to his mother, having asked her for permission, having returned with her, together with them,

original: santikaṃ gantvā, pabbājetvā upasampadaṃ akāsi. Atha tesaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ ācikkhi, te
analyzed: santikam gantvā pabbājetvā upasampadam akāsi atha tesam kammaṭṭhānam ācikkhi te
translated: having gone to the presence of his preceptor, having gone forth, he gave them the full admission. Then he explained the meditation subject to them.

original: nacirasseva arahatte patiṭṭhahiṃsu. Tena vuttaṃ “pabbajitvā…pe… asaṅkhata”nti.
analyzed: nacirassa iva arahatte patiṭṭhahiṃsu tena vuttam pabbajitvā āpe asaṅkhatam ti
translated: They were established in Arahantship in no long time. Hence it was said: “Having gone forth … they had touched the deathless.”

original: Adhimuttattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: adhimutta thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Adhimutta is finished.

original: 2. Pārāpariyattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Pārāpariya

original: Samaṇassa ahu cintātiādikā āyasmato pārāpariyattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi
analyzed: samaṇassa ahu cintā ati ādikā āyasmataḥ pārāpariya ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi
translated: The story of the Elder Parāpariya is told in the Theragāthā, in the stanza beginning, “The monk reflected thus.”

original: purimabuddhesu katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ kusalaṃ upacinitvā
analyzed: purima buddhesu kata adhikāraḥ tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭu upanissayam kusalam upacinitvā
translated: In a previous state of existence he had formed a root of merit by rendering service to the Buddhas of the past, and in the course of his wanderings through the round of existences, he had accumulated much merit.

original: sugatīsuyeva saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde sāvatthiyaṃ aññatarassa brāhmaṇamahāsālassa
analyzed: sugatīsuyā iva saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde sāvatthiyam aññatarassa brāhmaṇa mahāsālassa
translated: In the dispensation of the present Buddha, he was reborn in Sāvatthi as the son of a certain wealthy brāhmaṇa.

original: putto hutvā nibbatti. Tassa vayappattassa gottavasena pārāpariyotveva samaññā ahosi.
analyzed: puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti tassa vaya ppattassa gotta vasena samaññā ahosi
translated: When he had grown up, he was called Parāpariya after his clan.

original: So tayo vede uggahetvā brāhmaṇasippesu nipphattiṃ gato. Ekadivasaṃ satthu dhammadesanākāle
analyzed: saḥ tayaḥ vede uggahetvā brāhmaṇa sippesu nipphattim gataḥ eka divasam satthu dhamma desanā kāle
translated: He mastered the Three Vedas and attained proficiency in the lore of the brāhmaṇas. One day, when the Teacher was preaching the Law,

original: jetavanavihāraṃ gantvā parisapariyante nisīdi. Satthā tassa ajjhāsayaṃ oloketvā indriyabhāvanāsuttaṃ
analyzed: jetavana vihāram gantvā parisa pariyante nisīdi satthā tassa ajjhāsayam oloketvā indriya bhāvanā suttaṃ
translated: he went to the Jetavana Monastery and sat down in the outer circle of the congregation. The Teacher perceived the trend of his thoughts and preached the Indriyabhāvanā Sutta.

original: desesi. So taṃ sutvā paṭiladdhasaddho pabbaji. Taṃ suttaṃ uggahetvā tadatthamanucintesi.
analyzed: desesi saḥ tam sutvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbaji tam suttam uggahetvā tad attham anucintesi
translated: Hearing this discourse, he was confirmed in the Faith and retired from the world. He mastered this discourse and pondered its meaning.

original: Yathā pana anucintesi, svāyamattho gāthāsu eva āvi bhavissati. So tathā anuvicintento
analyzed: yathā pana anucintesi svāyamatthaḥ gāthāsu eva bhavissati saḥ tathā anuvicintento
translated: As he was thinking thus,

original: āyatanamukhena vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā nacirasseva arahattaṃ patto. Aparabhāge attanā
analyzed: āyatana mukhena vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā nacirassa iva arahattam pattaḥ aparabhāge attanā
translated: he set about his insight meditation by way of the sense bases. Before long he reached Arahantship. Later,

original: cintitākāraṃ pakāsento –
analyzed: cintita ākāram
translated: revealing the form in which he had thought,🔽“The thought occurred to me,

original: “Samaṇassa ahu cintā, pārāpariyassa bhikkhuno;
analyzed: samaṇassa ahu cintā pārāpariyassa bhikkhuno
translated: Of the monk who has gone to the other shore,

original: Ekakassa nisinnassa, pavivittassa jhāyino.
analyzed: ekakassa nisinnassa pavivittassa jhāyinaḥ
translated: Who sits alone, secluded, and absorbed in meditation:🔽“What is the gradual training,

original: “Kimānupubbaṃ puriso, kiṃ vataṃ kiṃ samācāraṃ;
analyzed: kimānupubbam puriso kim vatam kim samācāram
translated: What the practice, what the conduct,🔽By which a man, doing his duty,

original: Attano kiccakārīssa, na ca kañci viheṭhaye.
analyzed: attano kicca kārīssa na ca kañci viheṭhaye
translated: Would not harm anyone?🔽“The faculties of men

original: “Indriyāni manussānaṃ, hitāya ahitāya ca;
analyzed: indriyāni manussānam hitāya ahitāya ca
translated: Lead to their harm or welfare;🔽Unguarded, they lead to harm,

original: Arakkhitāni ahitāya, rakkhitāni hitāya ca.
analyzed: a rakkhitāni ahitāya rakkhitāni hitāya ca
translated: But guarded, they lead to welfare.🔽“Guarding the faculties,

original: “Indriyāneva sārakkhaṃ, indriyāni ca gopayaṃ;
analyzed: indriyān eva sārakkham indriyāni ca gopayan
translated: Protecting the faculties,🔽A man, doing his duty,

original: Attano kiccakārīssa, na ca kañci viheṭhaye.
analyzed: attano kicca kārīssa na ca kañci viheṭhaye
translated: Would not harm anyone.🔽“If a man does not restrain the faculty of sight

original: “Cakkhundriyaṃ ce rūpesu, gacchantaṃ anivārayaṃ;
analyzed: cakkhu indriyam ce rūpesu gacchantam a nivārayam
translated: When it goes to forms,🔽Not seeing the danger,

original: Anādīnavadassāvī, so dukkhā na hi muccati.
analyzed: anādīnava dassāvī so dukkhā na hi muccati
translated: He is not freed from suffering.🔽“If a man does not restrain the faculty of hearing

original: “Sotindriyaṃ ce saddesu, gacchantaṃ anivārayaṃ;
analyzed: sotindriyam ce saddesu gacchantam anivārayam
translated: When it goes to sounds,

original: Anādīnavadassāvī, so dukkhā na hi muccati.
analyzed: anādīnava dassāvī so dukkhā na hi muccati
translated: Not seeing the danger, he is not freed from suffering.

original: “Anissaraṇadassāvī, gandhe ce paṭisevati;
analyzed: a nissaraṇa dassāvī gandhe ce paṭisevati
translated: If he enjoys smells, not seeing the escape,

original: Na so muccati dukkhamhā, gandhesu adhimucchito.
analyzed: na saḥ mucchati dukkhamhā gandhesu adhimucchito
translated: he is not freed from suffering, obsessed with smells.

original: “Ambilaṃ madhuraggañca, tittakaggamanussaraṃ;
analyzed: ambilam madhuraggam ca tittakaggam anussaram
translated: Remembering sour, sweet, and bitter tastes,

original: Rasataṇhāya gadhito, hadayaṃ nāvabujjhati.
analyzed: rasa taṇhāya gadhitaḥ hadayam na avabujjhati
translated: he is bound by craving for tastes, and does not awaken to the heart’s release.

original: “Subhānyappaṭikūlāni, phoṭṭhabbāni anussaraṃ;
analyzed: subhāni appaṭikūlāni phoṭṭhabbāni anussaraṃ
translated: Remembering pleasant, unrepulsive tactile objects,

original: Ratto rāgādhikaraṇaṃ, vividhaṃ vindate dukhaṃ.
analyzed: rattaḥ rāga adhikaraṇam vividham vindate dukham
translated: he is passionate, and because of passion he experiences manifold suffering.

original: “Manaṃ cetehi dhammehi, yo na sakkoti rakkhituṃ;
analyzed: manam ca itehi dhammehi yaḥ na sakkoti rakkhitum
translated: If one cannot guard the mind against these things,

analyzed: tatas nam dukkham anveti sabbehi etehi pañcahi
translated: then suffering follows him, as the wheel follows the ox’s hoof.🔽Filled with blood and pus,

original: “Pubbalohitasampuṇṇaṃ, bahussa kuṇapassa ca;
analyzed: pubba lohita sampuṇṇam bahussa kuṇapassa ca
translated: and with much filth,🔽made beautiful by the hero of men,

analyzed: nara vīra katam vaggum samuggam iva  kaṭukam madhuraḥ sādam piya nibandhanam dukham
translated: like a well-decorated chariot.🔽Bitter, sweet, and pleasant, the bond of what is dear is suffering.🔽Like a razor smeared with honey, like a knife in the mouth,

original: Khuraṃva madhunā littaṃ, ullihaṃ nāvabujjhati.
analyzed: khuram iva madhunā littam ulliham na avabujjhati
translated: one does not awaken to it.

original: “Itthirūpe itthisare, phoṭṭhabbepi ca itthiyā;
analyzed: itthi rūpe itthi sare phoṭṭhabbe pi ca itthiyā
translated: In the form and voice of a woman, and in the tactile object of a woman,

original: Itthigandhesu sāratto, vividhaṃ vindate dukhaṃ.
analyzed: itthi gandhesu sārattaḥ vividham vindate dukham
translated: he is passionate, and experiences manifold suffering.

original: “Itthisotāni sabbāni, sandanti pañca pañcasu;
analyzed: itthi sotāni sabbāni sandanti pañca pañcasu
translated: “All the streams of women flow to the five in the five,

analyzed: kātum yaḥ sakkoti vīriyavā
translated: he who is able to shut off their flood, he is the one with energy.

original: “So atthavā so dhammaṭṭho, so dakkho so vicakkhaṇo;
analyzed: saḥ atthavā saḥ dhammaṭṭho saḥ dakkho saḥ vicakkhaṇaḥ
translated: “He is the one with purpose, he is the one with Dhamma-firmness, he is the skilled one, he is the one with insight,

original: Kareyya ramamānopi, kiccaṃ dhammatthasaṃhitaṃ.
analyzed: kareyya ramamānaḥ api kiccam dhamma attha saṃhitam
translated: he should do the duty that is connected with purpose and Dhamma even if he is enjoying himself.

original: “Atho sīdati saññuttaṃ, vajje kiccaṃ niratthakaṃ;

translated: and with jhāna, insight, etc., it is the basis for the virtue of restraint. analyzed: atthaḥ hadayam na avabujjhati iti dukkhassantam karissāmi iti pabbajja ādi kkhaṇe uppannam  cittam na jānāti na sallakkheti sāsanassa hadayam abbhantaram anavajja dhammānam
translated: thinking “I shall make an end of suffering,” when it has gone forth, etc.,

original: sammaddanarasataṇhāya gadhito nāvabujjhati na jānāti, na paṭipajjatīti attho.
analyzed: sammaddana rasa taṇhāya gadhitaḥ na avabujjhati na jānāti na paṭipajjati iti attho
translated: because it is stuck in the bog of craving for the taste of the bliss of the life of purity. The meaning is that it does not know, does not understand, does not practice.

original: Subhānīti sundarāni. Appaṭikūlānīti manoramāni, iṭṭhāni. Phoṭṭhabbānīti upādiṇṇānupādiṇṇappabhede
analyzed: subhāni iti sundarāni appaṭikūlāni iti manoramāni iṭṭhāni phoṭṭhabbāni iti upādiṇṇa anupādiṇṇa ppabhede
translated: Beautiful: lovely. Not repulsive: delightful, agreeable. Textures:

original: phasse. Rattoti rajjanasabhāvena rāgena ratto. Rāgādhikaraṇanti rāgahetu. Vividhaṃ🔽vindate dukhanti rāgapariḷāhādivasena diṭṭhadhammikañca nirayasantāpādivasena abhisamparāyañca
analyzed: phasse rattoti rajjana sabhāvena rāgena rattaḥ rāga adhikaraṇanti rāga hetu vividham  vindate rāga pariḷāha ādi vasena diṭṭhadhammikam ca niraya santāpa ādi vasena abhisamparāyañca
translated: In contact. Is attached: is attached by attachment in the nature of lust. Because of attachment: because of the cause of attachment.

original: nānappakāraṃ dukkhaṃ paṭilabhati.🔽Manaṃ cetehīti manañca etehi rūpārammaṇādīhi dhammārammaṇappabhedehi ca. Nanti puggalaṃ.
analyzed: nānappakāram dukkham paṭilabhati  manam ca itehi iti manam ca etehi rūpa ārammaṇa ādīhi dhamma ārammaṇa ppabhedehi ca puggalam
translated: He finds various kinds of suffering: he obtains various kinds of suffering in the present life through the fever of lust, etc., and in the life to come through the torments of hell, etc.🔽If he guards his mind: if he guards his mind, the mind door,🔽from all: from all five,

original: Sabbehīti sabbehi pañcahipi. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yo puggalo manaṃ, manodvāraṃ, etehi🔽yathāvuttehi rūpādīhi pañcahi dhammehi dhammārammaṇappabhedato ca. Tattha pavattanakapāpakammanivāraṇena
analyzed: sabbehi iti sabbehi pañcahi pi idam vuttam hoti yaḥ puggalaḥ manam manaḥ dvāram etehi  yathā vuttehi rūpa ādīhi pañcahi dhammehi dhamma ārammaṇa ppabhedato ca tattha pavattanaka pāpa kamma nivāraṇena
translated: this is what is meant: if a person is unable to guard, to keep, his mind, the mind door, from these five things beginning with visible forms and ending with mind-objects,🔽by preventing the occurrence of evil-doing in regard to them,

original: rakkhituṃ, gopituṃ na sakkoti, tato tassa arakkhaṇato naṃ puggalaṃ taṃnimittaṃ dukkhaṃ
analyzed: rakkhitum gopitum na sakkoti tatas tassa arakkhaṇataḥ nam puggalam taṃnimittam dukkham
translated: then because he does not guard it, suffering follows him,

original: anveti, anugacchati, anugacchantañca etehi pañcahipi rūpārammaṇādīhi chaṭṭhārammaṇena
analyzed: anveti anugacchati anugacchantam ca etehi pañcahi pi rūpa ārammaṇa ādīhi chaṭṭha ārammaṇena
translated: goes after him, and, going after him, it goes after him by means of these five things beginning with visible forms and ending with mind-objects, and by means of the sixth, the mind-object of the sense base of mental data.

original: saddhiṃ sabbehipi ārammaṇappaccayabhūtehi anugacchatīti. Ettha cakkhundriyaṃ, sotindriyañca
analyzed: saddhim sabbehi pi ārammaṇa ppaccaya bhūtehi anugacchati iti ettha cakkhu indriyam sotindriyam ca
translated: and it goes along with all the objects that are its conditions.

original: asampattaggāhibhāvato “gacchantaṃ anivāraya”nti vuttaṃ itaraṃ sampattaggāhīti “gandhe
analyzed: a sampatta gāhi bhāvataḥ gacchantam a nivārayanti vuttam itaram sampatta gāhi iti gandhe
translated: Herein, the eye faculty and the ear faculty are said to “not restrain what goes” because they apprehend what is not yet reached. The other two are said to “use scents” and so on because they apprehend what is reached.

original: ce paṭisevatī”tiādinā vuttaṃ. Tatthāpi ca rasataṇhā ca phoṭṭhabbataṇhā ca sattānaṃ
analyzed: ce paṭisevati iti ādinā vuttam tattha api ca rasa taṇhā ca phoṭṭhabba taṇhā ca sattānam
translated: And here too craving for tastes and craving for contact are to be seen as especially strong in beings,

original: visesato balavatīti “rasataṇhāya gadhito, phoṭṭhabbāni anussarantoti” vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Evaṃ aguttadvārassa puggalassa chahi dvārehi chasupi ārammaṇesu asaṃvaranimittaṃ
analyzed: visesataḥ balavatī iti rasa taṇhāya gadhitaḥ phoṭṭhabbāni anussaranto ti vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam  evam agutta dvārassa puggalassa chahi dvārehi chasu pi ārammaṇesu asaṃvara nimittam
translated: so it is said: “Craving for tastes, he is caught, remembering contacts” .🔽Having thus shown the suffering that arises from lack of restraint in the six objects through the six doors of the person whose doors are unguarded,

original: uppajjanakadukkhaṃ dassetvā svāyamasaṃvaro yasmā sarīrasabhāvānavabodhena hoti, tasmā
analyzed: uppajjanaka dukkham dassetvā svāyam asaṃvaraḥ yasmā sarīra sabhāva anavabodhena hoti tasmā
translated: since that lack of restraint is due to non-understanding of the nature of the body,

original: sarīrasabhāvaṃ vicinanto “pubbalohitasampuṇṇa”ntiādinā gāthādvayamāha. Tassattho🔽– sarīraṃ nāmetaṃ pubbena lohitena ca sampuṇṇaṃ bharitaṃ aññena ca pittasemhādinā
analyzed: sarīra sabhāvam vicinantaḥ pubba lohita sampuṇṇa iti ādinā gāthā dvayam āha tassa atthaḥ 🔽sarīram nāma etat pubbena lohitena ca sampuṇṇam bharitam aññena ca pitta semha ādinā
translated: he said the two verses beginning, “Filled with old blood” , investigating the nature of the body. Its meaning is this:

original: bahunā kuṇapena, tayidaṃ naravīrena naresu chekena sippācariyena kataṃ vaggu maṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: bahunā kuṇapena tayā idam nara vīrena naresu chekena sippa ācariyena katam
translated: And this body, which is a mere skinful of ordure, is well shaped and well coloured,

original: lākhāparikammādinā cittitaṃ, anto pana gūthādiasucibharitaṃ samuggaṃ viya chavimattamanoharaṃ
analyzed: lākhā parikamma ādinā antar pana gūtha ādi asuci bharitam samuggam viya chavi matta manoharam
translated: like a toy made of lac and so on, but inside it is full of ordure, etc., like a bag full of impurities, and it is only the skin that makes it seem attractive.

original: bālajanasammohaṃ dukkhasabhāvatāya nirayādidukkhatāpanato ca kaṭukaṃ, parikappasambhavena
analyzed: bāla jana sammoham dukkha sabhāva tāya niraya ādi dukkha tāpanato ca kaṭukam parikappa sambhavena
translated: It is bitter because it is the source of suffering and because it is tormented by the suffering of the hells, and so on.

original: amūlakena assādamattena madhuratāya madhurassādaṃ, tato eva piyabhāvanibandhanena🔽piyanibandhanaṃ, dussahatāya appatītatāya ca dukhaṃ, īdise sarīre assādalobhena mahādukkhaṃ
analyzed: amūlakena assāda mattena madhuratāya madhura ssādam tatas eva piya bhāva nibandhanena  piya nibandhanam dussaha tāya appatīta tāya ca dukham īdise sarīre assāda lobhena mahā dukkham
translated: It is sweet because it is sweet-tasting, being the source of a pleasant feeling that arises in a particular way.🔽It is a bond of what is dear because it is the cause of the state of what is dear.🔽It is suffering because it is hard to support and because it is impermanent.

original: paccanubhuyyamānaṃ anavabujjhanto loko madhuragiddho khuradhārālehakapuriso viya daṭṭhabboti.🔽Idāni ete cakkhādīnaṃ gocarabhūtā rūpādayo vuttā, te visesato purisassa itthipaṭibaddhā
analyzed: paccanubhuyyamānam an avabujjhantaḥ lokaḥ madhura giddhaḥ khura dhārā lehaka puriso viya daṭṭhabbaḥ ti 🔽idāni ete cakkha ādīnam gocara bhūtā rūpa ādayaḥ vuttā te visesato purisassa itthi paṭibaddhā
translated: The world, which is unaware that it is experiencing great suffering through greed for the taste of the body, should be seen as like the man who licks the sharp edge of a razor.

original: kamanīyāti tattha saṃvaro kātabboti dassento “itthirūpe”tiādimāha. Tattha itthirūpeti
analyzed: kamanīyā ti tattha saṃvaro kātabbo ti dassentaḥ itthi rūpā iti ādim āha tattha itthi rūpā iti
translated: “One should restrain oneself in regard to it” means that one should restrain oneself in regard to the form of a woman.🔽

original: itthiyā catusamuṭṭhānikarūpāyatanasaṅkhāte vaṇṇe. Api ca yo koci itthiyā nivatthassa🔽alaṅkārassa vā gandhavaṇṇakādīnaṃ vā piḷandhanamālānaṃ vā kāyapaṭibaddho vaṇṇo purisassa
analyzed: itthiyā catu samuṭṭhānika rūpa āyatana saṅkhāte vaṇṇe api ca yaḥ koci itthiyā nivatthassa  alaṅkārassa vā gandha vaṇṇaka ādīnam vā piḷandhana mālānam vā kāya paṭibaddhaḥ vaṇṇaḥ purisassa
translated: “In the case of a woman’s form” : he says this in order to show that one should exercise restraint in regard to that which is lovable. Herein, a woman’s form is the visible-form base consisting of the four primary elements of a woman. Furthermore, whatever is the colour of a woman’s clothing,

original: cakkhuviññāṇassa ārammaṇabhāvāya upakappati, sabbametaṃ “itthirūpa”ntveva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇassa ārammaṇa bhāvāya upakappati sabbam etat itthi rūpam tu eva veditabbam
translated: ornament, perfume, cosmetic, garland, or bodily adornment, all this should be understood as “a woman’s form” in the sense that it is a condition for the appearance of the eye-consciousness of a man.

original: Itthisareti itthiyā gītalapitahasitaruditasadde. Api ca itthiyā nivatthavatthassapi🔽alaṅkataalaṅkārassapi itthipayoganipphāditā veṇuvīṇāsaṅkhapaṇavādīnampi saddā idha🔽itthisaraggahaṇena gahitāti veditabbā. Sabbopeso purisassa cittaṃ ākaḍḍhatīti. “Itthirase”ti
analyzed: itthi sarā iti itthiyāḥ gīta lapita hasita rudita sadde api ca itthiyāḥ  alaṅkata alaṅkārassa api itthi payoga nipphāditā veṇu vīṇā saṅkha paṇava ādīnam pi saddāḥ idha  itthi sara gahaṇena gahitā ati veditabbā sabbā upesaḥ purisassa cittam ākaḍḍhati iti itthi rasa iti
translated: “In the case of a woman’s voice” : this is a woman’s sound consisting of the four primary elements. Furthermore, the sound of a woman’s clothing,

original: pana pāḷiyā catusamuṭṭhānikarasāyatanavasena vuttaṃ. Itthiyā kiṃkārapaṭissāvitādivasena
analyzed: pana pāḷiyā catu samuṭṭhānika rasa āyatana vasena vuttam itthiyā kiṃkāra paṭissāvita ādi vasena
translated: ornament, or the sound of a flute, conch, or tabor produced by a woman’s effort, should be understood as included by the expression “a woman’s voice.” All this attracts a man’s mind. “In the case of a woman’s manner” : this is stated in the text by way of the four primary elements of the taste base. A woman’s manner is the taste of a woman’s food, drink, etc., that she has accepted in return for a service rendered.

original: assavaraso ceva paribhogaraso ca itthirasoti eke. Yo pana itthiyā oṭṭhamaṃsasammakkhitakheḷādiraso,
analyzed: assava rasaḥ ca iva paribhoga rasaḥ ca itthi rasaḥ ti eke yaḥ pana itthiyā oṭṭha maṃsa sammakkhita kheḷa ādi rasaḥ
translated: But the essence of the female is the taste of the saliva mixed with the mucus from the womb and so on,

original: yo ca tāya purisassa dinnayāgubhattādīnaṃ raso, sabbopeso “itthiraso”tveva veditabbo.
analyzed: yaḥ ca tāya purisassa dinna yāgu bhatta ādīnam raso sabba upesaḥ itthi rasaḥ tu eva veditabbaḥ
translated: and the taste of the rice gruel, boiled rice, etc., given by her to a man when she has had sexual intercourse with him.🔽The touch of the female is the touch of her body and of the clothes, ornaments, garlands, etc., worn by her.

original: Phoṭṭhabbepi ca itthiyā kāyasamphasso, itthisarīrārūḷhānaṃ vatthālaṅkāramālādīnaṃ
analyzed: phoṭṭhabbe pi ca itthiyā kāya samphassaḥ itthi sarīra ārūḍhānam vattha alaṅkāra mālā ādīnam
translated: And in the texts where the words “form of a woman” and “essence of a woman” are given,

original: phasso “itthiphoṭṭhabbo”tveva veditabbo. Ettha ca yesaṃ itthirūpe itthisareti pāḷi,
analyzed: phassaḥ itthi phoṭṭhabbaḥ tu eva veditabbaḥ ettha ca yesam itthi rūpe itthi sarā iti
translated: the “taste of a woman” should be understood to be included by the word “woman.”

original: tesaṃ api-saddena itthirasasaṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Itthigandhesūti itthiyā catusamuṭṭhānikagandhāyatanesu.🔽Itthiyā sarīragandho nāma duggandho. Ekaccā hi itthī assagandhinī hoti, ekaccā meṇḍagandhinī,
analyzed: tesam api saddena itthi rasa saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo itthi gandhesu ti itthiyā catu samuṭṭhānika gandha āyatanesu  itthiyā sarīra gandhaḥ nāma duggandhaḥ ekaccā hi itthī assa gandhinī hoti ekaccā meṇḍa gandhinī
translated: As regards “odours of a woman”: the odour of a woman is the odour of the four primary elements in a woman’s body.

original: ekaccā sedagandhinī, ekaccā soṇitagandhinī, tathāpi tāsu andhabālo rajjateva. Cakkavattino
analyzed: ekaccā seda gandhinī ekaccā soṇita gandhinī tathā api tāsu andha bālaḥ rajjatā iva
translated: The odour of a woman’s body is a bad smell. For some women smell like a horse, some like a goat, some like a fowl, some like a dog, some like a cat, some like a jackal, some like a human being, some like a cow, some like a buffalo, some like a boar, some like a snake, some like a fish, some like a crab, some like a shrimp, some like a clam, some like a snail, some like a kind of fruit, and some have a sweet odour like sandalwood.

original: pana itthiratanassa kāyato candanagandho vāyati, mukhato uppalagandho, ayaṃ na sabbāsaṃ
analyzed: pana itthi ratanassa kāyataḥ candana gandhaḥ vāyati mukhataḥ uppala gandhaḥ ayam na sabbāsam
translated: But the scent of sandalwood comes from the woman’s body and the scent of a blue lotus from her mouth. This is not so in all cases.

original: hotīti, itthiyā sarīre ārūḷho āgantuko anulimpanādigandho “itthigandho”ti veditabbo.
analyzed: hoti iti itthiyā sarīre ārūḍhaḥ āgantukaḥ anulimpana ādi gandhaḥ itthi gandhaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: So the scent that comes to be in a woman’s body by chance, whether it is applied externally or arises internally, should be understood as “the scent of a woman.”

original: Sārattoti suṭṭhu ratto gadhito mucchito, idaṃ pana padaṃ “itthirūpe”tiādīsupi yojetabbaṃ.🔽Vividhaṃ vindate dukhanti itthirūpādīsu sarāganimittaṃ diṭṭhadhammikaṃ vadhabandhanādivasena
analyzed: sārattaḥ ti suṭṭhu rattaḥ gadhitaḥ mucchitaḥ idam pana padam itthi rūpa iti ādīsu pi yojetabbam  vividham vindate itthi rūpa ādīsu sa rāga nimittam diṭṭhadhammikam vadha bandhana ādi vasena
translated: “Is attached” : is well attached, is infatuated. But this word should be construed also with “a woman’s form” and so on.

original: samparāyikaṃ pañcavidhabandhanādivasena nānappakāraṃ dukkhaṃ paṭilabhati.
analyzed: samparāyikam pañcavidha bandhana ādi vasena nānappakāram dukkham paṭilabhati
translated: “He finds various kinds of pain” : he obtains various kinds of pain, both in the present life and in lives to come, in the form of killing, imprisonment, etc., and in the form of the five kinds of bondage, etc., which are the reason for lust for a woman’s form, etc.

original: Itthisotāni sabbānīti itthiyā rūpādiārammaṇāni sabbāni anavasesāni pañca taṇhāsotāni
analyzed: itthi sotāni sabbāni iti itthiyāḥ rūpa ādi ārammaṇāni sabbāni anavasesāni pañca taṇhā sotāni
translated: “All the streams of a woman” : all the five streams of craving for the five objects beginning with a woman’s form, without exception,

original: sandanti. Pañcasūti purisassa pañcasu dvāresu. Tesanti tesaṃ pañcannaṃ sotānaṃ. Āvaraṇanti
analyzed: sandanti pañcasu uti purisassa pañcasu dvāresu tesanti tesam pañcannam sotānam
translated: “flow into” the five doors of a man. “Of those five streams” : of those five streams. “The dam” :

original: saṃvaraṇaṃ, yathā asaṃvaro na uppajjati, evaṃ satisampajaññaṃ paccupaṭṭhapetvā saṃvaraṃ
analyzed: saṃvaraṇam yathā asaṃvaraḥ na uppajjati evam sati sampajaññam paccupaṭṭhapetvā saṃvaram
translated: the restraint. The establishment of mindfulness and clear comprehension in such a way that non-restraint does not arise,

original: pavattetuṃ yo sakkoti, so vīriyavā āraddhavīriyo akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya kusalānaṃ
analyzed: pavattetum yaḥ sakkoti so vīriyavā āraddha vīriyaḥ akusalānam dhammānam pahānāya kusalānam
translated: Who can practice, he is energetic, he has begun energy, for the abandoning of unwholesome states, for the up-rising of wholesome states,

original: dhammānaṃ upasampadāyāti attho.🔽Evaṃ rūpādigocare pabbajitassa paṭipattiṃ dassetvā idāni gahaṭṭhassa dassetuṃ “so
analyzed: dhammānam upasampadāya ati atthaḥ  evam rūpa ādi gocare pabbajitassa paṭipattim dassetvā idāni gahaṭṭhassa dassetum so
translated: this is the meaning.

original: atthavā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha so atthavā so dhammaṭṭho, so dakkho so vicakkhaṇoti
analyzed: atthavā ti ādi vuttam tattha saḥ atthavā saḥ dhammaṭṭho saḥ dakkho so vicakkhaṇo ti
translated: Having thus shown the practice for one gone forth in the sphere of form and so on, now in order to show it for the house-dweller, “He who is wise” and so on is said. Herein, he who is wise, he who is firm in Dhamma, he who is clever, he who is discerning,

original: so puggalo imasmiṃ loke atthavā, buddhimā, dhamme ṭhito, dhamme dakkho, dhamme cheko,
analyzed: saḥ puggalaḥ imasmin loke atthavā buddhimā dhamme ṭhitaḥ dhamme dakkhaḥ dhamme cheko
translated: this person is wise in this world, he is intelligent, he is firm in Dhamma, he is clever in Dhamma, he is skilled in Dhamma,

original: analaso vā vicakkhaṇo iti kattabbatāsu kusalo nāma. Kareyya ramamānopi, kiccaṃ dhammatthasaṃhitanti
analyzed: analasaḥ vā vicakkhaṇaḥ iti kattabba tāsu kusalaḥ nāma kareyya ramamānaḥ api kiccam dhamma attha saṃhitan ti
translated: or he is discerning, he is skilled in what should be done. He should do what is to be done, even if he is enjoying himself, for it is connected with Dhamma and meaning.

original: geharatiyā ramamānopi dhammatthasaṃhitaṃ dhammato atthato ca anapetameva taṃ taṃ
analyzed: geha ratiyā ramamānaḥ api dhamma attha saṃhitam dhammataḥ atthataḥ ca an apetam eva tam tam
translated: Even if he is enjoying himself in the delight of the home life, he should do this and that which is to be done, which is connected with Dhamma and meaning, which is not separated from Dhamma and meaning,

original: kattabbaṃ. Anuppannānaṃ bhogānaṃ uppādanaṃ, uppannānaṃ paripālanaṃ, paribhogañca
analyzed: kattabbam anuppannānam bhogānam uppādanam uppannānam paripālanam paribhogañca
translated: the arising of wealth that has not arisen, the preservation of wealth that has arisen, the enjoyment of wealth,

original: kareyya, aññamaññaṃ, avirodhena, aññamaññaṃ, abādhanena, tivaggatthaṃ anuyuñjeyyāti
analyzed: kareyya aññamaññam avirodhena aññamaññam a bādhanena tivagga attham anuyuñjeyya ati
translated: He should pursue the three goals without conflict, without mutual obstruction.

original: adhippāyo. Ayañca nayo yesaṃ sammāpaṭipattiavirodhena tivaggatthassa vasena vattati
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ ayam ca nayaḥ yesam sammā paṭipatti avirodhena ti vagga atthassa vasena vattati
translated: This is the purport. And this method is stated in terms of those who pursue the three goals without conflict with right practice,

original: bimbisāramahārājādīnaṃ viya, tesaṃ vasena vutto. Na yesaṃ kesañci vasenāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: bimbisāra mahārāja ādīnam viya tesam vasena vuttaḥ na yesam kesañci vasena ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: like the Great King Bimbisāra and others. It should not be taken as stated in terms of just anyone.

original: Atho sīdati saññuttanti yadi idhaloke supasaṃhitaṃ diṭṭhadhammikaṃ atthaṃ pariggahetvā
analyzed: atho sīdati yadi idha loke su pasaṃhitam diṭṭhadhammikam attham pariggahetvā
translated: And he should shun what leads to loss: if he should find a goal in the here and now that is well-integrated and well-acquired,

original: ṭhitaṃ. Vajje kiccaṃ niratthakanti samparāyikattharahitaṃ anatthupasaṃhitaṃ kiccaṃ🔽sacepi vissajjeyya pariccajeyya. Na taṃ kiccanti maññitvā, appamatto vicakkhaṇoti🔽satiavippavāsena appamatto vicāraṇapaññāsambhavena vicakkhaṇo anatthupasaṃhitaṃ,
analyzed: ṭhitam vajje kiccam niratthakanti samparāyika attha rahitam anattha upasaṃhitam kiccam  sace api vissajjeyya pariccajeyya na tam kiccanti maññitvā appamattaḥ vicakkhaṇo ti  sati a vippavāsena appamattaḥ vicāraṇa paññā sambhavena vicakkhaṇaḥ anattha upasaṃhitam
translated: he should reject a goal that is useless, that is, one that is not related to the goal of the next world, even if it is given up.🔽Not thinking: “That is not my goal,” he should be heedful and discerning.

original: taṃ kiccaṃ mayā na kātabbanti maññitvā vivajjeyya.
analyzed: tam kiccam mayā na kātabbanti maññitvā vivajjeyya
translated: Not thinking: “That is not my goal,” he should be heedful through non-abandonment of mindfulness and discerning through the arising of the discernment of investigation.🔽He should shun a goal related to what is unbeneficial.

original: Vivajjetvā pana yañca atthena saññuttaṃ, yā ca dhammagatā rati. Taṃ samādāya vattethāti
analyzed: vivajjetvā pana yat ca atthena saññuttam yā ca dhamma gatā rati tam samādāya vattetha ati
translated: But having rejected, he should live by what is connected with the good of both and by delight in the Dhamma.

original: yaṃkiñci diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikappabhedena atthena hitena saṃyuttaṃ tadubhayahitāvahaṃ,
analyzed: yaṃ kiñci diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika ppa bhedena atthena hitena saṃyuttam tad ubhaya hita āvaham
translated: Whatever is connected with the good of both, which is divided into the here and now and the life to come,

original: yā ca adhikusaladhammagatā samathavipassanāsahitā rati, tadubhayaṃ sammā ādiyitvā🔽pariggahaṃ katvā vatteyya. “Sabbaṃ ratiṃ dhammarati jinātī”ti vacanato sā hi ekaṃsena
analyzed: yā ca adhi kusala dhamma gatā samatha vipassanā sahitā rati tat ubhayam sammā ādiyitvā  pariggaham katvā vatteyya sabbam ratim dhamma rati jināti iti vacanataḥ sā hi ekaṃsena
translated: and whatever delight in the Dhamma that is associated with serenity and insight, which is good in both ways,

original: uttamatthassa pāpanato uttamā rati nāma.
analyzed: uttama atthassa uttamā rati nāma
translated: he should take that all round, that is, he should take it all round by making it his all-round resort. For it is said, “Delight in the Dhamma surpasses all delights” . For that is called “supreme delight” because it is the means for attaining the supreme good.

original: Yaṃ pana kāmaratisaṃyuttaṃ kiccaṃ niratthakanti vuttaṃ, tassā anatthupasaṃhitabhāvaṃ
analyzed: yam pana kāma rati saṃyuttam kiccam niratthakam ti vuttam tassāḥ anattha upasaṃhita bhāvam
translated: But the task connected with delight in sensual desires is said to be useless.

original: dassetuṃ “uccāvacehī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha uccāvacehīti mahantehi ceva khuddakehi
analyzed: dassetum uccāvacehi itiādi vuttam tattha uccāvacehi iti mahantehi ca iva khuddakehi
translated: In order to show that it is useless he said, “By high and low devices” , etc. Herein, by high and low devices means by great and small devices.

original: ca. Upāyehīti nayehi. Paresamabhijigīsatīti paresaṃ santakaṃ āharituṃ icchati, pare
analyzed: ca upāyehi iti nayehi paresam abhijigīsati iti paresam santakam āharitum icchati pare
translated: By means of means means by means of methods. He seeks to overcome others means he wishes to take what belongs to others.

original: vā sabbathā hāpeti, jināpeti paraṃ hantvā, vadhitvā atha socayitvā, ālopati sāhasā
analyzed: vā sabbathā hāpeti jināpeti param hantvā vadhitvā atha socayitvā ālopati sāhasā
translated: He steals away all, he wins by killing others, by slaying, by tormenting, by plundering, by violence.

original: yo paresaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yo puggalo kāmahetu pare hananto, ghātento, socento🔽sandhicchedasandhiruhanapasayhāvahārādīhi nānupāyehi paresaṃ santakaṃ harituṃ vāyamanto
analyzed: yo paresam idam vuttam hoti yaḥ puggalo kāma hetu pare hanantaḥ ghātentaḥ socento  sandhi cheda sandhi ruha na pasayha avahāra ādīhi na anupāyehi paresam santakam haritum
translated: He who is bent on others’ wealth. This is the meaning: he who, for the sake of sensual desires, kills others, slays others, torments others,🔽and strives by various means such as breaking of limbs, cutting off of limbs, plundering, etc., to take the wealth of others,

original: sāhasākāraṃ karoti, ālopati, jigīsati sāpateyyavasena pare hāpeti, tassa taṃ kiccaṃ
analyzed: sāhasa ākāram karoti ālopati jigīsati sāpateyya vasena pare tassa tam kiccam
translated: and acts violently, plunders, and covets others’ wealth,

original: kāmaratisannissitaṃ anatthupasaṃhitaṃ ekantanihīnanti. Etena tappaṭipakkhato dhammagatāya
analyzed: kāma rati sannissitam anattha upasaṃhitam ekanta nihīnam ti etena tad paṭipakkhataḥ dhamma gatāya
translated: his action is based on sensual pleasure, is unbeneficial, and is entirely low. By this he shows that the pleasure based on the opposite of that,

original: ratiyā ekaṃsato uttamabhāvaṃyeva vibhāveti.🔽Idāni yaṃ “tesamāvaraṇaṃ kātuṃ yo sakkotī”ti indriyānaṃ āvaraṇaṃ vuttaṃ, taṃ upāyena
analyzed: ratiyāḥ uttama bhāvaṃyā iva  idāni yam tesam āvaraṇam kātum yaḥ sakkoti iti indriyānam āvaraṇam vuttam tam upāyena
translated: which is in conformity with the Dhamma, is entirely superior.🔽Now, the obscuring of the faculties, which was said to be “that by which one is not able to do this,”

original: saha vibhāvento “tacchanto āṇiyā āṇiṃ, nihanti balavā yathā”ti āha. Yathā balavā
analyzed: saha āṇiyā āṇim nihanti balavā yathā iti āha yathā balavā
translated: he shows together with the means of removing it, saying, “The strong man, restraining thought by thought, destroys them as a strong man a weaker man.”

original: kāyabalena, ñāṇabalena ca samannāgato tacchako rukkhadaṇḍagataṃ āṇiṃ nīharitukāmo
analyzed: kāya balena ñāṇa balena ca samannāgataḥ tad śakaḥ rukkha daṇḍa gatam āṇim nīharitu kāmo
translated: He is endowed with strength of body and strength of knowledge. He is able to draw out the arrow stuck in the body.

original: tato balavatiṃ āṇiṃ koṭento tato nīharati, tathā kusalo bhikkhu cakkhādīni indriyāni
analyzed: tatas balavatim āṇim koṭento tatas nīharati tathā kusalaḥ bhikkhu cakkha ādīni indriyāni
translated: He draws it out by striking with a strong arrow. In the same way, a wise bhikkhu,

original: vipassanābalena nihantukāmo indriyehi eva nihanti.
analyzed: vipassanā balena nihantu kāmaḥ indriyehi eva nihanti
translated: who is able to destroy the eye faculty, etc., destroys them by means of the faculties.

original: Katamehi panāti āha “saddha”ntiādi. Tassattho – adhimokkhalakkhaṇaṃ saddhaṃ, paggahalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: katamehi pana iti āha saddha ntiādi tassa atthaḥ adhimokkha lakkhaṇam saddham paggaha lakkhaṇam
translated: But by which faculties? He says: “Faith” and so on. The meaning is as follows: He develops and increases the five faculties that ripen in liberation—faith, which has the characteristic of resolve;

original: vīriyaṃ, avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ samādhiṃ, upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇaṃ satiṃ, dassanalakkhaṇaṃ🔽paññanti imānipi vimuttiparipācakāni pañcindriyāni bhāvento vaḍḍhento etehi pañcahi
analyzed: vīriyam avikkhepa lakkhaṇam samādhim upaṭṭhāna lakkhaṇam satim dassana lakkhaṇam  imāni api vimutti paripācakāni pañca indriyāni bhāventaḥ vaḍḍhentaḥ etehi pañcahi
translated: energy, which has the characteristic of exertion; concentration, which has the characteristic of non-distraction; mindfulness, which has the characteristic of establishing ;🔽and wisdom, which has the characteristic of seeing.🔽By means of these five faculties,

original: indriyehi cakkhādīni pañcindriyāni anunayapaṭighādikilesuppattiyā dvārabhāvavihanena
analyzed: indriyehi cakkha ādīni pañca indriyāni anunaya paṭigha ādi kilesa uppattiyā dvāra bhāva vihanena
translated: he destroys the five faculties of the eye, etc., by preventing the arising of defilements such as lust and ill will, which are the doors to the faculties.

original: hantvā, ariyamaggena tadupanissaye kilese samucchinditvā, tato eva anīgho niddukkho
analyzed: hantvā ariya maggena tad upanissaye kilese samucchinditvā tatas eva anīghaḥ niddukkhaḥ
translated: Having destroyed them by the noble path, he cuts off the defilements that are their proximate causes. Then he is free from bondage, free from suffering,

original: brāhmaṇo anupādisesaparinibbānameva yāti upagacchatīti.🔽So atthavāti so yathāvutto brāhmaṇo uttamatthena samannāgatattā atthavā, taṃ sampāpake
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ anupādisesa parinibbānam eva yāti upagacchati iti  so atthavā ati saḥ yathāvuttaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ uttama atthena samannāgata ttā atthavā tam sampāpake
translated: a brahmin goes to and reaches extinction without trace remaining.

original: dhamme ṭhitattā dhammaṭṭho. Sabbena sabbaṃ anavasesena vidhinā anavasesaṃ buddhassa🔽bhagavato vākyabhūtaṃ anusāsaniṃ katvā yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjitvā ṭhito. Tato eva
analyzed: dhamme ṭhita ttā dhammaṭṭho sabbena sabbam anavasesena vidhinā anavasesam buddhassa  bhagavataḥ vākya bhūtam anusāsanim katvā yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjitvā ṭhitaḥ tatas eva
translated: He is a speaker of truth: he is a speaker of truth because he possesses the highest meaning. He is a maintainer of the Dhamma: he is a maintainer of the Dhamma because he is established in the dhammas that lead to welfare. He is a follower of the Dhamma: he is a follower of the Dhamma because he has followed the entire,

original: so naro uttamapuriso nibbānasukhañca edhati, brūheti, vaḍḍhetīti.
analyzed: saḥ naraḥ uttama purisaḥ nibbāna sukham ca edhati brūheti vaḍḍheti iti
translated: unbroken, complete, pure, and purified way of practice that is the Blessed One’s instruction. He is a man: he is a man because he is a supreme person. He is a seeker of the bliss of extinction: he is a seeker of the bliss of extinction because he seeks, speaks of, and increases the bliss of extinction.

original: Evaṃ therena attano cintitākāravibhāvanāvasena paṭipattiyā pakāsitattā idameva cassa aññābyākaraṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam therena attano cintita ākāra vibhāvanā vasena paṭipattiyā pakāsita ttā idam eva cassa aññā byākaraṇam daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: Thus, since the elder has shown his practice by revealing the way he has thought, this should be regarded as his declaration of his knowledge.

original: Pārāpariyattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pārāpariya thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the verses of the elder Pārāpariya is finished.

original: 3. Telakānittheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: telakānitthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the verses of the elder Telakāni

original: Cirarattaṃ vatātāpītiādikā āyasmato telakānittherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi purimabuddhesu
analyzed: cira rattam vata atāpi iti ādikā āyasmataḥ telakāni ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi purima buddhesu
translated: The verses beginning “For a long time, enduring wind and heat” are spoken by the elder Telakāni. How did they arise? This elder too, in the time of former Buddhas,

original: katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ kusalaṃ upacinitvā imasmiṃ buddhuppāde
analyzed: kata adhikāraḥ tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭu upanissayam kusalam upacinitvā imasmin buddhuppāde
translated: Having thus made his resolve, he accumulated merit in various existences, and in this dispensation of the Buddha,

original: satthu abhijātito puretaraṃyeva sāvatthiyaṃ aññatarasmiṃ brāhmaṇakule nibbattitvā
analyzed: satthu abhijātitaḥ puretaraṃya iva sāvatthiyam aññatarasmim brāhmaṇa kule nibbattitvā
translated: he was born in Sāvatthi in the family of a brāhmaṇa, before the birth of the Teacher.

original: telakānīti laddhanāmo vayappatto hetusampannatāya kāme jigucchanto gharāvāsaṃ pahāya
analyzed: telakāni iti laddha nāmaḥ vaya ppattaḥ hetu sampanna tāya kāme jigucchantaḥ ghara āvāsam pahāya
translated: He was called Telakaṇḍaka. When he reached manhood, he became disgusted with sensual pleasures, because he was endowed with the root of merit. He left his home,

original: paribbājakapabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā vivaṭṭajjhāsayo “ko so pāraṅgato loke”tiādinā vimokkhapariyesanaṃ
analyzed: paribbājaka pabbajjam pabbajitvā kaḥ saḥ pāraṅgataḥ loka iti ādinā vimokkha pariyesanam
translated: and became a wanderer. He was desirous of deliverance. He went about seeking deliverance, asking such questions as, “Who has crossed the flood?”

original: caramāno te te samaṇabrāhmaṇe upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchati, te na sampāyanti. So
analyzed: caramānaḥ te te samaṇa brāhmaṇe upasaṅkamitvā pañham pucchati te na sampāyanti saḥ
translated: He approached various recluses and brāhmaṇas, and asked them questions, but they were unable to satisfy him.

original: tena anārādhitacitto vicarati. Atha amhākaṃ bhagavati loke uppajjitvā pavattitavaradhammacakke
analyzed: tena an ārādhita cittaḥ vicarati atha amhākam bhagavati loke uppajjitvā pavattita vara dhamma cakke
translated: Discontented, he wandered about. Then, when our Lord Buddha appeared in the world, and set rolling the wheel of the Dhamma,

original: lokahitaṃ karonte ekadivasaṃ satthāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā dhammaṃ sutvā paṭiladdhasaddho
analyzed: loka hitam karonte eka divasam satthāram upasaṅkamitvā dhammam sutvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ
translated: and began to work for the welfare of the world, he approached the Teacher one day, and hearing the Dhamma, he obtained faith.

original: pabbajitvā vipassanāya kammaṃ karonto nacirasseva arahatte patiṭṭhāti. So ekadivasaṃ
analyzed: pabbajitvā vipassanāya kammam karontaḥ nacirassa iva arahatte patiṭṭhāti saḥ eka divasam
translated: He became a monk, and in no long time attained Arahatship by the practice of insight. One day,

original: bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ nisinno attanā adhigatavisesaṃ paccavekkhitvā tadanusārena attano
analyzed: bhikkhūhi saddhim nisinnaḥ attanā adhigata visesam paccavekkhitvā tad anusārena attano
translated: Sitting together with the monks, he reviewed the distinction he had attained, and recollecting his own practice in accordance with that,

original: paṭipattiṃ anussaritvā taṃ sabbaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ ācikkhanto –
analyzed: paṭipattim anussaritvā tam sabbam bhikkhūnam ācikkhantaḥ
translated: he told all that to the monks, saying:

original: “Cirarattaṃ vatātāpī, dhammaṃ anuvicintayaṃ;
analyzed: cira rattam vata ātāpī dhammaṃ anuvicintayan
translated: “For a long time I have been tormented by wind and heat,🔽contemplating the Dhamma, but I did not attain evenness of mind,

original: Samaṃ cittassa nālatthaṃ, pucchaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇe.
analyzed: samam cittassa na alattham puccham samaṇa brāhmaṇe
translated: so I asked ascetics and brahmins.

original: “Ko so pāraṅgato loke, ko patto amatogadhaṃ;
analyzed: kaḥ saḥ loke kaḥ
translated: “Who has gone beyond in the world? Who has attained the deathless state?

original: Kassa dhammaṃ paṭicchāmi, paramatthavijānanaṃ.
analyzed: kassa dhammam paṭicchāmi parama attha vijānanam
translated: Whose Dhamma will I accept, the knowledge of the ultimate truth?

original: “Antovaṅkagato āsi, macchova ghasamāmisaṃ;
analyzed: antar vaṅka gataḥ āsi maccha uva ghasam amisam
translated: “He was caught in his own noose, like a fish in a snare,

original: Baddho mahindapāsena, vepacityasuro yathā.
analyzed: baddhaḥ mahinda pāsena vepa citi asuraḥ yathā
translated: bound by the noose of Māra, like the demon Vepacitti.

original: “Añchāmi naṃ na muñcāmi, asmā sokapariddavā;
analyzed: añchāmi nam na muñcāmi asmai soka pariddavā
translated: “I cling to him, I do not let go, from this grief and lamentation,

original: Ko me bandhaṃ muñcaṃ loke, sambodhiṃ vedayissati.
analyzed: kaḥ me bandham muñcam loke sambodhim vedayissati
translated: who in the world will release me from the bond, and make me experience full enlightenment?

original: “Samaṇaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ vā kaṃ, ādisantaṃ pabhaṅgunaṃ;
analyzed: samaṇam brāhmaṇam vā kam ādisantam pabhaṅgunam
translated: “Which ascetic or brahmin, who proclaims a doctrine of breaking up,

original: Kassa dhammaṃ paṭicchāmi, jarāmaccupavāhanaṃ.
analyzed: kassa dhammam paṭicchāmi jarā maccu pavāhanam
translated: whose Dhamma will I accept, the chariot that carries away old age and death?

original: “Vicikicchākaṅkhāganthitaṃ, sārambhabalasaññutaṃ;
analyzed: vicikicchā kaṅkhā ganthitam sa ārambha bala saññu tam
translated: “Bound by doubt and uncertainty, with a sense of urgency and strength,

original: Kodhappattamanatthaddhaṃ, abhijappappadāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: kodha ppattam anatthaddham abhijappa ppadāraṇam
translated: The arrow of anger, the shaft of conceit, the shaft of pride, the shaft of arrogance, the shaft of self-praise, the shaft of disparaging others.

original: “Taṇhādhanusamuṭṭhānaṃ, dve ca pannarasāyutaṃ;
analyzed: taṇhā dhanu samuṭṭhānam dve ca pannarasa ayutam
translated: “The bow of craving, the two shafts of delusion and ignorance, the two shafts of the five hindrances and the five aggregates, the two shafts of the six internal and external sense bases.

original: Passa orasikaṃ bāḷhaṃ, bhetvāna yadi tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: passaḥ orasikam bāḷham bhetvāna yadi tiṭṭhati
translated: “If one can see this great and terrible arrow, and can pull it out, one can stand.

original: “Anudiṭṭhīnaṃ appahānaṃ, saṅkappaparatejitaṃ;
analyzed: anudiṭṭhīnam appahānam saṅkappa para tejitam
translated: “The non-abandonment of wrong views, the shaft of wrong thought, the shaft of wrong speech, the shaft of wrong action, the shaft of wrong livelihood, the shaft of wrong effort, the shaft of wrong mindfulness, the shaft of wrong concentration.

original: Tena viddho pavedhāmi, pattaṃva māluteritaṃ.
analyzed: tena viddhaḥ pavedhāmi māluta īritam
translated: “I am pierced by these shafts, and I am shaking like a palm leaf in the wind.

original: “Ajjhattaṃ me samuṭṭhāya, khippaṃ paccati māmakaṃ;
analyzed: ajjhattam me samuṭṭhāya khippam paccati māmakam
translated: “Arisen from within me, it quickly burns me.

original: Chaphassāyatanī kāyo, yattha sarati sabbadā.
analyzed: cha phassa āyatanī kāyaḥ yattha sarati sabbadā
translated: The body with its six sense bases, where it always goes.

original: “Taṃ na passāmi tekicchaṃ, yo metaṃ sallamuddhare;
analyzed: tam na passāmi tekiccham yaḥ mā etam sallam uddhare
translated: “I do not see a doctor who can pull out this shaft,

original: Nānārajjena satthena, nāññena vicikicchitaṃ.
analyzed: na anārajjena satthena na aññena vicikicchitam
translated: With a knife of various colors, not with any other.

original: “Ko me asattho avaṇo, sallamabbhantarapassayaṃ;
analyzed: kaḥ me asatthaḥ avaṇaḥ sallam abbhantara passayam
translated: “Who is my friend without a shaft, without a wound, with a shaft within his sight?

original: Ahiṃsaṃ sabbagattāni, sallaṃ me uddharissati.
analyzed: ahiṃsam sabba gattāni sallam me uddharissati
translated: He will pull out my shaft without harming any part of my body.

original: “Dhammappati hi so seṭṭho, visadosappavāhako;
analyzed: dhammappati hi so seṭṭhaḥ visa dosa ppavāhako
translated: “The best friend is the Dhamma, the remover of poison.

original: Gambhīre patitassa me, thalaṃ pāṇiñca dassaye.🔽“Rahadehamasmi ogāḷho, ahāriyarajamattike;
analyzed: gambhīre patitassa me thalam pāṇiñca dassaye  ogāḍhaḥ
translated: For one who has fallen into the deep, he shows the shore and the hand.🔽“I am submerged in the body of craving, in the mire of non-giving.

original: Māyāusūyasārambha, thinamiddhamapatthaṭe.
analyzed: māyā usūya sārambha thinam iddham apatthaṭe
translated: In deceit, envy, and anger, in sloth and torpor, in doubt.

original: “Uddhaccameghathanitaṃ, saṃyojanavalāhakaṃ;
analyzed: uddhacca megha thanitam saṃyojana valāhakam
translated: “The cloud of restlessness thunders, the rain of fetters pours down;

original: Vāhā vahanti kuddiṭṭhiṃ, saṅkappā rāganissitā.
analyzed: vāhāḥ vahanti kuddiṭṭhim saṅkappāḥ rāga nissitā
translated: The current carries away wrong view, thoughts based on passion.

original: “Savanti sabbadhi sotā, latā ubbhijja tiṭṭhati;
analyzed: savanti sabbadhi sotā latā ubbhijja tiṭṭhati
translated: “The streams flow everywhere, the creeper grows up and stands;

original: Te sote ko nivāreyya, taṃ lataṃ ko hi checchati.
analyzed: te sote kaḥ nivāreyya tam latam kaḥ hi checchati
translated: Who will stop those streams? Who will cut down that creeper?

translated: burns quickly, burns fast, like a fire with its fuel. Like what fire? Like a fire that burns with its own fuel.

original: taṃyeva māmakaṃ mama santakaṃ attabhāvaṃ ḍahanto yattha uppanno, tattheva sarati pavattati.🔽Taṃ na passāmi tekicchanti tādisāya tikicchāya niyuttatāya tekicchaṃ sallakattaṃ🔽bhisakkaṃ taṃ na passāmi. Yo metaṃ sallamuddhareti yo bhisakko etaṃ diṭṭhisallaṃ
analyzed: taṃya iva māmakam mama santakam atta bhāvam ḍahantaḥ yattha uppannaḥ tattha iva sarati pavattati  tam na passāmi tekicchanti tādisāya tikicchāya niyutta tāya tekiccham sallakattam  bhisakkam tam na passāmi yaḥ mā etam sallam uddhareti yaḥ bhisakkaḥ etam diṭṭhi sallam
translated: Burning that very self of mine, it goes on burning where it arises.🔽I do not see a doctor who could cure it with such a treatment, with a treatment of a hundred thousand.🔽I do not see a doctor who could remove this dart, who could remove this dart of view

original: kilesasallañca uddhareyya, uddharanto ca nānārajjena rajjusadisasaṅkhātāya esanisalākāya
analyzed: kilesa sallam ca uddhareyya uddharantaḥ ca nānā rajjena rajju sadisa saṅkhātāya esanisalākāya
translated: and this dart of defilement. And removing it, he would not insert another dart, a dart called a rope,

original: pavesetvāna satthena kantitvā nāññena mantāgadappayogena vicikicchitaṃ sallaṃ tikicchituṃ
analyzed: pavesetvāna satthena kantitvā na aññena mantā gada ppayogena vicikicchitam sallam tikicchitum
translated: and having pierced it with a knife, he would not treat the dart of doubt with any other means of incantation.

original: sakkāti āharitvā yojetabbaṃ. Vicikicchitanti, ca nidassanamattametaṃ. Sabbassapi
analyzed: sakkā iti āharitvā yojetabbam vicikicchitanti ca nidassanam attam etam sabbassa api
translated: “Can be removed” should be construed with “doubt” as well.

original: kilesasallassa vasena attho veditabbo.🔽Asatthoti sattharahito. Avaṇoti vaṇena vinā. Abbhantarapassayanti abbhantarasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: kilesa sallassa vasena atthaḥ veditabbo  asatthaḥ ti sattha rahitaḥ a vaṇoti vaṇena vinā abbhantara passayanti abbhantara saṅkhātam
translated: The meaning should be understood in terms of all the defilements,🔽which are “enemies” .🔽“Without an enemy” : without a slayer. “Without a wound” : without a wound. “Within the heart” : situated within the heart, which is called the “inner” .

original: hadayaṃ nissāya ṭhitaṃ. Ahiṃsanti apīḷento. “Ahiṃsā”ti ca pāṭho, ahiṃsāya apīḷanenāti🔽attho. Ayañhettha saṅkhepattho – ko nu kho kiñci satthaṃ aggahetvā vaṇañca akaronto🔽tato eva sabbagattāni abādhento mama hadayabbhantaragataṃ pīḷājananato anto tudanato
analyzed: hadayam nissāya ṭhitam a hiṃsanti a pīḷentaḥ ahiṃsa ati ca pāṭhaḥ ahiṃsāya a pīḷanena ati  atthaḥ ayam ha ittha saṅkhepa atthaḥ kaḥ nu kho kiñci sattham aggahetvā vaṇam ca a karontaḥ  tatas eva sabba gattāni a bādhentaḥ mama hadaya bbhantara gatam pīḷā jananataḥ antar tudanataḥ
translated: “Without violence” : without oppression. The reading “ahiṃsā” is also correct; the meaning is “without oppression by non-violence” .🔽The condensed meaning here is this: “Who will remove the defilements, which are enemies, from within my heart, which is a house, without taking up a weapon, without causing a wound,

original: anto ruddhanato ca paramattheneva sallabhūtaṃ kilesasallaṃ uddharissatīti.
analyzed: antar ruddha nataḥ ca paramatthena iva salla bhūtam kilesa sallam uddharissati iti
translated: without afflicting any of the bodily parts, without violence, without oppression, without causing pain, without causing obstruction, in the ultimate sense?”

original: Evaṃ dasahi gāthāhi pubbe attanā cintitākāraṃ dassetvā punapi taṃ pakārantarena dassetuṃ
analyzed: evam dasahi gāthāhi pubbe attanā cintita ākāram dassetvā puna api tam pakāra antarena dassetum
translated: Having thus shown the mode of reflection in ten stanzas, he again shows it in another way:

original: “dhammappati hi so seṭṭho”tiādimāha. Tattha dhammappatīti dhammanimittaṃ dhammahetu.
analyzed: dhamma ppati hi so seṭṭhaḥ ti ādim āha tattha dhamma ppati iti dhamma nimittam dhamma hetu
translated: Herein, he has the Dhamma as his guide : he has the sign of the Dhamma as his guide, the Dhamma as his cause.🔽Hi is merely a particle. The best : the most excellent person.

original: Hīti nipātamattaṃ. So seṭṭhoti so puggalo uttamo. Visadosappavāhakoti yo mayhaṃ rāgādikilesassa🔽pavāhako ucchinnako. Gambhīre patitassa me, thalaṃ pāṇiñca dassayeti ko nu kho atigambhīre
analyzed: hi iti nipāta mattam so seṭṭhaḥ ti so puggalaḥ uttamaḥ visa dosa pavāhako ti yaḥ mayham rāga ādi kilesassa  pavāhakaḥ ucchinnakaḥ gambhīre patitassa me thalam pāṇiñca dassaya iti kaḥ nu kho ati gambhīre
translated: The poison-dispeller : he who dispels, removes, my defilement of lust, etc.,

original: saṃsāramahoghe patitassa mayhaṃ “mā bhāyī”ti assāsento nibbānathalaṃ taṃsampāpakaṃ
analyzed: saṃsāra mahā oghe patitassa mayham mā bhāyi iti assāsentaḥ nibbāna thalam tad sampāpakam
translated: The one who shows me the shore and hand when I have fallen into the deep : who will show me the shore of extinction and the hand of the noble path that leads to it, giving me confidence by saying “Do not fear” when I have fallen into the great flood of the samsara ocean,

original: ariyamaggahatthañca dasseyya.
analyzed: ariya magga hatthañca dasseyya
translated: deep and fathomless?

original: Rahadehamasmi ogāḷhoti mahati saṃsārarahade ahamasmi sasīsaṃ nimujjanavasena otiṇṇo🔽anupaviṭṭho. Ahāriyarajamattiketi apanetuṃ asakkuṇeyyo rāgādirajo mattikā kaddamo
analyzed: rahadeham asmi mahati saṃsāra rahade aham asmi sa sīsam nimujjana vasena otiṇṇaḥ  an upaviṭṭhaḥ a hāriya raja mattikā iti apanetum a sakkuṇeyyaḥ rāga ādi rajaḥ mattikā kaddamaḥ
translated: I am sunk in the mire of the great pit of samsara : I am sunk, submerged, up to my head, in the great pit of samsara.🔽The mire of hard-to-cross mud : the mud of the defilements of lust, etc., which is hard to cross over, hard to get out of.

original: etassāti ahāriyarajamattiko, rahado. Tasmiṃ rahadasmiṃ. “Ahāriyarajamantike”ti vā
analyzed: etassa ati ahāriyarajamattikaḥ rahadaḥ tasmin rahadasmin ahāriyarajamantikā iti vā
translated: He who has that is the one who has the mire of hard-to-cross mud, the pit. In that pit. “Aharīyarajamantike” is an alternative reading.

original: pāṭho, antike ṭhitarāgādīsu dunnīharaṇīyarāgādirajeti attho. Santadosapaṭicchādanalakkhaṇā
analyzed: antike ṭhita rāga ādīsu dunnīharaṇīya rāga ādi rajā iti attho santa dosa paṭicchādana lakkhaṇā
translated: Deceit has the characteristic of concealing one’s real faults.🔽Envy has the characteristic of inability to bear another’s success.🔽Violence has the characteristic of doing harm.

original: māyā, parasampattiasahanalakkhaṇā usūyā, karaṇuttariyakaraṇalakkhaṇo sārambho, cittālasiyalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: māyā para sampatti a sahana lakkhaṇā usūyā karaṇa uttariya karaṇa lakkhaṇaḥ sa ārambhaḥ citta alasiya lakkhaṇam
translated: Dullness has the characteristic of mental sluggishness.

original: thinaṃ, kāyālasiyalakkhaṇaṃ middhanti ime pāpadhammā patthaṭā yaṃ rahadaṃ, tasmiṃ🔽māyāusūyasārambhathinamiddhamapatthaṭe, makāro cettha padasandhikaro vutto. Yathāvuttehi
analyzed: thinam kāya alasiya lakkhaṇam ime pāpa dhammā patthaṭāḥ yam rahadam tasmin  māyā usūya sārambha thinamiddham apatthaṭe makāraḥ ca ittha pada sandhi karaḥ vuttaḥ yathā vuttehi
translated: Drowsiness has the characteristic of bodily sluggishness.

original: imehi pāpadhammehi patthaṭeti attho.
analyzed: imehi pāpa dhammehi patthaṭā iti atthaḥ
translated: These evil things are the mud in the pool.🔽In the pool of deceit, envy, violence, dullness, and drowsiness,

original: Uddhaccameghathanitaṃ, saṃyojanavalāhakanti vacanavipallāsena vuttaṃ, bhantasabhāvaṃ
analyzed: uddhacca megha thanitam saṃyojana valāhakanti vacana vipallāsena vuttam
translated: The meaning is: in the pool that is muddied by these evil things stated as above.🔽The cloud of agitation, the lightning of the fetters,🔽The meaning is: the cloud of agitation, the lightning of the fetters. Agitation is the state of agitation.

original: uddhaccaṃ meghathanitaṃ meghagajjitaṃ etesanti uddhaccameghathanitā. Dasavidhā saṃyojanā
analyzed: uddhaccam megha thanitam megha gajjitam uddhacca megha thanitā dasavidhā saṃyojanā
translated: The lightning of the cloud of agitation is the lightning of the cloud of agitation. The ten fetters

original: eva valāhakā etesanti saṃyojanavalāhakā. Vāhā mahāudakavāhasadisā rāganissitā micchāsaṅkappā
analyzed: eva valāhakāḥ etesanti saṃyojana valāhakāḥ vāhāḥ mahā udaka vāha sadisāḥ rāga nissitāḥ micchā saṅkappā
translated: are the clouds in this. The meaning is: the lightning of the clouds of the fetters. The wrong thoughts associated with greed are like the great downpours of water.

original: asubhādīsu ṭhitā kuddiṭṭhiṃ maṃ vahanti apāyasamuddameva uddissa kaḍḍhantīti attho.
analyzed: asubha ādīsu ṭhitā kuddiṭṭhim mam vahanti a pāyasa muddam eva uddissa kaḍḍhanti iti attho
translated: The meaning is that they carry me along to the states of deprivation, to the ocean of suffering, as though they were taking me to the place of my choice.

original: Savanti sabbadhi sotāti taṇhāsoto, diṭṭhisoto, mānasoto, avijjāsoto, kilesasototi
analyzed: savanti sabbadhi sotā ti taṇhā sotaḥ diṭṭhi sotaḥ māna sotaḥ avijjā sotaḥ kilesa sototi
translated: “Flowing everywhere” : the craving stream, the view stream, the conceit stream, the ignorance stream, the defilement stream.🔽These five streams flow in all objects such as visible forms, etc., through the eye door, etc. Or they flow everywhere by flowing in all aspects, such as “craving for visible forms” … “craving for mental objects.”

original: Velaṃ karothāti tesaṃ sotānaṃ velaṃ setuṃ karotha sannivāraṇaṃ. Bhaddanteti ālapanākāradassanaṃ.🔽Mā te manomayo sototi udakasoto oḷāriko, tassa bālamahājanenapi setuṃ katvā nivāraṇaṃ

translated: Make a dam : make a dam, a barrier, for those streams. Bhaddante : this shows the mode of address.

original: sakkā. Ayaṃ pana manomayo soto sukhumo dunnivāraṇo. So yathā udakasoto vaḍḍhanto
analyzed: sakkā ayam pana manaḥ mayaḥ soto sukhumaḥ dunnivāraṇo saḥ yathā udaka soto vaḍḍhanto

analyzed: kūle ṭhitam rukkham pātetvā ava nāseti evam tumhe apāya tīre ṭhite tattha sahasā pātetvā
translated: overthrows a tree standing on the bank and destroys it. So also, you, standing on the bank of the states of woe, will suddenly be overthrown there and

analyzed: a pāyasa muddam pāpentaḥ mā luve mā vināseyya mā anaya byasanam pāpeyya ati attho
translated: be cast into the ocean of states of woe. Do not be destroyed, do not be ruined, do not be brought to destruction and ruin.

original: Evaṃ ayaṃ thero purimattabhāve parimadditasaṅkhārattā ñāṇaparipākaṃ gatattā pavattidukkhaṃ
analyzed: evam ayam thero purimatta bhāve ñāṇa paripākam gata ttā pavatti dukkham
translated: Thus this elder, because of the rubbing away of the formations in his previous existence, and because of the maturity of his knowledge,🔽having reflected on the suffering of existence,

original: upadhārento yathā vicikicchādike saṃkilesadhamme pariggaṇhi, tamākāraṃ dassetvā idāni
analyzed: upadhārentaḥ yathā vicikicchā ādike saṃkilesa dhamme pariggaṇhi tam ākāram dassetvā idāni
translated: having discerned such defiled states as doubt, etc., and having shown that mode,

original: jātasaṃvego kiṃkusalagavesī satthu santikaṃ gato yaṃ visesaṃ adhimucci, taṃ dassento
analyzed: jāta saṃvegaḥ kiṃkusala gavesī satthu santikam gataḥ yam visesam tam dassentaḥ
translated: now, being stirred to his heart’s core and seeking what is wholesome, having gone into the presence of the Teacher, attained a distinction,🔽and showing that distinction, he said:

original: “evaṃ me bhayajātassā”tiādimāha. Tattha evaṃ me bhayajātassāti evaṃ vuttappakārena🔽saṃsāre jātabhayassa apārā orimatīrato sappaṭibhayato saṃsāravaṭṭato “kathaṃ nu kho🔽muñceyya”nti pāraṃ nibbānaṃ, esato gavesato, tāṇo sadevakassa lokassa tāṇabhūto kilesasamucchedanī🔽paññā āvudho etassāti paññāvudho. Diṭṭhadhammikādiatthena sattānaṃ yathārahaṃ anusāsanato
analyzed: evam me bhaya jātassa ati ādim āha tattha evam me bhaya jātassa ati evam vutta ppakārena  saṃsāre jāta bhayassa apārā orima tīrataḥ sa paṭibhayataḥ saṃsāra vaṭṭataḥ katham nu kho  muñceyyanti pāram nibbānam esataḥ gavesataḥ tāṇo sa devakassa lokassa tāṇa bhūto kilesa samucchedanī  paññā āvudhaḥ etassa ati paññāvudhaḥ diṭṭhadhammika ādi atthena sattānam yathāraham anusāsanato
translated: “Thus, being frightened, etc.” Herein, thus being frightened means thus being frightened in the way stated above.🔽In the round of rebirths, which is without any apparent end, without any near or far side, with fear, with the round of rebirths as its opposite, “How, indeed,🔽might I be freed from this?” — seeking the other shore, which is Nibbāna, a refuge for the world with its gods, a state of refuge that is the cutting off of defilements,🔽a weapon of wisdom. He who has this is a “weapon-bearer of wisdom.” Because he instructs beings in the way appropriate to each, according to the meaning of the present life, etc.,🔽

original: “iminā te sotthi bhavissatī”ti samassāsento mā bhāyīti ca abravi, kathesi.
analyzed: iminā te sotthi bhavissati iti samassāsentaḥ mā bhāyi iti ca abravi kathesi
translated: and he spoke the verse beginning, “Do not fear,” encouraging him, saying, “By this you will be safe.”

original: Satipaṭṭhānapāsādanti tena vipassanāsopānena kāyānupassanādinā laddhabbacatubbidhasāmaññaphalavisesena

translated: The Palace of the Arousing of Mindfulness: having ascended the palace of the arousing of mindfulness, which is endowed with the four stages and which is the special fourfold fruit of recluseship that can be obtained by means of the means of insight, namely, contemplation of the body, etc.,

analyzed: deva lokā cavitvāna sukka mūlena coditaḥ
translated: “Having fallen from the world of the gods, urged on by the root of merit,

analyzed: aḍḍhe kule mahā bhoge nibbattissati tāvade
translated: He will be reborn in a wealthy and prosperous family.

original: “So pacchā pabbajitvāna, sukkamūlena codito;
analyzed: so pacchā pabbajitvāna sukka mūlena coditaḥ
translated: “Later, having gone forth, urged on by the root of merit,
