analyzed: raṭṭhapālaḥ iti nāmena hessati satthu sāvako
translated: He will be a disciple of the Teacher named Raṭṭhapāla.

original: “Padhānapahitatto so, upasanto nirūpadhi;
analyzed: saḥ upasantaḥ
translated: “He will be devoted to striving, peaceful, and free from attachments;

original: Sabbāsave pariññāya, nibbāyissatināsavo.
analyzed: sabba asave pariññāya
translated: Having fully understood all the pollutants, he will be extinguished, without pollutants.

original: “Uṭṭhāya abhinikkhamma, jahitā bhogasampadā;
analyzed: uṭṭhāya abhinikkhamma jahitā bhoga sampadā
translated: “Having risen and gone forth, having abandoned the wealth of possessions,

original: Kheḷapiṇḍeva bhogamhi, pemaṃ mayhaṃ na vijjati.
analyzed: kheḷa piṇḍā iva bhogamhi mayham na vijjati
translated: I have no affection for wealth, as if it were a lump of spittle.

original: “Vīriyaṃ me dhuradhorayhaṃ, yogakkhemādhivāhanaṃ;
analyzed: vīriyam me yoga khema adhivāhanam
translated: “My energy is the yoke-bearing beast, the vehicle for attaining security;

original: Dhāremi antimaṃ dehaṃ, sammāsambuddhasāsane.
analyzed: dhāremi antimam deham sammāsambuddha sāsane
translated: I bear this last body in the Dispensation of the Perfectly Awakened One.

original: “Paṭisambhidā catasso, vimokkhāpi ca aṭṭhime;
analyzed: paṭisambhidā catasso vimokkhā api ca aṭṭhime
translated: “The four analytical insights, and also the eight liberations,

original: Chaḷabhiññā sacchikatā, kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: chaṭṭhā abhiññā sacchikatā katam buddhassa sāsanam ti
translated: The six supernormal knowledges have been realized; the Buddha’s Dispensation has been done.”

original: Arahattaṃ pana patvā satthāraṃ anujānāpetvā mātāpitaro passituṃ thullakoṭṭhikaṃ gantvā,
analyzed: arahattam pana patvā satthāram anujānāpetvā mātā pitaro passitum thullakoṭṭhikam gantvā
translated: But after attaining Liberation, having obtained the Teacher’s permission, he went to Thullakoṭṭhika to see his parents,

original: tattha sapadānaṃ piṇḍāya caranto pitu nivesane ābhidosikaṃ kummāsaṃ labhitvā taṃ🔽amataṃ viya paribhuñjanto, pitarā nimantito svātanāya adhivāsetvā, dutiyadivase pitu🔽nivesane piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā alaṅkatapaṭiyatte itthāgārajane upagantvā “kīdisā
analyzed: tattha sa padānam piṇḍāya carantaḥ pitu nivesane ābhidosikam kummāsam labhitvā tam  amatam viya paribhuñjantaḥ pitarā nimantitaḥ svātanāya adhivāsetvā dutiya divase  nivesane piṇḍapātam paribhuñjitvā alaṅkata paṭiyatte itthā āgāra jane upagantvā kīdisā
translated: As he was going his round for alms, he came to his father’s house and received a portion of boiled rice and kidney-beans.🔽He ate it as if it were ambrosia, and when his father invited him to take his meal with him the next day, he accepted the invitation.

original: nāma tā, ayyaputta, accharāyo, yāsaṃ tvaṃ hetu brahmacariyaṃ carasī”tiādīni vatvā,
analyzed: nāma tāḥ ayya putta accharāyaḥ yāsam tvam hetu brahmacariyam carasi itiādīni vatvā
translated: The next day he took his meal in his father’s house. After the meal he went to the harem, where the women were all decked out in finery. “What are these like, my dear? ” they asked. “The celestial nymphs for whose sake you lead the life of a monk.”

original: palobhanakammaṃ kātuṃ āraddhe tassa adhippāyaṃ parivattetvā aniccatādipaṭisaṃyuttaṃ dhammaṃ kathento –
analyzed: palobhana kammam kātum āraddhe tassa adhippāyam parivattetvā anicca tā ādi paṭisaṃyuttam dhammam kathentaḥ
translated: They began to tempt him, but he turned their intentions aside and preached to them the Law as it is set forth in the following stanzas:

original: “Passa cittakataṃ bimbaṃ, arukāyaṃ samussitaṃ;
analyzed: passa citta katam bimbam aru kāyam samussitam
translated: “Behold the painted figure, set up in the house,

original: Āturaṃ bahusaṅkappaṃ, yassa natthi dhuvaṃ ṭhiti.
analyzed: āturam bahu saṅkappam yassa natthi dhuvam ṭhiti
translated: The sick man, full of thoughts, who hath no abiding.

original: “Passa cittakataṃ rūpaṃ, maṇinā kuṇḍalena ca;
analyzed: passa citta katam rūpam maṇinā kuṇḍalena ca
translated: “Behold the figure, well-painted with jewels and earrings,

original: Aṭṭhiṃ tacena onaddhaṃ, saha vatthehi sobhati.
analyzed: aṭṭhim tacena onaddham saha vatthehi sobhati
translated: The bone covered with skin, shining with its raiment.

original: “Alattakakatā pādā, mukhaṃ cuṇṇakamakkhitaṃ;
analyzed: alattaka katā pādāḥ mukham cuṇṇaka makkhitam
translated: “The feet painted with lac, the face anointed with powder,

original: Alaṃ bālassa mohāya, no ca pāragavesino.
analyzed: alam bālassa mohāya no ca pāra gavesinaḥ
translated: Enough to make a fool go mad, But not enough for one who seeks the further shore.

original: “Aṭṭhāpadakatā kesā, nettā añjanamakkhitā;
analyzed: aṭṭhāpada katā kesāḥ nettāḥ añjana makkhitā
translated: His hair is done in eight-strand plait, His eyebrows painted with collyrium,

original: Alaṃ bālassa mohāya, no ca pāragavesino.
analyzed: alam bālassa mohāya no ca pāra gavesinaḥ
translated: Enough to make a fool go mad, But not enough for one who seeks the further shore.

original: “Añjanīva navā cittā, pūtikāyo alaṅkato;
analyzed: añjanī iva navā cittā pūti kāyaḥ alaṅkataḥ
translated: Like a new toy, his body decked, With foulness all concealed,

original: Alaṃ bālassa mohāya, no ca pāragavesino.
analyzed: alam bālassa mohāya no ca pāra gavesinaḥ
translated: Enough to make a fool go mad, But not enough for one who seeks the further shore.

original: “Odahi migavo pāsaṃ, nāsadā vāguraṃ migo;
analyzed: migavaḥ pāsam nāsadā vāguram migo
translated: The deer has caught the snare, The deer has not escaped the snare.

original: Bhutvā nivāpaṃ gacchāma, kandante migabandhake.
analyzed: bhutvā nivāpam gacchāma kandante migabandhake
translated: Having eaten bait, we go away, The deer-trapper cries in vain.

original: “Chinno pāso migavassa, nāsadā vāguraṃ migo;
analyzed: chinnaḥ pāsaḥ migavassa nāsadā vāguram migaḥ
translated: The deer has cut the snare, The deer has escaped the snare.

original: Bhutvā nivāpaṃ gacchāma, socante migaluddake”ti. – imā gāthā abhāsi;🔽Tattha cittakatanti cittaṃ kataṃ cittakataṃ, vatthābharaṇamālādīhi vicittaṃ katanti
analyzed: bhutvā nivāpam gacchāma socante migaluddaka iti imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi  tattha citta katanti cittam katam citta katam vattha ābharaṇa mālā ādīhi vicittam katanti
translated: Having eaten bait, we go away, The deer-trapper grieves in vain.

original: attho. Bimbanti dīghādibhāvena yuttaṭṭhānesu dīghādīhi aṅgapaccaṅgehi maṇḍitaṃ attabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: atthaḥ bimbanti dīgha ādi bhāvena yutta ṭṭhānesu dīgha ādīhi aṅga paccaṅgehi maṇḍitam atta bhāvam
translated: Herein, done with thought is thought-made , made with various things such as cloth, ornaments, garlands, etc., is made with thought , the meaning is. Image is a self-image adorned with limbs and minor limbs that are long, etc., in the places where they should be long, etc.

original: Arukāyanti navannaṃ vaṇamukhānaṃ lomakūpānañca vasena vissandamānaasuciṃ, sabbaso
analyzed: arukāyanti nava annam vaṇa mukhānam lomakūpānam ca vasena vissandamāna asucim sabbaso
translated: A foul-smelling body is one that oozes foulness in every way by means of the nine orifices and the pores of the body-hairs.

original: ca arubhūtaṃ vaṇabhūtaṃ arūnaṃ vā kāyaṃ. Samussitanti tīhi aṭṭhisatehi samussitaṃ.🔽Āturanti sabbakālaṃ iriyāpathantarādīhi pariharitabbatāya niccaṃ gilānaṃ. Bahusaṅkappanti
analyzed: ca aru bhūtam vaṇa bhūtam arūnam vā kāyam samussitanti tīhi aṭṭhi satehi samussitam  āturanti sabba kālam iriyāpatha antara ādīhi pariharitabba tāya niccam gilānam bahu saṅkappanti
translated: and it is a wound, a sore, a boil, a festering sore, a putrid thing. “Heap” : heaped up with three hundred bones.🔽“Sickly” : always sick, because it must be constantly looked after with the four postures, etc., by the foolish. “Much thought” :

original: bālajanena abhūtaṃ āropetvā bahudhā saṅkappitabbaṃ. Yassa natthi dhuvaṃ ṭhitīti yassa
analyzed: bāla janena abhūtam āropetvā bahudhā saṅkappitabbam yassa natthi dhuvam ṭhiti iti yassa
translated: it must be thought about in many ways by the foolish, who attribute to it what is not so. “It has no stable state” :

original: kāyassa dhuvabhāvo ṭhitisabhāvo natthi, ekaṃsato bhedanavikiraṇaviddhaṃsanadhammoyeva.
analyzed: kāyassa dhuva bhāvaḥ ṭhiti sabhāvaḥ natthi ekaṃsataḥ
translated: this body has no stable state, no state of firmness, it is by nature subject to breaking up, scattering, and dissolution.

original: Taṃ passāti samīpe ṭhitaṃ janaṃ, attānameva vā sandhāya vadati.🔽Rūpanti sarīraṃ. Sarīrampi hi “aṭṭhiñca paṭicca, nhāruñca paṭicca, maṃsañca paṭicca,
analyzed: tam passāti samīpe ṭhitam janam attānam eva vā sandhāya vadati  rūpanti sarīram sarīram pi hi aṭṭhim ca paṭicca nhārum ca paṭicca maṃsam ca paṭicca
translated: “He sees” : he sees a person standing nearby, or he speaks with reference to himself.

original: cammañca paṭicca, ākāso parivārito ‘rūpantveva saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”tiādīsu rūpanti vuccati.
analyzed: cammañca paṭicca ākāsaḥ parivāritaḥ rūpam tu eva saṅkham gacchati iti ādīsu rūpam vuccati
translated: “Form” : the body. For the body is called “form” in such passages as “The space element is form that is not clung to, derived from the four great primaries” .

original: Maṇinā kuṇḍalena cāti sīsūpagādiābharaṇagatena maṇinā kuṇḍalena cittakataṃ. Aṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: maṇinā kuṇḍalena ca ati sīsūpaga ādi ābharaṇa gatena maṇinā kuṇḍalena citta katam aṭṭhim
translated: “With gems and earrings” : adorned with gems and earrings worn as head ornaments, etc. “Bones” :

original: tacena onaddhanti allacammena pariyonaddhaṃ atirekatisatapabhedaṃ aṭṭhiṃ passāti
analyzed: tacena onaddhanti alla cammena pariyonaddham atireka tisa tapa bhedam aṭṭhim passāti
translated: The meaning is that he sees a bone divided into more than three hundred pieces, smeared with flesh and sinews, wrapped in a wet hide.🔽With earrings: the word “with” includes the rest of the ornaments.

original: yojanā. Kuṇḍalena cāti ca-saddena sesābharaṇālaṅkāre saṅgaṇhāti. Saha vatthehi sobhatīti
analyzed: yojanā kuṇḍalena ca ati ca saddena sesa ābharaṇa alaṅkāre saṅgaṇhāti saha vatthehi sobhati iti
translated: It is only when it is clothed that it is beautiful.

original: tayidaṃ rūpaṃ maṇinā cittakatampi vatthehi paṭicchāditameva sobhati, na apaṭicchāditanti
analyzed: tayā idam rūpam maṇinā vatthehi paṭicchāditam eva sobhati na a paṭicchāditan ti
translated: The meaning is that this beauty is only when it is clothed with a cloth or with a painted cloth, not when it is unclothed.

original: attho. Ye pana “aṭṭhitacenā”ti paṭhanti, tesaṃ aṭṭhitacenaṃ onaddhaṃ sobhati, onaddhattā
analyzed: atthaḥ ye pana aṭṭhitacenā ti paṭhanti tesam aṭṭhitacenam onaddham sobhati onaddha ttā
translated: But those who read “with a bone ornament” take it to mean that it is only when it is adorned with a bone ornament that it is beautiful,

original: aṭṭhitacenāti attho.🔽Alattakakatāti alattakena katarañjanā lākhāya saṃrañjitā. Pādāti caraṇā. Mukhaṃ cuṇṇakamakkhitanti🔽mukhaṃ cuṇṇakena makkhitaṃ, yaṃ maṇḍanamanuyuttā sāsapakakkena mukhapīḷakādīni haritvā
analyzed: aṭṭhitacena ati atthaḥ  alattaka katā ati alattakena kata rañjanā lākhāya saṃrañjitā pādā ati caraṇāḥ mukham cuṇṇakam akkhitanti  mukham cuṇṇakena makkhitam yam maṇḍanam anuyuttā sāsapa kakkena mukha pīḷaka ādīni haritvā
translated: the meaning being that it is adorned with a bone ornament.🔽Painted with lac: dyed with lac and turmeric. Feet: legs.🔽Face smeared with powder:🔽the meaning is that the face is smeared with powder, which is to say that those who are devoted to adornment remove the blackheads, pimples, etc., from the face with a paste of ground sesamum seeds,

original: loṇamattikāya duṭṭhalohitaṃ haritvā mukhacuṇṇakavilepanaṃ karonti, taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: loṇa mattikāya duṭṭha lohitam haritvā mukha cuṇṇaka vilepanam karonti tam sandhāya vuttam
translated: remove the bad colour with salt earth, and then apply a face-powder and a face-cream.

original: Alanti bālassa andhaputhujjanassa no ca pāragavesino vaṭṭābhiratassa mohāya sammohanāya
analyzed: alanti bālassa andha puthujjanassa no ca pāra gavesinaḥ vaṭṭa abhiratassa mohāya sammohanāya
translated: It is not enough for the fool, the blind man, the worldling who delights in the round of existence, to be deluded and confused.

original: samatthaṃ tassa cittaṃ mohetuṃ pariyattaṃ, pāragavesino pana vivaṭṭābhiratassa no alaṃ na pariyattaṃ.
analyzed: samattham tassa cittam mohetum pariyattam pāra gavesinaḥ pana vivaṭṭa abhiratassa no alam na pariyattam
translated: His mind is capable of being deluded and confused, but it is not enough for one who seeks the other shore and delights in the cessation of the round of existence.

original: Aṭṭhāpadakatāti aṭṭhapadākārena katā sañcitā purimabhāge kese kappetvā nalāṭassa
analyzed: aṭṭhāpada katā ti aṭṭhapada ākārena katā sañcitā purima bhāge kese kappetvā nalāṭassa
translated: A crest-jewel: a crest-jewel made in the shape of an eight-spoked wheel, piled up, with the hair arranged on the forehead

original: paṭicchādanavasena katā kesaracanā aṭṭhapadaṃ nāma, yaṃ “alaka”ntipi vuccati. Nettā
analyzed: paṭicchādana vasena katā kesa racanā aṭṭhapadam nāma yam vuccati nettā
translated: to cover the forehead. A crest-jewel is called a “hair-arrangement” , which is also called an “alaka.”

original: añjanamakkhitāti ubhopi nayanāni anto dvīsu antesu ca yathā añjanacchāyā dissati, evaṃ añjitañjanāni.
analyzed: añjana makkhitā ti ubho pi nayanāni antar dvīsu antesu ca yathā añjana chāyā dissati evam añjita ñjanāni
translated: With eyes anointed with collyrium: both eyes are anointed with collyrium so that the reflection of the collyrium appears inside and on both corners.

original: Añjanīva navā cittā, pūtikāyo alaṅkatoti yathā añjanī añjananāḷikā navā abhinavā
analyzed: añjanī iva navā cittā pūti kāyaḥ yathā añjanī añjana nāḷikā navā abhinavā
translated: Adorned with a foul body like a new painted casket: just as a new, fresh

original: mālākammamakaradantādivasena cittā bahi maṭṭhā ujjalā dassanīyā, anto pana na dassanīyā
analyzed: mālā kamma makara danta ādi vasena cittā bahi maṭṭhā ujjalā dassanīyā antar pana na dassanīyā
translated: painted casket is well polished, bright, and beautiful to behold outside, but inside

original: hoti, evameva tāsaṃ kāyo nhānabbhañjanavatthālaṅkārehi alaṅkato bahi ujjalo, anto
analyzed: hoti evam eva tāsam kāyaḥ nhāna abbhañjana vattha alaṅkārehi alaṅkataḥ bahi ujjalaḥ antaḥ
translated: Just as a well-polished looking-glass, though outwardly bright, is inwardly filled with impurities, so too, though their bodies are adorned with bathing, massage, clothes, ornaments, etc.,

original: pana pūti nānappakāraasucīhi bharito tiṭṭhatīti attho.
analyzed: pana pūti nānappakāra asucīhi bharitaḥ tiṭṭhati iti attho
translated: they are inwardly filled with various kinds of impurities.

original: Odahīti oḍḍesi. Migavoti, migaluddako. Pāsanti, daṇḍavāguraṃ. Nāsadāti na saṅghaṭṭesi.🔽Vāguranti pāsaṃ. Nivāpanti migānaṃ khādanatthāya khittaṃ tiṇādighāsaṃ. Upamā kho
analyzed: odahi iti oḍḍesi migavo ti miga luddakaḥ pāsanti daṇḍa vāguram na āsadāti na saṅghaṭṭesi  vāguranti pāsam nivāpanti migānam khādana atthāya khittam tiṇa ādi ghāsam upamā kho
translated: He set the snare: he laid the snare. The hunter: the deer-hunter. The snare: the trap. He did not touch it: he did not touch the trap.

original: ayaṃ therena katā atthassa viññāpanāya. Ayañhettha attho – yathā migānaṃ māraṇatthāya
analyzed: ayam therena katā atthassa viññāpanāya ayam ha ittha atthaḥ yathā migānam māraṇa atthāya
translated: The bait: the food. The deer: the deer. He went: he went. The hunter: the deer-hunter. The trap: the snare. The bait: the grass, etc., thrown down for the deer to eat. This simile was given by the Elder for the purpose of making the meaning clear. This is the meaning here: Just as when a deer-hunter,🔽having set a trap for the purpose of killing deer, scattered bait around it, and lay hidden nearby,

original: daṇḍavāguraṃ oḍḍetvā tattha nivāpaṃ vikiriya migaluddake nilīne ṭhite tattheko javaparakkamasampanno
analyzed: daṇḍa vāguram oḍḍetvā tattha nivāpam vikiriya miga luddake nilīne ṭhite tattha ekaḥ java parakkama sampanno
translated: then a clever deer, endowed with speed and strength,

original: cheko migo pāsaṃ aphusanto eva yathāsukhaṃ nivāpaṃ khāditvā, “vañcesi vata migo”ti
analyzed: chekaḥ migaḥ pāsam a phusantaḥ eva yathāsukham nivāpam khāditvā vañcesi vata migo ti
translated: having eaten the bait as it liked without touching the trap, went away, while the deer-hunter cried out, “The deer has cheated me!”

original: migaluddake viravante eva gacchati. Aparo migo balavā cheko javasampannova tattha
analyzed: miga luddake viravante eva gacchati aparaḥ migaḥ balavā chekaḥ java sampannaḥ iva tattha
translated: Then another deer, clever, strong, and endowed with speed,

original: gantvā nivāpaṃ khāditvā tattha tattha pāsaṃ chinditvā, “vañcesi vata migo, pāso chinno”ti🔽migaluddake socante eva gacchati, evaṃ mayampi pubbe puthujjanakāle mātāpitūhi āsajjanatthāya
analyzed: gantvā nivāpam khāditvā tattha tattha pāsam chinditvā vañcesi vata migo pāso chinnoti  migaluddake socante eva gacchati evam mayam pi pubbe puthujjana kāle mātā pitūhi āsajjana tthāya
translated: and after eating the bait, he breaks the snare here and there, and goes away, while the hunters lament, “The deer has deceived us, the snare is broken.”

original: niyyādite bhoge bhuñjitvā tattha tattha asajjamānā nikkhantā. Idāni pana sabbaso
analyzed: niyyādite bhoge bhuñjitvā tattha tattha a sajjamānāḥ nikkhantāḥ idāni pana sabbaso
translated: In the same way, we too, in the past, when we were ordinary people, went away after eating the wealth that our parents had sent us to get, without paying them back. But now,

original: chinnakilesā apāsā hutvā ṭhitā, tehi dinnabhojanaṃ bhuñjitvā tesu socantesu eva gacchāmāti.
analyzed: chinna kilesā apāsā hutvā ṭhitā tehi dinna bhojanam bhuñjitvā tesu socantesu eva gacchāma iti
translated: having cut off all the defilements, we are like the deer that has broken the snare, and we go away after eating the food given to us by our parents, while they lament.

original: Evaṃ thero migaluddakaṃ viya mātāpitaro, hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ itthāgārañca vāgurajālaṃ
analyzed: evam theraḥ miga luddakam viya mātā pitaraḥ hirañña suvaṇṇam itthā āgāram ca vāgura jālam
translated: Thus the Elder, like the deer, showed his parents, like the hunters, the wealth that they had given him, like the golden net and the harem,

original: viya, attanā pubbe bhuttabhoge ca idāni bhuttabhojanañca nivāpatiṇaṃ viya, attānaṃ🔽mahāmigaṃ viya ca katvā dasseti. Imā gāthā vatvā vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā rañño korabyassa
analyzed: viya attanā pubbe bhutta bhoge ca idāni bhutta bhojanam ca nivāpa tiṇam viya attānam  mahā migam viya ca katvā dassa iti imāḥ gāthāḥ vatvā vehāsam abbhut gantvā raññaḥ korabyassa
translated: and the food that he had eaten in the past and the food that he was eating now, like the bait, and himself,

original: Luddhā dhanaṃ sannicayaṃ karonti, bhiyyova kāme abhipatthayanti.
analyzed: luddhāḥ dhanam sannicayam karonti bhiyyas uva kāme abhipatthayanti
translated: Greedy, they make their hoard of riches, and still they crave for more and more.

original: “Rājā pasayhappathaviṃ vijetvā, sasāgarantaṃ mahimāvasanto;
analyzed: rājā pasayhappathavim vijetvā sa sāgarantam mahimā vasantaḥ
translated: Having conquered the earth to the ocean’s edge, the king, still unsatisfied,

original: Oraṃ samuddassa atittarūpo, pāraṃ samuddassapi patthayetha.🔽“Rājā ca aññe ca bahū manussā, avītataṇhā maraṇaṃ upenti;
analyzed: oram samuddassa pāram samuddassa api patthayetha  rājā ca aññe ca bahū manussā a vīta taṇhāḥ maraṇam upenti
translated: may cross the ocean to the further shore.🔽Kings and other men, not free from craving, die.

original: Ūnāva hutvāna jahanti dehaṃ, kāmehi lokamhi na hatthi titti.
analyzed: ūna ava hutvāna jahanti deham kāmehi lokamhi na hatthi titti
translated: They leave the body behind, still unsatisfied, for sensual pleasures in the world are never filling.

original: “Kandanti naṃ ñātī pakiriya kese, ‘aho vatā no amarā’ti cāhu;
analyzed: kandanti nam ñātī kese aho vata naḥ amarāti ca āhu
translated: His relatives weep and tear their hair, saying: ‘Alas, we shall see him no more.’

original: Vatthena naṃ pārutaṃ nīharitvā, citaṃ samodhāya tato ḍahanti.
analyzed: vatthena nam pārutam nīharitvā citam samodhāya tatas ḍahanti
translated: They carry him out wrapped in a shroud, and then they burn him with a pyre.

original: “So ḍayhati sūlehi tujjamāno, ekena vatthena pahāya bhoge;
analyzed: saḥ ḍayhati sūlehi tujjamānaḥ ekena vatthena pahāya bhoge
translated: He is burned, pierced by the stakes of suffering, leaving his wealth behind, wrapped in a single cloth.

original: Na mīyamānassa bhavanti tāṇā, ñātī ca mittā atha vā sahāyā.
analyzed: na mīyamānassa bhavanti tāṇāḥ ñātī ca mittā atha vā sahāyā
translated: When he dies, relatives, friends, and companions are of no help.

original: “Dāyādakā tassa dhanaṃ haranti, satto pana gacchati yenakammaṃ;
analyzed: dāyādakā tassa dhanam haranti satto pana gacchati yenakammam
translated: His heirs take away his wealth, but the being goes on according to his kamma.

original: Na mīyamānaṃ dhanamanveti kiñci, puttā ca dārā ca dhanañca raṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: na mīyamānam dhanam anveti kiñci puttā ca dārā ca dhanañca raṭṭham
translated: When he dies, nothing follows him: neither wealth, nor children, nor wife, nor relatives.

original: “Na dīghamāyuṃ labhate dhanena, na cāpi vittena jaraṃ vihanti;
analyzed: na dīgham āyum labhate dhanena na ca api vittena jaram vihanti
translated: “Wealth does not bring about a long life, nor does it ward off old age.

original: Appaṃ hidaṃ jīvitamāhu dhīrā, asassataṃ vippariṇāmadhammaṃ.
analyzed: appam hi dam jīvitam āhu dhīrāḥ asassatam vippariṇāma dhammam
translated: The wise say that life is short, impermanent, and subject to change.

original: “Aḍḍhā daliddā ca phusanti phassaṃ, bālo ca dhīro ca tatheva phuṭṭho;
analyzed: aḍḍhāḥ daliddā ca phusanti phassam bālo ca dhīro ca tathā iva phuṭṭhaḥ
translated: “The rich and the poor alike experience contact. When the fool and the wise man are touched by contact,

original: Bālo hi bālyā vadhitova seti, dhīro ca no vedhati phassaphuṭṭho.
analyzed: bālaḥ hi bālyā vadhitaḥ uva seti dhīro ca no vedhati phassa phuṭṭhaḥ
translated: the fool, being foolish, lies down defeated, but the wise man is not made to suffer by contact.

original: “Tasmā hi paññāva dhanena seyyā, yāya vosānamidhādhigacchati;
analyzed: tasmā hi dhanena seyyā
translated: “Therefore, wisdom is better than wealth, by which one attains the end.

original: Abyositattā hi bhavābhavesu, pāpāni kammāni karoti mohā.
analyzed: a byosita ttā hi bhava abhavesu pāpāni kammāni karoti mohā
translated: For, being unawakened, through delusion one does the evil deeds in this existence and the next.

original: “Upeti gabbhañca parañca lokaṃ, saṃsāramāpajja paramparāya;
analyzed: upeti gabbham ca param ca lokam saṃsāram āpajja paramparāya
translated: “One goes to the womb and to the other world, passing from existence to existence.

original: Tassappapañño abhisaddahanto, upeti gabbhañca parañca lokaṃ.
analyzed: tassa appapaññaḥ abhisaddahantaḥ upeti gabbhañca parañca lokaṃ
translated: The unwise one, believing, goes to the womb and to the other world.

original: “Coro yathā sandhimukhe gahīto, sakammunā haññati pāpadhammo;
analyzed: coraḥ yathā sandhi mukhe gahītaḥ sa kammunā haññati pāpa dhammaḥ
translated: “Just as a thief caught in a break-in is punished by his own deed, the evil-natured one,

original: Evaṃ pajā pecca paramhi loke, sakammunā haññati pāpadhammo.
analyzed: evam pajā pecca paramhi loke sa kammunā haññati pāpa dhammaḥ
translated: so the people, after death, in the other world are punished by their own deeds, the evil-natured one.

original: “Kāmā hi citrā madhurā manoramā, virūparūpena mathenti cittaṃ;
analyzed: kāmāḥ hi citrāḥ madhurāḥ manoramāḥ virūpa rūpena mathenti cittam
translated: “Sensual pleasures are varied, sweet, and delightful, but they distort the mind with their false appearance.

original: Ādīnavaṃ kāmaguṇesu disvā, tasmā ahaṃ pabbajitomhi rāja.
analyzed: ādīnavam kāma guṇesu disvā tasmai aham pabbajitaḥ amhi rāja
translated: Seeing the danger in the strands of sensual pleasure, therefore, O King, I went forth.

original: “Dumapphalānīva patanti māṇavā, daharā ca vuḍḍhā ca sarīrabhedā;
analyzed: duma pphalāni iva patanti māṇavāḥ daharā ca vuḍḍhā ca sarīra bhedā
translated: Young men fall down like fruit from trees, young and old alike, their bodies broken.

original: Etampi disvā pabbajitomhi rāja, apaṇṇakaṃ sāmaññameva seyyo.
analyzed: etam pi disvā pabbajitaḥ amhi rāja apaṇṇakam sāmaññam eva seyyo
translated: Seeing this, too, I went forth, O King, for the incomparable life of a contemplative is better.

original: “Saddhāyāhaṃ pabbajito, upeto jinasāsane;
analyzed: saddhāya aham pabbajitaḥ upetaḥ jina sāsane
translated: “With faith I went forth, O King, and I have come to the Jina’s teaching.

original: Avañjhā mayhaṃ pabbajjā, anaṇo bhuñjāmi bhojanaṃ.
analyzed: avañjhā mayham pabbajjā anaṇaḥ bhuñjāmi bhojanam
translated: My going forth is not in vain. I eat my food free from debt.

original: “Kāme ādittato disvā, jātarūpāni satthato;
analyzed: kāme disvā jātarūpāni satthataḥ
translated: “Seeing sensual desires as burning, as goldsmith’s fire,

original: Gabbhavokkantito dukkhaṃ, nirayesu mahabbhayaṃ.
analyzed: gabbha vokkantitaḥ dukkham nirayesu mahat bhayam
translated: the pain of being conceived in the womb, the great fear in the hells,

original: “Etamādīnavaṃ ñatvā, saṃvegaṃ alabhiṃ tadā;
analyzed: etam ādīnavam ñatvā saṃvegam alabhim tadā
translated: “Knowing this danger, I was inspired then.

original: Sohaṃ viddho tadā santo, sampatto āsavakkhayaṃ.
analyzed: saḥ ham viddhaḥ tadā santaḥ sampattaḥ āsava kkhayam
translated: Pierced by that , I became calm and attained the ending of effluents.

original: “Pariciṇṇo mayā satthā, kataṃ buddhassa sāsanaṃ;
analyzed: pariciṇṇaḥ mayā satthā katam buddhassa sāsanam
translated: “The Teacher has been served by me. The teaching of the Buddha has been done.

original: Ohito garuko bhāro, bhavanetti samūhatā.
analyzed: ohitaḥ garukaḥ bhāraḥ samūha tā
translated: The heavy burden has been put down. The fetter has been destroyed.

original: “Yassatthāya pabbajito, agārasmānagāriyaṃ;
analyzed: yassa atthāya pabbajitaḥ agārasmā anagāriyam
translated: “The purpose for which I went forth from the home life into homelessness🔽has been achieved: the ending of all fetters.”

original: So me attho anuppatto, sabbasaṃyojanakkhayo”ti. – imā gāthā avoca;
analyzed: saḥ me atthaḥ anuppattaḥ sabba saṃyojana kkhayo ti imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: These verses were spoken, it is said, by the venerable Anuruddha.

original: Tattha passāmi loketi ahaṃ, mahārāja, imasmiṃ loke sadhane dhanasampanne aḍḍhe manusse🔽passāmi, te pana laddhāna vittaṃ dhanaṃ labhitvā bhogasampattiyaṃ ṭhitā samaṇabrāhmaṇādīsu
analyzed: tattha passāmi loke iti aham mahā rāja imasmin loke sa dhane dhana sampanne aḍḍhe manusse  passāmi te pana vittam dhanam labhitvā bhoga sampattiyam ṭhitā samaṇa brāhmaṇa ādīsu
translated: Herein, I see in this world, great king, rich men, men endowed with wealth, men who have attained to prosperity,

original: kassaci kiñcipi na dadanti. Kasmā? Mohā kammassakatāpaññāya abhāvato. Luddhā lobhābhibhūtā🔽yathāladdhaṃ dhanaṃ sannicayaṃ sabbaso nicetabbaṃ nidhetabbaṃ karonti. Bhiyyova yathādhigatakāmato
analyzed: kassaci kiñcipi na dadanti kasmā mohā kammassaka tā paññāya abhāvataḥ luddhāḥ lobha abhibhūtāḥ  yathā laddham dhanam sannicayam sabbasas nicetabbam nidhetabbam karonti bhiyyas iva yathā adhigata kāmataḥ
translated: but having attained to wealth and riches and having become established in the enjoyment of prosperity, they give nothing to anyone, not even to ascetics and brahmans. Why is that? Because of delusion, because of the absence of the understanding of the ownership of kamma. Greedy, overcome by greed,

original: upari kāme kāmaguṇe “tathāhaṃ edise ca bhoge paṭilabheyya”nti abhipatthayanti paccāsīsanti
analyzed: upari kāme kāma guṇe tathā aham edise ca bhoge paṭilabheyyanti abhipatthayanti
translated: they hoard all that wealth and riches which they have acquired, they store it away. They desire still more than they have already acquired,

original: tajjañca vāyāmaṃ karonti.
analyzed: tad jam ca vā āyāmam karonti
translated: they long for more, they aspire to more, they make an effort for more.

original: Bhiyyo kāmapatthanāya udāharaṇaṃ dassento “rājā”tiādimāha. Tattha pasayhappathaviṃ
analyzed: bhiyyas kāma patthanāya udāharaṇam dassentaḥ rājā iti ādim āha tattha
translated: In order to give an illustration of the desire for more, he said, “A king” and so on. Herein, having conquered the earth up to the ocean,

original: vijetvāti attano vaṃsānugataṃ pathaviṃ balakkārena abhivijiya. Āvasantoti pasāsento.
analyzed: vijetvā ati attanaḥ vaṃsa anugatam pathavim balakkārena abhivijiya āvasantaḥ iti pasāsentaḥ
translated: having conquered the earth that had come down in his family by force, he ruled it, he governed it.

original: Oraṃ samuddassāti anavasesaṃ samuddassa orabhāgaṃ labhitvāpi tena atittarūpo pāraṃ
analyzed: oram samuddassa ati anavasesam samuddassa ora bhāgam labhitvā api tena pāram
translated: Having obtained the near shore of the ocean without exception, he was not satisfied with that, but he went to the other shore.

original: samuddassa dīpantarampi patthayeyya.
analyzed: samuddassa dīpa antaram pi patthayeyya
translated: Even if he had the whole ocean’s near shore, he would be dissatisfied with it and would seek the far shore of the ocean, an island beyond.

original: Avītataṇhāti avigatataṇhā. Ūnāvāti aparipuṇṇamanorathāva. Kāmehi lokamhi na hatthi tittīti taṇhāvipannānaṃ imasmiṃ loke vatthukāmehi titti nāma natthi.🔽Kandanti nanti matapurisaṃ uddissa tassa guṇe kittentā kandanaṃ karonti. Aho vatā
analyzed: avīta taṇhā ati avigata taṇhā ūnā ava ati aparipuṇṇa manorathā ava kāmehi lokamhi na titti iti taṇhā vipannānam imasmin loke vatthu kāmehi titti nāma natthi  kandanti nanti mata purisam uddissa tassa guṇe kittentā kandanam karonti aho vatā
translated: “With craving unabated” means with craving not gone. “With wants unfulfilled” means with wishes not fulfilled. “In the world of sensual pleasures there is no satiety” means that for those who are overcome by craving there is no satiety in the world with respect to sensual pleasures as objects.

original: no amarāti cāhūti aho vata amhākaṃ ñātī amarā siyunti ca kathenti, gāthāsukhatthañhettha🔽vatā-iti dīghaṃ katvā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: no amarāti aho vata amhākam ñātī amarā ca kathenti gāthā sukhattham ha ittha  vatā iti dīgham katvā vuttam
translated: “They weep” means that they weep, lamenting his virtues. “They call out ‘Alas!’” means that they say: “Alas, may our relatives not die!” Here the word “alas” is lengthened for the sake of the meter.

original: So ḍayhati sūlehi tujjamānoti so matasatto chavaḍāhakehi sammā jhāpetuṃ sūlehi tujjamāno. Tāṇāti parittāṇakarā.
analyzed: saḥ ḍayhati sūlehi tujjamānaḥ iti saḥ mata sattaḥ chava ḍāhakehi sammā jhāpetum sūlehi tujjamāno tāṇāti parittāṇa karā
translated: “He is burned with heated pikes” means that the dead being is burned well with heated pikes in the charnel ground. “Protection” means that which protects.

original: Yenakammanti yathākammaṃ. Dhananti dhanāyitabbaṃ yaṃkiñci vatthu. Puna dhananti hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ sandhāya vadati.
analyzed: yenakammanti yathākammam dhananti dhanāyitabbam yaṃ kiñci vatthu puna dhananti hirañña suvaṇṇam sandhāya vadati
translated: “According to his deeds” means according to his kamma. “Wealth” means any object that should be made into wealth. “Again, wealth” he says with reference to gold and silver.

original: “Na dīghamāyu”ntiādinā kāmaguṇassa jarāya ca paṭikārābhāvaṃ vatvā puna tassa ekantikabhāvaṃ🔽dassetuṃ “appaṃ hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Phusantīti aniṭṭhaphassaṃ phusanti pāpuṇanti, tattha🔽aḍḍhadaliddatā akāraṇanti dasseti. Phassaṃ bālo ca dhīro ca tatheva phuṭṭhoti yathā
analyzed: na dīgham āyunti ādinā kāma guṇassa jarāya ca paṭikāra abhāvam vatvā puna tassa ekantika bhāvam  dassetum appam hi itiādi vuttam phusanti iti aniṭṭha phassam phusanti pāpuṇanti tattha  aḍḍha dalidda tā akāraṇanti dasseti phassam bālo ca dhīro ca tathā iva phuṭṭhaḥ ti yathā
translated: Having stated the absence of any remedy for the aging of the sense-desires, he says “little and brief” in order to show their absolute nature. “They touch” : they touch, they experience, the undesirable touch. There, the poverty of the rich and the poor is the reason. “The fool and the wise man are touched by the touch in the same way” : just as the fool is touched by the touch, so is the wise man.

original: bālo iṭṭhāniṭṭhasamphassaṃ phuṭṭho, tatheva dhīro iṭṭhāniṭṭhaphassaṃ phuṭṭho hoti,
analyzed: bālaḥ iṭṭha aniṭṭha samphassam phuṭṭhaḥ tathā iva dhīraḥ iṭṭha aniṭṭha phassam phuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: “No long life” and so on. Having stated the absence of any remedy for the gratification of the sense faculties by aging, he now says “Little or much” in order to show the one-sidedness of that gratification. “They touch” : they touch unpleasant contact, they experience it. Therein, the fact that “the poor and the rich” are “alike” shows that poverty and wealth are not the cause . “The fool and the wise man are touched by contact just the same” : just as the fool is touched by pleasant and unpleasant contact, so too is the wise man touched by pleasant and unpleasant contact.

original: na ettha bālapaṇḍitānaṃ koci viseso. Ayaṃ pana viseso, bālo hi bālyā vadhitova setīti🔽bālapuggalo kenaci dukkhadhammena phuṭṭho socanto kilamanto urattāḷiṃ kandanto bālabhāvena
analyzed: na ettha bāla paṇḍitānam koci visesaḥ ayam pana visesaḥ bālaḥ hi bālyā seti iti  bāla puggalo kenacid dukkha dhammena phuṭṭho socantaḥ kilamantaḥ uras tāḷim kandantaḥ bāla bhāvena
translated: There is no difference between the fool and the wise man in this respect. But there is this difference: the fool, being overcome by his foolishness, lies down

original: vadhito pīḷitova hutvā seti sayati. Ito cito ca āvaṭṭanto vivaṭṭanto virodhento vedhati
analyzed: vadhitaḥ pīḍitaḥ uva hutvā seti sayati itas citas ca āvaṭṭantaḥ vivaṭṭantaḥ virodhentaḥ vedhati
translated: as if he were struck down. When the fool is touched by any painful thing, he lies down, he sleeps, as if he were struck down, afflicted, oppressed by his foolishness, lamenting, and exhausted. He turns this way and that, rolls about, and struggles,

original: phassaphuṭṭhoti dhīro pana paṇḍito dukkhasamphassena samphuṭṭho na vedhati kampanamattampi tassa na hotīti.
analyzed: phassa phuṭṭhaḥ ti dhīraḥ pana paṇḍitaḥ dukkha samphassena samphuṭṭhaḥ na vedhati kampana mattam pi tassa na hoti iti
translated: The wise one, however, the wise man, the wise person, when touched by painful contact does not tremble, does not shake, does not quiver.

original: Tasmāti yasmā bālapaṇḍitānaṃ lokadhamme edisī pavatti, tasmā hi paññāva dhanena seyyā,
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmā bāla paṇḍitānam loka dhamme edisī pavatti tasmā hi paññā ava dhanena seyyā
translated: Therefore, since the occurrence of worldly things is of this kind for the fool and the wise man, therefore wisdom is better than wealth,

original: yāya vosānamidhādhigacchatīti paññāva dhanato pāsaṃsatarā, yāya paññāya vosānaṃ bhavassa
analyzed: yāya vosānam idha adhigacchati iti paññā ava dhanataḥ pāsaṃsatarā yāya paññāya vosānam bhavassa
translated: by which one attains the end of suffering. Wisdom is more praiseworthy than wealth. By which wisdom one attains the end of suffering,

original: pariyosānabhūtaṃ nibbānaṃ adhigacchati. Abyositattā hīti anadhigataniṭṭhattā. Bhavābhavesūti
analyzed: pariyosāna bhūtam nibbānam adhigacchati a byosita ttā hi iti an adhigata niṭṭha ttā bhava abhavesu iti
translated: the end of existence, which is Nibbāna. Because of not being exhausted: because of not being attained to completion. In existence after existence:

original: mahantāmahantesu bhavesu.
analyzed: mahanta amahantesu bhavesu
translated: in great and small existences.

original: Upeti gabbhañca parañca lokaṃ, saṃsāramāpajja paramparāyāti yo pāpāni katvā aparāparaṃ
analyzed: upeti gabbham ca param ca lokam saṃsāram āpajja paramparāyā ati yaḥ pāpāni katvā apara aparam
translated: He goes to the womb and to the other world, to the round of rebirths, by succession. He who, having done evil, goes to the womb and to the other world, to the round of rebirths, by succession,

original: saṃsaraṇamāpajjitvā upeti gabbhañca parañca lokaṃ gabbhaseyyāya paralokuppattiyā
analyzed: saṃsaraṇam āpajjitvā upeti gabbham ca param ca lokam gabbhaseyyāya para loka uppattiyā
translated: by taking up the round of rebirths again and again, he goes to the womb and to the other world, and he is not freed from the womb and from rebirth in the other world.

original: ca na muccati, tassa pāpakammakārino puggalassa kiriyaṃ abhisaddahanto “attā ca me
analyzed: ca na muccati tassa pāpa kamma kārino puggalassa kiriyam abhisaddahantaḥ attā ca me
translated: He is not freed from the womb and from rebirth in the other world, because of the fault of his evil deeds. Confident in the deed of that person who has done evil, saying: “My self

original: hotī”ti pattiyāyanto aññopi appapañño bālo yathā paṭipajjitvā upeti gabbhañca parañca
analyzed: hoti iti aññaḥ api appapaññaḥ bālaḥ yathā paṭipajjitvā upeti gabbhañca parañca
translated: and so on.

original: lokaṃ, na tato parimuccati.
analyzed: lokam na tatas parimuccati
translated: Even a fool who is not very wise, if he practices in this way, will go to a good rebirth and to the world beyond. He will not be released from this world.

original: Coro yathāti yathā coro pāpadhammo gharasandhiṃ chindanto sandhimukhe ārakkhakapurisehi🔽gahito sakammunā tena attano sandhicchedakammunā kāraṇabhūtena kasādīhi tāḷanādivasena
analyzed: coraḥ yathā ati yathā coraḥ pāpa dhammaḥ ghara sandhim chindanto sandhi mukhe ārakkhaka purisehi  gahitaḥ sa kammunā tena sandhi cheda kammunā kāraṇa bhūtena kasā ādīhi tāḷanā ādi vasena
translated: As a thief: just as a thief, a wicked man, who is caught by the guards at the opening of a house that he is breaking into, is killed by them with sticks, etc.,

original: haññati rājapurisehi bādhiyyati bajjhati ca. Evaṃ pajāti evamayaṃ sattaloko idha
analyzed: haññati rāja purisehi bādhiyyati bajjhati ca evam pajāti evam ayam satta lokaḥ idha
translated: with his own act of housebreaking as the cause, is afflicted, is punished, by the king’s men;

original: pāpāni karitvā pecca patvā tena kammunā paramhi loke nirayādīsu haññati, pañcavidhabandhanakammakāraṇādivasena bādhiyyati.🔽Evametāhi ekādasahi gāthāhi yathārahaṃ cattāro dhammuddese pakāsetvā idāni kāmesu
analyzed: pāpāni karitvā tena kammunā paramhi loke niraya ādīsu haññati pañcavidha bandhana kamma kāraṇa ādi vasena  evam etāhi ekādasahi gāthāhi yathāraham cattāraḥ dhammuddese pakāsetvā idāni kāmesu
translated: so too, this world of beings is born here and, after dying here, passes on to the next world. Having done evil deeds here, he is killed in the next world, in the hells, etc., by the results of those deeds, is afflicted by the five kinds of bonds, etc.

original: saṃsāre ca ādīnavaṃ disvā saddhāya attano pabbajitabhāvaṃ pabbajitakiccassa ca matthakappattiṃ
analyzed: saṃsāre ca ādīnavam disvā saddhāya attano pabbajita bhāvam pabbajita kiccassa ca matthaka ppattim
translated: Having thus expounded the four doctrinal items in the proper sequence by means of eleven stanzas, the Exalted One now shows that, having seen the danger in sense pleasures and in the round of rebirths, he went forth from the home life, and that he reached the peak of the duties of a recluse and of a brāhmaṇa by means of faith.

original: vibhāvento “kāmā hī”tiādimāha. Tattha kāmāti vatthukāmā manāpiyā rūpādayo dhammā,
analyzed: vibhāventaḥ kāmāḥ hi iti ādim āha tattha kāmā ati vatthu kāmāḥ rūpa ādayaḥ dhammā
translated: and he said, “Sensual desires are manifold” and so on. Herein, sensual desires are sensual desires as object, namely, forms, etc., that are agreeable as objects,

original: kilesakāmā sabbepi rāgappabhedā. Idha pana vatthukāmā veditabbā. Te hi rūpādivasena🔽anekappakāratāya citrā. Lokassādavasena iṭṭhākāratāya madhurā. Bālaputhujjanānaṃ
analyzed: kilesa kāmā sabbe pi rāga ppabhedāḥ idha pana vatthu kāmā veditabbā te hi rūpa ādi vasena  aneka ppakāra tāya citrā lokassāda vasena iṭṭhākāra tāya madhurā bāla puthujjanānam
translated: and sensual desires as defilement, namely, all the kinds of greed. But here sensual desires as object should be understood. For these are manifold because of the variety of forms, etc.,🔽they are varied because of the variety of agreeable aspects in the world, they are sweet because of the variety of agreeable aspects in the world, they are delightful because they delight the minds of foolish ordinary men.

original: manaṃ ramentīti manoramā. Virūparūpenāti vividharūpena, anekavidhasabhāvenāti attho.
analyzed: ramenti iti manoramāḥ virūpa rūpena ati vividha rūpena anekavidha sabhāvena ati
translated: With manifold forms: with many kinds of forms, with many kinds of individual essences, is the meaning.

original: Te hi rūpādivasena citrā, nīlādivasena vividharūpā. Evaṃ tena virūparūpena tathā🔽tathā assādaṃ dassetvā mathenti cittaṃ pabbajjāya abhiramituṃ na dentīti iminā appassādabahudukkhatādinā
analyzed: te hi rūpa ādi vasena citrāḥ nīla ādi vasena vividha rūpāḥ evam tena virūpa rūpena tathā  tathā assādam dassetvā mathenti cittam pabbajjāya abhiramitum na denti iti iminā appassāda bahu dukkha tā ādinā
translated: For these are manifold because of the variety of forms, etc., and they are many kinds of forms because of the variety of blue, etc. So with such manifold forms,

original: ādīnavaṃ kāmaguṇesu disvā tasmā taṃnimittaṃ ahaṃ pabbajito amhi. Dumapphalāni pakkakāle
analyzed: ādīnavam kāma guṇesu disvā tasmai tad nimittam aham pabbajitaḥ amhi duma phalāni pakka kāle
translated: having shown the taste in this way and that, they intoxicate the mind and do not allow it to delight in going forth. Thus seeing the danger in the strands of sensual desire in this way, “Because of that I went forth,”🔽just as, when the fruits of a tree are ripe, they fall here and there of their own accord whether or not someone climbs the tree, or whether or not someone shoots them down with a catapult,

original: aparipakkakāle ca yattha katthaci parūpakkamato sarasato vā patanti, evaṃ sattā daharā
analyzed: a paripakka kāle ca yattha katthaci parūpakkamataḥ sarasataḥ vā patanti evam sattā daharā
translated: so too, when beings are young

original: ca vuḍḍhā ca sarīrassa bhedā patantiyeva. Etampi disvāti evaṃ aniccatampi paññācakkhunā
analyzed: ca vuḍḍhā ca sarīrassa bhedāḥ etam pi disvā ati evam paññācakkhunā
translated: and when the body breaks up they fall away. Having seen this too: having seen this world in this way as impermanent,

original: disvā, na kevalaṃ appassādatāditāya ādīnavamevāti adhippāyo. Apaṇṇakanti aviraddhanakaṃ🔽sāmaññameva samaṇabhāvova seyyo uttaritaro.
analyzed: disvā na kevalam appassāda tāditāya ādīnavam eva ati adhippāyaḥ apaṇṇakam ti a viraddha nakam  sāmaññam eva seyyaḥ uttaritaraḥ
translated: and the old, and the body’s dissolution, they fall away. Seeing this too: the intention is that he sees thus not only the danger in it as unsatisfactoriness, etc., but also impermanence with the eye of understanding. The state of a recluse is better: the state of a recluse is better, is superior.

original: Saddhāyāti kammaṃ kammaphalaṃ buddhasubuddhataṃ dhammasudhammataṃ saṅghasuppaṭipattiñca
analyzed: saddhāya ati kammam kamma phalam buddha su buddha tam dhamma su dhamma tam saṅgha su paṭipattiñca
translated: Through faith: having faith in action, in the fruit of action, in the Perfect Awakening of the Buddha, in the good Gotama, in the good training of the Community.

original: saddahitvā. Upeto jinasāsaneti satthu sāsane sammāpaṭipattiṃ upagato. Avañjhā mayhaṃ🔽pabbajjā arahattassa adhigatattā. Tato eva anaṇo bhuñjāmi bhojanaṃ nikkilesavasena
analyzed: saddahitvā upetaḥ jina sāsane iti satthu sāsane sammā paṭipattim upagataḥ avañjhā mayham  pabbajjāḥ arahattassa adhigata ttā tatas eva anaṇaḥ bhuñjāmi bhojanam nikkilesa vasena
translated: Approached the Jina’s Dispensation: gone to the right practice in the Master’s Dispensation. My going forth is not barren: my going forth is not barren, is not fruitless, because I have reached Arahantship.

original: sāmibhāvato sāmiparibhogena paribhuñjanato.
analyzed: sāmi bhāvataḥ sāmi paribhogena paribhuñjanataḥ
translated: Therefore I eat my food without debt: I eat my food without debt, without stain, because I use it as a master by using it as one who has the right to do so.

original: Kāme ādittato disvāti vatthukāme kilesakāme ca ekādasahi aggīhi ādittabhāvato disvā.
analyzed: kāme ādittataḥ disvā ati vatthu kāme kilesa kāme ca ekādasahi aggīhi āditta bhāvataḥ disvā
translated: Seeing sense desires as burning: seeing sense desires as burning with eleven fires.

original: Jātarūpāni satthatoti katākatappabhedā sabbasuvaṇṇavikatiyo anatthāvahatāya nisitasatthato.
analyzed: jātarūpāni satthataḥ ti kata akata ppabhedā sabba suvaṇṇa vikatiyaḥ anattha avahatāya nisita satthato
translated: From the edge of a sword: from the edge of a sword that is not blunted by what it cuts through, that is, all kinds of gold of whatever kind.

original: Gabbhavokkantito dukkhanti gabbhavokkantito paṭṭhāya sabbasaṃsārapavattidukkhaṃ.
analyzed: gabbha vokkantitaḥ dukkhanti gabbha vokkantitaḥ paṭṭhāya sabba saṃsāra pavatti dukkhaṃ
translated: From the descent into the womb, suffering: the suffering of the entire round of existence beginning with the descent into the womb.

original: Nirayesu mahabbhayanti saussadesu aṭṭhasu mahānirayesu labbhamānaṃ mahābhayañca sabbattha disvāti yojanā.
analyzed: nirayesu mahabbhayanti saussadesu aṭṭhasu mahānirayesu labbhamānam mahā bhayañca sabbattha disvā iti yojanā
translated: In the hells, great fear: seeing the great fear that is found in the eight great hells beginning with Saṃjīva.

original: Etamādīnavaṃ ñatvāti etaṃ kāmānaṃ ādittatādiṃ saṃsāre ādīnavaṃ dosaṃ ñatvā. Saṃvegaṃ
analyzed: etam ādīnavam ñatvā ati etam kāmānam saṃsāre ādīnavam dosam ñatvā saṃvegam
translated: Having known this danger: having known this danger, this fault, this burning of the defilements of sensual pleasures, in the round of existence.

original: alabhiṃ tadāti tasmiṃ satthu santike dhammassa sutakāle bhavādike saṃvegaṃ alatthaṃ.🔽Viddho tadā santoti tasmiṃ gahaṭṭhakāle rāgasallādīhi viddho samāno idāni satthu
analyzed: alabhim tadā ti tasmim satthu santike dhammassa suta kāle bhava ādike saṃvegam alattham  viddhaḥ tadā santo ti tasmin gahaṭṭha kāle rāga salla ādīhi viddhaḥ samānaḥ idāni satthu
translated: I gained a sense of spiritual urgency: at the time of hearing the Dhamma in the presence of the Teacher, I gained a sense of spiritual urgency regarding existence, etc.

original: sāsanaṃ āgamma sampatto āsavakkhayaṃ, viddho vā cattāri saccāni, paṭividdhoti attho.
analyzed: sāsanam āgamma sampattaḥ āsava kkhayam viddhaḥ vā cattāri saccāni paṭividdhaḥ ti attho
translated: Then, pierced, I was at peace: pierced then by the arrows of lust, etc., while still a householder, I have now attained the destruction of the taints, having come to the Teacher’s Dispensation. Or the meaning can be taken as: pierced, i.e., penetrated, the four truths.

original: Sesaṃ antarantarādīsu vuttattā suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: sesam antar antara ādīsu vutta ttā su viññeyyam eva
translated: The rest is easy to understand, since it has been explained above in the section on the three rounds .

original: Evaṃ thero rañño korabyassa dhammaṃ desetvā satthu santikameva gato. Satthā ca aparabhāge ariyagaṇamajjhe nisinno theraṃ saddhāpabbajitānaṃ aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapesīti.
analyzed: evam theraḥ raññaḥ korabyassa dhammam desetvā satthu santikam eva gataḥ satthā ca aparabhāge ariya gaṇa majjhe nisinno theram saddhā pabbajitānam aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapesi iti
translated: Thus the Elder preached the Dhamma to King Koravya and then returned to the Teacher. Later the Teacher, seated in the midst of the Congregation of Monks, assigned the Elder to the position of being the foremost of those who had gone forth in faith.

original: Raṭṭhapālattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: raṭṭhapāla thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Raṭṭhapāla is finished.

original: 5. Mālukyaputtattheragāthāvaṇṇanā🔽Rūpaṃ disvā sati muṭṭhātiādikā āyasmato mālukyaputtassa gāthā. Imassa āyasmato vatthu
analyzed: rūpam disvā sati muṭṭhā ati ādikā āyasmataḥ mālukyaputtassa gāthā imassa āyasmataḥ vatthu
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Māluṅkyaputta

original: heṭṭhā chakkanipāte vuttameva. Tā pana gāthā therena arahatte patiṭṭhitena ñātīnaṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhā chakkanipāte vuttam eva tā pana gāthā therena arahatte patiṭṭhitena ñātīnam
translated: The Elder Māluṅkyaputta’s verses beginning with the line, “When he sees a form, his mindfulness fails him,” were spoken by the Elder after he had attained Arahatship. The story of the Elder is related in the Commentary on the Fetter of Sense-Desire.🔽The verses were spoken by the Elder in the course of preaching the Dhamma to his kinsmen.

original: dhammadesanāvasena bhāsitā. Idha pana puthujjanakāle “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṃkhittena🔽dhammaṃ desetū”ti yācitena satthārā “taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mālukyaputta, ye te cakkhuviññeyyā
analyzed: dhamma desanā vasena bhāsitā idha pana puthujjana kāle sādhu me bhante bhagavā saṃkhittena  dhammam desetu uti yācitena satthārā tam kim maññasi mālukyaputta ye te cakkhu viññeyyā
translated: But on the occasion referred to in the text, the Elder, while still an ordinary man, said to the Teacher, “Reverend Sir, preach the Dhamma to me in brief.”

original: rūpā adiṭṭhā adiṭṭhapubbā, na ca passasi, na ca te hoti passeyyanti, atthi te tattha
analyzed: rūpā a diṭṭhā a diṭṭha pubbā na ca passasi na ca te hoti passeyyanti atthi te tattha
translated: The Teacher replied, “What think you, Māluṅkyaputta? There are visible objects cognizable by the eye, which you have not seen, have not seen before, and do not see, and it may be that you will not see. Do you say, ‘This is not, this does not come to be; this is not true, this does not exist,’ with reference to what you have not seen, have not seen before, and do not see, and it may be that you will not see?”

original: chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vā”ti? “No hetaṃ, bhante”. “Ye te sotaviññeyyā saddā…pe…🔽ghāna…jivhā…kāya…manoviññeyyā dhammā aviññātā aviññātapubbā, na ca vijānāsi, na ca
analyzed: chandaḥ vā rāgaḥ vā vāti no hetam bhante ye te sota viññeyyā  ghāna jivhā kāya manaḥ viññeyyāḥ dhammāḥ a viññātāḥ a viññāta pubbāḥ na ca vijānāsi na ca
translated: “No, venerable sir.”🔽“Those things cognizable by the ear…🔽cognizable by the mind that have not been cognized, are not being cognized, and are not intended to be cognized, do you have any desire, lust, and affection for them?”

original: te hoti vijāneyyanti, atthi te tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vā”ti? “No hetaṃ, bhante”.🔽“Ettha ca te, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhasutamutaviññātabbesu dhammesu diṭṭhe diṭṭhamattaṃ
analyzed: te hoti vijāneyyanti atthi te tattha chandaḥ vā rāgaḥ vā vāti no ha itam bhante  ettha ca te mālukyaputta diṭṭha suta muta viññātabbesu dhammesu diṭṭhe diṭṭha mattam
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

original: bhavissati, sute sutamattaṃ, mute mutamattaṃ, viññāte viññātamattaṃ bhavissati. Yato🔽kho te, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhasutamutaviññātabbesu dhammesu diṭṭhe diṭṭhamattaṃ, sute
analyzed: bhavissati sute suta mattam mute muta mattam viññāte viññāta mattam bhavissati yatas  kho te mālukyaputta diṭṭha suta muta viññātabbesu dhammesu diṭṭhe diṭṭha mattam sute
translated: “Then, Malunkyaputta, in regard to those things that are seen, heard, sensed, or cognized—in regard to those things that are seen, heard, sensed, or cognized—there will be only what is seen, heard, sensed, and cognized.🔽When there is only what is seen, heard, sensed, and cognized,

original: sutamattaṃ, mute mutamattaṃ, viññāte viññātamattaṃ bhavissati, tato tvaṃ, mālukyaputta,
analyzed: suta mattam mute muta mattam viññāte viññāta mattam bhavissati tatas tvam mālukyaputta
translated: then there is only what is seen, heard, sensed, and cognized.🔽When there is only what is seen, heard, sensed, and cognized, then there is no ‘because of that, that exists.’

original: na tena. Yato tvaṃ, mālukyaputta, na tena, tato tvaṃ, mālukyaputta, na tattha. Yato
analyzed: na tena yatas tvam mālukyaputta na tena tatas tvam mālukyaputta na tattha yatas
translated: When there is no ‘because of that, that exists,’ then there is no dependence on anything in the world.🔽When there is no dependence on anything in the world,

original: tvaṃ, mālukyaputta, na tattha, tato tvaṃ, mālukyaputta, nevidha na huraṃ na ubhayamantarena,
analyzed: tvam mālukyaputta na tattha tvam mālukyaputta na ubhayam antarena
translated: You, Māluṅkyaputta, are not there, and so you are neither here nor beyond,🔽and that is the end of suffering.”

original: esevanto dukkhassā”ti. Saṃkhittena dhamme desite tassa dhammassa sādhukaṃ uggahitabhāvaṃ pakāsentena –
analyzed: esevantaḥ dukkhassa ati saṃkhittena dhamme desite tassa dhammassa sādhukam uggahita bhāvam pakāsentena
translated: When the Dhamma had been taught in brief, he showed the venerable Māluṅkyaputta how he had properly grasped its meaning by saying:

original: “Rūpaṃ disvā sati muṭṭhā, piyaṃ nimittaṃ manasi karoto;
analyzed: rūpam disvā sati muṭṭhā piyam nimittam manasi karoto
translated: “Having seen a visible form, his mindfulness is confused, he attends to the sign of the visible-form,

original: Sārattacitto vedeti, tañca ajjhosa tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: sāratta cittaḥ vedeti tat ca ajjhosa tiṭṭhati
translated: he experiences it with a mind full of greed, and he misconstrues it.

original: “Tassa vaḍḍhanti vedanā, anekā rūpasambhavā;
analyzed: tassa vaḍḍhanti vedanāḥ anekāḥ rūpa sambhavā
translated: “His feelings increase, many kinds of visible-form arise,

original: Abhijjhā ca vihesā ca, cittamassūpahaññati;
analyzed: abhijjhā ca vihesā ca cittam assu upahaññati
translated: and his mind is overcome by covetousness and ill will.

original: Evamācinato dukkhaṃ, ārā nibbāna vuccati.
analyzed: evam ācinataḥ dukkham ārā nibbāna vuccati
translated: Thus suffering is stored up for him, and that is called far from Nibbāna.

original: “Saddaṃ sutvā sati muṭṭhā, piyaṃ nimittaṃ manasi karoto;
analyzed: saddam sutvā sati muṭṭhā piyam nimittam manasi karoto
translated: “Having heard a sound, his mindfulness is confused, he attends to the sign of the sound,

original: Sārattacitto vedeti, tañca ajjhosa tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: sāratta cittaḥ vedeti tat ca ajjhosa tiṭṭhati
translated: he experiences it with a mind full of greed, and he misconstrues it.

original: “Tassa vaḍḍhanti vedanā, anekā saddasambhavā;
analyzed: tassa vaḍḍhanti vedanā anekā sadda sambhavā
translated: “His feelings increase, many kinds of sound arise,

original: Abhijjhā ca vihesā ca, cittamassūpahaññati;
analyzed: abhijjhā ca vihesā ca cittam assu upahaññati
translated: and his mind is overcome by covetousness and ill will.

original: Evamācinato dukkhaṃ, ārā nibbāna vuccati.
analyzed: evam ācinataḥ dukkham ārā nibbāna vuccati
translated: Thus suffering is stored up for him, and that is called far from Nibbāna.
