original: Imā gāthā abhāsi.
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: He spoke these verses.

original: Tattha rūpaṃ disvāti cakkhuviññeyyaṃ rūpaṃ cakkhudvārena upalabhitvā. Sati muṭṭhā,🔽piyaṃ nimittaṃ manasi karototi tasmiṃ rūpe diṭṭhamatte eva aṭṭhatvā subhanimittaṃ
analyzed: tattha rūpam disvā ati cakkhu viññeyyam rūpam cakkhu dvārena upalabhitvā sati muṭṭhā  piyam nimittam manasi karota iti tasmin rūpe diṭṭha matte eva subha nimittam
translated: Herein, having seen a visible object with the eye: having perceived visible object cognizable by the eye by means of the eye faculty. His mindfulness is muddled,

original: manasi karoto subhākāraggahaṇavasena ayoniso manasi karoto sati muṭṭhā hoti. Tathā
analyzed: manasi karoto subha ākāra ggahaṇa vasena ayonisaḥ manasi karoto sati muṭṭhā hoti tathā
translated: When he gives attention to the sign of the sensual aspect: when, instead of remaining with the mere seen aspect of that visible object, he gives attention to the sign of the sensual aspect, that is, when he gives attention to it by apprehending the aspect of beauty, he gives attention to it unprofitably. His mindfulness is muddled.

original: ca sati sārattacitto vedeti taṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ ratto, giddho, gadhito hutvā anubhavati,
analyzed: ca sati sā aratta cittaḥ veda iti tam rūpa ārammaṇam rattaḥ giddhaḥ gadhitaḥ hutvā anubhavati
translated: And so, with his mind attached, he feels: he experiences that visible-object-as-object with a mind attached to it, with a mind greedy for it, with a mind that clings to it.

original: assādeti, abhinandati. Tathābhūto ca tañca ajjhosa tiṭṭhatīti tañca rūpārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: assādeti abhinandati tathābhūtaḥ ca tat ca ajjhosa tiṭṭhati iti tat ca rūpa ārammaṇam
translated: He relishes it and delights in it. And he persists in misapprehending that object thus:

original: ajjhosāya “sukhaṃ sukha”nti abhinivissa gilitvā pariniṭṭhāpetvā tiṭṭhati.🔽Tassa vaḍḍhanti vedanā, anekā rūpasambhavāti tassa evarūpassa puggalassa rūpasambhavā
analyzed: ajjhosāya sukham sukhanti abhinivissa gilitvā pariniṭṭhāpetvā tiṭṭhati  tassa vaḍḍhanti vedanāḥ anekāḥ tassa evarūpassa puggalassa rūpa sambhavā
translated: He persists in misapprehending that visible-data object thus, “Pleasure, pleasure!” He swallows it whole, he takes it to his heart, he misapprehends it.🔽His feelings grow, and many a form arises in him:

original: rūpārammaṇā sukhādibhedena anekā vedanā kilesuppattihetubhūtā vaḍḍhanti. Abhijjhā
analyzed: rūpa ārammaṇā sukha ādi bhedena anekā vedanā kilesu patti hetu bhūtā vaḍḍhanti abhijjhā
translated: As a result of the arising of the visible-data object, many feelings of pleasure, etc., arise in him, and they grow, and they become causes for the arising of defilements.🔽Covetousness and ill will:

original: ca vihesā ca, cittamassūpahaññatīti piyarūpe sārajjanavasena uppajjamānāya abhijjhāya,
analyzed: ca vihesā ca cittam assu upahaññati iti piya rūpe sārajjana vasena uppajjamānāya abhijjhāya
translated: His mind is overcome and enslaved: his mind is overcome and enslaved by the covetousness that arises through attachment to what is likeable,

original: apiyarūpe byāpajjanavasena piyarūpasseva vipariṇāmaññathābhāvāya uppajjamānāya sokādilakkhaṇāya🔽vihesāya ca assa puggalassa cittaṃ upahaññati bādhīyati. Evamācinato dukkhanti vuttākārena
analyzed: apiya rūpe byāpajjana vasena piya rūpassa iva vipariṇāma aññathābhāvāya uppajjamānāya soka ādi lakkhaṇāya  vihesāya ca assa puggalassa cittam upahaññati bādhīyati evam ācinataḥ dukkhanti vutta ākārena
translated: and by the ill will that arises through aversion to what is unlikeable, and by the grief that arises through the change of what is likeable into something unlikeable.🔽Thus he stores up pain:

original: taṃ taṃ vedanassādavasena bhavābhisaṅkhāraṃ ācinato vaṭṭadukkhaṃ pavattati. Tenāha
analyzed: tam tam vedanā ssāda vasena bhava abhisaṅkhāram ācinataḥ vaṭṭa dukkham pavattati tena āha
translated: he stores up the suffering of the round by storing up the kamma that generates it through relishing the various kinds of feeling. Hence it is said:

original: bhagavā – “vedanāpaccayā taṇhā…pe… dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hotī”ti. Tathābhūtassa
analyzed: bhagavā vedanā paccayā taṇhā pe dukkha kkhandhassa samudayaḥ hoti iti tathābhūtassa
translated: The Blessed One said: “With feeling as condition, craving. … The origin of this whole mass of suffering is the craving that leads to further becoming, for with the cessation of craving there is the cessation of dukkha.🔽Nibbana is said to be far from one who is thus, far away, remote. The meaning is that it is difficult for him to attain.

original: ārā ārakā dūre nibbānaṃ vuccati, tassa taṃ dullabhanti attho. Saddaṃ sutvātiādigāthāsupi
analyzed: ārā ārakā dūre nibbānam vuccati tassa tam dullabhanti attho saddam sutvā iti ādi gāthāsu pi
translated: The meaning of the verses beginning with “Having heard a sound” should be understood in the way already stated.

original: vuttanayeneva attho veditabbo. Tattha ghatvāti ghāyitvā. Bhotvāti sāyitvā. Phussāti
analyzed: vutta nayena iva atthaḥ veditabbaḥ tattha ghatvā iti ghāyitvā bhotvā ati sāyitvā phussa ati
translated: Herein, having smelled : having smelled a smell. Having tasted : having tasted a taste. Having touched : having touched a tangible datum.

original: phusitvā. Dhammaṃ ñatvāti dhammārammaṇaṃ vijānitvā.🔽Evaṃ chadvāragocare sārajjantassa vaṭṭaṃ dassetvā idāni tattha virajjantassa vivaṭṭaṃ🔽dassento “na so rajjati rūpesū”tiādimāha. Tattha na so rajjati rūpesu, rūpaṃ disvā🔽paṭissatoti yo puggalo rūpaṃ disvā āpāthagataṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ cakkhudvārikena viññāṇasantānena
analyzed: phusitvā dhammam ñatvā ati dhamma ārammaṇam vijānitvā  evam cha dvāra gocare sārajjantassa vaṭṭam dassetvā idāni tattha virajjantassa vivaṭṭam  dassentaḥ na saḥ rajjati rūpesu uti ādim āha tattha na saḥ rajjati rūpesu rūpam disvā  paṭissato ti yaḥ puggalaḥ rūpam disvā āpātha gatam rūpa ārammaṇam cakkhu dvārikena viññāṇa santānena
translated: Having known a mental object : having cognized a mental-object object.🔽Having thus shown the round of existence for one who is enamored with the sense objects of the six sense doors, now, in order to show the cessation of the round for one who is dispassionate with regard to them, he said, “He does not delight in visible forms” .

original: gahetvā catusampajaññavasena sampajānakāritāya paṭissato hoti, so rūpārammaṇesu na
analyzed: gahetvā catu sampajañña vasena sampajāna kāri tāya paṭissataḥ hoti so rūpa ārammaṇesu na
translated: Herein, he does not delight in visible forms, mindful, having seen a visible form: that person who, having seen a visible form that has come into the focus of the eye, having apprehended the visible-form object by means of the consciousness series that enters through the eye door, and having made himself fully aware by means of the four kinds of full awareness , is mindful, is fully aware, he does not delight in the visible-form objects.

original: rajjati rāgaṃ na janeti, aññadatthu virattacitto vedeti, rūpārammaṇamhi samudayādito🔽yathābhūtaṃ pajānanto nibbindati, nibbindanto taṃ tatthuppannavedanañca virattacitto
analyzed: rajjati rāgam na janeti aññadatthu viratta cittaḥ vedeti rūpa ārammaṇamhi samudaya āditaḥ  yathābhūtam pajānantaḥ nibbindati nibbindantaḥ tam tattha uppanna vedanam ca viratta cittaḥ
translated: He feels it with a mind free from attachment.🔽He understands as it actually is the gratification in the form, the danger in the form, and the escape from the form.

original: vedeti, tathābhūto ca tañca najjhosa tiṭṭhatīti taṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ sammadeva virattacittatāya
analyzed: vedeti tathābhūtaḥ ca tat ca tiṭṭhati iti tam rūpa ārammaṇam sammat eva viratta citta tāya
translated: He becomes dispassionate towards the form. With a mind dispassionate he feels the feeling that has arisen in him.🔽And he does not remain clinging to that form.

original: ajjhosāya na tiṭṭhati “etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”ti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivasena nābhinivisati.🔽Yathāssa passato rūpanti assa yogino yathā tattha abhijjhādayo nappavattanti, evaṃ
analyzed: ajjhosāya na tiṭṭhati etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati taṇhā māna diṭṭhi vasena na abhinivisati  yathā assa passataḥ assa yoginaḥ yathā tattha abhijjhā ādayaḥ na pavattanti evam
translated: He does not remain clinging to that form by way of craving, conceit, and views, thinking “This is mine, this I am, this is my self.”🔽As he sees the form in this way,🔽and as he cultivates the contemplation of the form as impermanent, etc.,

original: aniccādito rūpaṃ passantassa. Sevato cāpi vedananti taṃ ārabbha uppannaṃ vedanaṃ
analyzed: anicca āditaḥ rūpam passantassa sevataḥ ca api vedanan ti tam ārabbha uppannam vedanam
translated: and as he cultivates the feeling that arises in him in connection with that form,🔽and the states associated with that feeling, by making them the object of his contemplation,

original: taṃsampayuttadhamme ca gocarasevanāya sevato cāpi. Khīyatīti sabbaṃ kilesavaṭṭaṃ
analyzed: tad sampayutta dhamme ca gocara sevanāya sevataḥ ca api khīyati iti sabbam kilesa vaṭṭam
translated: all the round of defilements comes to destruction and exhaustion.

original: parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gacchati. Nopacīyatīti na upaciyati na ācayaṃ gacchati. Evaṃ
analyzed: parikkhayam pariyādānam gacchati na upacīyati iti na upaciyati na ācayam gacchati evam
translated: It does not increase, it does not go on accumulating.

original: so caratī satoti evaṃ kilesāpanayanapaṭipattiyā sato sampajāno hutvā carati, viharati.
analyzed: saḥ carati sato ti evam kilesa apanayana paṭipattiyā sato sampajānaḥ hutvā carati viharati
translated: He fares thus mindful : he fares thus, he lives thus, mindful, clearly comprehending, by the practice of the removal of defilements.

original: Evaṃ apacinato dukkhanti vuttanayena apacayagāminiyā maggapaññāya sakalaṃ vaṭṭadukkhaṃ
analyzed: evam apacinataḥ dukkhan ti vutta nayena apacaya gāminiyā magga paññāya sakalam vaṭṭa dukkham
translated: Thus for one who is removing : thus for one who is removing the entire suffering of the round of rebirths by the path of insight which leads to the removal of suffering,

original: apacinantassa. Santike nibbāna vuccatīti saupādisesaanupādisesanibbānadhātusamīpe🔽evāti vuccati asaṅkhatāya dhātuyā sacchikatattā. Na so rajjati saddesūtiādīsupi imināva
analyzed: apacinantassa santike nibbāna vuccati iti sa aupādisesa anupādisesa nibbāna dhātu samīpe  eva ati vuccati asaṅkhatāya dhātuyā sacchikata ttā na saḥ rajjati
translated: Nibbāna is said to be near : Nibbāna is said to be near to the element of Nibbāna with and without residue of clinging respectively,

original: nayena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: nayena atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: because the unformed element has been realized. He is not excited by sounds : the meaning should be understood in this way too.

original: Evaṃ thero imāhi gāthāhi satthu ovādassa attanā upadhāritabhāvaṃ pavedetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā satthāraṃ vanditvā gato nacirasseva vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇīti.
analyzed: evam theraḥ imāhi gāthāhi satthu ovādassa attanā upadhārita bhāvam pavedetvā uṭṭhāya āsanā satthāram vanditvā gataḥ nacirassa iva vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam pāpuṇi iti
translated: After the elder had thus declared his own retention of the Teacher’s advice, he rose from his seat, paid homage to the Teacher, and departed. Before long he increased his insight and attained Arahantship.

original: Mālukyaputtattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mālukyaputta thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Māluṅkyaputta is finished.

original: 6. Selattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: selatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Verses of the Elder Selā

original: Paripuṇṇakāyotiādikā āyasmato selattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayaṃ kira padumuttarabhagavato
analyzed: paripuṇṇa kāyaḥ ti ādikā āyasmataḥ sela ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam kira padumuttara bhagavataḥ
translated: The verses beginning with the words “Paripuṇṇakāyo” are those of the Elder Selā. What is the origin of the story? It seems that this elder was a lay devotee of the Blessed One Padumuttara.

original: kāle kulagehe nibbattitvā viññutaṃ patto gaṇapāmokkho hutvā tīṇi purisasatāni samādapetvā🔽tehi saddhiṃ satthu gandhakuṭiṃ kāretvā katapariyositāya gandhakuṭiyā sabhikkhusaṅghassa
analyzed: kāle kula gehe nibbattitvā viññutam pattaḥ gaṇapāmokkhaḥ hutvā tīṇi purisa satāni samādapetvā  tehi saddhim satthu gandha kuṭim kāretvā kata pariyositāya gandha kuṭiyā sa bhikkhu saṅghassa
translated: He was born in a good family in a suitable time, and when he had attained to years of discretion, he became the head of a company of three hundred men.🔽He built a Perfumed Chamber for the Teacher, and when the Perfumed Chamber was completed, he made a great offering to the Teacher and to the Congregation of Monks,

original: bhagavato mahādānaṃ pavattetvā satthāraṃ bhikkhū ca ticīvarena acchādesi. So tena
analyzed: bhagavataḥ mahādānam pavattetvā satthāram bhikkhū ca ti cīvarena acchādesi saḥ tena
translated: and clothed the Teacher and the Congregation of Monks with three robes each. By reason of this meritorious deed,

original: puññakammena ekaṃ buddhantaraṃ devaloke eva vasitvā tato cuto devamanussesu saṃsaranto
analyzed: puñña kammena ekam buddha antaram deva loke eva vasitvā tatas cutaḥ deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ
translated: he dwelt in the World of the Gods for the interval of one Buddha-epoch, and when he passed thence, he was reborn among gods and men (in a succession of births) that was exclusively happy.

original: imasmiṃ buddhuppāde aṅguttarāpesu āpaṇe nāma brāhmaṇagāme brāhmaṇakule nibbattitvā🔽seloti laddhanāmo ahosi. So vayappatto tīsu vedesu, brāhmaṇasippesu ca nipphattiṃ🔽gantvā tīṇi māṇavakasatāni mante vācento āpaṇe paṭivasati. Tena ca samayena satthā
analyzed: imasmin buddhuppāde aṅguttarāpesu āpaṇe nāma brāhmaṇa gāme brāhmaṇa kule nibbattitvā  selaḥ iti laddha nāmaḥ ahosi saḥ vaya patto tīsu vedesu brāhmaṇa sippesu ca nipphattim  gantvā tīṇi māṇavaka satāni mante vācentaḥ āpaṇe paṭivasati tena ca samayena satthā
translated: In this present Buddha-epoch he was reborn in the Brahmana family of a Brahmana village named Āpaṇa, in the country of the Anguttarāpas.🔽He was given the name of Seḷa. When he had attained to years of discretion, he mastered the Three Vedas and the eighteen branches of learning pertaining to Brahmans,🔽and became a teacher of the Vedas, and dwelt in Āpaṇa, teaching three hundred youths. At that time the Teacher,

original: sāvatthito nikkhamitvā aḍḍhateḷasahi bhikkhusatehi saddhiṃ aṅguttarāpesu cārikaṃ
analyzed: sāvatthitaḥ nikkhamitvā aḍḍhateḷasahi bhikkhu satehi saddhim aṅguttarāpesu cārikam
translated: having left Sāvatthi,

original: caranto selassa, antevāsikānañca ñāṇaparipākaṃ disvā aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe viharati.
analyzed: carantaḥ selassa antevāsikānam ca ñāṇa paripākam disvā aññatarasmim vana saṇḍe viharati
translated: As he was walking about, he saw that the time was ripe for the conversion of the pupils of the Hermit Selā, and therefore he went and dwelt in a certain forest grove.

original: Atha keṇiyo nāma jaṭilo satthu āgamanaṃ sutvā tattha gantvā saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena
analyzed: atha keṇiyaḥ nāma jaṭilaḥ satthu āgamanam sutvā tattha gantvā saddhim bhikkhu saṅghena
translated: When the Hermit Keṇiya heard that the Teacher had come, he went to him, and

original: satthāraṃ svātanāya nimantetvā sake assame pahūtaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādeti.
analyzed: satthāram svātanāya nimantetvā sake assame pahūtam khādanīyam bhojanīyam paṭiyādeti
translated: invited the Teacher and the Congregation of Monks to take a meal with him on the morrow. Accordingly he prepared in his own hermitage a plentiful supply of hard and soft food.

original: Tasmiñca samaye selo brāhmaṇo saddhiṃ tīhi māṇavakasatehi jaṅghāvihāraṃ anuvicaranto🔽keṇiyassa assamaṃ pavisitvā jaṭile kaṭṭhaphālanuddhanasampādanādinā dānūpakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: tasmin ca samaye selaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ saddhim tīhi māṇavaka satehi jaṅghāvihāram anuvicarantaḥ  keṇiyassa assamam pavisitvā jaṭile kaṭṭha phālana uddhana sampādana ādinā dānu upakaraṇam
translated: Now on that occasion the Brahman Selā, accompanied by three hundred young men, was walking up and down,🔽and he entered the hermitage of Keṇiya. He saw the hermits engaged in preparing the requisites for the entertainment, such as splitting firewood, preparing the water-barrel, and so forth,

original: sajjente disvā, “kiṃ nu kho te, keṇiya, mahāyañño paccupaṭṭhito”tiādiṃ pucchitvā
analyzed: sajja inte disvā kim nu kho te keṇiya mahā yaññaḥ paccupaṭṭhitaḥ tiādim pucchitvā
translated: and asked, “Keṇiya, are you preparing for a great sacrifice?” and so forth.

original: tena “buddho bhagavā mayā svātanāya nimantito”ti vutte “buddho”ti vacanaṃ sutvāva
analyzed: tena buddhaḥ bhagavā mayā svātanāya nimantitaḥ iti vutte buddhaḥ iti vacanam sutvā ava
translated: When Keṇiya replied, “The Buddha, the Blessed One, has been invited by me to take a meal with me on the morrow,” the Brahman Selā, as soon as he heard the word “Buddha,”

original: haṭṭho udaggo pītisomanassajāto tāvadeva māṇavakehi saddhiṃ satthāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: haṭṭhaḥ udaggaḥ pīti somanassa jātaḥ tāvat eva māṇavakehi saddhim satthāram upasaṅkamitvā
translated: was filled with joy and gladness, and accompanied by the young men, went to the Teacher.

original: katapaṭisanthāro ekamantaṃ nisinno bhagavato kāye bāttiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni disvā
analyzed: kata paṭisanthāraḥ ekamantam nisinnaḥ bhagavato kāye bāttiṃsa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇāni disvā
translated: Seeing the thirty-two marks of a Great Man on the Lord’s body,🔽he thought: ‘One who has a body with these marks is of two kinds:

original: “imehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato rājā vā hoti cakkavattī, buddho vā loke vivaṭṭacchado,
analyzed: imehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgataḥ rājā vā hoti cakkavattī buddhaḥ vā loke vivaṭṭa chado
translated: either a Tathāgata perfected one, fully awakened Buddha, or a universal monarch.

original: ayaṃ pana pabbajito, no ca kho naṃ jānāmi ‘buddho vā, no vā’, sutaṃ kho pana metaṃ
analyzed: ayam pana pabbajitaḥ no ca kho nam jānāmi buddhaḥ vā no vā sutam kho pana mā etam
translated: But this one is gone forth, and I do not know whether he is a Buddha or not.

original: brāhmaṇānaṃ vuddhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ ‘ye te bhavanti
analyzed: brāhmaṇānam vuddhānam mahallakānam ācariya pācariyānam bhāsamānānam ye te bhavanti
translated: I have heard from old and venerable Brahmins, teachers of teachers,🔽that when a Tathāgata, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha arises in the world,

original: arahanto sammāsambuddhā, te sake vaṇṇe bhaññamāne attānaṃ pātukarontī’ti asammāsambuddho
analyzed: arahantaḥ sammāsambuddhā te sake vaṇṇe bhaññamāne attānam pātukaronti iti a sammāsambuddhaḥ
translated: one who is not a fully awakened Buddha is embarrassed and abashed

original: hi sammukhe ṭhatvā buddhaguṇehi abhitthavīyamāno sārajjati maṅkubhāvaṃ āpajjati avesārajjappattatāya
analyzed: hi sammukhe ṭhatvā buddha guṇehi sārajjati maṅku bhāvam āpajjati a vesārajja ppatta tāya
translated: in the presence of a fully awakened Buddha, and is unable to stand before him.

original: ananuyogakkhamattā, yaṃnūnāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthaveyya”nti
analyzed: an anuyoga khama ttā yaṃ nūna aham samaṇam gotamam sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi
translated: So let me now praise the recluse Gotama with fitting verses.’

original: evaṃ pana cintetvā –
analyzed: evam pana cintetvā
translated: Having thought thus, he said:

original: “Paripuṇṇakāyo suruci, sujāto cārudassano;
analyzed: paripuṇṇa kāyaḥ su ruci sujātaḥ cāru dassano
translated: ‘With a body complete, lovely, well-formed, well-proportioned,

original: Suvaṇṇavaṇṇosi bhagavā, susukkadāṭhosi vīriyavā.
analyzed: suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ asi bhagavā su sukka dāṭhaḥ asi vīriyavā
translated: “You are golden-hued, O Blessed One, with beautiful white teeth and energy.

original: “Narassa hi sujātassa, ye bhavanti viyañjanā;
analyzed: narassa hi su jātassa ye bhavanti viyañjanā
translated: “For a man of good birth, whatever marks there are,

original: Sabbe te tava kāyasmiṃ, mahāpurisalakkhaṇā.
analyzed: sabbe te tava kāyasmim mahā purisa lakkhaṇā
translated: All of them are on your body, O Great Man’s Characteristics.

original: “Pasannanetto sumukho, brahā uju patāpavā;
analyzed: pasanna nettaḥ su mukhaḥ brahāḥ uju patāpavā
translated: “With clear eyes and a beautiful face, you are tall, straight, and radiant;

original: Majjhe samaṇasaṅghassa, ādiccova virocasi.
analyzed: majjhe samaṇa saṅghassa ādicca uva virocasi
translated: In the midst of the Saṅgha of monks, you shine like the sun.

original: “Kalyāṇadassano bhikkhu, kañcanasannibhattaco;
analyzed: kalyāṇa dassanaḥ
translated: “A monk of beautiful appearance, with a body like gold,

original: Kiṃ te samaṇabhāvena, evaṃ uttamavaṇṇino.
analyzed: kim te samaṇa bhāvena evam uttama vaṇṇinaḥ
translated: Why do you have the state of a monk, being so supremely beautiful?

original: “Rājā arahasi bhavituṃ, cakkavattī rathesabho;
analyzed: rājā arahasi bhavitum cakkavattī rathesabhaḥ
translated: “You are fit to be a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a charioteer,

original: Cāturanto vijitāvī, jambusaṇḍassa issaro.
analyzed: cāturantaḥ vijitāvī jambusaṇḍassa issaraḥ
translated: A conqueror of the four quarters who has gained stability in the Rose-Apple Island.

original: “Khattiyā bhogī rājāno, anuyantā bhavanti te;
analyzed: khattiyāḥ bhogī rājānaḥ anuyantā bhavanti te
translated: “The Khattiyas, the rich, and the kings will be your followers;

original: Rājābhirājā manujindo, rajjaṃ kārehi gotamā”ti. –
analyzed: rāja abhirājā manujindaḥ rajjam kārehi gotama ati
translated: You are a king of kings, a lord of men. Rule, O Gotama!”

original: Chahi gāthāhi bhagavantaṃ abhitthavi.
analyzed: chahi gāthāhi bhagavantam
translated: He praised the Blessed One with these six stanzas.

original: Tattha paripuṇṇakāyoti abhibyattarūpānaṃ dvattiṃsāya mahāpurisalakkhaṇānaṃ paripuṇṇatāya
analyzed: tattha paripuṇṇa kāyaḥ ti abhibyatta rūpānam dvattiṃsāya mahāpurisa lakkhaṇānam paripuṇṇa tāya
translated: Therein, “with a body complete with the characteristics” means that he is complete with the thirty-two characteristics of a Great Man.

original: ahīnaṅgapaccaṅgatāya ca paripuṇṇasarīro. Surucīti sundarasarīrappabho. Sujātoti ārohapariṇāhasampattiyā,
analyzed: ca paripuṇṇa sarīro suruci iti sundara sarīra ppabho sujātaḥ iti āroha pariṇāha sampattiyā
translated: and he was complete in all his limbs and minor parts, and his body was well-proportioned. Suruci means having a beautiful body. Sujata means well-born, well-produced, by the excellence of his height and breadth,

original: saṇṭhānasampattiyā ca sunibbatto. Cārudassanoti sucirampi passantānaṃ atittijanakaṃ🔽appaṭikkūlaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ cāru eva dassanaṃ assāti cārudassano. Keci panāhu “cārudassanoti
analyzed: saṇṭhāna sampattiyā ca su nibbattaḥ cāru dassanaḥ ti su ciram pi passantānam a tittijanakam  appaṭikkūlam ramaṇīyam cāru eva dassanam assāti cāru dassano keci pana āhu cāru dassano ti
translated: and by the excellence of his figure. Cāru-dassano means he had a beautiful appearance,🔽which was so delightful that those who saw it were never satisfied, even for a long time.🔽But some say that cāru-dassano means he had beautiful eyes. Suvaṇṇavaṇṇo means having a golden complexion. Asīti bhavasi, this line should be connected with all the lines beginning with “paripuṇṇakāyo asī.”

original: sundaranetto”ti. Suvaṇṇavaṇṇoti suvaṇṇasadisavaṇṇo. Asīti bhavasi, idaṃ padaṃ “paripuṇṇakāyo
analyzed: sundara nettaḥ iti suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ ti suvaṇṇa sadisa vaṇṇaḥ asi iti bhavasi idam padam paripuṇṇa kāyaḥ
translated: Susukkadāṭho means having very white teeth.

original: asī”tiādinā sabbapadehi yojetabbaṃ. Susukkadāṭhoti suṭṭhu sukkadāṭho. Bhagavato hi
analyzed: asi iti ādinā sabba padehi yojetabbam su sukka dāṭho ti suṭṭhu sukka dāṭhaḥ bhagavataḥ hi
translated: For from the Blessed One’s teeth

original: dāṭhāhi candakiraṇā viya dhavalarasmiyo niccharanti. Vīriyavāti vīriyapāramīpāripūriyā
analyzed: candakiraṇāḥ viya dhavala rasmiyaḥ niccharanti vīriya vāti vīriya pāramī pāripūriyā
translated: rays of light shine forth like moonbeams. Vīriyavāti means endowed with excellence, by the fulfilment of the perfection of energy,

original: caturaṅgasamannāgatavīriyādhiṭṭhānato catubbidhassa sammappadhānassa sampattiyā ca atisayayutto.
analyzed: catur aṅga samannāgata vīriya adhiṭṭhānato catubbidhassa sammappadhānassa sampattiyā ca atisaya yutto
translated: and by the excellence of the four right endeavours, which are based on energy endowed with the four factors.

original: Narassa hi sujātassāti samatiṃsāya pāramīnaṃ, ariyassa vā cakkavattīvattassa paripūritattā
analyzed: narassa hi sujātassa ati samatiṃsāya ariyassa vā cakkavattī vattassa paripūrita ttā
translated: For the man well-born: because of the fulfilment of the thirty perfections, or of the noble wheel-turning monarch’s duties,

original: suṭṭhu sammadeva jātassa narassa, mahāpurisassāti attho. Sabbe teti ye mahāpurisabhāvaṃ
analyzed: suṭṭhu sammat eva jātassa narassa mahā purisassa ati attho sabbe te iti ye mahā purisa bhāvam
translated: the man well-born, well-born indeed, is the meaning. All those: all those who show the state of a great man,

original: loke aggapuggalabhāvaṃ byañjayantīti byañjanāti laddhavohārasuppatiṭṭhitapādatādibāttiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇasaṅkhātā
analyzed: loke agga puggala bhāvam byañjayanti iti laddha vohāra su patiṭṭhita pāda tādi bāttiṃsa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇa saṅkhātā
translated: the state of the foremost person in the world, are called characteristics and marks. The thirty-two characteristics of a great man, such as having feet with level tread, etc.,

original: tambanakhatuṅganakhatādiasītianubyañjanasaṅkhātā ca rūpaguṇā, te anavasesā, tava
analyzed: tamba nakha tuṅga nakha tā ādi asi iti anubyañjana saṅkhātā ca rūpa guṇā te anavasesā tava
translated: and the eighty minor marks, such as having toes and fingers connected by webs of skin, etc., are called characteristics and marks. Those, without exception,

original: kāyasmiṃ santīti vacanaseso.
analyzed: kāyasmim santi iti vacana sesaḥ
translated: are in your body, is the meaning of the words.

original: Mahāpurisalakkhaṇāti pubbe vuttabyañjanāneva vacanantarena nigamento āha.
analyzed: mahāpurisa lakkhaṇā ti pubbe vutta byañjanāni eva vacana antarena nigamentaḥ āha
translated: Great man’s characteristics: he said this in order to point out by another expression the characteristics mentioned above.

original: Idāni tesu lakkhaṇesu attanā abhirucitehi lakkhaṇehi bhagavantaṃ thomento “pasannanetto”tiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni tesu lakkhaṇesu attanā abhirucitehi lakkhaṇehi bhagavantam thomentaḥ pasanna netto ti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to praise the Blessed One with the characteristics he himself approved, he said, “With eyes serene,” and so forth.🔽For the Blessed One has eyes serene because of the perfection of the five kinds of clearness of complexion,

original: Bhagavā hi pañca vaṇṇapasādasampattiyā pasannanetto. Paripuṇṇacandamaṇḍalasadisamukhatāya
analyzed: bhagavā hi pañca vaṇṇa pasāda sampattiyā pasanna nettaḥ paripuṇṇa canda maṇḍala sadisa mukha tāya
translated: and a face like the full moon.

original: sumukho. Ārohapariṇāhasampattiyā brahā. Brahmujugattatāya uju. Jutimantatāya patāpavā.
analyzed: su mukhaḥ āroha pariṇāha sampattiyā brahāḥ uju jutimantatāya patāpavā
translated: He is Sumukha (the one with a beautiful face). He is Brahmā because he is endowed with the perfection of height and breadth. He is Uju because he is endowed with the straightness of Brahmā. He is Patāpavā because he is endowed with splendour.

original: Idāni tameva patāpavantataṃ ādiccūpamāya vibhāvento “majjhe samaṇasaṅghassā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni tam eva vibhāventaḥ majjhe samaṇa saṅghassa ati ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to illustrate his splendour by means of the simile of the sun, he says, “In the midst of the Saṅgha of monks,” etc.

original: Tattha ādiccova virocasīti yathā ādicco uggacchanto sabbaṃ tamagataṃ vidhametvā ālokaṃ
analyzed: tattha ādiccaḥ uva virocasi iti yathā ādiccaḥ uggacchantaḥ sabbam tama gatam vidhametvā ālokam
translated: There, he says, “You shine like the sun,” meaning that just as the sun, rising, dispels all darkness and makes light,

original: karonto virocati, evaṃ tvampi anto ceva bahi ca sabbaṃ avijjātamaṃ viddhaṃsetvā ñāṇālokaṃ karonto virocasi.
analyzed: karontaḥ virocati evam tvam pi antar ca iva bahi ca sabbam avijjātamam viddhaṃsetvā ñāṇa ālokam karontaḥ virocasi
translated: so you also, dispelling all the darkness of ignorance, both within and without, make the light of knowledge.

original: Dassanīyarūpatāya aṅgīgatānaṃ dassanasampattīnaṃ āvahanato, kalyāṇehi pañcahi dassanehi samannāgatattā ca kalyāṇadassano. Uttamavaṇṇinoti uttamavaṇṇasampannassa.
analyzed: dassanīya rūpatāya aṅgīgatānam dassana sampattīnam āvahanataḥ kalyāṇehi pañcahi dassanehi samannāgata ttā ca kalyāṇa dassanaḥ uttama vaṇṇinaḥ ti uttama vaṇṇa sampannassa
translated: He is Kalyāṇadassana because he is endowed with the five good sights, that is, because he is endowed with the five good sights of being worthy of being seen, of being worthy of being invited to accept alms, of being worthy of being worshipped, of being worthy of being saluted with joined palms, and of being worthy of being endowed with the perfection of the highest beauty.

original: Cakkavattīti cakkaratanaṃ vatteti, catūhi sampatticakkehi vatteti, tehi ca pare vatteti.
analyzed: cakkavattī iti cakka ratanam vattā iti catūhi sampatti cakkehi vattā iti tehi ca pare vattā iti
translated: He is Cakkavatti because he turns the wheel of the Dhamma, because he turns the four wheels of prosperity, and because he causes others to turn them.

original: Parahitāya iriyāpathacakkānaṃ vatto etasmiṃ atthīti cakkavattī. Atha vā catūhi acchariyadhammehi🔽ca saṅgahavatthūhi ca samannāgamena parehi anabhibhavanīyassa āṇācakkassa vatto etasmiṃ
analyzed: para hitāya iriyāpatha cakkānam vatto etasmin atthi iti cakkavattī atha vā catūhi acchariya dhammehi  ca saṅgaha vatthūhi ca samannāgamena parehi an abhibhavanīyassa āṇā cakkassa vatto etasmin
translated: He is a “wheel-turner” because of the possession of the wheel of conduct that is beneficial to others.🔽Or alternatively, he is a “wheel-turner” because of the possession of the wheel of command that is not surpassed by others by means of the four kinds of wonderful and marvellous things and by means of the four means of gathering .🔽

translated: He is the best. Atitulo: he has gone beyond the scale, the meaning is, he is incomparable. Vase katvā: having brought under his own control. Modāmi akutobhayo: I rejoice, being free from fear from anywhere.

All his foes: all his adversaries, namely, the aggregates, the defilements, the death that is a formation, the devaputramara, and so on. Having brought under his control: having brought under his own control. I rejoice, free from fear: I rejoice with the happiness of concentration and the happiness of the bliss of Nibbana, free from fear from any quarter.

translated: “Like a flame on a mountain-top, like the moon on the night of the full moon,

original: Naḷaggivaṇṇasaṅkāso, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: naḷaggi vaṇṇa saṅkāsaḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: Like the flame of a reed, he has been invited for tomorrow.

original: “Asambhīto bhayātīto, bhavantakaraṇo muni;
analyzed: asambhītaḥ bhaya atītaḥ muni
translated: “Fearless, gone beyond fear, the sage who has made an end of all becoming,

original: Sīhūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: sīha upamaḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The great hero, who is like a lion, has been invited for tomorrow.

original: “Kusalo buddhadhammehi, apasayho parehi so;
analyzed: kusalaḥ buddha dhammehi apasayhaḥ parehi so
translated: “Skilled in the Buddha’s teachings, unconquerable by others,

original: Nāgūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: nāga upamaḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The one like a great elephant, the great hero, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Saddhammācārakusalo, buddhanāgo asādiso;
analyzed: saddhamma ācāra kusalaḥ buddha nāgaḥ asādisaḥ
translated: “Skilled in the practice of the true Dhamma, the unequalled elephant of a Buddha,

original: Usabhūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: usabha upamaḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The one like a great bull, the great hero, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Anantavaṇṇo amitayaso, vicittasabbalakkhaṇo;
analyzed: ananta vaṇṇaḥ amita yasaḥ vicitta sabba lakkhaṇo
translated: “Of infinite color, of immeasurable fame, of various characteristics,

original: Sakkūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: sakku upamaḥ mahāvīro saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The one like Sakka, the great hero, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Vasī gaṇī patāpī ca, tejassī ca durāsado;
analyzed: vasī gaṇī patāpī ca tejassī ca durāsadaḥ
translated: “The one with mastery, the one with control, the one with splendor, the one with brilliance, the one hard to approach,

original: Brahmūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: brahma upamaḥ mahā vīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The one like Brahmā, the great hero, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Pattadhammo dasabalo, balātibalapārago;
translated: “The one with the Dhamma as his inheritance, the one with the ten powers, the one who has gone to the other shore of strength and power,

original: Dharaṇūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: dharaṇūpamaḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The one like the earth, the great hero, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Sīlavīcisamākiṇṇo, dhammaviññāṇakhobhito;
analyzed: sīla vīci samākiṇṇaḥ dhamma viññāṇa khobhito
translated: “Filled with the ocean of virtue, stirred by the waters of the Dhamma,

original: Udadhūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: udadhū upamaḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The one like the ocean, the great hero, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Durāsado duppasaho, acalo uggato brahā;
analyzed: durāsadaḥ duppasahaḥ acalaḥ uggataḥ brahā
translated: “The one hard to approach, the one hard to overcome, the one unshakable, the one risen high,

original: Nerūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: nerūpamaḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The one like Meru, the great hero, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Anantañāṇo asamasamo, atulo aggataṃ gato;
analyzed: ananta ñāṇaḥ asamasamaḥ atulaḥ aggatam gataḥ
translated: “The one of infinite knowledge, the one without equal, the one incomparable, the one who has attained the highest,

original: Gaganūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: gagana upamaḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The one like the sky, the great hero, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Patiṭṭhā bhayabhītānaṃ, tāṇo saraṇagāminaṃ;
analyzed: patiṭṭhāḥ bhaya bhītānam tāṇo saraṇa gāminam
translated: “The support for those frightened by fear, the refuge for those who have gone for refuge,

original: Assāsako mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: assāsakaḥ mahāvīro saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The Great Hero, the one who gives relief, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Āsayo buddhimantānaṃ, puññakkhettaṃ sukhesinaṃ;
analyzed: āsayaḥ buddhimantānam puñña kkhettam sukhesinam
translated: “The abode of the wise, the field of merit for those seeking happiness,

original: Ratanākaro mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: ratanākaraḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The Great Hero, the maker of the jewel, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Assāsako vedakaro, sāmaññaphaladāyako;
translated: “The one who gives relief, the one who makes us feel, the giver of the fruits of asceticism,

original: Meghūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: megha upamaḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The Great Hero, the one like a cloud, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Lokacakkhu mahātejo, sabbatamavinodano;
translated: “The eye of the world, of great splendor, the dispeller of all darkness,

original: Sūriyūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: sūriyu upamaḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The Great Hero, the one like the sun, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Ārammaṇavimuttīsu, sabhāvadassano muni;
analyzed: ārammaṇa vimuttīsu sa bhāva dassanaḥ muni
translated: “The sage who sees the nature of things, among those liberated by means of objects,

original: Candūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: canda upamaḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The Great Hero, the one like the moon, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Buddho samussito loke, lakkhaṇehi alaṅkato;
analyzed: buddhaḥ samussitaḥ loke lakkhaṇehi alaṅkato
translated: “The Buddha, the supreme one in the world, adorned with the major marks,

original: Appameyyo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: appameyyaḥ mahāvīro saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The Great Hero, the immeasurable one, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Yassa ñāṇaṃ appameyyaṃ, sīlaṃ yassa anūpamaṃ;
analyzed: yassa ñāṇam appameyyam sīlam yassa anūpamam
translated: “The one whose knowledge is immeasurable, whose virtue is incomparable,

original: Vimutti asadisā yassa, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: vimutti asadisā yassa saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantito
translated: Whose liberation is unequaled, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Yassa dhīti asadisā, thāmo yassa acintiyo;
analyzed: yassa dhīti asadisā thāmaḥ yassa acintiyaḥ
translated: “The one whose wisdom is unequaled, whose fortitude is inconceivable,

original: Yassa parakkamo jeṭṭho, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: yassa parakkamaḥ jeṭṭhaḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: Whose heroism is supreme, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Rāgo doso ca moho ca, visā sabbe samūhatā;
analyzed: rāgaḥ doso ca moho ca sabbe
translated: “Lust, hate, and delusion, all poisons, are destroyed;

original: Agadūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: agada upamaḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The Great Hero is like a medicine, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Klesabyādhibahudukkha-sabbatamavinodano;
translated: “The remover of the darkness of the many afflictions, illnesses, and sufferings,

original: Vejjūpamo mahāvīro, so me buddho nimantito.
analyzed: vejjūpamaḥ mahāvīraḥ saḥ me buddhaḥ nimantitaḥ
translated: The Great Hero is like a doctor, he is the Buddha I invite.

original: “Buddhoti bho yaṃ vadesi, ghosopeso sudullabho;
analyzed: buddhaḥ iti bho yam vadesi ghosa upeso su dullabho
translated: “You say ‘Buddha,’ but this word is very hard to find;

original: Buddho buddhoti sutvāna, pīti me udapajjatha.
analyzed: buddhaḥ buddhaḥ iti sutvāna pi iti me udapajjatha
translated: Hearing ‘Buddha, Buddha,’ I felt joy arise.

original: “Abbhantaraṃ agaṇhantaṃ, pīti me bahi nicchare;
analyzed: abbhantaram a gaṇhantam pīti me bahis nicchare
translated: “Not finding it within, my joy went outside;

original: Sohaṃ pītimano santo, idaṃ vacanamabraviṃ.
analyzed: saḥ aham pīti manaḥ santaḥ idam vacanam abravim
translated: With a joyful mind, I spoke these words.

original: “Kahaṃ nu kho so bhagavā, lokajeṭṭho narāsabho;
analyzed: kaham nu kho saḥ bhagavā loka jeṭṭhaḥ narāsabhaḥ
translated: “Where is that Blessed One, the world’s chief, the bull among men;

original: Tattha gantvā namassissaṃ, sāmaññaphaladāyakaṃ.
analyzed: tattha gantvā namassissam sāmañña phala dāyakam
translated: Having gone there, I will pay homage to him, the giver of the fruits of asceticism.

original: “Paggayha dakkhiṇaṃ bāhuṃ, vedajāto katañjalī;
analyzed: paggayha dakkhiṇam bāhum veda jātaḥ katañjalī
translated: Raising my right arm, born of knowledge, with palms joined,

original: Ācikkhi me dhammarājaṃ, sokasallavinodanaṃ.
analyzed: ācikkhi me dhamma rājam soka salla vinodanam
translated: Please tell me about the King of the Dhamma, the remover of the dart of sorrow.

original: “Udentaṃva mahāmeghaṃ, nīlaṃ añjanasannibhaṃ;
analyzed: mahā megham nīlam añjana sannibham
translated: “Like a great cloud rising, blue like collyrium,

original: Sāgaraṃ viya dissantaṃ, passasetaṃ mahāvanaṃ.
analyzed: sāgaram viya dissantam passasetam mahā vanam
translated: Seen like the ocean, this great forest.

original: “Ettha so vasate buddho, adantadamako muni;
analyzed: ettha saḥ vasate buddhaḥ a danta damakaḥ muni
translated: “There dwells the Buddha, the sage who tames the untamed;

original: Vinayanto ca veneyye, bodhento bodhipakkhiye.
analyzed: vinayantaḥ ca veneyye bodhentaḥ bodhi pakkhiye
translated: Training those who should be trained, and teaching the factors of awakening.

original: “Pipāsitova udakaṃ, bhojanaṃva jighacchito;
analyzed: pipāsitaḥ uva udakam bhojanam iva jighacchitaḥ
translated: “Like one thirsty for water, or hungry for food,

original: Gāvī yathā vacchagiddhā, evāhaṃ viciniṃ jinaṃ.
analyzed: gāvī yathā vaccha giddhā eva aham vicinim jinam
translated: Like a cow longing for her calf, so I long for the Victor.

original: “Ācāraupacāraññū, dhammānucchavisaṃvaraṃ;
analyzed: ācāra aupacāra aññū dhamma anucchavi saṃvaram
translated: “Knowing conduct and deportment, the restraint of following the Dhamma,

original: Sikkhāpemi sake sisse, gacchante jinasantikaṃ.
analyzed: sikkhāpemi sake sisse gacchante jina santikam
translated: I instruct my own disciples, as they go to the Victor’s presence.

original: “Durāsadā bhagavanto, sīhāva ekacārino;
analyzed: durāsadāḥ bhagavantaḥ ekacārinaḥ
translated: “The Fortunate Ones are hard to approach, like lions who live alone;

original: Pade padaṃ nikkhipantā, āgaccheyyātha māṇavā.
analyzed: pade padam nikkhipantāḥ āgaccheyyātha māṇavā
translated: Placing one foot after another, you should go, young men.

original: “Āsīviso yathā ghoro, migarājāva kesarī;
analyzed: āsīvisaḥ yathā ghoraḥ miga rājā ava kesarī
translated: “Like a fierce poisonous snake, like a lion the king of beasts,

original: Mattova kuñjaro dantī, evaṃ buddhā durāsadā.
analyzed: mattaḥ uva kuñjaraḥ dantī evam buddhā durāsadā
translated: Like an intoxicated tusker, so the Buddhas are hard to approach.

original: “Ukkāsitañca khipitaṃ, ajjhupekkhiya māṇavā;
analyzed: ukkāsitam ca khipitam ajjhupekkhiya māṇavā
translated: “The one who sneezes or coughs, you should pay no attention, young men;

original: Pade padaṃ nikkhipantā, upetha buddhasantikaṃ.
analyzed: pade padam nikkhipantāḥ upetha buddha santikam
translated: Placing one foot after another, you should go to the Buddha’s presence.

original: “Paṭisallānagarukā, appasaddā durāsadā;
analyzed: paṭisallāna garukāḥ appasaddāḥ durāsadāḥ
translated: “They value seclusion, are quiet, hard to approach,

original: Durūpasaṅkamā buddhā, garū honti sadevake.
analyzed: durūpa saṅkamāḥ buddhāḥ honti sa devake
translated: The Buddhas are hard to approach, they are revered in the world with its gods.

original: “Yadāhaṃ pañhaṃ pucchāmi, paṭisammodayāmi vā;
analyzed: yadā aham pañham pucchāmi paṭisammodayāmi vā
translated: “When I ask a question, or greet you,

original: Appasaddā tadā hotha, munibhūtāva tiṭṭhatha.
analyzed: appasaddā tadā hotha muni bhūtā ava tiṭṭhatha
translated: Be quiet then, stand as if you were sages.

original: “Yaṃ so deseti sambuddho, khemaṃ nibbānapattiyā;
analyzed: yam saḥ deseti sambuddhaḥ khemam nibbāna pattiyā
translated: “What the Sambuddha teaches, the way to the safe state of Nibbana,

original: Tamevatthaṃ nisāmetha, saddhammasavanaṃ sukhaṃ.
analyzed: tam eva attham nisāmetha saddhamma savanam sukham
translated: Listen to that, for it is happiness to hear the true Dhamma.

original: “Upasaṅkamma sambuddhaṃ, sammodiṃ muninā ahaṃ;
analyzed: upasaṅkamma sambuddham sammodim muninā aham
translated: “Having approached the Sambuddha, I exchanged greetings with the Sage;

original: Taṃ kathaṃ vītisāretvā, lakkhaṇe upadhārayiṃ.
analyzed: tam katham vītisāretvā lakkhaṇe upadhārayiṃ
translated: After having completed that conversation, I considered his characteristics.

original: “Lakkhaṇe dve ca kaṅkhāmi, passāmi tiṃsalakkhaṇe;
analyzed: lakkhaṇe dve ca kaṅkhāmi passāmi tiṃsa lakkhaṇe
translated: “I had doubts about two characteristics, I saw thirty characteristics;

original: Kosohitavatthaguyhaṃ, iddhiyā dassayī muni.
analyzed: iddhiyā dassayī muni
translated: The Sage, with his psychic power, showed me the sheathed male organ.

original: “Jivhaṃ ninnāmayitvāna, kaṇṇasote ca nāsike;
analyzed: jivham ninnāmayitvāna kaṇṇa sote ca nāsike
translated: “Having extended his tongue, he covered with it both ears and the nostrils;

original: Paṭimasi nalāṭantaṃ, kevalaṃ chādayī jino.
analyzed: kevalam
translated: The Victor covered the whole of his forehead with it.

original: “Tassāhaṃ lakkhaṇe disvā, paripuṇṇe sabyañjane;
analyzed: tassa aham lakkhaṇe disvā paripuṇṇe sa byañjane
translated: “Having seen those characteristics, complete with all the minor marks,

original: Buddhoti niṭṭhaṃ gantvāna, saha sissehi pabbajiṃ.
analyzed: buddhaḥ ti niṭṭham gantvāna saha sissehi pabbajim
translated: Having come to the conclusion that he was the Buddha, I went forth with my disciples.

original: “Satehi tīhi sahito, pabbajiṃ anagāriyaṃ;
analyzed: satehi tīhi sahitaḥ pabbajim anagāriyam
translated: “Together with three hundred (disciples) I went forth into homelessness;

original: Aḍḍhamāse asampatte, sabbe pattāmha nibbutiṃ.
analyzed: aḍḍha māse a sampatte sabbe pattāmha nibbutim
translated: Before half a month had passed, we all attained Nibbana.

original: “Ekato kammaṃ katvāna, puññakkhette anuttare;
analyzed: ekatas kammam katvāna puñña kkhette anuttare
translated: “Having performed our duties together, in the unsurpassed field of merit,

original: Ekato saṃsaritvāna, ekato vinivattayuṃ.
analyzed: ekatas saṃsaritvānaḥ ekatas vinivattayum
translated: Having gone together through the round (of births), we turned back together.

original: “Gopānasiyo datvāna, pūgadhamme vasiṃ ahaṃ
analyzed: gopānasiyaḥ pūga dhamme vasim aham
translated: “Having given the Gavesi (gift), I dwelt in the fulfilled Dhamma.

original: Tena kammena sukatena, aṭṭha hetū labhāmahaṃ.
analyzed: tena kammena su katena aṭṭha hetū labhāmaham
translated: Because of that good deed, I obtained eight benefits.

original: “Disāsu pūjito homi, bhogā ca amitā mama;
analyzed: disāsu pūjitaḥ homi bhogā ca amitā mama
translated: “I am worshipped in the directions, and my wealth is immeasurable;

original: Patiṭṭhā homi sabbesaṃ, tāso mama na vijjati.
analyzed: patiṭṭhā homi sabbesam tāsaḥ mama na vijjati
translated: I am a support for all, and I have no anxiety.

original: “Byādhayo me na vijjanti, dīghāyuṃ pālayāmi ca;
analyzed: byādhayaḥ me na vijjanti dīgha āyum pālayāmi ca
translated: “I have no illnesses, and I protect my long life;

original: Sukhumacchaviko homi, āvāse patthite vase.
analyzed: sukhuma chavikaḥ homi āvāse patthite vase
translated: I have fine skin, and I live in the monastery I wished for.

original: “Aṭṭha gopānasī datvā, pūgadhamme vasiṃ ahaṃ;
analyzed: gopānasī da tvā pūga dhamme vasim aham
translated: “Having given eight gateways, I lived fulfilling the Dhamma;

original: Paṭisambhidārahattañca, etaṃ me aparaṭṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisambhidā rahattam ca etam me aparaṭṭhamam
translated: And the state of mastery of the analytical knowledges, this is my third.

original: “Sabbavositavosāno, katakicco anāsavo;
analyzed: sabba vosita vosānaḥ kata kiccaḥ anāsavaḥ
translated: “Having completed all the duties, having done what was to be done, being without defilements,

original: Aṭṭha gopānasī nāma, tava putto mahāmuni.
analyzed: aṭṭha gopānasī nāma tava puttaḥ mahā muni
translated: The one called Aṭṭha-gopānasī, your son, the Great Sage.

original: “Pañca thambhāni datvāna, pūgadhamme vasiṃ ahaṃ;
analyzed: pañca thambhāni datvāna pūgadhamme vasim aham
translated: “Having given five pillars, I lived fulfilling the Dhamma;

original: Tena kammena sukatena, pañca hetū labhāmahaṃ.
analyzed: tena kammena su katena pañca hetū labhāmaham
translated: Because of that good deed, I obtained five benefits.

original: “Acalo homi mettāya, anūnaṅgo bhavāmahaṃ;
analyzed: acalaḥ homi mettāya anūnaṅgaḥ bhavām aham
translated: “I am unshakeable in loving-kindness, and I am not lacking in limbs;

original: Ādeyyavacano homi, na dhaṃsemi yathā ahaṃ.
analyzed: ādeyya vacanaḥ homi na dhaṃsemi yathā aham
translated: I am one whose words are accepted, and I do not break (my vows).

original: “Abhantaṃ hoti me cittaṃ, akhilo homi kassaci;
analyzed: abhantam hoti me cittam akhilaḥ homi kassaci
translated: “My mind is free from debt, and I am not hostile to anyone;

original: Tena kammena sukatena, vimalo homi sāsane.
analyzed: tena kammena su katena vimalaḥ homi sāsane
translated: Because of that good deed, I am pure in the Dispensation.

original: “Sagāravo sappatisso, katakicco anāsavo;
analyzed: sa gāravaḥ sappatissaḥ kata kiccaḥ anāsavaḥ
translated: “With respect and reverence, having done what had to be done, without defilements,

original: Sāvako te mahāvīra, bhikkhu taṃ vandate muni.
analyzed: sāvako te mahāvīra bhikkhu tam vandate muni
translated: your disciple, O Great Hero, a monk, pays homage to you, O Sage.

original: “Katvā sukatapallaṅkaṃ, sālāyaṃ paññapesahaṃ;
analyzed: katvā su kata pallaṅkam sālāyam paññapesaham
translated: “Having made a well-made couch, I arranged it in a hall.

original: Tena kammena sukatena, pañca hetū labhāmahaṃ.
analyzed: tena kammena su katena pañca hetū labhāmaham
translated: By that well-done deed, I obtained five benefits.

original: “Ucce kule pajāyitvā, mahābhogo bhavāmahaṃ;
analyzed: ucce kule mahā bhogaḥ bhavām aham
translated: “Having been born in a high family, I became very wealthy.

original: Sabbasampattiko homi, maccheraṃ me na vijjati.🔽“Gamane patthite mayhaṃ, pallaṅko upatiṭṭhati;
analyzed: sabba sampattikaḥ homi maccheram me na vijjati  gamane patthite mayham pallaṅkaḥ upatiṭṭhati
translated: I was endowed with every perfection; I had no stinginess.🔽“When I set out on a journey, the couch followed me.

original: Saha pallaṅkaseṭṭhena, gacchāmi mama patthitaṃ.
analyzed: saha pallaṅka seṭṭhena gacchāmi mama patthitam
translated: Together with the best couch, I went to my desired destination.

original: “Tena pallaṅkadānena, tamaṃ sabbaṃ vinodayiṃ;
analyzed: tena pallaṅka dānena tamam sabbam vinodayiṃ
translated: “By that gift of the couch, I dispelled all darkness.

original: Sabbābhiññābalappatto, thero vandati taṃ muni.
analyzed: sabba abhiññā bala ppatto theraḥ vandati tam muni
translated: The Elder, who attained all the powers of direct knowledge, pays homage to you, O Sage.

original: “Parikiccattakiccāni, sabbakiccāni sādhayiṃ;
analyzed: sabba kiccāni sādhayiṃ
translated: “Having done all the duties that had to be done, I accomplished all duties.

original: Tena kammena sukatena, pāvisiṃ abhayaṃ puraṃ.
analyzed: tena kammena su katena pāvisim abhayam puram
translated: By that well-done deed, I entered the city of fearlessness.

original: “Pariniṭṭhitasālamhi, paribhogamadāsahaṃ;
analyzed: pariniṭṭhita sālamhi paribhoga mada asaham
translated: “In a completed hall, I gave a dwelling.

original: Tena kammena sukatena, seṭṭhattaṃ ajjhupāgato.
analyzed: tena kammena su katena seṭṭha ttam ajjhupāgataḥ

original: Imāhi gāthāhi satthu purato sīhanādaṃ nadi.
analyzed: imāhi gāthāhi puratas sīhanādam nadi
translated: With these verses he roared his lion’s roar in the presence of the Teacher.

original: Tattha yātaṃ me hatthigīvāyāti, bhante, pubbe mayā gacchantenāpi hatthigīvāya hatthikkhandhe🔽nisīditvā yātaṃ caritaṃ. Vatthāni pariharantenāpi sukhumā sukhasamphassā kāsikavatthavisesā🔽dhāritā. Odanaṃ bhuñjantenāpi tivassikānaṃ purāṇagandhasālīnaṃ odano tittirakapiñjarādinā
analyzed: tattha yātam me hatthi gīvāya ati bhante pubbe mayā gacchantena api hatthi gīvāya hatthi kkhandhe  nisīditvā yātam caritam vatthāni pariharantena api sukhumā sukha samphassā kāsika vattha visesā  dhāritāḥ odanam bhuñjantena api tivassikānam purāṇagandhasālīnam odanaḥ tittira kapiñjara ādinā
translated: Herein, in the past, venerable sir, when I was going, I went, I travelled, by means of an elephant’s neck, by means of an elephant’s shoulder,🔽and I wore delicate, soft, fine Kāsi garments.

original: sucinā maṃsena upasittatāya sucimaṃsūpasecano bhutto, tathāpi taṃ sukhaṃ na mayhaṃ
analyzed: sucinā maṃsena suci maṃsu upasecanaḥ bhuttaḥ tathā api tam sukham na mayham
translated: When I was eating rice, I ate rice of three-year old grain, mixed with ghee and meat, and moistened with honey, and I ate it with various sauces, and still that happiness did not give me

original: cittaparitosakaraṃ ahosi, yathā etarahi vivekasukhanti dassento āha “sojja bhaddo”tiādi.
analyzed: citta paritosa karam ahosi yathā etarahi viveka sukhanti dassentaḥ āha bhadda itiādi
translated: the mental satisfaction that I now have in the happiness of seclusion. Showing this, he said “Now I am happy” and so on.

original: Ettha ca hatthiggahaṇeneva assarathayānāni, vatthaggahaṇena sabbarājālaṅkārā, odanaggahaṇena
analyzed: ettha ca hatthi ggahaṇena iva assa ratha yānāni vattha ggahaṇena sabba rāja alaṅkārāḥ odana ggahaṇena
translated: And here, by the mention of the elephant, the horse, the chariot, and the vehicle are included; by the mention of the garments, all royal ornaments are included; by the mention of the rice,

original: sabbabhojanavikati gahitāti veditabbaṃ. Sojjāti so ajja etarahi pabbajjāyaṃ ṭhito.
analyzed: sabba bhojana vikati gahitā iti veditabbam sojjā ati saḥ ajja etarahi pabbajja ayam ṭhitaḥ
translated: should be understood as “all kinds of food.” Sojjha means “today.” He is sojjha in that he is established today in the life of a bhikkhu.

original: Bhaddoti sīlādiguṇehi samannāgatattā bhaddo. Sātatikoti samaṇadhamme diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāre
analyzed: bhaddo ti sīla ādi guṇehi samannāgata ttā bhaddo sātatiko ti samaṇa dhamme diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāre
translated: Bhadda means “good.” He is bhadda in that he is endowed with the good qualities of virtue, etc. Sātatiko means “endowed with persistence.” He is endowed with persistence in the practice of the ascetic’s life, in the enjoyment of the bliss of seclusion.

original: sātaccayutto. Uñchāpattāgate ratoti uñchācariyāya patte āgate pattapariyāpanne abhirato,
analyzed: sātacca yuttaḥ uñchā patta āgate rataḥ ti uñchā cariyāya patte āgate patta pariyāpanne abhirataḥ
translated: Uñchāpattāgate rato means “delighting in what is obtained by wandering for alms.” He delights in what is obtained by wandering for alms, in what is included in the alms obtained by wandering for alms.

original: teneva santuṭṭhoti adhippāyo. Jhāyatīti phalasamāpattijhānena jhāyati. Putto godhāyāti
analyzed: tena iva santuṭṭhaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ jhāyati iti phala samāpatti jhānena jhāyati puttaḥ godhāya ati
translated: The intention is that he is satisfied with that. Jhāyati means “he meditates.” He meditates by means of the meditation of the attainment of fruition. Putto godhāyāti means “the son of Godhā.”

original: kāḷigodhāya nāma khattiyāya putto. Bhaddiyoti evaṃnāmo attānameva thero aññaṃ viya katvā vadati.🔽Gahapaticīvaraṃ paṭikkhipitvā paṃsukūlikaṅgasamādānena paṃsukūliko. Saṅghabhattaṃ
analyzed: kāḷigodhāya nāma khattiyāya putto bhaddiyaḥ ti evaṃnāmaḥ attānam eva theraḥ aññam viya katvā vadati  gahapati cīvaram paṭikkhipitvā paṃsukūlika aṅga samādānena paṃsukūlikaḥ saṅgha bhattam
translated: The son of the noble woman named Kāḷigodhā. Bhaddiyo means “the one named Bhaddiya.” The Elder refers to himself as if he were another.🔽Paṃsukūliko means “one who wears refuse rags.” He is a refuse-rag wearer in that he has undertaken the refuse-rag-wearer’s practice by rejecting the use of robes given by householders. Piṇḍapātiko means “one who eats almsfood.”

original: paṭikkhipitvā piṇḍapātikaṅgasamādānena piṇḍapātiko. Atirekacīvaraṃ paṭikkhipitvā
analyzed: paṭikkhipitvā piṇḍapātika aṅga samādānena piṇḍapātikaḥ atireka cīvaram paṭikkhipitvā
translated: He is an alms-food eater in that he has undertaken the alms-food-eater’s practice by rejecting the use of invitations to meals. Atirekacīvaraṃ paṭikkhipitvā means “having rejected an extra robe.”

original: tecīvarikaṅgasamādānena tecīvariko. Loluppacāraṃ paṭikkhipitvā sapadānacārikaṅgasamādānena
analyzed: tecīvarika aṅga samādānena tecīvarikaḥ loluppa cāram paṭikkhipitvā sa padāna cārika aṅga samādānena
translated: by undertaking the practice of the triple-robe-wearer, he is a triple-robe-wearer. By undertaking the practice of the alms-food-eater,

original: sapadānacārī. Nānāsanabhojanaṃ paṭikkhipitvā ekāsanikaṅgasamādānena ekāsaniko. Dutiyakabhājanaṃ🔽paṭikkhipitvā pattapiṇḍikaṅgasamādānena pattapiṇḍiko. Atirittabhojanaṃ paṭikkhipitvā🔽khalupacchābhattikaṅgasamādānena khalupacchābhattiko. Gāmantasenāsanaṃ paṭikkhipitvā
analyzed: sa padāna cārī nānā āsana bhojanam paṭikkhipitvā eka āsanika aṅga samādānena eka āsanikaḥ dutiyaka bhājanam  paṭikkhipitvā patta piṇḍika aṅga samādānena patta piṇḍikaḥ atiritta bhojanam paṭikkhipitvā  khalu pacchābhattika aṅga samādānena khalu pacchābhattikaḥ gāmanta senāsanam paṭikkhipitvā
translated: he is an alms-food-eater. By undertaking the practice of the one-sessioner, he is a one-sessioner. By undertaking the practice of the bowl-food-eater,🔽he is a bowl-food-eater. By undertaking the practice of the later-food-refuser, he is a later-food-refuser. By undertaking the practice of the forest-dweller,

original: āraññikaṅgasamādānena āraññiko. Channavāsaṃ paṭikkhipitvā rukkhamūlikaṅgasamādānena🔽rukkhamūliko. Channarukkhamūlāni paṭikkhipitvā abbhokāsikaṅgasamādānena abbhokāsiko.
analyzed: āraññika aṅga samādānena āraññikaḥ channa vāsam paṭikkhipitvā rukkhamūlika aṅga samādānena  rukkhamūlikaḥ channa rukkha mūlāni paṭikkhipitvā abbhokāsika aṅga samādānena abbhokāsikaḥ
translated: he is a forest-dweller. By undertaking the practice of the tree-root-dweller, he is a tree-root-dweller. By undertaking the practice of the open-air-dweller,

original: Nasusānaṃ paṭikkhipitvā sosānikaṅgasamādānena sosāniko. Senāsanaloluppaṃ paṭikkhipitvā
analyzed: na susānam paṭikkhipitvā sosānika aṅga samādānena sosānikaḥ senāsana loluppam paṭikkhipitvā
translated: he is an open-air-dweller. By undertaking the practice of the charnel-ground-dweller, he is a charnel-ground-dweller. By undertaking the practice of the whatever-bed-user,🔽he is a whatever-bed-user.

original: yathāsanthatikaṅgasamādānena yathāsanthatiko. Sayanaṃ paṭikkhipitvā nesajjikaṅgasamādānena🔽nesajjiko. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthārato pana dhutaṅgakathā visuddhimagge vuttanayeneva gahetabbā.
analyzed: yathā santhatika aṅga samādānena yathā santhatikaḥ sayanam paṭikkhipitvā nesajjika aṅga samādānena  nesajjikaḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārataḥ pana dhutaṅga kathā visuddhi magge vutta nayena iva gahetabbā
translated: and by undertaking the practice of using what is available he becomes one who uses what is available. By undertaking the practice of the sitter he becomes one who does not lie down, having rejected lying down. This is the brief account. But the detailed account can be understood from the method of treatment in the Visuddhimagga.

original: Ucceti uccādiṭṭhāne, uparipāsādatāya vā ucce. Maṇḍalipākāreti maṇḍalākārena pākāraparikkhitte.
analyzed: uccā iti ucca ādi ṭṭhāne vā ucce maṇḍali pākārā iti maṇḍala ākārena pākāra parikkhitte
translated: On a high seat: in a high place, such as a high pulpit, or on a high seat.

original: Daḷhamaṭṭālakoṭṭhaketi thirehi aṭṭālehi dvārakoṭṭhakehi ca samannāgate, nagareti attho.🔽Satiṃ paññañcāti ettha satisīsena samādhiṃ vadati. Phalasamāpattinirodhasamāpattiyo sandhāya “satiṃ paññañca bhāvaya”nti vutto. Sesaṃ tattha tattha vuttanayattā uttānameva.
analyzed: daḷham aṭṭāla koṭṭhake iti thirehi aṭṭālehi dvāra koṭṭhakehi ca samannāgate nagare ti attho  satim paññam ca ati ettha sati sīsena samādhim vadati phala samāpatti nirodha samāpattiyo sandhāya satim paññam ca bhāvayanti vuttaḥ sesam tattha tattha vutta naya ttā uttānam eva
translated: In a town with strong ramparts and walls: in a town surrounded by a wall with strong gates, is the meaning.

original: Evaṃ thero satthu sammukhā sīhanādaṃ nadi. Taṃ sutvā bhikkhū abhippasannā ahesuṃ.🔽Kāḷigodhāputtabhaddiyattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: evam thero satthu sammukhā sīhanādam nadi tam sutvā bhikkhū abhippasannāḥ ahesuṃ 🔽kāḷi godhāputta bhaddiya tthera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Mindfulness and understanding: here he speaks of concentration under the heading of mindfulness. “Mindfulness and understanding he should cultivate” is said with reference to the attainment of fruition and the attainment of cessation. The rest is clear in its evident meaning, as it is given here and there.

original: 8. Aṅgulimālattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: aṅgulimālatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: 8. The Elder Aṅgulimāla🔽The Elder Aṅgulimāla’s verses begin with the words: “As he was going, he spoke.”

analyzed: gaccham vadesi iti ādikā āyasmataḥ aṅgulimāla ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi purima buddhesu
translated: What was their origin? He too had made his resolve in the presence of former Buddhas,

analyzed: kata adhikāraḥ tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭu upanissayam kusalam upacinitvā imasmin buddhuppāde
translated: and had stored up the wholesome roots necessary for his rebirth in the time of this Buddha.

original: sāvatthiyaṃ kosalarañño purohitassa bhaggavassa nāma brāhmaṇassa putto hutvā nibbatti.
analyzed: sāvatthiyam kosala raññaḥ purohitassa bhaggavassa nāma brāhmaṇassa puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti
translated: He was born in Sāvatthi as the son of a brāhmaṇa named Bhaggava, the king’s chaplain.

analyzed: tassa jāta divase sakala nagare āvudhāni pajjaliṃsu raññaḥ ca maṅgala āvudham sayana pīṭhe
translated: On the day of his birth all the weapons in the city blazed up, and the king’s own lucky weapon, which was kept in his bed-chamber,

analyzed: ṭhapitam pajjali tam disvā rājā bhīto saṃviggo niddam na labhi purohito
translated: also blazed up. Seeing this, the king was frightened and agitated and could not sleep. The chaplain, who was looking up at the stars

analyzed: nakkhatta yogam ullokento cora nakkhattena jātaḥ iti sanniṭṭhānam akāsi saḥ vibhātāya
translated: at that time, decided that the child had been born under an inauspicious constellation. When the night had passed,🔽he went to the king and asked him if he had slept well. “Where, teacher,” said the king,

analyzed: rattiyā rañño santikam gataḥ sukhaseyyam pucchi rājā kutas ācariya sukhaseyyam
translated: “could I find sleep?

original: rattiyaṃ mayhaṃ maṅgalāvudhaṃ pajjali, tassa ko nu kho vipāko bhavissatī”ti? “Mā
analyzed: rattiyam mayham maṅgalāvudham pajjali tassa kaḥ nu kho vipākaḥ bhavissati iti mā
translated: “What will be the result of this?”

original: bhāyi, mahārāja, mayhaṃ ghare dārako jāto. Tassa ānubhāvena sakalanagarepi āvudhāni
analyzed: bhāyi mahā rāja mayham ghare dārakaḥ jātaḥ tassa ānubhāvena sakala nagare pi
translated: “Do not fear, sire. A son has been born in my house. It is through his power that the weapons have been set ablaze in the whole city.”🔽“What will he be, teacher?”🔽“He will be a thief, sire.”

original: pajjaliṃsū”ti. “Kiṃ bhavissati, ācariyā”ti? “Dārako coro bhavissatī”ti. “Kiṃ ekacārī
analyzed: pajjaliṃsūti kim bhavissati ācariyā ati dārako coraḥ bhavissati iti kim ekacārī
translated: “Will he be a single thief or the chief of a gang?”🔽“A single thief, sire.”🔽“What shall we do to him?”

original: coro, udāhu gaṇajeṭṭhako”ti? “Ekacāriko, deva”. “Kiṃ naṃ māremā”ti? “Ekacāriko ce,🔽paṭijaggatha tāva na”nti āha. Tassa nāmaṃ karontā yasmā jāyamāno rañño cittaṃ vihesento
analyzed: coraḥ udāhu gaṇa jeṭṭhakaḥ ti ekacārikaḥ deva kim naṃ mārema iti ekacārikaḥ ce  paṭijaggatha tāva nanti āha tassa nāmam karontā yasmā jāyamānaḥ rañño cittam vihesento
translated: “If he is a single thief, then take care of him for a time.”

original: jāto, tasmā hiṃsakoti katvā pacchā diṭṭhaṃ adiṭṭhanti viya ahiṃsakoti vohariṃsu.
analyzed: jātaḥ tasmai hiṃsako ti katvā pacchā diṭṭham a diṭṭhanti viya ahiṃsako ti vohariṃsu
translated: When they came to give him a name, because he was born causing pain to the king’s mind, they called him Ahiṃsaka, as if saying: “What was seen afterwards was not seen before.”

analyzed: so vaya pattaḥ pubba kamma balena sattannam hatthīnam balam dhāreti tassa idam pubba kammaṃ
translated: When he grew up, he possessed the strength of seven elephants, by the power of his previous karma. This was his previous karma:

analyzed: buddhasuññe loke kassakaḥ hutvā nibbattaḥ ekam paccekabuddham vassa udakena tintam
translated: In a time when there was no Buddha in the world, he was born as a farmer. He saw a Paccekabuddha who was covered with rain water.

analyzed: alla cīvaram sīta pīḷitam attano khetta bhūmim upagatam disvā puñña khettam me upaṭṭhitanti
translated: and seeing his own field of merit come to him,

analyzed: somanassa jātaḥ aggim katvā adāsi so tassa kammassa balena nibbatta nibbatta ṭṭhāne
translated: he was glad and made a fire and gave him the food. By the power of that deed,

analyzed: ca hutvā imasmin pacchimatta bhāve sattannam hatthīnam balam
translated: in every existence in which he was reborn he was strong, swift, and powerful. In this his last existence he has the strength of seven elephants.

analyzed: dhāreti saḥ takkasilam gantvā disāpāmokkhassa ācariyassa santike dhamma antevāsī hutvā  sippam uggaṇhataḥ ācariya brāhmaṇam tassa bhariyam ca sakkaccam paṭijaggati tena assa
translated: He went to Takkasilā and became a pupil of a teacher who was the foremost in the whole of India.🔽He served his teacher and his wife with the utmost devotion.🔽The teacher’s wife took a fancy to him and gave him all the food and other requisites of the household.

original: sā brāhmaṇī gehe labbhamānena bhattādinā saṅgahaṃ karoti. Taṃ asahamānā aññe māṇavā🔽ācariyena saddhiṃ bhedaṃ akaṃsu. Brāhmaṇo tesaṃ vacanaṃ dve tayo vāre asaddahanto

translated: Unable to bear this, the other pupils🔽caused a rift between the teacher and the young brāhman. The teacher, not believing their story,

original: hutvā pacchā saddahitvā “mahābalo māṇavo, na sakkā kenaci mārāpetuṃ, upāyena naṃ
analyzed: hutvā pacchā saddahitvā mahā balaḥ māṇavaḥ na sakkā kenacid mārāpetum upāyena naṃ
translated: and after that he believed them and said, “This young brāhman is very strong. No one can kill him. But by a trick🔽we can kill him.

original: māressāmī”ti cintetvā niṭṭhitasippaṃ attano nagaraṃ gantuṃ āpucchantaṃ māṇavaṃ āha
analyzed: māressāmi iti cintetvā niṭṭhita sippam attanaḥ nagaram gantum āpucchantam māṇavam āha
translated: and he thought, “I will kill him.” When the student, having completed his studies, asked permission to return to his own city, the teacher said to him,

original: – “tāta ahiṃsaka, niṭṭhitasippena nāma antevāsinā ācariyassa garudakkhiṇā dātabbā,
analyzed: tāta ahiṃsaka niṭṭhitasippena nāma antevāsinā ācariyassa garu dakkhiṇā dātabbā
translated: “My dear Ahiṃsaka, a student who has completed his studies should give his teacher a suitable fee.

original: taṃ mayhaṃ dehī”ti. “Sādhu, ācariya, kiṃ dassāmī”ti? “Manussānaṃ sahassadakkhiṇahatthaṅgaliyo
analyzed: tam mayham dehi iti sādhu ācariya kim dassāmi iti manussānam sahassa dakkhiṇa hatthaṅgaliyo
translated: Give me this.” “Very well, teacher. What shall I give you?” “Bring me the right hand of a thousand men, as an offering.”

original: ānehī”ti. Brāhmaṇassa kira ayamassa adhippāyo – bahūsu māriyamānesu ekantato eko
analyzed: ānehi iti brāhmaṇassa kira ayam assa adhippāyaḥ bahūsu māriyamānesu ekantataḥ ekaḥ
translated: The teacher’s idea was this: “If many are killed, it is possible that one of them may escape;

analyzed: nam māreyya iti tam sutvā ahiṃsakaḥ attanaḥ cira paricitam purakkhatvā sannaddha pañcāvudhaḥ
translated: but if only one is killed, he will certainly die.” When Ahiṃsaka heard this, he remembered his teacher’s long-continued kindness, and, taking his five weapons,

analyzed: kosala raññaḥ vijite jālinam vanam pavisitvā mahā magga samīpe pabbata antare vasantaḥ pabbata sikhare
translated: he entered the forest of Jālini, in the kingdom of Kosala, and, after wandering about, he settled down in a mountain fastness near the high-road. Standing on the top of a mountain,

analyzed: ṭhatvā maggena gacchante manusse oloketvā vegena gantvā aṅguliyaḥ gahetvā rukkha gge
translated: he watched the road, and when he saw men coming, he ran down the mountain, seized them by the fingers, and dragged them up the mountain.

translated: and hung them on his shoulder. Crows and vultures ate them, and those that fell to the ground became rotten. In this way

analyzed: gāmataḥ apakkamiṃsu gāmā suññāḥ ahesum tathā nigamāḥ janapadā ca evam tena so padeso  ubbāsitaḥ ahosi aṅguli mālassa ca ekāya ūnā sahassa aṅguliyaḥ saṅgahāḥ ahesuṃ atha manussā

analyzed: aṅgulimāla coram gaṇhāma balakāyaḥ āgacchatu uti tam sutvā aṅgulimālassa mātā mantāṇī

analyzed: nāma brāhmaṇī tassa pitaram āha putto kira te coraḥ hutvā idam ca idam ca karoti tam  īdisam mā kari iti saññāpetvā ānehi aññathā nam rājā ghāteyya ati brāhmaṇaḥ na mayham

analyzed: pūressāmi iti mātaram pi māressati so ca pacchimabhavikaḥ sacā aham na gamissam mahājāni

translated: The Buddha appeared between them. When Aṅgulimāla saw the Buddha, he thought,

analyzed: saḥ parihīna javaḥ ghuru ghuru passāsī kacchehi sa idam muñcantaḥ padam uddharitum pi a sakkontaḥ  viya ṭhitaḥ bhagavantam tiṭṭha tiṭṭha samaṇa iti āha bhagavā gacchantaḥ uva ṭhitaḥ

translated: “At long last the Great Seer has been honored by me, the ascetic has entered the Great Wood;

translated: I will abandon. Sahassapāpaṃ means a thousand evils. Sutvāna gāthaṃ tava dhammayuttaṃ means having heard your verse connected with the Dhamma.

analyzed: tava gātham suṇim soham tam sutvāna cirassam pi cira kālena api saṅgatam paricitam

translated: Having spoken thus, in order to show how he conducted himself and how he was helped by the Blessed One, (the Elders) said:

analyzed: id ca iva coraḥ asim āvudhañca sobbhe papāte narake anvakāsi
translated: “Thus the thief threw away his sword and weapon, the pit, the precipice, and the hell;

analyzed: avandi coraḥ sugatassa pāde tattha iva pabbajjam ayāci buddham
translated: The thief praised the feet of the Happy One, and right there he asked for the Buddha’s going-forth.

original: “Buddho ca kho kāruṇiko mahesi, yo satthā lokassa sadevakassa;
analyzed: buddhaḥ ca kho kāruṇikaḥ mahesi yaḥ satthā lokassa sa devakassa
translated: “The Buddha, the compassionate Great Seer, the Teacher of the world with its gods,

original: Tattha iccevāti iti eva evaṃ vatvā anantarameva. Coroti aṅgulimālo. Asinti khaggaṃ.

translated: Herein, thus: in this way, immediately after saying this. Thief: Aṅgulimāla. Sword: the sword.

original: Āvudhanti sesāvudhaṃ. Sobbheti samantato chinnataṭe. Papāteti ekato chinnataṭe. Naraketi
analyzed: āvudhanti sesa āvudham sobbheti samantataḥ chinna taṭe papāta iti ekatas chinna taṭe naraka iti

original: bhūmiyā phalitavivare. Idha pana tīhipi padehi yattha patitaṃ aññena gahetuṃ na sakkā,🔽tādisaṃ pabbatantarameva vadati. Anvakāsīti anu akāsi, pañcavidhampi attano āvudhaṃ🔽anu khipi chaḍḍesi, tāni chaḍḍetvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā “pabbājetha
analyzed: bhūmiyā phalita vivare idha pana tīhi pi padehi yattha patitam aññena gahetum na sakkā  tādisam pabbata antaram eva vadati anvakāsi iti anu akāsi pañcavidham pi attanaḥ āvudham  anu khipi chaḍḍesi tāni chaḍḍetvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā pabbājetha
translated: and in a crevice in the ground. But here, by all three terms, he means a mountain cave so deep that it is impossible for anyone else to take hold of what has been thrown in there.🔽“He threw down his weapons”: he threw down his five kinds of weapons. After throwing them down, he fell at the Blessed One’s feet and said, “Venerable sir, let me go forth.”

original: maṃ, bhante”ti āha. Tena vuttaṃ “avandi coro sugatassa pāde, tattheva pabbajjamayāci🔽buddha”nti. Evaṃ tena pabbajjāya yācitāya satthā tassa purimakammaṃ olokento ehibhikkhubhāvāya
analyzed: mam bhante ti āha tena vuttam avandi coraḥ sugatassa pāde tattha iva pabbajjam ayāci  buddha nti evam tena pabbajjāya yācitāya satthā tassa purima kammaṃ olokentaḥ ehibhikkhu bhāvāya
translated: Therefore it is said: “The thief threw down his weapons at the Sugata’s feet; right there he asked for the going forth from the Buddha.”🔽When he asked for the going forth in this way, the Teacher, looking into his past, saw that he possessed the requisite conditions for the state of a bhikkhu.

original: hetusampattiṃ disvā dakkhiṇahatthaṃ pasāretvā – “ehi, bhikkhu, svākhāto dhammo, cara
analyzed: hetu sampattim disvā dakkhiṇa hattham pasāretvā ehi bhikkhu su ākhātaḥ dhammaḥ cara
translated: Seeing this, he extended his right hand and said, “Come, bhikkhu. The Dhamma has been well-proclaimed.🔽Practice the holy life. The end of suffering is the goal.”

original: brahmacariyaṃ, sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāyā”ti āha. Sā eva ca tassa pabbajjā upasampadā
analyzed: brahmacariyam sammā dukkhassa anta kiriyāya ati āha sā eva ca tassa pabbajjā upasampadā
translated: That was his going forth and his full admission.

original: ca ahosi. Tenāha “tamehi bhikkhūti tadā avoca, eseva tassa ahu bhikkhubhāvo”ti.
analyzed: ca ahosi tena āha tam ehi bhikkhu iti tadā avoca esa iva tassa ahu bhikkhu bhāvaḥ ti
translated: Therefore it is said: “Then he said, ‘Come, bhikkhu.’ That was his bhikkhuhood.

original: Evaṃ thero satthu santike ehibhikkhubhāvena pabbajjaṃ upasampadañca labhitvā vipassanāya kammaṃ karonto arahattaṃ patvā vimuttisukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedento pītisomanassajāto udānavasena –
analyzed: evam thero satthu santike ehi bhikkhu bhāvena pabbajjam upasampadam ca labhitvā vipassanāya kammam karontaḥ arahattam patvā vimutti sukham paṭisaṃvedento pīti somanassa jātaḥ udāna vasena
translated: The Elder, having thus received the going-forth and the higher ordination in the presence of the Teacher by means of the “Come, bhikkhu!” formula, and having undertaken insight-meditation practice, attained arahatship. Experiencing the bliss of liberation, he was filled with joy and happiness. He uttered the following inspired utterance:🔽“He who, having been heedless before,

analyzed: yaḥ ca pubbe pamajjitvā pacchā so na ppamajjati
translated: Is not heedless later on,

analyzed: somam lokam pabhāseti abbhā muttaḥ uva candimā
translated: Illumines this world like the moon freed from a cloud.🔽“He who, having done evil deeds,

original: “Yassa pāpaṃ kataṃ kammaṃ, kusalena pidhīyati;
analyzed: yassa pāpam katam kammam kusalena pidhīyati
translated: Hides them with good deeds,

original: Somaṃ lokaṃ pabhāseti, abbhā muttova candimā.
analyzed: somam lokam pabhāseti abbhā muttaḥ uva candimā
translated: Illumines this world like the moon freed from a cloud.🔽“The young bhikkhu who applies himself

analyzed: yaḥ have daharaḥ bhikkhu yuñjati buddha sāsane
translated: To the Dispensation of the Buddha,

original: Somaṃ lokaṃ pabhāseti, abbhā muttova candimā”ti. – gāthattayaṃ abhāsi;🔽Tassattho – yo puggalo gahaṭṭho vā pabbajito vā kalyāṇamittasaṃsaggato pubbe pāpamittasaṃsaggena
analyzed: somam lokam pabhāsā iti abbhā muttaḥ uva candimā iti gāthattayam abhāsi  tassa atthaḥ yaḥ puggalaḥ gahaṭṭhaḥ vā pabbajitaḥ vā kalyāṇa mitta saṃsaggataḥ pubbe pāpa mitta saṃsaggena
translated: Illumines this world like the moon freed from a cloud.”🔽The meaning of this triad of stanzas is as follows: The person who, whether a layman or one gone forth into homelessness,🔽having been heedless before,

analyzed: vā attanaḥ vā paṭisaṅkhāna abhāvena pamajjitvā sammāpaṭipattiyam pamādam āpajjitvā

analyzed: pacchā kalyāṇa mitta saṃsaggena yonisas ummujjantaḥ na pamajjati sammā paṭipajjati
translated: and later, by associating with good friends, by rightly striving, he does not neglect the practice, he practices rightly,

analyzed: candaḥ viya okāsa lokam attanā adhigatāhi vijjā abhiññāhi imam khandha ādi lokam obhāseti iti

original: Yassa puggalassa kataṃ upacitaṃ pāpakammaṃ kammakkhayakarena lokuttarakusalena avipākārahabhāvassa āharitattā vipākuppādane dvārapidhānena pidhīyati thakīyati. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: yassa puggalassa katam upacitam pāpa kammam kamma khaya karena lokuttara kusalena a vipāka araha bhāvassa āharita ttā vipāka uppādane dvāra pidhānena pidhīyati thakīyati sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: When a person has done and accumulated evil deeds, but by means of supramundane wholesome states that lead to the exhaustion of action he has brought it about that they are incapable of producing results, then the ripening of those deeds is blocked, is stopped, by the two-fold prevention of the opportunity for their ripening. The rest is as already stated.

original: Daharoti taruṇo, tenassa yogakkhamasarīrataṃ dasseti. So hi uppannaṃ vātātapaparissayaṃ

analyzed: evam pīti somanassa jātaḥ vimutti sukhena viharantaḥ yadā nagaram piṇḍāya pavisati tadā

translated: With his bowl broken, he returned to the monastery and went to the Teacher.🔽The Teacher admonished him, saying, “Be patient, Brāhman, be patient. Brāhman, you are experiencing here and now the fruit of deeds for the ripening of which you might have been boiled in Hell for many a thousand years.”

original: brāhmaṇa, kammassa vipākaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme paṭisaṃvedesī”ti. Atha thero anodhiso
analyzed: brāhmaṇa kammassa vipākam diṭṭhe iva dhamme paṭisaṃvedesi iti atha theraḥ anodhisaḥ
translated: Then the Elder, without a murmur,

analyzed: sabba sattesu metta cittam upaṭṭhapetvā
translated: meditated on loving-kindness towards all living beings,

original: “Disāpi me dhammakathaṃ suṇantu, disāpi me yuñjantu buddhasāsane;
analyzed: disā api me dhamma katham suṇantu disā api me yuñjantu buddha sāsane
translated: “Let even the quarters of the heavens listen to my preaching of the Law; let even the quarters of the heavens apply themselves to the Dispensation of the Buddha;

analyzed: disā api me te manuje bhajantu ye dhammam eva ādapayanti santo

original: “Disā hi me khantivādānaṃ, avirodhappasaṃsinaṃ;
analyzed: disā hi me khanti vādānam a virodha ppasaṃsinam
translated: “The quarters are favorable to me, and the wind blows in my favor;

analyzed: suṇantu dhammam kālena tat ca anuvidhīyantu
translated: Let them listen to the Dhamma in season, and may they follow it.

original: “Na hi jātu so mamaṃ hiṃse, aññaṃ vā pana kañci naṃ;
analyzed: na hi jātu saḥ mamam hiṃse aññam vā pana kañci naṃ

analyzed: pappuyya paramam santim rakkheyya tasa thāvare
translated: Having attained the highest peace, he will protect the most vulnerable.

translated: “Carpenters tame wood, and fletchers tame reeds;

analyzed: dārum damayanti tat śakāḥ attānam damayanti paṇḍitā

analyzed: vuyhamānaḥ mahā oghena buddham saraṇam āgamam
translated: Buffeted by a great flood, I went for refuge to the Buddha.

original: “Lohitapāṇi pure āsiṃ, aṅgulimāloti vissuto;
analyzed: lohita pāṇi pure āsim aṅguli mālā iti vissutaḥ
translated: “In the past I was a murderer, known as Aṅgulimāla;

original: Saraṇagamanaṃ passa, bhavanetti samūhatā.
analyzed: saraṇa gamanam samūha tā
translated: See how I went for refuge, and the fetter of existence was destroyed.

original: “Tādisaṃ kammaṃ katvāna, bahuṃ duggatigāminaṃ;
analyzed: tādisam kammam katvāna bahum duggati gāminam
translated: “Having done such deeds, leading to a bad destination,

analyzed: phuṭṭhaḥ kamma vipākena anaṇaḥ bhuñjāmi bhojanaṃ

analyzed: pamādam anuyuñjanti bālāḥ dummedhinaḥ janā
