analyzed: mā pamādam anuyuñjetha mā kāma rati santhavam
translated: Do not be intimate with sensual pleasures.🔽For the heedful one who practices meditation

translated: Attains the highest bliss.

analyzed: svāgatam na apagatam na itam dummantitam mama
translated: “Welcome is the arrival, not the departure,🔽Of the one who has not reflected on the Dhamma.🔽I have attained the best of all things

analyzed: sa vibhattesu dhammesu yam seṭṭham tad upāgamam

translated: “Welcome is the arrival, not the departure,🔽Of the one who has reflected on the Dhamma.🔽I have attained the three true knowledges;

analyzed: tissaḥ vijjāḥ anuppattā katam buddhassa sāsanam
translated: I have fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.🔽“In the forest, at the foot of a tree,

analyzed: araññe rukkha mūle vā pabbatesu guhāsu vā
translated: Or in an empty hut,🔽Here and there I stood,

analyzed: tattha tattha iva aṭṭhāsim ubbigga manasaḥ tadā
translated: My mind agitated.🔽“I sleep well, I stand well,

analyzed: sukham sayāmi ṭhāyāmi sukham kappemi jīvitaṃ
translated: I live my life well.🔽I am not in Mara’s noose;

original: Ahatthapāso mārassa, aho satthānukampito.
analyzed: ahattha pāsaḥ mārassa aho sattha anukampito
translated: Oh, how I have been helped by the Teacher!🔽“Formerly I was a brahmin,

analyzed: brahmajaccaḥ pure āsim udiccaḥ ubhatas ahu
translated: Renowned, prosperous on both sides.🔽Now I am the son of the Sugata,

analyzed: putto sugatassa dhammarājassa satthuno
translated: The Teacher, the King of the Dhamma.

analyzed: vīta taṇhaḥ anādānaḥ gutta dvāraḥ su saṃvutaḥ
translated: My doors are guarded, well-restrained.🔽Having cut the root of evil,

analyzed: agha mūlam vadhitvāna pattaḥ me āsava kkhayaḥ
translated: My taints are destroyed.🔽“The Teacher has been served by me,

analyzed: pariciṇṇaḥ mayā satthā katam buddhassa sāsanam
translated: The Buddha’s discipline fulfilled.🔽The heavy burden is laid down,

analyzed: ohitaḥ garukaḥ bhāraḥ samūhata ati imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi  tattha disā api iti mayham disā api amittā paccatthikā api ye mam evam upavadanti yathā
translated: The fetter’s root is broken.”🔽Herein, in all directions means in all directions, in the east, etc., and also in the sense of “enemies” .🔽May my enemies, too, who revile me thus: “Just as we have come to suffering through separation from our relatives because of Aṅgulimāla,

analyzed: mayam aṅguli mālassa vasena ñāti viyoga dukkha paretāḥ dukkham pāpuṇāma evam aṅguli mālopi

analyzed: dukkham pāpuṇātu iti me dhamma katham suṇantu iti mayā satthu santike sutam catu sacca dhamma paṭisaṃyuttam

analyzed: katham suṇantu yuñjantu iti sutvā ca tad atthāya paṭipajjantu te manuje bhajantu iti

analyzed: tādise sappurise kalyāṇa mitte bhajantu sevantu ye dhammam eva ādapayanti santi iti ye

analyzed: khanti vādānam ti adhivāsana khantim eva vadantānam tatas eva kenacid  avirodha bhūtāya mettāya eva pasaṃsana sīlānam suṇantu dhammam kālena ati yutta ppayutta kāle  tesam santike dhammam suṇantu tat ca anuvidhīyantu iti tat ca yathā sutam dhammam sammat eva
translated: Those who speak of patience, who praise non-opposition, who are of a nature to praise non-opposition,🔽let them listen to the Dhamma at the right time.🔽Let them listen to the Dhamma in their presence. And let them follow it.

original: uggahitvā anukarontu dhammānudhammaṃ paṭipajjantūti attho.
analyzed: uggahitvā anukarontu dhamma anudhammam paṭipajjantu iti atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: having properly received the Dhamma as they have heard it, let them imitate it, let them practice in accordance with the Dhamma.

original: Na hi jātu so mamaṃ hiṃseti so mayhaṃ diso paccatthiko jātu, ekaṃseneva maṃ na hiṃse,
analyzed: na hi jātu saḥ mamam hiṃseti saḥ mayham disaḥ paccatthikaḥ jātu ekaṃsena iva mamam na hiṃse
translated: For he will never harm me. That direction, my enemy, will never harm me in any way.

original: na bādheyya. Aññaṃ vā pana kañci nanti na kevalaṃ maṃyeva, aññaṃ vāpi kañci sattaṃ
analyzed: na bādheyya aññam vā pana kañci nanti na kevalam aññam vā api kañci sattam
translated: Or anyone else. He will not harm anyone else,

original: na hiṃseyya, pappuyya paramaṃ santinti, paramaṃ uttamaṃ santiṃ nibbānaṃ pāpuṇeyya,
analyzed: na hiṃseyya pappuyya paramam santim ti paramam uttamam santim nibbānam pāpuṇeyya
translated: having attained the highest peace. Having attained the highest, supreme peace, Nibbana,

original: pāpuṇitvā ca rakkheyya tasathāvareti sabbe ca satte paramāya rakkhāya rakkheyya,
analyzed: pāpuṇitvā ca rakkheyya tasa thāvare iti sabbe ca satte paramāya rakkhāya rakkheyya
translated: and having reached them, he should guard them, and he should protect all beings with the highest protection,

original: sissaṃ puttaṃ viya paripāleyyāti attho.
analyzed: sissam puttam viya paripāleyya attho
translated: he should look after them as he would a pupil or a son.

original: Evaṃ thero imāhi gāthāhi pare pāpato parimocento parittakiriyaṃ nāma katvā attano🔽paṭipattiṃ pakāsento “udakaṃ hī”ti gāthamāha. Tattha pathaviyā thalaṭṭhānaṃ khaṇitvā
analyzed: evam theraḥ imāhi gāthāhi pare pāpataḥ parimocento parittakiriyam nāma katvā attano  paṭipattim pakāsentaḥ udakam hi iti gātham āha tattha pathaviyā thala ṭṭhānam khaṇitvā
translated: Thus the Elder, by means of these stanzas, having delivered others from evil, having performed what is called the Paritta Ceremony,🔽and having shown his own practice, uttered the stanza beginning with “Nettikā,”🔽in which he said: “Nettikā, usukārā, tacchakā, and so on, are the names of those who dig the earth,

original: ninnaṭṭhānaṃ pūretvā mātikaṃ vā katvā rukkhadoṇiṃ vā ṭhapetvā attanā icchikicchitaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ninna ṭhānam pūretvā mātikam vā katvā rukkha doṇim vā ṭhapetvā attanā icchikicchita ṭṭhānam
translated: fill up the low-lying places, and make a channel for the water to flow into a tree-hole or a pot, and then carry the water to the place they desire.

original: udakaṃ nentīti nettikā, udakahārino. Tejananti kaṇḍaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – nettikā
analyzed: udakam nenti iti nettikāḥ udaka hārino tejananti kaṇḍam idam vuttam hoti nettikā
translated: Tejan means ‘chaff.’ This is what is said: Nettikā

original: attano ruciyā udakaṃ nayanti, usukārāpi tāpetvā vaṅkābhāvaṃ harantā tejanaṃ usuṃ
analyzed: ruciyā udakam nayanti usukārā api tāpetvā vaṅka abhāvam harantā tejanam usum
translated: carry the water according to their own desire. Usus, too, having heated it, remove the crookedness, and they tame the tejan, the fire,

original: damayanti, ujukaṃ karonti, tacchakāpi nemiādīnaṃ atthāya tacchantā dāruṃ damayanti
analyzed: damayanti ujukam karonti nemi ādīnam tad śantā dārum damayanti
translated: they make it straight. Tacchakā, too, for the sake of the rim and so on, having cut the wood, tame the wood,

original: attano ruciyā ujuṃ vā vaṅkaṃ vā karonti. Evaṃ ettakaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā paṇḍitā sappaññā
analyzed: attanaḥ ruciyā ujum vā vaṅkam vā karonti evam ettakam ārammaṇam katvā paṇḍitā sappaññā
translated: They make it straight or crooked according to their own wish. So the wise, the sagacious,

original: ariyamaggaṃ uppādentā attānaṃ damenti, arahattappattā pana ekantadantā nāma hontīti.🔽Idāni purisadammasārathinā satthārā attano damitākāraṃ kataññutañca pakāsento “daṇḍeneke”tiādikā🔽pañca gāthā abhāsi. Tattha daṇḍeneke damayantīti rājarājamahāmattādayo daṇḍena, hatthiassādinā
analyzed: ariya maggaṃ uppādentā attānam damenti arahatta pattā pana ekanta dantāḥ nāma honti iti  idāni purisa damma sārathinā satthārā attanaḥ damita ākāram pakāsentaḥ daṇḍena eka iti ādikā  pañca gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha daṇḍena eke damayanti iti rāja rāja mahāmatta ādayaḥ daṇḍena hatthi assa ādinā
translated: having taken this much as their object, when they arouse the noble path, they tame themselves. But when they have attained Arahantship, they are called ‘thoroughly tamed.’🔽Now, the Teacher, the Leader of men to be tamed, spoke five stanzas beginning with ‘Some are tamed with a stick’

original: balakāyena ca paccatthikādike damenti, gopālādayo ca gāvādike daṇḍena yaṭṭhiyā damenti.
analyzed: balakāyena ca paccatthika ādike damenti gopāla ādayo ca gāvā ādike daṇḍena yaṭṭhiyā damenti
translated: in order to show how he himself was tamed and how he was grateful. Herein, some are tamed with a stick: kings, royal ministers, etc., tame their enemies, etc., with a stick, with an army of elephants, horses, and so on. And cowherds, etc., tame cows, etc., with a stick, with a staff.🔽Elephant trainers tame elephants with hooks, and horse trainers tame horses with whips.

original: Hatthācariyā hatthiṃ aṅkusehi, assācariyā asse kasāhi ca damenti. Adaṇḍena asatthena,
analyzed: hatthā cariyāḥ hatthim aṅkusehi assā cariyāḥ asse kasāhi ca damenti a daṇḍena a satthena
translated: I am tamed without a stick, without a weapon,

original: ahaṃ dantomhi tādināti ahaṃ pana iṭṭhādīsu tādibhāvappattena sammāsambuddhena vinā
analyzed: aham dantaḥ asmi tādinā ati aham pana iṭṭha ādīsu tādi bhāva ppattena sammāsambuddhena vinā
translated: I am tamed, the Tamer unsurpassed.

original: eva daṇḍena, vinā satthena, nihitadaṇḍanihitasatthabhāvena danto damito nibbisevano gato amhi.
analyzed: eva daṇḍena vinā satthena nihita daṇḍa nihita sattha bhāvena dantaḥ damitaḥ nibbisevanaḥ gataḥ amhi
translated: I am now tamed, restrained, and disciplined, having become one who has laid aside the rod and laid aside the sword, having a conscience and full of pity for all living beings.

original: Ahiṃsakoti me nāmaṃ, hiṃsakassa pure satoti satthārā samāgamato pubbe hiṃsakassa
analyzed: ahiṃsako ti me nāmam hiṃsakassa pure sato ti satthārā samāgamataḥ pubbe hiṃsakassa
translated: I was called Ahiṃsaka, though formerly I was a killer: before I met the Teacher I was a killer,

original: me samānassa ahiṃsakoti nāmamattaṃ ahosi. Ajjāhanti idāni panāhaṃ “ahiṃsako”ti saccanāmo
analyzed: me samānassa ahiṃsako ti nāma mattam ahosi ajja aham idāni pana aham ahiṃsako ti sacca nāmo
translated: but my name was Ahiṃsaka, “non-violent,” only in name. But now I am a true Ahiṃsaka,

original: avitathanāmo amhi. Tasmā na naṃ hiṃsāmi kañcipi sattaṃ na hiṃsāmi na bādhemi, nanti nipātamattaṃ.🔽Vissutoti “pāṇātipātī luddo lohitapāṇī”tiādinā paññāto. Mahoghenāti kāmoghādinā mahatā
analyzed: avitatha nāmaḥ amhi tasmā na nam hiṃsāmi kañcipi sattam na hiṃsāmi na bādhemi nipāta mattam  vissuto ti pāṇa atipātī luddaḥ lohitapāṇi iti ādinā paññātaḥ mahoghena ati kāma ogha ādinā mahatā
translated: my name is not false. Therefore I do not harm any being, I do not oppress any being.

original: oghena, tassa oghassa vicchedakaraṃ buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ buddhasaṅkhātaṃ saraṇaṃ agamaṃ upagacchiṃ.
analyzed: oghena tassa oghassa viccheda karam buddham saraṇam buddha saṅkhātam saraṇam agamam upagacchiṃ
translated: I am well known as a killer, a hunter, a blood-stained hand: I was known as a killer, a hunter, a blood-stained hand, and so on. I went for refuge to the Buddha, the remover of the great flood: I went for refuge to the Buddha, the remover of the great flood of sense desire, etc.

original: Lohitapāṇīti pāṇamatipātanena paresaṃ lohitena ruhirena makkhitapāṇi. Saraṇagamanaṃ passāti mahapphalaṃ mama saraṇagamanaṃ passāti attānamevālapati.
analyzed: lohita pāṇi iti pāṇam atipātanena paresam lohitena ruhirena makkhita pāṇi saraṇa gamanam passāti mahapphalam mama saraṇa gamanam passāti attānam eva ālapati
translated: I was a blood-stained hand: my hands were smeared with the blood of others by killing them. I see the fruit of going for refuge: I see the great fruit of my going for refuge. He speaks to himself.

original: Tādisaṃ kammanti anekasatapurisavadhaṃ dāruṇaṃ tathārūpaṃ pāpakammaṃ. Phuṭṭho kammavipākenāti
analyzed: tādisam aneka sata purisa vadham dāruṇam tathārūpam pāpa kammam phuṭṭhaḥ kamma vipākena ati
translated: Such a deed: a terrible deed of killing many hundreds of men, such a evil deed.🔽I was touched by the result of my deed:

original: pubbe katassa pāpakammassa vipākena phuṭṭho, sabbaso pahīnakammo vipākamattaṃ paccanubhonto.
analyzed: pubbe katassa pāpa kammassa vipākena phuṭṭhaḥ sabbasas pahīna kammaḥ vipāka mattam paccanubhontaḥ
translated: I was touched by the result of the evil deed done in the past, experiencing only the result, having given up the deed completely.

original: Atha vā phuṭṭho kammavipākenāti upanissayabhūtassa kusalakammassa phalabhūtena lokuttaramaggena,
analyzed: atha vā phuṭṭhaḥ kamma vipākena ati upanissaya bhūtassa kusala kammassa phala bhūtena lokuttara maggena
translated: Or else, I was touched by the result of my deed: I was touched by the supramundane path, which is the fruit of the wholesome deed that is the support,🔽or else I was touched by the fruit of the supramundane deed, by the bliss of liberation.

original: lokuttarakammasseva vā phalena vimuttisukhena phuṭṭho. Sabbaso kilesānaṃ khīṇattā
analyzed: lokuttara kammassa iva vā phalena vimutti sukhena phuṭṭhaḥ sabbaso kilesānam khīṇa ttā
translated: Because all defilements were destroyed,

original: anaṇo bhuñjāmi bhojanaṃ, bhojanāpadesena cattāropi paccaye vadati.
analyzed: anaṇaḥ bhuñjāmi bhojanam bhojana apadesena cattāraḥ api paccaye vadati
translated: I eat my food without debt. And by the word “food” he means the four requisites.

original: Idāni pubbe attano pamādavihāraṃ garahāmukhena pacchā appamādapaṭipattiṃ pasaṃsanto
analyzed: idāni pubbe attanaḥ pamāda vihāram garahā mukhena pacchā appamāda paṭipattim pasaṃsanto
translated: Now, praising the practice of heedfulness in the future by way of reproaching his own heedless conduct in the past,

original: tattha ca paresaṃ ussāhaṃ janento “pamādamanuyuñjantī”tiādikā gāthā abhāsi. Tattha
analyzed: tattha ca paresam ussāham janentaḥ pamādam anuyuñjanti iti ādikāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha
translated: and encouraging others to practice heedfulness in the future, he spoke the verses beginning with “Those who delight in heedlessness.” There

original: bālāti bālyena samannāgatā idhalokaparalokatthaṃ ajānantā. Dummedhinoti nippaññā,
analyzed: bālā ati bālyena samannāgatāḥ idhaloka paralokattham a jānantāḥ dummedhinaḥ ti nippaññāḥ
translated: Fools: endowed with foolishness, not knowing the benefit of this world and the next. Ignorant: unskilled.

original: te pamāde ādīnavaṃ apassantā pamādaṃ anuyuñjanti pavattenti, pamādeneva kālaṃ vītināmenti.
analyzed: te pamāde ādīnavam a passantā pamādam anuyuñjanti pavattenti pamādena iva kālam vītināmenti
translated: They do not see the danger in negligence, and so they pursue and practice negligence, and they spend their time in negligence.

original: Medhāvīti dhammojapaññāya samannāgato pana paṇḍito kulavaṃsāgataṃ seṭṭhaṃ uttamaṃ
analyzed: medhāvī iti dhamma oja paññāya samannāgataḥ pana paṇḍitaḥ kula vaṃsa āgatam seṭṭham uttamam
translated: The wise man: the wise man is endowed with the wisdom of the Dhamma. He protects his diligence as if it were the best, the most excellent,

original: sattaratanadhanaṃ viya appamādaṃ rakkhati. Yathā hi “uttamaṃ dhanaṃ nissāya bhogasampattiṃ
analyzed: satta ratana dhanam viya appamādam rakkhati yathā hi uttamam dhanam nissāya bhoga sampattim
translated: wealth of the seven kinds of precious jewels. Just as people, seeing the benefits in wealth, protect their wealth, thinking, “By means of this excellent wealth we shall attain the abundance of sensual pleasures,

original: pāpuṇissāma, puttadāraṃ posessāma, sugatimaggaṃ sodhessāmā”ti dhane ānisaṃsaṃ passantā
analyzed: pāpuṇissāma putta dāram posessāma sugati maggam sodhessāma ati dhane ānisaṃsam passantā
translated: we shall support our children and wives, and we shall clear the path to a good destiny,”

original: dhanaṃ rakkhanti; evaṃ paṇḍitopi “appamādaṃ nissāya paṭhamajjhānādīni paṭilabhissāmi,
analyzed: dhanam rakkhanti evam paṇḍitaḥ api appamādam nissāya paṭhamajjhāna ādīni paṭilabhissāmi
translated: so the wise man, seeing the benefits in diligence, protects his diligence as if it were the best wealth, thinking, “By means of this diligence I shall attain the first jhana, etc.,

original: maggaphalāni pāpuṇissāmi, tisso vijjā cha abhiññā sampādessāmī”ti appamāde ānisaṃsaṃ🔽passanto dhanaṃ seṭṭhaṃva appamādaṃ rakkhatīti attho.
analyzed: magga phalāni pāpuṇissāmi tissaḥ vijjāḥ cha abhiññāḥ sampādessāmi iti appamāde ānisaṃsam  passantaḥ dhanam seṭṭham va appamādam rakkhati iti attho
translated: I shall attain the paths and fruits, and I shall perfect the three true knowledges and the six kinds of direct knowledge.”

original: Mā pamādanti pamādaṃ mā anuyuñjetha pamādena kālaṃ mā vītināmayittha. Kāmaratisanthavanti
analyzed: mā pamādanti pamādam mā anuyuñjetha pamādena kālam mā vītināmayittha kāma rati santhavanti
translated: Do not be negligent: do not pursue negligence; do not spend your time in negligence. In the enjoyment of sensual pleasures: in the enjoyment of the pleasures of the five cords of sense desire.

original: vatthukāmesu, kilesakāmesu ca ratisaṅkhātaṃ taṇhāsanthavampi mā anuyuñjetha mā vindittha
analyzed: vatthu kāmesu kilesa kāmesu ca rati saṅkhātam taṇhā santhavam pi mā anuyuñjetha mā vindittha
translated: Do not pursue, do not seek, do not obtain the craving-coverlet called delight in the objects of sensual pleasure and in the defilements.

original: mā paṭilabhittha. Appamatto hīti upaṭṭhitasatitāya appamatto puggalo jhāyanto jhāyanappasuto
analyzed: mā paṭilabhittha appamattaḥ hi iti upaṭṭhita sati tāya appamattaḥ puggalo jhāyantaḥ jhāyana ppasuto
translated: The person who is heedful, who is heedful through the establishment of mindfulness, who is devoted to meditation,

original: paramaṃ uttamaṃ nibbānasukhaṃ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: paramam uttamam nibbāna sukham pāpuṇāti
translated: attains the supreme, the highest, the bliss of Nibbāna.

original: Svāgataṃ nāpagatanti yaṃ tadā mama satthu santike āgataṃ āgamanaṃ, satthu vā tasmiṃ
analyzed: svāgatam yam tadā mama satthu santike āgatam āgamanam satthu vā tasmin
translated: The welcome that has not departed: the welcome, the coming, that has come to me at that time in the presence of the Teacher, or the Teacher’s coming

original: mahāvane āgamanaṃ, taṃ svāgataṃ svāgamanaṃ nāpagataṃ, atthato apetaṃ vigataṃ na hoti.
analyzed: mahā vane āgamanam tam svāgatam svāgamanam na apagatam atthataḥ apetam vigatam na hoti
translated: to that Great Wood, that welcome has not departed, has not gone away, has not disappeared.

original: Netaṃ dummantitaṃ mamāti yaṃ tadā mayā “satthu santike pabbajissāmī”ti mantitaṃ,
analyzed: na itam dummantitam mama ati yam tadā mayā satthu santike pabbajissāmi iti mantitam
translated: This is not a bad thought of mine: this thought of mine at that time, “I will go forth in the presence of the Teacher,”

original: idampi mama na dummantitaṃ, sumantitameva. Kasmā? Savibhattesu dhammesūti sāvajjānavajjādivasena
analyzed: idam pi mama na dummantitam su mantitam eva kasmā sa vibhattesu dhammesu iti sāvajja anavajja ādi vasena
translated: this too is not a bad thought of mine, it is a good thought. Why? In the well-analysed ideas: in the ideas that are analysed by way of the blameworthy, the blameless, etc.,

original: pakārato vibhattesu dhammesu yaṃ seṭṭhaṃ uttamaṃ pavaraṃ nibbānaṃ. Tadupāgamaṃ tadeva upagacchinti attho.
analyzed: pakārataḥ vibhattesu dhammesu yam seṭṭham uttamam pavaram nibbānam tad upāgamam tat eva upagacchinti attho
translated: the best, the highest, the excellent, Nibbāna. I have come to that: the meaning is, I have come to that very Nibbāna.

original: “Tadā puthujjanakāle payogāsayavipannatāya araññādīsu dukkhaṃ vihāsiṃ, idāni payogāsayasampannatāya🔽tattha sukhaṃ viharāmī”ti sukhavihārabhāvañceva “pubbe jātimattena brāhmaṇo, idāni
analyzed: tadā puthujjana kāle payoga āsaya vipanna tāya arañña ādīsu dukkham idāni payoga āsaya sampanna tāya  tattha sukham viharāmi iti sukha vihāra bhāvañca iva pubbe jātimattena brāhmaṇaḥ idāni
translated: “At the time when I was an ordinary man, I lived in suffering in the forest, etc., because my practice and my resting place were defective. Now,🔽because my practice and my resting place are perfect, I live in happiness there.

original: satthu orasaputtatāya brāhmaṇo”ti paramatthabrāhmaṇabhāvañca dassento “araññe”tiādimāha.
analyzed: satthu orasa putta tāya brāhmaṇo ti paramattha brāhmaṇa bhāvañca dassentaḥ arañña iti ādim āha
translated: ” And showing the state of living in happiness and the state of being a supreme brahman, saying, “Formerly I was a brahman by birth alone, now I am a brahman🔽because I am the Teacher’s own son,” he spoke the stanza beginning with “In the forest.”

original: Tattha sukhaṃ sayāmīti sayantopi sukhaṃ sukhena nidukkhena cittutrāsādīnaṃ abhāvena
analyzed: tattha sukham sayāmi iti sayantaḥ api sukham sukhena nidukkhena cittu trāsa ādīnam abhāvena
translated: Therein, I sleep happily: while sleeping, I sleep happily, without suffering, without mental anguish, etc.

original: cetodukkharahito sayāmi. Ṭhāyāmīti ṭhāmi. Ahatthapāso mārassāti kilesamārādīnaṃ agocaro.
analyzed: cetaḥ dukkha rahitaḥ sayāmi ṭhāyāmi iti ṭhāmi ahattha pāsaḥ mārassa ati kilesa māra ādīnam agocaraḥ
translated: I live happily: I live without mental suffering. I stand happily: I stand. I am not in Mara’s grip: I am not in the range of the defilement Mara, etc.

original: Aho satthānukampitoti satthārānukampito aho.
analyzed: aho satthā anukampito ti satthārā anukampitaḥ aho
translated: Oh, I am favored by the Teacher: I am favored by the Teacher.

original: Brahmajaccoti brāhmaṇajātiko. Udicco ubhatoti mātito ca pitito ca ubhato udito saṃsuddhagahaṇiko. Sesaṃ tattha tattha vuttanayameva.🔽Aṅgulimālattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽9. Anuruddhattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: brahmajacco ti brāhmaṇa jātikaḥ udiccaḥ ubhatas ti mātitaḥ ca pititaḥ ca ubhatas uditaḥ saṃsuddha gahaṇiko sesam tattha tattha vutta nayam eva 🔽aṅgulimāla thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽anuruddhatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: I am of the Brahma race: I am of the brahman caste. I am of noble birth on both sides: I am of pure descent on both my mother’s side and my father’s side. The rest is as explained in the appropriate places.

original: Pahāya mātāpitarotiādikā āyasmato anuruddhattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi purimabuddhesu
analyzed: pahāya mātā pitaraḥ ti ādikā āyasmataḥ anuruddha ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi purima buddhesu
translated: The story of the Elder Anuruddha is given in the Theragāthā Commentary, in the explanation of the stanza, “Having abandoned mother and father, and having abandoned wife and children. ”🔽In a previous state of existence he had made his preparation for the attainment of Arahatship under former Buddhas.

original: katādhikāro padumuttarassa bhagavato kāle vibhavasampanno kuṭumbiko hutvā nibbatti.
analyzed: kata adhikāraḥ padumuttarassa bhagavataḥ kāle vibhava sampannaḥ kuṭumbikaḥ hutvā nibbatti
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Padumuttara he was reborn in great wealth as the son of a wealthy householder.

original: So ekadivasaṃ vihāraṃ gantvā satthu santike dhammaṃ suṇanto satthāraṃ ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ🔽dibbacakkhukānaṃ aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapentaṃ disvā sayampi taṃ ṭhānantaraṃ patthetvā satasahassabhikkhuparivārassa🔽bhagavato sattāhaṃ mahādānaṃ pavattetvā sattame divase bhagavato, bhikkhusaṅghassa
analyzed: saḥ eka divasam vihāram gantvā satthu santike dhammaṃ suṇantaḥ satthāram ekam bhikkhum  dibba cakkhukānam agga ṭṭhāne ṭhapentam disvā sayam pi tam ṭhāna antaram patthetvā sata sahassa bhikkhu parivārassa  bhagavataḥ sattāham mahādānam pavattetvā sattame divase bhagavataḥ bhikkhu saṅghassa
translated: One day he went to the monastery and listened to the Law in the presence of the Teacher. The Teacher set him up as the foremost of those possessing the Supernatural Vision.🔽He himself aspired to that place of distinction, and for seven days entertained the Teacher and his retinue of six hundred thousand monks with abundant offerings.

original: ca uttamāni vatthāni datvā paṇidhānamakāsi. Satthāpissa anantarāyena samijjhanabhāvaṃ
analyzed: ca uttamāni vatthāni da tvā paṇidhānam akāsi satthā api issa anantarāyena samijjhana bhāvam
translated: On the seventh day he gave to the Teacher and to the Congregation of Monks the choicest garments.

original: disvā “anāgate gotamassa nāma sammāsambuddhassa sāsane dibbacakkhukānaṃ aggo bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: disvā anāgate gotamassa nāma sammāsambuddhassa sāsane dibba cakkhukānam aggaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: The Teacher perceived that his aspiration would be fulfilled without hindrance, and said, “In the dispensation of the Supremely Enlightened One named Gotama he shall become the foremost of those possessing the Supernatural Vision.”

original: byākāsi. Sopi tattha puññāni karonto satthari parinibbute niṭṭhite sattayojanike🔽suvaṇṇacetiye anekasahassehi dīparukkhehi dīpakapallikāhi ca “dibbacakkhuñāṇassa
analyzed: byākāsi saḥ api tattha puññāni karontaḥ satthari parinibbute niṭṭhite satta yojanike  suvaṇṇa cetiye aneka sahassehi dīpa rukkhehi dīpaka pallikāhi ca dibba cakkhu ñāṇassa
translated: and he also made merit there. When the Teacher had attained Parinibbāna, and when the seven-league golden Caitya had been completed,

original: upanissayapaccayo hotū”ti uḷāraṃ dīpapūjaṃ akāsi.
analyzed: upanissaya paccayaḥ hotu uti uḷāram dīpa pūjam akāsi
translated: he made a great offering of lamps, with many thousands of oil-lamps and oil-wicks, saying, “Let this be a condition for the knowledge of the Divine Eye.”

original: Evaṃ yāvajīvaṃ puññāni katvā devamanussesu saṃsaranto kassapassa bhagavato kāle bārāṇasiyaṃ
analyzed: evam yāvajīvam puññāni katvā deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ kassapassa bhagavato kāle bārāṇasiyam
translated: Thus he made merit all his life, and passing from birth to birth among gods and men, he was reborn in the time of the Exalted Kassapa,

original: kuṭumbikagehe nibbattitvā viññutaṃ patto satthari parinibbute niṭṭhite yojanike kanakathūpe
analyzed: kuṭumbika gehe nibbattitvā viññutam patto satthari parinibbute niṭṭhite yojanike kanaka thūpe
translated: in Benares, in the house of a wealthy man. When he had attained maturity, after the Teacher had attained Parinibbāna, and when the golden Caitya of a league in height had been completed,

original: bahū kaṃsapātiyo kāretvā sappimaṇḍassa pūretvā majjhe ekekaṃ guḷapiṇḍaṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: bahū kaṃsapātiyaḥ kāretvā sappi maṇḍassa pūretvā majjhe ekekam guḷa piṇḍam ṭhapetvā
translated: he had many bronze bowls made, filled them with ghee, placed a lump of sugar in the middle of each,

original: mukhavaṭṭiyā mukhavaṭṭiṃ phusāpento cetiyaṃ parikkhipāpetvā attanā ekaṃ mahatiṃ kaṃsapātiṃ
analyzed: mukhavaṭṭiyāḥ mukhavaṭṭim phusāpentaḥ cetiyam parikkhipāpetvā attanā ekam mahatim kaṃsapātim
translated: and had them carried around the Caitya, touching the bowls to the bowls. He himself had a great bronze bowl made,

original: kāretvā sappimaṇḍassa pūretvā sahassavaṭṭiyo jālāpetvā sīse ṭhapetvā sabbarattiṃ🔽cetiyaṃ anupariyāyi.
analyzed: kāretvā sappimaṇḍassa pūretvā sahassa vaṭṭiyaḥ jālāpetvā sīse ṭhapetvā sabbarattim 🔽cetiyam anupariyāyi
translated: filled it with ghee, had a thousand wicks lighted in it, placed it on his head, and went around the Caitya all night long.

original: Evaṃ tasmimpi attabhāve yāvajīvaṃ kusalaṃ katvā tato cuto devaloke nibbattitvā tattha
analyzed: evam tasmin pi atta bhāve yāvajīvam kusalam katvā tatas cutaḥ deva loke nibbattitvā tattha
translated: and so he did. When he died he was reborn in the World of the Gods,

original: yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā tato cuto anuppanne buddhe bārāṇasiyaṃyeva duggatakule nibbatti,
analyzed: yāvatāyukam ṭhatvā tatas cutaḥ an uppanne buddhe bārāṇasiyam yeva duggata kule nibbatti
translated: and after living there until he had exhausted the fruit of his good deeds, he was reborn in Benares in a poor family,

original: annabhārotissa nāmaṃ ahosi. So sumanaseṭṭhissa nāma gehe kammaṃ karonto jīvati. So
analyzed: annabhārotissa nāmam ahosi so sumanaseṭṭhissa nāma gehe kammam karontaḥ jīvati so
translated: and he was called Annabhara. He lived by working for a merchant named Sumanasena.

original: ekadivasaṃ upariṭṭhaṃ nāma paccekabuddhaṃ nirodhasamāpattito vuṭṭhāya gandhamādanapabbatato
analyzed: eka divasam upariṭṭham nāma paccekabuddham nirodha samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāya gandhamādana pabbatato
translated: One day he saw the Paccekabuddha named Upatissa coming through the air from the Gandhamadana mountain,

original: ākāsenāgantvā bārāṇasīnagaradvāre otaritvā cīvaraṃ pārupitvā nagare piṇḍāya pavisantaṃ🔽disvā pasannacitto pattaṃ gahetvā attano atthāya ṭhapitaṃ ekaṃ bhāgabhattaṃ patte🔽pakkhipitvā paccekabuddhassa dātukāmo ārabhi. Bhariyāpissa attano bhāgabhattaṃ tattheva
analyzed: ākāsena āgantvā bārāṇasī nagara dvāre otaritvā cīvaram nagare piṇḍāya pavisantam  disvā pasanna cittaḥ pattam gahetvā attanaḥ atthāya ṭhapitam ekam bhāgabhattam patte  pakkhipitvā paccekabuddhassa dātu kāmaḥ ārabhi bhariyā pissa attanaḥ bhāga bhattam tattha eva
translated: having emerged from the attainment of cessation, and alighting at the gate of the city of Benares, putting on his robe, and entering the city for alms.🔽Seeing him, he was filled with faith, and taking his bowl, he put into it a portion of food which he had set aside for his own supper,

original: pakkhipi. So taṃ netvā paccekabuddhassa hatthe ṭhapesi. Paccekabuddho taṃ gahetvā
analyzed: pakkhipi saḥ tam netvā paccekabuddhassa hatthe ṭhapesi paccekabuddhaḥ tam gahetvā
translated: and was about to give it to the Paccekabuddha. His wife also put her portion of food into the bowl. He took it and put it into the hand of the Paccekabuddha. The Paccekabuddha took it and went away.

original: anumodanaṃ katvā pakkāmi. Taṃ disvā rattiṃ sumanaseṭṭhissa chatte adhivatthā devatā
analyzed: anumodanam katvā pakkāmi tam disvā rattim sumanasā iṭṭhissa chatte adhivatthā devatā
translated: and after he had expressed his satisfaction, he departed. A deity who dwelt in the umbrella of the merchant Sumana, seeing the alms,

analyzed: aho dānam parama dānam upariṭṭhe su patiṭṭhitanti mahā saddena anumodi tam sutvā

analyzed: evam devatāya anumoditam idam eva uttama dānam ti cintetvā tattha pattim  yāci anna bhāraḥ pana tassa pattim adāsi tena pasanna citto sumanaseṭṭhi tassa sahassam
translated: Hearing this, the merchant Sumana thought to himself, “Since the deity expresses herself in this manner, this must be the best of gifts.” So he asked for the boon🔽of being allowed to give alms to the Private Buddha. The man Annabhāra granted his request.

original: datvā “ito paṭṭhāya tuyhaṃ sahatthena kammakaraṇakiccaṃ natthi, patirūpaṃ gehaṃ katvā
analyzed: datvā itas paṭṭhāya tuyham sahatthena kamma karaṇa kiccam natthi patirūpam geham katvā
translated: The merchant Sumana, filled with joy, gave him a thousand pieces of money and said to him, “Henceforth you shall have no more work to do with your own hands. Build yourself a suitable house and

original: niccaṃ vasāhī”ti āha.
analyzed: niccam vasāhi iti āha
translated: live there permanently.”

original: Yasmā nirodhato vuṭṭhitassa paccekabuddhassa dinnapiṇḍapāto taṃdivasameva uḷārataravipāko
analyzed: yasmā nirodhataḥ vuṭṭhitassa paccekabuddhassa dinna piṇḍapāto taṃ divasam eva uḷāratara vipāko
translated: Now whatever alms are given to a Private Buddha who has emerged from the state of trance, the reward thereof is very great.

original: hoti, tasmā taṃdivasaṃ sumanaseṭṭhi rañño santikaṃ gacchanto taṃ gahetvā agamāsi.
analyzed: hoti tasmai taṃ divasam sumanaseṭṭhi rañño santikam gacchantaḥ tam gahetvā agamāsi
translated: Therefore the merchant Sumana, on the day he gave alms to the Private Buddha, took him with him when he went to the king.

original: Rājā pana taṃ ādaravasena olokesi. Seṭṭhi “mahārāja, ayaṃ oloketabbayuttoyevā”ti
analyzed: rājā pana tam ādara vasena olokesi seṭṭhi mahā rāja ayam oloketabba yuttaḥ yā iva ati
translated: But the king looked at him with respect. The treasurer said, “Your majesty, he is worthy to be looked at.”

original: vatvā tadā tena katapuññaṃ attanāpissa sahassaṃ dinnabhāvaṃ kathesi. Taṃ sutvā rājā
analyzed: vatvā tadā tena kata puññam attanā api issa sahassam dinna bhāvam kathesi tam sutvā rājā
translated: And he told the story of the merit that he had made and of the thousand pieces of money that he had given. When the king heard this,

original: tussitvā sahassaṃ datvā asukasmiṃ nāma ṭhāne gehaṃ katvā vasā”ti gehaṭṭhānamassa
analyzed: tussitvā sahassam da tvā asukasmin nāma ṭhāne geham katvā vasāti geha ṭṭhānam assa
translated: he was pleased, and he gave him a thousand pieces of money, and he ordered a place to be assigned to him, saying, “Build a house in such a place and live there.”

original: āṇāpesi. Tassa taṃ ṭhānaṃ sodhāpentassa mahantiyo nidhikumbhiyo uṭṭhahiṃsu. Tā disvā
analyzed: āṇāpesi tassa tam ṭhānam sodhāpentassa mahantiyaḥ nidhikumbhiyaḥ uṭṭhahiṃsu tāḥ disvā
translated: While he was having the place cleared, a great many treasure-pots came to light. When he saw them,

analyzed: saḥ raññaḥ ārocesi rājā sabbam dhanam uddharāpetvā rāsikatam disvā ettakam dhanam  imasmin nagare kassa gehe atthi iti na kassaci tena hi ayam anna bhāraḥ
translated: he informed the king. The king had all the treasure dug up, and when he saw it heaped in a pile, he said, “In this city there is no one else so rich as this man.”

original: imasmiṃ nagare mahādhanaseṭṭhi nāma hotū”ti taṃdivasameva tassa seṭṭhichattaṃ ussāpesi.
analyzed: imasmin nagare mahādhana seṭṭhi nāma hotu uti taṃ divasam eva tassa seṭṭhi chattam ussāpesi
translated: “No one, your majesty.” “Well then, let this Annabhāra be the chief treasurer in this city.” And on that very day he raised him to the rank of treasurer.

original: So tato paṭṭhāya yāvajīvaṃ kusalakammaṃ katvā tato cuto devamanussesu saṃsaritvā
analyzed: so tatas paṭṭhāya yāvajīvam kusala kammam katvā tatas cutaḥ deva manussesu saṃsaritvā
translated: From that time forth he continued to perform meritorious deeds as long as he lived, and when he died he passed on to the World of the Gods.

original: imasmiṃ buddhuppāde kapilavatthunagare sukkodanasakkassa gehe paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhi,🔽anuruddhotissa nāmaṃ ahosi. So mahānāmassa sakkassa kaniṭṭhabhātā, satthu cūḷapitu🔽putto paramasukhumālo mahāpuñño tiṇṇaṃ utūnaṃ anucchavikesu tīsu pāsādesu alaṅkatanāṭakitthīhi🔽parivuto devo viya sampattiṃ anubhavanto suddhodanamahārājena ussāhitehi sakyarājūhi
analyzed: imasmin buddhuppāde kapilavatthu nagare sukkodana sakkassa gehe paṭisandhim gaṇhi  anuruddhotissa nāmam ahosi so mahānāmassa sakkassa kaniṭṭha bhātā satthu  putto parama sukhu mālaḥ mahā puññaḥ tiṇṇam utūnam anucchavikesu tīsu pāsādesu alaṅkata nāṭaki itthīhi  parivutaḥ devaḥ viya sampattim anubhavantaḥ suddhodana mahā rājena ussāhitehi sakya rājūhi
translated: In this dispensation of the Buddha he was conceived in the womb of the wife of King Suddhodana in the city of Kapilavatthu.🔽He was the younger brother of Mahānāma the Sakyan and the son of the Buddha’s maternal uncle. He was exceedingly delicate, very wealthy, and lived in luxury, like a god. In three palaces, each suitable for one of the three seasons, he was waited upon by dancing girls.

original: satthu parivāratthaṃ pesitehi bhaddiyakumārādīhi anupiyambavane viharantaṃ satthāraṃ
analyzed: satthu parivāra attham pesitehi bhaddiya kumāra ādīhi anupiyamba vane viharantam satthāram
translated: He was surrounded by the Sakyan princes sent by King Suddhodana to wait upon the Buddha, and by Bhaddiya the Sakyan, etc., who had been sent by the king to be his companions.🔽He went to the Teacher, who was residing in the Anupiya Mango Grove,

analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā satthu santike pabbajitvā antovasseya iva dibba cakkhum nibbattetvā puna
translated: and received the going forth in the presence of the Teacher. Before the end of the first rainy season he attained the Supernatural Faculties, and then,

analyzed: dhammasenāpatissa santike kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā cetiya raṭṭhe pācīna vaṃsa dāyam gantvā

analyzed: samaṇa dhammam karonto satta mahāpurisa vitakke vitakketvā aṭṭhamam jānitum na asakkhi
translated: There he applied himself to the practice of meditation. He reflected upon the Seven Discourses for Laymen, but he was unable to understand the eighth discourse.

analyzed: tassa tam pavattim ñatvā satthā aṭṭhamam mahāpurisa vitakkam kathetvā catu paccaya santosa bhāvanā ārāma paṭimaṇḍitaṃ
translated: The Teacher, knowing his thoughts, expounded the eighth Great Man’s Vitakka, and then he taught him the Noble Lineage, which is adorned with the meditation on contentment with the four requisites.

original: mahāariyavaṃsapaṭipadaṃ deseti. So desanānusārena vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā abhiññāpaṭisambhidāparivāraṃ
analyzed: mahā ariya vaṃsa paṭipadam deseti saḥ desanā anusārena vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā abhiññā paṭisambhidā parivāram
translated: By following the teaching, the Elder developed insight, and surrounded by the higher knowledge and the analytical knowledges,

original: arahattaṃ sacchākāsi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: arahattam sacchākāsi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: he reached Arahantship. Therefore it is said in the Apadana:

translated: “I saw the Blessed One, Sumedha, the world’s chief, the bull of men,

translated: The leader of the world, who lived detached.

translated: “I approached the Sambuddha, Sumedha, the world’s leader,

analyzed: añjalim paggahetvāna buddha seṭṭham ayācaham
translated: And with my hands raised in reverence, I asked the Buddha, the Best:

analyzed: anukampa mahā vīra loka jeṭṭha narāsabha
translated: “‘Have compassion, O great hero, O world’s chief, O bull of men!

analyzed: padīpam te padassāmi rukkha mūlamhi jhāyato
translated: I will light a lamp for you as you meditate at the foot of the tree.’

original: “Adhivāsesi so dhīro, sayambhū vadataṃ varo;
analyzed: adhivāsesi saḥ dhīraḥ sayambhū vadatam varaḥ
translated: “The Sage, the Self-Existent One, the Best of Speakers, consented,

analyzed: dumesu vinivijjhitvā yantam tadā
translated: And I cut down some sticks and made a torch.🔽“I offered a torch with a thousand wicks

analyzed: sahassa vaṭṭim pādāsim buddhassa loka bandhunaḥ
translated: To the Buddha, the friend of the world,

original: Sattāhaṃ pajjalitvāna, dīpā vūpasamiṃsu me.
analyzed: satta aham dīpāḥ vūpasamiṃsu me
translated: For seven days they burned, and then the lamps went out.

original: “Tena cittappasādena, cetanāpaṇidhīhi ca;
analyzed: tena citta ppasādena cetanā paṇidhīhi ca
translated: “Through that faith and that aspiration,

original: Jahitvā mānusaṃ dehaṃ, vimānamupapajjahaṃ.
analyzed: jahitvā mānusam deham vimānam upapad jaham
translated: I gave up my human body and was reborn in a heavenly mansion.🔽“When I was reborn in the deva world,

original: “Upapannassa devattaṃ, byamhaṃ āsi sunimmitaṃ;
analyzed: upapannassa devattam byamham āsi su nimmitam
translated: I was radiant,

original: Samantato pajjalati, dīpadānassidaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: samantataḥ pajjalati dīpa dānaḥ idam phalam
translated: Shining all around, the result of giving a lamp.

original: “Samantā yojanasataṃ, virocesimahaṃ tadā;
analyzed: samantā yojana satam virocesim aham tadā
translated: “I shone all around for a hundred leagues,

analyzed: sabbe deve abhibhomi dīpa dānassa idam phalam
translated: I surpassed all the devas, the result of giving a lamp.

analyzed: tiṃsa kappāni devindaḥ deva rajjam akārayim
translated: “For thirty eons I was Sakka, king of the devas,

analyzed: na mam keci iti maññanti dīpa dānassa idam phalam

translated: “Twenty-eight times I was a wheel-turning monarch,

analyzed: divā rattim ca passāmi samantā yojanam tadā
translated: And I saw all around for a league, both by day and by night.

translated: “In the dispensation of the Teacher, I saw a thousand worlds with my knowledge,

analyzed: dibba cakkhum anuppatto dīpa dānassa idam phalam
translated: And I attained the deva eye, the result of giving a lamp.🔽“The Fully Enlightened One named Sumedha,

analyzed: sumedhaḥ nāma sambuddhaḥ tiṃsa kappa sahassitaḥ
translated: after thirty thousand eons,

analyzed: tassa dīpaḥ mayā dinnaḥ vippasannena cetasā

original: “Paṭisambhidā catasso…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.

analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇe sarūpataḥ dassetum rūpā saddā tiādi vuttam tattha manoramā ti lobhanīya ṭṭhena  manam ramayanti iti manoramā manāpiyā iti vuttam hoti yathā āha katame pañca manāpiyā

original: Vicinīti esantova tattha tattha saṅkārakūṭādike paṃsukūluppattiṭṭhāne vicini. Aggahīti
analyzed: vicini iti tattha tattha saṅkārakūṭa ādike paṃsukūla uppatti ṭhāne vicini aggahi iti
translated: He searched: while seeking, he searched in places where rags were likely to be found, such as in a charnel ground, a midden, etc.🔽He took: without being disgusted, he took it even if it was stained with blood.

original: vicinitvā asucimakkhitampi ajigucchanto gaṇhi. Dhovīti, vikkhālesi. Rajayīti dhovitvā
analyzed: vicinitvā asuci makkhitam pi a jigucchantaḥ gaṇhi dhovi iti vikkhālesi rajayi iti dhovitvā
translated: He washed: he washed it.🔽He dyed: after washing it, he dyed it with a suitable dye.

original: gahitaṃ sibbitvā kappiyarajanena rajayi. Dhārayīti rajitvā kappabinduṃ datvā dhāresi,🔽nivāsesi ceva pārupi ca.
analyzed: gahitam sibbitvā kappiya rajanena rajayi dhārayi iti rajitvā kappa bindum da tvā dhāresi  ca iva ca
translated: He wore: after dyeing it, he gave it a suitable beating and then wore it, that is, he put it on.

original: Idāni pācīnavaṃsadāye satthārā dinnaovādaṃ tassa ca attanā matthakappattabhāvaṃ dīpento🔽“mahiccho ca asantuṭṭho”tiādikā gāthā abhāsi. Tattha mahicchoti mahatiyā paccayicchāya
analyzed: idāni pācīna vaṃsa dāye satthārā dinna ovādam tassa ca attanā matthaka ppatta bhāvam dīpento  mahiccho ca asantuṭṭhaḥ ti ādikā gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha mahiccho ti mahatiyā paccayicchāya
translated: Now, in order to show the instruction given by the Teacher to Pācīnavaṁsa and how he himself reached the peak of perfection,🔽he recited the following stanzas, beginning with:🔽“He who is greedy and discontented” . Herein, greedy means

original: samannāgato, uḷāruḷāre bahū ca paccaye icchantoti attho. Asantuṭṭhoti nissantuṭṭho,
analyzed: samannāgataḥ uḷāra uḷāre bahū ca paccaye icchanto ti attho asantuṭṭho ti nissantuṭṭhaḥ
translated: endowed with a great desire for requisites; the meaning is, desiring many requisites, superior and inferior. Discontented means dissatisfied,🔽devoid of contentment such as being satisfied with whatever is obtained. Associating means

original: yathālābhasantosādinā santosena virahito. Saṃsaṭṭhoti gihīhi ceva pabbajitehi ca
analyzed: yathā lābha santosa ādinā santosena virahito saṃsaṭṭho ti gihīhi ca iva pabbajitehi ca
translated: associating with householders and those gone forth.

original: ananulomikena saṃsaggena saṃsaṭṭho. Uddhatoti ukkhitto. Tassāti “mahiccho”tiādinā🔽vuttapuggalassa. Dhammāti mahicchatā asantoso, saṃsaṭṭhatā vikkhepoti īdisā. Lāmakaṭṭhena
analyzed: ananulomikena saṃsaggena saṃsaṭṭhaḥ uddhataḥ ti ukkhittaḥ tassa ti mahiccho ti ādinā  vutta puggalassa dhammā ati mahiccha tā asantosaḥ saṃsaṭṭha tā vikkhepo ti īdisā lāmaka ṭṭhena
translated: He is mixed up with the unbeneficial. He is excited: he is elated. His: of the person described in the way beginning “with great desires” .🔽Ideas: great desires are discontent, being mixed up is distraction.

original: pāpakā. Saṃkilesikāti tassa cittassa malīnabhāvakaraṇato saṃkilesikā dhammā honti.
analyzed: pāpakā saṃkilesikā ti tassa cittassa malīna bhāva karaṇataḥ saṃkilesikāḥ dhammāḥ honti
translated: They are bad because they are blameworthy. They are corrupters: they are corrupters of that cognizance because they cause it to be stained.

original: Sato ca hoti appicchoti yadā panāyaṃ puggalo kalyāṇamitte sevanto bhajanto payirupāsanto
analyzed: sataḥ ca hoti appiccho ti yadā pana ayam puggalo kalyāṇa mitte sevantaḥ bhajantaḥ payis upāsantaḥ
translated: And he is mindful and has few desires: but when this person is associating with, attending on, and honouring good friends,

original: saddhammaṃ suṇanto yoniso manasi karonto satimā ca mahicchataṃ pahāya appiccho ca
analyzed: saddhammam suṇantaḥ yonisas manasi karontaḥ satimā ca mahicchatam pahāya appiccho ca
translated: and when he is hearing the good Dhamma and giving attention to it wisely, then he is mindful and, having abandoned great desires, he has few desires,

original: hoti. Asantosaṃ pahāya santuṭṭho, cittassa vighātakaraṃ vikkhepaṃ pahāya avighātavā🔽avikkhitto samāhito, gaṇasaṅgaṇikaṃ pahāya pavivekarato, vivekābhiratiyā nibbidāya
analyzed: hoti a santosam pahāya santuṭṭhaḥ cittassa vighāta karam vikkhepam pahāya a vighātavā  a vikkhittaḥ samāhitaḥ gaṇa saṅgaṇikam pahāya pa viveka rataḥ viveka abhiratiyā nibbidāya
translated: having abandoned discontent he is content, having abandoned the distraction that is a hindrance to cognizance he is unhindered,🔽undistracted, concentrated, having abandoned society he is fond of solitude, and he is devoted to the idea of dispassion,

original: dhammapītiyā vitto sumano tuṭṭhacitto, sabbaso kosajjapahānena āraddhavīriyo.
analyzed: dhamma pītiyā vittaḥ sumanaḥ tuṭṭha citto sabbaso kosajja pahānena āraddha vīriyo
translated: to the idea of fading away of lust, to the idea of cessation, to the idea of relinquishment. He is gladdened, pleased, and delighted with the idea of bliss, and he is energetic with the abandonment of all slackness.

original: Tassa evaṃ appicchatādiguṇasamannāgatassa ime satipaṭṭhānādayo sattatiṃsappabhedā
analyzed: tassa evam appiccha tā ādi guṇa samannāgatassa ime sati paṭṭhāna ādayo sattatiṃsa ppabhedā
translated: And for him who is endowed with the qualities of fewness of wishes, etc., these foundations of mindfulness, etc., which are of seventy-three kinds,

original: tividhavipassanāsaṅgahā kosallasambhūtaṭṭhena kusalā, maggapariyāpannā bodhipakkhikā
analyzed: tividha vipassanā saṅgahā kosalla sambhūta ṭṭhena kusalā magga pariyāpannā bodhi pakkhikā
translated: are profitable in the sense of being the source of skill in the sense of being included in the three kinds of clear-vision . They are states that are conascent with the path and are called “states that are enlightenment factors”

original: dhammā honti. So tehi samannāgato sabbaso āsavānaṃ khepanena aggamaggakkhaṇato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: dhammāḥ honti so tehi samannāgataḥ sabbaso āsavānaṃ khepanena agga magga kkhaṇataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: and “states that are path factors.” He who is endowed with them is also “without taints” in the sense of the exhaustion of all taints from the moment of the path onwards.

original: anāsavo ca hoti. Iti evaṃ vuttaṃ mahesinā sammāsambuddhena pācīnavaṃsadāye mahāpurisavitakke🔽matthakaṃ pāpanavasenāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: anāsavaḥ ca hoti iti evam vuttam mahesinā sammāsambuddhena pācīna vaṃsa dāye mahāpurisavitakke  matthakam pāpana vasena āti adhippāyaḥ
translated: So the purport of the Great Man’s utterance, which was made in the Eastern Bamboo Grove to the Elder Ānanda, is this: “The foundations of mindfulness, etc., are profitable, and so on.”

original: Mama saṅkappamaññāyāti “apicchassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo mahicchassā”tiādinā
analyzed: mama saṅkappam aññāya ati apicchassa ayam bhikkhave dhammo na ayam dhammo mahicchassa ātiādinā
translated: “Knowing my thought”: knowing my thought, which was aroused by the Great Man’s utterance in the words, “Monks, this Dhamma is for one of fewness of wishes, not for one of many wishes” , etc.,

original: mahāpurisavitakkavasena āraddhaṃ, te ca matthakaṃ pāpetuṃ asamatthabhāvena ṭhitaṃ
analyzed: mahā purisa vitakka vasena āraddham te ca matthakam pāpetum asamattha bhāvena ṭhitam
translated: and which remained in the form of a wish that could not be fulfilled.

original: mama saṅkappaṃ jānitvā. Manomayenāti manomayena viya, manasā nimmitasadisena pariṇāmitenāti
analyzed: mama saṅkappam jānitvā manaḥ mayena ati manaḥ mayena viya manasā nimmita sadisena pariṇāmitena ati
translated: “With a mind-made body”: with a body made of mind, as though made of mind, as though fashioned by mind.

original: attho. Iddhiyāti “ayaṃ kāyo idaṃ cittaṃ viya hotū”ti evaṃ pavattaadhiṭṭhāniddhiyā.
analyzed: attho iddhiyā ti ayam kāyaḥ idam cittam viya hotu uti evam pavatta adhiṭṭhāna iddhiyā
translated: ‘Meaning’: by psychic potency.

original: Yadā me ahu saṅkappoti yasmiṃ kāle mayhaṃ “kīdiso nu kho aṭṭhamo mahāpurisavitakko”ti
analyzed: yadā me ahu saṅkappo ti yasmin kāle mayham kīdisaḥ nu kho aṭṭhamaḥ mahā purisa vitakko ti
translated: ‘When I had this thought’: at the time when I had this thought, ‘What is the eighth great man’s thought like?’

original: parivitakko ahosi. Tato mama saṅkappamaññāya iddhiyā upasaṅkamīti yojanā. Uttari
analyzed: parivitakkaḥ ahosi tatas mama saṅkappa maññāya iddhiyā upasaṅkami iti yojanā uttari
translated: ‘Then, knowing my thought’: the construction is that he came by psychic potency.

original: desayīti “nippapañcārāmassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo nippapañcaratino, nāyaṃdhammo papañcārāmassa
analyzed: desayīti nippapañca ārāmassa ayam bhikkhave dhammaḥ nippapañca ratino na ayam dhammaḥ papañca ārāmassa
translated: ‘He taught me further’: ‘Monks, this state of things is for one who delights in non- proliferation, who has non-proliferation as his practice, not for one who delights in proliferation, who has proliferation as his practice.’🔽While fulfilling this eighth great man’s thought, he taught me further.

original: papañcaratino”ti imamaṭṭhamaṃ mahāpurisavitakkaṃ pūrento upari desayi. Taṃ pana desitaṃ
analyzed: imam aṭṭhamam mahāpurisa vitakkam pūrentaḥ upari tam pana desitam
translated: But when he taught this state of things, he said:🔽‘The Enlightened One, who delights in non-proliferation,🔽taught the state of non-proliferation.’

original: dhammaṃ desento āha “nippapañcarato buddho, nippapañcamadesayī”ti. Papañcā nāma rāgādayo
analyzed: dhammam desentaḥ āha nippapañca rataḥ buddhaḥ nippapañcam adesayi iti papañcāḥ nāma rāga ādayaḥ
translated: Proliferation is defilements such as lust, etc.,

original: kilesā, tesaṃ vūpasamatāya, tadabhāvato ca lokuttaradhammā nippapañcā nāma. Tasmiṃ
analyzed: kilesā tesam vūpasama tāya tad abhāvato ca lokuttara dhammā nippapañcāḥ nāma tasmin
translated: and because of the stilling of these and their absence, the supramundane states are called ‘non-proliferation.’

original: nippapañce rato abhirato sammāsambuddho yathā taṃ pāpuṇāmi, tathā tādisaṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: nippapañce rataḥ abhirataḥ sammāsambuddhaḥ yathā tam pāpuṇāmi tathā tādisam dhammaṃ
translated: The Fully Enlightened One delights in, takes delight in, that non-proliferation,

original: adesayi, sāmukkaṃsikaṃ catusaccadhammadesanaṃ pakāsayīti attho.
analyzed: adesayi sāmukkaṃsikam catu sacca dhamma desanam pakāsayi iti attho
translated: He taught, he made clear the Dhamma of the Four Noble Truths in its entirety.

original: Tassāhaṃ dhammamaññāyāti tassā satthu desanāya dhammaṃ jānitvā yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjanto vihāsiṃ sikkhattayasaṅgahe sāsane rato abhirato hutvāti attho.
analyzed: tassa aham dhammam aññāya ati tassā satthu desanāya dhammam jānitvā yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjantaḥ vihāsim sikkhattaya saṅgahe sāsane rataḥ abhirataḥ hutvā ati attho
translated: I understood the Dhamma of that Teacher: the meaning is, I lived delighting in, devoted to, the Dispensation consisting of the Three Rounds of Training, having understood the Dhamma of that Teacher’s teaching by practising in accordance with the advice.

original: Satthārā attano samāgamaṃ tena sādhitamatthaṃ dassetvā idāni attano pabbajitakālato
analyzed: satthārā attano samāgamam tena sādhitam attham dassetvā idāni attano pabbajita kālataḥ
translated: Having shown by himself the Blessed One’s attainment of his goal by his own meeting with the Teacher, now, from the time of his own going forth,

original: paṭṭhāya āraddhavīriyataṃ, kāye anapekkhatāya seyyasukhapassasukhānaṃ pariccāgaṃ,
analyzed: paṭṭhāya āraddha vīriya tam kāye an apekkha tāya seyya sukha passa sukhānam pariccāgam
translated: he shows his own exertion, his relinquishment of the pleasure of lying down and the pleasure of drowsiness through his disregard for the body,

analyzed: appamiddha kālataḥ paṭṭhāya āraddha vīriya tañca dassento pañca paññāsa vassāni iti gātham āha
translated: and his exertion from the time of his being free from drowsiness, in the stanza ‘For fifty-five years’.

original: Tattha yato nesajjiko ahanti yato paṭṭhāya “yogānukūlatā kammaṭṭhānapariyuṭṭhitasappurisacariyā
analyzed: tattha yatas nesajjikaḥ ahanti yatas paṭṭhāya yoga anukūla tā kammaṭṭhāna pariyuṭṭhita sappurisa cariyā
translated: Herein, from the time when I was a non-recliner: from the time when, having seen the advantages of the non-reclining posture in this way, ‘It is favourable to energy, it is a human being’s proper conduct when he is devoted to a meditation subject,

original: sallekhavuttī”ti evamādiguṇe disvā nesajjiko ahosiṃ tāni pañcapaññāsa vassāni. Yato
analyzed: sallekha vutti iti evamādi guṇe disvā nesajjikaḥ ahosim tāni pañca paññāsa vassāni yatas
translated: it is a way of dwelling that inspires full confidence ‘, I was a non-recliner for those fifty-five years.

original: middhaṃ samūhatanti yato paṭṭhāya mayā niddā pariccattā tāni pañcavīsativassāni.
analyzed: middham yatas paṭṭhāya mayā niddā pariccattā tāni pañcavīsati vassāni
translated: “I have overcome drowsiness” means: from the time I have renounced sleep.

original: “Therassa pañcapaññāsāya vassesu nesajjikassa sato ādito pañcavīsativassāni niddā
analyzed: therassa vassesu nesajjikassa sataḥ āditas pañcavīsati vassāni niddā
translated: “In the Elder’s fifty-five years of standing, being mindful, from the beginning for twenty-five years sleep

original: nāhosi, tato paraṃ sarīrakilamathena pacchimayāme niddā ahosī”ti vadanti.
analyzed: tato param sarīra kilamathena pacchima yāme niddā ahosi iti vadanti
translated: did not exist. After that, because of the weariness of the body, in the last watch of the night sleep did exist.”

original: “Nāhu assāsapassāsā” tiādikā tisso gāthā satthu parinibbānakāle bhikkhūhi “kiṃ bhagavā
analyzed: na ahu assāsa passāsā ti ādikā tissaḥ gāthā satthu parinibbāna kāle bhikkhūhi kim bhagavā
translated: “There were no in-breaths and out-breaths” and so forth, the three verses, were spoken by the Elder Ānanda when the monks asked him: “Did the Fortunate One

analyzed: parinibbutaḥ iti puṭṭhaḥ parinibbāna bhāvam pavedentaḥ āha tattha na āhu assāsa passāsā
translated: enter Nibbāna?” and he announced the state of Nibbāna. Therein, “There were no in-breaths and out-breaths,

analyzed: ṭhita cittassa tādinaḥ ti anuloma paṭilomataḥ aneka ākāra vokārā sabbā samāpattiyaḥ samāpajjitvā

analyzed: vuṭṭhāya sabba pacchā catuttha jjhāne ṭhita cittassa tādinaḥ buddhassa bhagavato assāsa passāsā
translated: and after emerging, the one with a mind that is standing in the last of all the fourth jhānas, the one who is steadfast, the Buddha, the Fortunate One,🔽there were no in-breaths and out-breaths,

original: nāhu nāhesunti attho. Etena yasmā catutthajjhānaṃ samāpannassa kāyasaṅkhārā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: na ahu na ahesun ti atthaḥ etena yasmā catuttha jhānam samāpannassa kāya saṅkhārāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: this is the meaning. By this (it is shown that) because the in-breaths and out-breaths cease for one who has entered the fourth jhāna,

analyzed: kāya saṅkhārā ti ca assāsa passāsāḥ vuccanti tasmā catuttha jhāna kkhaṇato paṭṭhāya assāsa passāsāḥ  na ahesun ti dasseti taṇhā saṅkhātāya ejāya abhāvataḥ anejaḥ samādhismim ṭhita ttā vā
translated: “Without agitation”: he is without agitation because of the absence of craving called “agitation” , or he is without agitation because he is steadied in concentration.

original: anejo. Santimārabbhāti anupādisesaṃ nibbānaṃ ārabbha paṭicca sandhāya. Cakkhumāti
analyzed: anejaḥ santim ārabbha ati anupādisesam nibbānam ārabbha paṭicca sandhāya cakkhumā ti
translated: “With reference to calm”: with reference to, depending on, the Nibbāna-element without residue left.🔽“With the eye”: he is “with the eye” because of the five eyes.

original: pañcahi cakkhūhi cakkhumā. Parinibbutoti parinibbāyi. Ayañhettha attho – nibbānārammaṇacatutthajjhānaphalasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: pañcahi cakkhūhi cakkhumā parinibbutaḥ ti parinibbāyi ayam ha ittha atthaḥ nibbāna ārammaṇa catuttha jhāna phala samāpattim
translated: “He has attained complete extinction”: he has attained complete Nibbāna. This is the meaning here: he has attained the fourth jhana, which is the attainment of the fruit of arahantship, with Nibbāna as its object,

original: samāpajjitvā tadanantarameva anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbutoti.
analyzed: samāpajjitvā tad anantaram eva anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbutaḥ ti
translated: and immediately afterwards he has attained complete Nibbāna in the Nibbāna element without residue left.

original: Asallīnenāti alīnena asaṃkuṭitena suvikasiteneva cittena. Vedanaṃ ajjhavāsayīti sato
analyzed: a sat līnena ati a līnena a saṃkuṭitena su vikasitena iva cittena vedanam ajjhavāsayi iti sato
translated: “Without wavering”: with a mind that is not wavering, not contracted, but well expanded.

analyzed: sampajānaḥ hutvā māraṇa antikam vedanam adhivāsesi na vedanā anuvattī hutvā itas citas
