analyzed: ca samparivatti pajjotassa iva nibbānam vimokkhaḥ cetasaḥ ahūti yathā telam ca paṭicca
translated: “His mind was liberated”: his mind was liberated from the aggregates.🔽“His mind was liberated”: his mind was liberated from the sense bases.🔽“His mind was liberated”: his mind was liberated from the world.🔽“His mind was liberated”: his mind was liberated from existence.🔽“His mind was liberated”: his mind was liberated from suffering.🔽“His mind was liberated”: his mind was liberated from the round.🔽“His mind was liberated”: his mind was liberated from the root-cause of the round.🔽“His mind was liberated”: his mind was liberated from the root-cause of suffering.🔽“His mind was liberated”: his mind was liberated from the root-cause of the round and of suffering.🔽“His mind was liberated”: his mind was liberated from the root-cause of the round and of suffering.🔽“His mind was liberated”: his mind was liberated from the root-cause of the round and of suffering.🔽“His mind was liberated”: his mind was liberated from the

original: vaṭṭiñca paṭicca pajjalanto pajjoto padīpo tesaṃ parikkhaye nibbāyati. Nibbuto ca
analyzed: vaṭṭiñca paṭicca pajjalantaḥ pajjoto padīpo tesam parikkhaye nibbāyati nibbutaḥ ca
translated: and the flame of the lamp is extinguished when the wick and the oil are used up. And when it is extinguished

original: katthaci gantvā na tiṭṭhati, aññadatthu antaradhāyati, adassanameva gacchati; evaṃ
analyzed: katthaci gantvā na tiṭṭhati aññadatthu antaradhāyati a dassanam eva gacchati evam
translated: it does not go anywhere, it simply disappears, is not seen. So too,

original: kilesābhisaṅkhāre nissāya pavattamāno khandhasantāno tesaṃ parikkhaye nibbāyati,
analyzed: kilesa abhisaṅkhāre nissāya pavattamāno khandha santāno tesam parikkhaye nibbāyati
translated: the continuum of aggregates that occurs in dependence on defilements and determinations is extinguished when they are used up.

original: nibbuto ca katthaci gantvā na tiṭṭhati, aññadatthu antaradhāyati, adassanameva gacchatīti
analyzed: nibbutaḥ ca katthaci gantvā na tiṭṭhati añña datthu antaradhāyati a dassanam eva gacchati iti
translated: And when it is extinguished it does not go anywhere, it simply disappears, is not seen.

original: dasseti. Tena vuttaṃ “nibbanti dhīrā yathāyaṃ padīpo”ti, “accī yathā vātavegena khittā”ti ca ādi.
analyzed: dassa iti tena vuttam nibbanti dhīrāḥ yathā ayam accī yathā vāta vegena khittā iti ca ādi
translated: This is what is shown. Hence it was said above, “The wise man’s quenched as is the lamp” and “As when a lamp is blown out” , etc.

original: Eteti parinibbānakkhaṇe satthu santāne pavattamānānaṃ dhammānaṃ attano paccakkhatāya
analyzed: ete ti parinibbāna khaṇe satthu santāne pavattamānānam dhammānam attanaḥ paccakkha tāya
translated: “These” : this is said with reference to the dhammas occurring in the Master’s continuum at the moment of his parinibbāna.

original: vuttaṃ. Pacchimakā tato paraṃ cittuppādābhāvato. Dānīti etarahi. Phassapañcamāti
analyzed: vuttam pacchimakā tatas param cittuppāda abhāvataḥ dāni iti etarahi phassa pañcamā ti
translated: “The last” : after that there is no further arising of consciousness.🔽“Now” : at present.

original: phassapañcamakānaṃ dhammānaṃ pākaṭabhāvato vuttaṃ. Tathā hi cittuppādakathāyampi
analyzed: phassa pañcamakānam dhammānam pākaṭa bhāvataḥ vuttam tathā hi cittuppāda kathāyam pi
translated: “With contact as fifth” : this is said because the dhammas with contact as fifth are evident. For in the discussion of the arising of consciousness

original: phassapañcamakāva ādito vuttā. Aññe dhammāti saha nissayena aññe cittacetasikā dhammā,
analyzed: āditas vuttāḥ aññe dhammā ti saha nissayena aññe citta cetasikāḥ dhammā
translated: The five beginning with contact are mentioned first. Other states: other states of consciousness and its concomitants together with their concomitants.

original: na parinibbānacittacetasikā. Nanu tepi na bhavissantevāti? Saccaṃ na bhavissanti,🔽āsaṅkābhāvato pana te sandhāya “na bhavissantī”ti na vattabbameva. “Itare pana sekkhaputhujjanānaṃ
analyzed: na parinibbāna citta cetasikāḥ nanu te pi na bhavissanti iva ati saccam na bhavissanti  āsaṅka abhāvataḥ pana te sandhāya na bhavissanti iti na vattabbam eva itare pana sekkha puthujjanānam
translated: Not the states of consciousness and its concomitants at the time of attaining Nibbāna. But won’t they also not come to be? It is true that they will not come to be,

original: viya bhavissanti nu kho”ti siyā āsaṅkāti tadāsaṅkānivattanatthaṃ “nāññe dhammā bhavissantī”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Natthi dāni punāvāso, devakāyasmi jālinīti, ettha jālinīti devataṃ ālapati, devate
analyzed: viya bhavissanti nu kho ti siyā āsaṅkā ati tad āsaṅkā nivattana attham na aññe dhammā bhavissanti iti vuttam  natthi dāni jālinī iti ettha jālinī iti devatam ālapati devate
translated: but because there is no doubt about them, it is not proper to say “they will not come to be” with reference to them. But with reference to the other states of consciousness and its concomitants, it might be doubted whether they will come to be or not, as in the case of those of the trainee and the worldling. Therefore, in order to remove that doubt, it is said: “Other states will not come to be.”🔽There is no more dwelling for me in the womb, O Goddess,

original: devakāyasmiṃ devasamūhe upapajjanavasena puna āvāso āvasanaṃ idāni mayhaṃ natthīti
analyzed: deva kāyasmim deva samūhe upapajjana vasena punar āvāsaḥ āvasanam idāni mayham na atthi iti
translated: Here the goddess is addressed with the vocative “O Goddess.” The meaning is: “There is no more dwelling, no more living for me in the womb by way of rebirth in the womb of a goddess, in the group of gods, in the multitude of gods.”

original: attho. Tattha kāraṇamāha “vikkhīṇo”tiādinā. Sā kira devatā purimattabhāve therassa
analyzed: tattha kāraṇam āha vikkhīṇa iti ādinā sā kira devatā purimatta bhāve therassa
translated: Here the reason is given: “My defilements are destroyed.” It is said that in a previous existence this goddess was the mother of the Elder.

original: pādaparicārikā, tasmā idāni theraṃ jiṇṇaṃ vuddhaṃ disvā purimasinehena āgantvā “tattha
analyzed: pāda paricārikā tasmai idāni theram jiṇṇam vuddham disvā purima sinehena āgantvā tattha
translated: and she had been his attendant. Now, seeing the Elder as an aged man, she remembered her former affection, and she came and asked him for a rebirth in the deva-world, saying, “Make a wish for that place where you dwelt in former times.”

original: cittaṃ paṇidhehi, yattha te vusitaṃ pure”ti devūpapattiṃ yāci. Atha “dāni natthī”tiādinā
analyzed: cittam paṇidhehi yattha te vusitam purā iti deva upapattim yāci atha dāni natthi itiādinā
translated: Then the Elder replied, “Now there is none,” etc.

original: thero tassā paṭivacanaṃ adāsi. Taṃ sutvā devatā vihatāsā tatthevantaradhāyi.🔽Atha thero vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā attano ānubhāvaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ pakāsento “yassa🔽muhuttenā”ti gāthamāha. Tassattho – yassa khīṇāsavabhikkhuno muhuttamattena eva sahassadhā🔽sahassappakāro tisahassimahāsahassipabhedo, loko sabrahmakappo sahabrahmaloko, saṃvidito
analyzed: thero tassā paṭivacanam adāsi tam sutvā devatā tattha iva antaradhāyi  atha theraḥ vehāsam abbhut gantvā attanaḥ ānubhāvam sabrahmacārīnam pakāsentaḥ yassa  muhuttena iti gātham āha tassa atthaḥ yassa khīṇāsava bhikkhunaḥ muhutta mattena eva sahassadhā  sahassa ppakāraḥ ti sahassi mahā sahassi pabhedaḥ lokaḥ sa brahmakappaḥ saha brahma lokaḥ saṃviditaḥ
translated: When the deva heard this, she was disappointed and vanished on the spot.

original: sammadeva vidito ñāto paccakkhaṃ kato, evaṃ iddhiguṇe iddhisampadāya cutūpapāte ca🔽vasībhāvappatto so bhikkhu upagatakāle devatā passati, na tassa devatānaṃ dassane
analyzed: sammat eva viditaḥ ñātaḥ paccakkham kato evam iddhi guṇe iddhi sampadāya cutūpapāte ca 🔽vasībhāva ppatto so bhikkhu upagata kāle devatāḥ passati na tassa devatānam dassane
translated: Then the Elder rose up into the air and, in order to show his own power to his fellows in the life of purity, he uttered the stanza, “In a moment,” etc. The meaning is as follows: In a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, the world with its gods, its Maras, and its Brahmas, the world with its ascetics and Brahmans, with its gods and men, the thousand-fold world system, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand moons and suns and thousand worlds of the Rose Apple and of the Outlying Regions, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Oceans and thousand Great Earth Masses, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Iron Rail-Fences, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Mount Kailasas, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great World-Systems of the Four Dhyanas, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmā Abodes, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas of Radiant Eternity, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas of Limited Radiance, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas of Immeasurable Radiance, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas of Streaming Radiance, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas of Glory, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas of Limited Splendor, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas of Immeasurable Splendor, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas of Refulgent Splendor, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas of Great Fruit, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas of Streaming Radiance, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas of Great Fruit, the thousand-fold world system with its thousand Great Brahmas of Non-percipient Devas, the thousand-fold world system

original: parihānīti. Therena kira jāliniyā devatāya paṭivacanadānavasena “natthi dānī”ti gāthāya
analyzed: therena kira jāliniyā devatāya paṭivacana dāna vasena natthi dāni iti gāthāya
translated: “Loss” . The Elder, it seems, had said the verse, “Now there is none” , in reply to a question asked by the deity Jālini.

original: vuttāya bhikkhū jāliniṃ apassantā “kiṃ nu kho thero dhammālapanavasena kiñci ālapatī”ti
analyzed: vuttāya bhikkhū jālinim a passantā kim nu kho theraḥ dhamma ālapana vasena kiñci ālapati iti
translated: When the bhikkhus did not see Jālini, they thought, “What is the Elder talking about? Is he talking about something by way of a Dhamma talk?”

original: cintesuṃ. Tesaṃ cittācāraṃ ñatvā thero “yassa muhuttenā”ti imaṃ gāthamāha.🔽Annabhāro pureti evaṃnāmo purimattabhāve. Ghāsahārakoti ghāsamattassa atthāya bhattiṃ🔽katvā jīvanako. Samaṇanti samitapāpaṃ. Paṭipādesinti paṭimukho hutvā pādāsiṃ, pasādena
analyzed: cintesum tesam citta ācāram ñatvā theraḥ yassa muhuttena ati imam gātham āha  anna bhāraḥ purā iti evaṃnāmaḥ purimatta bhāve ghāsa hārakaḥ iti ghāsa mattassa atthāya bhattim  katvā jīvanakaḥ samaṇanti samita pāpam paṭipādesinti paṭimukhaḥ hutvā pādāsim pasādena
translated: When the Elder knew their thoughts, he spoke this verse, “He who in a moment.”🔽“Annabhāra in the past” : one who had that name in a previous existence. “A grass-bearer” : one who made a living by cutting grass for the sake of mere food.🔽“Ascetic” : one who has destroyed evil. “I served” : the intention is that he served by giving food with confidence, by facing him.

original: abhimukho hutvā āhāradānaṃ adāsinti adhippāyo. Upariṭṭhanti evaṃnāmakaṃ paccekabuddhaṃ.
analyzed: abhimukhaḥ hutvā āhāra dānam adāsinti adhippāyaḥ upariṭṭhanti evaṃnāmakam paccekabuddham
translated: “Upariṭṭha” : a paccekabuddha of that name.

original: Yasassinanti kittimantaṃ patthaṭayasaṃ. Imāya gāthāya yāva carimattabhāvā uḷārasampattihetubhūtaṃ
analyzed: kittimantam patthaṭa yasam imāya gāthāya uḷāra sampatti hetu bhūtam
translated: “Yasassin” : one who was famous, one whose fame was spread about. By this verse he shows his own previous kamma, which was the cause for his great prosperity up to his last existence.

original: attano pubbakammaṃ dasseti. Tenāha “somhi sakyakule jāto”tiādi.
analyzed: attanaḥ pubba kammam dasseti tena āha somhi sakya kule jātaḥ itiādi
translated: Therefore he said, “I was born in the Sakyan clan” and so on.

original: Ito sattāti ito manussalokato cavitvā devaloke dibbena ādhipaccena satta. Tato sattāti
analyzed: itas satta ati itas manussa lokataḥ cavitvā deva loke dibbena ādhipaccena satta tatas satta ati
translated: From here seven times: having passed away from here, from the human world, seven times in the deva world with divine lordship. From there seven times:

original: tato devalokato cavitvā manussaloke cakkavattibhāvena satta. Saṃsārāni catuddasāti
analyzed: tatas deva lokataḥ cavitvā manussa loke cakkavatti bhāvena satta saṃsārāni catuddasāti
translated: having passed away from there, from the deva world, seven times in the human world with universal sovereignty. I will know fourteen births:

original: catuddasa bhavantarasaṃsaraṇāni. Nivāsamabhijānissanti pubbenivāsaṃ aññāsiṃ. Devaloke🔽ṭhito tadāti tañca kho na imasmiṃyeva attabhāve, api ca kho yadā ito anantarātīte
analyzed: catuddasa bhavantara saṃsaraṇāni nivāsam abhijānissanti pubbenivāsam aññāsim deva loke  tat ca na imasmin yeva atta bhāve api ca kho yadā itas anantara atīte
translated: I will know fourteen transmigrations in the various realms of existence. I remember my past lives: I knew my past lives.🔽Standing in the deva world: standing in the deva world, not in this very existence, but rather in the existence immediately preceding this one.

original: attabhāve devaloke ṭhito, tadā aññāsinti attho.🔽Idāni attanā dibbacakkhuñāṇacutūpapātañāṇānaṃ adhigatākāraṃ dassento “pañcaṅgike”tiādinā
analyzed: attabhāve deva loke ṭhitaḥ tadā aññāsin ti attho  idāni attanā dibba cakkhu ñāṇa cutūpapāta ñāṇānaṃ adhigata ākāram dassento pañcaṅgika iti ādinā
translated: Then I knew: this is the meaning.🔽Now, showing the mode of his own attainment of the knowledge of the divine eye and of death and rebirth, he spoke the two verses beginning with “In the five-factored concentration.”

original: dve gāthā abhāsi. Tattha pañcaṅgike samādhimhīti abhiññāpādakacatutthajjhānasamādhimhi.
analyzed: dve gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha pañcaṅgike samādhimhi iti abhiññā pādaka catuttha jhāna samādhimhi
translated: Therein, in the five-factored concentration: in the concentration of the fourth jhāna, which is the basis for direct knowledge.

original: So hi pītipharaṇatā, sukhapharaṇatā, cetopharaṇatā, ālokapharaṇatā, paccavekkhaṇanimittanti
analyzed: saḥ hi pīti pharaṇa tā sukha pharaṇa tā cetaḥ pharaṇa tā āloka pharaṇa tā paccavekkhaṇa nimittan ti
translated: For that is the pervasion of happiness, the pervasion of pleasure, the pervasion of mind, the pervasion of light, and the sign of review.

original: imehi pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgatattā pañcaṅgiko samādhīti vuccati. Santeti paṭipakkhavūpasamena
analyzed: imehi pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgata ttā pañcaṅgiko samādhi iti vuccati sante ti paṭipakkha vūpasamena
translated: Because he possesses these five factors, concentration is called “five- factored.” Tranquil: tranquil by the subsiding of its opposing states

original: aṅgasantatāya ca sante. Ekodibhāviteti ekodibhāvagate, suciṇṇe vasībhāvappatteti
analyzed: aṅga santatāya ca sante ekodi bhāvitā iti ekodi bhāva gate su ciṇṇe vasībhāva ppattā iti
translated: and by the continuity of its factors. Well concentrated: well attained, well reached, well developed, well penetrated.

original: attho. Paṭippassaddhiladdhamhīti kilesānaṃ paṭippassaddhiyā laddhe. Dibbacakkhu visujjhi
analyzed: attho paṭippassaddhi laddhamhi iti kilesānam paṭippassaddhiyā laddhe dibba cakkhu
translated: Having attained to perfect stillness: having attained to the stillness of defilements.

original: meti evaṃvidhe samādhimhi sampādite mayhaṃ dibbacakkhuñāṇaṃ visujjhi, ekādasahi upakkilesehi
analyzed: mā iti evaṃvidhe samādhimhi sampādite mayham dibba cakkhu ñāṇam visujjhi ekādasahi upakkilesehi
translated: My deva-eye: my knowledge of the deva-eye. Is purified: is purified from the eleven imperfections,

original: vimuttiyā visuddhaṃ ahosi.🔽Cutūpapātaṃ jānāmīti sattānaṃ cutiñca upapattiñca jānāmi, jānanto ca “ime sattā amumhā🔽lokamhā āgantvā idhūpapannā, imamhā ca lokā gantvā amumhi loke upapajjissantī”ti
analyzed: vimuttiyāḥ visuddham ahosi  cutūpapātam jānāmi iti sattānam cutiñca upapattiñca jānāmi jānantaḥ ca ime sattāḥ amumhā  lokamhā āgantvā idhu upapannāḥ imamhā ca lokāḥ gantvā amumhi loke upapajjissanti iti
translated: is liberated from the eleven imperfections.🔽I know how beings fare on: I know the passing away and reappearance of beings. Knowing this, I know that these beings who have come from such a world and reappeared here will go from this world and reappear there.

original: sattānaṃ āgatiṃ gatiñca jānāmi, jānanto eva ca nesaṃ itthabhāvaṃ manussabhāvaṃ tato
analyzed: sattānam āgatim gatiñca jānāmi jānantaḥ eva ca na isam itthabhāvam manussa bhāvam tatas
translated: I know the coming and going of beings. Knowing this, I know their state as female, their state as male, and their state as neither female nor male.

original: aññathābhāvaṃ aññathātiracchānabhāvañca upapattito puretarameva jānāmi. Tayidaṃ sabbampi
analyzed: aññathā bhāvam upapattitaḥ puretaram eva jānāmi tayidam sabbam pi
translated: I know that the state of being a human being is otherwise, and the state of being an animal is otherwise, even before they are born. All this

original: pañcaṅgike samādhimhi sampādite evāti dassento āha “jhāne pañcaṅgike ṭhito”ti. Tattha
analyzed: pañcaṅgike samādhimhi sampādite eva ati dassentaḥ āha jhāne pañcaṅgike ṭhitaḥ ti tattha
translated: I know, having attained the five-factored concentration. Showing this, he said: “Standing in the five-factored jhāna.” Herein,

original: pañcaṅgike jhāne ṭhito patiṭṭhito hutvā evaṃ jānāmīti attho.🔽Evaṃ vijjāttayaṃ dassetvā tappasaṅgena pubbe dassitampi tatiyavijjaṃ saha kiccanipphattiyā
analyzed: pañcaṅgike jhāne ṭhitaḥ patiṭṭhitaḥ hutvā evam jānāmi iti attho  evam vijja āttayam dassetvā tad pasaṅgena pubbe dassitam pi tatiya vijjam saha kicca nipphattiyā
translated: standing in the five-factored jhāna, having become established, thus I know.

original: dassento “pariciṇṇo mayā satthā”tiādinā gāthādvayamāha. Tattha vajjīnaṃ veḷuvagāmeti
analyzed: dassentaḥ pariciṇṇaḥ mayā satthā atiādinā gāthā dvayam āha tattha vajjīnam veḷuvagāmā iti
translated: Having thus shown the three kinds of knowledge, he said the two stanzas beginning with “The Teacher has been served by me,” showing the third kind of knowledge, which he had shown earlier in connection with that , together with the fulfilment of its function. Herein,🔽in the Veḷuva village of the Vajjis,

original: vajjiraṭṭhassa veḷuvagāme, vajjiraṭṭhe yattha pacchimavassaṃ upagacchi veḷuvagāme.🔽Heṭṭhato veḷugumbasminti tattha aññatarassa veḷugumbassa heṭṭhā. Nibbāyissanti nibbāyissāmi,
analyzed: vajjiraṭṭhassa veḷuvagāme vajjiraṭṭhe yattha pacchima vassam upagacchi veḷuvagāme  heṭṭhataḥ veḷugumbasmin ti tattha aññatarassa veḷugumbassa heṭṭhā nibbāyissanti nibbāyissāmi
translated: in the Veḷuva village of the Vajji country, where he entered upon the last rainy season, in the Veḷuva village.🔽Under the bamboo, below,

original: anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyissāmīti attho.
analyzed: anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyissāmi iti atthaḥ
translated: there I shall attain final Nibbāna, I shall attain final Nibbāna in the element of Nibbāna without residue of clinging remaining.

original: Anuruddhattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: anuruddha thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Anuruddha is finished.

original: 10. Pārāpariyattheragāthāvaṇṇanā🔽Samaṇassa ahu cintātiādikā āyasmato pārāpariyattherassa gāthā. Imassa vatthu heṭṭhā🔽āgatameva. Tā ca gāthā satthari dharante attano puthujjanakāle manacchaṭṭhānaṃ indriyānaṃ
analyzed: samaṇassa ahu cintā ati ādikā āyasmataḥ pārāpariya therassa gāthā imassa vatthu heṭṭhā  āgatam eva tāḥ ca gāthāḥ satthari dharante attano puthujjana kāle manaccha ṭṭhānam
translated: The verse of the elder Parāpariya,🔽“The thought occurred to the recluse, in the great wood in full flower;🔽As he sat alone, secluded, in jhāna” ,🔽was spoken by the elder Parāpariya. The story of this is given below .

original: niggaṇhanacintāya pakāsanavasena bhāsitā. Imā pana aparabhāge satthari parinibbute
analyzed: niggaṇhana cintāya pakāsana vasena bhāsitāḥ imāḥ pana apara bhāge satthari parinibbute
translated: And those verses were spoken by him in the time of the Teacher’s presence, in the way of proclaiming the thought of his own restraint of the six bases beginning with the mind, which was his as an ordinary man. But these were spoken by him later, after the Teacher’s final extinction,

original: attano ca parinibbāne upaṭṭhite tadā āyatiñca bhikkhūnaṃ uddhammapaṭipattiyā pakāsanavasena bhāsitā. Tattha –
analyzed: attano ca parinibbāne upaṭṭhite tadā āyatim ca bhikkhūnam uddhamma paṭipattiyā pakāsana vasena bhāsitā tattha
translated: when his own final extinction was imminent, in the way of proclaiming the higher practice for bhikkhus then and in the future. Herein,

original: “Samaṇassa ahu cintā, pupphitamhi mahāvane;
analyzed: samaṇassa ahu cintā pupphitamhi mahā vane
translated: “The thought occurred to the recluse, in the great wood in full flower;

original: Ekaggassa nisinnassa, pavivittassa jhāyino”ti. –
analyzed: ekaggassa nisinnassa pavivittassa jhāyinaḥ
translated: As he sat alone, secluded, in jhāna” ,

original: Ayaṃ gāthā saṅgītikārehi ṭhapitā. Tassattho heṭṭhā vuttanayova. Ayaṃ pana sambandho
analyzed: ayam gāthā saṅgīti kārehi ṭhapitā tassa atthaḥ heṭṭhā vutta nayaḥ eva ayam pana sambandho
translated: is a verse placed here by the compilers of the canon. Its meaning is the same as that given above. But the connection is this.

original: – satthari aggasāvakesu ekaccesu mahātheresu ca parinibbutesu atītasatthuke pāvacane
analyzed: satthari aggasāvakesu ekaccesu mahā theresu ca parinibbutesu atīta satthuke pāvacane
translated: After the Teacher’s final extinction and that of some of his chief disciples and some great elders,

original: subbacesu sikkhākāmesu bhikkhūsu dullabhesu, dubbacesu micchāpaṭipattibahulesu bhikkhūsu
analyzed: subbacesu sikkhā kāmesu bhikkhūsu dullabhesu dubbacesu micchā paṭipatti bahulesu bhikkhūsu
translated: in the monks who were hard to find, who were desirous of training, who were hard to please, who were many in wrong practice,

original: ca jātesu supupphite mahante sālavane nisinnassa pavivittassa ekaggassa jhāyanasīlassa,
analyzed: ca jātesu su pupphite mahante sāla vane nisinnassa pavivittassa ekaggassa jhāyana sīlassa
translated: while sitting in a great Sāla-wood, which was well-flowered, which was well-filled, which was secluded, which was solitary, which was suitable for meditation,

original: samitapāpatāya samaṇassa, pārāpariyattherassa paṭipattiṃ nissāya cintā vīmaṃsā ahosīti itarā –
analyzed: samita pāpa tāya samaṇassa pārāpariya therassa paṭipattim nissāya cintā vīmaṃsā ahosi iti itarā
translated: the thought and reflection arose in the other, the Elder Pārāpariya, through the practice of the ascetic who had destroyed his faults:

original: “Aññathā lokanāthamhi, tiṭṭhante purisuttame;
analyzed: aññathā lokanāthamhi tiṭṭhante purisuttame
translated: “In a different way it was for the monks, while the Lord of the World, the Supreme One, was standing,

original: Iriyaṃ āsi bhikkhūnaṃ, aññathā dāni dissati.
analyzed: iriyam āsi bhikkhūnam aññathā dāni dissati
translated: in a different way it is seen now.

original: “Sītavātaparittāṇaṃ, hirikopīnachādanaṃ;
analyzed: sīta vāta parittāṇam hiri kopīna chādanam
translated: “The protection from cold and wind, the covering of the robe of shame,

original: Mattaṭṭhiyaṃ abhuñjiṃsu, santuṭṭhā itarītare.
analyzed: mattaṭṭhiyam abhuñjiṃsu santuṭṭhāḥ itarītare
translated: they ate in moderation, being content with whatever was obtained.

original: “Paṇītaṃ yadi vā lūkhaṃ, appaṃ vā yadi vā bahuṃ;
analyzed: paṇītam yadi vā lūkham appam vā yadi vā bahum
translated: “Whether it was fine or coarse, whether it was little or much,

original: Yāpanatthaṃ abhuñjiṃsu, agiddhā nādhimucchitā.
analyzed: yāpana attham a bhuñjiṃsu a giddhā na adhimucchitā
translated: they ate for the purpose of sustenance, being free from greed, not being greedy.

original: “Jīvitānaṃ parikkhāre, bhesajje atha paccaye;
analyzed: jīvitānam parikkhāre bhesajje atha paccaye
translated: “In regard to the requisites for life, in regard to medicine, and in regard to the conditions,

original: Na bāḷhaṃ ussukā āsuṃ, yathā te āsavakkhaye.
analyzed: na bāḷham ussukāḥ āsum yathā te āsava khaye
translated: they were not very eager, as they were for the destruction of the pollutants.

original: “Araññe rukkhamūlesu, kandarāsu guhāsu ca;
analyzed: araññe rukkha mūlesu kandarāsu guhāsu ca
translated: “In the wilderness, at the foot of trees, in caves and grottoes,

original: Vivekamanubrūhantā, vihaṃsu tapparāyaṇā.
analyzed: vivekam anubrūhantā vihaṃsu tad parāyaṇā
translated: They lived intent on solitude, following the example of the Sage.

original: “Nīcā niviṭṭhā subharā, mudū athaddhamānasā;
analyzed: nīcā niviṭṭhā subharā mudū athaddha mānasā
translated: “They were humble, easy to support, gentle, and had subdued their minds.

original: Abyāsekā amukharā, atthacintāvasānugā.
analyzed: a byāsekā a mukharā attha cintā vasā anugā
translated: They were not quarrelsome, not garrulous, and were intent on the goal.

original: “Tato pāsādikaṃ āsi, gataṃ bhuttaṃ nisevitaṃ;
analyzed: tato pāsādikam āsi gatam bhuttam nisevitam
translated: “Then they became dignified, having gone forth, having eaten, having lived.

original: Siniddhā teladhārāva, ahosi iriyāpatho.
analyzed: siniddhā teladhārāva ahosi iriyāpatho
translated: Their deportment was like a well-oiled chariot.

original: “Sabbāsavaparikkhīṇā, mahājhāyī mahāhitā;
analyzed: sabba āsava parikkhīṇā mahā jhāyī mahā hitā
translated: “They were all of their defilements exhausted, great meditators, of great benefit.

original: Nibbutā dāni te therā, parittā dāni tādisā.
analyzed: nibbutāḥ dāni te therā parittāḥ dāni tādisā
translated: Now those elders are extinguished, now those like them are few.

original: “Kusalānañca dhammānaṃ, paññāya ca parikkhayā;
analyzed: kusalānam ca dhammānam paññāya ca parikkhayā
translated: “With the exhaustion of wholesome states and wisdom,

original: Sabbākāravarūpetaṃ, lujjate jinasāsanaṃ.
analyzed: lujjate jina sāsanam
translated: the Dispensation of the Victor is decaying, which is endowed with all good qualities.

original: “Pāpakānañca dhammānaṃ, kilesānañca yo utu;
analyzed: pāpakānam ca dhammānam kilesānam ca yaḥ utu
translated: “With the increase of unwholesome states and defilements,

original: Upaṭṭhitā vivekāya, ye ca saddhammasesakā.
analyzed: upaṭṭhitāḥ vivekāya ye ca saddhamma sesakā
translated: those who are intent on solitude and who are the remainder of the True Dhamma

original: “Te kilesā pavaḍḍhantā, āvisanti bahuṃ janaṃ;
analyzed: te kilesā pavaḍḍhantā āvisanti bahum janam
translated: “Those defilements, having increased, are entering into many people,

original: Kīḷanti maññe bālehi, ummattehiva rakkhasā.
analyzed: kīḷanti maññe bālehi ummattehi iva rakkhasā
translated: as if the demons were playing with the foolish, as if with the insane.

original: “Kilesehābhibhūtā te, tena tena vidhāvitā;
analyzed: kilesa iha abhibhūtā te tena tena vidhāvitā
translated: “Those people, overcome by defilements, are running here and there,

original: Narā kilesavatthūsu, sasaṅgāmeva ghosite.
analyzed: narā kilesa vatthūsu ghosite
translated: as if in a battle, with defilements as their weapons.

original: “Pariccajitvā saddhammaṃ, aññamaññehi bhaṇḍare;
analyzed: pariccajitvā saddhammam añña maññehi bhaṇḍare
translated: “Having abandoned the True Dhamma, quarreling with each other,

original: Diṭṭhigatāni anventā, idaṃ seyyoti maññare.
analyzed: diṭṭhigatāni anventāḥ idam seyyaḥ ti maññare
translated: Following their views, they think: ‘This is the best.’

original: “Dhanañca puttaṃ bhariyañca, chaḍḍayitvāna niggatā;
analyzed: dhanam ca puttam bhariyam ca chaḍḍayitvāna niggatā
translated: “Having abandoned wealth, children, and wife, they have gone forth,

original: Kaṭacchubhikkhahetūpi, akicchāni nisevare.
analyzed: a kicchāni nisevare
translated: But for the sake of a mere morsel of alms, they do not avoid what is improper.

original: “Udarāvadehakaṃ bhutvā, sayantuttānaseyyakā;
analyzed: udarāvadehakam bhutvā
translated: “Having eaten until their bellies are full, they lie down to sleep on their left sides,

original: Kathā vaḍḍhenti paṭibuddhā, yā kathā satthugarahitā.
analyzed: kathā vaḍḍhenti paṭibuddhāḥ yā kathā
translated: And when they wake up, they increase their talk, the kind of talk the Teacher has warned against.

original: “Sabbakārukasippāni, cittiṃ katvāna sikkhare;
analyzed: sabba kāruka sippāni cittim katvāna sikkhare
translated: “Having devoted their minds to all kinds of crafts and skills,

original: Avūpasantā ajjhattaṃ, sāmaññatthotiacchati.
analyzed: a vūpasantāḥ ajjhattam
translated: They do not attain inner tranquility, and they claim that this is the purpose of the spiritual life.

original: “Mattikaṃ telacuṇṇañca, udakāsanabhojanaṃ;
analyzed: mattikam tela cuṇṇam ca udaka āsana bhojanam
translated: “Clay, oil-seed flour, water, seats, and food—

original: Gihīnaṃ upanāmenti, ākaṅkhantā bahuttaraṃ.
analyzed: gihīnam upanāmenti ākaṅkhantāḥ bahuttaram
translated: They offer these to householders, hoping for much more in return.

original: “Dantaponaṃ kapitthañca, pupphaṃ khādaniyāni ca;
analyzed: kapittham ca puppham khādaniyāni ca
translated: “Tooth cleaners, wood-apple fruit, flowers, and edible leaves—

original: Piṇḍapāte ca sampanne, ambe āmalakāni ca.
analyzed: piṇḍapāte ca sampanne ambe āmalakāni ca
translated: When the almsfood is finished, mangoes and emblic myrobalan fruits.

original: “Bhesajjesu yathā vejjā, kiccākicce yathā gihī;
analyzed: bhesajjesu yathā vejjā kicca akicce yathā gihī
translated: “Just as doctors prescribe medicine for the sick, and householders know what is to be done and what is not to be done,

original: Gaṇikāva vibhūsāyaṃ, issare khattiyā yathā.
analyzed: gaṇikā ava issare khattiyāḥ yathā
translated: Just like a prostitute adorns herself, and just like the nobles are under the control of the king.

original: “Nekatikā vañcanikā, kūṭasakkhī apāṭukā;
analyzed: nekatikā vañcanikā kūṭasakkhī apāṭukā
translated: “They are deceitful and fraudulent, perjurers and unreliable,

original: Bahūhi parikappehi, āmisaṃ paribhuñjare.
analyzed: bahūhi parikappehi āmisam paribhuñjare
translated: And with many excuses, they enjoy material things.

original: “Lesakappe pariyāye, parikappenudhāvitā;
analyzed: lesa kappe pariyāye
translated: “They run around with their mouths open, with their theories and their explanations,

original: Jīvikatthā upāyena, saṅkaḍḍhanti bahuṃ dhanaṃ.
analyzed: jīvikatthāḥ upāyena saṅkaḍḍhanti bahum dhanam
translated: and with their livelihood they gather up much wealth.

original: “Upaṭṭhāpenti parisaṃ, kammato no ca dhammato;
analyzed: upaṭṭhāpenti parisam kammataḥ no ca dhammataḥ
translated: “They serve the assembly for the sake of work, not for the sake of the Dhamma,

original: Dhammaṃ paresaṃ desenti, lābhato no ca atthato.
analyzed: dhammam paresam desenti lābhataḥ no ca atthato
translated: and they teach the Dhamma to others for the sake of gain, not for the sake of the goal.

original: “Saṅghalābhassa bhaṇḍanti, saṅghato paribāhirā;
analyzed: saṅgha lābhassa bhaṇḍanti saṅghataḥ paribāhirā
translated: “They quarrel over the gains of the Saṅgha, and they are excluded from the Saṅgha.

original: Paralābhopajīvantā, ahirīkā na lajjare.
analyzed: para lābha upajīvantāḥ ahirīkāḥ na lajjare
translated: Living off the gains of others, they are shameless and have no fear of wrongdoing.

original: “Nānuyuttā tathā eke, muṇḍā saṅghāṭipārutā;
analyzed: na anuyuttā tathā eke muṇḍā saṅghāṭi pārutā
translated: “Some, though not devoted to this, are shaven-headed and wear the outer robe,

original: Sambhāvanaṃyevicchanti, lābhasakkāramucchitā.
analyzed: lābha sakkāram ucchitā
translated: and they are intent on being respected, intoxicated with the intoxication of gain.

original: “Evaṃ nānappayātamhi, na dāni sukaraṃ tathā;
analyzed: evam na an appayātamhi na dāni sukaram tathā
translated: “When it has thus gone to many, it is not easy to do as before,

original: Aphusitaṃ vā phusituṃ, phusitaṃ vānurakkhituṃ.
analyzed: a phusitam vā phusitum phusitam vā anurakkhitum
translated: to touch what has not been touched or to guard what has been touched.

original: “Yathā kaṇṭakaṭṭhānamhi, careyya anupāhano;
analyzed: yathā kaṇṭakaṭṭhānamhi careyya anupāhanaḥ
translated: “Just as one would walk in a place with thorns, without hurting one’s feet,

original: Satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvāna, evaṃ gāme munī care.
analyzed: satim upaṭṭhapetvānaḥ evam gāme munī care
translated: so the sage should walk in the village, having established mindfulness.

original: “Saritvā pubbake yogī, tesaṃ vattamanussaraṃ;
analyzed: saritvā pubbake yogī tesam vattam anussaram
translated: “Remembering the former yogis, recollecting their practice,

original: Kiñcāpi pacchimo kālo, phuseyya amataṃ padaṃ.
analyzed: kiñca api pacchimaḥ kālo phuseyya amatam padam
translated: even though it is a later time, one may touch the deathless state.

original: “Idaṃ vatvā sālavane, samaṇo bhāvitindriyo;
analyzed: idam vatvā sāla vane samaṇaḥ bhāvitindriyaḥ
translated: “Having spoken thus in the Sālā Grove, the monk with developed faculties,

original: Brāhmaṇo parinibbāyī, isi khīṇapunabbhavo”ti. –
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ parinibbāyī isi khīṇa punabbhavaḥ ti
translated: The brahmin has attained extinction, The seer has made an end of birth.

original: Imā gāthā thereneva bhāsitā.
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ therena iva bhāsitā
translated: These verses were spoken by the Elder himself.

original: Tattha iriyaṃ āsi bhikkhūnanti purisuttame lokanāthamhi sammāsambuddhe tiṭṭhante
analyzed: tattha iriyam āsi bhikkhūnam ti purisuttame lokanāthamhi sammāsambuddhe tiṭṭhante
translated: Herein, the meaning of the words should be understood in this way. The Elder said this: “The conduct of the bhikkhus was thus when the Supreme Man, the world’s Foremost Man, the Fully Enlightened One,

original: dharante etarahi paṭipattibhāvato. Aññathā aññena pakārena bhikkhūnaṃ iriyaṃ caritaṃ
analyzed: dharante etarahi paṭipatti bhāvataḥ aññathā aññena pakārena bhikkhūnam iriyam caritam
translated: was present and was teaching the way to practice. Otherwise, in another way, the conduct of the bhikkhus

original: ahosi yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipattibhāvato. Aññathā dāni dissatīti idāni pana tato aññathā
analyzed: ahosi yathānusiṭṭham paṭipatti bhāvataḥ aññathā dāni dissati iti idāni pana tatas aññathā
translated: was then. Now, however, it is seen otherwise.

original: bhikkhūnaṃ iriyaṃ dissati ayāthāvapaṭipattibhāvatoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: bhikkhūnam iriyam dissati ayāthāva paṭipatti bhāvato ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is that now the conduct of the bhikkhus is seen otherwise, in that they do not practice in accordance with the way taught.

original: Idāni satthari dharante yenākārena bhikkhūnaṃ paṭipatti ahosi, taṃ tāva dassetuṃ🔽“sītavātaparittāṇa”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha mattaṭṭhiyanti taṃ mattaṃ payojanaṃ. Yāvadeva
analyzed: idāni satthari dharante yena ākārena bhikkhūnam paṭipatti ahosi tam tāva dassetuṃ  vuttam tattha mattaṭṭhiyan ti tam mattam payojanam yāvat eva
translated: Now, in order to show how the bhikkhus’ practice was when the Teacher was teaching,

original: sītavātaparittāṇaṃ, yāvadeva hirīkopīnapaṭicchādanaṃ katvā cīvaraṃ paribhuñjiṃsu.
analyzed: sīta vāta parittāṇam yāvat eva hirī kopīna paṭicchādanam katvā cīvaram paribhuñjiṃsu
translated: he said “The shelter of the cold and wind” and so on. Herein, the meaning of the words should be understood in this way. They used the robe, he said, “just for the shelter of the cold and wind, just for the purpose of covering the parts of the body that cause shame” .

original: Kathaṃ? Santuṭṭhā itarītare yasmiṃ tasmiṃ hīne paṇīte vā yathāladdhe paccaye santosaṃ āpannā.
analyzed: katham santuṭṭhāḥ itarītare yasmin tasmin hīne paṇīte vā yathā laddhe paccaye santosam āpannā
translated: How? They were content with whatever was inferior or superior, with whatever they got, in the way of requisites.

original: Paṇītanti uḷāraṃ sappiādinā saṃsaṭṭhaṃ, tadabhāvena lūkhaṃ. Appanti, catupañcālopamattampi.
analyzed: paṇītam ti uḷāram sappi ādinā saṃsaṭṭham tad abhāvena lūkham appanti catu pañcāla upamattam pi
translated: “Superior” means excellent, mixed with ghee, etc.; “inferior” means poor, lacking those things. “Little” means only four or five lumps.

original: Bahuṃ yāpanatthaṃ abhuñjiṃsūti paṇītaṃ bahuṃ bhuñjantāpi yāpanamattameva āhāraṃ bhuñjiṃsu.🔽Tato eva agiddhā gedhaṃ anāpannā. Nādhimucchitā na ajjhositā akkhabbhañjanaṃ viya
analyzed: bahum yāpana attham abhuñjiṃsu iti paṇītam bahum bhuñjantā api yāpana mattam eva āhāram bhuñjiṃsu  tatas eva a giddhāḥ gedham an āpannāḥ na adhimucchitāḥ na ajjhositāḥ akkhabbhañjanam viya
translated: They did not eat much for the sake of mere sustenance. Even though they ate excellent food in abundance, they ate only for the sake of mere sustenance.🔽Because of that, they were not greedy, they did not fall into greed. They were not infatuated, not attached, like a cart-driver with a broken axle,

original: sākaṭikā, vaṇalepanaṃ viya vaṇino abhuñjiṃsu.
analyzed: sākaṭikāḥ vaṇa lepanam viya vaṇinaḥ abhuñjiṃsu
translated: like a leper with his rotting flesh.

original: Jīvitānaṃ parikkhāre, bhesajje atha paccayepi jīvitānaṃ pavattiyā parikkhārabhūte
analyzed: jīvitānam parikkhāre bhesajje atha paccaye pi jīvitānam pavattiyā parikkhāra bhūte
translated: “For the sake of life” means for the sake of the occurrence of life.🔽“For medicine” means for the sake of medicine, for the sake of requisites. “For the cure of the sick” means for the sake of the cure of the sick.

original: bhesajjasaṅkhāte paccaye gilānapaccaye. Yathā teti yathā te purimakā bhikkhū āsavakkhaye
analyzed: bhesajja saṅkhāte paccaye gilāna paccaye yathā te ti yathā te purimakāḥ bhikkhū āsava kkhaye
translated: “As did the ancient Buddhas” means as did the ancient Buddhas in the destruction of the cankers.

original: ussukā yuttā āsuṃ, tathā te rogābhibhūtāpi gilānapaccaye bāḷhaṃ ativiya ussukā nāhesunti attho.
analyzed: ussukāḥ yuttāḥ āsum tathā te roga abhibhūtāḥ api gilāna paccaye bāḷham ativiya ussukāḥ na ahesuṃ ti attho
translated: “So too, though overcome by sickness” means though overcome by sickness, they were not very eager for requisites for the cure of the sick.

original: Tapparāyaṇāti vivekaparāyaṇā vivekapoṇā. Evaṃ catūhi gāthāhi catupaccayasantosaṃ bhāvanābhiratiñca dassentena tesaṃ ariyavaṃsapaṭipadā dassitā.
analyzed: tad parāyaṇā ati viveka parāyaṇā viveka poṇā evam catūhi gāthāhi catu paccaya santosam bhāvanā abhiratiñca dassentena tesam ariya vaṃsa paṭipadā dassitā
translated: Tapparāyaṇā means devoted to seclusion, inclined to seclusion. So by these four verses he shows the practice of the noble lineage, showing contentment with the four requisites and delight in development.

original: Nīcāti “mayaṃ paṃsukūlikā piṇḍapātikā”ti attukkaṃsanaparavambhanāni akatvā nīcavuttino,
analyzed: nīcā ati mayam paṃsukūlikā piṇḍapātikā ati attukkaṃsana paravambhanāni a katvā nīca vuttinaḥ
translated: Nīcā means not being self-praising and disparaging others, saying “We are rag-robe wearers, almsfood eaters,” but being humble,

original: nivātavuttinoti attho. Niviṭṭhāti sāsane niviṭṭhasaddhā. Subharāti appicchatādibhāvena🔽suposā. Mudūti vattapaṭipattiyaṃ sakale ca brahmacariye mudū, suparikammakatasuvaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: nivāta vuttino ti atthaḥ niviṭṭhā ati sāsane niviṭṭha saddhā subharā ati appiccha tā ādi bhāvena  su posā mudū ti vatta paṭipattiyam sakale ca brahmacariye mudū su parikamma kata suvaṇṇam
translated: having a humble way of life, is the meaning. Niviṭṭhā means having faith established in the Dispensation. Subharā means well-nourished by fewness of wishes, etc.

original: viya viniyogakkhamā. Mudūti vā abhākuṭikā uttānamukhā pupphitamukhena paṭisanthāravuttino,
analyzed: viya viniyoga kkhamā vā abhākuṭikā uttāna mukhā pupphita mukhena paṭisanthāra vuttino
translated: Mudū means pliant in the practice of the duties and in the whole of the spiritual life, fit for use like well-refined gold. Mudū means not frowning, open-faced, hospitable with a blooming face,

original: sutitthaṃ viya sukhāvahāti vuttaṃ hoti. Athaddhamānasāti akathinacittā tena subbacabhāvamāha.
analyzed: su tittham viya sukha āvahā iti vuttam hoti athaddha mānasā ati akathina cittā tena subbaca bhāvam āha
translated: easy to talk with, like a good ford, easy to cross, is what is meant. Athaddhamānasā means not having a mind that is not contented with the bowl, and so on, and so he speaks of their excellence.

original: Abyāsekāti sativippavāsābhāvato kilesabyāsekarahitā, antarantarā taṇhādiṭṭhimānādīhi
analyzed: abyāseka ati sati vippavāsa abhāvato kilesa byāseka rahitā antarantarā taṇhā diṭṭhi māna ādīhi
translated: Abyāsekā means free from the disturbance of defilements because of the absence of any lapse of mindfulness. Now and again, by craving, views, conceit, etc.,

original: avokiṇṇāti attho. Amukharāti na mukharā, na mukhena kharā vacīpāgabbhiyarahitāti
analyzed: avokiṇṇā ati attho a mukharā ati na mukharā na mukhena kharā vacī pāgabbhiya rahitā ati
translated: The meaning is: not crowded. Not noisy: not noisy, not harsh in the mouth, free from the fault of harsh speech.

original: vā attho. Atthacintāvasānugāti hitacintāvasānugāhitacintāvasikā, attano paresañca
analyzed: vā atthaḥ attha cintā vasā anugā ati hita cintā vasā anugā ahita cintā vasikā attano paresam ca
translated: The meaning is: ending in the thought of welfare. Following the thought of welfare: following the thought of what is fitting, following the thought of what is beneficial for oneself and others.

original: hitacintameva anuparivattanakā.
analyzed: anuparivattanakā
translated: The meaning is: revolving only in the thought of what is beneficial for oneself and others.

original: Tatoti tasmā nīcavuttādihetu. Pāsādikanti pasādajanikaṃ paṭipattiṃ passantānaṃ suṇantānañca
analyzed: tatas ti tasmai nīca vutta ādi hetu pāsādikam ti pasāda janikam paṭipattim passantānam suṇantānam ca
translated: From that: for that reason, because of the low-spokenness, etc. Pleasing: generating confidence, causing confidence to arise in those who see and hear the practice.

original: pasādāvahaṃ. Gatanti abhikkantapaṭikkantaparivattanādigamanaṃ. Gatanti vā kāyavācāpavatti.
analyzed: pasāda āvaham gatanti abhikkanta paṭikkanta parivattana ādi gamanam gatanti vā kāya vācā apavatti
translated: Going: going forth and back, turning around, etc. Going: the occurrence of bodily and verbal action.

original: Bhuttanti catupaccayaparibhogo. Nisevitanti gocaranisevanaṃ. Siniddhā teladhārāvāti🔽yathā anivattitā kusalajanābhisiñcitā savantī teladhārā avicchinnā siniddhā maṭṭhā
analyzed: bhuttanti catu paccaya paribhogaḥ nisevitanti gocara nisevanam siniddhā tela dhārā vāti  yathā a nivattitā kusala jana abhisiñcitā savantī tela dhārā avicchinnā siniddhā maṭṭhā
translated: Eating: the use of the four requisites. Enjoying: enjoying the resort.🔽Well-proportioned, like a continuous stream of oil: just as an uninterrupted, well-proportioned, well-polished,

original: dassanīyā pāsādikā hoti, evaṃ tesaṃ ākappasampannānaṃ iriyāpatho acchiddo saṇho maṭṭho
analyzed: dassanīyā pāsādikā hoti evam tesam ākappa sampannānam iriyāpathaḥ acchiddaḥ saṇhaḥ maṭṭhaḥ
translated: beautiful, pleasing stream of oil flows without turning back, having been poured on a meritorious person, so too their deportment, which was endowed with dignity, was unbroken, gentle, well-polished,

original: dassanīyo pāsādiko ahosi.
analyzed: dassanīyaḥ pāsādikaḥ ahosi
translated: beautiful, and pleasing.

original: Mahājhāyīti mahantehi jhānehi jhāyanasīlā, mahantaṃ vā nibbānaṃ jhāyantīti mahājhāyī.🔽Tato eva mahāhitā, mahantehi hitehi samannāgatāti attho. Te therāti te yathāvuttappakārā🔽paṭipattiparāyaṇā therā idāni parinibbutāti attho. Parittā dāni tādisāti idāni pacchime
analyzed: mahā jhāyī iti mahantehi jhānehi jhāyana sīlāḥ mahantam vā nibbānam jhāyanti iti mahā jhāyī  tatas eva mahā hitāḥ mahantehi hitehi samannāgatā ati te therā ati te yathā vutta ppakārā  paṭipatti parāyaṇā therāḥ idāni parinibbutā ati attho parittā dāni tādisā ati idāni pacchime
translated: Those elders: those elders of the kind already described, who are intent on the way of practice, have now attained Nibbāna, is the meaning.

original: kāle tādisā tathārūpā therā parittā appakā katipayā evāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: kāle tādisā tathārūpā therā parittā appakā katipayā eva ati vuttam hoti
translated: Now few such: now in the last period, few such, of that kind, of that sort, of that description, of that nature, of that make, of that sort, of that class, of that category, of that origin, of that occurrence, of that destiny, of that fate, of that manifestation, of that appearance, of that action, of that conduct, of that practice, of that performance, of that observance, of that discipline, of that training, of that rule, of that teaching, of that instruction, of that explanation, of that description, of that definition, of that clarification, of that elucidation, of that kind of elders, are to be found, a mere handful, a mere few, a mere minority, is what is said.

original: Kusalānañca dhammānanti vivaṭṭassa upanissayabhūtānaṃ vimokkhasambhārānaṃ anavajjadhammānaṃ.
analyzed: kusalānaṃ ca dhammānan ti vivaṭṭassa upanissaya bhūtānam vimokkha sambhārānam anavajja dhammānam
translated: And of wholesome states: of blameless states, which are the requisites of deliverance and are the conditions for emergence.🔽And of wisdom: and of that kind of wisdom.

original: Paññāya cāti tathārūpāya paññāya ca. Parikkhayāti abhāvato anuppattito. Kāmañcettha🔽paññāpi siyā anavajjadhammā, bahukārabhāvadassanatthaṃ panassā visuṃ gahaṇaṃ yathā
analyzed: paññāya ca ati tathārūpāya paññāya ca parikkhayā ati abhāvataḥ anuppattitaḥ kāmañca ittha  paññā api siyā anavajja dhammā bahu kāra bhāva dassana attham pana assā visum gahaṇam yathā
translated: Are destroyed: are non-existent, are unarisen.🔽Though wisdom is blameless here,🔽it is mentioned separately in order to show that it has many functions, just as🔽merit and the requisites of enlightenment are.

original: puññañāṇasambhārāti. Sabbākāravarūpetanti ādikalyāṇatādīhi sabbehi ākāravarehi pakāravisesehi
analyzed: puñña ñāṇa sambhārā āti ādi kalyāṇa tā ādīhi sabbehi ākāra varehi pakāra visesehi
translated: In every way the best: in every way, in all ways, in every respect, in every connexion, in every category, in every class, in every sort, in every manner, in every method, in every occurrence, in every manifestation, in every appearance, in every action, in every conduct, in every practice, in every performance, in every observance, in every discipline, in every training, in every rule, in every teaching, in every instruction, in every explanation, in every description, in every definition, in every clarification, in every elucidation, in every kind of way, the best, the most excellent, the most outstanding, the most sublime, the most exalted, the most lofty, the most superlative, the most select, the most excellent, the most refined, the most consummate, the most perfect, the most consummate and perfect, the most consummate and supreme.

original: upetaṃ yuttaṃ jinassa bhagavato sāsanaṃ lujjati vinassatīti attho.
analyzed: upetam yuttam jinassa bhagavato sāsanam lujjati vinassati iti attho
translated: The word “occasion” for bad things

original: Pāpakānañca dhammānaṃ, kilesānañca yo utūti kāyaduccaritādīnaṃ pāpadhammānaṃ lobhādīnañca
analyzed: pāpakānam ca dhammānam kilesānam ca kāya duccarita ādīnam pāpa dhammānam lobha ādīnam ca
translated: and for defilements is the time for bad things such as bodily misconduct, etc., and for defilements such as greed, etc.🔽The rest of the sentence is “that time is now come.”

original: kilesānaṃ yo utu yo kālo, so ayaṃ vattatīti vacanaseso. Upaṭṭhitā vivekāya, ye ca🔽saddhammasesakāti ye pana evarūpe kāle kāyacittaupadhivivekatthāya upaṭṭhitā āraddhavīriyā,
analyzed: kilesānam yaḥ utu yaḥ kālo so ayam vattati iti vacana sesaḥ upaṭṭhitāḥ vivekāya ye ca  saddhamma sesakā ti ye pana evarūpe kāle kāya citta upadhi viveka atthāya upaṭṭhitāḥ āraddha vīriyāḥ
translated: Those who are intent on solitude🔽and on the true Dhamma’s remainder

original: te ca sesapaṭipattisaddhammakā honti. Ayañhettha adhippāyo – suvisuddhasīlācārāpi
analyzed: te ca sesa paṭipatti saddhammakāḥ honti ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ su visuddha sīla ācārā api
translated: are those who, at such a time as this, are intent on solitude of body, mind, and belongings, and who have aroused energy for the purpose of attaining the remainder of the true Dhamma, namely, the practice.

original: samānā idāni ekacce bhikkhū iriyāpathasaṇṭhāpanaṃ, samathavipassanābhāvanāvidhānaṃ,🔽mahāpalibodhūpacchedo, khuddakapalibodhūpacchedoti evamādipubbakiccaṃ sampādetvā
analyzed: samānāḥ idāni ekacce bhikkhū iriyāpatha saṇṭhāpanam samatha vipassanā bhāvanā vidhānam  mahā pali bodhūpacchedo khuddaka pali bodhūpacchedo ti evamādi pubba kiccam sampādetvā
translated: The purport here is this: although some bhikkhus are of very pure virtue and conduct,🔽they now fail to perfect the practice by bringing it to its culmination. For they undertake development after accomplishing the preliminary work, namely, the regulation of bodily behavior, the direction of samatha and vipassanā,

original: bhāvanamanuyuñjanti. Te sesapaṭipattisaddhammakā, paṭipattiṃ matthakaṃ pāpetuṃ na sakkontīti.
analyzed: bhāvanam anuyuñjanti te sesa paṭipatti saddhammakā paṭipattim matthakam pāpetum na sakkonti iti
translated: the severing of the great impediments, and the severing of the minor impediments.

original: Te kilesā pavaḍḍhantāti ye bhagavato orasaputtehi ca tadā parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ
analyzed: te kilesā pavaḍḍhantā ati ye bhagavato orasa puttehi ca tadā parikkhayam pariyādānam
translated: “Those defilements increase” means that at that time, for the Fortunate One’s pupils, those defilements were destroyed, were brought to an end,

original: gamitā kilesā, te etarahi laddhokāsā bhikkhūsu vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjantā.
analyzed: gamitā kilesā te etarahi laddha okāsā bhikkhūsu vuddhim virūḷhim vepullam āpajjantā
translated: The defilements grow in strength. The defilements that had been destroyed and exhausted in the Blessed One’s immediate disciples now get an opportunity to grow in strength and increase in the bhikkhus.

original: Āvisanti bahuṃ jananti kalyāṇamittarahitaṃ ayonisomanasikārabahulaṃ andhabālajanaṃ
analyzed: bahum jananti kalyāṇa mitta rahitam a yoni soma nasikāra bahulam andha bāla janam
translated: They invade the multitude. The multitude of blind fools who are devoid of good friends and abound in unwise attention

original: abhibhavitvā avasaṃ karontā āvisanti santānaṃ anupavisanti. Evaṃbhūtā ca te kīḷanti
analyzed: abhibhavitvā avasam karontāḥ āvisanti santānam anupavisanti evaṃbhūtā ca te kīḍanti
translated: are invaded by the defilements, which enter their mental continuity. The defilements seem to be playing with the fools

original: maññe bālehi, ummattehiva rakkhasā, yathā nāma keḷisīlā rakkhasā bhisakkarahite ummatte🔽āvisitvā te anayabyasanaṃ āpādentā tehi kīḷanti, evaṃ te kilesā sammāsambuddhabhisakkarahite🔽andhabāle bhikkhū āvisitvā tesaṃ diṭṭhadhammikādibhedaṃ anatthaṃ uppādentā tehi saddhiṃ
analyzed: maññe bālehi ummattehi iva rakkhasā yathā nāma keḷisīlāḥ rakkhasā bhisakka rahite ummatte  āvisitvā te anaya byasanam tehi kīḍanti evam te kilesā sammāsambuddha bhisakka rahite  andha bāle bhikkhū āvisitvā tesam diṭṭhadhammika ādi bhedam anattham uppādentā tehi saddhim
translated: as demons play with the insane. Just as demons who delight in play, having invaded the insane who are devoid of a physician,🔽make them dance and sing and do other foolish things, bringing them to ruin and despair, so too the defilements, having invaded the blind fools who are devoid of the physician, the Supremely Enlightened One,

original: kīḷanti maññe, kīḷantā viya hontīti attho.
analyzed: kīḷanti maññe kīḷantāḥ viya honti iti attho
translated: bring them to misfortune in this very life, etc., and make them play with them, as it were. The meaning is that they act as if they were playing with them.

original: Tena tenāti tena tena ārammaṇabhāgena. Vidhāvitāti virūpaṃ dhāvitā asāruppavasena🔽paṭipajjantā. Kilesavatthūsūti paṭhamaṃ uppannaṃ kilesā pacchā uppajjanakānaṃ kāraṇabhāvato
analyzed: tena tena ati tena tena ārammaṇa bhāgena vidhāvitā ati virūpam dhāvitā a sāruppa vasena  paṭipajjantā kilesa vatthūsu ti paṭhamam uppannam kilesā pacchā uppajjanakānam kāraṇa bhāvato
translated: By this and that means by this and that object. They run hither and thither: they run in a distorted way, in a way that is not in accordance with the way to welfare. In the field of the defilements: the defilements are the field of the defilements since they are the cause of the defilements that arise later.

original: kilesāva kilesavatthūni, tesu kilesavatthūsu samūhitesu. Sasaṅgāmeva ghositeti hiraññasuvaṇṇamaṇimuttādikaṃ🔽dhanaṃ vippakiritvā “yaṃ yaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇādi yassa yassa hatthagataṃ, taṃ taṃ tassa🔽tasseva hotū”ti evaṃ kāmaghosanā sasaṅgāmaghosanā nāma. Tatthāyamattho – kilesavatthūsu
analyzed: kilesā ava kilesa vatthūni tesu kilesa vatthūsu samūhitesu ghositā iti hirañña suvaṇṇa maṇi mutta ādikam  dhanam vippakiritvā yam yam hirañña suvaṇṇa ādi yassa yassa hattha gatam tam tam tassa  tassa iva hotu uti evam kāmaghosanā sa saṅgāmaghosanā nāma tattha ayam attho kilesa vatthūsu
translated: When they are assembled in the field of the defilements,

original: “yo yo kileso yaṃ yaṃ sattaṃ gaṇhāti abhibhavati, so so tassa tassa hotū”ti kilesasenāpatinā
analyzed: yaḥ yaḥ kilesaḥ yam yam sattam gaṇhāti abhibhavati saḥ saḥ tassa tassa hotu uti kilesa senāpatinā
translated: The battle is joined and the shout goes up: the battle is joined when gold, silver, gems, pearls, etc., are scattered about, and the shout goes up when it is announced: “Let what falls into anyone’s hand be his!” This is called the battle shout. Herein, the meaning is this: “Let whatever defilement overpowers whatever being be his!”🔽Thus the battle is joined by Mara, the general of the defilements.🔽As if the shout goes up,

original: mārena sasaṅgāme ghosite viya. Tehi tehi kilesehi abhibhūtā te bālaputhujjanā tena🔽tena ārammaṇabhāgena vidhāvitā vositāti.
analyzed: mārena sa saṅgāme ghosite viya tehi tehi kilesehi abhibhūtā te bāla puthujjanā tena 🔽tena ārammaṇa bhāgena vidhāvitā vositā ati
translated: Overpowered by this and that defilement, the foolish ordinary men run hither and thither by this and that object, and they are lost.

original: Te evaṃ vidhāvitā kiṃ karontīti āha “pariccajitvā saddhammaṃ, aññamaññehi bhaṇḍare”ti.
analyzed: te evam vidhāvitā kim karonti iti āha pariccajitvā saddhammam añña maññehi bhaṇḍareti
translated: “They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽The meaning is this. Having abandoned the True Idea of practice, they quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites of alms food, etc.,

original: Tassattho – paṭipattisaddhammaṃ chaḍḍetvā āmisakiñjakkhahetu aññamaññehi bhaṇḍare🔽kalahaṃ karontīti. Diṭṭhigatānīti “viññāṇamattameva atthi, nattheva rūpadhammā”ti,
analyzed: tassatthaḥ paṭipatti saddhammam chaḍḍetvā āmisa kiñjakkha hetu aññamaññehi bhaṇḍare  kalaham karonti iti diṭṭhi gatāni iti viññāṇamattam eva atthi nattha iva rūpa dhammā ti
translated: for the sake of the mere requisites of robes, etc., for the sake of the mere requisites of resting places, etc., for the sake of the mere requisites of medicines, etc.🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .

original: “yathā puggalo nāma paramatthato natthi, evaṃ sabhāvadhammāpi paramatthato natthi,🔽vohāramattamevā”ti ca evamādīni diṭṭhigatāni micchāgāhe anventā anugacchantā idaṃ
analyzed: yathā puggalaḥ nāma paramatthataḥ natthi evam sabhāva dhammā api paramatthataḥ natthi  vohāra mattam eva ati ca evamādīni diṭṭhi gatāni micchāgāhe anventā anugacchantā idam
translated: “They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .

original: seyyo idameva seṭṭhaṃ, aññaṃ micchāti maññanti.
analyzed: idam eva seṭṭham aññam micchā ati maññanti
translated: “They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .🔽“They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .

original: Niggatāti gehato nikkhantā. Kaṭacchubhikkhahetūpīti kaṭacchumattabhikkhānimittampi.
analyzed: niggatā ati gehataḥ nikkhantā kaṭacchu bhikkha hetu upī ti kaṭacchu matta bhikkhā nimittam pi
translated: “They, having abandoned the True Idea, quarrel with each other for the sake of the mere requisites” .

original: Taṃ dadantassa gahaṭṭhassa ananulomikasaṃsaggavasena akiccāni pabbajitena akattabbāni🔽kammāni nisevare karonti.
analyzed: tam dadantassa gahaṭṭhassa ananulomika saṃsagga vasena akiccāni pabbajitena akattabbāni 🔽kammāni nisevare karonti
translated: “They, having abandoned the

original: Udarāvadehakaṃ bhutvāti “ūnūdaro mitāhāro”ti vuttavacanaṃ acintetvā udarapūraṃ bhuñjitvā.🔽Sayantuttānaseyyakāti “dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappeti pāde pādaṃ accādhāya
analyzed: udara avadehakam bhutvā ati ūna udaraḥ mita āhāraḥ iti vutta vacanam a cintetvā udara pūram bhuñjitvā  sayantuttānaseyyakā ti dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyam kappeti pāde pādam accādhāya
translated: Having eaten till they are full: not considering the words, “With a limited amount of food, with a small amount of food” , they eat until their stomachs are full.🔽They lie down in the lion’s posture: not remembering the words, “He lies down in the lion’s posture, placing one foot on the other, mindful and clearly comprehending” , they lie down in the lion’s posture with their bodies outstretched.

original: sato sampajāno”ti vuttavidhānaṃ ananussaritvā uttānaseyyakā sayanti. Yā kathā satthugarahitāti
analyzed: sataḥ sampajānoti vutta vidhānam an anussaritvā uttānaseyyakā sayanti yā kathā satthuga rahitā ati
translated: The kind of talk that is condemned by the Teacher:

original: rājakathāditiracchānakathaṃ sandhāya vadati.
analyzed: rāja kathā aditiḥ acchāna katham sandhāya vadati
translated: he refers to talk about kings, etc., as “the kind of talk that is condemned by the Teacher.”

original: Sabbakārukasippānīti sabbehi vessādīhi kārukehi kattabbāni bhattatālavaṇṭakaraṇādīni
analyzed: sabba kāruka sippāni iti sabbehi vessa ādīhi kārukehi kattabbāni bhatta tāla vaṇṭa karaṇa ādīni
translated: All kinds of crafts: all the crafts of carpenters, etc., such as the making of bowls, fans, etc.🔽Having made a resolve: having made a resolve with respect, with reverence.

original: hatthasippāni. Cittiṃ katvānāti sakkaccaṃ sādaraṃ katvā. Avūpasantā ajjhattanti kilesavūpasamābhāvato
analyzed: hattha sippāni cittim katvā anāti sakkaccam sādaram katvā a vūpasantāḥ ajjhattanti kilesa vūpasama abhāvataḥ
translated: Not calmed internally: because of the absence of the calming of defilements,

original: gadduhanamattampi samādhānābhāvato ca ajjhattaṃ avūpasantā, avūpasantacittāti attho.
analyzed: samādhāna abhāvato ca ajjhattam a vūpasantā a vūpasanta cittā ti attho
translated: because of the absence of the attainment of even the access-level concentration, they are not calmed internally; the meaning is, they are not calmed in mind.🔽The purpose of recluseship: the state of a recluse.

original: Sāmaññatthoti samaṇadhammo. Atiacchatīti tesaṃ ājīvakiccapasutatāya ekadesampi aphusanato
analyzed: sāmañña atthaḥ ti samaṇa dhammo atiacchati iti tesam ājīva kicca pasuta tāya eka desam pi a phusanato
translated: It is too much: because of their excessive devotion to the means of livelihood, they do not even touch one part of it.

original: visuṃyeva nisīdati, anallīyatīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: visuṃyā iva nisīdati anallīyati iti vuttam hoti
translated: He sits down elsewhere: he does not sit down together.

original: Mattikanti pākatikaṃ vā pañcavaṇṇaṃ vā gihīnaṃ viniyogakkhamaṃ mattikaṃ. Telacuṇṇañcāti
analyzed: mattikanti pākatikam vā pañca vaṇṇam vā gihīnam viniyoga khamam mattikam tela cuṇṇam ca ati
translated: Clay: clay for making cakes, or clay of five colours, clay that is suitable for householders to use. Oil-seed flour and oil:

original: pākatikaṃ, abhisaṅkhataṃ vā telañca cuṇṇañca. Udakāsanabhojananti udakañca āsanañca🔽bhojanañca. Ākaṅkhantā bahuttaranti bahuṃ piṇḍapātādiuttaruttaraṃ ākaṅkhantā “amhehi
analyzed: pākatikam abhisaṅkhatam vā telam ca cuṇṇam ca udaka āsana bhojananti udakam ca āsanañca  bhojanam ca ākaṅkhantāḥ bahuttaranti bahum piṇḍapāta ādi uttaruttaram ākaṅkhantāḥ amhehi
translated: oil-seed flour, or oil made from oil-seeds. Water, a seat, and food: water, a seat,

original: mattikādīsu dinnesu manussā daḷhabhattikā hutvā bahuṃ uttaruttaraṃ catupaccayajātaṃ
analyzed: mattika ādīsu dinnesu manussāḥ daḷhabhattikāḥ hutvā bahum uttaruttaram catu paccaya jātam
translated: and food. If they wish, they can ask for more: if they wish, they can ask for more and more almsfood, etc., with the idea that “if we give them clay, etc., they will be satisfied with food, and they will give us more and more of the four requisites.”

original: dassantī”ti adhippāyena gihīnaṃ upanāmentīti attho.
analyzed: dassanti iti adhippāyena gihīnam upanāmenti iti atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they offer them to householders.

original: Dante punanti sodhenti etenāti dantaponaṃ, dantakaṭṭhaṃ. Kapitthanti kapitthaphalaṃ.🔽Pupphanti sumanacampakādipupphaṃ. Khādanīyānīti aṭṭhārasavidhepi khajjakavisese.
analyzed: dante punanti sodhenti etena ati dantaponam dantakaṭṭham kapitthanti kapittha phalam  pupphanti sumana campaka ādi puppham khādanīyāni iti aṭṭhārasavidhe pi khajjaka visese
translated: Tooth-cleanser: that by which they cleanse and purify their teeth. Wood-apple: the wood-apple fruit.🔽Flowers: jasmine, champak, and so on. Edible leaves: the eighteen kinds of edible leaves.

translated: our livelihood is dependent on others.”🔽They are not devoted: they are not devoted to the things that make one an ascetic.

original: Nānuyuttāti samaṇakaraṇehi dhammehi ananuyuttā. Tathāti yathā pubbe vuttā bandhanakārakādayo,

translated: Just as: just as the monks who cause quarrels, etc., are described in the previous stanza,

original: tathā. Eketi ekacce. Muṇḍā saṅghāṭipārutāti kevalaṃ muṇḍitakesatāya muṇḍā pilotikakhaṇḍehi
analyzed: tathā ekā iti ekacce muṇḍā saṅghāṭi pārutā ati kevalam muṇḍita kesa tāya muṇḍā pilotika khaṇḍehi
translated: so too are these. Shaved: they are shaved only with the shaving of the hair of the head and hair of the face.

original: saṅghaṭitaṭṭhena “saṅghāṭī”ti laddhanāmena cīvarena pārutasarīrā. Sambhāvanaṃyevicchanti,
analyzed: saṅghaṭita ṭṭhena saṅghāṭī iti laddha nāmena cīvarena pāruta sarīrā
translated: Clad in robes: their bodies are covered with robes that are called “saṅghāṭī” in the sense of being made up of pieces of cloth sewn together.

original: lābhasakkāramucchitāti lābhasakkārāsāya mucchitā ajjhositā hutvā, “pesalo dhutavādo
analyzed: lābha sakkāra mucchitā ati lābha sakkāra āsāya mucchitā ajjhositā hutvā pesalaḥ dhuta vādaḥ
translated: They seek only to be respected: they are infatuated with, and attached to, the desire for gain and honour.

original: bahussuto”ti vā madhuravacanamanuyuttā “ariyo”ti ca kevalaṃ sambhāvanaṃ bahumānaṃyeva
analyzed: vā madhura vacanam anuyuttāḥ ca kevalam sambhāvanam
translated: “He is learned,” or “He is one who speaks sweetly,” or “He is noble,” they merely wish for, desire, mere respect, mere esteem,

original: icchanti esanti, na tannimitte guṇeti attho.
analyzed: icchanti na tad nimitte guṇa iti attho
translated: not for the qualities that are the grounds for that respect.

original: Evanti “kusalānañca dhammānaṃ paññāya ca parikkhayā”ti vuttanayena. Nānappayātamhīti
analyzed: evam ti kusalānam ca dhammānam paññāya ca parikkhayā ati vutta nayena nānappayātamhi iti
translated: Thus: in the way stated thus: “Through the exhaustion of wholesome and unwholesome states and through the exhaustion of wisdom” .

original: nānappakāre bhedanadhamme payāte samakate, nānappakārena vā saṃkilesadhamme payātuṃ

original: hoti, tathā anurakkhituṃ pāletuṃ sukaraṃ, tathā na sukaraṃ, tathā sampādetuṃ na sakkāti attho.

analyzed: idāni attanaḥ parinibbāna kālassa āsanna ttā saṃkhittena ovādena sabrahmacārim ovadantaḥ

translated: “As a man who walks unhurt through a place full of thorns for some purpose

analyzed: tiṃsa nipātaḥ
translated: . The Thirty-Third Chapter

original: 1. Phussattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
translated: . The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Phussa

original: Tiṃsanipāte pāsādike bahū disvātiādikā āyasmato phussattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti?
analyzed: tiṃsa nipāte pāsa ādike bahū āyasmataḥ phussa therassa gāthā kā uppatti
translated: In the Thirty-third Chapter, in the stanza beginning with the words, “Having seen many who were worthy of offerings,” etc., are the verses of the Elder Phussa. What is the origin of these verses?

original: Ayampi purimabuddhesu katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ kusalaṃ upacinitvā
analyzed: ayam pi purima buddhesu kata adhikāraḥ tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭu upanissayam kusalam upacinitvā
translated: This Elder also had performed meritorious deeds under former Buddhas, and had accumulated wholesome roots of merit in various existences,

original: devamanussesu saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde ekassa maṇḍalikarañño putto hutvā nibbatti,
analyzed: deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde ekassa maṇḍalika raññaḥ puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti
translated: and had been reborn in the heavens and among mankind. At the time of the appearance of this Buddha, he was born as the son of a certain king of Maṇḍagāma.

original: phussoti nāmaṃ ahosi. So viññutaṃ patto khattiyakumārehi sikkhitabbasippesu nipphattiṃ
analyzed: phussaḥ ti nāmam ahosi so viññutam pattaḥ khattiya kumārehi sikkhitabba sippesu nipphattim
translated: and his name was Phussa. When he had reached years of discretion, he became proficient in all the arts that a prince should learn.

original: gato. Upanissayasampannattā kāmesu alaggacitto aññatarassa mahātherassa santike dhammaṃ
analyzed: gataḥ upanissaya sampanna ttā kāmesu a lagga cittaḥ aññatarassa mahā therassa santike dhammaṃ
translated: Because he had the necessary faculties, he was not attached to sensual pleasures. He heard the Dhamma from a certain great elder,

original: sutvā paṭiladdhasaddho pabbajitvā cariyānukūlaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā bhāvanaṃ anuyuñjanto
analyzed: sutvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbajitvā cariyā anukūlam kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā bhāvanam anuyuñjantaḥ
translated: and he gained faith. He went forth into homelessness and took up a meditation subject suitable for his temperament.

original: jhānāni nibbattetvā jhānapādakaṃ vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā nacirasseva chaḷabhiñño ahosi.
analyzed: jhānāni nibbattetvā jhāna pādakam vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā nacirassa iva chaḍabhiññaḥ ahosi
translated: He devoted himself to meditation and produced the jhanas. Then he made the jhanas a basis for insight, and in no long time he reached Arahantship with the six kinds of direct knowledge.

original: Athekadivasaṃ paṇḍaragotto nāma eko tāpaso tassa santike dhammaṃ sutvā nisinno sambahule
analyzed: atha eka divasam paṇḍaragottaḥ nāma ekaḥ tāpasaḥ tassa santike dhammam sutvā nisinno sambahule
translated: One day a certain ascetic of the Pandara clan, who was sitting listening to the Dhamma,

translated: “Listen carefully, and I will tell you what will happen in the future.”

original: Tassattho – bho paṇḍaranāma isi, yaṃ tvaṃ maṃ pucchasi, taṃ te anāgataṃ ācikkhissāmi,
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ bho paṇḍara nāma isi yam tvam mama pucchasi tam te anāgatam ācikkhissāmi
translated: The meaning is: “Sir, I will tell you what you ask me about, what will happen in the future.

original: ācikkhato pana mama vacanaṃ suṇāhi anāgatatthadīpanato saṃvegāvahato ca sakkaccaṃ upadhārehīti.
analyzed: ācikkhataḥ pana mama vacanam suṇāhi anāgata attha dīpanataḥ saṃvega āvahataḥ ca sakkaccam upadhārehi iti
translated: But listen carefully to my words as I tell you about the future, and be stirred to your innermost being.”

original: Atha thero anāgataṃsañāṇena bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnañca bhāviniṃ pavattiṃ yathābhūtaṃ disvā tassa ācikkhanto –🔽“Kodhanā upanāhī ca, makkhī thambhī saṭhā bahū;

original: Issukī nānāvādā ca, bhavissanti anāgate.
analyzed: issukī nānāvādā ca bhavissanti anāgate
translated: Haughty, obstinate, and deceitful, envious and of various views.

original: “Aññātamānino dhamme, gambhīre tīragocarā;
analyzed: aññāta māninaḥ dhamme gambhīre tīra gocarā

original: Lahukā agarū dhamme, aññamaññamagāravā.
analyzed: lahukā agarū dhamme aññam aññam agāravā
translated: Not revering the Dhamma or one another.

original: “Bahū ādīnavā loke, uppajjissantyanāgate;
analyzed: bahū ādīnavāḥ loke uppajjissanti anāgate
translated: “Many dangers will arise in the world in the future;

original: Sudesitaṃ imaṃ dhammaṃ, kilesissanti dummatī.
analyzed: su desitam imam dhammam kilesissanti dummatī
translated: The Dhamma will be corrupted by the foolish.

original: “Guṇahīnāpi saṅghamhi, voharantā visāradā;
analyzed: guṇa hīnā api saṅghamhi voharantā visāra dā
translated: “Even those who are inferior in virtue🔽Will be bold in teaching the Dhamma;

original: Balavanto bhavissanti, mukharā assutāvino.
analyzed: balavantaḥ bhavissanti mukharāḥ assutāvinaḥ
translated: They will be powerful, garrulous, and ignorant.

original: “Guṇavantopi saṅghamhi, voharantā yathātthato;
analyzed: guṇavantaḥ api saṅghamhi voharantāḥ
translated: “Even those with virtue, when they speak in the Saṅgha according to what is true,

original: Dubbalā te bhavissanti, hirīmanā anatthikā.
analyzed: dubbalā te bhavissanti hirīmanāḥ anatthikā
translated: will be weak, ashamed, and useless.

original: “Rajataṃ jātarūpañca, khettaṃ vatthumajeḷakaṃ.
analyzed: rajatam jātarūpam ca khettam
translated: “Silver, gold, fields, cloth, cattle,

original: Dāsidāsañca dummedhā, sādiyissantyanāgate.

translated: and slaves—the foolish will accept these in the future.

original: “Ujjhānasaññino bālā, sīlesu asamāhitā;
analyzed: ujjhāna saññinaḥ bālā sīlesu asamāhitā
translated: “The foolish, perceiving blame, not concentrated in virtue,

original: “Uddhatā ca bhavissanti, nīlacīvarapārutā;
analyzed: uddhatā ca bhavissanti nīla cīvara pārutā
translated: “They will be arrogant, wearing blue-black robes,

translated: “With their hair anointed with oil, fickle, with kohl-lined eyes,

translated: “They will be greedy for gain, lazy, with low energy,

translated: “Those who get gain, always devoted to wrong livelihood,

translated: Silver: silver is the same as money, and by that is included iron coins, copper coins, etc. Gold:

analyzed: te ṭhapetvā avasesā pasujātī ajā nāma ajeḷaka ggahaṇena iva ha ittha go mahiṃsa ādīnam pi  saṅgahaḥ kataḥ dāsi dāsam ca ati dāsiyaḥ ca dāse ca dummedhā ati aviddasuno kappiya akappiyam
