analyzed: pametum parikappeyya vighātam va labheyya saḥ
translated: Were to measure and praise, he would only meet with vexation.

original: “Sāsane te patiṭṭhāya, sakyaputta mahāyasa;
analyzed: sāsane te patiṭṭhāya sakyaputta mahāyasa
translated: “Having been established in your Dispensation, Sakyan Son of great fame,

original: Paññāya pāramiṃ gantvā, viharāmi anāsavo.
analyzed: paññāya pāramim gantvā viharāmi anāsavaḥ
translated: Having gone to the perfection of wisdom, I dwell without defilements.

original: “Titthiye sampamaddāmi, vattemi jinasāsanaṃ;
analyzed: titthiye sampamaddāmi vattemi jina sāsanaṃ
translated: “I defeat the sectarians, I proclaim the Dispensation of the Jina,

original: Dhammasenāpati ajja, sakyaputtassa sāsane.
analyzed: dhammasenāpati ajja sakyaputtassa sāsane
translated: Today I am the Commander of the Faith, in the Sakyan Son’s Dispensation.

original: “Aparimeyye kataṃ kammaṃ, phalaṃ dassesi me idha;
analyzed: aparimeyye katam kammam phalam dassesi me idha
translated: “The deed that I did in the past, the fruit of that has appeared to me here;

original: Sukhitto saravegova, kilese jhāpayī mama.
analyzed: su khittaḥ sara vegaḥ uva kilese mama
translated: Happy, like a swift-flowing river, I have burnt up my defilements.

original: “Yo koci manujo bhāraṃ, dhāreyya matthake sadā;
analyzed: yaḥ koci manujaḥ bhāram dhāreyya matthake sadā
translated: “Whatever man would always carry a load on his head,

original: Bhārena dukkhito assa, bhārehi bharito tathā.
analyzed: bhārena dukkhitaḥ assa bhārehi bharitaḥ tathā
translated: He would be afflicted by the load, and so would be burdened by the loads.

original: “Ḍayhamāno tīhaggīhi, bhavesu saṃsariṃ ahaṃ;
analyzed: ḍayhamānaḥ bhavesu saṃsarim aham
translated: “Burning with the three fires, I wandered through the various existences;

original: Bharito bhavabhārena, giriṃ uccārito yathā.
analyzed: bharitaḥ bhava bhārena girim uccāritaḥ yathā
translated: Burdened by the burden of existence, as if I had been thrown on a mountain.

original: “Oropito ca me bhāro, bhavā ugghāṭitā mayā;
analyzed: ca me bhāraḥ ugghāṭitā mayā
translated: “The burden is laid down, existence is destroyed,

original: Karaṇīyaṃ kataṃ sabbaṃ, sakyaputtassa sāsane.
analyzed: karaṇīyam katam sabbam sakya puttassa sāsane
translated: All that is to be done is done, in the teaching of the Sakyan Son.

original: “Yāvatā buddhakhettamhi, ṭhapetvā sakyapuṅgavaṃ;
analyzed: yāvatā buddha khettamhi ṭhapetvā sakya puṅgavam
translated: “As far as the Buddha-field extends, except for the Sakyan Bull,

original: Ahaṃ aggomhi paññāya, sadiso me na vijjati.
analyzed: aham aggomhi paññāya sadisaḥ me na vijjati
translated: I am foremost in wisdom, there is no one equal to me.

original: “Samādhimhi sukusalo, iddhiyā pāramiṃ gato;
analyzed: samādhimhi su kusalaḥ iddhiyā pāramim gataḥ
translated: “Skilled in concentration, having attained perfection in psychic power,

original: Icchamāno cahaṃ ajja, sahassaṃ abhinimmine.
analyzed: icchamānaḥ caham ajja sahassam abhinimmine
translated: If I so wished, I could create a thousand replicas of myself.

original: “Anupubbavihārassa, vasībhūto mahāmuni;
analyzed: anupubba vihārassa vasībhūtaḥ mahā muni
translated: “Having attained mastery in the successive stages of attainment, the Great Sage

original: Kathesi sāsanaṃ mayhaṃ, nirodho sayanaṃ mama.
analyzed: kathesi sāsanam mayham nirodhaḥ sayanam mama
translated: Taught me the Teaching, and cessation is my bed.

original: “Dibbacakkhu visuddhaṃ me, samādhikusalo ahaṃ;
analyzed: dibba cakkhu visuddham me samādhi kusalaḥ aham
translated: “My divine eye is purified, I am skilled in concentration,

original: Sammappadhānānuyutto, bojjhaṅgabhāvanārato.
analyzed: sammappadhāna anuyuttaḥ bojjhaṅga bhāvanā rataḥ
translated: I am devoted to right endeavour, delighting in the development of the factors of awakening.

original: “Sāvakena hi pattabbaṃ, sabbameva kataṃ mayā;
analyzed: sāvakena hi pattabbam sabbam eva katam mayā
translated: “What is to be attained by a disciple, all that has been done by me;

original: Lokanāthaṃ ṭhapetvāna, sadiso me na vijjati.
analyzed: lokanātham sadisaḥ me na vijjati
translated: Except for the Lord of the World, there is no one equal to me.

original: “Samāpattīnaṃ kusalo, jhānavimokkhāna khippapaṭilābhī;
analyzed: samāpattīnam kusalaḥ jhāna vimokkhāna khippa paṭilābhī
translated: “Skilled in the attainments, quickly attaining the jhānas and liberations,

original: Bojjhaṅgabhāvanārato, sāvakaguṇapāramigatosmi.
analyzed: sāvaka guṇa pārami gataḥ asmi
translated: Delighting in the development of the factors of awakening, I have reached the perfection of the qualities of a disciple.

original: “Sāvakaguṇenapi phussena, buddhiyā parisuttamabhāravā;
analyzed: sāvaka guṇena api phussena buddhiyā
translated: “By the qualities of a disciple, by the supreme wisdom of Phussa,

original: Yaṃ saddhāsaṅgahitaṃ cittaṃ, sadā sabrahmacārīsu.🔽“Uddhatavisova sappo, chinnavisāṇova usabho;
analyzed: yam saddhā saṅga hitam cittam sadā sabrahmacārīsu  uddhata visaḥ uva sappaḥ chinna visāṇaḥ uva usabhaḥ
translated: The mind that is full of faith in spiritual companions,🔽Like a snake whose fangs have been pulled out, like a bull whose horns have been cut off,

original: Nikkhittamānadappova, upemi garugāravena gaṇaṃ.
analyzed: upemi garu gāravena gaṇam
translated: Like a fire whose fuel has been removed, I approach the assembly with great respect.

original: “Yadi rūpinī bhaveyya, paññā me vasumatīpi na sameyya;
analyzed: yadi rūpinī bhaveyya paññā me vasumatī api na sameyya
translated: If wisdom were to have a form, the entire earth would not be enough to contain it.

original: Anomadassissa bhagavato, phalametaṃ ñāṇathavanāya.
analyzed: anomadassissa bhagavataḥ phalam etam ñāṇa thavanāya
translated: This is the fruit of the knowledge of the forest, of the Blessed One Anomadassī.

original: “Pavattitaṃ dhammacakkaṃ, sakyaputtena tādinā;
analyzed: pavattitam dhamma cakkam sakya puttena tādinā
translated: The wheel of Dhamma has been set in motion by the Tathāgata, the son of the Sakyans.

original: Anuvattemahaṃ sammā, ñāṇathavanāyidaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: anuvattemaham sammā ñāṇa thavanāya idam phalam
translated: I follow the right path, this is the fruit of the knowledge of the forest.

original: “Mā me kadāci pāpiccho, kusīto hīnavīriyo;
analyzed: mā me kadāci pāpa iccho kusītaḥ hīna vīriyo
translated: May I never be a wicked person, lazy, with inferior energy,

original: Appassuto anācāro, sameto ahu katthaci.
analyzed: appassutaḥ anācāraḥ sametaḥ ahu katthaci
translated: Unlearned, of bad conduct, associated with anyone anywhere.

original: “Bahussuto ca medhāvī, sīlesu susamāhito;
analyzed: bahu sutaḥ ca medhāvī sīlesu su samāhitaḥ
translated: Learned and wise, well-composed in morality,

original: Cetosamathānuyutto, api muddhani tiṭṭhatu.
analyzed: cetaḥ samatha anuyuttaḥ api muddhani tiṭṭhatu
translated: Devoted to mental calm, may he stand on my head.

original: “Taṃ vo vadāmi bhaddante, tāvantettha samāgatā;
analyzed: tam vaḥ vadāmi bhaddante tāvantā itthā samāgatā
translated: I say to you, good sirs, all assembled here,

original: Appicchā hotha santuṭṭhā, jhāyī jhānaratā sadā.
analyzed: appicchāḥ hotha santuṭṭhāḥ jhāyī jhāna ratā sadā
translated: Be content with little, always be meditators, delighting in meditation.

original: “Yamahaṃ paṭhamaṃ disvā, virajo vimalo ahuṃ;
analyzed: yam aham paṭhamam disvā virajaḥ vimalaḥ
translated: Whom I first saw, who was free from passion and pure,

original: So me ācariyo dhīro, assaji nāma sāvako.
analyzed: saḥ me ācariyaḥ dhīraḥ assaji nāma sāvakaḥ
translated: He is my wise teacher, the disciple named Assaji.

original: “Tassāhaṃ vāhasā ajja, dhammasenāpatī ahuṃ;
analyzed: tassa aham vāhasā ajja dhamma senāpatī ahum
translated: “By the power of that deed, I have become today the general of the Dhamma.

original: Sabbattha pāramiṃ patvā, viharāmi anāsavo.
analyzed: sabbattha pāramim patvā viharāmi anāsavaḥ
translated: Having reached perfection in all things, I live on, passionless.

original: “Yo me ācariyo āsi, assaji nāma sāvako;
analyzed: yaḥ me ācariyaḥ āsi assaji nāma sāvakaḥ
translated: “My teacher was a disciple of the Buddha named Assaji.

original: Yassaṃ disāyaṃ vasati, ussīsamhi karomahaṃ.
analyzed: disā ayam vasati ussīsamhi karomaham
translated: In whatever direction he lives, I raise my umbrella of state.

original: “Mama kammaṃ saritvāna, gotamo sakyapuṅgavo;
analyzed: mama kammam saritvāna gotamaḥ sakya puṅgavaḥ
translated: Remembering my deed, the Buddha, the chief of the Sakyans,

original: Bhikkhusaṅghe nisīditvā, aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapesi maṃ.
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghe nisīditvā aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapesi mama
translated: sitting in the midst of the Bhikkhu Sangha, placed me in the foremost rank.

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.🔽Aparabhāge pana satthā jetavanamahāvihāre ariyagaṇamajjhe nisinno attano sāvake tena
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti  aparabhāge pana satthā jetavana mahāvihāre ariya gaṇa majjhe nisinno attano sāvake tena
translated: I have burned up all my lusts. … I have done the Buddha’s bidding.”

original: tena guṇavisesena etadagge ṭhapento – “etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, mama sāvakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: tena guṇa visesena etad agge ṭhapentaḥ etad aggam bhikkhave mama sāvakānam bhikkhūnam
translated: Later, the Teacher, sitting in the midst of the Congregation of the Noble Ones in the Great Monastery in Jetavana, as he pointed out the various excellences of his disciples, declared him foremost among those who were possessed of great wisdom, saying, “Among my disciples who are possessed of great wisdom, the foremost is the Elder Sāriputta.”

original: mahāpaññānaṃ yadidaṃ sāriputto”ti theraṃ mahāpaññabhāvena etadagge ṭhapesi. So evaṃ
analyzed: mahā paññānam yat idam sāriputto ti theram mahā pañña bhāvena etad agge ṭhapesi saḥ evam
translated: Thus did he place the Elder in the foremost rank as one possessed of great wisdom.

original: sāvakapāramīñāṇassa matthakaṃ patvā dhammasenāpatiṭṭhāne patiṭṭhahitvā sattahitaṃ
analyzed: sāvaka pāramī ñāṇassa matthakam patvā dhamma senāpatiṭṭhāne patiṭṭhahitvā satta hitam
translated: Having reached the summit of knowledge of the perfection of discipleship, having been established in the position of general of the Dhamma, and having fulfilled the welfare of the world for the period of time allotted to him,

original: karonto ekadivasaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ attano cariyavibhāvanamukhena aññaṃ byākaronto –🔽“Yathācārī yathāsato satīmā, yatasaṅkappajjhāyi appamatto;
analyzed: karontaḥ eka divasam sabrahmacārīnam attano cariya vibhāvana mukhena aññam byākarontaḥ  yathā cārī yathā satīmā yata saṅkappa jhāyī appamattaḥ
translated: While doing so, one day, he gave a discourse on his own conduct to his fellow monks, in the form of a reply to a question.

original: Ajjhattarato samāhitatto, eko santusito tamāhu bhikkhuṃ.
analyzed: ekaḥ santusitaḥ tam āhu bhikkhum
translated: “He who is mindful, who is thus composed, who is thus concentrated, who is thus guarded, who is thus self-controlled, who is thus tranquil, who is thus self-awakened, who is thus perfected, who is thus liberated, who is thus completely cooled, is called a monk.”

original: “Allaṃ sukkhaṃ vā bhuñjanto, na bāḷhaṃ suhito siyā;
analyzed: allam sukkham vā bhuñjantaḥ na bāḷham su hitaḥ siyā
translated: “Whether eating coarse or fine food, he should not be overly fond of it;

original: Ūnūdaro mitāhāro, sato bhikkhu paribbaje.
analyzed: ūnūdaraḥ mita āhāraḥ sataḥ bhikkhu paribbaje
translated: With a small stomach and little food, the mindful monk should wander.

original: “Cattāro pañca ālope, abhutvā udakaṃ pive;
analyzed: cattāraḥ pañca ālope a bhutvā udakam pive
translated: “Having eaten four or five mouthfuls without drinking water,

original: Alaṃ phāsuvihārāya, pahitattassa bhikkhuno.
analyzed: alam phāsu vihārāya pahitattassa bhikkhuno
translated: That is enough for the monk who is intent on living comfortably.

original: “Kappiyaṃ tañce chādeti, cīvaraṃ idamatthikaṃ;
analyzed: kappiyam tat ce chādeti cīvaraṃ idam atthikaṃ
translated: “If he covers himself with what is allowable, with a robe for the sake of modesty,

original: Alaṃ phāsuvihārāya, pahitattassa bhikkhuno.
analyzed: alam phāsu vihārāya pahitattassa bhikkhuno
translated: That is enough for the living comfortably of the monk who is intent.

original: “Pallaṅkena nisinnassa, jaṇṇuke nābhivassati;
analyzed: pallaṅkena nisinnassa jaṇṇuke na abhivassati
translated: “When sitting cross-legged, the rain does not touch his knees;

original: Alaṃ phāsuvihārāya, pahitattassa bhikkhuno.
analyzed: alam phāsu vihārāya pahitattassa bhikkhuno
translated: That is enough for the living comfortably of the monk who is intent.

original: “Yo sukhaṃ dukkhato adda, dukkhamaddakkhi sallato;
analyzed: yaḥ sukham dukkhataḥ adda dukkham addakkhi sallataḥ
translated: “He who sees pleasure as pain, and pain as a dart,

original: Ubhayantarena nāhosi, kena lokasmi kiṃ siyā.
analyzed: ubhayantarena kim siyā
translated: And is not between the two, what in the world could be for him?”

original: “Mā me kadāci pāpiccho, kusīto hīnavīriyo;
analyzed: mā me kadāci pāpa iccho kusītaḥ hīna vīriyo
translated: “May I never be a lustful, lazy, weak-willed person,

original: Appassuto anādaro, kena lokasmi kiṃ siyā.
analyzed: appassutaḥ anādaro kena lokasmi kim siyā
translated: unlearned, disrespectful. What would I be in the world?

original: “Bahussuto ca medhāvī, sīlesu susamāhito;
analyzed: bahu sutaḥ ca medhāvī sīlesu su samāhitaḥ
translated: “The learned and wise one, well-composed in virtue,

original: Cetosamathamanuyutto, api muddhani tiṭṭhatu.
analyzed: cetaḥ samatham anuyuttaḥ api muddhani tiṭṭhatu
translated: attuned to mental stillness, may he stand on my head.

original: “Yo papañcamanuyutto, papañcābhirato mago;
analyzed: yaḥ papañca manuyuttaḥ papañca abhirataḥ magaḥ
translated: “The fool who pursues proliferation, delights in proliferation,

original: Virādhayī so nibbānaṃ, yogakkhemaṃ anuttaraṃ.
analyzed: virādhayī saḥ nibbānam yogakkhemam anuttaram
translated: disdains Nibbāna, the unsurpassed security from bondage.

original: “Yo ca papañcaṃ hitvāna, nippapañcapathe rato;
analyzed: yaḥ ca papañcam hitvāna nippapañca pathe rataḥ
translated: “But the one who, having abandoned proliferation, delights in the path of non-proliferation,

original: Ārādhayī so nibbānaṃ, yogakkhemaṃ anuttaraṃ.
analyzed: ārādhayī saḥ nibbānam yogakkhemam anuttaram
translated: attains Nibbāna, the unsurpassed security from bondage.

original: “Gāme vā yadi vāraññe, ninne vā yadi vā thale;
analyzed: gāme vā yadi vā araññe ninne vā yadi vā thale
translated: “Whether in a village or in the forest, in a low-lying or a high-lying place,

original: Yattha arahanto viharanti, taṃ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṃ.
analyzed: yattha arahantaḥ viharanti tam bhūmirāmaṇeyyakam
translated: wherever the Worthy Ones dwell, that place is delightful.

original: “Ramaṇīyāni araññāni, yattha na ramatī jano;
analyzed: ramaṇīyāni araññāni yattha na ramatī jano
translated: “Delightful are the wilderness areas, where people take no delight,

original: Vītarāgā ramissanti, na te kāmagavesino.
analyzed: vīta rāgāḥ ramissanti na te kāma gavesinaḥ
translated: the dispassionate will delight there, not those who seek sensual pleasures.🔽“One should associate with such a wise one,

original: “Nidhīnaṃva pavattāraṃ, yaṃ passe vajjadassinaṃ;🔽Niggayhavādiṃ medhāviṃ, tādisaṃ paṇḍitaṃ bhaje;
analyzed: nidhīnam iva pavattāram yam passe vajja dassinam  niggayha vādim medhāvim tādisam paṇḍitam bhaje
translated: who sees his own faults,🔽for one who associates with such a one

original: Tādisaṃ bhajamānassa, seyyo hoti na pāpiyo.
analyzed: tādisam bhajamānassa seyyaḥ hoti na pāpiyaḥ
translated: only improves and does not decline.”

original: “Ovadeyyānusāseyya, asabbhā ca nivāraye;
analyzed: ovadeyya anusāseyya a sabbhā ca nivāraye
translated: “One should advise and instruct, and keep out the unrighteous;

original: Satañhi so piyo hoti, asataṃ hoti appiyo.🔽“Aññassa bhagavā buddho, dhammaṃ desesi cakkhumā;
analyzed: satan hi saḥ piyaḥ hoti asatam hoti appiyaḥ  aññassa bhagavā buddhaḥ dhammam desesi cakkhumā
translated: For he is dear to the righteous, but not to the unrighteous.🔽“The Blessed One, the Buddha, taught the Dhamma to another;

original: Dhamme desiyamānamhi, sotamādhesimatthiko;
analyzed: dhamme desiyamānamhi
translated: While the Dhamma was being taught, he lent an ear with a desire to understand.

original: Taṃ me amoghaṃ savanaṃ, vimuttomhi anāsavo.
analyzed: tam me amogham savanam vimuttaḥ asmi anāsavaḥ
translated: My hearing of it was not in vain, I am liberated, without taints.

original: “Neva pubbenivāsāya, napi dibbassa cakkhuno;🔽Cetopariyāya iddhiyā, cutiyā upapattiyā;
analyzed: na iva pubbenivāsāya na pi dibbassa cakkhuno  cetaḥ upariyāya iddhiyai cutiyai upapattiyai
translated: “Neither for the knowledge of past lives, nor for the divine eye,🔽Nor for the knowledge of others’ minds, nor for the destruction of the taints,

original: Sotadhātuvisuddhiyā, paṇidhī me na vijjati.
analyzed: paṇidhī me na vijjati
translated: Do I have any aspiration.🔽“Having gone forth from the home life into homelessness,

original: “Rukkhamūlaṃva nissāya, muṇḍo saṅghāṭipāruto;
analyzed: rukkha mūlam va nissāya muṇḍaḥ saṅghāṭi pārutaḥ
translated: Shaven-headed, wearing a patchwork cloak,

original: Paññāya uttamo thero, upatissova jhāyati.
analyzed: paññāya uttamaḥ theraḥ upatissaḥ uva jhāyati
translated: The elder Uttiya, supreme in wisdom, meditates.

original: “Avitakkaṃ samāpanno, sammāsambuddhasāvako;
analyzed: a vitakkam samāpannaḥ sammāsambuddha sāvakaḥ
translated: “The disciple of the Perfectly Enlightened One, having attained the state of no-thought,

original: Ariyena tuṇhībhāvena, upeto hoti tāvade.
analyzed: ariyena tuṇhībhāvena upetaḥ hoti tāvade
translated: Is then endowed with noble silence.

original: “Yathāpi pabbato selo, acalo suppatiṭṭhito;
analyzed: yathā api pabbataḥ selaḥ acalaḥ su patiṭṭhitaḥ
translated: “Just as a rock, a mountain, is unshakable, well-established,

original: Evaṃ mohakkhayā bhikkhu, pabbatova na vedhati.
analyzed: evam moha kkhayā bhikkhu pabbataḥ iva na vedhati
translated: So too, with the destruction of delusion, the bhikkhu does not tremble, like a mountain.

original: “Anaṅgaṇassa posassa, niccaṃ sucigavesino;
analyzed: anaṅgaṇassa posassa niccam suci gavesinaḥ
translated: “For the one without blemish, the one who always seeks purity,

original: Vālaggamattaṃ pāpassa, abbhamattaṃva khāyati.
analyzed: vālagga mattam pāpassa abbha mattam va khāyati
translated: Even a little bit of evil appears as big as a strand of hair.

original: “Nābhinandāmi maraṇaṃ, nābhinandāmi jīvitaṃ;
analyzed: na abhinandāmi maraṇam na abhinandāmi jīvitam
translated: I do not delight in death, nor do I delight in life;

original: Nikkhipissaṃ imaṃ kāyaṃ, sampajāno paṭissato.
analyzed: nikkhipissam imam kāyam sampajānaḥ paṭissataḥ
translated: I will lay down this body, fully aware and mindful.

original: “Nābhinandāmi maraṇaṃ, nābhinandāmi jīvitaṃ;
analyzed: na abhinandāmi maraṇam na abhinandāmi jīvitam
translated: I do not delight in death, nor do I delight in life;

original: Kālañca paṭikaṅkhāmi, nibbisaṃ bhatako yathā.
analyzed: kālam ca paṭikaṅkhāmi nibbisam bhatakaḥ yathā
translated: I will wait for the time, like a servant for his wages.

original: “Ubhayena midaṃ maraṇameva, nāmaraṇaṃ pacchā vā pure vā;
analyzed: ubhayena mā idam maraṇam eva na amaraṇam pacchā vā pure vā
translated: This death is the same in both cases, whether it comes later or sooner;

original: Paṭipajjatha mā vinassatha, khaṇo vo mā upaccagā.
analyzed: paṭipajjatha mā vinassatha khaṇaḥ vaḥ mā upaccagā
translated: Practice the path, do not be negligent, lest the time pass for you.

original: “Nagaraṃ yathā paccantaṃ, guttaṃ santarabāhiraṃ;
analyzed: nagaram yathā paccantam guttam santara bāhiram
translated: Just as a frontier fortress is well supplied with timber and grass,

original: Evaṃ gopetha attānaṃ, khaṇo vo mā upaccagā;
analyzed: evam gopetha attānam khaṇaḥ vaḥ mā upaccagā
translated: so guard yourselves well, lest the time pass for you.

original: Khaṇātītā hi socanti, nirayamhi samappitā.
analyzed: khaṇātītāḥ hi socanti nirayamhi
translated: For those who have let the time pass, who have fallen into hell, they lament.

original: “Upasanto uparato, mantabhāṇī anuddhato;
analyzed: upasantaḥ uparataḥ manta bhāṇī anuddhataḥ
translated: The one who is calm, restrained, speaking truth, not puffed up,

original: Dhunāti pāpake dhamme, dumapattaṃva māluto.
analyzed: dhunāti pāpake dhamme duma pattam iva mālutaḥ
translated: shakes off evil qualities, like a horse-hair from a ball of lac.

original: “Upasanto uparato, mantabhāṇī anuddhato;
analyzed: upasantaḥ uparataḥ manta bhāṇī anuddhataḥ
translated: The one who is calm, restrained, speaking truth, not puffed up,

original: Appāsi pāpake dhamme, dumapattaṃva māluto.
analyzed: appāsi pāpake dhamme duma pattam iva mālutaḥ
translated: shakes off evil qualities, like a horse-hair from a ball of lac.

original: “Upasanto anāyāso, vippasanno anāvilo;
analyzed: upasantaḥ anāyāsaḥ vippasannaḥ anāvilaḥ
translated: The one who is calm, not agitated, clear, unclouded,

original: Kalyāṇasīlo medhāvī, dukkhassantakaro siyā.
analyzed: kalyāṇa sīlaḥ medhāvī dukkhassanta karaḥ siyā
translated: The one of good character and intelligence can put an end to suffering.

original: “Na vissase ekatiyesu evaṃ, agārisu pabbajitesu cāpi;
analyzed: na vissase ekatiyesu evam agārisu pabbajitesu ca api
translated: “One should not trust just anyone, whether a householder or one gone forth;

original: Sādhūpi hutvāna asādhu honti, asādhu hutvā puna sādhu honti.
analyzed: sādhu upi hutvāna asādhu honti asādhu hutvā puna sādhu honti
translated: They may be good, but then become bad, and having been bad, may again become good.

original: “Kāmacchando ca byāpādo, thinamiddhañca bhikkhuno;
analyzed: kāmacchandaḥ ca byāpādaḥ thinam iddham ca bhikkhuno
translated: Sensual desire, ill will, and sloth and torpor in a monk,

original: Uddhaccaṃ vicikicchā ca, pañcete cittakelisā.
analyzed: uddhaccam vicikicchā ca pañca ete citta keli sā
translated: agitation and worry, and doubt—these are the five hindrances.

original: “Yassa sakkariyamānassa, asakkārena cūbhayaṃ;
analyzed: yassa sakkariyamānassa a sakkārena ca ubhayam
translated: For one who is honored, but who is not honored,

original: Samādhi na vikampati, appamādavihārino.
analyzed: na vikampati appamāda vihārino
translated: his concentration does not waver, he who dwells heedful.

original: “Taṃ jhāyinaṃ sātatikaṃ, sukhumadiṭṭhipassakaṃ;
analyzed: tam jhāyinam sātatikam sukhuma diṭṭhi passakam
translated: The one who is in jhāna, who is full of joy, who sees subtle things,

original: Upādānakkhayārāmaṃ, āhu sappuriso iti.
analyzed: upādāna khaya ārāmam āhu sappurisaḥ iti
translated: who delights in the destruction of attachment, he is called a true person.

original: “Mahāsamuddo pathavī, pabbato anilopi ca;
analyzed: mahā samuddaḥ pathavī pabbataḥ anilaḥ api ca
translated: The ocean, the earth, a mountain, and the wind—

original: Upamāya na yujjanti, satthu varavimuttiyā.
analyzed: upamāya na yujjanti satthu vara vimuttiyā
translated: they are not suitable as a simile for the Teacher’s supreme liberation.

original: “Cakkānuvattako thero, mahāñāṇī samāhito;
analyzed: cakkānuvattakaḥ theraḥ mahā ñāṇī samāhito
translated: The elder who is a follower of the wheel, who has great knowledge and is concentrated,

original: Pathavāpaggisamāno, na rajjati na dussati.
analyzed: pathavā apaggi samānaḥ na rajjati na dussati
translated: who is equal to the earth, water, and fire, does not get excited or upset.

original: “Paññāpāramitaṃ patto, mahābuddhi mahāmati;
analyzed: paññāpāramitam pattaḥ mahā buddhi mahāmati
translated: Having attained the perfection of wisdom, the one of great understanding and great wisdom,

original: Ajaḷo jaḷasamāno, sadā carati nibbuto.
analyzed: ajaḷaḥ jaḷa samānaḥ sadā carati nibbutaḥ
translated: the one who is not dull, who is equal to the dull, always goes about extinguished.

original: “Pariciṇṇo mayā satthā…pe… bhavanettisamūhatā.
analyzed: pariciṇṇaḥ mayā bhavanetti samūha tā
translated: “The Teacher has been served by me, etc.

original: “Sampādethappamādena, esā me anusāsanī;
analyzed: sampādetha appamādena esā me anusāsanī
translated: “Fulfil this, with heedfulness, as my instruction;

original: Handāhaṃ parinibbissaṃ, vippamuttomhi sabbadhī”ti. –
analyzed: handa aham parinibbissam vippamuttaḥ mhi sabbadhi iti
translated: Now I will attain Nibbāna, I am released in every way.”

original: Imā gāthā abhāsi. Imā hi kāci gāthā therena bhāsitā, kāci theraṃ ārabbha bhagavatā bhāsitā, sabbā pacchā attano cariyapavedanavasena therena bhāsitattā therasseva gāthā ahesuṃ.
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi imāḥ hi kāci gāthā therena bhāsitā kāci theram ārabbha bhagavatā bhāsitā sabbā pacchā attano cariya pavedana vasena therena bhāsita ttā therassa iva gāthāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: These verses were spoken. For some of these verses were spoken by the Elder himself, and some were spoken by the Blessed One referring to the Elder. But all were spoken by the Elder himself later on in the recital of his own conduct.

original: Tattha yathācārīti yathā kāyādīhi saṃyato, saṃvuto hutvā carati viharati, yathācaraṇasīloti🔽vā yathācārī, sīlasampannoti attho. Yathāsatoti yathāsanto. Gāthāsukhatthañhi anunāsikalopaṃ
analyzed: tattha yathācārī iti yathā kāya ādīhi saṃyataḥ saṃvutaḥ hutvā carati viharati yathā caraṇa sīlaḥ iti  vā yathā cārī sīla sampanno ti atthaḥ yathā sato ti yathā santaḥ gāthā sukha attham hi anunāsika lopam
translated: Herein, as to how he fares : how he fares, how he lives, by being restrained and controlled in body, etc., is as he fares, or as his conduct is ;🔽the meaning is, he is endowed with virtue. As to how he is calm : as to how he is peaceful. For the demonstrative pronoun is used in the sense of an indefinite term

original: katvā niddeso kato, santo viya, ariyehi nibbisesoti attho. Satīmāti paramāya satiyā
analyzed: katvā niddeso kataḥ santaḥ viya ariyehi nibbiseso ti attho paramāya satiyā
translated: with elision of the vowel ; the meaning is, as if he were peaceful, as if he were a noble one. As to how he is mindful : as to how he is endowed with the highest mindfulness. As to how he meditates with directed thought :

original: samannāgato. Yatasaṅkappajjhāyīti sabbaso micchāsaṅkappaṃ pahāya nekkhammasaṅkappādivasena
analyzed: samannāgataḥ yata saṅkappa jhāyī iti sabbaso micchā saṅkappam pahāya nekkhamma saṅkappa ādi vasena
translated: having abandoned all wrong thoughts,

original: saṃyatasaṅkappo hutvā ārammaṇūpanijjhānena lakkhaṇūpanijjhānena ca jhāyanasīlo. Appamattoti🔽tasmiṃyeva yathācāribhāve yatasaṅkappo hutvā jhāyanena ca pamādarahito sabbattha
analyzed: saṃyata saṅkappaḥ hutvā ārammaṇa upanijjhānena lakkhaṇa upanijjhānena ca jhāyana sīlaḥ appamatto ti  tasmin yeva yathācāri bhāve yata saṅkappaḥ hutvā jhāyanena ca pamāda rahitaḥ sabbattha
translated: and his thoughts are restrained. He is “meditative” in that he is devoted to meditation by directing his mind to the object and by discerning its characteristics. He is “vigilant”

original: suppatiṭṭhitasatisampajañño. Ajjhattaratoti gocarajjhatte kammaṭṭhānabhāvanāya abhirato.🔽Samāhitattoti tāya eva bhāvanāya ekaggacitto. Ekoti asahāyo gaṇasaṃsaggaṃ, kilesasaṃsaggañca🔽pahāya kāyavivekaṃ, cittavivekañca paribrūhayanto. Santusitoti paccayasantosena ca
analyzed: su patiṭṭhita sati sampajaññaḥ ajjhatta rataḥ ti gocara jjhatte kammaṭṭhāna bhāvanāya abhirataḥ  samāhita ttaḥ ti tāya eva bhāvanāya ekagga cittaḥ ekaḥ ti asahāyaḥ gaṇa saṃsaggam kilesa saṃsaggam ca  pahāya kāya vivekam citta vivekañca paribrūhayantaḥ santusito ti paccaya santosena ca
translated: in that he is intent on his conduct and on his thoughts in the way described, and he is free from negligence in his meditation. He is “mindful” in that he is well established in mindfulness and full awareness in all his postures. He is “delighted in seclusion” in that he delights in the seclusion of the domain of his meditation subject.🔽He is “concentrated” in that his mind is unified by that meditation. He is “alone” in that he has no companion, and he abandons the company of the multitude and the company of defilements, thus increasing bodily and mental seclusion. He is “content” in that he is truly content and satisfied with the contentment that is the condition for his meditation and with the delight in meditation.

original: bhāvanārāmasantosena ca sammadeva tusito tuṭṭho. Bhāvanāya hi uparūpari visesaṃ āvahantiyā
analyzed: bhāvanā ārāma santosena ca sammadā eva tusitaḥ tuṭṭhaḥ bhāvanāya hi upari upari visesam āvahantiyā
translated: For as meditation progresses and one attains higher and higher distinction,

original: uḷāraṃ pītipāmojjaṃ uppajjati, matthakaṃ pattāya pana vattabbameva natthi. Tamāhu
analyzed: uḷāram pīti pāmojjam uppajjati matthakam pattāya pana vattabbam eva natthi tam āhu
translated: an exalted rapture and gladness arise. But when it reaches its peak, there is nothing more to say.

original: bhikkhunti taṃ evarūpaṃ puggalaṃ sikkhattayapāripūriyā bhayaṃ ikkhanatāya bhinnakilesatāya
analyzed: bhikkhunti tam evarūpam puggalam sikkhattaya pāripūriyā bhayam ikkhanatāya bhinna kilesa tāya
translated: A bhikkhu: a person who has gone forth in this Dispensation.🔽He is afraid of the three kinds of failure to fulfil the three trainings, and he sees fear in what is subject to fear.

original: ca bhikkhūti vadanti.
analyzed: ca bhikkhū iti vadanti
translated: A bhikkhu is so called because he sees danger in what is blameworthy, because he is broken out from the round of rebirths, and because he is broken out from the defilements.

original: Idāni yathāvuttasantosadvaye paccayasantosaṃ tāva dassento “allaṃ sukkhaṃ vā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni yathā vutta santosa dvaye paccaya santosam tāva dassento allam sukkham vā ti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to show the two kinds of contentment stated thus, he said, “If he gets coarse or fine” , beginning with the external condition.

original: Tattha allanti sappiādiupasekena tintaṃ siniddhaṃ. Sukkhanti tadabhāvena lūkhaṃ.
analyzed: tattha allanti sappi ādi upasekena tintam siniddham sukkhanti tad abhāvena lūkham
translated: Herein, coarse means rough, dry, etc., because it is not mixed with ghee, etc. Fine means the opposite.🔽The word or is in the sense of non-restriction.🔽He is content with what he gets, whether coarse or fine.

original: Vā-saddo aniyamattho, allaṃ vā sukkhaṃ vāti. Bāḷhanti ativiya. Suhitoti dhāto na🔽siyāti attho. Kathaṃ pana siyāti āha “ūnūdaro mitāhāro”ti paṇītaṃ lūkhaṃ vāpi bhojanaṃ
analyzed: vā saddaḥ aniyama atthaḥ allam vā sukkham vā ati bāḷhanti ativiya su hitaḥ iti dhāto na  siyā ti attho katham pana siyā iti āha ūnūdaraḥ mita āhāraḥ iti paṇītam lūkham vā api bhojanam
translated: Suhito means “he has gone well” .🔽How has he gone well? He said: “with a lean belly and a moderate amount of food.”🔽A bhikkhu who eats neither too much nor too little, whether the food is choice or coarse,

original: bhuñjanto bhikkhu yāvadatthaṃ abhuñjitvā ūnūdaro sallahukudaro, tato eva mitāhāro🔽parimitabhojano aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ āhāraṃ āharanto tattha mattaññutāya paccavekkhaṇasatiyā
analyzed: bhuñjantaḥ bhikkhu yāvadattham a bhuñjitvā ūnūdaraḥ san lahu kudaraḥ eva mita āhāro  parimita bhojanaḥ aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam āhāram āharantaḥ tattha mattaññu tāya paccavekkhaṇa satiyā
translated: is one who has a lean belly, a light belly, and a moderate amount of food,

original: ca sato hutvā paribbaje vihareyya.
analyzed: ca sataḥ hutvā paribbaje vihareyya
translated: because he eats a moderate amount. He should wander about, he should live, mindful, with regard to that, by means of the mindfulness of moderation and the mindfulness of reviewing.

original: Yathā pana ūnūdaro mitāhāro ca nāma hoti, taṃ dassetuṃ “cattāro”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: yathā pana ūnūdaraḥ mita āhāro ca nāma hoti tam dassetum cattāro tiādi vuttam tattha
translated: But how is one a man of little food and a man of measured food? To show this, the following is said:

original: abhutvāti cattāro vā pañca vā ālope kabaḷe abhuñjitvā tattakassa āhārassa okāsaṃ🔽ṭhapetvā pānīyaṃ piveyya. Ayañhi āhāre sallahukavutti. Nibbānañhi pesitacittassa
analyzed: a bhutvā ati cattāraḥ vā pañca vā ālope kabaḷe a bhuñjitvā tattakassa āhārassa okāsam  ṭhapetvā pānīyam piveyya ayam hi āhāre sat lahuka vutti nibbānam hi pesita cittassa
translated: “Without eating”: without eating four or five mouthfuls of food, he should drink water, leaving a space

original: bhikkhuno phāsuvihārāya jhānādīnaṃ adhigamayogyatāya sukhavihārāya alaṃ pariyattanti🔽attho. Iminā kucchiparihāriyaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ vadanto piṇḍapāte itarītarasantosaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: bhikkhuno phāsu vihārāya jhāna ādīnam adhigama yogyatāya sukha vihārāya alam pariyattanti  iminā kucchi parihāriyam piṇḍapātam vadantaḥ piṇḍapāte itarītara santosam dasseti
translated: above for that amount of food. For this is a man who is easy to feed. The meaning is that it is enough for the bhikkhu whose mind is bent on Nibbāna to live comfortably and happily by attaining jhāna, etc.,🔽since it is enough for him to live happily by attaining jhāna, etc., for the sake of living in comfort with a mind free from preoccupation with food.🔽By this he shows contentment with whatever alms he gets, whether coarse or fine.

original: “Bhutvānā”ti vā pāṭho, so catupañcālopamattenāpi āhārena sarīraṃ yāpetuṃ samatthassa🔽ativiya thirapakatikassa puggalassa vasena vutto siyā, uttaragāthāhipi saṃsandati🔽eva appakasseva cīvarassa senāsanassa ca vakkhamānattā.
analyzed: vā pāṭhaḥ so catu pañcāla upamattena api āhārena sarīram yāpetum samatthassa 🔽ativiya thira pakatikassa puggalassa vasena vuttaḥ siyā uttara gāthāhi pi saṃsandati 🔽eva appakassa iva cīvarassa senāsanassa ca vakkhamānattā
translated: Or the reading may be “bhuñjitvāna,” in which case the statement would apply to the person who is able to maintain his body with only four or five mouthfuls of food and who is very strong.

original: Kappiyanti yaṃ kappiyakappiyānulomesu khomādīsu aññataranti attho. Tañce chādetīti
analyzed: kappiyanti yam kappiya kappiya anulomesu khoma ādīsu aññataranti tam ce chādeti iti
translated: What is allowable: the meaning is, any one of the kinds beginning with khomā, which are allowable and conform to the allowable.

original: kappiyaṃ cīvaraṃ samānaṃ chādetabbaṃ ṭhānaṃ chādeti ce, satthārā anuññātajātiyaṃ🔽santaṃ heṭṭhimantena anuññātapamāṇayuttaṃ ce hotīti attho. Idamatthikanti idaṃ payojanatthaṃ
analyzed: kappiyam cīvaram samānam chādetabbam ṭhānam chādeti ce satthārā anuññāta jātiyam  santam heṭṭhimantena anuññāta pamāṇa yuttam ce hoti iti attho idam atthikam ti idam payojana attham
translated: If he conceals it: if he conceals a place where a robe that is allowable as robe-material should be concealed,🔽the meaning is, if it is of a kind allowed by the Teacher, and if it is the right size as allowed by the Teacher.🔽For this purpose: for this purpose stated by the Teacher,

original: satthārā vuttapayojanatthaṃ yāvadeva sītādipaṭighātanatthañceva hirīkopīnapaṭicchādanatthañcāti
analyzed: satthārā vutta payojana attham yāvat eva sītā ādi paṭighātana ttham ca iva hirī kopīna paṭicchādana ttham ca ati
translated: the meaning is, for the purpose of warding off cold, etc., and for the purpose of concealing the private parts.

original: attho. Etena kāyaparihāriyaṃ cīvaraṃ tattha itarītarasantosañca vadati.🔽Pallaṅkena nisinnassāti pallaṅkaṃ vuccati samantato ūrubaddhāsanaṃ, tena nisinnassa,
analyzed: attho etena kāya parihāriyam cīvaram tattha itarītara santosam ca vadati  pallaṅkena nisinnassa ati pallaṅkam vuccati samantataḥ ūru baddha āsanam tena nisinnassa
translated: This shows that the robe is for the protection of the body and that he should be satisfied with whatever is obtained.🔽If he sits cross-legged: a cross-legged posture is one in which the legs are drawn up crosswise and the feet are placed on the opposite thighs.🔽If he sits in that way, the meaning is, if he sits with his legs drawn up crosswise and his elbows on his knees.

original: tisandhipallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā nisinnassāti attho. Jaṇṇuke nābhivassatīti yassaṃ kuṭiyaṃ
analyzed: ti sandhi pallaṅkam ābhujitvā nisinnassa ati attho jaṇṇuke na abhivassati iti yassam kuṭiyam
translated: If it does not rain on his knees:

original: tathā nisinnassa deve vassante jaṇṇukadvayaṃ vassodakena na temiyati, ettakampi sabbapariyantasenāsanaṃ,
analyzed: tathā nisinnassa deve vassante jaṇṇuka dvayam vassa udakena na temiyati ettakam pi sabba pariyanta senāsanam
translated: When it rains, the two knees are not wetted by the rain. This much is the whole extent of the lodging.

original: sakkā hi tattha nisīditvā atthakāmarūpena kulaputtena sadatthaṃ nipphādetuṃ. Tenāha
analyzed: sakkā hi tattha nisīditvā attha kāmarūpena kula puttena sadattham nipphādetum tena āha
translated: For it is possible for a clansman who desires his own good to achieve his own good by sitting there. Hence it was said:🔽“Enough for the bhikkhu who is ardent,

original: “alaṃ phāsuvihārāya, pahitattassa bhikkhuno”ti.
analyzed: alam phāsu vihārāya pahitattassa bhikkhuno ti
translated: To live in any kind of lodging.”

original: Evaṃ thero imāhi catūhi gāthāhi ye te bhikkhū mahicchā asantuṭṭhā, tesaṃ paramukkaṃsagataṃ
analyzed: evam theraḥ imāhi catūhi gāthāhi ye te bhikkhū mahicchāḥ asantuṭṭhāḥ tesam paramukkaṃsa gatam
translated: So the Elder, by these four stanzas, having given a censure and advice to those bhikkhus who were of great desires and not contented,

original: sallekhaovādaṃ pakāsetvā idāni vedanāmukhena bhāvanārāmasantosaṃ dassento “yo sukha”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: pakāsetvā idāni vedanā mukhena bhāvanā ārāma santosam dassentaḥ yaḥ sukha nti ādim āha
translated: now said “He who finds pleasure in feeling” in order to show the delight in development and contentment by way of feeling.

original: Tattha sukhanti sukhavedanaṃ. Dukkhatoti vipariṇāmadukkhato. Addāti addasa, vipassanāpaññāsahitāya
analyzed: tattha sukham ti sukha vedanam dukkhato ti vipariṇāma dukkhato addā ti addasa vipassanā paññā sahitāya
translated: Herein, in feeling pleasure he sees suffering in change. He who sees: he who has seen with the knowledge of the path accompanied by insight knowledge,

original: maggapaññāya yathābhūtaṃ yo apassīti attho. Sukhavedanā hi paribhogakāle assādiyamānāpi
analyzed: magga paññāya yathābhūtam yaḥ apassi iti attho sukha vedanā hi paribhoga kāle assādiyamānā api
translated: as it really is. For feeling pleasure is agreeable while it lasts,

original: visamissaṃ viya bhojanaṃ vipariṇāmakāle dukkhāyeva hoti. Tenettha dukkhānupassanaṃ
analyzed: visamissam viya bhojanam vipariṇāma kāle dukkhāya iva hoti tena ittha dukkha anupassanam
translated: but like food mixed with poison it becomes suffering in the end. Therefore here the contemplation of suffering

original: dasseti. Dukkhamaddakkhi sallatoti dukkhavedanaṃ yo sallanti passi. Dukkhavedanā🔽hi yathā sallaṃ sarīraṃ anupavisantampi anupavisitvā ṭhitampi uddhariyamānampi pīḷanameva
analyzed: dassa iti dukkham addakkhi sallatoti dukkha vedanam yaḥ dukkha vedanā  hi yathā sallam sarīram anupavisantam api anupavisitvā ṭhitam api uddhariyamānam api pīḷanam eva
translated: He shows that. He saw suffering as a dart: he saw painful feeling as a dart.🔽For painful feeling, even though it does not enter the body and even though it abides and is extracted without entering, still it generates only affliction,

original: janeti, evaṃ uppajjamānāpi ṭhitippattāpi bhijjamānāpi vibādhatiyevāti. Etenettha🔽dukkhānupassanaṃyeva ukkaṃsetvā vadati, tena ca “yaṃ dukkhaṃ tadanattā”ti vacanato🔽vedanādvaye attattaniyagāhaṃ viniveṭheti. Ubhayantarenāti ubhayesaṃ antare, sukhadukkhavedanānaṃ
analyzed: janeti evam uppajjamānā api ṭhiti pattā api bhijjamānā api vibādhatiyā iva ati etena itthā  dukkha anupassanaṃ yeva ukkaṃsetvā vadati tena ca yat dukkham tat anattā ati vacanato  vedanā dvaye viniveṭheti ubhaya antarena ati ubhayesam antare sukha dukkha vedanānaṃ
translated: just as a dart does. So too, when it arises, when it reaches presence, and when it dissolves, it afflicts. Thus he says this,🔽accentuating the contemplation of pain here. And by that he turns aside the assumption of self in the two kinds of feeling, since it is said, “What is pain that is not self” .🔽Between the two: between the two, that is, between pleasant and painful feeling. The meaning is: in the middle between pleasant and painful feeling.

original: majjhabhūte adukkhamasukheti attho. Nāhosīti yathābhūtāvabodhane attattaniyābhinivesanaṃ
analyzed: majjha bhūte adukkham asukha iti atthaḥ yathā bhūta avabodhane atta ttaniyā abhinivesanam
translated: Was not: there was not the assumption of self due to the discovery of how it actually is.

original: ahosi. Kena lokasmi kiṃ siyāti evaṃ vedanāmukhena pañcapi upādānakkhandhe parijānitvā
analyzed: evam vedanā mukhena upādāna khandhe parijānitvā
translated: By what, in the world, would one be? Having thus fully understood the five aggregates as objects of clinging by way of the feelings,

original: tappaṭibaddhaṃ sakalakilesajālaṃ samucchinditvā ṭhito kena nāma kilesena lokasmiṃ
analyzed: tad paṭibaddham sakala kilesa jālam samucchinditvā ṭhitaḥ kena nāma kilesena lokasmin
translated: he stood having cut off the whole tangle of defilements bound up with the aggregates. By what defilement, in the world,🔽would one be?

original: baddho, devatādīsu kiṃ vā āyati siyā, aññadatthu chinnabandhano apaññattikova siyāti adhippāyo.🔽Idāni micchāpaṭipanne puggale garahanto sammāpaṭipanne pasaṃsanto “mā me”tiādikā🔽catasso gāthā abhāsi. Tattha mā me kadāci pāpicchoti yo asantaguṇasambhāvanicchāya🔽pāpiccho, samaṇadhamme ussāhābhāvena kusīto, tatoyeva hīnavīriyo, saccapaṭiccasamuppādādipaṭisaṃyuttassa
analyzed: baddhaḥ devatā ādīsu kim vā āyati siyā aññadatthu chinna bandhanaḥ a paññattikaḥ va siyāti adhippāyaḥ  idāni micchā paṭipanne puggale garahantaḥ sammā paṭipanne pasaṃsantaḥ mā mā iti ādikā  catassaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha mā me kadāci pāpa iccho ti yaḥ asanta guṇa sambhāvanicchāya  pāpa icchaḥ samaṇa dhamme ussāha abhāvena kusītaḥ hīna vīriyaḥ sacca paṭiccasamuppāda ādi paṭisaṃyuttassa
translated: What will be the outcome for me in the future? ”

original: sutassa abhāvena appassuto, ovādānusāsanīsu ādarābhāvena anādaro, tādiso atihīnapuggalo
analyzed: sutassa abhāvena appassutaḥ ovāda anusāsanīsu ādara abhāvena anādaraḥ tādisaḥ ati hīna puggalo
translated: Now, in order to censure the person who practices wrongly and to praise the person who practices rightly, he spoke the four stanzas beginning with “May no evil-minded person ever come to me. ” Herein, may no evil-minded person ever come to me means: may no person who is evil-minded, who is lazy through lack of effort in the recluse’s duties, who is of low energy in that very respect, who is of little learning through lack of the scriptures dealing with the Truths of Suffering, etc., who is disrespectful through lack of reverence for the advice and instruction, who is such a very low person ever come to me.

original: mama santike kadācipi mā hotu. Kasmā? Kena lokasmi kiṃ siyāti lokasmiṃ sattanikāye
analyzed: mama santike kadācipi mā hotu kasmai kena lokasmi kim siyāti lokasmim satta nikāye
translated: Why? What will be the outcome for me in the world? What will be the outcome for me in the world, in the world of beings,

original: tassa tādisassa puggalassa kena ovādena kiṃ bhavitabbaṃ, kena vā katena kiṃ siyā,
analyzed: tassa tādisassa puggalassa kena ovādena kim bhavitabbam kena vā katena kim siyā
translated: of such a person? What advice will be given to him? What will be the outcome of what is done by him?

original: niratthakamevāti attho.
analyzed: niratthakam eva ati
translated: The meaning is: it is useless.

original: Bahussuto cāti yo puggalo sīlādipaṭisaṃyuttassa suttageyyādibhedassa bahuno sutassa
analyzed: bahu sutaḥ ca ati yaḥ puggalo sīla ādi paṭisaṃyuttassa sutta geyyā ādi bhedassa bahuno sutassa
translated: And the one who is learned: the person who is learned because of the abundance of his learning in the many kinds of discourses, etc., that are connected with virtue, etc.,

original: sambhavena bahussuto, dhammojapaññāya pārihāriyapaññāya paṭivedhapaññāya ca vasena🔽medhāvī, sīlesu ca suṭṭhu patiṭṭhitattā susamāhito, cetosamathaṃ lokiyalokuttarabhedaṃ
analyzed: sambhavena bahussutaḥ dhammoja paññāya pārihāriya paññāya paṭivedha paññāya ca vasena  medhāvī sīlesu ca suṭṭhu patiṭṭhita ttā su samāhitaḥ cetaḥ samatham lokiya lokuttara bhedam
translated: and who is wise because of his wisdom in the investigation of dhammas, his wisdom in the acquisition of the requisites of enlightenment, and his wisdom in penetration ,

original: cittasamādhānaṃ anuyutto, tādiso puggalo mayhaṃ matthakepi tiṭṭhatu, pageva sahavāso.
analyzed: citta samādhānam anuyuttaḥ tādisaḥ puggalaḥ mayham matthake pi tiṭṭhatu pagā iva sahavāso
translated: and who is well concentrated because of his being well established in virtue, and who is devoted to the development of serenity and insight, which are the concentration of the mind in the mundane and supramundane paths, let such a person stand on my head, to say nothing of living with him.

original: Yo papañcamanuyuttoti yo pana puggalo kammārāmatādivasena rūpābhisaṅgādivasena ca🔽pavattiyā papañcanaṭṭhena taṇhādibhedaṃ papañcaṃ anuyutto, tattha ca anādīnavadassanena🔽abhirato magasadiso, so nibbānaṃ virādhayi, so nibbānā suvidūravidūre ṭhito.
analyzed: yaḥ yaḥ pana puggalo kamma ārāma tā ādi vasena rūpa abhisaṅga ādi vasena ca  pavattiyā papañcana ṭṭhena taṇhā ādi bhedam papañcam anuyuttaḥ tattha ca anādīnava dassanena  abhirataḥ maga sadiso so nibbānam so nibbānā su vidūra vidūre ṭhitaḥ
translated: The one who follows after proliferation: the person who follows after proliferation, which is of the nature of the proliferation of becoming by way of delight in sensual pleasure, etc., and by way of delight in gain, etc.,🔽and who is devoted to it because of not seeing its danger, like a deer in the forest, he has rejected Nibbāna. He stands far away from Nibbāna, very far away.

original: Yo ca papañcaṃ hitvānāti yo pana puggalo taṇhāpapañcaṃ pahāya tadabhāvato nippapañcassa
analyzed: yaḥ ca papañcam hitvā anāti yaḥ pana puggalaḥ taṇhā papañcam pahāya tad abhāvataḥ nippapañcassa
translated: But the one who has abandoned proliferation: the person who has abandoned the proliferation of craving and who, because of the absence of that, is free from proliferation and is devoted to the development of the path, which is the means to the attainment of Nibbāna.

original: nibbānassa pathe adhigamupāye ariyamagge rato bhāvanābhisamaye abhirato, so nibbānaṃ
analyzed: nibbānassa pathe adhigama upāye ariya magge rataḥ bhāvanā abhisamaye abhirataḥ so nibbānam
translated: delighting in the path to Nibbāna, delighting in the attainment of the Noble Path, delighting in the development of insight, he is one who has attained Nibbāna,

original: ārādhayi sādhesi adhigacchīti attho.
analyzed: ārādhayi sādhesi adhigacchi iti attho
translated: He was devoted to the path of Nibbana, to the Noble Eightfold Path which is the means of attaining Nibbana. He was devoted to the realization of Nibbana through meditation. He attained Nibbana, he accomplished Nibbana, he reached Nibbana, is the meaning.

original: Athekadivasaṃ thero attano kaniṭṭhabhātikassa revatattherassa kaṇṭakanicitakhadirarukkhasañchanne
analyzed: atha eka divasam thero attano kaniṭṭha bhātikassa revata therassa kaṇṭaka nicita khadira rukkha sañchanne
translated: Then one day the Elder saw his younger brother, the Elder Revata, living in a waterless desert, in a place covered with thorny Khadira trees.

original: nirudakakantāre vāsaṃ disvā taṃ pasaṃsanto “gāme vā”tiādikā dve gāthā abhāsi. Tattha
analyzed: nirudaka kantāre vāsam disvā tam pasaṃsantaḥ gāme vāti ādikāḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha
translated: Seeing this, he praised him, and uttered the two stanzas beginning with the words, “In village or in forest.”

original: gāme vāti kiñcāpi arahanto gāmante kāyavivekaṃ na labhanti, cittavivekaṃ pana labhanteva.
analyzed: gāme vāti kiñca api arahantaḥ gāmante kāya vivekam na labhanti citta vivekam pana labhanta iva
translated: In village or in forest: although Arahats do not obtain bodily seclusion in villages and towns, they do obtain mental seclusion.

original: Tesañhi dibbapaṭibhāgānipi ārammaṇāni cittaṃ cāletuṃ na sakkonti, tasmā gāme vā hotu🔽araññādīsu aññataraṃ vā, yattha arahanto viharanti, taṃ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakanti so bhūmippadeso
analyzed: tesam hi dibba paṭibhāgāni pi ārammaṇāni cittam cāletum na sakkonti tasmai gāme vā hotu  arañña ādīsu aññataram vā yattha arahantaḥ viharanti tam bhūmirāmaṇeyyakam ti saḥ bhūmi ppadeso
translated: For the objects of their thoughts are like the objects of the thoughts of the devas, and cannot disturb their minds. Therefore, whether it be in a village or🔽in a forest or in any other place, wherever Arahats live, that place is delightful.

original: ramaṇīyo evāti attho.
analyzed: ramaṇīyaḥ eva ati atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that that place is delightful because of the Arahats who live there.

original: Araññānīti supupphitatarusaṇḍamaṇḍitāni vimalasalilāsayasampannāni araññāni ramaṇīyānīti
analyzed: araññāni iti su pupphita taru saṇḍa maṇḍitāni vimala salila āsaya sampannāni araññāni ramaṇīyāni iti
translated: Forests are delightful: forests adorned with trees in full bloom, and possessing lakes of clear water, are delightful.

original: sambandho. Yatthāti yesu araññesu vikasitesu viya ramamānesu kāmapakkhiko kāmagavesako
analyzed: sambandhaḥ yattha ati yesu araññesu vikasitesu viya ramamānesu kāma pakkhiko kāma gavesako
translated: Sambandho. Yattha means in which forests, when they are developed, people who are on the side of sense desires, who are seeking sense desires,

original: jano na ramati. Vītarāgāti vigatarāgā pana khīṇāsavā bhamaramadhukarā viya padumavanesu
analyzed: janaḥ na ramati vīta rāgā ati vigata rāgā pana khīṇa āsavāḥ bhamara madhukarāḥ viya paduma vanesu
translated: do not delight, like people who do not delight in forests when they are developed. Vītarāgā means those who are free from passion, but those who are without passion, who are without pollutants, like bees who make honey in lotus groves,

original: tathārūpesu araññesu ramissantīti. Na te kāmagavesinoti yasmā te vītarāgā kāmagavesino na hontīti attho.
analyzed: tathārūpesu araññesu ramissanti iti na te kāma gavesinaḥ ti yasmā te vīta rāgā kāma gavesinaḥ na honti iti attho
translated: delight in such forests. Na te kāmagavesino means because they are without passion, they are not seeking sense desires, is the meaning.

original: Puna thero rādhaṃ nāma duggatabrāhmaṇaṃ anukampāya pabbājetvā, upasampādetvā tameva
analyzed: puna theraḥ rādham nāma duggata brāhmaṇam anukampāya pabbājetvā upasampādetvā tam eva
translated: Again, the Elder, having had compassion on a poor brahmin named Rādha, having given him the going-forth, having given him full ordination, and making him his attendant,

original: pacchāsamaṇaṃ katvā vicaranto ekadivasaṃ tassa ca subbacabhāvena tussitvā ovādaṃ🔽dento “nidhīnaṃvā”tiādimāha. Tattha nidhīnaṃvāti tattha tattha nidahitvā ṭhapitānaṃ
analyzed: pacchā samaṇam katvā vicarantaḥ eka divasam tassa ca subbaca bhāvena tussitvā ovādam  dentaḥ nidhīnam vā iti ādim āha tattha nidhīnam vā ati tattha tattha nidahitvā
translated: while wandering about, one day, being satisfied with his good qualities, spoke this stanza, “Nidhīnaṃvā,” etc., in order to give advice.

original: hiraññasuvaṇṇādipūrānaṃ nidhikumbhīnaṃ. Pavattāranti kicchajīvike duggatamanusse
analyzed: hirañña suvaṇṇa ādi pūrānam nidhi kumbhīnam pavattāranti kiccha jīvike duggata manusse
translated: Herein, nidhīnaṃvā means of the treasure-pots filled with gold, silver, etc., which have been hidden here and there. Pavattā means having had compassion on poor people who are living a difficult life,🔽“Come, I will show you a means of living easily,” having taken them to the place where the treasure is, having pointed it out to them, saying, “Here is your treasure,”

original: anukampaṃ katvā “ehi te sukhena jīvituṃ upāyaṃ dassessāmī”ti nidhiṭṭhānaṃ netvā hatthaṃ
analyzed: anukampam katvā ehi te sukhena jīvitum upāyam dassessāmi iti nidhi ṭṭhānam netvā hattham
translated: and having had them dig it up, having given them the treasure, and having had them live happily,

original: pasāretvā “imaṃ gahetvā sukhaṃ jīvāhī”ti ācikkhitāraṃ viya. Vajjadassinanti dve vajjadassino
analyzed: pasāretvā imam gahetvā sukham jīvāhi iti ācikkhitāram viya vajja dassinan ti dve vajja dassinaḥ
translated: as if he were to point out a treasure to someone and say, “Take this, live happily.” One who sees faults: there are two kinds of people who see faults:

original: – “iminā naṃ asāruppena vā khalitena vā saṅghamajjhe niggaṇhissāmī”ti randhagavesako
analyzed: iminā nam a sāruppena vā khalitena vā saṅgha majjhe niggaṇhissāmi iti randha gavesakaḥ
translated: one who is a seeker of loopholes, thinking, “By means of this unseemly or faulty action I will accuse him in the midst of the Sangha,”

original: ca, aññātaṃ ñāpetukāmo ñātaṃ assādento sīlādivuddhikāmatāya taṃ taṃ vajjaṃ olokento🔽ullumpanasabhāvasaṇṭhito cāti, ayaṃ idha adhippeto. Yathā hi duggatamanusso “imaṃ
analyzed: ca aññātam ñā petu kāmaḥ ñātam assādento sīla ādi vuddhi kāma tāya tam tam vajjam olokento  ullumpana sabhāva saṇṭhitaḥ ca ati ayam idha adhippetaḥ yathā hi duggata manusso imaṃ
translated: and one who is intent on exposing, who sees this or that fault in order to increase his own virtue, etc., and who is pleased with what he has found out and wants to make it known.

original: nidhiṃ gaṇhāhī”ti niggayhamānopi nidhidassane kopaṃ na karoti, pamuditova hoti, evaṃ🔽evarūpesu puggalesu asāruppaṃ vā khalitaṃ vā disvā ācikkhante kopo na kātabbo, tuṭṭhacitteneva
analyzed: nidhim gaṇhāhi iti niggayhamānaḥ api nidhi dassane kopam na karoti pamuditaḥ uva hoti evam  evarūpesu puggalesu asāruppam vā khalitam vā disvā ācikkhante kopaḥ na kātabbo tuṭṭha cittena iva
translated: The one referred to here is the latter. For just as a poor man, even though he is pointed out a treasure, does not get angry at the one who shows him the treasure, but is pleased,

original: bhavitabbaṃ, “bhante, punapi maṃ evarūpaṃ vadeyyāthā”ti pavāretabbameva. Niggayhavādinti
analyzed: bhavitabbam bhante puna api mam evarūpam vadeyyātha ati pavāretabbam eva niggayha vādin ti
translated: so too, when such people point out an unseemly or faulty action, one should not get angry, but should be pleased and should even request them, “Venerable sir, please tell me again.” One who speaks after being asked:

original: yo vajjaṃ disvā ayaṃ me saddhivihāriko, antevāsiko, upakārakoti acintetvā vajjānurūpaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ vajjam disvā ayam me saddhivihārikaḥ antevāsikaḥ upakārakaḥ iti a cintetvā vajja anurūpam
translated: one who, having seen a fault, does not consider whether the other is his co-resident, pupil, or benefactor, but speaks after being asked in accordance with the fault.

original: tajjento paṇāmento daṇḍakammaṃ karonto sikkhāpeti, ayaṃ niggayhavādī nāma sammāsambuddho🔽viya. Vuttañhetaṃ – “niggayha niggayhāhaṃ, ānanda, vakkhāmi; pavayha pavayha, ānanda,
analyzed: tajjentaḥ paṇāmentaḥ daṇḍa kammam karontaḥ sikkhāpeti ayam niggayhavādī nāma sammāsambuddho  viya vuttam ha etam niggayha niggayha aham ānanda vakkhāmi pavayha pavayha ānanda
translated: He instructs, he teaches, he makes (them) train, he makes (them) do the punishment, he is called one who teaches face to face, like the Sambuddha.🔽This is said: “Having analysed, having analysed, Ānanda, I will speak; having sifted, having sifted, Ānanda, I will speak;

original: vakkhāmi. Yo sāro so ṭhassatī”ti. Medhāvinti dhammojapaññāya samannāgataṃ. Tādisanti🔽evarūpaṃ paṇḍitaṃ. Bhajeti payirupāseyya. Tādisañhi ācariyaṃ bhajamānassa antevāsikassa🔽seyyo hoti, na pāpiyo, vuḍḍhiyeva hoti, no parihānīti attho.
analyzed: vakkhāmi yaḥ sāro saḥ ṭhassati iti medhāvin ti dhamma oja paññāya samannāgatam tādisanti  evarūpam paṇḍitam bhaja iti payirupāseyya tādisam hi ācariyam bhajamānassa antevāsikassa  seyyaḥ hoti na pāpiyaḥ vuḍḍhiyā iva hoti no parihāni iti attho
translated: He instructs, he exhorts, he admonishes, he trains, he is a teacher of this kind, like a Fully Enlightened One. For this is said: “I will speak, Ananda, after distinguishing, after making a distinction. What is essential will remain, Ananda.” He is wise: he is endowed with the wisdom of the Dhamma. Such a one: such a wise man. Should serve: should attend upon. For when a pupil attends upon a teacher of this kind, he becomes better, not worse; he improves, not otherwise—this is the meaning.

original: Athekadā assajipunabbasukehi kīṭāgirismiṃ āvāse dūsite satthārā āṇatto attano parisāya
analyzed: atha ekadā assa jipu nabbasukehi kīṭāgirismin āvāse dūsite satthārā āṇattaḥ attano parisāya
translated: Then one day, when the dwelling place at Kīṭāgiri was defiled by Assaji and Punabbasuka, the Teacher, being informed, went there with the Elder Mahā Moggallāna,

original: mahāmoggallānena ca saddhiṃ tattha gato dhammasenāpati assajipunabbasukesu ovādaṃ🔽anādiyantesu imaṃ gāthamāha. Tattha ovadeyyāti ovādaṃ anusiṭṭhiṃ dadeyya. Anusāseyyāti
analyzed: mahāmoggallānena ca saddhim tattha gataḥ dhamma senāpati assajipu nabbasukesu ovādam 🔽an ādiyantesu imam gātham āha tattha ovadeyya ati ovādam anusiṭṭhim dadeyya anusāseyya iti
translated: and when the Dhamma-General, the Elder Sāriputta, the Teacher’s attendant, went there with the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, the Dhamma-General, the Elder Sāriputta, the Teacher’s attendant, went there with the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, the Teacher’s attendant, the Elder Sāriputta, the Dhamma-General, went there with the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, the Teacher’s attendant, the Elder Sāriputta, the Dhamma-General, went there with the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, the Teacher’s attendant, the Elder Sāriputta, the Dhamma-General, went there with the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, the Teacher’s attendant, the Elder Sāriputta, the Dhamma-General, went there with the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, the Teacher’s attendant, the Elder Sāriputta, the Dhamma-General, went there with the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, the Teacher’s attendant, the Elder Sāriputta, the Dhamma-General, went there with the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, the Teacher’s attendant, the Elder Sāriputta, the Dhamma-General, went there with the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, the Teacher’s attendant, the Elder Sāriputta, the Dhamma-General, went there with the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, the Teacher’s attendant, the Elder Sāriputta, the Dhamma-General, went there with the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, the Teacher’s attendant,

original: tasseva pariyāyavacanaṃ. Atha vā uppanne vatthusmiṃ vadanto ovadati nāma, anuppanne🔽“ayasopi te siyā”tiādiṃ anāgataṃ uddissa vadanto anusāsati nāma. Sammukhā vadanto🔽vā ovadati nāma, parammukhā dūtaṃ, sāsanaṃ vā pesetvā vadanto anusāsati nāma. Sakiṃ🔽vadanto vā ovadati nāma, punappunaṃ vadanto anusāsati nāma. Asabbhā cāti akusalā
analyzed: tassa iva pariyāya vacanam atha vā uppanne vatthusmiṃ vadantaḥ ovadati nāma anuppanne  ayasaḥ pi te siyā ati ādim anāgatam uddissa vadantaḥ anusāsati nāma sammukhāḥ vadantaḥ  vā ovadati nāma parammukhāḥ dūtam sāsanam vā pesetvā vadantaḥ anusāsati nāma sakim  vadantaḥ vai ovadati nāma punappunam vadantaḥ anusāsati nāma asabbhā ca ati akusalā
translated: and this is a synonym for the former. Or else, when he speaks with a basis that has arisen, he is said to “advise”; when he speaks with reference to the future, saying, “This may happen to you,” he is said to “instruct.” When he speaks face to face, he is said to “advise”; when he sends a messenger or a message, he is said to “instruct.” When he speaks once, he is said to “advise”; when he speaks again and again, he is said to “instruct.” Unbeneficial: unwholesome,

original: dhammā ca nivāraye, kusale dhamme ca patiṭṭhāpeyyāti attho. Satañhi soti evarūpo🔽puggalo sādhūnaṃ piyo hoti. Ye pana asantā asappurisā vitiṇṇaparalokā āmisacakkhukā🔽jīvikatthāya pabbajitā, tesaṃ so ovādako anusāsako “na tvaṃ amhākaṃ upajjhāyo, na🔽ācariyo, kasmā amhe vadasī”ti evaṃ mukhasattīhi vijjhantānaṃ appiyo hotīti.
analyzed: dhammā ca nivāraye kusale dhamme ca patiṭṭhāpeyya ati attho satañhi saḥ ti evarūpo 🔽puggalo sādhūnam piyaḥ hoti ye pana asantā asappurisāḥ vitiṇṇa para lokāḥ āmisa cakkhukā 🔽jīvika thāya pabbajitā tesam saḥ ovādakaḥ anusāsakaḥ na tvam amhākam upajjhāyaḥ na 🔽ācariyo kasmai amhe vadasi iti evam mukhasattīhi vijjhantānam appiyaḥ hoti iti
translated: and this is a synonym for the latter. Or else, when he speaks with a basis that has arisen, he is said to “advise”; when he speaks with a basis that has not yet arisen, he is said to “instruct” , referring to the future thus: “This may happen to you.” When he speaks face to face, he is said to “advise”; when he sends a messenger or a message and speaks indirectly, he is said to “instruct.” When he speaks once, he is said to “advise”; when he speaks again and again, he is said to “instruct.” He should ward off unwholesome states and establish wholesome states: the meaning is that he should ward off unprofitable things and establish profitable things. For such a person is dear to the good: such a person is dear to the good, to those who are virtuous. But to the bad, to the scoundrels, who have no regard for the other world, who are greedy for sensual desires, who have gone astray and gone beyond the bounds, who have gone forth for the sake of livelihood, he is not dear when he advises and instructs them, saying: “You are not my preceptor or teacher. Why do you advise me?”—for they pierce him with the darts of their words.

original: “Yaṃ ārabbha satthā dhammaṃ deseti, so eva upanissayasampanno”ti bhikkhūsu kathāya
analyzed: yam ārabbha satthā dhammaṃ deseti saḥ eva upanissaya sampannaḥ ti bhikkhūsu kathāya
translated: “The one in regard to whom the Teacher teaches the Dhamma is himself endowed with the necessary conditions.”

original: samuṭṭhitāya “nayidameta”nti dassento “aññassā”ti gāthamāha. Tattha aññassāti attano
analyzed: samuṭṭhitāya na idam etat ti dassentaḥ aññassa iti gātham āha tattha aññassa ati attanaḥ
translated: When this talk had arisen among the bhikkhus, the Master, saying “This is not so,” uttered the stanza, “Another.”🔽Herein, another means his sister’s son, the wanderer Dīghanakha.

original: bhāgineyyaṃ dīghanakhaparibbājakaṃ sandhāyāha. Tassa hi satthārā vedanāpariggahasutte
analyzed: bhāgineyyam dīghanakha paribbājakam sandhāya āha tassa hi satthārā vedanā pariggaha sutte
translated: For when the Master was teaching the Discourse on the Analysis of Feeling,

original: desiyamāne ayaṃ mahāthero bhāvanāmagge adhigantvā sāvakapāramīñāṇassa matthakaṃ patto.
analyzed: desiyamāne ayam mahā theraḥ bhāvanā magge adhigantvā sāvaka pāramī ñāṇassa matthakam patto
translated: this great Elder had attained the path of development and reached the summit of the knowledge of a disciple.

original: Sotamodhesimatthikoti satthāraṃ bījayamāno ṭhito atthiko hutvā sussūsanto sotaṃ odahiṃ.
analyzed: sota modhesim atthikaḥ iti satthāram bījayamānaḥ ṭhitaḥ atthikaḥ hutvā sussūsantaḥ sotam odahim
translated: Standing, he stood, being desirous, and he directed his ear,

original: Taṃ me amoghaṃ savananti taṃ tathā sutaṃ savanaṃ mayhaṃ amoghaṃ avañjhaṃ ahosi, aggasāvakena
analyzed: tam me amogham savanam ti tam tathā sutam savanam mayham amogham avañjham ahosi agga sāvakena
translated: That hearing of mine was not in vain. That hearing of mine, thus heard by me, was not in vain, not barren, but it was a support for those who had attained what can be attained by a chief disciple.

original: pattabbaṃ sampattīnaṃ avassayo ahosi. Tenāha “vimuttomhī”tiādi.
analyzed: pattabbam sampattīnam avassayaḥ ahosi tena āha vimuttaḥ amhi itiādi
translated: Therefore he said, “I am liberated,” and so on.

original: Tattha neva pubbenivāsāyāti attano paresañca pubbenivāsajānanañāṇatthāya, paṇidhī
analyzed: tattha na iva pubbenivāsāya ati attanaḥ paresam ca pubbenivāsa jānana ñāṇa atthāya paṇidhī
translated: Herein, not for the knowledge of past lives, not for the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings,

original: me neva vijjatīti yojanā. Parikammakaraṇavasena tadatthaṃ cittapaṇidhānamattampi
analyzed: me na iva vijjati iti yojanā parikamma karaṇa vasena tad attham citta paṇidhāna mattam pi
translated: The construction is: “I have no desire for that.” The meaning is: “I have no desire for that, no mental resolve for that purpose, not even for the purpose of mere attention.”

original: nevatthi neva ahosīti attho. Cetopariyāyāti cetopariyañāṇassa. Iddhiyāti iddhividhañāṇassa.
analyzed: na iva atthi na iva ahosi iti attho cetas pariyāya āti cetas pariya ñāṇassa iddhiyā āti iddhividha ñāṇassa
translated: “I have no desire for the knowledge of others’ minds”: for the knowledge of the thoughts of others.🔽“I have no desire for the knowledge of psychic power”: for the knowledge of the various kinds of psychic power.

original: Cutiyā upapattiyāti, sattānaṃ cutiyā upapattiyā ca jānanañāṇāya cutūpapātañāṇatthāya.
analyzed: cutiyāḥ upapattiyā ti sattānam cutiyāḥ upapattiyā ca jānana ñāṇāya cutūpapāta ñāṇa atthāya
translated: “I have no desire for the knowledge of passing away and reappearance”: for the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.

original: Sotadhātuvisuddhiyāti dibbasotañāṇassa. Paṇidhī me na vijjatīti imesaṃ abhiññāvisesānaṃ
analyzed: sota dhātu visuddhiyā ti dibba sota ñāṇassa paṇidhī me na vijjati iti imesam abhiññā visesānam
translated: “I have no desire for the purification of the divine ear”: for the knowledge of the divine ear.

original: atthāya parikammavasena cittassa paṇidhi cittābhinīhāro me natthi nāhosīti attho.
analyzed: atthāya parikamma vasena cittassa paṇidhi citta abhinīhāro me natthi na ahosi iti attho
translated: The meaning is: “I have no desire, no mental resolve, no mental aspiration for the purpose of these special kinds of direct knowledge.”

original: Sabbaññuguṇā viya hi buddhānaṃ aggamaggādhigameneva sāvakānaṃ sabbe sāvakaguṇā hatthagatā
analyzed: sabbaññu guṇāḥ viya hi buddhānam agga magga adhigamena iva sāvakānam sabbe sāvaka guṇāḥ hattha gatāḥ
translated: For just as the special qualities of a Buddha are acquired by the Buddha himself, so too the special qualities of a disciple are acquired by the disciple himself.

original: honti, na tesaṃ adhigamāya visuṃ parikammakaraṇakiccaṃ atthīti.
analyzed: honti na tesam adhigamāya visum parikamma karaṇa kiccam atthi iti
translated: There is no need for him to perform any separate preparatory task for their acquisition.

original: Rukkhamūlantiādikā tisso gāthā kapotakandarāyaṃ viharantassa yakkhena pahatakāle
analyzed: rukkha mūlam ti ādikā tissaḥ gāthā kapotakandarāyam viharantassa yakkhena pahata kāle
translated: The three verses beginning with the words “at the foot of a tree” were uttered by the Elder Mahā Moggallāna when he was attacked by a yakkha while he was living in the Pigeon Cave.

original: samāpattibalena attano nibbikāratādīpanavasena vuttā. Tattha muṇḍoti na voropitakeso.
analyzed: samāpatti balena attanaḥ nibbikāra tā dīpana vasena vuttā tattha muṇḍaḥ ti na voropita keso
translated: and by the power of his attainment he was speaking of his own non-concern. Herein, shaven-headed means not having his head shaved.

original: Saṅghāṭipārutoti saṅghāṭiṃ pārupitvā nisinno. “Saṅghāṭiyā supāruto”ti ca paṭhanti.
analyzed: saṅghāṭi pārutā iti saṅghāṭim pārupitvā nisinnaḥ saṅghāṭiyā su pārutā iti ca paṭhanti
translated: Wearing the inner and outer robes means sitting down after putting on the inner and outer robes.

original: Paññāya uttamo theroti thero hutvā paññāya uttamo, sāvakesu paññāya seṭṭhoti attho.
analyzed: paññāya uttamo thero ti theraḥ hutvā paññāya uttamo sāvakesu paññāya seṭṭhaḥ ti attho
translated: The elder was supreme in wisdom: he was an elder and he was supreme in wisdom. The meaning is that he was best in wisdom among the disciples.

original: Jhāyatīti ārammaṇūpanijjhānena lakkhaṇūpanijjhānena ca jhāyati, bahulaṃ samāpattivihārena viharatīti attho.🔽Upeto hoti tāvadeti yadā yakkhena sīse pahato, tāvadeva avitakkaṃ catutthajjhānikaphalasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: jhāyati iti ārammaṇa upanijjhānena lakkhaṇa upanijjhānena ca jhāyati bahulam samāpatti vihārena viharati iti attho  upetaḥ hoti tāvat eti yadā yakkhena sīse pahato tāvat eva avitakkam catuttha jhānika phala samāpattim
translated: He was meditating: he was meditating by means of the act of insight consisting in the act of insight consisting in contemplation of an object and by means of the act of insight consisting in contemplation of mental aspects. The meaning is that he was often living by means of the life of attainment.🔽He was endowed with that: when he was struck on the head by the ogre, he was then endowed, possessed, with the noble silence, which is the attainment of the fruition of the fourth jhāna, free from thought-conception.

original: samāpanno ariyena tuṇhībhāvena upeto samannāgato ahosi. Atītatthe hi hotīti idaṃ vattamānavacanaṃ.
analyzed: samāpannaḥ ariyena tuṇhībhāvena upetaḥ samannāgato ahosi atīta atthe hi hoti iti idam vattamāna vacanam
translated: For the word “endowed” is in the present tense in the sense of the past.

original: Pabbatova na vedhatīti mohakkhayā bhinnasabbakileso bhikkhu. So selamayapabbato viya acalo suppatiṭṭhito iṭṭhādinā kenaci na vedhati, sabbattha nibbikāro hotīti attho.
analyzed: pabbataḥ iva na vedhati iti moha kkhayā bhinna sabba kilesaḥ bhikkhu so sela maya pabbataḥ viya acalaḥ su patiṭṭhitaḥ iṭṭha ādinā kenaci na vedhati sabbattha nibbikāraḥ hoti iti attho
translated: Pabbatova na vedhati : a Bhikkhu, by the destruction of ignorance, is one who has broken all the defilements. He is unshaken, well-established, like a mountain made of rock, and is not shaken by any of the desirable, etc. What is meant is that he is indifferent to everything.

original: Athekadivasaṃ therassa asatiyā nivāsanakaṇṇe olambante aññataro sāmaṇero, “bhante,
analyzed: atha eka divasam therassa asatiyāḥ nivāsana kaṇṇe olambante aññataraḥ sāmaṇeraḥ bhante
translated: Then one day, when the Elder’s under robe was hanging down because he was not paying attention, a certain novice said, “Venerable sir,

original: parimaṇḍalaṃ nivāsetabba”nti āha. Taṃ sutvā “bhaddaṃ tayā suṭṭhu vutta”nti sirasā🔽viya sampaṭicchanto tāvadeva thokaṃ apakkamitvā parimaṇḍalaṃ nivāsetvā “mādisānaṃ
analyzed: parimaṇḍalam nivāsetabbanti āha tam sutvā bhaddam tayā suṭṭhu vuttanti sirasā  viya sampaṭicchantaḥ tāvat eva thokam a pakkamitvā parimaṇḍalam nivāsetvā
translated: the under robe should be worn evenly all around.” On hearing this, the Elder thought, “It is well said by you.”

original: ayampi dosoyevā”ti dassento “anaṅgaṇassā”ti gāthamāha.
analyzed: ayam pi dosaḥ yā iva ati dassentaḥ anaṅgaṇassa ati gātham āha
translated: As though he were bowing his head in assent, he stepped back a little, put on his under robe evenly all around, and showing that this fault was common to those like him, he uttered the first stanza, “Anaṅgaṇassa.”

original: Puna maraṇe jīvite ca attano samacittataṃ dassento “nābhinandāmī”tiādinā dve gāthā
analyzed: puna maraṇe jīvite ca attanaḥ samacitta tam dassentaḥ na abhinandāmi itiādinā dve gāthā
translated: Then, showing his equanimity of mind in regard to death and life, he uttered the two stanzas beginning with the words, “Nābhinandāmi.”

original: vatvā paresaṃ dhammaṃ kathento “ubhayena mida”ntiādinā gāthādvayamāha. Tattha ubhayenāti
analyzed: vatvā paresam dhammam kathentaḥ ubhayena midanti ādinā gāthā dvayam āha tattha ubhayena ati
translated: After that, teaching the Dhamma to others, he uttered the two stanzas beginning with the words, “Ubhayena mida.”

original: ubhayesu, ubhosu kālesūti attho. Midanti ma-kāro padasandhikaro. Idaṃ maraṇameva,
analyzed: ubhayesu ubhosu kālesu iti atthaḥ makāraḥ pada sandhi karaḥ idam maraṇam eva
translated: Both times: the meaning is, at both times. Mid: the letter ma is a link in the compound. This death

analyzed: maraṇam attha iva nāma amaraṇam nāma natthi kesu ubhosu kālesu iti āha pacchā vā pure
translated: is just death, there is no non-death. At what two times? He said “afterwards or before” .

original: vā”ti majjhimavayassa pacchā vā jarājiṇṇakāle pure vā daharakāle maraṇameva maraṇaṃ

translated: Death is just death, whether it is afterwards at the time of being worn out with old age or before at the time of being a youth.

original: ekantikameva. Tasmā paṭipajjatha sammā paṭipattiṃ pūretha vippaṭipajjitvā mā vinassatha🔽apāyesu mahādukkhaṃ mānubhavatha. Khaṇo vo mā upaccagāti aṭṭhahi akkhaṇehi vivajjito
analyzed: ekantikam eva tasmai paṭipajjatha sammā paṭipattim pūretha vippaṭipajjitvā mā vinassatha  apāyesu mahā dukkham mā anubhavatha khaṇaḥ vaḥ mā upaccagāti aṭṭhahi akkhaṇehi vivajjitaḥ

original: viya ca anavaṭṭhito, tasmā ekacce ādito sādhū hutvā ṭhitāpi pacchā asādhū honti.

translated: and they are not constant, some being good at first but later bad.

original: Yathā devadatto pubbe sīlasampanno abhiññāsamāpattilābhī hutvā lābhasakkārapakato🔽idāni parihīnaviseso chinnapakkhakāko viya āpāyiko jāto. Tasmā tādiso diṭṭhamattena

analyzed: kāmacchanda ādayaḥ cittu pakkilesāḥ a vigatā te asādhu yesam te vigatā te sādhu iti  dassetum kāmacchandaḥ iti gātham vatvā asādhāraṇataḥ ukkaṃsa gatam sādhu lakkhaṇam dassetum
translated: Those in whom the mental defilements such as lust are not absent are bad; those in whom they are absent are good.

original: “yassa sakkariyamānassā”tiādinā gāthādvayaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: yassa sakkariyamānassa ati ādinā gāthā dvayam vuttam
translated: To show this, the first stanza says “Lust, hatred, delusion, and conceit.” The next two stanzas are stated to show the characteristics of a good person by way of his pre-eminence, which is not shared by others.

analyzed: asādhāraṇataḥ pana ukkaṃsa gatam tam dassetum satthāram attānam ca udāharantaḥ mahā samudda uti ādikā
translated: In order to show that it is the most excellent and not shared in common, he cited himself and the Master as examples, and he uttered the following stanza:

analyzed: gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha mahā samuddo ti ayam mahā samuddaḥ mahā pathavī selaḥ pabbato puratthima ādi bhedato

analyzed: anilaḥ ca attanaḥ acetanā bhāvena iṭṭha aniṭṭham sahanti na paṭisaṅkhāna balena satthā
translated: The wind, which is not conscious, endures the pleasant and the unpleasant, not through the power of reflection,🔽But the Master, who is equal in all circumstances, pleasant and unpleasant,

original: pana yassā arahattuppattiyā vasena uttame tādibhāve ṭhito iṭṭhādīsu sabbattha samo
analyzed: pana yassā arahatta uppattiyā vasena uttame ta ādi bhāve ṭhitaḥ iṭṭha ādīsu sabbattha samaḥ
translated: Through the attainment of arahatship, is established in the highest state of equality,

original: nibbikāro, tassā satthu varavimuttiyā aggaphalavimuttiyā te mahāsamuddādayo upamāya
analyzed: nibbikāraḥ tassā satthu vara vimuttiyā agga phala vimuttiyā te mahā samudda ādayaḥ upamāya
translated: The Master’s excellent deliverance, the supreme fruit of deliverance, is not comparable to the great ocean, etc.,

original: upamābhāvena na yujjanti kalabhāgampi na upentīti attho.🔽Cakkānuvattakoti satthārā vattitassa dhammacakkassa anuvattako. Theroti asekkhehi
analyzed: upamā bhāvena na yujjanti kalabhāgam pi na upenti iti attho  cakka anuvattakaḥ ti satthārā vattitassa dhamma cakkassa anuvattakaḥ thero ti asekkhehi
translated: It does not even bear comparison with them.🔽A follower of the Wheel-turner: a follower of the Wheel of the Dhamma turned by the Master. The Elder: the Elder who is endowed with the aggregates of virtue, etc., of one beyond training.

original: sīlakkhandhādīhi samannāgamena thero. Mahāñāṇīti mahāpañño. Samāhitoti upacārappanāsamādhinā
analyzed: sīla kkhandha ādīhi samannāgamena theraḥ mahāñāṇi iti mahā pañño samāhito ti upacāra ppanā samādhinā
translated: Great in knowledge: of great wisdom. Concentrated: concentrated through access concentration and absorption concentration.

original: anuttarasamādhinā ca samāhito. Paṭhavāpaggisamānoti iṭṭhādiārammaṇasannipāte nibbikāratāya
analyzed: anuttara samādhinā ca samāhito paṭhava apaggi samāno ti iṭṭha ādi ārammaṇa sannipāte nibbikāra tāya
translated: He is like earth, water, and fire, in that he is indifferent to the contact of desirable and undesirable objects.

original: pathaviyā āpena agginā ca sadisavuttiko. Tenāha “na rajjati na dussatī”ti.🔽Paññāpāramitaṃ pattoti sāvakañāṇassa pāramiṃ pārakoṭiṃ patto. Mahābuddhīti mahāputhuhāsajavanatikkhanibbedhikabhāvappattāya
analyzed: pathaviyā āpena agginā ca sadisa vuttikaḥ tena āha na rajjati na dussati iti  paññāpāramitam pattoti sāvaka ñāṇassa pāramim pāra koṭim pattaḥ mahābuddhī iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “He is not attached, he is not hostile.”🔽He has attained the perfection of wisdom: he has reached the perfection, the culmination, of the wisdom of the disciples.🔽He has great understanding: he is endowed with great understanding, with wisdom that has attained the state of being able to penetrate the four great floods of information.

original: mahatiyā buddhiyā paññāya samannāgato. Mahāmatīti dhammanvayaveditasaṅkhātāya mahatiyā
analyzed: mahatiyā buddhiyā paññāya samannāgataḥ mahāmatī iti dhamma nvaya vedita saṅkhātāya mahatiyā
