original: cakkhu…pe… jarāmaraṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ aniccaṃ saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ
analyzed: cakkhupe jarā maraṇam atīta anāgata paccuppannam aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam
translated: The eye … Aging-and-death is inconstant, stressful, subject to change.

original: khayadhammaṃ vayadhammaṃ virāgadhammaṃ nirodhadhammanti tulayitvā tīrayitvā vibhāvayitvā🔽vibhūtaṃ katvā jarāmaraṇanirodhe nibbāne khippaṃ javatīti javanapaññā.
analyzed: khaya dhammam vaya dhammam virāga dhammam nirodha dhammanti tulayitvā tīrayitvā vibhāvayitvā  vibhūtam katvā jarā maraṇa nirodhe nibbāne khippam javati iti javana paññā
translated: and that it is subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, he quickly penetrates it.🔽This is called quick-working understanding.

original: “Katamā tikkhapaññā? Khippaṃ kilese chindatīti tikkhapaññā, uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ
analyzed: katamā tikkha paññā khippam kilese chindati iti tikkha paññā uppannam kāma vitakkam
translated: “What is keen understanding? It is understanding that quickly cuts off defilements. When a thought of sensual desire has arisen,

original: nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gametīti tikkhapaññā; uppannaṃ🔽byāpādavitakkaṃ nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gametīti tikkhapaññā;
analyzed: na adhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gameti iti tikkha paññā uppannam  byāpāda vitakkam na adhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gameti iti tikkha paññā
translated: he does not tolerate it; he abandons it, dispels it, terminates it, and obliterates it. This is called keen understanding. When a thought of ill will has arisen…

original: uppannaṃ vihiṃsāvitakkaṃ nādhivāseti…pe… uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti
analyzed: uppannam vihiṃsā vitakkam na adhivāseti pe uppanna uppanne pāpake akusale dhamme na adhivāseti
translated: When a thought of cruelty has arisen… When any bad, unwholesome states have arisen, he does not tolerate them;

original: pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gametīti tikkhapaññā; uppannaṃ rāgaṃ nādhivāseti
analyzed: pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gameti iti tikkha paññā uppannam rāgam na adhivāseti
translated: he abandons them, dispels them, terminates them, and obliterates them. This is called keen understanding. When greed has arisen,

original: pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gametīti tikkhapaññā; uppannaṃ dosaṃ…pe…
analyzed: pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gameti iti tikkha paññā uppannam
translated: he does not tolerate it; he abandons it, dispels it, terminates it, and obliterates it. This is called keen understanding. When hatred has arisen…

original: uppannaṃ mohaṃ… uppannaṃ kodhaṃ… uppannaṃ upanāhaṃ… makkhaṃ… paḷāsaṃ… issaṃ… macchariyaṃ…
analyzed: uppannam moham uppannam kodham uppannam upanāham makkham paḷāsam issam macchariyam
translated: He does not acquiesce in arisen lust … arisen hate … arisen conceit … arisen envy … arisen stinginess …🔽arisen deceit … arisen fraud … arisen obstinacy … arisen craftiness … arisen vanity …

original: māyaṃ… sāṭheyyaṃ… thambhaṃ… sārambhaṃ… mānaṃ… atimānaṃ… madaṃ… pamādaṃ… sabbe kilese…
analyzed: māyam sāṭheyyam thambham sa ārambham mānam atimānam madam pamādam sabbe kilese
translated: arisen arrogance … arisen sensual desire … arisen ill will … all defilements …

original: sabbe duccarite… sabbe abhisaṅkhāre…pe… sabbe bhavagāmikamme nādhivāseti pajahati🔽vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gametīti tikkhapaññā. Ekasmiṃ āsane cattāro ca ariyamaggā,🔽cattāri sāmaññaphalāni, catasso paṭisambhidāyo, cha abhiññāyo adhigatā honti sacchikatā
analyzed: sabbe duccarite sabbe abhisaṅkhārepe sabbe bhava gāmi kamme na adhivāseti pajahati  vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gameti iti tikkha paññā ekasmim āsane cattāro ca ariya maggā  cattāri sāmañña phalāni catasso paṭisambhidāyo cha abhiññāyo adhigatāḥ honti sacchikatā
translated: all bad actions … all volitions … all deeds that lead to renewed existence. He abandons them, …🔽he makes them disappear, … he wipes them out completely. He is one of quick understanding regarding wholesome teachings. He attains the four jhānas …

original: phassitā paññāyāti tikkhapaññā.
analyzed: phassitā paññāyāti tikkha paññā
translated: the four noble paths … the four noble fruits … the four discriminations … the six direct knowledges. He has realized the knowledge and vision of release. He has touched with his body the deathless element. He is one of quick understanding regarding the deathless element.

original: “Katamā nibbedhikapaññā? Idhekacco sabbasaṅkhāresu ubbegabahulo hoti uttāsabahulo
analyzed: katamā nibbedhika paññā idha ekaccaḥ sabba saṅkhāresu ubbega bahulaḥ hoti uttāsa bahulaḥ
translated: “What is deep wisdom? Here someone is fearful, anxious, and concerned about all conditioned things.

original: ukkaṇṭhanabahulo aratibahulo anabhiratibahulo bahimukho na ramati sabbasaṅkhāresu,
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhana bahulaḥ arati bahulaḥ anabhirati bahulaḥ bahimukhaḥ na ramati sabba saṅkhāresu
translated: He is disgusted, humiliated, and repelled by all conditioned things. He is turned away from all conditioned things and does not delight in them.

original: anibbiddhapubbaṃ apadālitapubbaṃ lobhakkhandhaṃ nibbijjhati padāletīti nibbedhikapaññā,🔽anibbiddhapubbaṃ apadālitapubbaṃ dosakkhandhaṃ nibbijjhati padāletīti nibbedhikapaññā,🔽anibbiddhapubbaṃ apadālitapubbaṃ mohakkhandhaṃ nibbijjhati padāletīti nibbedhikapaññā;
analyzed: a nibbiddha pubbam a padālita pubbam lobha kkhandham nibbijjhati padāleti iti nibbedhika paññā  a nibbiddha pubbam a padālita pubbam dosa kkhandham nibbijjhati padāleti iti nibbedhika paññā  a nibbiddha pubbam a padālita pubbam moha kkhandham nibbijjhati padāleti iti nibbedhika paññā
translated: He penetrates and bursts asunder the mass of greed that was not penetrated and burst asunder before. He penetrates and bursts asunder the mass of hate that was not penetrated and burst asunder before. He penetrates and bursts asunder the mass of delusion that was not penetrated and burst asunder before.

original: anibbiddhapubbaṃ apadālitapubbaṃ kodhaṃ…pe… upanāhaṃ…pe… sabbe bhavagāmikamme nibbijjhati
analyzed: a nibbiddha pubbam a padālita pubbam kodhaṃpe upanāhaṃpe sabbe bhava gāmi kamme nibbijjhati
translated: He penetrates and bursts asunder anger, enmity, conceit, vanity, arrogance, mental darkness, sloth, laziness, forgetfulness, inattention, agitation, inertia, lack of knowledge, and all other states that are the root of what is unskillful, that are on the side of what is unskillful.🔽He penetrates and bursts asunder all actions that lead to a renewed existence.

original: padāletīti nibbedhikapaññā”ti.
analyzed: padāleti iti nibbedhika paññā ati
translated: He penetrates and bursts asunder all actions that lead to a renewed existence. Thus his discernment is penetrating. ”

original: Evaṃ yathāvuttavibhāgāya mahatiyā paññāya samannāgatattā “mahābuddhī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: evam yathā vutta vibhāgāya mahatiyā paññāya samannāgata ttā mahābuddhī iti vuttam
translated: Thus, because he is endowed with the great discernment of the kind just described, he is called “one of great discernment. ”

original: Apica anupadadhammavipassanāvasenāpi imassa therassa mahāpaññatā veditabbā. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: apica anupada dhamma vipassanā vasena api imassa therassa mahā paññatā veditabbā vuttam ha etam
translated: Moreover, his great discernment should be understood as follows. For it was said:

original: “Sāriputto, bhikkhave, aḍḍhamāsaṃ anupadadhammavipassanaṃ vipassati. Tatridaṃ, bhikkhave, sāriputtassa anupadadhammavipassanāya hoti.
analyzed: sāriputtaḥ bhikkhave aḍḍha māsam anupada dhamma vipassanam vipassati tatra idam bhikkhave sāriputtassa anupada dhamma vipassanāya hoti
translated: “For half a month, bhikkhus, Sariputta contemplates a phenomenon that is not subject to disintegration. And this is how Sariputta contemplates a phenomenon that is not subject to disintegration.

original: “Idha, bhikkhave, sāriputto vivicceva kāmehi…pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave sāriputtaḥ vivicca iva kāmehipe paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, Sariputta, secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, enters and dwells in the first jhana…

original: Ye ca paṭhame jhāne dhammā vitakko ca…pe… cittekaggatā ca phasso vedanā saññā cetanā🔽cittaṃ chando adhimokkho vīriyaṃ sati upekkhā manasikāro, tyāssa dhammā anupadavavatthitā
analyzed: ye ca paṭhame jhāne dhammā vitakko cape citta ekagga tā ca phassaḥ vedanā saññā cetanā  cittam chandaḥ adhimokkhaḥ vīriyam sati upekkhā manasikāro dhammā
translated: Whatever states are included in the first jhana, such as applied thought and sustained thought, rapture and happiness born of seclusion: these states are known to him as they arise, known as they appear, known as they subside.

original: honti, tyāssa dhammā viditā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti.🔽So evaṃ pajānāti ‘evaṃ kira me dhammā ahutvā sambhonti, hutvā paṭiventī’ti. So tesu
analyzed: honti tyāssa dhammā viditāḥ uppajjanti viditāḥ upaṭṭhahanti viditāḥ abbhattham gacchanti  saḥ evam pajānāti evam kira me dhammā a hutvā sambhonti hutvā paṭiventi iti saḥ tesu
translated: These states are known to him as they arise, known as they appear, known as they subside.🔽He understands thus: ‘Such is form, such its origin, such its passing away; such is feeling… such is perception… such are volitional formations… such is consciousness, such its origin, such its passing away.’

original: dhammesu anupāyo anapāyo anissito appaṭibaddho vippamutto visaṃyutto vimariyādīkatena
analyzed: dhammesu anupāyaḥ anapāyaḥ anissitaḥ appaṭibaddhaḥ vippamuttaḥ visaṃyuttaḥ vimariyādīkatena
translated: With regard to these six bases of contact, he dwells contemplating their arising and vanishing: ‘Such is form, such its origin, such its passing away; such is feeling… such is perception… such are volitional formations… such is consciousness, such its origin, such its passing away.’

original: cetasā viharati. So ‘atthi uttari nissaraṇa’nti pajānāti. Tabbahulīkārā atthitvevassa hoti.
analyzed: cetasā viharati saḥ atthi uttari nissaraṇanti pajānāti tad bahulīkārā atthi tvā iva assa hoti
translated: He understands: ‘There is an escape beyond,’ and with the cultivation of that attainment he reaches the termination of suffering.

original: “Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sāriputto vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā…pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ…
analyzed: puna ca param bhikkhave sāriputto vitakka vicārānam vūpasamāpe dutiyam jhānam
translated: “Again, bhikkhus, when vitakka and vicara have subsided within him, a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the second jhana…

original: tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ… viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ…
analyzed: tatiyam jhānam catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati ākāsānañcāyatanam viññāṇañcāyatanam
translated: the third jhāna… the fourth jhāna… the base of infinite space… the base of infinite consciousness…

original: ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ… sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatanam sabbasas ākiñcaññāyatanam samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam upasampajja
translated: the base of nothingness… the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: viharati. So tāya samāpattiyā sato vuṭṭhahati, so tāya samāpattiyā sato vuṭṭhahitvā
analyzed: viharati saḥ tāya samāpattiyā sataḥ vuṭṭhahati saḥ tāya samāpattiyā sataḥ vuṭṭhahitvā
translated: He emerges mindful from that attainment.

original: ye dhammā atītā niruddhā vipariṇatā, te dhamme samanupassati “evaṃ kira me dhammā
analyzed: ye dhammā atītā niruddhā vipariṇatā te dhamme samanupassati evam kira me dhammā
translated: He sees those things that have passed, ceased, and changed as “Such were our perceptions, such our thoughts, such our views.”

original: ahutvā sambhonti, hutvā paṭiventī”ti. So tesu dhammesu anupāyo anapāyo anissito appaṭibaddho🔽vippamutto visaṃyutto vimariyādīkatena cetasā viharati. So ‘atthi uttari nissaraṇa’nti
analyzed: a hutvā sambhonti hutvā paṭiventi iti so tesu dhammesu anupāyaḥ anapāyaḥ anissitaḥ appaṭibaddhaḥ  vippamuttaḥ visaṃyuttaḥ vimariyādīkatena cetasā viharati so atthi uttari nissaraṇan ti
translated: He is unattached to those things, uninfatuated with them, and does not adhere to them.🔽He dwells with a mind that is open and free, and he understands that mind as it really is.

original: pajānāti. Tabbahulīkārā atthitvevassa hoti.
analyzed: pajānāti tad bahulīkārā atthitvā iva assa hoti
translated: He understands: ‘There is a further escape,’ and by that he understands: ‘There is a further escape.’

original: “Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sāriputto sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma
analyzed: puna ca param bhikkhave sāriputto sabbasas nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam samatikkamma
translated: “Again, Sāriputta, with the complete surmounting of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,

original: saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati. Paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā
analyzed: saññā vedayita nirodham upasampajja viharati paññāya ca ssa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā
translated: and he abides in that attainment. And by realising for himself with direct knowledge, he here and now enters upon and abides in the deliverance of mind and deliverance by wisdom that are taintless with the destruction of the taints.

original: honti. So tāya samāpattiyā sato vuṭṭhahati, so tāya samāpattiyā sato vuṭṭhahitvā🔽ye dhammā atītā niruddhā vipariṇatā, te dhamme samanupassati ‘evaṃ kira me dhammā
analyzed: honti saḥ tāya samāpattiyā sataḥ vuṭṭhahati saḥ tāya samāpattiyā sataḥ vuṭṭhahitvā  ye dhammā atītā niruddhā vipariṇatā te dhamme samanupassati evam kira me dhammā
translated: He emerges mindful from that attainment.

original: ahutvā sambhonti, hutvā paṭiventī’ti. So tesu dhammesu anupāyo anapāyo anissito appaṭibaddho🔽vippamutto visaṃyutto vimariyādīkatena cetasā viharati, so ‘natthi uttari nissaraṇa’nti
analyzed: a hutvā sambhonti hutvā paṭiventi iti so tesu dhammesu anupāyaḥ anapāyaḥ anissitaḥ appaṭibaddhaḥ  vippamuttaḥ visaṃyuttaḥ vimariyādīkatena cetasā viharati so na atthi uttari nissaraṇan ti
translated: He sees those things that are past, ceased, changed, as being like this: ‘So indeed, these things, not having been, come into being; having been, they vanish.’🔽He abides independent, not clinging to anything in the world.🔽He understands: ‘There is nothing further in this world.’

original: pajānāti. Tabbahulīkārā natthitvevassa hoti.🔽“Yaṃ kho taṃ, bhikkhave, sammā vadamāno vadeyya ‘vasippatto pāramippatto ariyasmiṃ
analyzed: pajānāti tad bahulīkārā na atthitvā iva assa hoti  yam kho tam bhikkhave sammā vadamānaḥ vadeyya vasi pattaḥ pārami pattaḥ ariyasmin
translated: He abides independent, not clinging to anything in the world.🔽“Bhikkhus, if anyone were to speak rightly of a person who has attained perfection in virtue, attained perfection in concentration, and attained perfection in wisdom, he would speak thus:

original: sīlasmiṃ, vasippatto pāramippatto ariyasmiṃ samādhismiṃ, vasippatto pāramippatto
analyzed: sīlasmim vasippatto pāramippatto ariyasmim samādhismim vasippatto pāramippatto
translated: ‘He has attained perfection in virtue, perfection in concentration, and perfection in wisdom.’

original: ariyāya paññāya, vasippatto pāramippatto ariyāya vimuttiyā’ti. Sāriputtamevetaṃ sammā
analyzed: ariyāya paññāya vasi patto pārami patto ariyāya vimuttiyā ati sāriputtam eva etam sammā
translated: He has reached the end of the Ariyan path of wisdom, he has reached the end of the Ariyan search, he has reached the end of the Ariyan way of life, he has reached the end of the quest for wisdom. He is a great man, a supreme man, a man who has reached the goal, a man who has done his task, a man who has laid down the burden, a man who has reached his wish, a man who has reached the highest deva-state, a man who has attained to inner calm, a man who has attained to knowledge of the destruction of the cankers, a man who has attained to freedom by the highest knowledge, a man who has attained to the destruction of the cankers by the highest wisdom, a man who has attained to the Ariyan freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom.

original: vadamāno vadeyyā”ti.
analyzed: vadamānaḥ vadeyyā iti
translated: He who rightly speaks, speaks rightly when he speaks of Sāriputta.”

original: Evaṃ mahāputhuhāsajavanatikkhanibbedhikabhāvappattāya mahatiyā buddhiyā samannāgatattā
analyzed: evam mahā puthu hāsa javana tikkha nibbedhika bhāva ppattāya mahatiyā buddhiyā samannāgata ttā
translated: Thus, because he is endowed with great understanding which has attained to the state of being able to cross over the great plain of the Javana forest,

original: thero mahābuddhīti attho. Dhammanvayaveditā panassa sampasādanīyasuttena dīpetabbā.
analyzed: theraḥ mahābuddhi iti atthaḥ dhamma anvaya vedi tā pana assa sampasādanīya suttena dīpetabbā
translated: the meaning is that the Elder is of great understanding. But his knowledge of the connection of the Dhamma should be illustrated by the Sampasādanīyasutta.

original: Tattha hi sabbaññutaññāṇasadiso therassa nayaggāho vutto. Ajaḷo jaḷasamānoti sāvakesu
analyzed: tattha hi sabbaññu taññāṇa sadisaḥ therassa naya ggāhaḥ vuttaḥ ajaḷaḥ jaḷa samānaḥ ti sāvakesu
translated: For there the Elder’s grasp of the method is said to be like the knowledge of omniscience. He is not dull, though dull he seems:

original: paññāya ukkaṃsagatattā sabbathāpi ajaḷo samāno paramappicchatāya attānaṃ ajānantaṃ
analyzed: paññāya ukkaṃsa gata ttā sabbathā api ajaḷaḥ samāno param appicchatāya attānam a jānantam
translated: because of his pre-eminence in understanding among the disciples, he is not dull at all. But as if not knowing himself because of his extreme modesty,

original: viya katvā, dassanena jaḷasadiso mandasarikkho kilesapariḷāhābhāvena nibbuto sītibhūto
analyzed: viya katvā dassanena jaḷa sadisaḥ manda sa rikkhaḥ kilesa pariḷāha abhāvena nibbutaḥ sīti bhūtaḥ
translated: he is as if dull, as if slow-witted, and because of the absence of defilements and of fever he is extinguished, cool,

original: sadā carati niccaṃ viharatīti attho.
analyzed: sadā carati niccam viharati iti attho
translated: he always goes, he always abides.

original: Pariciṇṇoti gāthā therena attano katakiccataṃ pakāsentena bhāsitā, sāpi vuttatthāyeva.
analyzed: pariciṇṇā iti gāthā therena pakāsentena bhāsitā sā api vutta tthāya iva
translated: The verse Paricita is spoken by the Elder to show that his task is done, and it has the same meaning as the above.

original: Sampādethappamādenāti ayaṃ pana attano parinibbānakāle sannipatitānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ ovādadānavasena bhāsitā. Sāpi vuttatthāyevāti.
analyzed: sampādetha ppamādena āti ayam pana attanaḥ parinibbāna kāle sannipatitānam bhikkhūnam ovāda dāna vasena bhāsitā sā api vutta tthāya eva ati
translated: Sampādethappamādenā ti ayaṃ pana attano parinibbānakāle sannipatitānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ ovādadānavasena bhāsitā. Sāpi vuttatthāyevāti.

original: Sāriputtattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sāriputta thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Sāriputtattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.

original: 3. Ānandattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: ānanda thera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: Ānandattheragāthāvaṇṇanā

original: Pisuṇena ca kodhanenātiādikā āyasmato ānandattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi purimabuddhesu
analyzed: pisuṇena ca kodhanena ati ādikā āyasmataḥ ānanda ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi purima buddhesu
translated: Pisuṇena ca kodhanenātiādikā āyasmato ānandattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi purimabuddhesu

original: katādhikāro padumuttarassa bhagavato kāle haṃsavatīnagare satthu vemātikabhātā hutvā
analyzed: kata adhikāraḥ padumuttarassa bhagavataḥ kāle haṃsavatī nagare satthu vemātika bhātā hutvā
translated: katādhikāro padumuttarassa bhagavato kāle haṃsavatīnagare satthu vemātikabhātā hutvā

original: nibbatti, sumanotissa nāmaṃ ahosi. Pitā panassa ānandarājā nāma. So attano puttassa
analyzed: nibbatti sumanotissa nāmam ahosi pitā panassa ānanda rājā nāma so attano puttassa

analyzed: sabbāni tāni bālataḥ uppajjanti no paṇḍitataḥ tiādi
translated: all arise because of the fool, not because of the wise man” .

original: Yena pana saṃsaggo kātabbo, taṃ dassetuṃ “saddhena cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha saddhenāti🔽kammakammaphalasaddhāya ceva, ratanattayasaddhāya ca samannāgatena. Pesalenāti piyasīlena
analyzed: yena pana saṃsaggaḥ kātabbo tam dassetum saddhena ca atiādi vuttam tattha saddhena ati  kamma kamma phala saddhāya ca iva rata nattaya saddhāya ca samannāgatena pesalena ati piya sīlena
translated: But the following is said in order to show with whom one should associate: “With the virtuous” , and so on. Herein, with the virtuous means with one possessing virtue.

original: sīlasampannena. Paññavatāti udayatthagāminiyā nibbedhikāya paññāya vasena paññāsampannena.
analyzed: sīla sampannena paññavatā ati udaya attha gāminiyā nibbedhikāya paññāya vasena paññā sampannena
translated: With the wise means with one possessing understanding, in other words, with one who has the understanding that penetrates the rise and fall .

original: Bahussutenāti pariyattipaṭivedhabāhusaccānaṃ pāripūriyā bahussutena. Bhaddoti tena
analyzed: bahussutena ati pariyatti paṭivedha bāhu saccānam pāripūriyā bahussutena bhadda iti tena
translated: With the learned means with one who is learned in other words, with one who has fulfilled the learning that comes by study and by attainment.

original: tādisena sādhunā saṅgamo bhaddo sundaro kalyāṇo diṭṭhadhammikādibhedaṃ atthaṃ āvahatīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: tādisena sādhunā saṅgamaḥ bhaddaḥ sundaraḥ kalyāṇaḥ diṭṭhadhammika ādi bhedam attham āvahati iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: With the good means with one who is good in other words, with one who is virtuous. The meaning is that association with such a good person brings welfare, beauty, and excellence in this present life, and so on.

original: Passa cittakatantiādikā satta gāthā attano rūpasampattiṃ disvā kāmasaññaṃ uppādentiyā
analyzed: passa cittaka tanti ādikā satta gāthāḥ attanaḥ rūpa sampattim disvā kāma saññam uppādentiyā
translated: The seven verses beginning with “Look at Citta” were spoken by the Blessed One, it seems, with reference to a certain bhikkhu.

original: uttarāya nāma upāsikāya kāyavicchandajananatthaṃ bhāsitā. “Ambapāliṃ gaṇikaṃ disvā
analyzed: uttarāya nāma upāsikāya kāya vicchanda janana attham bhāsitāḥ ambapālim gaṇikam disvā
translated: “Having seen the courtesan Ambapālī,”

original: vikkhittacittānaṃ ovādadānattha”ntipi vadanti. Tā heṭṭhā vuttatthā eva.
analyzed: vikkhitta cittānam ovāda dāna ttham ti pi vadanti tāḥ heṭṭhā vutta tthāḥ eva
translated: “for the purpose of advising those with distracted minds,” they say. Those are the same as the purposes stated above.

original: Bahussuto cittakathītiādikā dve gāthā therena arahattaṃ patvā udānavasena bhāsitā.
analyzed: bahussutaḥ cittakathī iti ādikā dve gāthā therena arahattam patvā udāna vasena bhāsitā
translated: The two verses beginning with “Learned, a speaker of what is fitting” were spoken by the Elder as a spontaneous utterance after he had attained arahantship.

original: Tattha paricārakoti upaṭṭhāko. Seyyaṃ kappetīti arahattappattisamanantaraṃ sayitattā
analyzed: tattha paricārako ti upaṭṭhāko seyyam kappeti iti arahatta ppatti samanantaram
translated: Herein, attendant means supporter. He prepared a bed means he lay down because immediately after attaining arahantship

original: vuttaṃ. Thero hi bahudeva rattiṃ caṅkamena vītināmetvā sarīraṃ utuṃ gāhāpetuṃ ovarakaṃ
analyzed: vuttam theraḥ hi bahu deva rattim caṅkamena vītināmetvā sarīram utum gāhāpetum ovarakam
translated: he entered the inner room to take a rest after spending most of the night walking up and down.

original: pavisitvā sayituṃ mañcake nisinno pādā ca bhūmito muttā, appattañca sīsaṃ bimbohanaṃ,
analyzed: pavisitvā sayitum mañcake nisinnaḥ pādā ca bhūmitaḥ muttāḥ appattam ca sīsam bimbohanam
translated: Sitting on the bed, he let his feet hang down to the ground and his head was not yet on the pillow.

original: etthantare arahattaṃ patvā sayi.
analyzed: etthantare arahattam patvā sayi
translated: In that interval he attained arahantship and lay down.

original: Khīṇāsavoti parikkhīṇacaturāsavo, tato eva catūhipi yogehi visaṃyutto, rāgasaṅgādīnaṃ atikkantattā saṅgātīto, sabbaso kilesapariḷāhassa vūpasantattā sunibbuto sītibhūtoti attho.
analyzed: khīṇa āsavaḥ ti parikkhīṇa catur āsavaḥ tatas eva catūhi pi yogehi visaṃyuttaḥ rāga saṅga ādīnam atikkanta ttā saṅga atītaḥ sabbaso kilesa pariḷāhassa vūpasanta ttā su nibbutaḥ sīti bhūtaḥ iti attho
translated: “With cankers destroyed”: with the four cankers destroyed, and therefore dissociated from the four yokes. He is “beyond the attachments” because he has gone beyond the attachments of lust, etc. The meaning is that he is “well quenched” and “cooled” because the fever of all defilements has been removed.

original: Yasmiṃ patiṭṭhitā dhammāti theraṃ uddissa khīṇāsavamahābrahmunā bhāsitā gāthā. Upaṭṭhitāya
analyzed: yasmin patiṭṭhitā dhammā ati theram uddissa khīṇāsava mahābrahmunā bhāsitā gāthā upaṭṭhitāya
translated: “In whom the states are well established”: this verse was spoken by the Great Brahma, who had destroyed the cankers, in reference to the Elder. For at the time of the rehearsal of the Dhamma,

original: hi dhammasaṅgītiyā theraṃ uddissa yehi bhikkhūhi “eko bhikkhu vissagandhaṃ vāyatī”ti
analyzed: hi dhammasaṅgītiyā theram uddissa yehi bhikkhūhi ekaḥ bhikkhu vissa gandham vāyati iti
translated: when the Elder was accused by the bhikkhus who said, “One bhikkhu smells bad,”

original: vuttaṃ. Atha thero adhigate arahatte sattapaṇṇiguhādvāraṃ saṅghassa sāmaggīdānatthaṃ
analyzed: vuttam atha theraḥ adhigate arahatte satta paṇṇi guhā dvāram saṅghassa sāmaggī dāna attham
translated: the Elder, having attained arahantship, came to the door of the Sattapaṇṇiguha in order to give the bhikkhus a lesson in harmony.

original: āgato, tassa khīṇāsavabhāvappakāsanena suddhāvāsamahābrahmā. Te bhikkhū lajjāpento🔽“yasmiṃ patiṭṭhitā dhammā”ti gāthamāha. Tassattho – buddhassa bhagavato dhammā teneva
analyzed: āgataḥ tassa khīṇāsava bhāva ppakāsanena suddhāvāsa mahābrahmā te bhikkhū lajjāpentaḥ  yasmin patiṭṭhitāḥ dhammā ti gātham āha tassa atthaḥ buddhassa bhagavataḥ dhammā tena iva
translated: Then the Great Brahma, who had destroyed the cankers, in order to shame those bhikkhus by demonstrating the Elder’s purity,🔽said this verse, “In whom the states are well established.”

original: adhigatā paveditā ca paṭivedhapariyattidhammā. Yasmiṃ purisavisese patiṭṭhitā, soyaṃ
analyzed: adhigatā paveditā ca paṭivedha pariyatti dhammā yasmin purisa visese patiṭṭhitā saḥ ayam
translated: The meaning is this: the states of the Blessed One, the Buddha, were attained and proclaimed by him. In which person are they well established?

original: gottato gotamo dhammabhaṇḍāgāriko saupādisesanibbānassa adhigatattā idāni anupādisesanibbānagamane
analyzed: gottataḥ gotamaḥ dhammabhaṇḍāgāriko sa upādisesa nibbānassa adhigata ttā idāni anupādisesa nibbāna gamane
translated: He is a Gotama by clan. He is the treasurer of the Dhamma. He has attained Nibbāna with a residue of clinging left. Now he is going to Nibbāna without any residue of clinging left.

original: magge patiṭṭhahi, tassa ekaṃsabhāgīti.
analyzed: magge patiṭṭhahi tassa eka aṃsa bhāgī iti
translated: He was of the Gotama clan, and he was the treasurer of the Dhamma. He had attained Nibbāna with a residue of clinging left, and now he was established in the path to Nibbāna without residue of clinging left. He was a “part-liver.”

original: Athekadivasaṃ gopakamoggallāno nāma brāhmaṇo theraṃ pucchi – “tvaṃ bahussutoti buddhassa
analyzed: atha eka divasam gopakamoggallānaḥ nāma brāhmaṇaḥ theram pucchi tvam bahu ssuta iti buddhassa
translated: One day a brahmin named Gopaka Moggallāna asked the Elder, “You are well known as a man of great learning in the Buddha’s

original: sāsane pākaṭo, kittakā dhammā te satthārā bhāsitā, tayā dhāritā”ti? Tassa thero paṭivacanaṃ
analyzed: sāsane pākaṭaḥ kittakāḥ dhammā te satthārā bhāsitā tayā dhāritā ati tassa theraḥ paṭivacanaṃ
translated: Sāsana. How many teachings has the Master taught you, and how many have you memorized?” The Elder replied to him,

original: dento “dvāsītī”ti gāthamāha. Tattha dvāsīti sahassānīti yojanā, buddhato gaṇhinti🔽sammāsambuddhato uggaṇhiṃ dvisahassādhikāni asītidhammakkhandhasahassāni satthu santikā🔽adhigaṇhinti attho. Dve sahassāni bhikkhutoti dve dhammakkhandhasahassāni bhikkhuto
analyzed: dentaḥ dvāsīti iti gātham āha tattha dvāsīti sahassāni iti yojanā buddhataḥ  sammāsambuddhataḥ uggaṇhim dvi sahassa adhikāni asīti dhammakkhandha sahassāni satthu santikā  adhigaṇhinti attho dve sahassāni bhikkhuto ti dve dhammakkhandha sahassāni bhikkhuto
translated: saying, “I have memorized two thousand and eighty thousand teachings.” Here the word “thousand” is to be understood as a “myriad.”🔽He said, “I have memorized two thousand and eighty thousand teachings from the Fully Enlightened One.” The meaning is that he had memorized two thousand and eighty myriads of teachings from the Master.

original: gaṇhiṃ, dhammasenāpatiādīnaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ santikā adhigacchiṃ. Caturāsītisahassānīti
analyzed: gaṇhim dhammasenāpati ādīnam bhikkhūnam santikāḥ adhigacchim caturāsīti sahassāni iti
translated: He said, “I have memorized two thousand teachings from the bhikkhus.” He had memorized two myriads of teachings from the bhikkhus, from the bhikkhus headed by the General of the Dhamma.🔽He said, “I have memorized eighty-four thousand teachings.”

original: tadubhayaṃ samodhānetvā catusahassādhikāni asītisahassāni. Ye me dhammā pavattinoti
analyzed: tat ubhayam samodhānetvā catu sahassa adhikāni asīti sahassāni ye me dhammā pavattino ti
translated: and the two together make eighty-four thousand. ‘The ideas that occur to me’

original: ye yathāvuttaparimāṇā dhammakkhandhā mayhaṃ paguṇā vācuggatā jivhagge parivattantīti.
analyzed: ye yathā vutta parimāṇāḥ dhamma kkhandhāḥ mayham paguṇāḥ jivhagge parivattanti iti
translated: means the ideas in the form of the aggregates of existence, which are the above-mentioned extent, that occur to me, that are familiar to me, that are uttered by speech, that revolve in the mouth.

original: Athekadā thero sāsane pabbajitvā vipassanādhurepi ganthadhurepi ananuyuttaṃ ekaṃ
analyzed: atha ekadā theraḥ sāsane pabbajitvā vipassanā dhure pi gantha dhure pi an anuyuttam ekam
translated: Then, on a certain occasion, the Elder saw a certain person who had gone forth in the Dispensation, who was not devoted to either insight or to the scriptures,

original: puggalaṃ disvā bāhusaccābhāve ādīnavaṃ pakāsento “appassutāya”nti gāthamāha. Tattha
analyzed: puggalam disvā bāhu sacca abhāve ādīnavam pakāsentaḥ appassutāyanti gātham āha tattha
translated: and, in order to show the disadvantage in the absence of much learning, he uttered this stanza, ‘Because of little learning’. Herein,

original: appassutāyanti ekassa dvinnaṃ vā paṇṇāsānaṃ, atha vā pana vaggānaṃ antamaso ekassa🔽dvinnaṃ vā suttantānampi uggahitānaṃ abhāvena appassuto ayaṃ, kammaṭṭhānaṃ pana uggahetvā
analyzed: appassutāyanti ekassa dvinnam vā paṇṇāsānam atha vā pana vaggānam antamasaḥ ekassa  dvinnam vā suttantānam pi uggahitānam abhāvena appassutaḥ ayam kammaṭṭhānam pana uggahetvā
translated: ‘Because of little learning’ means that he is little learned because he has not learnt even one or two of the fifty or, again, of the nine-divisioned

original: anuyuñjanto bahussutova. Balibaddova jīratīti yathā balibaddo jīramāno vaḍḍhamāno
analyzed: anuyuñjantaḥ bahu ssutaḥ iva balibaddaḥ iva jīrati iti yathā balibaddaḥ jīramānaḥ vaḍḍhamānaḥ
translated: texts, but he is much learned if he has learnt a meditation subject and is devoted to it. ‘He grows old like a sacrificial ox’ means that just as a sacrificial ox grows old and gets fatter and fatter

original: neva mātu na pitu, na sesañātakānaṃ atthāya vaḍḍhati, atha kho niratthakameva jīrati;
analyzed: na iva mātu na pitu na sesa ñātakānaṃ atthāya vaḍḍhati atha kho niratthakam eva jīrati
translated: and yet does not grow for the sake of mother or father or for the sake of any other kinsmen, but he just grows uselessly,

original: evamevaṃ ayampi na upajjhāyavattaṃ karoti, na ācariyavattaṃ, na āgantukavattādīni,
analyzed: evam evam ayam pi na upajjhāya vattam karoti na ācariya vattam na āgantuka vatta ādīni
translated: So too, this man does not perform the duties to the preceptor, the duties to the teacher, the duties to visitors, etc.,

original: na bhāvanaṃ anuyuñjati, niratthakameva jīrati. Maṃsāni tassa vaḍḍhantīti yathā balibaddassa🔽“kasanabhāravahanādīsu asamattho eso”ti araññe vissaṭṭhassa yathā tathā vicarantassa
analyzed: na bhāvanam anuyuñjati niratthakam eva jīrati maṃsāni tassa vaḍḍhanti iti yathā balibaddassa  kasana bhāra vahana ādīsu asamatthaḥ esaḥ ti araññe vissaṭṭhassa yathā tathā vicarantassa
translated: and he does not apply himself to development. He just wastes away. His flesh grows fat: just as the flesh of a sacrificial animal🔽is incapable of work such as ploughing, etc., and is fed with nothing but grain and oil, so too,

original: khādantassa pivantassa maṃsāni tassa vaḍḍhanti; evamevaṃ imassāpi upajjhāyādīhi vissaṭṭhassa🔽saṅghaṃ nissāya cattāro paccaye labhitvā uddhaṃvirecanādīni katvā kāyaṃ posentassa
analyzed: khādantassa pivantassa maṃsāni tassa vaḍḍhanti evam evam imassa api upajjhāya ādīhi vissaṭṭhassa  saṅgham nissāya cattāraḥ paccaye labhitvā uddhaṃvirecana ādīni katvā kāyam posentassa
translated: as he wanders about here and there, eating and drinking, his flesh grows fat.

original: maṃsāni vaḍḍhanti thūlasarīro hutvā vicarati. Paññāti lokiyalokuttarā panassa paññā🔽ekaṅgulimattāpi na vaḍḍhati, araññe gacchalatādīni viya assa chadvārāni nissāya taṇhā
analyzed: maṃsāni vaḍḍhanti thūla sarīraḥ hutvā vicarati paññā ati lokiya lokuttarā panassa paññā  na vaḍḍhati araññe gaccha latā ādīni viya assa cha dvārāni nissāya taṇhā
translated: His wisdom does not grow: his wisdom, both mundane and supramundane,

original: ceva navavidhamāno ca vaḍḍhatīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: ca iva navavidha māno ca vaḍḍhati iti adhippāyo
translated: does not grow even as much as a finger’s breadth. The intention is that craving and the nine kinds of mental effluents grow in him through the six sense doors, like creepers in the forest.

original: Bahussutoti gāthā attano bāhusaccaṃ nissāya aññaṃ atimaññantaṃ ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ uddissa
analyzed: bahussuto ti gāthā attanaḥ bāhusaccam nissāya aññam atimaññantam ekam bhikkhum uddissa
translated: The verse “Bahussuto” was spoken with reference to a certain monk who was overweening because of his own great learning.

original: vuttā. Tattha sutenāti sutahetu attano bāhusaccanimittaṃ. Atimaññatīti atikkamitvā
analyzed: vuttā tattha sutena ati suta hetu attanaḥ bāhusacca nimittam atimaññati iti atikkamitvā
translated: Herein, he has studied : he has studied for the sake of learning, for the purpose of learning.🔽He is overweening : he is overweening, he exalts himself, he disparages others.

original: maññati attānaṃ ukkaṃsento paraṃ paribhavati. Tathevāti yathā andho andhakāre telapajjotaṃ
analyzed: maññati attānam ukkaṃsentaḥ param paribhavati tathā iva ati yathā andhaḥ andhakāre tela pajjotam
translated: Just as a blind man carrying a lamp

original: dhārento ālokadānena paresaṃyeva atthāvaho, na attano, tatheva pariyattibāhusaccena
analyzed: dhārentaḥ āloka dānena paresaṃyā iva na tathā iva pariyatti bāhusaccena
translated: is only a provider of light for others, not for himself,

original: sutavā puggalo sutena anupapanno attano atthaṃ aparipūrento andho ñāṇālokadānena
analyzed: sutavā puggalaḥ sutena anupapannaḥ attanaḥ attham a paripūrentaḥ andhaḥ ñāṇa āloka dānena
translated: so too the man of learning who is not provided with learning

original: paresaṃyeva atthāvaho, na attano, dīpadhāro andho viya mayhaṃ upaṭṭhātīti.
analyzed: paresam yeva attha āvahaḥ na attanaḥ dīpa dhāro andhaḥ viya mayham upaṭṭhāti iti
translated: is only a provider of light for others, not for himself, like the blind man carrying a lamp.

original: Idāni bāhusacce ānisaṃsaṃ dassento “bahussuta”nti gāthamāha. Tattha upāseyyāti payirupāseyya.
analyzed: idāni bāhusacce ānisaṃsam dassentaḥ bahussutam ti gātham āha tattha upāseyya ati payirupāseyya
translated: Now, showing the benefit in great learning, he said the verse “Bahussuto” . Herein, he should serve : he should serve him.

original: Sutañca na vināsayeti bahussutaṃ payirupāsitvā laddhaṃ sutañca na vināseyya, na susseyya
analyzed: sutam ca na vināsaya iti bahuḥ sutam payiḥ upāsitvā laddham sutam ca na vināseyya na susseyya
translated: And he should not destroy what he has learned : he should not let what he has learned by serving the man of learning be lost, he should not let it be forgotten.

original: dhāraṇaparicayaparipucchāmanasikārehi vaḍḍheyya. Taṃ mūlaṃ brahmacariyassāti yasmā🔽bahussutaṃ payirupāsitvā laddhaṃ taṃ sutaṃ pariyattibāhusaccaṃ maggabrahmacariyassa🔽mūlaṃ padhānakāraṇaṃ. Tasmā dhammadharo siyā vimuttāyatanasīse ṭhatvā yathāsutassa
analyzed: dhāraṇa paricaya paripucchā manasikārehi vaḍḍheyya tam mūlam brahmacariyassa ati yasmai  bahussutam payis upāsitvā laddham tam sutam pariyatti bāhu saccam magga brahmacariyassa  mūlam padhāna kāraṇam tasmā dhamma dharo siyā vimutta āyatana sīse ṭhatvā yathā sutassa
translated: The root of the holy life: since the learning that is the learning of the scriptures is the root, the basic cause, of the path holy life,

original: dhammassa dhāraṇe paṭhamaṃ pariyattidhammadharo bhaveyya.
analyzed: dhammassa dhāraṇe paṭhamam pariyatti dhamma dharaḥ bhaveyya
translated: therefore he should be a Dhamma-hoarder, that is, he should first be a Dhamma-hoarder of the scriptures by learning the Dhamma as heard, by standing with the head of the liberation-faculty of faith.

original: Idāni pariyattibāhusaccena sādhetabbamatthaṃ dassetuṃ “pubbāparaññū”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idāni pariyatti bāhusaccena sādhetabbam attham dassetum pubba aparaññu iti ādi vuttam
translated: Now, in order to show the meaning to be accomplished by means of the learning of the scriptures, “knowing the prior and subsequent” is said.

original: Tattha pubbañca aparañca jānātīti pubbāparaññū. Ekissā hi gāthāya pubbabhāge apaññāyamānepi
analyzed: tattha pubbam ca aparam ca jānāti iti pubba aparaññū ekissā hi gāthāya pubba bhāge a paññāyamāne pi
translated: Herein, he knows the prior and the subsequent, thus he is a knower of the prior and subsequent. For even though the prior part is not known in a single stanza,

original: pubbabhāge vā paññāyamāne aparabhāge apaññāyamānepi “imassa aparabhāgassa iminā pubbabhāgena,
analyzed: pubbabhāge vā paññāyamāne aparabhāge a paññāyamāne pi imassa aparabhāgassa iminā pubbabhāgena
translated: or even though the subsequent part is not known when the prior part is known, he knows that “the prior part of this should be by this subsequent part,

original: imassa vā pubbabhāgassa iminā aparabhāgena bhavitabba”nti jānanto pubbāparaññū nāma.
analyzed: imassa vā pubba bhāgassa iminā apara bhāgena bhavitabbanti jānantaḥ pubba aparaññū nāma
translated: or the subsequent part of this should be by this prior part.” Thus he is called a knower of the prior and subsequent.

original: Attatthādibhedaṃ tassa tassa bhāsitassa atthaṃ jānātīti atthaññū. Niruttipadakovidoti
analyzed: atta ttha ādi bhedam tassa tassa bhāsitassa attham jānāti iti atthaññū nirutti pada kovidaḥ ti
translated: He knows the meaning of what is spoken, which is classed as one’s own benefit and so on, thus he is “one who knows the meaning” . He is skilled in the phrasing of the vernacular,

original: niruttiyaṃ sesapadesupi cāti catūsupi paṭisambhidāsu cheko. Suggahītañca gaṇhātīti🔽teneva kovidabhāvena atthato byañjanato ca dhammaṃ sugahitameva katvā gaṇhāti. Atthañcopaparikkhatīti
analyzed: niruttiyam sesa padesu pi ca ati catūsu pi paṭisambhidāsu chekaḥ suggahītam ca gaṇhāti iti  tena iva kovida bhāvena atthataḥ byañjanato ca dhammam sugahitam eva katvā gaṇhāti attham ca upaparikkhati iti
translated: he is skilled in the four discriminations, namely, in the vernacular itself, in the rest of the terms, and in the four discriminations. He takes it by the ear,🔽by virtue of his skill he takes the True Idea by the ear, that is, he takes it well by the meaning and by the phrasing. He examines the meaning,

original: yathāsutassa yathāpariyattassa dhammassa atthaṃ upaparikkhati “iti sīlaṃ, iti samādhi,
analyzed: yathā sutassa yathā pariyattassa dhammassa attham upaparikkhati iti sīlam iti samādhi
translated: he examines the meaning of the True Idea as he has heard it and learned it thus: “Thus virtue, thus concentration,

original: iti paññā, ime rūpārūpadhammā”ti manasā anupekkhati.🔽Khantyā chandikato hotīti tesu manasā anupekkhitesu dhammesu diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā🔽nijjhānaṃ khamāpetvā rūpapariggahādimukhena vipassanābhinivese chandikato chandajāto
analyzed: iti paññāḥ ime rūpa arūpa dhammā ati manasā anupekkhati  khantyā chandikataḥ hoti iti tesu manasā an upekkhitesu dhammesu diṭṭhi nijjhāna khantiyā  nijjhānam khamāpetvā rūpa pariggaha ādi mukhena vipassanā abhinivese chandikataḥ chanda jātaḥ
translated: thus understanding, these are states with form, these are formless states” . He looks on at it with the mind.🔽He is eager to have it confirmed by acceptance,🔽when he has looked on at the states with the mind in this way, then by acceptance of the confirmed he is eager to have it confirmed by acceptance,

analyzed: hoti tathābhūtaḥ ca vipassanāya kammam karontaḥ ussahitvā tuleti taṃ taṃ paccaya nāma rūpa dassana vasena

original: ussāhaṃ katvā tato paraṃ tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā tuleti “anicca”ntipi, “dukkha”ntipi,
analyzed: ussāham katvā tato param tila khaṇam āropetvā tuleti aniccanti pi dukkhanti pi
translated: Then, after making endeavour, he should superimpose the three characteristics on it and weigh it thus: “impermanent,” “painful,” “not-self.”🔽He should turn that mentality-materiality over and over again in insight.

original: “anattā”tipi taṃ nāmarūpaṃ tīreti vipassati. Samaye so padahati, ajjhattaṃ susamāhitoti
analyzed: tam nāma rūpam tīreti vipassati samaye so padahati ajjhattam su samāhitaḥ ti
translated: He should make endeavour at the time of exerting the mind, well concentrated internally.

original: so evaṃ passanto paggahetabbādisamaye cittassa paggaṇhanādinā padahati, padahanto
analyzed: saḥ evam passantaḥ paggahetabba ādi samaye cittassa paggaṇhana ādinā padahati padahantaḥ
translated: Seeing thus, he should make endeavour at the time of exerting the mind, etc.,

original: ca ajjhattaṃ gocarajjhatte vipassanāsamādhinā maggasamādhinā ca suṭṭhu samāhito bhaveyya,
analyzed: ca ajjhattam gocara jjhatte vipassanā samādhinā magga samādhinā ca suṭṭhu samāhitaḥ bhaveyya
translated: and while making endeavour he should be well concentrated internally by means of the concentration of insight and the concentration of the path in the internal field of the exercise of insight.🔽He should abandon the defilements that are the cause of lack of concentration.

original: asamādhānahetubhūte kilese pajaheyya. Svāyaṃ guṇo sabbopi yasmā bahussutaṃ dhammadharaṃ🔽sappaññaṃ buddhasāvakaṃ payirupāsantassa hoti, tasmā asaṅkhataṃ dhammaṃ ārabbha dukkhādīsu
analyzed: asamādhāna hetu bhūte kilese pajaheyya svā ayam guṇo sabbaḥ api yasmai bahu ssutam dhamma dharam  sappaññam buddha sāvakam payirupāsantassa hoti tasmai asaṅkhatam dhammaṃ ārabbha dukkha ādīsu
translated: And this good quality of his, namely, that he has much learning and is a bearer of the Dhamma,🔽is due to his attendance on a good friend who is a disciple of the Enlightened One, who is wise,🔽Therefore, desiring to know the Dhamma called “knowledge of the Dhamma” in the sense of the three kinds of clear knowledge, namely, about suffering, etc.,

original: pariññādivisiṭṭhakiccatāya dhammaviññāṇasaṅkhātaṃ dhammañāṇaṃ ākaṅkhanto tathāvidhaṃ
analyzed: pariññā ādi visiṭṭha kicca tāya dhamma viññāṇa saṅkhātam dhamma ñāṇam ākaṅkhanto tathāvidham
translated: which is concerned with the unformed element, he should frequent

original: vuttappakāraṃ kalyāṇamittaṃ bhajetha, seveyya payirupāseyyāti attho.
analyzed: vutta ppakāram kalyāṇa mittam bhajetha seveyya payirupāseyya ati attho
translated: a good friend of the kind already described. The meaning is that he should serve him, wait on him, attend on him.

original: Evaṃ bahupakāratāya tassa pūjanīyakaṃ dassento “bahussuto”ti gāthamāha. Tassattho
analyzed: evam bahu pakāra tāya tassa pūjanīyakam dassentaḥ bahu ssutaḥ ti gātham āha tassa atthaḥ
translated: Showing him to be worthy of worship because of his great helpfulness, he uttered the stanza, “Bahussuto.” Its meaning is this:

original: – suttageyyādi bahu sutaṃ etassāti bahussuto. Tameva desanādhammaṃ suvaṇṇabhājane🔽pakkhittasīhavasā viya avinassantaṃ dhāretīti dhammadharo. Tato eva mahesino bhagavato
analyzed: sutta geyya ādi bahu sutam etassa ati bahussutaḥ tam eva desanā dhammam suvaṇṇa bhājane  pakkhitta sīha vasāḥ viya avinassantam dhāreti iti dhammadharo tatas eva mahesinaḥ bhagavataḥ
translated: He is called “bahussuto” because he has heard much of the Dhamma in the form of suttas, geyyas, etc.🔽He is called “dhammadharo” because he bears in mind that Dhamma which he has been taught, as if it were the oil of the lion’s flesh put into a golden vessel.

original: dhammakosaṃ dhammaratanaṃ ārakkhatīti kosārakkho. Yasmā sadevakassa lokassa samadassanena
analyzed: dhammakosam dhamma ratanam ārakkhati iti kosārakkhaḥ yasmā sa devakassa lokassa sama dassanena
translated: He is called “kosārakkho” because he guards the Dhamma-store, the Dhamma-jewel, of the great seer, the Blessed One.

original: cakkhubhūto, tasmā cakkhu sabbassa lokassa pūjanīyo mānanīyoti, bahussutabhāvena
analyzed: cakkhu bhūtaḥ tasmā cakkhu sabbassa lokassa pūjanīyaḥ mānanīyaḥ iti bahu ssuta bhāvena
translated: Because he is the eye of the world with its gods, he is worthy of the worship and reverence of the whole world.

original: bahujanassa pūjanīyabhāvadassanatthaṃ nigamanavasena punapi “bahussuto”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Evarūpaṃ kalyāṇamittaṃ labhitvāpi kārakasseva aparihāni, na akārakassāti dassento
analyzed: bahu janassa pūjanīya bhāva dassana attham nigamana vasena puna api bahussuto ti vuttam  evarūpam kalyāṇa mittam labhitvā api kārakassa iva na akārakassa ati dassento
translated: Therefore, in order to show that he is worthy of the worship of the multitude because of his great learning, he again says, “Bahussuto,” by way of conclusion.

original: “dhammārāmo”ti gāthamāha. Tattha nivāsanaṭṭhena samathavipassanādhammo ārāmo, tasmiṃ
analyzed: dhamma ārāmaḥ ti gātham āha tattha nivāsana ṭṭhena samatha vipassanā dhammo ārāmaḥ tasmin
translated: Even though one has obtained such a good friend, one does not attain the state of non-decline if one does not act. Showing this, he uttered the stanza, “Dhammārāmo.” Herein, the Dhamma of serenity and insight is the pleasure-park in the sense of a place of dwelling.

original: eva dhamme rato abhiratoti dhammarato, tasseva dhammassa punappunaṃ vicintanena dhammaṃ
analyzed: eva dhamme rataḥ abhirataḥ ati dhamma rataḥ tassa iva dhammassa punappunam vicintanena dhammaṃ
translated: He is delighted, pleased with that Dhamma, thus he is one who delights in Dhamma. By thinking again and again about that Dhamma, he is one who reflects on Dhamma. The meaning is: he adverts to Dhamma, he gives attention to Dhamma.

original: anuvicintayaṃ dhammaṃ āvajjento manasi karotīti attho. Anussaranti tameva dhammaṃ🔽anussaranto. Saddhammāti evarūpo bhikkhu sattatiṃsapabhedā bodhipakkhiyadhammā navavidhalokuttaradhammā
analyzed: anuvicintayan dhammaṃ āvajjentaḥ manasi karoti iti atthaḥ anussaranti tam eva dhammam  anussarantaḥ saddhammā ti evarūpaḥ bhikkhu sattatiṃsa pabhedāḥ bodhi pakkhiya dhammāḥ navavidha lokuttara dhammāḥ
translated: He remembers that same Dhamma.

original: ca na parihāyati, na kadāci tassa tato parihāni hotīti attho.🔽Athekadivasaṃ kāye avītarāgaṃ kusītaṃ hīnavīriyaṃ kosallāyā ti nāmaṃ bhikkhuṃ saṃvejento
analyzed: ca na parihāyati na kadāci tassa tato hoti iti attho  atha eka divasam kāye a vīta rāgam kusītam hīna vīriyam kosallāya ti nāmam bhikkhum saṃvejento
translated: He does not fall away from the true Dhamma. The meaning is that he never falls away from it.🔽Then, on a certain occasion, he spoke this stanza in order to stir up the monk named Kosalla, who was lazy and lacking in energy because he was not yet free from passion for sensual desires:

original: “kāyamaccheragaruno”ti gāthamāha. Tattha kāyamaccheragarunoti “kāyadaḷhībahulassa🔽kāye mamattassa ācariyupajjhāyānampi kāyena kattabbaṃ kiñci akatvā vicarantassa.
analyzed: gātham āha tattha kāya daḷhī bahulassa  kāye mamattassa ācariya upajjhāyānam pi kāyena kattabbam kiñci a katvā vicarantassa
translated: “Who, though his body’s strong and lusty,🔽Who, though his body’s strong and lusty,🔽who is full of bodily strength, who is self-indulgent in the body, who goes about doing nothing for his teachers and preceptors with his body,

original: Hiyyamāneti attano kāye jīvite ca khaṇe khaṇe parihiyyamāne. Anuṭṭhaheti sīlādīnaṃ
analyzed: hiyyamāna iti kāye jīvite ca khaṇe khaṇe parihiyyamāne anuṭṭhaha iti sīla ādīnam
translated: who is decaying, whose body and life are dwindling moment by moment,🔽who does not strive, who does not make effort, who does not exert energy, who does not put forth power, in the development of virtue, concentration, wisdom,

original: paripūraṇavasena uṭṭhānavīriyaṃ na kareyya. Sarīrasukhagiddhassāti attano sarīrassa🔽sukhāpaneneva gedhaṃ āpannassa. Kuto samaṇaphāsutāti evarūpassa puggalassa sāmaññavasena
analyzed: paripūraṇa vasena uṭṭhāna vīriyam na kareyya sarīra sukha giddhassa ati attanaḥ sarīrassa  sukhāpanena iva gedham āpannassa kutas samaṇa phāsu tā ti evarūpassa puggalassa sāmañña vasena
translated: He would not make the effort to fulfill them. Craving the ease of his body: he is intent on the ease of his own body.🔽How can there be the comfort of recluseship?🔽

original: kuto sukhavihāro, phāsuvihāro na tassa vijjatīti attho.🔽Na pakkhantītiādikā āyasmato sāriputtassa dhammasenāpatino parinibbutabhāvaṃ sutvā🔽therena bhāsitā. Tattha na pakkhanti disā sabbāti puratthimādibhedā sabbā disā na🔽pakkhayanti, disāmūḷhoti attho. Dhammā na paṭibhanti manti pubbe suṭṭhu paguṇāpi
analyzed: kutas sukha vihāro phāsu vihāro na tassa vijjati iti attho  na pakkhanti iti ādikā āyasmataḥ sāriputtassa dhamma senāpatino parinibbuta bhāvam sutvā  therena bhāsitā tattha na disā sabbā ti puratthima ādi bhedā sabbā disā na  pakkhayanti disāmūḷhaḥ ti atthaḥ dhammā na paṭibhanti manti pubbe suṭṭhu paguṇā api
translated: He would not make the effort to fulfill them. Greedy for the pleasure of his body: he has become greedy for the pleasure of his own body. Where is the recluse’s ease? : where is the recluse’s ease for such a person? The meaning is, it does not exist for him.

original: pariyattidhammā idāni sakkaccaṃ samannāhariyamānāpi mayhaṃ na upaṭṭhahanti. Gate
analyzed: pariyatti dhammāḥ idāni sakkaccam samannāhariyamānā api mayham na upaṭṭhahanti gate
translated: They do not shine: this was said by the elder when he heard of the final nibbana of the venerable Sariputta, the general of the Dhamma. Herein, they do not shine, the directions all: all the directions, divided into east, etc., do not shine, the meaning is, he is confused about the directions. The Dhamma does not shine, the mind: the Dhamma of the scriptures, though formerly well learned, does not appear to me now even though I strive to recollect it carefully. Gone

original: kalyāṇamittamhīti sadevakassa lokassa kalyāṇamittabhūte dhammasenāpatimhi anupādisesanibbānaṃ
analyzed: kalyāṇa mittamhi iti sa devakassa lokassa kalyāṇa mitta bhūte dhamma senāpatimhi anupādisesa nibbānam
translated: is my good friend: the general of the Dhamma, who was a good friend to the world with its gods, has attained the complete extinction in which no basis for further becoming is left behind.

original: gate. Andhakāraṃva khāyatīti sabbopāyaṃ loko andhakāro viya upaṭṭhāti.
analyzed: gate andhakāram va khāyati iti sabba upāyam lokaḥ andhakāraḥ viya upaṭṭhāti
translated: “It seems as if darkness has come” : the whole world appears to him as if it were darkness.

original: Abbhatītasahāyassāti apagatasahāyassa, kalyāṇamittarahitassāti attho. Atītagatasatthunoti🔽āyasmato atīto hutvā nibbānagatasatthukassa, satthari parinibbuteti attho. Yathā
analyzed: abbhatīta sahāyassa ati apagata sahāyassa kalyāṇa mitta rahitassa ati atthaḥ atīta gata satthuno ti  āyasmataḥ atītaḥ hutvā nibbāna gata satthukassa satthari parinibbutā iti atthaḥ yathā
translated: “With a friend gone beyond” : with a friend who has gone beyond, who has departed, the meaning is, “devoid of a good friend.” “With a teacher gone beyond” :

original: kāyagatā satīti kāyagatāsatibhāvanā takkarassa yathā ekantahitāvahā, evaṃ etādisaṃ🔽anāthassa puggalassa ekantahitāvahaṃ aññaṃ mittaṃ nāma natthi, sanāthassa aññāpi
analyzed: kāya gatā satī iti kāya gatā asati bhāvanā takkarassa yathā ekanta hita āvahā evam etādisam  anāthassa puggalassa ekanta hita āvaham aññam mittam nāma natthi sa nāthassa aññā api
translated: with a teacher who has gone beyond, who has attained Nibbāna, the meaning is, “with a teacher who has attained final Nibbāna.” “Just as” : just as the development of mindfulness directed to the body

original: bhāvanā hitāvahā evāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: bhāvanā hita āvahā eva ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: is the only friend of one who is devoted to it, so too there is no other friend who is so helpful to a person who is without a protector. The intention is that for one who has a protector, other kinds of development are also helpful.

original: Purāṇāti porāṇā, sāriputtādike kalyāṇamitte sandhāya vadati. Navehīti navakehi. Na🔽sameti meti mayhaṃ cittaṃ na samāgacchati, na te mama cittaṃ ārādhentīti attho. Svajja
analyzed: purāṇā iti porāṇā sāriputta ādike kalyāṇa mitte sandhāya vadati navehi iti navakehi na  sameti mā iti mayham cittam na samāgacchati na te mama cittam ārādhenti iti
translated: “Old” : ancient, referring to good friends such as Sāriputta. “And new” : the new ones.

original: ekova jhāyāmīti sohaṃ ajja vuḍḍhatarehi virahito ekova hutvā jhāyāmi jhānapasuto
analyzed: ekaḥ iva jhāyāmi iti saḥ ham ajja vuḍḍhatarehi virahitaḥ ekaḥ iva hutvā jhāyāmi jhānapa sutaḥ
translated: “Does not agree with me” : my mind does not agree with them, the meaning is, they do not please my mind. “Today I meditate alone” : today, being devoid of those who are older, I meditate alone, devoted to jhāna.

original: homi. Vassupetoti vassakāle kulāvakaṃ upeto pakkhī viya. “Vāsupeto”tipi pāḷi, vāsaṃ upagatoti attho.🔽Dassanāya abhikkanteti gāthā satthārā bhāsitā. Tassattho – mama dassanāya abhikkante🔽nānāvidhavidesapavāsikabahujane, ānanda, mama upasaṅkamanaṃ mā vāresi. Kasmā? Te
analyzed: homi vassupeto ti vassa kāle kulāvakam upeto pakkhī viya vāsupeto tipi vāsam upagato ti attho  dassanāya abhikkante iti gāthā satthārā bhāsitā tassa atthaḥ mama dassanāya abhikkante  nānāvidha videsapavāsika bahu jane ānanda mama upasaṅkamanam mā vāresi kasmā te
translated: I am. “I am settled for the Rains” means: I am settled for the Rains like a bird that has settled in a tree-hollow. “Vāsupeto” is also a reading, the meaning being: I have gone to live .

original: sotāro dhammassa, mamaṃ passantu, ayameva dassanāya samayoti.
analyzed: sotāraḥ dhammassa mamam passantu ayam eva dassanāya samayaḥ ti
translated: The verse “When they come to see me” was spoken by the Teacher. Its meaning is this: “When they come to see me, Ānanda, do not prevent the people who come from various countries and regions from approaching me. Why? Because they are hearers of the Dhamma. Let them see me. This is the purpose of their coming to see me.”

original: Taṃ sutvā thero “dassanāya abhikkante”ti aparaṃ gāthamāha. Imāya hi gāthāya sambandhatthaṃ🔽purimagāthā idha nikkhittā. Teneva sacāhaṃ desantarato āgatāgate tāvadeva dassetuṃ
analyzed: tam sutvā theraḥ dassanāya abhikkanta iti aparam gātham āha imāya hi gāthāya sambandha ttham  purima gāthā idha nikkhittā tena iva sacā aham desantarataḥ āgata āgate tāvat eva dassetuṃ
translated: Having heard this, the Elder recited the verse “When they come to see me.” For the meaning of this verse is connected with the previous verse.

original: lacchāmīti etassa padassa atthasiddhiṃ dasseti.
analyzed: lacchāmi iti etassa padassa attha siddhim dasseti
translated: Therefore the previous verse is included here. Thus he shows the meaning of the expression “if I were to show them” by saying that he could show them as soon as they arrived from other countries.

original: Paṇṇavīsati vassānīti pañca gāthā attano aggupaṭṭhākabhāvaṃ dīpetuṃ vuttā. Āraddhakammaṭṭhānabhāvena
analyzed: paṇṇavīsati vassāni iti pañca gāthāḥ attanaḥ aggupaṭṭhāka bhāvam dīpetum vuttāḥ āraddha kammaṭṭhāna bhāvena
translated: The five verses beginning with “For twenty-nine years” were spoken in order to show his own status as the foremost attendant.

original: hi satthu upaṭṭhānapasutabhāvena ca therassa maggena asamucchinnāpi kāmasaññādayo
analyzed: hi satthu upaṭṭhāna pasuta bhāvena ca therassa maggena asamucchinnā api kāma saññā ādayaḥ
translated: and because of his service to the Teacher and his attendance on the Elder,

original: na uppajjiṃsu, kāyavacīmanokammāni ca sabbakālaṃ satthari mettāpubbaṅgamāni mettānuparivattāni
analyzed: na uppajjiṃsu kāya vacī manaḥ kammāni ca sabbakālam satthari mettā pubbaṅgamāni mettā anuparivattāni
translated: the perceptions of sensual desire, etc., which had not been completely eradicated by the path, did not arise. And his bodily, verbal, and mental actions were always preceded by and followed by loving-kindness.

original: ahesuṃ. Tattha paṇṇavīsati vassānīti pañcavīsati saṃvaccharāni. Sekhabhūtassa me
analyzed: ahesum tattha paṇṇavīsati vassāni iti pañcavīsati saṃvaccharāni sekha bhūtassa me
translated: Herein, twenty-five years means twenty-five years.

original: satoti sekhabhūmiyaṃ sotāpattiphale ṭhitassa me sato. Kāmasaññāti kāmasahagatā saññā
analyzed: sataḥ ti sekha bhūmiyam sotāpatti phale ṭhitassa me sataḥ kāma saññā ti kāma sahagatā saññā
translated: While I was still a learner means while I was still established in the fruit of stream-entry, the stage of a learner. The perception of sensual desire means the perception associated with sensual desire.

original: na uppajji, ettha ca kāmasaññādianuppattivacanena attano āsayasuddhiṃ dasseti, “mettena🔽kāyakammenā”tiādinā payogasuddhiṃ. Tattha gandhakuṭiyaṃ paribhaṇḍakaraṇādinā satthu
analyzed: na uppajji ettha ca kāma saññā ādi anuppatti vacanena attanaḥ āsaya suddhim dasseti mettena  kāya kammena ati ādinā payoga suddhim tattha gandhakuṭiyam paribhaṇḍa karaṇa ādinā satthu
translated: Did not arise. And by the statement that the perception of sensual desire, etc., did not arise, he shows the purity of his own inclination, and by the statement “with loving-kindness” he shows the purity of his own application.🔽Herein, loving-kindness in bodily action should be understood as the performance of service to the Teacher by such acts as cleaning his dwelling at the Fragrant Cell, etc.;

original: vattapaṭivattakaraṇena ca mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ veditabbaṃ, dhammadesanākālārocanādinā
analyzed: vatta paṭivatta karaṇena ca mettam kāya kammam veditabbam dhamma desanā kāla ārocanā ādinā
translated: loving-kindness in verbal action as the announcement of the time for the Dhamma talk, etc.;

original: mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ, rahogatassa satthāraṃ uddissa hitūpasaṃhāramanasikārena mettaṃ
analyzed: mettam vacī kammam rahogatassa satthāram uddissa hitu upasaṃhāra manasikārena mettam
translated: and loving-kindness in mental action as the directing of one’s thoughts to the welfare of the Teacher when one is alone.

original: manokammaṃ. Ñāṇaṃ me udapajjathāti attano sekkhabhūmipattimāha.
analyzed: manaḥ kammam ñāṇam me udapajjatha iti attanaḥ sekkha bhūmi pattim āha
translated: and mind-action. “Knowledge arose in me” : he says this to show his attainment of the stage of a disciple in higher training.

original: Ahaṃ sakaraṇīyomhīti satthu parinibbāne upaṭṭhite maṇḍalamāḷaṃ pavisitvā kapisīsaṃ
analyzed: aham sa karaṇīyaḥ ahi iti satthu parinibbāne upaṭṭhite maṇḍalamāḷam pavisitvā kapisīsam
translated: “I have a task to do” : when the Teacher’s parinibbāna was announced, he entered the circular hall,

original: ālambitvā sokābhibhūtena vuttagāthā. Tattha sakaraṇīyomhīti dukkhaparijānanādinā
analyzed: ālambitvā soka abhibhūtena vutta gāthā tattha sa karaṇīyaḥ asmi iti dukkha parijānana ādinā
translated: and, leaning on the door-post, he uttered the verse in his grief. There, “I have a task to do” : I have a task to do by way of the full understanding of suffering, etc.

original: karaṇīyena sakaraṇīyo amhi. Appattamānasoti anadhigatārahatto. Satthu ca parinibbānanti
analyzed: karaṇīyena sa karaṇīyaḥ amhi appatta mānasaḥ ti an adhigata arahattaḥ satthu ca parinibbānanti
translated: “My mind is not yet satisfied” : I have not yet attained arahatship. “And the Teacher’s parinibbāna” :

original: mayhaṃ satthu parinibbānañca upaṭṭhitaṃ. Yo amhaṃ anukampakoti yo satthā mayhaṃ anuggāhako.
analyzed: mayham satthu parinibbānañca upaṭṭhitam yaḥ amham anukampako ti yaḥ satthā mayham anuggāhako
translated: the Teacher’s parinibbāna has been announced. “The one who had compassion on me” : the Teacher who was my supporter.

original: Tadāsi yaṃ bhiṃsanakanti gāthā satthu parinibbānakāle pathavīkampanadevadundubhiphalanādike disvā sañjātasaṃvegena vuttagāthā.
analyzed: tadā asi yam bhiṃsanakanti gāthā satthu parinibbāna kāle pathavī kampana deva dundubhi phalana ādike disvā sañjāta saṃvegena vutta gāthā
translated: “That was a fearful time” : these verses were uttered by the Elder when he was overcome with grief on seeing the quaking of the earth, the falling of celestial drums, etc., at the time of the Teacher’s parinibbāna.

original: Bahussutotiādikā tisso gāthā theraṃ pasaṃsantehi saṅgītikārehi ṭhapitā. Tattha gatimantoti
analyzed: bahussutaḥ ti ādikā tissaḥ gāthā theram pasaṃsantehi saṅgīti kārehi ṭhapitā tattha gatimanto ti

original: asadisāya ñāṇagatiyā samannāgato. Satimantoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgato.
analyzed: asadisāya ñāṇa gatiyā samannāgato satimanto ti paramena sati nepakkena samannāgato
translated: He was endowed with a unique understanding of the Dhamma.🔽He was endowed with mindfulness, with the highest mindfulness and self-possession.

original: Dhitimantoti asādhāraṇāya byañjanatthāvadhāraṇasamatthāya dhitisampattiyā samannāgato.
analyzed: dhitimanto ti asādhāraṇāya byañjana attha avadhāraṇa samatthāya dhiti sampattiyā samannāgataḥ
translated: He was endowed with steadfastness, with the steadfastness that is able to grasp the letter and the meaning of the Dhamma.

original: Ayañhi thero ekapadeyeva ṭhatvā saṭṭhipadasahassāni satthārā kathitaniyāmeneva gaṇhāti,
analyzed: ayam hi theraḥ eka padeyā iva ṭhatvā saṭṭhi pada sahassāni satthārā kathita niyāmena iva gaṇhāti
translated: For this Elder, standing in one place, could grasp in the very same way that the Teacher had taught it the six thousand sections of the Dhamma.

translated: And what he had grasped did not disappear at any time, just as the fat of a lion poured into a golden vessel.🔽He was endowed with the wisdom that has mindfulness as its forerunner, which is able to grasp the letter of the Dhamma without error,

original: satipubbaṅgamāya paññāya, atthāvadhāraṇasamatthāya paññāpubbaṅgamāya satiyā ca samannāgato.
analyzed: sati pubbaṅgamāya paññāya attha avadhāraṇa samatthāya paññā pubbaṅgamāya satiyā ca samannāgataḥ
translated: and with the mindfulness that has wisdom as its forerunner, which is able to grasp the meaning of the Dhamma.

original: Tenāha bhagavā – “etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, mama sāvakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bahussutāna”ntiādi.

original: Pariciṇṇoti gāthā parinibbānakāle therena bhāsitā, sā vuttatthā eva.

translated: The verse Paricinnā is one spoken by the Elder at the time of his attaining Nibbāna. Its meaning is self-evident.

translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Ānanda is finished.

The layman, perceiving that the Teacher had accepted his invitation,

analyzed: so therassa pattam gahetvā piṇḍapātassa pūretvā adāsi tatas theram anugantvā nivatto  satthu santike nisīditvā evam āha mahānisabha theraḥ bhante satthā api gehe nisinnaḥ ti

analyzed: vutte api pavisitum na icchi atthi nu kho etassa tumhākam guṇehi atireka guṇaḥ ti buddhānam ca  vaṇṇamaccheram nāma natthi tasmā satthā evam āha upāsaka mayam bhikkham āgamayamānā

analyzed: sayam tam vattham pārupitvā gacchati brāhmaṇīnam sannipāte sati sayam gehe acchati

analyzed: brāhmaṇī tam vattham pārupitvā gacchati tasmin pana divase brāhmaṇaḥ brāhmaṇim āha  bhoti kim rattim dhammam suṇissasi divā ati mayam mātugāmajātikāḥ nāma rattim
translated: The Brahman himself put on the robe and went. When the Brahmans had assembled, the Brahman’s wife put on the robe and went.

analyzed: sotum na sakkoma divā sossāma ati brāhmaṇam gehe ṭhapetvā tam vattham pārupitvā upāsikāhi

original: saddhiṃ divā gantvā satthāraṃ vanditvā ekamante nisinnā dhammaṃ sutvā upāsikāhiyeva
analyzed: saddhim divā gantvā satthāram vanditvā ekamante nisinnā dhammam sutvā upāsikā hiyā iva
translated: After paying obeisance to the Teacher, she sat down respectfully and listened to the Law. Then she returned with the female lay disciples.

original: saddhiṃ āgamāsi. Atha brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇiṃ gehe ṭhapetvā taṃ vatthaṃ pārupitvā vihāraṃ gato.🔽Tasmiṃ samaye satthā parisamajjhe alaṅkatadhammāsane nisinno cittabījaniṃ ādāya ākāsagaṅgaṃ
analyzed: saddhim āgamāsi atha brāhmaṇaḥ brāhmaṇim gehe ṭhapetvā tam vattham pārupitvā vihāram gataḥ  tasmin samaye satthā parisamajjhe alaṅkata dhammāsane nisinnaḥ citta bījanim ādāya ākāsagaṅgaṃ
translated: The Brahman remained at home, and his wife put on the robe and went to the monastery.

original: otārento viya, sineruṃ manthaṃ katvā sāgaraṃ nimmathento viya, dhammakathaṃ kathesi.

analyzed: pūrayamānā pañca vaṇṇā pīti uppajji saḥ pāruta vattham saṅgharitvā dasabalassa dassāmi iti  cintesi atha assa ādīnava sahassam dassayamānam maccheram uppajji saḥ brāhmaṇiyā mayham ca

analyzed: na sakkā ati sabbathā api a dātu kāmo ahosi atha assa nikkhante paṭhama yāme majjhima yāme pi  tathā iva pīti uppajji tathā iva cintetvā tathā iva a dātu kāmo ahosi athassa majjhima yāme

translated: ” He folded up the garment and placed it at the Teacher’s feet. Then he extended his left hand

analyzed: raññaḥ ca nāma jitam me iti saddaḥ amanāpaḥ hoti so purisam pesesi gaccha etam  puccha kim vadasi iti so tena gantvā pucchitaḥ avasesā hatthi yāna ādīni āruyha asi camma ādīni  gahetvā para senam jinanti na tam acchariyam aham pana pacchatas āgacchantassa kūṭagoṇassa
translated: And it is unpleasant for a king to hear the words “I have won.” So he sent a man, saying, “Go and ask him

analyzed: dasabalassa adāsim tam me mad śariyam jitanti āha saḥ purisaḥ āgantvā tam pavattim

translated: The man returned and reported this to the king. The king said, “We did not know, my good man, what was suitable for the ten powers. The brahmin

analyzed: jāni iti vattha yugam pesesi tam disvā brāhmaṇaḥ cintesi ayam mayham tuṇhī nisinnassa

analyzed: paṭhamam kiñci a datvā satthu guṇe kathentassa adāsi satthu guṇe paṭicca uppannena

analyzed: pana mayham kaḥ atthaḥ iti tam pi vattha yugam dasabalassa iva adāsi rājā api kim brāhmaṇena
translated: ” So he gave the pair of garments to the Teacher. The king asked, “What did the brāhmaṇa do?”

analyzed: katanti pucchitvā tam pi tena vattha yugam tathāgatassa iva dinnanti sutvā aññāni pi

translated: And from that time forth he became a faithful supporter of the Teacher.

translated: One day the king saw him listening to the Law in the Teacher’s presence, and when he saw him, he said, “What a noble young man! What a noble young man!”🔽

translated: One day the king saw him listening to the Law in the presence of the Teacher, and gave him a blanket worth a hundred thousand pieces of money, saying, “Henceforth listen to the Law wrapped in this blanket.”

translated: and went his way. One day the king went to the monastery early in the morning and sat down in the Perfumed Chamber in the presence of the Teacher.

original: kambale paṭihaññanti, kambalo ativiya virocati. Rājā ullokento sañjānitvā āha – “amhākaṃ,
analyzed: kambale paṭihaññanti kambalaḥ ativiya virocati rājā ullokentaḥ sañjānitvā āha amhākam
translated: On that occasion the seven-colored rays of the Buddha shone upon the blanket, and the blanket shone with exceeding splendor. The king looked and recognized it, and said, “Reverend Sir, this blanket belongs to us. We gave it to a certain monk.”

analyzed: bhante esa kambalaḥ amhehi eka sāṭaka brāhmaṇassa dinnaḥ ti tumhehi mahā rāja brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: “Great king, you gave it to a certain monk, but that monk gave it to me.”

original: pūjito, brāhmaṇena mayaṃ pūjitā”ti. Rājā “brāhmaṇo yuttaṃ aññāsi, na maya”nti pasīditvā
analyzed: pūjitaḥ brāhmaṇena mayam pūjitā ati rājā brāhmaṇaḥ yuttam na pasīditvā
translated: “The brahmin has been honoured, and so we have been honoured.” The king was pleased, and thought, “The brahmin is right, I am not.”🔽He gave the brahmin the position of chief priest, and the brahmin gave the king advice on how to rule the country. The king gave the brahmin all the things that were useful to people, dividing them into eight portions, and gave him the first portion.

original: yaṃ manussānaṃ upakārabhūtaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ aṭṭhaṭṭhakaṃ katvā sabbaṭṭhakaṃ nāma dānaṃ🔽datvā purohitaṭṭhāne ṭhapesi. Sopi “aṭṭhaṭṭhakaṃ nāla catusaṭṭhi hotī”ti catusaṭṭhi
analyzed: yam manussānam upakāra bhūtam tam sabbam aṭṭhaṭṭhakam katvā sabbaṭṭhakam nāma dānam  datvā purohita ṭṭhāne ṭhapesi saḥ api aṭṭhaṭṭhakam na āla catusaṭṭhi hoti iti catusaṭṭhi
translated: This gift was called the “first portion” (sabbaṭṭhaka).

original: salākabhattāni upanibandhāpetvā yāvajīvaṃ dānaṃ datvā sīlaṃ rakkhitvā tato cuto sagge nibbatti.

translated: The brahmin thought, “Eight portions make forty-eight,” and he had forty-eight portions set aside. He gave gifts for the rest of his life, observed the precepts, and after his death was reborn in heaven.

original: Puna tato cuto imasmiṃ kappe koṇāgamanassa ca bhagavato kassapadasabalassa cāti dvinnaṃ
analyzed: puna tatas imasmin kappe koṇāgamanassa ca bhagavataḥ kassapadasabalassa ca ati dvinnam
translated: After he was reborn in heaven, he was reborn in the time of two Buddhas, Koṇāgamana and Kassapa,

analyzed: buddhānam antare bārāṇasiyam kuṭumbiya ghare nibbattaḥ saḥ vuddhim anvāya ghara āvāsam
translated: in the family of a householder in Bārāṇasī. He grew up, married, and lived at home.

analyzed: vasantaḥ eka divasam araññe jaṅghavihāram carati tasmin ca samaye paccekabuddhaḥ nadī tīre
translated: One day he went for a walk in the forest. At that time a Private Buddha was making a robe on the bank of a river.

analyzed: cīvara kammam karontaḥ anuvāte appahonte saṅgharitvā ṭhapetum āraddhaḥ saḥ disvā kasmā
translated: He had collected some grass to make a cushion, but there was not enough to make a windbreak. The householder saw him and thought, “Why is he sitting there?

analyzed: bhante saṅgharitvā ṭhapetha ati āha anuvātaḥ na pahoti iti iminā bhante karotha ati
translated: “The wind will not carry it away.” “Do this, Reverend Sir.”

original: uttarasāṭakaṃ datvā “nibbattanibbattaṭṭhāne me kenaci parihāni mā hotū”ti patthanaṃ paṭṭhapesi.
analyzed: uttara sāṭakam datvā nibbatta nibbatta ṭhāne me kenaci parihāni mā hotu uti patthanam paṭṭhapesi
translated: And he gave him his upper robe, and made the wish, “Wherever I am reborn, let me never be deprived of anything.”

analyzed: bhaginiyā saddhim bhariyāya kalaham karontiyā paccekabuddhaḥ piṇḍāya pāvisi  atha assa bhaginī paccekabuddhassa piṇḍapātam da tvā tassa bhariyam sandhāya evarūpam  bālam yojana satena parivajjeyyanti patthanam paṭṭhapesi sā gehaṅgaṇe ṭhitā sutvā
translated: Now a certain man was quarreling with his wife, who was also his sister. A Private Buddha entered the village for alms.🔽The sister gave alms to the Private Buddha, and made the wish, “May I never meet with such a fool again, even in a dream.”

original: “imāya dinnabhattaṃ mā esa bhuñjatū”ti pattaṃ gahetvā piṇḍapātaṃ chaḍḍetvā kalalassa🔽pūretvā adāsi. Itarā disvā “bāle, tvaṃ maṃ tāva akkosa vā pahara vā, evarūpassa pana
analyzed: imāya dinna bhattam mā esa bhuñjatu iti pattam gahetvā piṇḍapātam chaḍḍetvā kalalassa  pūretvā adāsi itarā disvā bāle tvam mam tāva akkosa vā pahara vā evarūpassa pana
translated: The wife heard her, and standing in the doorway, said to herself, “Let him not eat the food she has given him.” So she took the bowl, threw the food away, filled the bowl with mud, and gave it to him.

original: dve asaṅkhyeyyāni pūritapāramissa pattato bhattaṃ chaḍḍetvā kalalaṃ dātuṃ na yutta”nti
analyzed: dve asaṅkhyeyyāni pūrita pāramissa pattataḥ bhattam chaḍḍetvā kalalam dātum na yuttanti
translated: The sister saw what she had done, and said, “You fool, you may revile me and beat me, but it is not proper for you to throw away the food he has given you and to give him mud in return, for he has fulfilled the Perfections during two incalculable periods and a hundred thousand cycles.”

analyzed: āha atha assa bhariyāya paṭisaṅkhānam uppajji sā tiṭṭhatha bhante ti kalalam chaḍḍetvā
translated: His wife reflected, “What is the use of this?” She said, “Wait, Reverend Sir,” and throwing away the lump of flesh,

analyzed: pattam dhovitvā gandha cuṇṇena ubbaṭṭetvā paṇīta bhattassa catu madhurassa ca pūretvā  upari āsittena paduma gabbha vaṇṇena sappinā vijjotamānam paccekabuddhassa hatthe ṭhapetvā
translated: washing the bowl, and filling it with perfumed powder, she filled it with choice rice and the four sweet foods,

original: “yathā ayaṃ piṇḍapāto obhāsajāto, evaṃ obhāsajātaṃ me sarīraṃ hotū”ti patthanaṃ paṭṭhapesi.
