translated: “One should not have much work, avoid crowds and exertion,

original: Ussukko so rasānugiddho, atthaṃ riñcati yo sukhāvaho.
analyzed: ussukkaḥ saḥ rasa anugiddhaḥ attham riñcati yaḥ sukha āvahaḥ
translated: The one who is diligent, greedy for tastes, abandons the good, which brings happiness.

original: “Kammaṃ bahukaṃ na kāraye, parivajjeyya anattaneyyametaṃ;
analyzed: kammam bahukam na kāraye parivajjeyya
translated: “One should not have much work, avoid what is not one’s own,

original: Kicchati kāyo kilamati, dukkhito so samathaṃ na vindati.
analyzed: kicchati kāyaḥ kilamati dukkhitaḥ so samatham na vindati
translated: The body suffers, is exhausted, and being afflicted, does not find peace.

original: “Oṭṭhappahatamattena, attānampi na passati;
analyzed: oṭṭha ppahata mattena attānam pi na passati
translated: “By just a little effort, one does not see oneself,

original: Patthaddhagīvo carati, ahaṃ seyyoti maññati.
analyzed: carati aham seyyo ti maññati
translated: With neck stretched out, one goes about, thinking ‘I am better.’

original: “Aseyyo seyyasamānaṃ, bālo maññati attānaṃ;
analyzed: aseyyo seyya samānam bālaḥ maññati attānam
translated: “The fool thinks himself equal, or better, than his equal;

original: Na taṃ viññū pasaṃsanti, patthaddhamānasaṃ naraṃ.
analyzed: na tam viññū pasaṃsanti patthaddha mānasam naram
translated: The wise man praises the one who is better than himself.

original: “Yo ca seyyohamasmīti, nāhaṃ seyyoti vā pana;
analyzed: ca seyyā uham asmi iti na aham vā pana
translated: “The one who thinks ‘I am better’ or ‘I am equal’ or ‘I am worse’

original: Hīno taṃsadiso vāti, vidhāsu na vikampati.
analyzed: hīnaḥ taṃsa disaḥ vāti vidhāsu na vikampati
translated: is shaken by the fluctuations of the mind.

original: “Paññavantaṃ tathā tādiṃ, sīlesu susamāhitaṃ;
analyzed: paññavantam tathā tādim sīlesu su samāhitam
translated: “The wise man praises the one who is wise, who is well-composed in virtue,

original: Cetosamathamanuyuttaṃ, tañce viññū pasaṃsare.
analyzed: cetaḥ samatham anuyuttam tat ce viññū pasaṃsare
translated: who is devoted to mental unification.

original: “Yassa sabrahmacārīsu, gāravo nūpalabbhati;
analyzed: yassa sabrahmacārīsu gāravaḥ nu upalabbhati
translated: “The one who has no respect for his companions in the holy life

original: Ārakā hoti saddhammā, nabhato puthavī yathā.
analyzed: ārakā hoti saddhammā nabhataḥ puthavī yathā
translated: is far from the true Dhamma, like the earth from the sky.

original: “Yesañca hiri ottappaṃ, sadā sammā upaṭṭhitaṃ;🔽Virūḷhabrahmacariyā te, tesaṃ khīṇā punabbhavā.
analyzed: yesam ca hiri ottappam sadā sammā upaṭṭhitam  virūḍha brahmacariyā te tesam khīṇā punabbhavā
translated: “The one in whom conscience and shame are always well established🔽has developed the holy life; for him there is no renewed existence.

original: “Uddhato capalo bhikkhu, paṃsukūlena pāruto;
analyzed: uddhataḥ capalaḥ bhikkhu paṃsukūlena pārutaḥ
translated: “The monk who is restless and puffed up, covered with rags,

original: Kapīva sīhacammena, na so tenupasobhati.
analyzed: kapī iva sīha cammena na saḥ tena upasobhati
translated: is like a monkey in a lion’s skin; he does not shine with that.

original: “Anuddhato acapalo, nipako saṃvutindriyo;
analyzed: an uddhataḥ a capalaḥ nipakaḥ saṃvuti indriyaḥ
translated: “The one who is not restless and puffed up, the one who is mindful and controlled,

original: Sobhati paṃsukūlena, sīhova girigabbhare.
analyzed: sobhati paṃsukūlena sīhā uva giri gabbhare
translated: shines with his rags, like a lion in his mountain cave.

original: “Ete sambahulā devā, iddhimanto yasassino;
analyzed: ete sambahulāḥ devāḥ iddhimantaḥ yasassinaḥ
translated: “These many gods, powerful and glorious,

original: Dasadevasahassāni, sabbe te brahmakāyikā.
analyzed: dasa deva sahassāni sabbe te brahmakāyikā
translated: Ten thousand gods, all of them of the Brahmā group,

original: “Dhammasenāpatiṃ vīraṃ, mahājhāyiṃ samāhitaṃ;
analyzed: dhamma senāpatim vīram mahā jhāyim samāhitam
translated: “The hero, the general of the Dhamma, the great meditator, the one in equipoise,

original: Sāriputtaṃ namassantā, tiṭṭhanti pañjalīkatā.
analyzed: sāriputtam namassantā tiṭṭhanti pañjalīkatā
translated: Sāriputta, they stand with hands together in homage, paying homage to him.

original: “Namo te purisājañña, namo te purisuttama;
analyzed: namaḥ te purisājañña namaḥ te purisuttama
translated: “Homage to you, O noble person, homage to you, O supreme person;

original: Yassa te nābhijānāma, yampi nissāya jhāyati.
analyzed: yassa te na abhijānāma yam pi nissāya jhāyati
translated: We do not know what you are recollecting, or what you are meditating on.

original: “Accheraṃ vata buddhānaṃ, gambhīro gocaro sako;
analyzed: accheram vata buddhānam gambhīraḥ gocaraḥ sakaḥ
translated: “How amazing the Buddhas are! Their domain is profound indeed,

original: Ye mayaṃ nābhijānāma, vālavedhisamāgatā.
analyzed: ye mayam na abhijānāma vāla vedhi samāgatā
translated: Since we, who have come here like a flock of sheep, do not know.

original: “Taṃ tathā devakāyehi, pūjitaṃ pūjanārahaṃ;
analyzed: tam tathā pūjitam pūjana araham
translated: “That one, who is worshipped by the gods, who is worthy of worship,

original: Sāriputtaṃ tadā disvā, kappinassa sitaṃ ahu.
analyzed: sāriputtam tadā disvā kappinassa sitam ahu
translated: Seeing Sāriputta then, Kappina’s mind became serene.

original: “Yāvatā buddhakhettamhi, ṭhapayitvā mahāmuniṃ;
analyzed: yāvatā buddha khettamhi ṭhapayitvā mahā munim
translated: “As far as the Buddha-field extends, except for the Great Sage,

original: Dhutaguṇe visiṭṭhohaṃ, sadiso me na vijjati.
analyzed: dhuta guṇe visiṭṭhaḥ ūham sadisaḥ me na vijjati
translated: I am preeminent in the ascetic qualities; there is no one equal to me.

original: “Pariciṇṇo mayā satthā, kataṃ buddhassa sāsanaṃ;
analyzed: pariciṇṇaḥ mayā satthā katam buddhassa sāsanam
translated: “The Teacher has been attended to by me, the Buddha’s instruction has been done by me;

original: Ohito garuko bhāro, natthi dāni punabbhavo.
analyzed: ohitaḥ garukaḥ bhāraḥ na atthi dāni punabbhavaḥ
translated: The heavy burden has been put down, there is no more continuation in existence.

original: “Na cīvare na sayane, bhojane nupalimpati;
analyzed: na cīvare na sayane bhojane na upalimpati
translated: “He is not attached to robes, to beds and seats, or to food;

original: Gotamo anappameyyo, mūḷālapupphaṃ vimalaṃva;
analyzed: gotamaḥ anappameyyaḥ mūḷāla puppham vimalam va
translated: Gotama is immeasurable, like a spotless jasmine flower;

original: Ambunā nekkhammaninno, tibhavābhinissaṭo.
analyzed: ambunā nekkhamma ninno ti bhava abhinissaṭaḥ
translated: He is intent on renunciation, with water,🔽And he has passed beyond the three.🔽He has the neck of the Arousings of Mindfulness,

original: “Satipaṭṭhānagīvo so, saddhāhattho mahāmuni;
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna gīvaḥ so saddhā hatthaḥ mahā muni
translated: The hand of faith, the Great Seer,🔽The head of wisdom, the Great Knowledge,

original: Paññāsīso mahāñāṇī, sadā carati nibbuto”ti. –
analyzed: paññāsīsaḥ mahāñāṇī sadā carati nibbutaḥ ti
translated: He goes about always quenched.

original: Imā gāthā abhāsi. Tattha ādito tisso gāthā gaṇesu kulesu ca saṃsaṭṭhe bhikkhū disvā tesaṃ ovādadānavasena vuttā.
analyzed: imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha āditas tissaḥ gāthāḥ gaṇesu kulesu ca saṃsaṭṭhe bhikkhū disvā tesam ovāda dāna vasena vuttā
translated: He spoke these stanzas. Herein, the first three stanzas were spoken after seeing bhikkhus who were associating with families and with groups and after advising them.

original: Tattha na gaṇena purakkhato careti bhikkhugaṇehi purakkhato parivārito hutvā na careyya
analyzed: tattha na gaṇena purakkhataḥ careti bhikkhu gaṇehi purakkhataḥ parivāritaḥ hutvā na careyya
translated: Herein, Na gaṇena purakkhato care means he should not go about being honoured and surrounded by groups of bhikkhus.

original: na vihareyya. Kasmā? Vimano hoti samādhi dullabho gaṇaṃ pariharantassa dukkhuppattiyā🔽byākulamanatāya, uddesena ovādena anusāsaniyā anuggahaṃ karonto yathānusiṭṭhaṃ appaṭipattiyā
analyzed: na vihareyya kasmai vimanaḥ hoti samādhi dullabhaḥ gaṇam pariharantassa dukkha uppattiyā  byākula manatāya uddesena ovādena anusāsaniyā anuggaham karontaḥ yathānusiṭṭham appaṭipattiyā
translated: He should not live thus. Why? Because concentration is difficult to obtain for one who keeps company with groups, because of the arising of suffering through the agitation of the distracted mind,

original: ca vimano vikāribhūtacitto hoti, tato saṃsaggena ekaggataṃ alabhantassa samādhi dullabho
analyzed: ca vimanaḥ vikāri bhūta cittaḥ hoti tatas saṃsaggena ekagga tam a labhantassa samādhi dullabhaḥ
translated: and because of the difficulty of obtaining concentration for one who does not obtain unification of mind through association with such people.

original: hoti. Tathārūpassa hi upacārasamādhimattampi na ijjhati, pageva itaro. Nānājanasaṅgahoti
analyzed: hoti tathārūpassa hi upacāra samādhimattam pi na ijjhati pagā iva itaraḥ nānā jana saṅgaho ti
translated: For such a person even access concentration is not successful, much less the other. Na nānājanasaṅgaho means

original: nānajjhāsayassa nānārucikassa janassa peyyakhajjādinā saṅgaho. Dukhoti kiccho kasiro.
analyzed: nānajjhāsayassa nānārucikassa janassa peyya khajja ādinā saṅgahaḥ kiccho kasiro
translated: and the gathering in of people of various views and desires by means of food, drink, etc. is “painful” in the sense of being troublesome and laborious.

original: Iti disvānāti evaṃ gaṇasaṅgahe bahuvidhaṃ ādīnavaṃ disvā ñāṇacakkhunā oloketvā. Gaṇaṃ
analyzed: iti evam gaṇa saṅgahe bahuvidham ādīnavam disvā ñāṇa cakkhunā oloketvā gaṇam
translated: “Having seen thus”: having seen, having looked with the eye of knowledge, the many dangers in the gathering in of a following in this way.

original: gaṇavāsaṃ na rocaye na roceyya na iccheyya.
analyzed: gaṇa vāsam na rocaye na roceyya naḥ iccheyya
translated: “I do not delight in a following” : I do not delight in, do not approve of, do not wish for a following.

original: Na kulāni upabbaje munīti imasmiṃ sāsane pabbajito khattiyādikulūpako hutvā na upagaccheyya.
analyzed: na kulāni upabbaje muni iti imasmin sāsane pabbajitaḥ khattiya ādi kulūpakaḥ hutvā na upagaccheyya
translated: “The sage should not visit families” : one who has gone forth in this Dispensation should not visit families of nobles, etc.

original: Kiṃkāraṇā? Vimano hoti samādhi dullabho. So ussukko kulūpasaṅkamane ussukkaṃ āpanno
analyzed: kiṃkāraṇā vimanaḥ hoti samādhi dullabhaḥ saḥ ussukkaḥ kula upasaṅkamane ussukkam āpanno
translated: Why? Because “concentration is hard to obtain,” and one who is eager to visit families becomes eager to be busy.

original: kulesu laddhabbesu madhurādirasesu anugiddho gedhaṃ āpanno tattha uppannesu kiccakaraṇīyesu
analyzed: kulesu laddhabbesu madhura ādi rasesu anugiddhaḥ gedham āpannaḥ tattha uppannesu kicca karaṇīyesu
translated: And when he is eager to visit families, he becomes greedy for the sweet tastes, etc., that he may obtain in families. He becomes attached to them. He becomes involved in the duties that arise in connection with them.

original: attanāva yogaṃ āpajjanto. Atthaṃ riñcati yo sukhāvahoti yo attano maggaphalanibbānasukhāvaho
analyzed: attanā ava yogam āpajjantaḥ attham riñcati yaḥ sukha āvahaḥ ti yaḥ attanaḥ magga phala nibbāna sukha āvahaḥ
translated: He neglects the good, which is the bringer of happiness. He neglects the good, which is the bringer of the happiness of the path, fruit, and Nibbāna,

original: taṃ sīlavisuddhiādisaṅkhātaṃ atthaṃ riñcati jahati, nānuyuñjatīti attho.
analyzed: tam sīla visuddhi ādi saṅkhātam attham riñcati jahati na anuyuñjati iti
translated: which is called purification of virtue, etc. The meaning is that he does not pursue it.

original: Tatiyagāthā heṭṭhā vuttā eva.
analyzed: tatiya gāthā heṭṭhā vuttā eva
translated: The third stanza has already been explained .

original: Senāsanamhā oruyhātiādikā catasso gāthā paccayesu attano santosadassanamukhena “bhikkhunā
analyzed: senāsanamhā oruyha ati ādikā catasso gāthā paccayesu attano santosa dassana mukhena bhikkhunā
translated: The four verses beginning with “Having come down from the lodging” show that the bhikkhu should be content with requisites.

original: nāma evaṃ paṭipajjitabba”nti bhikkhūnaṃ ovādadānavasena vuttā. Tattha senāsanamhā
analyzed: nāma evam paṭipajjitabbanti bhikkhūnam ovāda dāna vasena vuttā tattha senāsana mhā
translated: The four verses beginning with “Having come down from the lodging” are spoken in order to advise the bhikkhus, showing that a bhikkhu should conduct himself in this way.

original: oruyhāti pabbatasenāsanattā vuttaṃ. Sakkaccaṃ taṃ upaṭṭhahinti taṃ kuṭṭhipurisaṃ🔽uḷārasampattiṃ pāpetukāmatāya bhikkhāya atthiko hutvā paṇītabhikkhadāyakaṃ kulaṃ
analyzed: oruyha āti pabbata senāsana ttā vuttam sakkaccam tam upaṭṭhahinti tam kuṭṭhi purisam  uḷāra sampattim pāpetu kāma tāya bhikkhāya atthikaḥ hutvā paṇīta bhikkha dāyakam kulam
translated: Herein, having come down from the lodging means that he came down from the mountain lodging.

original: mahicchapuggalo viya ādarena upagantvā aṭṭhāsiṃ.🔽Pakkenāti aṭṭhigatakuṭṭharogatāya upakkena kuthitena. Aṅguli cettha chijjathāti ettha patte tassa aṅguli chijjitvā āhārena saddhiṃ patatīti attho.
analyzed: mahiccha puggalaḥ viya ādarena upagantvā aṭṭhāsim  pakkena ati aṭṭhi gata kuṭṭha roga tāya upakkena kuthitena aṅguli ca ittha chijjatha ati ettha patte tassa aṅguli chijjitvā āhārena saddhim patati iti attho
translated: I attended on him carefully means that he went to the house of a donor of fine almsfood with the desire to bring that leper to a high state of prosperity, as if he were a man of great influence, and stood there.🔽With a bowl means with a bowl that was cracked. My finger was cut means that his finger was cut and fell into the bowl together with the food.

original: Kuṭṭamūlaṃ nissāyāti tassa purisassa pasādajananatthaṃ tādise gharabhittisamīpe nisīditvā
analyzed: kuṭṭa mūlam nissāyāti tassa purisassa pasāda janana attham tādise ghara bhitti samīpe nisīditvā
translated: I sat down at the foot of a wall means that he sat down near a house wall of that kind in order to generate confidence in that man.

original: ālopaṃ taṃ abhuñjisaṃ paribhuñjiṃ. Ayaṃ pana therassa paṭipatti sikkhāpade apaññatteti
analyzed: ālopam tam abhuñjisam paribhuñjim ayam pana therassa paṭipatti sikkhāpade a paññattā iti
translated: I ate it, I used it. But the Elder’s practice should be regarded as being in the absence of a training precept.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Paṭikkūle ca appaṭikkūle iva appaṭikkūlasaññitāya ariyiddhiyā ukkaṃsagatattā
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam paṭikkūle ca appaṭikkūle iva appaṭikkūla saññitāya ariyiddhiyā ukkaṃsa gata ttā
translated: And because of the noble supernormal power that is not repelled by what is repulsive, and that is like the non-repulsion of what is not repulsive,

original: therassa taṃ ajjhoharantassa jigucchā na uppajji, puthujjanassa pana tādisaṃ bhuñjantassa
analyzed: therassa tam ajjhoharantassa jigucchā na uppajji puthujjanassa pana tādisam bhuñjantassa
translated: the Elder did not feel disgust while he was eating it. But if an ordinary man were to eat such food,

original: antāni nikkhameyyuṃ. Tenāha “bhuñjamāne vā bhutte vā, jegucchaṃ me na vijjatī”ti.🔽Uttiṭṭhapiṇḍoti uttiṭṭhitvā paresaṃ gharadvāre ṭhatvā gahetabbapiṇḍo, jaṅghabalaṃ
analyzed: antāni nikkhameyyum tena āha bhuñjamāne vā bhutte vā jeguccham me na vijjati iti  uttiṭṭha piṇḍo ti uttiṭṭhitvā paresam ghara dvāre ṭhatvā gahetabba piṇḍaḥ jaṅgha balam
translated: his bowels would burst. That is why he said, “While I am eating or after I have eaten, I have no feeling of disgust” .🔽The “alms dropped on the way” are alms that can be received by standing at the door of a house after one has set out on a journey. The meaning is, alms that are received by going to a house by one’s own strength of legs.

original: nissāya anugharaṃ gantvā laddhabbamissakabhikkhāti attho. Pūtimuttanti gomuttaparibhāvitaharīṭakādi
analyzed: nissāya anugharam gantvā laddhabba missaka bhikkhā ti attho pūti muttam ti gomutta paribhāvita harīṭaka ādi
translated: “Rotten urine” is harītaki fruit soaked in cow’s urine.

original: ca. Yassete abhisambhutvāti, yo bhikkhu ete uttiṭṭhapiṇḍādayo cattāro paccaye antimantena
analyzed: ca yassa ete abhisambhutvā ati yaḥ bhikkhu ete uttiṭṭha piṇḍa ādayo cattāro paccaye antimantena
translated: “Having mastered these”: having attained mastery over these four requisites, the alms dropped on the way, etc., by means of the extreme limit of life.

original: abhiramitvā paribhuñjati. Sa ve cātuddiso naroti so puggalo ekaṃsena cātuddiso puratthimādicatudisāyogyo,
analyzed: abhiramitvā paribhuñjati sa ve cātuddisaḥ so puggalo ekaṃsena cātuddisaḥ puratthima ādi catu disā yogyo
translated: and he enjoys them without attachment. He is a man who faces all directions: that person is one who faces all directions in the sense of being fit to face all directions, the eastern direction, etc.,

original: katthaci appaṭigho yāya kāyaci disāya viharituṃ sakkotīti attho.
analyzed: katthaci appaṭighaḥ yāya kāyaci disāya viharitum sakkoti iti atthaḥ
translated: without obstruction anywhere, without being obstructed in any direction, in whatever direction he may live.

original: Atha thero attano mahallakakāle manussehi “kathaṃ, bhante, tumhe evarūpāya jarāya
analyzed: atha theraḥ attanaḥ mahallaka kāle manussehi katham bhante tumhe evarūpāya jarāya
translated: Then, when the Elder was old, people asked him, “How is it, venerable sir, that you climb the mountain every day in this kind of old age?”

original: vattamānāya dine dine pabbataṃ abhiruhathā”ti vutte “yattha eke”tiādikā catasso gāthā
analyzed: vattamānāya dine dine pabbatam abhiruhatha ati vutte yattha eka iti ādikā catassaḥ gāthā
translated: When they asked this, he recited these four stanzas beginning, “Where some are harassed” .

original: abhāsi. Tattha yatthāti yasmiṃ pacchimavaye. Eketi ekacce. Vihaññantīti sarīrakilamathena
analyzed: abhāsi tattha yattha ati yasmin pacchima vaye eke iti ekacce vihaññanti iti sarīra kilamathena
translated: Herein, where means in what last stage of life. Some means some people. Are harassed means they undergo mental anguish through bodily weariness.

original: cittena vighātaṃ āpajjanti. Siluccayanti pabbataṃ. Tatthāti tasmiṃ jarājiṇṇakālepi.
analyzed: cittena vighātam āpajjanti siluccayanti pabbatam tattha ati tasmin jarā jiṇṇa kāle pi
translated: Climb the mountain means they climb the mountain of the corpse. There too means even in that time of old age.

original: Sampajāno paṭissatoti iminā cittakhedābhāvaṃ dasseti, iddhibalenupatthaddhoti iminā sarīrakhedābhāvaṃ.
analyzed: sampajānaḥ paṭissatoti iminā citta kheda abhāvam dasseti iddhi balena upatthaddhaḥ ti iminā sarīra kheda abhāvam
translated: Mindful and clearly comprehending: he shows thereby that his mind was not exhausted. Supported by the strength of his psychic potency: he shows thereby that his body was not exhausted.

original: Bhayahetūnaṃ kilesānaṃ samucchinnattā pahīnabhayabheravo.
analyzed: bhaya hetūnam kilesānam pahīna bhaya bheravaḥ
translated: He is without fear and dread because he has cut off the defilements that are the cause of fear.

original: Ḍayhamānesūti rāgaggiādīhi ekādasahi aggīhi sattesu ḍayhamānesu. Saṃkilesapariḷāhābhāvena nibbuto sītibhūto.🔽Puna manussehi “kiṃ, bhante, jiṇṇakālepi araññapabbateyeva viharatha, nanu ime veḷuvanādayo🔽vihārā manoramā”ti vutte araññapabbatā eva mayhaṃ manoramāti dassento “karerimālāvitatā”tiādikā🔽dvādasa gāthā abhāsi. Tattha karerimālāvitatāti varuṇarukkhapantīhi samāgatā. “Kālavaṇṇapupphehi
analyzed: ḍayhamānesu iti rāga aggi ādīhi ekādasahi aggīhi sattesu ḍayhamānesu saṃkilesa pariḷāha abhāvena nibbutaḥ sīti bhūtaḥ  puna manussehi kim bhante jiṇṇa kāle pi arañña pabbateya iva viharatha nanu ime veḷuvana ādayaḥ  vihārāḥ manoramā iti vutte arañña pabbatāḥ eva mayham manoramā ti dassento kareri mālā vitata ati ādikā  dvādasa gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha kareri mālā vitatā ati varuṇa rukkha pantīhi samāgatā kāla vaṇṇa pupphehi
translated: When beings are burning means when beings are burning with the eleven fires of lust, etc. He is quenched, cooled, by the absence of the defilement-fires.🔽Again, when people said to him, “Venerable sir, why do you live in the forest and on mountain slopes even in old age? Are not the delightful monasteries of Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Grove, and the Gabled Hall not delightful?” he spoke these twelve verses beginning with “Adorned with creepers’ wreaths” in order to show that the forest and mountain slopes are delightful to him.

original: otthaṭā”tipi vadanti. Kuñjarābhirudāti paṭighosādiguṇībhūtehi hatthīnaṃ gocaresīnaṃ🔽gajjitehi abhitthanitā.🔽Abhivuṭṭhāti mahāmeghena abhippavuṭṭhā. Rammatalāti teneva rajojallapaṇṇeyyādīnaṃ
analyzed: vadanti paṭighosa ādi guṇībhūtehi hatthīnam  gajjitehi abhitthanitā  mahā meghena abhippavuṭṭhā rammatalā ti tena iva rajojalla paṇṇeyya ādīnam
translated: Herein, adorned with creepers’ wreaths means covered with the creepers of the varuṇa tree. “Adorned with the flowers of the kāla tree” is another reading.🔽With the trumpeting of elephants means with the trumpeting of the elephants that live there, which is a quality that enhances the place.

original: apagamena ramaṇīyatalā. Nagāti desantaraṃ agamanato “nagā”ti selamayatāya “selā”ti
analyzed: apagamena ramaṇīya talā nagāti a gamanataḥ nagāti
translated: With the downpour of the great cloud means with the downpour of the great rain cloud. Delightful ground means delightful because of the absence of dust, dirt, grass, stumps, and so on.🔽With the rocks’ peaks means with the peaks of the rocks that are like walls because of their not going elsewhere.

original: ca laddhanāmā pabbatā. Abbhunnaditā sikhīhīti madhurassarena unnaditā.
analyzed: ca laddha nāmā pabbatā abbhunnaditā sikhīhi iti madhurassarena unnaditā
translated: Abhunnādita sikhīhīti = was resounded with the sweet sounds of peacocks.🔽Alanti = is suitable or fit.

original: Alanti yuttaṃ samatthaṃ vā. Jhāyitukāmassa atthakāmassātiādīsupi iminā nayena yojetabbaṃ. Bhikkhunoti bhinnakilesabhikkhuno, meti sambandho.
analyzed: alam iti yuttam samattham vā jhāyitu kāmassa attha kāmassa ati ādīsu pi iminā nayena yojetabbam bhikkhuno ti bhinna kilesa bhikkhunaḥ mā iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Bhikkhuno = for a bhikkhu whose defilements are destroyed.🔽Umāpupphena samānā = like the umā flower in colour.

original: Umāpupphena samānāti mecakanibhatāya umākusumasadisā. Gaganāvabbha chāditāti tato eva saradassa gaganaabbhā viya kāḷameghasañchāditā, nīlavaṇṇāti attho.
analyzed: umā pupphena samānā ati mecaka nibha tāya umā kusuma sadisā chāditā ati tatas eva saradassa gagana abbhā viya kāḷa megha sañchāditā nīla vaṇṇā ti attho
translated: Gaganāvabbha chāditā = covered by a black cloud like the sky in the rainy season.🔽Anākiṇṇā = uncrowded, unconfined.

original: Anākiṇṇāti asaṃkiṇṇā asambādhā. Pañcaṅgikenāti ātatādīhi pañcahi aṅgehi yuttena tūriyena🔽parivāriyamānassa tādisīpi na hoti, yathā yādisī ekaggacittassa samāhitacittassa
analyzed: an ākiṇṇā ati a saṃkiṇṇā a sambādhā pañcaṅgikena ati ātata ādīhi pañcahi aṅgehi yuttena tūriyena  parivāriyamānassa tādisī api na hoti yathā yādisī ekagga cittassa samāhita cittassa
translated: Pañcaṅgikena = by a musical instrument consisting of five parts, such as the āṭānāṭīya.🔽Even such a sound does not compare with the sound of the five aggregates of clinging as impermanent, etc.,🔽to one who is concentrated, whose mind is unified.

original: sammadeva rūpārūpadhammaṃ aniccādivasena vipassantassa rati hoti. Tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: sammat eva rūpa arūpa dhammaṃ anicca ādi vasena vipassantassa rati hoti tena āha bhagavā
translated: Therefore the Blessed One said:

original: “Yato yato sammasati, khandhānaṃ udayabbayaṃ;
analyzed: yatas yatas sammasati khandhānam udaya bbayam
translated: “From whatever point one comprehends🔽The rise and fall of the five aggregates,

original: Labhatī pītipāmojjaṃ, amataṃ taṃ vijānata”nti.
analyzed: labhatī pīti pāmojjam amatam tam
translated: He gains the rapture and delight That are the deathlessness of one who knows.

original: Kammaṃ bahukantiādinā dve gāthā kammārāmānaṃ paccayagiddhānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ ovādadānavasena
analyzed: kammam bahukam ti ādinā dve gāthā kamma ārāmānam paccaya giddhānam bhikkhūnam ovāda dāna vasena
translated: The two verses beginning, “One who is bent on work” were spoken in order to advise monks who are bent on work and greedy for requisites.

original: vuttā. Tattha kammaṃ bahukaṃ na kārayeti kammārāmo hutvā bahuṃ nāma kammaṃ na kāraye
analyzed: vuttā tattha kammam bahukam na kārayeti kamma ārāmaḥ hutvā bahum nāma kammam na kāraye
translated: Herein, one who is bent on work should not have much work done, should not undertake much work.

original: na adhiṭṭhahe, khaṇḍaphullapaṭisaṅkharaṇaṃ pana satthārā anuññātameva. Parivajjeyya
analyzed: na adhiṭṭhahe khaṇḍa phulla paṭisaṅkharaṇam pana satthārā anuññātam eva parivajjeyya
translated: But the repairing of what is dilapidated and in need of repair is allowed by the Teacher.🔽He should avoid people: he should avoid people who are bad friends.

original: jananti akalyāṇamittabhūtaṃ janaṃ vajjeyya. Na uyyameti paccayuppādanagaṇabandhādivasena vāyāmaṃ na kareyya.
analyzed: jananti akalyāṇa mitta bhūtam janam vajjeyya na uyyama iti paccaya uppādana gaṇa bandha ādi vasena vā āyāmam na kareyya
translated: He should not strive: he should not make effort by undertaking the duties of a monastery attendant, the duties of a storekeeper, etc.

original: Anattaneyyametanti etaṃ navakammādhiṭṭhānādikaṃ attano atthāvahaṃ na hotīti attho.🔽Tattha kāraṇamāha “kicchati kāyo kilamatī”ti. Navakammādipasutassa hi tahaṃ tahaṃ
analyzed: anattaneyyam etat ti etam nava kamma adhiṭṭhāna ādikam attanaḥ attha āvaham na hoti iti attho  tattha kāraṇam āha kicchati kāyaḥ kilamati iti nava kamma ādi pasutassa hi taham taham
translated: This is not for one’s own good: this undertaking of new work, etc., is not for one’s own welfare.

original: vicarato kāyasukhādialābhena kicchappatto hoti kilamati khedaṃ āpajjati, tena ca
analyzed: vicarataḥ kāya sukha ādi alābhena kiccha ppattaḥ hoti kilamati khedam āpajjati tena ca
translated: Here is a reason: “The body tires and weariness arises.” For when one who is bent on new work, etc., moves about here and there, he reaches the point of tiredness through lack of bodily comfort. He becomes weary, he undergoes fatigue. And because of that

original: kāyakilamathena dukkhito. Vatthuvisadaattaneyyakiriyādīnaṃ abhāvena so puggalo samathaṃ
analyzed: kāya kilamathena dukkhitaḥ vatthu visada atta neyya kiriyā ādīnam abhāvena so puggalo samatham
translated: and he is afflicted by bodily weariness. Because of the absence of the clarity of the object, of the act of attention, etc., that person is unable to develop concentration.

original: na vindati cittasamādhānaṃ na labhatīti.🔽Oṭṭhappahatamattenātiādinā dve gāthā sutaparamassa paṇḍitamānino garahavasena, tato
analyzed: na vindati citta samādhānam na labhati iti  oṭṭha ppahata mattena ati ādinā dve gāthā suta paramassa paṇḍita māninaḥ garaha vasena tatas
translated: and he is afflicted by bodily weariness. Because of the absence of the conditions of a clear medium, of being sent out, and so on, that person does not find serenity, does not obtain mental unification.

original: parā dve paṇḍitassa pasaṃsāvasena vuttā. Tattha oṭṭhappahatamattenāti sajjhāyasīsena
analyzed: parā dve paṇḍitassa pasaṃsā vasena vuttā tattha oṭṭha ppahata mattena ati sajjhāya sīsena
translated: The two verses beginning with the words “By mere recitation” are spoken in order to censure the fool who is conceited with the conceit of learning. The two verses that follow are spoken in order to praise the wise man.

original: oṭṭhaparivattanamattena, buddhavacanaṃ sajjhāyakaraṇamattenāti attho. Attānampi na🔽passatīti anatthaññutāya attano paccakkhabhūtampi atthaṃ na jānāti, yāthāvato attano🔽pamāṇaṃ na paricchindatīti attho. Patthaddhagīvo caratīti “ahaṃ bahussuto, satimā,
analyzed: oṭṭha parivattana mattena buddha vacanam sajjhāya karaṇa mattena ati atthaḥ attānam pi na  passati iti anatthaññutāya attano paccakkha bhūtam pi attham na jānāti yāthāvataḥ attano  pamāṇam na paricchindati iti carati iti aham bahu sutaḥ satimā
translated: Herein, by mere recitation means by mere turning over of the leaves of the scriptures. The meaning is: by mere recitation of the Buddha’s word.🔽He does not see himself means: because of his ignorance of what is beneficial, he does not know the benefit that is right before his eyes. The meaning is: he does not determine the measure of himself as it truly is.

original: paññavā, na mayā sadiso añño atthī”ti mānatthaddho hutvā garuṭṭhāniyānampi apacitiṃ
analyzed: paññavā na mayā sadisaḥ aññaḥ atthi iti mānatthaddhaḥ hutvā garuṭṭhā niyānam pi apacitim
translated: He walks about with his neck outstretched means: puffed up with conceit, thinking “I am learned, mindful, wise; there is no one like me,” he shows disrespect even to those worthy of respect.

original: adassento ayosalākaṃ gilitvā ṭhito viya thaddhagīvo carati. Ahaṃ seyyoti maññatīti
analyzed: a dassentaḥ ayosalākam gilitvā ṭhitaḥ viya thaddhagīvaḥ carati aham seyyo ti maññati iti
translated: Not seeing, he goes about stiff-necked, as if he had swallowed a poker, thinking, “I am the best.”

original: ahameva seyyo uttamoti maññati.🔽Aseyyo seyyasamānaṃ, bālo maññati attānanti ayaṃ aseyyo hīno samāno aññena seyyena
analyzed: aham eva seyyo uttamaḥ ti maññati  aseyyaḥ seyya samānam bālaḥ maññati attā ananti ayam aseyyaḥ hīnaḥ samānaḥ aññena seyyena
translated: He thinks, “I am the best, the most excellent.”🔽The fool thinks himself equal to the equal,

original: uttamena samānaṃ sadisaṃ katvā attānaṃ bālo mandabuddhi bālabhāveneva maññatīti.🔽Na taṃ viññū pasaṃsantīti taṃ tādisaṃ bālaṃ paggahitacittatāya patthaddhamānasaṃ
analyzed: uttamena samānam sadisam katvā attānam bālaḥ manda buddhi bāla bhāvena iva maññati iti  na tam viññū pasaṃsanti iti tam tādisam bālam paggahita citta tāya patthaddha mānasam
translated: The fool, being foolish, thinks himself equal to one who is equal, or even better, to one who is better.🔽The wise do not praise him

original: thambhitattaṃ naraṃ viññū paṇḍitā na pasaṃsanti, aññadatthu garahantiyeva.🔽Seyyohamasmīti yo pana paṇḍito puggalo “seyyohamasmī”ti vā hīnasadisamānavasena “nāhaṃ
analyzed: thambhi tattam naram viññū paṇḍitāḥ na pasaṃsanti aññadatthu garahantiyā iva  seyya uham asmi iti yaḥ pana paṇḍito puggalo seyya uham asmi iti vā hīna sadisa māna vasena na aham
translated: The wise do not praise that fool who is puffed up with conceit and thinks himself equal to one who is equal, or even better, to one who is better. On the contrary, they censure him.🔽But the wise man does not waver

original: seyyo”ti vā kañcipi mānaṃ ajappento vidhāsu navasu mānakoṭṭhāsesu kassacipi vasena na vikampati.
analyzed: seyyo ti vā kañcipi mānam a jappentaḥ vidhāsu navasu māna koṭṭhāsesu kassacipi vasena na vikampati
translated: But the wise man, who is not puffed up with conceit, does not waver in any way, thinking, “I am the best,” or thinking, “I am not the best,” or thinking, “I am equal,” or thinking, “I am unequal,” in the nine ways of conceiving “I.”

original: Paññavantanti aggaphalapaññāvasena paññavantaṃ iṭṭhādīsu tādibhāvappattiyā tādiṃ,
analyzed: paññavantam ti agga phala paññā vasena paññavantam iṭṭha ādīsu tādi bhāva ppattiyā tādiṃ
translated: “Endowed with wisdom” : endowed with the wisdom of the highest fruit, “equal” in the sense of attaining the state of equality in regard to the desirable, etc.,

original: asekkhaphalasīlesu suṭṭhu patiṭṭhitattā sīlesu susamāhitaṃ, arahattaphalasamāpattisamāpajjanena
analyzed: asekkha phala sīlesu suṭṭhu patiṭṭhita ttā sīlesu su samāhitam arahatta phala samāpatti samāpajjanena
translated: “well-composed in virtue” : well-established in the virtue of the fruit of arahantship,

original: cetosamathamanuyuttanti tādisaṃ sabbaso pahīnamānaṃ khīṇāsavaṃ viññū buddhādayo paṇḍitā
analyzed: cetaḥ samatham anuyuttanti tādisam sabbasas pahīna mānam khīṇa āsavam viññū buddha ādayaḥ paṇḍitā
translated: “devoted to mental calm” : such a one, whose conceit has completely vanished, whose cankers are destroyed, is praised, extolled, and lauded by the wise, the Buddhas and so forth,

original: pasaṃsare vaṇṇenti thomentīti attho.🔽Puna aññataraṃ dubbacaṃ bhikkhuṃ disvā dovacassatāya ādīnavaṃ, sovacassatāya ānisaṃsañca pakāsento “yassa sabrahmacārīsū”tiādikā dve gāthā abhāsi. Tā vuttatthā eva.🔽Puna uddhataṃ unnaḷaṃ ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ disvā uddhatādibhāve dosaṃ, anuddhatādibhāve
analyzed: pasaṃsare vaṇṇenti thomenti iti attho  puna aññataram dubbacam bhikkhum disvā dovacassatāya ādīnavam sovacassatāya ānisaṃsañca pakāsento yassa sabrahmacārī sūti ādikā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi tāḥ vutta tthāḥ eva  punar uddhatam unnaḷam ekam bhikkhum disvā uddhata ādi bhāve dosam anuddhata ādi bhāve
translated: who are themselves endowed with the same qualities.🔽Having seen another monk who was difficult to admonish, he spoke two verses beginning with “He who is hard to admonish,” showing the danger in being difficult to admonish and the benefit in being easy to admonish. The meaning is self-evident.

original: ca guṇaṃ vibhāvento “uddhato capalo bhikkhū”tiādikā dve gāthā abhāsi. Tattha kapīva
analyzed: ca guṇam vibhāventaḥ uddhataḥ capalaḥ bhikkhu uti ādikā dve gāthāḥ abhāsi tattha kapī iva
translated: Having seen another monk who was agitated and puffed up, he spoke two verses beginning with “The monk who is agitated and fickle,” showing the fault in being agitated, etc., and the virtue in being free from agitation, etc. Herein, “like a monkey in the forest” means like a monkey in the forest.

original: sīhacammenāti sīhacammena pāruto makkaṭo viya. So uddhatādidosasaṃyutto bhikkhu tena
analyzed: sīha cammena ati sīha cammena pārutaḥ makkaṭaḥ viya saḥ uddhata ādi dosa saṃyuttaḥ tena
translated: “A lion’s hide” means covered with a lion’s hide, like a monkey. That monk is full of conceit and arrogance.

original: paṃsukūlena ariyaddhajena na upasobhati ariyaguṇānaṃ abhāvato.
analyzed: paṃsu kūlena na upasobhati ariya guṇānam abhāvataḥ
translated: “A lion’s hide” : a monkey dressed in a lion’s hide. A monk who is restless, puffed up, arrogant, and self-important does not shine with the noble banner of the refuse-rag robe because he lacks the noble qualities.

original: Yo pana upasobhati, taṃ dassetuṃ “anuddhato”tiādi vuttaṃ;
analyzed: yaḥ pana upasobhati tam dassetum anuddhata itiādi vuttam
translated: But the one who does shine is shown by the words “not restless” .

original: Ete sambahulātiādikā pañca gāthā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ namassante brahmakāyike deve
analyzed: ete sambahulā ati ādikā pañca gāthāḥ āyasmantam sāriputtam namassante brahmakāyike deve
translated: The five verses beginning with “Many devas” are spoken by the Brahma-world devas in homage to the venerable Sariputta.

original: disvā āyasmato kappinassa sitapātukammanimittaṃ vuttā. Tattha eteti tesaṃ paccakkhatāya🔽vuttaṃ. Sambahulāti bahubhāvato, taṃ pana bahubhāvaṃ “dasadevasahassānī”ti paricchinditvā
analyzed: disvā āyasmataḥ kappinassa sita pātukamma nimittam vuttā tattha ete iti tesam paccakkha tāya  vuttam sambahulā ati bahu bhāvato tam pana bahu bhāvam dasa deva sahassāni iti paricchinditvā
translated: They are spoken after seeing the venerable Kappina’s sign of the white-clothed one’s good destination. Herein, “many” is said by way of their direct knowledge.

original: āha. Devāti upapattidevā. Taṃ tesaṃ devabhāvaṃ aññehi visesetvā dassento “sabbe te🔽brahmakāyikā”ti āha. Yasmā te attano upapattiddhiyā mahatiyā deviddhiyā samannāgatā
analyzed: āha devā ti upapatti devā tam tesam deva bhāvam aññehi visesetvā dassento sabbe te  brahmakāyikā iti āha yasmai te upapatti ddhiyā mahatiyā devi ddhiyā samannāgatā
translated: “Devas” : devas by rebirth. “All of them” is said in order to distinguish them from other devas.🔽“Brahma-world” : the Brahma-world of the first jhana.

original: parivārasampannā ca, tasmā āha “iddhimanto yasassino”ti.
analyzed: parivāra sampannā ca tasmai āha iddhimantaḥ yasassinaḥ iti
translated: “Possessing great psychic power and glory” : they possess great psychic power by their own rebirth, and they possess great glory by their retinue.

original: “Ko nu senāpati bhoto”ti pucchāya vissajjanavasena “mayā pavattitaṃ dhammacakkaṃ
analyzed: kaḥ nu senāpati bhototi pucchāya vissajjana vasena mayā pavattitam dhammacakkam
translated: “Who is the general of your army?” In reply to this question, the Blessed One said: “Sariputta follows the wheel

original: anuttaraṃ sāriputto anuvattetī”ti vadantena bhagavatā āyasmato sāriputtattherassa
analyzed: anuttaram sāriputtaḥ anuvatteti iti vadantena bhagavatā āyasmataḥ sāriputta therassa
translated: of Dhamma set rolling by me.” By this statement the Blessed One approved the Elder Sariputta as the general of the Dhamma.

original: dhammasenāpatibhāvo anuññātoti āha – “dhammasenāpatiṃ vīraṃ mahājhāyiṃ samāhitaṃ
analyzed: dhamma senāpati bhāvaḥ anuññātaḥ ti āha dhamma senāpatim vīram mahājhāyim samāhitam
translated: Therefore the commentator says: “The general of the Dhamma, the hero, the great meditator, the concentrated one,

original: sāriputta”nti. Tattha vīranti kilesamārādīnaṃ nimmathanena vīriyavantaṃ mahāvikkantaṃ.🔽Mahājhāyinti dibbavihārādīnaṃ ukkaṃsagamanena mahantaṃ jhāyiṃ. Tato eva sabbaso vikkhepaviddhaṃsanavasena
analyzed: sāriputtam ti tattha vīram ti kilesa māra ādīnam nimmathanena vīriyavantam mahā vikkantam  mahā jhāyim ti dibba vihāra ādīnam ukkaṃsa gamanena mahantam jhāyim tatas eva sabbasas vikkhepa viddhaṃsana vasena
translated: Sariputta.” Herein, “hero” means one who is endowed with energy, a great conqueror, by conquering defilements, etc.🔽“Great meditator” means one who has gone to the summit of divine abiding, etc. By reason of that,

original: samāhitaṃ. Namassantāti sirasi añjaliṃ paggayha namassamānā tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: samāhitam namassantā iti sirasi añjalim paggayha namassamānā tiṭṭhanti
translated: “concentrated,” by reason of the complete destruction of all distraction. “They stand worshipping” means they stand with their heads bowed down, with their hands raised in reverential salutation.

original: Yampi nissāyāti yaṃ nu kho ārammaṇaṃ nissāya ārabbha jhāyatīti nābhijānāmāti puthujjanabhāvena brahmāno evaṃ āhaṃsu.
analyzed: yam pi nissāya ati yam nu kho ārammaṇam nissāya ārabbha jhāyati iti na abhijānāma ati puthujjana bhāvena brahmānaḥ evam āhaṃsu
translated: “We do not know the object” means: “We do not know the object, the basis, in dependence upon which he meditates.” The Brahmas said this because of their status as worldlings.

original: Accheraṃ vatāti acchariyaṃ vata. Buddhānanti catusaccabuddhānaṃ. Gambhīro gocaro
analyzed: vata ati vata buddhānam ti catur sacca buddhānam gambhīraḥ gocaraḥ
translated: Accheraṃ vata: how wonderful! Buddhānanti: of the Buddhas who have discovered the Four Noble Truths. Gambhīro gocaro: His sphere is profound,

original: sakoti paramagambhīro atiduddaso duranubodho puthujjanehi asādhāraṇo avisayo. Idāni
analyzed: parama gambhīraḥ ati duddasaḥ duranubodhaḥ puthujjanehi asādhāraṇaḥ avisayaḥ idāni
translated: very profound, difficult to see, difficult to understand, not within the range of reasoning, incomprehensible to the worldlings. Now,

original: tassa gambhīrabhāve kāraṇaṃ dassetuṃ “ye maya”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha vālavedhisamāgatāti
analyzed: tassa gambhīra bhāve kāraṇam dassetum ye maya nti ādi vuttam tattha vāla vedhi samāgatā ti
translated: in order to show the reason for his profundity, it is said: “Ye maya” and so forth. There, vālavedhisamāgatā:

original: ye mayaṃ vālavedhidhanuggahasadisā atisukhumampi visayaṃ paṭivijjhituṃ samatthā āgatā
analyzed: ye mayam vālavedhi dhanuggaha sadisāḥ ati su khumam pi visayam paṭivijjhitum samatthāḥ āgatā
translated: we have come to be able to penetrate even the most subtle object, like a hair-splitting arrow.

original: upaparikkhantā nābhijānāma, gambhīro vata buddhānaṃ visayoti attho. Taṃ tathā devakāyehīti
analyzed: upaparikkhantāḥ na abhijānāma gambhīraḥ vata buddhānam visayaḥ ti tam tathā deva kāyehi iti
translated: We do not know, the sphere of the Buddhas is indeed profound. The meaning is this. Taṃ tathā devakāyehīti:

original: taṃ tathārūpaṃ sāriputtaṃ sadevakassa lokassa pūjanārahaṃ tehi brahmakāyikehi tadā
analyzed: tam tathārūpam sāriputtam sa devakassa lokassa pūjana araham tehi brahmakāyikehi tadā
translated: having seen that such a Sāriputta was being worshipped by the Brahmakāyika gods in that way,

original: tathā pūjitaṃ disvā āyasmato mahākappinassa sitaṃ ahosi. Imesaṃ lokasammatānaṃ brahmūnampi
analyzed: tathā pūjitam disvā āyasmataḥ mahākappinassa sitam ahosi imesam loka sammatānam brahmūnam pi
translated: the venerable Mahā Kappaṇa was delighted. Even for these Brahmas, who are respected by the world,

original: avisayo, yattha sāvakānaṃ visayoti.
analyzed: a visayaḥ sāvakānam
translated: it is beyond their range, where the sphere of the disciples is.

original: Yāvatā buddhakhettamhīti gāthā therena attānaṃ ārabbha sīhanādaṃ nadantena bhāsitā.
analyzed: yāvatā buddha khettamhi iti gāthā therena attānam ārabbha sīha nādam nadantena bhāsitā
translated: The verse “As far as the Buddha-field extends” was uttered by the Elder when he was roaring his lion’s roar about himself.

original: Tattha buddhakhettamhīti āṇākhettaṃ sandhāya vadati. Ṭhapayitvā mahāmuninti sammāsambuddhaṃ
analyzed: tattha buddha khettamhi iti āṇā khettam sandhāya vadati ṭhapayitvā mahāmunin ti sammāsambuddham
translated: Herein, as far as the Buddha-field extends is said with reference to the field of his authority. Excepting the Great Sage: setting aside the Perfectly Enlightened One.

original: ṭhapetvā. Buddhā hi bhagavanto dhutaguṇehipi sabbasattehi paramukkaṃsagatā eva, kevalaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapetvā buddhāḥ hi bhagavantaḥ dhuta guṇehi pi sabba sattehi param ukkaṃsa gatāḥ eva kevalam
translated: For the Enlightened Ones, the Blessed Ones, are the foremost of all beings in the special qualities of the ascetic practices,

original: pana mahākaruṇāsañcoditamānasā sattānaṃ tādisaṃ mahantaṃ upakāraṃ oloketvā gāmantasenāsanavāsādiṃ
analyzed: pana mahā karuṇā sañcodita mānasā sattānam tādisam mahantam upakāram oloketvā gāmanta senāsana vāsa ādim
translated: but they live in the village- neighbourhood, etc., only after they have considered the great service to living beings that will accrue from their doing so, since their minds are urged on by their great compassion.

original: anuvattantīti taṃ taṃ dhutadhammavirodhī hoti. Dhutaguṇeti kilesānaṃ dhutena guṇena
analyzed: anuvattanti iti tam tam dhuta dhamma virodhī hoti dhuta guṇa iti kilesānam dhutena guṇena
translated: So that is incompatible with this or that ascetic practice. Ascetic practices is a bahuvrihi compound, meaning that the special qualities of the forest-dweller, etc., are looked up to by means of the ascetic practices that are the shaking off of defilements.🔽Or it is a locative determinative compound, meaning that the special qualities are looked up to in the ascetic practices that are the shaking off of defilements.

original: āraññakādibhāvena apekkhitaguṇe. Karaṇatthe vā etaṃ bhummavacanaṃ. Sadiso me na vijjati,
analyzed: āraññaka ādi bhāvena apekkhita guṇe karaṇa atthe vā etam bhumma vacanam sadisaḥ me na vijjati
translated: The intention is that there is none equal to me, let alone one superior.

original: kuto pana uttarīti adhippāyo. Tathā hesa thero tattha aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapito.
analyzed: kutas pana uttarī iti adhippāyo tathā ha isa thero tattha aggaṭṭhāne ṭhapito
translated: That is why the Elder was placed in the foremost position in this instance.

original: Na cīvareti gāthāya “ṭhapayitvā mahāmuni”nti vuttamevatthaṃ pākaṭataraṃ karoti, cīvarādīsu
analyzed: na cīvara iti gāthāya ṭhapayitvā mahāmunim ti vuttam evattham pākaṭataram karoti cīvara ādīsu
translated: In the verse “In robe” he makes clear the meaning stated in the words “excepting the Great Sage.”

original: taṇhāya anupalepo dhutaṅgaphalaṃ. Tattha na cīvare sampatte taṇhālepenāti yojanā.
analyzed: taṇhāya anupalepaḥ dhutaṅga phalam tattha na cīvare sampatte taṇhā lepena ati yojanā
translated: The fruit of the ascetic practice is the non-smearing of craving. Herein, the construction is this: “When the robe is obtained, there is no smearing of craving.”

original: Sayaneti senāsane. Gotamoti bhagavantaṃ gottena kitteti. Anappameyyoti pamāṇakarakilesābhāvato
analyzed: sayaneti senāsane gotamaḥ uti bhagavantam gottena kittā iti anappameyyaḥ ti pamāṇa kara kilesa abhāvato
translated: “Bed” means bed and chair. “Gotama” : he praises the Blessed One by his clan. “Incomparable” : he is incomparable because of the absence of defilements that can be measured,

original: aparimāṇaguṇatāya ca anappameyyo. Muḷālapupphaṃ vimalaṃva ambunāti yathā nimmalaṃ
analyzed: aparimāṇa guṇa tāya ca anappameyyaḥ muḷāla puppham ambunā ati yathā nimmalam
translated: and because of his immeasurable special qualities. “Like a water-lily unsmeared by the water” : just as a stainless,

original: virajaṃ naḷinaṃ udakena na limpati, evaṃ gotamo bhagavā taṇhālepādinā na limpatīti
analyzed: virajam naḷinam udakena na limpati evam gotamaḥ bhagavā taṇhā lepa ādinā na limpati iti
translated: undefiled lotus is not smeared by water, so the Blessed One is not smeared by the smearing of craving, etc.

original: attho. Nekkhammaninno abhinikkhammaninno tato eva tibhavābhinissaṭo bhavattayato
analyzed: atthaḥ nekkhamma ninnaḥ abhinikkhamma ninnaḥ tatas eva ti bhava abhinissaṭaḥ bhava tayataḥ
translated: This is the meaning. “Intent on renunciation” : intent on going forth, and therefore detached from the three kinds of becoming,

original: vinissaṭo visaṃyutto.
analyzed: vinissaṭaḥ visaṃyuttaḥ
translated: detached and unattached.

original: Yesaṃ satipaṭṭhānagīvādīnaṃ bhāvanāpāripūriyā yattha katthaci anupalitto nekkhammaninnova
analyzed: yesam sati paṭṭhāna gīvā ādīnam bhāvanā pāripūriyā yattha katthaci an upalittaḥ nekkhamma ninnaḥ uva
translated: Wherever he was, he was intent on renunciation, unsmeared by the defilements because of the fulfilment of the development of the factors of the path, such as the establishment of mindfulness, etc.

original: ahosi, te aṅgabhūte dassento “satipaṭṭhānagīvo”ti osānagāthamāha. Tattha guṇarāsito
analyzed: ahosi te aṅga bhūte dassento sati paṭṭhāna gīvā ti osāna gātham āha tattha guṇa rāsito
translated: Showing those factors, he uttered the last verse, “The establishment of mindfulness his neck.” Herein, “the mass of special qualities” means the mass of special qualities such as the powers, the confidences, the special qualities of a Buddha, etc.

original: uttamaṅgabhūtāya paññāya adhiṭṭhānabhāvato satipaṭṭhānaṃ gīvā etassāti satipaṭṭhānagīvo,
analyzed: uttamaṅga bhūtāya paññāya adhiṭṭhāna bhāvato sati paṭṭhānam gīvā etassa ati sati paṭṭhāna gīvaḥ
translated: The supreme head is understanding. The neck is the foundation of that, since it is the foundation for the supreme head of understanding.🔽The hand is faith, since faith is the hand for taking up the blameless states.

original: anavajjadhammānaṃ ādāne saddhā hattho etassāti saddhāhattho. Guṇasarīrassa uttamaṅgabhāvato🔽paññā sīsaṃ etassāti paññāsīso. Mahāsamudāgamanatāya mahāvisayatāya mahānubhāvatāya
analyzed: anavajja dhammānam ādāne saddhā hatthaḥ etassa ati saddhā hatthaḥ guṇa sarīrassa uttamaṅga bhāvato  paññā sīsam etassa ati paññāsīsaḥ mahā samudāgamana tāya mahā visaya tāya mahā anubhāva tāya
translated: The head is understanding, since it is the supreme head of the body of special qualities.🔽The great knowledge is the knowledge called omniscience, which he has, since he has come to the great ocean, since his domain is great, since his power is great, and since his strength is great.

original: mahābalatāya ca mahantaṃ sabbaññutasaṅkhātaṃ ñāṇaṃ etassa atthīti mahāñāṇī. Sadā
analyzed: mahā bala tāya ca mahantam sabbaññuta saṅkhātam ñāṇam etassa atthi iti mahā ñāṇī sadā
translated: He goes about always,

original: sabbakālaṃ nibbuto sītibhūto carati. “Susamāhito…pe… nāgo”ti suttapadañcettha nidassetabbaṃ.
analyzed: sabbakālam nibbutaḥ sīti bhūtaḥ carati su samāhita upe nāgaḥ ti sutta padam ca ittha nidassetabbam
translated: at all times, extinguished, cooled. The passage beginning, “Well concentrated … a noble one” should be cited here.

original: Yaṃ panettha atthato avibhattaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayameva.
analyzed: yam pana ittha atthataḥ avibhattam tam heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva
translated: But what has not been analyzed here should be understood as already explained above.

original: Mahākassapattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mahā kassapa thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Maha Kassapa is finished.

original: Cattālīsanipātavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: cattālīsa nipāta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Catukkanipata is finished.

original: 19. Paññāsanipāto
analyzed: paññāsa nipātaḥ
translated: The Fifty Collection

original: 1. Tālapuṭattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: tālapuṭa thera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Elder Tālapuṭa’s Verses

original: Paññāsanipāte kadā nuhantiādikā āyasmato tālapuṭattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi
analyzed: paññāsa nipāte kadā nu hanti ādikā āyasmataḥ tālapuṭa therassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi
translated: In the Paññāsa-nipāta are the verses of the Elder Tālapuṭa, beginning with the words, “When will I attain?” What was the origin of these verses?

original: purimabuddhesu katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ kusalaṃ upacinitvā🔽imasmiṃ buddhuppāde rājagahe aññatarasmiṃ naṭakule nibbattitvā viññutaṃ patto kulānurūpesu
analyzed: purima buddhesu kata adhikāraḥ tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭu upanissayam kusalam upacinitvā  imasmin buddhuppāde rājagahe aññatarasmim naṭa kule nibbattitvā viññutam pattaḥ kula anurūpesu
translated: This Elder, too, in the dispensation of former Buddhas, had fulfilled the perfections and had made his lives fruitful.🔽In this dispensation, he was reborn in Rājagaha in a family of dancers. When he had attained maturity, he became proficient in all the arts of dancing and singing.

original: naccaṭṭhānesu nipphattiṃ gantvā sakalajambudīpe pākaṭo naṭagāmaṇi ahosi. So pañcasatamātugāmaparivāro🔽mahatā naṭavibhavena gāmanigamarājadhānīsu samajjaṃ dassetvā, mahantaṃ pūjāsakkāraṃ
analyzed: nacca ṭṭhānesu nipphattim gantvā sakala jambudīpe pākaṭaḥ naṭa gāmaṇi ahosi saḥ pañca sata mātu gāma parivāro  mahatā naṭa vibhavena gāma nigama rājadhānīsu sa majjam dassetvā mahantam pūjā sakkāram
translated: He became the chief of all the dancers in the whole of Jambudīpa. He had a retinue of five hundred women.🔽With great pomp and circumstance, he went about the villages, towns, and cities, giving exhibitions of dancing and singing.🔽He received great honor and respect.

original: labhitvā, vicaranto rājagahaṃ āgantvā, nagaravāsīnaṃ samajjaṃ dassetvā, laddhasammānasakkāro
analyzed: labhitvā vicarantaḥ rājagaham āgantvā nagara vāsīnam sa majjam dassetvā laddha sammāna sakkāraḥ
translated: One day he came to Rājagaha and gave an exhibition of dancing and singing for the people of the city. He received great honor and respect.

original: ñāṇassa paripākaṃ gatattā satthu santikaṃ gantvā, vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisinno bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇassa paripākam gatattā satthu santikam gantvā vanditvā ekamantam nisinnaḥ bhagavantam
translated: As his wisdom matured, he went to the Teacher, paid obeisance to him, sat down respectfully on one side,

original: etadavoca – “sutametaṃ, bhante, pubbakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ naṭānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ🔽‘yo so naṭo raṅgamajjhe samajjamajjhe saccālikena janaṃ hāseti rameti, so kāyassa
analyzed: etat avoca sutam etam bhante pubbakānam ācariya pācariyānam naṭānam bhāsamānānam  yaḥ saḥ naṭaḥ raṅga majjhe sa majja majjhe sacca alikena janam hāseti rameti so kāyassa
translated: He said: “Venerable sir, I have heard it said by old teachers of the actors that

analyzed: bhedā param maraṇā pahāsānam devānam sahabyatam upapajjati iti idha bhagavā kim āha ati

original: Atha naṃ bhagavā tikkhattuṃ paṭikkhipi “mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī”ti. Catutthavāraṃ puṭṭho
analyzed: atha nam bhagavā tikkhattum paṭikkhipi mā mama etam pucchi iti catuttha vāram puṭṭhaḥ
translated: A second time…A third time he asked the same question, and a third time the Blessed One replied: “Do not ask me that, Gamaani.”🔽Then he asked: “Venerable sir, what has the Blessed One to say about this?”

original: āha – “gāmaṇi, ime sattā pakatiyāpi rāgabandhanabaddhā dosabandhanabaddhā mohabandhanabaddhā🔽tesaṃ bhiyyopi rajanīye dosanīye mohanīye dhamme upasaṃharanto pamādetvā kāyassa🔽bhedā paraṃ maraṇā niraye upapajjati. Sace panassa evaṃdiṭṭhi hoti ‘yo so naṭo raṅgamajjhe
analyzed: āha gāmaṇi ime sattā pakatiyā api rāga bandhana baddhā dosa bandhana baddhā moha bandhana baddhā  tesam bhiyyas api rajanīye dosanīye mohanīye dhamme upasaṃharantaḥ pamādetvā kāyassa  bhedā param maraṇā niraye upapajjati sace pana assa evaṃdiṭṭhi hoti yaḥ saḥ naṭaḥ raṅga majjhe
translated: The Blessed One replied: “Gamaani, these beings are bound by the bondage of passion, bound by the bondage of hatred, bound by the bondage of delusion.🔽They are brought to more and more bondage by things that arouse passion, hatred, and delusion. On the dissolution of the body, after death, they are reborn in states of woe, in an unhappy destination, in perdition, in hell.

original: samajjamajjhe saccālikena janaṃ hāseti rameti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pahāsānaṃ
analyzed: sa majja majjhe sacca alikena janam hāseti rameti saḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā pahāsānam
translated: But if he has the view: ‘The actor who entertains and amuses people by his truthfulness and honesty, on the dissolution of the body, after death, is reborn in the company of the laughing devas,’

original: devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”’ti sāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi. Micchādiṭṭhissa ca dvinnaṃ
analyzed: devānam sahabyatam upapajjati iti sā assa hoti micchādiṭṭhi micchādiṭṭhissa ca dvinnam
translated: one of two destinations is to be expected:

analyzed: gatīnam aññatarā gati icchitabbā nirayassa vā tiracchāna yoniyā vā ati tam sutvā tāla puṭaḥ

analyzed: gāmaṇi parodi nanu gāmaṇi pagā iva mayā paṭikkhittaḥ mā mama etam pucchi iti na aham  bhante etam rodāmi yam mam bhagavā naṭānam evam āha ati api ca aham
translated: cried. “But, overseer, didn’t I previously forbid you: ‘Don’t ask me that!’?” “Venerable Sir, I’m not crying

analyzed: bhante pubbakehi ācariya pācariyehi naṭehi vañcitaḥ naṭaḥ mahājanassa naṭa samajjam
translated: because the Fortunate One said this to the dancers about their future destiny.” “But, venerable Sir, I was deceived by the dancers of old, the teachers’ teachers, (who said): ‘The dancer, after showing the dancer’s delight to the great people,

analyzed: dassetvā sugatim upapajjati iti so satthu santike dhammam sutvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ  pabbajitvā laddhu upasampannaḥ vipassanāya kammam karontaḥ nacirassa iva arahattam pāpuṇi
translated: is reborn in a happy destiny.’ After hearing the Dhamma in the presence of the Teacher, having gained faith,🔽after going forth and attaining higher concentration, he made an effort in insight, and in no long time attained Liberation,

analyzed: yonisomanasikāraḥ udapādi tam anekadhā vibhajitvā dassetum
translated: and he has shown it by dividing it into many parts.

analyzed: kadā nuham pabbata kandarāsu ekākiyaḥ addutiyaḥ vihassam
translated: “When shall I live alone, without a companion,

analyzed: aniccataḥ sabba bhavam vipassam tam me idam tam nu kadā bhavissati
translated: in mountain caves, and see all existence as impermanent?🔽“When shall I be a sage with torn-up robe,

analyzed: kadā bhinna paṭandharaḥ muni amamaḥ nirāsaḥ
translated: with ochre robe, without possessions, without longings,

analyzed: rāgam ca dosam ca tathā iva moham hantvā sukhī pavana gataḥ vihassam
translated: and, having destroyed lust, hatred, and delusion, live happily in the wind?🔽“When shall I live alone in the forest,

translated: seeing this body as impermanent, subject to death and old age,

analyzed: vipassamānaḥ vīta bhayaḥ vihassam ekaḥ vane tam nu kadā bhavissati  kadā nuham bhaya jananim dukha āvaham taṇhā latam bahuvidha anuvattanim
translated: and free from fear?🔽“When shall I take the sharp sword of wisdom🔽and cut down the creeper of craving, which causes fear and brings suffering,

translated: When will drowsiness, hunger, thirst, wind, sun, insects, reptiles,

translated: not trouble me in the forest, when will that be the hermitage?🔽When will I, with a concentrated mind, mindful,

analyzed: kadā nu kaṭṭhe ca tiṇe latā ca khandhe amite ca dhamme
translated: “When will I be able to weigh on a scale these things, both internal and external,

analyzed: ajjhattikān eva ca bāhirāni ca samam tuleyyam tat idam kadā me

translated: “When will I be able to stand on the path of the ascetics,🔽And be refreshed by the rain of a timely shower, with a new rain-cloak?”🔽“When will I be able to hear the cry of the peacock,

translated: “When will I be able to cross the Ganges, the Yamunā, the Sārathi,🔽The Pātālakkhitā, and the Vaḷavāmukha, without touching them, by supernormal power?”

original: “Kadā nu nāgova asaṅgacārī, padālaye kāmaguṇesu chandaṃ;
analyzed: kadā nu nāga uva asaṅga cārī pada ālaye kāma guṇesu chandam
translated: “When will I be able to wander about without attachment, like an elephant,

analyzed: tam dāni mam pabbajitam samānam kiṃkāraṇā citta tuvam na yuñjasi

translated: “Have I not been asked by you, mind, in the Citta mountain, by the birds with variegated plumage,

analyzed: mama iva etam na hi tvam sannāha kāle paridevitena kim

analyzed: sabbam idam calam iti pekkhamānaḥ abhinikkhamim amata padam jigīsam

analyzed: cittam calam makkaṭa sannibham iti avīta rāgena

translated: “Sensual pleasures are varied, sweet, and delightful, where the unwary white-clad people

translated: “In a forest resounding with the calls of peacocks and cuckoos, dwelling in front of leopards and tigers,

translated: “See the five-aggregates as impermanent, suffering, void, non-self, and as a danger,🔽Suppress the mind’s discursive thought,

analyzed: ropetva rukkhāni yathā phalesī mūle tarum chettu tam eva icchasi

translated: so you are acting, mind, in that you urge me on to what is impermanent and unstable.

translated: “I am formless, far-reaching, and solitary, — I will not now do your bidding, mind.

translated: For sensual pleasures are painful, bitter, and very fearful; I will go forth to Nibbāna.🔽“I did not go forth, mind, because of lack of self-confidence or shamelessness,

analyzed: appiccha tā sappurisehi vaṇṇitā makkha ppahānam vūpasamaḥ dukhassa
translated: “Fewness of wishes is praised by the noble ones; the abandonment of conceit is the stilling of suffering.

analyzed: itissu mam citta tadā niyuñjasi idāni tvam gacchasi pubba ciṇṇam
translated: Thus, mind, you formerly urged me; now you go back on your word.

original: “Taṇhā avijjā ca piyāpiyañca, subhāni rūpāni sukhā ca vedanā;
analyzed: taṇhā avijjā ca piyā apiyam ca subhāni rūpāni sukhā ca vedanā
translated: “Craving, ignorance, and what is dear and undear, beautiful forms, and pleasant feeling,

translated: I have abandoned the objects of sensual pleasure, so delightful, I dare not enter them again.

original: “Sabbattha te citta vaco kataṃ mayā, bahūsu jātīsu namesi kopito;
analyzed: sabbattha te citta vaco katam mayā bahūsu jātīsu namesi kopitaḥ

analyzed: ajjhatta sambhavaḥ kataññu tāya te dukkhe ciram saṃsaritam tayā kate
translated: I have been born again and again in the womb, for a long time I have wandered in suffering, O mind.

original: “Tvaññeva no citta karosi brāhmaṇo, tvaṃ khattiyo rājadasī karosi;
analyzed: tvam na eva naḥ citta karosi brāhmaṇaḥ tvam khattiyaḥ rājadasī karosi
translated: “You, mind, make yourself a brahmin, you make yourself a noble, a king, a lord of the people;

original: Vessā ca suddā ca bhavāma ekadā, devattanaṃ vāpi taveva vāhasā.
analyzed: vessā ca suddā ca bhavāmaḥ ekadā devattanam vā api tava iva vāhasā
translated: Sometimes you become a merchant, a slave, or even a god, through your own power, O mind.

original: “Taveva hetū asurā bhavāmase, tvaṃmūlakaṃ nerayikā bhavāmase;
analyzed: tava iva hetū asurāḥ bhavāmase tvaṃmūlakam na īrayikāḥ bhavāmase

original: Atho tiracchānagatāpi ekadā, petattanaṃ vāpi taveva vāhasā.
analyzed: atho tiracchāna gatā api ekadā petattanam vā api tava iva vāhasā
translated: And sometimes we become animals, or even ghosts, through your own power, O mind.

original: “Nanu dubbhissasi maṃ punappunaṃ, muhuṃ muhuṃ cāraṇikaṃva dassayaṃ;
analyzed: nanu mam punappunam muhum muhum ca araṇikam iva dassayam
translated: “Will you not be angry with me again and again, showing yourself again and again like a wanderer?

original: Ummattakeneva mayā palobhasi, kiñcāpi te citta virādhitaṃ mayā.
analyzed: ummattakena iva mayā palobhasi kiñca api te citta virādhitam mayā
translated: You tempt me as if I were insane, although I have opposed you, O mind.

original: “Idaṃ pure cittamacāri cārikaṃ, yenicchakaṃ yatthakāmaṃ yathāsukhaṃ;
analyzed: idam pure cittam acāri cārikam yenicchakam yatthakāmam yathāsukham
translated: “This, O mind, was your former way of life, going wherever you wanted, wherever you liked, as you pleased;

original: Tadajjahaṃ niggahessāmi yoniso, hatthippabhinnaṃ viya aṅgusaggaho.
analyzed: tat ajja aham niggahessāmi yonisas hatthi ppabhinnam viya aṅgusaggaho
translated: I will now restrain it with wisdom, as one restrains an elephant with a goad when it is out of control.

original: “Satthā ca me lokamimaṃ adhiṭṭhahi, aniccato addhuvato asārato;
analyzed: satthā ca me lokam imam adhiṭṭhahi aniccataḥ addhuvataḥ asārataḥ
translated: “The Teacher has declared this world to be impermanent, insubstantial, and without a core.

original: Pakkhanda maṃ citta jinassa sāsane, tārehi oghā mahatā suduttarā.
analyzed: pakkhanda mam citta jinassa sāsane tārehi oghā mahatā su duttarā
translated: Turn away from it, O mind, and be victorious in the Dispensation of the Conqueror. Deliver me from the great flood that is so hard to cross.

original: “Na te idaṃ citta yathā purāṇakaṃ, nāhaṃ alaṃ tuyha vase nivattituṃ;
analyzed: na te idam citta yathā purāṇakam na aham alam vase nivattitum
translated: “O mind, you are not what you used to be. I am no longer able to submit to your control.

original: Mahesino pabbajitomhi sāsane, na mādisā honti vināsadhārino.
analyzed: mahesino pabbajitomhi sāsane na mādisāḥ honti vināsa dhārinaḥ
translated: I have gone forth into the Dispensation of the Great Seer. People like me do not destroy themselves.

original: “Nagā samuddā saritā vasundharā, disā catasso vidisā adho divā;
analyzed: nagā samuddā saritā vasundharā disā catassaḥ vidisāḥ adhas divā
translated: “The mountains, the oceans, the rivers, the earth, the four quarters, the intermediate points, below and above,

original: Sabbe aniccā tibhavā upaddutā, kuhiṃ gato citta sukhaṃ ramissasi.
analyzed: sabbe aniccā ti bhavā upaddutā kuhim gataḥ citta sukham ramissasi
translated: All are impermanent and afflicted by the three kinds of suffering. Where will you go, O mind, to enjoy happiness?

original: “Dhitipparaṃ kiṃ mama citta kāhisi, na te alaṃ citta vasānuvattako;
analyzed: kim mama citta kāhisi na te alam citta
translated: “What will you do to me, O mind, that you are so puffed up? I am not able to follow your control, O mind.

original: Na jātu bhastaṃ ubhatomukhaṃ chupe, dhiratthu pūraṃ navasotasandaniṃ.
analyzed: na jātu bhastam ubhatomukham chupe dhiratthu pūram nava sota sandanim
translated: I will not suck at the teat of the womb, which is like a bag filled with excrement and urine and connected at both ends.

original: “Varāhaeṇeyyavigāḷhasevite, pabbhārakuṭṭe pakateva sundare;
analyzed: varāha eṇeyya vigāḷha sevite pabbhāra kuṭṭe pakatā iva sundare
translated: “A beautiful mountain peak, frequented by the choicest of boars,

original: Navambunā pāvusasittakānane, tahiṃ guhāgehagato ramissasi.
analyzed: nava mbunā pāvusa sitta kānane tahim guhā geha gataḥ ramissasi
translated: In a forest that is fresh with new rain showers, you will delight in the dwelling of a cave.

original: “Sunīlagīvā susikhā supekhunā, sucittapattacchadanā vihaṅgamā;
analyzed: su nīla gīvā su sikhā su pekhunā su citta patta chadanā vihaṅgamā
translated: “Birds with beautiful necks, beautiful crests, beautiful eyes, beautiful leaf-like feathers,

original: Sumañjughosatthanitābhigajjino, te taṃ ramessanti vanamhi jhāyinaṃ.
analyzed: te tam ramessanti vanamhi jhāyinam
translated: Will delight in you, a meditator in the forest, as they listen to your very sweet voice.

original: “Vuṭṭhamhi deve caturaṅgule tiṇe, saṃpupphite meghanibhamhi kānane;
analyzed: vuṭṭhamhi deve caturaṅgule tiṇe saṃpupphite megha nibhamhi kānane
translated: “When the rain has fallen and the grass is four fingers high, and the forest is in full bloom, like a cloud,

original: Nagantare viṭapisamo sayissaṃ, taṃ me mudū hehiti tūlasannibhaṃ.
analyzed: naga antare viṭapi samaḥ sayissam tam me mudū tūla sannibham
translated: I will lie down in the open, like a lion, and that will be soft for me, like cotton.

original: “Tathā tu kassāmi yathāpi issaro, yaṃ labbhati tenapi hotu me alaṃ;
analyzed: tathā tu kassāmi yathā api issaraḥ yam labbhati tena api hotu me alam
translated: “I will work as much as the master tells me to, and that will be enough for me.

original: Na tāhaṃ kassāmi yathā atandito, biḷārabhastaṃva yathā sumadditaṃ.
analyzed: na tāham yathā a tanditaḥ yathā su madditam
translated: I will not work as much as I can, like a cat with a well-licked tail.

original: “Tathā tu kassāmi yathāpi issaro, yaṃ labbhati tenapi hotu me alaṃ;
analyzed: tathā tu kassāmi yathā api issaraḥ yam labbhati tena api hotu me alam
translated: “I will work as much as the master tells me to, and that will be enough for me.

original: Viriyena taṃ mayha vasānayissaṃ, gajaṃva mattaṃ kusalaṅkusaggaho.
analyzed: viriyena tam mayha vasā ānayissam gajam va mattam
translated: I will control you with energy, like a skilled elephant trainer controls an elephant.

original: “Tayā sudantena avaṭṭhitena hi, hayena yoggācariyova ujjunā;
analyzed: tayā su dantena avaṭṭhitena hi hayena ujjunā
translated: “When you are well-tamed and well-controlled, like a well-trained horse,

original: Pahomi maggaṃ paṭipajjituṃ sivaṃ, cittānurakkhīhi sadā nisevitaṃ.
analyzed: pahomi maggam paṭipajjitum sivam citta anurakkhīhi sadā nisevitam
translated: Always frequented by those who guard the mind.🔽“I will bind you firmly to the object,

original: “Ārammaṇe taṃ balasā nibandhisaṃ, nāgaṃva thambhamhi daḷhāya rajjuyā;
analyzed: ārammaṇe tam balasā nāgam iva thambhamhi daḷhāya rajjuyā
translated: Like a strong rope binds an elephant to a post.🔽Well-guarded by me, well-developed with mindfulness,

original: Taṃ me suguttaṃ satiyā subhāvitaṃ, anissitaṃ sabbabhavesu hehisi.
analyzed: tam me su guttam satiyā su bhāvitam anissitam sabba bhavesu hehisi
translated: You will go forth, not clinging to any existence.🔽“Having cut off with wisdom those that follow the wrong path,

original: “Paññāya chetvā vipathānusārinaṃ, yogena niggayha pathe nivesiya;
analyzed: paññāya chetvā vipatha anusārinam yogena niggayha pathe nivesiya
translated: Having discerned with yoga and established on the path,🔽Having seen the origin, the disappearance, and the arising,

original: Disvā samudayaṃ vibhavañca sambhavaṃ, dāyādako hehisi aggavādino.
analyzed: disvā samudayam vibhavam ca sambhavam dāyādakaḥ hehisi agga vādinaḥ
translated: You will become the heir of the foremost speaker.🔽“Established in the four inversions,

original: “Catubbipallāsavasaṃ adhiṭṭhitaṃ, gāmaṇḍalaṃva parinesi citta maṃ;
analyzed: adhiṭṭhitam gāmaṇḍalam va parinesi citta mama
translated: I led my mind around like a village boundary.🔽Didn’t you attend on the compassionate great sage,

original: Nanu saṃyojanabandhanacchidaṃ, saṃsevase kāruṇikaṃ mahāmuniṃ.
analyzed: nanu saṃyojana bandhana chidam saṃsevase kāruṇikam mahā munim
translated: The cutter of the bonds and fetters?🔽“Like a deer in a beautiful forest,

original: “Migo yathā seri sucittakānane, rammaṃ giriṃ pāvusaabbhamāliniṃ;
analyzed: migaḥ yathā su citta kānane rammam girim pāvusa abbha mālinim
translated: On a delightful mountain, adorned with rain clouds,🔽In a place free from disturbance, I will delight in that mountain,

original: Anākule tattha nage ramissaṃ, asaṃsayaṃ citta parā bhavissasi.
analyzed: an ākule tattha nage ramissam asaṃsayam citta parā bhavissasi
translated: O mind, you will certainly be supreme.

original: “Ye tuyha chandena vasena vattino,
analyzed: ye tuyha chandena vasena vattino
translated: “Those who live according to your will and rule,

original: Narā ca nārī ca anubhonti yaṃ sukhaṃ;
analyzed: narā ca nārī ca anubhonti yam sukham
translated: Men and women who experience happiness,

original: Aviddasū māravasānuvattino,
analyzed: aviddasū māra vasā anuvattinaḥ
translated: Not knowing, under the sway of Māra’s power,

original: Bhavābhinandī tava citta sāvakā”ti.🔽Tattha kadā nuhanti kadā nu ahaṃ. Pabbatakandarāsūti pabbatesu ca kandaresu ca, pabbatassa🔽vā kandarāsu. Ekākiyoti ekako. Addutiyoti nittaṇho. Taṇhā hi purisassa dutiyā nāma.🔽Vihassanti viharissāmi. Aniccato sabbabhavaṃ vipassanti kāmabhavādibhedaṃ sabbampi
analyzed: bhava abhinandī tava  tattha kadā nu hanti kadā nu aham pabbata kandarāsu iti pabbatesu ca kandaresu ca pabbatassa  vā kandarāsu ekākiyaḥ iti ekakaḥ addutiyaḥ iti nittaṇhaḥ taṇhā hi purisassa dutiyā nāma  vihassanti viharissāmi aniccataḥ sabba bhavam vipassanti kāma bhava ādi bhedam sabbam pi
translated: Your mind delights in becoming, disciple.

original: bhavaṃ “hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena anicca”nti vipassanto kadā nu viharissanti yojanā. Nidassanamattañcetaṃ,
analyzed: bhavam hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena aniccanti vipassanto kadā nu viharissanti yojanā
translated: Herein, when? : when shall I? In mountain caves : in mountains and in caves, or in the caves of mountains. Alone : by myself. Without a second : without a companion. Craving is called a man’s second because it is the cause of his being bound to a companion. Dwelling : I shall dwell. Contemplating all becoming as impermanent : contemplating all becoming, classed as sense-desire becoming, etc., as impermanent in the sense of non-existence. When? : when shall I dwell thus? This is the construction. But this is merely an illustration.

original: “yadaniccaṃ taṃ dukkhaṃ, yaṃ dukkhaṃ tadanattā”ti vacanato itarampi lakkhaṇadvayaṃ🔽vuttamevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Taṃ me idaṃ taṃ nu kadā bhavissatīti taṃ idaṃ me parivitakkitaṃ
analyzed: yat aniccam tam dukkham yam dukkham tat anattā ati vacanataḥ itaram pi lakkhaṇa dvayam  vuttam eva ati daṭṭhabbam tam me idam tam nu kadā bhavissati iti tam idam me parivitakkitam
translated: Since it is said: “What is impermanent is painful; what is painful is not-self” , the other two characteristics should be regarded as stated too.

original: kadā nu bhavissati, kadā nu kho matthakaṃ pāpuṇissatīti attho. Taṃ nūti cettha tanti
analyzed: kadā nu bhavissati kadā nu kho matthakam pāpuṇissati iti attho tam nu iti ca ittha tanti
translated: When will that be for me? : when will that which I have reflected on be for me? When will it come about? When will it reach its culmination? is the meaning. That now : here the word now is used in the sense of when.

original: nipātamattaṃ. Ayañhettha saṅkhepattho – kadā nu kho ahaṃ mahāgajo viya saṅkhalikabandhanaṃ,
analyzed: nipāta mattam kadā nu kho aham mahā gajaḥ saṅkhalika bandhanam
translated: The meaning is: When shall I, like a great elephant, cut the fetter of the household life,

original: gihibandhanaṃ chinditvā pabbajitvā kāyavivekaṃ paribrūhayanto ekākī pabbatakandarāsu
analyzed: gihi bandhanam chinditvā pabbajitvā kāya vivekam ekākī pabbata kandarāsu
translated: and, having gone forth, live alone in the mountain caves,

original: adutiyo sabbattha nirapekkho sabbasaṅkhāragataṃ aniccādito vipassanto viharissāmīti.🔽Bhinnapaṭandharoti bhinnavatthadharo, gāthāsukhatthaṃ nakārāgamaṃ katvā vuttaṃ. Satthakacchinnaagghaphassavaṇṇabhinnaṃ
analyzed: adutiyaḥ sabbattha nirapekkho sabba saṅkhāra gatam anicca āditaḥ vipassantaḥ viharissāmi iti  bhinnapaṭandharaḥ iti bhinna vatthadharaḥ gāthā sukha attham nakāra āgamam katvā vuttam satthaka chinna aggha phassa vaṇṇa bhinnam
translated: without a second, without concern, contemplating the nature of all formations as impermanent, etc.?🔽Wearing a robe of patches: wearing a robe that is patched, that is, made of pieces of cloth. The letter na is used for the sake of the metre. The meaning is: wearing a robe that is torn, that is, cut into pieces, by the edge of a knife.

original: paṭacīvaraṃ dhārentoti attho. Munīti pabbajito. Amamoti kule vā gaṇe vā mamattābhāvena🔽amamo. Katthacipi ārammaṇe āsīsanāya abhāvena nirāso. Hantvā sukhī pavanagato vihassanti🔽rāgādike kilese ariyamaggena samucchinditvā maggasukhena phalasukhena sukhī mahāvanagato
analyzed: paṭa cīvaram dhārento ti attho munī iti pabbajitaḥ amamaḥ ti kule vā gaṇe vā mamattā abhāvena  amamo katthacipi ārammaṇe āsīsanāya abhāvena nirāsaḥ hantvā sukhī pavana gataḥ vihassanti  rāga ādike kilese ariya maggena samucchinditvā magga sukhena phala sukhena sukhī mahā vana gataḥ
translated: The sage: the one who has gone forth. Without possessions: without the possession of a family or a group.🔽Without expectations: without the expectation of sitting down on any object.🔽Having destroyed, happy, I shall live in the forest.

original: kadā nu kho ahaṃ viharissāmi.
analyzed: kadā nu khalu aham viharissāmi
translated: When shall I live in the forest, happy with the happiness of the path and the happiness of fruition, having cut off the defilements such as lust, etc., with the noble path?

original: Vadharoganīḷanti maraṇassa ca rogassa ca kulāvakabhūtaṃ. Kāyaṃ imanti imaṃ khandhapañcakasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: maraṇassa ca rogassa ca kulāvaka bhūtam kāyam imanti imam khandha pañcaka saṅkhātam
translated: The source of sickness and death: the source of death and sickness. This body: this body consisting of the five aggregates.

original: kāyaṃ. Khandhapañcakopi hi “avijjāgatassa, bhikkhave, purisapuggalassa taṇhānugatassa
analyzed: kāyam khandha pañcakaḥ api hi avijjā gatassa bhikkhave purisa puggalassa taṇhā anugatassa
translated: For the five aggregates are called “body” in such passages as “Bhikkhus, for a person in the dark, in ignorance,

original: ayameva kāyo bahiddhā nāmarūpa”ntiādīsu kāyo vuccati. Maccujarāyupaddutanti maraṇena
analyzed: ayam eva kāyaḥ bahiddhā maccu jarāyu paddutanti maraṇena
translated: this body itself is a source of trouble to him externally, and also name is a source of trouble to him externally” .🔽Afflicted by death and old age: oppressed by death and old age.

original: ceva jarāya ca pīḷitaṃ, vipassamāno ahaṃ bhayahetupahānena vītabhayo, taṃ nu kadā bhavissatīti attho.🔽Bhayajananinti pañcavīsatiyā mahābhayānaṃ uppādakāraṇabhūtaṃ kāyikassa ca cetasikassa🔽ca sakalassapi vaṭṭadukkhassa āvahanato dukhāvahaṃ. Taṇhālataṃ bahuvidhānuvattaninti
analyzed: ca iva jarāya ca pīḍitam vipassamānaḥ aham bhaya hetu pahānena vīta bhayaḥ tam nu kadā bhavissati iti attho  pañcavīsatiyā mahā bhayānam uppāda kāraṇa bhūtam kāyikassa ca cetasikassa  ca sakalassa api vaṭṭa dukkhassa āvahanataḥ dukha āvaham taṇhā latam bahuvidha anuvattanin ti
translated: Contemplating: I, being free from fear by the abandoning of the cause of fear, when will I be? is the meaning.🔽The source of fear: the cause of the arising of the twenty-five kinds of fear.

original: bahuvidhañca ārammaṇaṃ bhavameva vā anuvattati santanotīti bahuvidhānuvattaniṃ, taṇhāsaṅkhātalataṃ.
analyzed: bahuvidham ca ārammaṇam bhavam eva vā anuvattati santanoti iti bahuvidha anuvattanim taṇhā saṅkhāta latam
translated: The cause of suffering: the cause of all the suffering of the round of rebirths, both bodily and mental. The creeper of craving, which spreads in many a way: the creeper of craving, which spreads in many a way, that is, which follows, which continues, many objects or mere becoming.

original: Paññāmayanti maggapaññāmayaṃ sunisitaṃ asikhaggaṃ vīriyapaggahitena saddhāhatthena
analyzed: paññāmayanti magga paññāmayam su nisitam asi khaggam vīriya paggahitena saddhā hatthena
translated: “When shall I be able to cut it down with the sharp sword of path-knowledge, which is the weapon of insight, and which I hold in the hand of faith, which is supported by energy?”

original: gahetvā samucchinditvā “kadā nuhaṃ vase”ti yaṃ parivitakkitaṃ, tampi kadā bhavissatīti yojanā.
analyzed: gahetvā samucchinditvā kadā nuham vasa iti yam parivitakkitam tam pi kadā bhavissati iti yojanā
translated: “When shall I be able to do this?” is the construction.🔽“With the sharp sword of insight”: with the sharp, keen sword of insight, which is sharp by means of serenity and insight.

original: Uggatejanti samathavipassanāvasena nisitatāya tikkhatejaṃ. Satthaṃ isīnanti buddhapaccekabuddhaariyasāvakaisīnaṃ🔽satthabhūtaṃ. Māraṃ sasenaṃ sahasā bhañjissanti kilesasenāya sasenaṃ abhisaṅkhārādimāraṃ
analyzed: ugga tejam ti samatha vipassanā vasena nisita tāya tikkha tejam sattham isīnam ti buddha paccekabuddha ariyasāvaka esīnam  sattha bhūtam māram sa senam sahasā bhañjissanti kilesa senāya sa senam abhisaṅkhāra ādi māram
translated: “The weapon of the seers”: the weapon of the Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and disciples.🔽“I shall crush Māra and his army”: I shall crush the army of defilements, together with the Māra of formations.

original: sahasā sīghameva bhañjissāmi. Sīhāsaneti thirāsane, aparājitapallaṅketi attho.
analyzed: sahasā sīgham eva bhañjissāmi sīhāsane iti thira āsane aparājita pallaṅkā iti attho
translated: “On the lion throne”: on the lion seat, the invincible seat.

original: Sabbhi samāgamesu diṭṭho bhaveti dhammagāravayuttatāya dhammagarūhi tādilakkhaṇappattiyā🔽tādīhi aviparītadassitāya yāthāvadassīhi ariyamaggeneva pāpajitindriyatāya jitindriyehi
analyzed: sabbhi samāgamesu diṭṭhaḥ bhaveti dhamma gārava yutta tāya dhamma garūhi ta ādi lakkhaṇa ppattiyā 🔽tādīhi aviparīta dassitāya yāthāvadassīhi ariya maggena iva pāpa jitindriyatāya jitindriyehi
translated: “I shall be seen by all who come”: by those who come out of respect for the Dhamma, who have attained the state of being led by the Dhamma,🔽by those who see things as they really are, by those who have attained the state of being led by the Dhamma, by those who have conquered the sense-bases through the noble path.

original: buddhādīhi sādhūhi samāgamesu “kadā nu ahaṃ padhāniyoti diṭṭho bhaveyya”nti yaṃ me🔽parivitakkitaṃ, taṃ nu kadā bhavissatīti yojanā. Iminā nayena sabbattha padayojanā
analyzed: buddha ādīhi sādhūhi samāgamesu kadā nu aham diṭṭhaḥ yam me  parivitakkitam tat nu kadā bhavissati iti yojanā iminā nayena sabbattha pada yojanā
translated: “When shall I be seen as the chief in the company of the good, the Buddhas and so on?” The construction is: “When will that come to pass which I have thought about?”

original: veditabbā, padatthamattameva vaṇṇayissāma.🔽Tandīti ālasiyaṃ. Khudāti jighacchā. Kīṭasarīsapāti kīṭañceva sarīsapā ca. Na bādhayissantīti
analyzed: veditabbā padattha mattam eva vaṇṇayissāma  tandī iti ālasiyam khudāti jighacchā kīṭa sarīsapā ati kīṭam ca iva sarīsapā ca na bādhayissanti iti
translated: In this way the construction should be understood in all instances. We shall comment only on the meaning of the words.
